headline: Top Prosecutor Stands Out by Pushing Back
text: THE other day, in his office down on Wall Street, Eric T. Schneiderman owned up to an awkward truth.

headline: Trying to Reverse a Guilty Plea, Blaming A.D.D.
text: They met in 1986, the setting improbable for romance. She was blond and pretty, but she was in a dentist’s chair, and he was pulling out her wisdom teeth.

headline: Want to Join Me for a Game? Anyone?
text: APP: Sportaneous

headline: Yankees-Tigers Game Suspended due to Rain
text: With the weather radar showing storms littering the area and the forecast expecting rain through the night, tonight’s game has been suspended due to rain. The game will be resumed Saturday night at 8:37 p.m. in the bottom of the second inning, where tonight’s game left off.

headline: Al-Awlaki Killed in Drone Strike
text: Anwar Al-Awlaki was killed in an American drone strike on his vehicle on Friday.

headline: 16-Year-Old Becomes Youngest L.P.G.A. Member
text: Lexi Thompson became the youngest member in L.P.G.A. history Friday when the tour commissioner, Mike Whan, approved her petition for full membership beginning in 2012.

headline: TimesCast | Al-Awlaki Killed In Yemen
text: September 30, 2011 - An American drone attack in Yemen kills United States-born Qaeda leader and key propagandist, Anwar al-Awlaki.

headline: A Décor to Match a New Connection
text: After 25 years of earning plaudits as “a high church of reverently prepared fish,” as Frank Bruni, then The New York Times’s restaurant critic, called it in 2005, Le Bernardin has undergone a sleek makeover. The restaurant has added a more contemporary feel, along with an extensive cocktail list and a lounge where patrons can order from a small-plate menu (no jackets required). The dining room is now dominated by a 24-foot triptych painting of waves, a design motif carried throughout in the twisted metal blades lining a few walls, a slatted teak room divider and the yellow striations of the white onyx bar.

headline: TimesCast | Al-Awlaki's Influence
text: September 30, 2011 - A look at Al-Awlaki's radicalizing influence on young Muslims in the English-speaking world.

headline: Another Look at the War in Libya
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Facebook, Neighborhoods as They Once Were
text: WHEN she and her husband moved out in 1980, Kathy LaPolla DeStefano was not at all happy with Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Try These On. But Take Them Seriously.
text: At some point in the 1950s, artists around the globe decided they wanted to do more than just paint on canvas. Inspired in part by Jackson Pollock’s dripped and poured paintings, and the idea that the process of making an artwork was as important as the final product, artists began puncturing, scorching and imprinting bodies on canvas. Franz Erhard Walther, a German artist whose work is currently on view at Dia:Beacon, took the idea a step further, creating objects out of fabric that people could manipulate to increase their awareness of time, space and the human body.

headline: Icahn Locks In a Deputy With a New Contract
text: Carl C. Icahn lost one of his top deal makers last year when Keith Meister left the billionaire investor’s firm to start his own fund seeded by Soros Fund Management. And two weeks ago, there were reports that another top Icahn deputy, Alex Denner, might be leaving to start his own fund.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Canada: Court Saves Drug Injection Center from Shutdown
text: An effort by the Conservative government to close the only center in North America where addicts may legally inject drugs was thwarted by the country’s Supreme Court in a unanimous decision released Friday. In 2008, the government said it would not extend the center’s exemption from federal narcotics laws, a position endorsed by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The Insite center in Vancouver, British Columbia, does not supply drugs, but allows addicts to inject them without fear of arrest under medical supervision on the condition that they undergo treatment. The court ruled that denying that permit and closing the clinic violated its users’ constitutional rights by “threatening their health and indeed their lives.” The justices also said that “during its eight years of operation, Insite has been proven to save lives with no discernible negative impact on the public safety and health objectives of Canada.”

headline: A Lively Villain in the Court of King Arthur
text: In most productions of “Camelot,” the character of Mordred, the evil spawn of King Arthur and a sorceress who seduced him in his youth, is a footnote. Usually, he’s barely remembered by theatergoers and mentioned only briefly in reviews; in the movie version, he was stripped of his two big numbers. In the stage musical, he doesn’t even appear until the second act.

headline: A House That Reflects an Island’s History
text: THE house at Montauk Highway and Ocean Road in Bridgehampton started out as a simple farmhouse around 1824, before being transformed in 1840 by a noted portrait artist into a handsome example of Greek Revival architecture, complete with four tall columns in front. In the 1880s, it became a boardinghouse for visitors to the “summer colony” that had taken root in the Hamptons. By 1894, it had been altered again, this time into an elegant inn, and then reverted to a private residence in the 1950s.

headline: You Love Your iPhone. Literally.
text: WITH Apple widely expected to release its iPhone 5 on Tuesday, Apple addicts across the world are getting ready for their latest fix.

headline: Devoted Fans Go to the Grave With Team Spirit
text: Mildred Ryan never missed a Yankee game. She was watching when Reggie Jackson swatted three home runs in Game 6 of the 1977 World Series. She was watching as Don Mattingly toiled for years to keep his team from plunging to the bottom of the standings. She was watching when Derek Jeter — “her boy,” her son, Ed, said — helped return the World Series trophy to the Bronx in 1996.

headline: Jack Ma Is Very Interested in Buying Yahoo
text: Jack Ma, chief executive of the Chinese e-commerce company the Alibaba Group, said on Friday that he was strongly considering buying Yahoo. It was the first public overture for the struggling Web portal.

headline: Rays Continue Their Run With Rout of Rangers
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The aura surrounding the adrenaline-fueled Tampa Bay Rays shifted to wonderment Friday. Now the question is when they might come crashing back to baseball reality instead of making more history.

headline: Brewers’ Biggest Opponent May Be Packers
text: MILWAUKEE — Naturally the question offended Milwaukee Brewers infielder Craig Counsell, who grew up a Brewers fan in Whitefish Bay, Wis., but knows what kind of pull the Green Bay Packers exert on his fellow Wisconsinites.

headline: Oh, a Happy Life if Back in Moscow
text: Sarah Ruhl has a taste for and a way with the classics. In 2003 she rewrote the Orpheus myth as “Eurydice,” in which the heroine falls from a high-rise and arrives in hell by elevator. Last fall, Classic Stage Company in New York presented her pitch-perfect 2003 re-creation of Virginia Woolf’s novel “Orlando.” Now she has tackled “Three Sisters,” Anton Chekhov’s 110-year-old drama about young women in the provinces with big-city dreams. Just as soon as they move back to Moscow, they say frequently, their dreary lives will become beautiful.

headline: Candidates Pursue Donations on Eve of a Fund-Raising Milestone
text: The presidential candidates sprinted toward the third-quarter fund-raising deadline on Friday night with a flurry of events and last-minute appeals for contributions, the fruits of which will help clarify the shape of the Republican field and shed light on whether President Obama’s political difficulties have hurt his powerful fund-raising operation.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Stepping Right Up for Jay-Z’s Carnival
text: Celebrities and other well-heeled folks don’t usually deign to engage in such hoi-polloi amusements as Whac-a-Mole. But the snaking lines for games at a carnival put on by Jay-Z to raise money for his Shawn Carter Scholarship Foundation on Thursday night were easily explained: Among the rows of stuffed-tiger prizes, things like Tory Burch bags poked out, along with gleaming Gibson guitars and a basketball signed by Magic Johnson.

headline: A Just Act of War
text: Santa Fe, N.M.

headline: The Romance Is Fraying, but the Banter Goes On
text: Richard Dresser tends to write compact comedies that glint with a dark edge. Among his best-known works, “Rounding Third” (2002) studies two Little League coaches with clashing attitudes toward competition; “Gun-Shy” (1997) looks at divorced mates suffering through rebound romances; and “Below the Belt” (1995) presents a satirical saga of three corporate minions antagonizing one another at a remote industrial outpost.

headline: Ahead on Emancipation
text: No politician was more determined than Senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts to ensure that secession and war resulted in emancipation. He interpreted every event through the lens of freedom. A quick end to the conflict, he feared, would leave slavery intact. Although he did not wish for it, he saw the benefit of the humiliating Union defeat at Bull Run in July 1861. He informed the abolitionist Wendell Phillips, “The battle & defeat have done much for the slave. I told the Predt that our defeat was the worst event & the best event in our history; the worst, as it was the greatest present calamity & shame, — the best, as it made the extinction of Slavery inevitable.”

headline: Mexico: Teachers End Strike
text: Teachers in Acapulco have agreed to go back to work on Monday after more than a month on strike in protest over crime. Thousands of the city’s teachers have stayed home after receiving extortion threats demanding half their salary. Leaders of the teachers signed an agreement with the state government late Thursday that lays out increased security measures around schools.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Wall Street Occupiers, Protesting Till Whenever
text: A man named Hero was here. So was Germ. There was the waitress from the dim sum restaurant in Evanston, Ill. And the liquor store worker. The Google consultant. The circus performer. The Brooklyn nanny.

headline: Amid G.O.P. Din, Santorum Wages Struggle to Be Heard
text: ANDERSON, S.C. — There was little fanfare and almost no entourage when Rick Santorum, a Republican candidate for president, rolled up to the Chick-fil-A on Clemson Boulevard here the other day.

headline: Adm. Michael Mullen Retires
text: After fours years of serving as the nation's highest-ranking military officer in both the Bush and Obama administrations, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Admiral Michael Mullen, retired.

headline: Can You Hear Them Now?
text: Do clothes matter? Do appearances?

headline: Enough With the Agony, Already
text: Every actor has had it.

headline: Warm and Communal, Like a Meal in Greece
text: THE large dining hall at Mythos, one of the latest additions to Thornwood’s roster of family-friendly restaurants, has the laid-back atmosphere — warm and unhurried, communal — that one might enjoy in similar neighborhood eating spots in sunny Greece, where families and other convivial groups enjoy lingering over their evening meal for hours. In fact, a large group near our table was doing just that — having a good time sharing a variety of dishes and washing them down with retsina or cloudy ouzo.

headline: The Curse of the Mitt
text: Everybody is talking about the Boston Red Sox and their spectacular, disastrous end-of-season collapse. They had a nine-game lead on Sept. 3! They went 7-20 in September! Blew the final, deciding game at the bottom of the ninth!

headline: Red Sox Part Ways With Francona
text: Philadelphia

headline: Stokley Is Both Out and Mum
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants receiver Brandon Stokley left practice on Wednesday with what was described as a strained quadriceps, which will sideline him for at least Sunday’s game against the Cardinals in Arizona.

headline: A Spirited Mexican Spot With a Pedigree
text: THERE’S a jolly fiesta atmosphere at Caracara Mexican Grill in Farmingdale. Diners entering the four-month-old restaurant on Main Street first encounter an attractive, popular bar, with a pressed-tin ceiling and Mexican tile floor. There, patrons nibble warm tortilla chips and sip the restaurant’s signature drink: a classic frozen margarita swirled with a pomegranate-hibiscus variation.

headline: Diana Taylor, Bloomberg’s Girlfriend, Criticizes Obama
text: As New York’s mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg is generally careful when discussing political leaders, measuring his words to avoid directly knocking anyone he might have to work with in representing the city’s interests. But his girlfriend, Diana L. Taylor, apparently feels no such constraints.

headline: The World This Week, Part 1
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Traditional Meal Ending Holy Days Becomes an Event
text: When Jill Medvedow, the director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, was growing up, she broke her fast after Yom Kippur at home, with just her family. After she married, she would go to her mother-in-law’s house for the annual meal known as the break-fast. But when her mother-in-law left Boston, Ms. Medvedow and her husband became break-fast orphans.

headline: Up to 22 Are Said to Face Charges in Tickets Inquiry
text: A Bronx grand jury that has heard evidence of widespread ticket-fixing by police union officials finished most of its work on Friday, after voting to charge as many as 17 police officers and 5 other people with a wide range of crimes, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Podcast: European Debt, a Tax Plan and General Motors
text: It’s been a difficult three months for the financial markets, and the global economy is weak. Unfortunately, more problems are probably on the way.

headline: Improving No Child Left Behind
text: The 2002 No Child Left Behind Act focused the country’s attention on school reform as never before, but the law is far from perfect. The Obama administration is wise to address its flaws, since Congress is four years overdue in updating the law.

headline: Anti-Qaddafi Fighters Are Accused of Torture
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — First there were the blindfold, the wrist-scarring handcuffs and the death threats. Then came beatings and electric shocks. In the fog of pain, the detainee, who said he had done nothing wrong, would have confessed to anything, he later recalled.

headline: Lottery Numbers
New Jersey Denies Bids for Two Mandarin Schools
text: Two proposed Mandarin language immersion charter schools that have drawn fierce opposition from school officials and parents in Millburn, Livingston and nearby areas failed to win approval Friday from the New Jersey Education Department.

headline: A Look Back at Mullen’s Tenure
text: After fours years of serving as the nation’s highest-ranking military officer in the administrations of Presidents Obama and George W. Bush, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, retired on Friday at a ceremony in Arlington, Va. His last day on the job also saw the death of Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born leader of Al Qaeda’s branch in Yemen who was killed by an American drone strike.

headline: A Tour of India, Colorful and Festive
text: THERE’S a lot to like about Utsav Indian Cuisine, a small restaurant in Vernon. The dramatic use of color — red, purple, green, orange, gold — gives the place a bright, contemporary look that is also quintessentially Indian. The food is good, the price is right and service is exceptionally friendly and helpful.

headline: Cardinals Plan to Lean on Ace Who Got Them In
text: The St. Louis Cardinals spent so long chasing the Atlanta Braves, Tony La Russa said, that their goal was simply to force a one-game playoff on Thursday. It was not until the pregame hours Wednesday that La Russa even looked ahead to the division series schedule.

headline: The Nuremberg Scripts
text: In November 1945, six months after Germany’s surrender to the Allies, a 24-year-old Army combat engineer named Harold Burson was handed a new assignment: to cover the upcoming Nuremberg trial for the American Forces Network. For the next five months, Burson was one of two soldiers who reported on the trial and produced a daily “script,” which was read over the air by the network’s announcers.

headline: This Sunday: Hong Kong Fish Balls, Baby
text: The fourth annual Food and Drink issue is like one of those dinner parties where you decide to make something you’ve never tried before. An experiment in real time, with inescapable consequences for your trusting guests. In place of the long-form narrative journalism that is our stock in trade, we concocted a completely bite-size issue made up of concise answers to a wide-ranging series of questions. Everything from “How can you tell if food is genetically engineered?” to “How many kinds of Pringles are there?” (Anyone for Hong Kong Fish Balls? Yes, that’s a flavor.) The longest answer is about 600 words, or less than one-tenth the size of a typical cover story, and there are more than 50 of them. We did this because it enabled us to cover a lot of ground, and because we thought it would be fun just to change up the menu.

headline: The World This Week, Part 2
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: America’s Man in Damascus
text: Robert Ford, the United States ambassador in Damascus, is an exemplary and courageous diplomat. While President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his henchmen have been slaughtering their people, Mr. Ford has been traveling the country, standing with the pro-democracy opposition and bearing witness to their sacrifice.

headline: Investor Fear Over Morgan Stanley Sharpens
text: It is Morgan Stanley’s turn on the hot seat.

headline: The Supreme Court and Health Care Reform
text: If the Supreme Court decides to take up the constitutionality of health care reform in its current term, which begins on Monday, a ruling could come by the end of June, well before the November elections. Pundits are already speculating over which party would gain the most traction from a decision that goes one way or another. The court must not let politics influence its decision.

headline: Another Day Passes Without N.B.A. Deal
text: The N.B.A. did not cancel the season on Friday, but it inched ever closer to deleting games from the calendar after another day passed without a labor deal.

headline: Rwanda: Two Convicted in Genocide
text: A special United Nations court convicted two men on Friday of helping mastermind the 1994 Rwandan genocide, and it acquitted two others. The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, based in Arusha, Tanzania, convicted Justin Mugenzi and Prosper Mugiraneza, the former ministers of trade and civil service, sentencing them to 30 years each. The tribunal acquitted two other senior members of Rwanda’s former government, Casimir Bizimungu, the former health minister, and Jerome-Clement Bicamumpaka, the former foreign minister.

headline: The Heart of the Art
text: X-rays of art objects from the J. Paul Getty Museum connect the contemporary viewer to the art impulse at the core of the ancient works.

headline: Lessons of the Listeria Outbreak
text: The deaths caused by listeria bacteria on cantaloupe is a warning that both the food industry and the government need to do more to protect the public. The outbreak has already sickened more than 70 people in 18 states and killed at least 15 of them, mostly elderly, in eight states. This is the deadliest outbreak of food-borne disease in the United States in more than a decade.

headline: In Change, Bloomberg Backs Obstacle to Deportation
text: In a significant reversal, the Bloomberg administration said Friday that it would support a City Council bill that would hamper federal authorities’ ability to detain, and eventually deport, foreign-born inmates on Rikers Island who are about to be released.

headline: Yanks Pick Up Where They Left Off: In Weather Delay
text: In a season that has been interrupted and elongated by incessant rain, it almost seemed fitting that the Yankees’ first game of the postseason was suspended Friday because of a deluge.

headline: Corrections: October 1
text: NATIONAL

headline: Saturday: Certain Adjustments
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Before we get to the puzzle, I’d just like to pose a question to you all: How is it October already? Is it just me, or did this year absolutely fly by?

headline: Obama Turns to Biden to Reassure Jewish Voters, and Get Them to Contribute, Too
text: WASHINGTON — In the middle of a meeting with 15 rabbis in Boca Raton, Fla., last week, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. took a punch meant for his boss.

headline: A Career Recharged, Along With France’s Global Role
text: PARIS

headline: A Pie That Tweaks the Pizza
text: A lot of pizzeria managers say their pies are different from those the other guys make. But John Ausiello, manager of Tomato Pie in Morristown, may have a better claim than most. “You see one of our pies and it’s clear they’re pretty not-regular,” Mr. Ausiello, 35, said.

headline: Latin Fusion, Created by a Homegrown Chef
text: A DECADE ago, Andrew DiCataldo was as hot as caliente gets, in the vanguard of the Nuevo Latino craze that rocketed up from Miami to Manhattan. In 2001, after he succeeded Douglas Rodriguez at Patria, the restaurant earned three stars from William Grimes in The New York Times. But a lackluster review at his next venture, and a wrong turn to a restaurant in London that never opened, left him slinging fajitas at a Mexican place in Teaneck where he had worked years before. By late last year, he was cooking for the Rail House in his hometown of Rahway.

headline: Remedy Is Elusive as Metallic Hips Fail at a Fast Rate
text: BOSTON — As surgeons here sliced through tissue surrounding a failed artificial hip in a 53-year-old man, they discovered what looked like a biological dead zone. There were matted strands of tissue stained gray and black; a large strip of muscle near the hip no longer contracted.

headline: For a Concert That Never Was, a Good Turnout Nonetheless
text: The frenzy began at 12:18 p.m. on Friday with an e-mail blast from the organizers of the anti-Wall Street demonstrations in Lower Manhattan: “Radiohead will play a surprise show for #occupywallstreet today at four in the afternoon.”

headline: N.J. to Repay U.S. $95 Million Over Hudson Tunnels
text: At the end of the long stare-down between the governor of New Jersey and federal officials over the money spent on tunnels that were never built, both sides blinked.

headline: Hippies and Hipsters Exhale
text: Ever since the Arab Spring, many people here have been pining for an American Autumn.

headline: Gains Made in Equality of Incomes in Downturn
text: The recession was bad for everyone, but women experienced at least one silver lining: Their median earnings edged a bit closer to men’s.

headline: 2nd American in Strike Waged Qaeda Media War
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — From his parents’ basement in a part of town where homes have lots of bedrooms and most children go to college, Samir Khan blogged his way into the highest circles of Al Qaeda, waging a media war he believed was as important as the battles with guns on the ground.

headline: Judge Stops Florida’s Plan to Privatize 29 State Prisons
text: MIAMI — A state judge ruled on Friday that it was unconstitutional for the Florida Legislature to attach a far-reaching proposal — one that would privatize 29 prisons in South Florida — to “the hidden recesses” of an appropriations bill.

headline: Injury From Metal Debris in Artificial Hips
text: How metal debris from hip implants reacts with the body.

headline: At the Stadium, a Parade of Respect
text: It is a generation now. Another Yankee epoch. Starting in 1995, the Yankees have appeared in the postseason in 16 of 17 years.

headline: Protests Stir Up Voices on the Web
text: As the Occupy Wall Street protests in New York cycled through their 14th day, with a surge of attention and confusion over a Radiohead show that wasn’t, an overwhelming amount of information continued to flood the Internet, from snarky Tweets to informational Web sites to blogs representing individual experiences during the economic crisis.

headline: Trustee Is Sought for Records of Solyndra
text: The Department of Justice asked a federal court on Friday to appoint a trustee to oversee the bankruptcy of the solar panel maker Solyndra because its top executives asserted their Fifth Amendment right to avoid self-incrimination before a House subcommittee.

headline: The Political Pulpit
text: This weekend, hundreds of pastors, including some of the nation’s evangelical leaders, will climb into their pulpits to preach about American politics, flouting a decades-old law that prohibits tax-exempt churches and other charities from campaigning on election issues.

headline: Changes Proposed for Reporting by Teacher Education Programs
text: Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, proposing changes to the nation’s teacher education programs on Friday, said the Education Department would negotiate changes to the rules governing what information the nation’s 1,400 teachers’ colleges and university programs must report to Washington. The department wants them to report how many graduates fill shortage positions, like teaching math in high-poverty schools; how satisfied school principals are with their preparation; and how much the graduates help students learn once they get to the classroom, based on their students’ test scores. The rule-rewriting process could take many months.

headline: On Free-Agent Market, Rollins and Reyes Will Be Rivals Again
text: PHILADELPHIA — Jimmy Rollins and Jose Reyes, star players for rival teams, have spent much of their careers juxtaposed with each other.

headline: Roger Kennedy, Who Was Parks Chief Under Clinton, Dies at 85
text: Roger G. Kennedy, who was director of the National Park Service during the Clinton administration and an ardent preservationist of the nation’s cultural, historic and artistic heritage for much of his life, died on Friday at his home in Rockville, Md. He was 85.

headline: Arizona Coach Baylor Is Hospitalized After Fainting
text: MILWAUKEE — Don Baylor, the Arizona Diamondbacks’ hitting coach, was taken to a local hospital Friday after fainting in the lunchroom of the visiting clubhouse at Miller Park.

headline: Palestinian Request Sent to Experts
text: The Security Council membership committee referred the Palestinian request for full United Nations membership to its experts on Friday to evaluate whether it meets the criteria for statehood. An initial report is due by mid-October. Many ambassadors noted that before moving on the application, they wanted to see if direct talks between Israel and the Palestinians could be started within a month.

headline: Rediscovering the Urban Palette
text: The images depicting the city of shadow-cloaked smokestacks and sun-drenched skyscrapers are tucked away in our minds. Manhattan streetscapes bursting with odd angles and odder people. Pastoral landscapes of misty Central Park mornings. Ragamuffins and ruffians, dandies and dowagers, all strutting across the city’s stage — and all frozen in black and white.

headline: Lee Davenport Dies at 95; Developed Battlefront Radar
text: Lee Davenport, a physicist who developed a radar device that helped bring Allied victories on major World War II battlefronts in Europe and the Pacific, died Friday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 95.

headline: No Front-Runner This Season, but Three Who Dazzle
text: They may not be the best or even necessarily the fastest horses in the land, but they certainly have provided the most drama and entertainment through an unpredictable but satisfying 2011 thoroughbred racing season. We’re talking about two boys and a girl — Stay Thirsty, Uncle Mo and Havre de Grace — all of whom are in town Saturday at Belmont Park for what is one of the sport’s best afternoons outside the Breeders’ Cup World Champions next month at Churchill Downs.

headline: Unesco Director Asks Dictator to Withdraw Science Prize
text: The director of Unesco called Friday for a West African dictator to withdraw the controversial prize he has endowed for the organization. The prize in the life sciences, financed by and named for President Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo of Equatorial Guinea, would damage the “prestige” and “credibility” of Unesco, its director general, Irina Bokova, said at a meeting of the group’s executive board in Paris. Human rights activists, scientists and political leaders have denounced the prize as a public-relations stunt by Mr. Obiang. The Unesco board is expected to meet again next week on the issue.

headline: Britain: Kurdish Protesters Besiege Newspaper
text: A group of about a dozen Kurdish separatist protesters broke into the newsroom of The Guardian newspaper on Friday and staged a brief demonstration, demanding further coverage of Kurdish conflicts with the Turkish government, according to reports from within the newspaper. A video of the incident showed the protesters gathered on a stairway, chanting and handing out literature to newspaper staff members, many of whom appeared bemused. The protests were low-key and peaceful, said one reporter, Alexandra Topping. The invasion of The Guardian comes amid a season of Kurdish protests against a campaign of Turkish airstrikes in northern Iraq in pursuit of violent Kurdish separatists.

headline: Germany Returns 20 Skulls to Africa
text: Namibian government representatives and leaders of the Herero and Nama tribes attended a ceremony at Charité Hospital in Berlin on Friday to take possession of 20 skulls brought to Germany for racial research a century ago.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
text: NO. 8 NEBRASKA AT NO. 7 WISCONSIN8 p.m. Eastern, ABC

headline: Belarus Withdraws from European Summit Meeting
text: Belarus withdrew Friday from a diplomatic summit meeting aimed at improving ties between the European Union and its former Soviet neighbors, complaining of “discrimination.” Western leaders have criticized the country’s authoritarian president for jailing and harassing his opponents, and the European Union has called for people it deems political prisoners to be released before talks on financial aid and economic ties can be resumed. Belarus’s Foreign Ministry said President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko had not been invited to attend the so-called Eastern Partnership summit meeting and that its delegation had been excluded from several events. Because of European Union sanctions against Belarus, Mr. Lukashenko is banned from entering the bloc.

headline: Changing Forests
text: Many of the world’s forests are robust carbon sponges, but others are threatened by a warming climate.

headline: Attacks on a Protective Canopy
text: Trees, which provide a crucial protection against climate change, are also under stress from some of climate change’s effects.

text: The young and old on what they hope to accomplish by joining the Occupy Wall Street demonstration in Zuccotti Park.

headline: With Deaths of Forests, a Loss of Key Climate Protectors
text: WISE RIVER, Mont. — The trees spanning many of the mountainsides of western Montana glow an earthy red, like a broadleaf forest at the beginning of autumn.

headline: The Forest for the Trees
text: In Arizona, trees are cut down to save forests from fires and to combat climate change.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,778 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: An African Mermaid
text: “Mami Wata” at the National Museum of African Art in Washington is as rousing as a drum roll, as piquant as a samba. Holland Cotter reviews.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Himachal Pradesh: More than 250 deities will grace the annual procession at this year’s Kullu Dussehra celebrations in Himachal Pradesh, part of the weeklong festivities in the Kullu Valley. Two deities have been banned, though, since their devotees demanded a special place of honor in the procession (The Times of India).Jharkhand: The state plans to construct a new capital city called New Ranchi on about 27,000 acres of land (Prabhat Khabar).

headline: At a Glance: Rick Santorum
text: RICHARD JOHN SANTORUM

headline: Modernity and Tradition Merge in Motherhood
text: My family moved to New Jersey from New Delhi when I was 7 years old, and I have always considered myself a modern Indian American woman.

headline: Forests and Climate Change: Ask the Reporter a Question
text: Justin Gillis reports on climatic threats to forests and the implications for the earth’s future. Please post your questions for him in the comment field below. He will respond next week on the Green blog.

headline: Giants-Cardinals: Matchup to Watch
text: Giants (2-1) at Cardinals (1-2), Sunday at 4:05 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: The Weekend Word: In It  to Win It
text: Today’s Times:

headline: For Small Business,  Bad News on Health Care Costs Isn’t as Bad
text: There’s bad news from the workplace: as The New York Times reported on Tuesday, the cost of health insurance rose sharply in 2011 after several years of relatively slow growth. According to the Kaiser Family Foundation‘s annual survey on employer health benefits, the average premium to insure a family of four grew 9 percent, to just over $15,073. For single coverage, premiums rose 8 percent, to $5,429.

headline: Styled to a T | Cristian Zuzunaga
text: The Designer

headline: Pakistani Is Sentenced in Killing of Governor
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A court on Saturday sentenced to death an elite police guard who assassinated a leading secular politician he had been charged with protecting, a killing that sent shockwaves throughout Pakistan and was seen as a clear marker of growing religious intolerance and extremism in the country.

headline: Out of the Box
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#714", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Unleash the Robot Dogs of War
text: In 2007 Boston Dynamics, a robotics company, posted a video online of a robot called the BigDog that could run on any type of terrain like a dog. The video quickly went viral, partly because people were in awe of the robot’s agility and also because it was so scary to watch.

headline: Bookshelf
text: In “The Scrapbook of Frankie Pratt” (Ecco, $26), Caroline Preston, a former archivist, pastes vintage postcards, Jazz Age ephemera and typewritten snippets into a sweetly beguiling novel about a New England girl who trades Vassar College for Greenwich Village on the advice of Edna St. Vincent Millay.

headline: Notes from the Underground | Bubbles
text: The synth-pop duo known as Bubbles recently performed at the Agnès B. flagship store in Soho. A crowd of forty or so looked on as Alain Levitt banged on his machines, and Jason P. Grisell flailed around the small stage area. Endearingly low-maintenance, the group wins hearts with their unpretentious slacks, sneakers, and baseball hats. Bubbles has played most of the better underground venues in New York, and is steadily gaining steam. And yet, while Levitt’s music was danceable and solidly interesting, Grisell’s vocals left the audience pondering whether or not we are in for a revival of that No-Wave school of “Can’t sing? Start a hit band!'”

headline: NATO Says It Caught a Haqqani Clan Leader
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — NATO forces said Saturday that they had captured a man they described as a high-ranking member of the Haqqani network, the brutal Pakistan-based clan the United States considers one of the biggest threats to bringing stability to Afghanistan.

headline: Americans Move Against Haqqani Network in Afghanistan
text: The insurgent group, based in Pakistan’s northwestern frontier, flows fighters into Afghanistan and has orchestrated a long campaign of guerrilla and terrorist attacks against the Afghan government and its American sponsors. It has also harbored Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups.

headline: Urban Forager | Maitake Mushrooms
text: The proliferation of steady rains from August onwards has yielded a stunning crop of mushrooms this fall, both edible and otherwise. Recently, I found a lovely maitake mushroom cluster that weighed over two pounds growing at the base of a giant pin oak near where I was staying just outside New Paltz. The maitake had grown over and around a fallen branch, and there were a few acorns attached to the bottom. I took the whole thing home.

headline: City Geometry, Seen From Above
text: In “New York From the Air: A Story of Architecture,” Yann Arthus-Bertrand transforms street-level scenes into abstract cityscapes.

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#577", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Q. and A.: N.A.S.L. Commissioner David Downs
text: MIAMI — The entrance to the office of the North American Soccer League’s commissioner is adorned with the jerseys of the league’s eight teams, which are arranged on hangers that can be moved as the standings change. The league’s six-team playoffs started Saturday.

headline: Jets-Ravens: Matchup to Watch
text: Jets (2-1) at Ravens (2-1), Sunday at 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NBC

headline: Frustration Is in the Forecast
text: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. He vows to keep Phillies homerism to a minimum.

headline: In Europe, Players Profit From Team Efforts
text: The difference between the game in the United States and Europe is easy to illustrate by comparing two team competitions currently under way.

headline: Runway In Review
text: Christian DiorDesigner: Bill GayttenDate and Location: Friday, Sept. 30, Musée Rodin, 77 Rue de Varenne, 7ePhotos: slide show

headline: Variety: A Brilliant Cryptic
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert:  In the Sunday puzzle, there will be a notepad that reads: Ten famous people are attending a costume party in this crossword. After the grid is filled, change the two shaded letters in each theme answer to “unmask” a celebrity.

headline: Bordeaux? Sediment? Tell It to the Judge
text: On a recent evening at Colicchio & Sons, in the Meatpacking District, the wine writer Mark Oldman attended an engagement dinner during which several bottles of 1970 Chateau Palmer were drunk. “I still remember the plums-and-truffle perfume and enduringly silky, savory finish,” Oldman said. He was so enamored, in fact, that before leaving, he snuck out an empty bottle with him as a souvenir. (Oenophiles, Oldman noted, refer to empties as “dead soldiers.”)

headline: Somali Gunmen Abduct Elderly Tourist in Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Somali gunmen staged another brazen attack inside Kenya on Saturday morning, snatching a French tourist from a beachside bungalow and escaping to Somalia three weeks after a similar assault.

headline: Putin’s Eye for Power Leads Some in Russia to Ponder Life Abroad
text: MOSCOW — “Time to shove off” is the name of a Web site for people who are fed up with life in Russia, and it is becoming a catchphrase for those dismayed by the newly announced plans of Vladimir V. Putin to keep a grip on power for perhaps two more terms as president.

headline: Dior and Galliano, After Galliano
text: Karlie Kloss closed the Dior show on Friday in a gown with a black lace top and a transparent pink skirt that revealed most of her rear end, a finale that some online commentators read as a pointed statement by its temporary designer. Bill Gaytten has been directing the studio while the label seeks a successor to John Galliano, who was fired in the spring, but Mr. Gaytten has not been seen as a likely candidate for the job since his couture collection, shown in July, was widely panned.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Isabel Marant
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#377", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Small Plane Crashes Into Ride During Festival in Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia — A small plane smashed into a Ferris wheel at a festival north of Sydney on Saturday, trapping a pair of children on the ride and two people in the aircraft, which dangled from the top of the ride for hours.

headline: Battered by Economic Crisis, Greeks Turn to Barter Networks
text: VOLOS, Greece — The first time he bought eggs, milk and jam at an outdoor market using not euros but an informal barter currency, Theodoros Mavridis, an unemployed electrician, was thrilled.

headline: Competing Confucius Award Bares Discord in China
text: BEIJING — When the Nobel Prize committee announced last year that it was giving its coveted Peace Prize to Liu Xiaobo, an imprisoned Chinese dissident writer, a group of patriotic Chinese came up with a rejoinder: they would offer up their own international award, called the Confucius Peace Prize.

headline: Voice of Yankees Draws High Ratings and Many Critics
text: Walking through the crowded hallway just outside the locker rooms at Yankee Stadium last week, John Sterling, unlike most everyone else, was not wearing a badge, security identification or media credential. Dressed in a crisp navy blue suit that he plucked from his closet that morning because he saw President Obama on television wearing a similar one, he merrily waved his hand as he passed attendants at various checkpoints.

headline: Businesslike Quarterback Has Stirred the Bills
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. —  The groundwork for the predictable career on Wall Street had already been laid — the coursework in economics, the internship at a Boston hedge fund. Then Ryan Fitzpatrick’s college coach surprised him with a suggestion after his junior season: spend a long weekend that summer at the Manning family’s passing academy in Louisiana.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Christian Dior
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#649", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Jets’ Mason, Taught to Endure Pain, Now Shows Others the Way
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Before he could become one of the N.F.L.’s most durable receivers, Derrick Mason had to stop crying. He was about 9 then, a football-loving boy in Detroit who played two-on-two games at the middle school across the street. Always he lined up against his older brother Jackie, who pushed him, bumped him, knocked him down, bringing him to tears. When Mason would get up, Jackie would push him — again and again and again.

headline: Strike Reflects U.S. Shift to Drones in Terror Fight
text: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. drone strike that killed Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born propagandist for Al Qaeda’s rising franchise in Yemen, was one more demonstration of what American officials describe as a cheap, safe and precise tool to eliminate enemies. It was also a sign that the decade-old American campaign against terrorism has reached a turning point.

headline: Yemen Notes Its Own Role in U.S. Attack on Militant
text: SANA, Yemen — Yemeni officials provided more details on Saturday about their role in the tracking and killing of an American-born cleric, while a government spokesman said that the United States should show more appreciation to Yemen’s embattled president for his assistance in the case.

headline: Showers Come and Go, Leaving Behind a Rainbow
text: When nothing happens, there is no better analyst to say pretty much nothing more eloquently than the tight-lipped Captain.

headline: Different Rules for Rainy Weather in Playoffs
text: Updated | 5:22 p.m. In his pregame comments, Manager Joe Girardi was asked if he would be hesitant to start the game if there was rain in the forecast for 9:30 or 10 p.m., and he said, “Unfortunately, I don’t get to make that decision. That’s in MLB’s hands. I would highly recommend that we don’t start if it’s going to rain half an hour, 45 minutes, an hour. But I’m not making the decisions.”

headline: In El Paso, a Storm Over Benefits for Gay Partners
text: EL PASO — Pastor Tom Brown wants homosexuals to repent and turn to Christ. He certainly does not want them to be given taxpayer-financed health benefits.

headline: Feisty Baylor Rejoins Diamondbacks
text: MILWAUKEE — The Arizona Diamondbacks hitting coach Don Baylor, who spent the night at a hospital after a fainting in the clubhouse Friday, returned to Miller Park on Saturday morning and brushed aside all concerns with one meaty arm.

headline: Occupying, and Now Publishing, Too
text: Just before noon, Chelsea Potter stood on the corner of Broadway and Liberty Street holding a sheaf of newspapers and offering them to passers-by.

headline: Racing Against Time and an Indelible Fear
text: Laura Arnez, a mother of five from outside Sacramento who likes to refer to her triathlon training as Mommy’s recess time, has long struggled with panic attacks during the most nerve-racking stage of such competitions: the open-water swim, which typically precedes a bike race and then a run.

headline: Mike Heimerdinger, 58, Who Helped to Coach Super Bowl Winners, Is Dead
text: Mike Heimerdinger, who coached offensive units for the Denver Broncos, the Jets and the Tennessee Titans, helped mold players like Steve McNair, Vince Young and Jay Cutler, and continued to work while undergoing chemotherapy, died Friday while in Mexico to receive experimental cancer treatments. He was 58.

headline: Revived Diamondbacks Follow Their Leaders
text: MILWAUKEE — Load everybody’s statistics into a computer game, and the manager and coaches of the Arizona Diamondbacks — mostly baseball swells from the 1980s and ’90s — might crush their players. That’s impressive, given that the actual playing Diamondbacks bounced back from a 97-loss season to outdistance the defending World Series champion San Francisco Giants and win the National League West.

headline: Festival Starts a 3-Day Run in Asbury Park
text: ASBURY PARK, N.J. — All Tomorrow’s Parties, the festival that pays lovingly microscopic attention to olden tastes in underground pop from around the world, started its three-day run last night. It has relocated its New York-area edition to Asbury Park from the Catskills, and this was a life-affirming move. The old place, Kutshers Country Club, is a down-at-heels resort — the enclosed and remote feeling there made the event feel like a quarantined zone for those afflicted with obscure interests.

headline: Khaled Abdel Nasser, Son of Egyptian Hero, Dies at 62
text: Khaled Abdel Nasser, a son of Egypt’s most revered leader, who captured the world’s attention in the late 1980s when he was tried and acquitted of helping to assassinate two Israeli diplomats, died Sept. 15 at a Cairo hospital. He was 62.

headline: Rolle Stands Out With Punishing Hits and Pugnacious Talk
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In a little more than a year and a half with the button-down, low-key Giants, Antrel Rolle has found some measure of controversy for, among other things, criticizing Tom Coughlin’s coaching style; comparing Coughlin to Rex Ryan; likening football players to soldiers serving in Iraq; opining on what would happen if the Giants were to play the Washington Redskins 100 times (the Giants would win 95); and, most recently, stating that it is sometimes essential for him to take a 15-yard unnecessary-roughness penalty.

headline: G.M.’s Big Pile-Up
text: Key moments from the decline of General Motors.

headline: On the Road to Detroit’s Big Pileup
text: If General Motors were any other company, it would probably be dead by now. In the summer of 2008, nearly a year before G.M. filed for bankruptcy, its executives were growing desperate. Rick Wagoner, its chief executive, secretly proposed a merger with Ford, while Bill Ford courted the future president, Barack Obama, in an attempt to safeguard his company. This article is adapted from “Once Upon a Car: The Fall and Resurrection of America’s Big Three Automakers — G.M., Ford and Chrysler” by Bill Vlasic, the Detroit bureau chief of The New York Times. The book, to be published Tuesday by William Morrow, reveals new details of the chaos at the Big Three. Conversations recounted in the book were based on more than 100 interviews.

headline: A Tropical Technique for Maine’s Shallows
text: PORTLAND, Me. — I was standing in the bow of a low-riding skiff as my angling companion poled us across white sand flats, illuminated by a warm summer sun. Suddenly, several wakes appeared before the boat.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: A Signature Home Run Balanced by Humility
text: I sat in the rear of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Manhattan during the memorial for the sports commentator and author Dick Schaap in January 2002. The place was packed as old friends said their final goodbyes.

headline: The Bank Case That Refuses to Die
text: ANGELO R. MOZILO and Kerry K. Killinger look like they’re in the clear: federal prosecutors have declined to go after them and many other masters of the mortgage disaster.

headline: Live Analysis: College Football Week Five
text: Zach Hillesland and Greg Bishop will be reporting on all of the day’s action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. Join the conversation in the comments section below.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Isabel Marant
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Christie Team Assessing How Fast a 2012 Campaign Could Be Mounted
text: WASHINGTON — Chris Christie’s political advisers are working to determine whether they could move fast enough to set up effective political operations in Iowa and New Hampshire in the wake of a relentless courtship aimed at persuading Mr. Christie, the governor of New Jersey, to plunge into the race for the Republican presidential nomination, according to operatives briefed on the preparations.

headline: Profits, but No Joy, for Merrill
text: IT sounded like a crank call, the business equivalent of “Do you have Prince Albert in a can?”: Hello, Warren Buffett wants to talk to your boss.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Photos
text: Officials searched for solutions to the European debt crisis, the United States government considered selling off assets and natural gas was flared off in North Dakota while more valuable oil was being extracted.

headline: Valuing Those Who Tell You the Bitter Truth
text: This interview with  Pamela Fields, chief executive of Stetson, the hat and apparel company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Battle for Libya | October 1, 2011
text: The military mission in Libya is largely complete and NATO’s involvement could begin to wrap up as soon as next week after allied leaders meet in Brussels, according to the top U.S. commander for Africa.

headline: Battle for Libya | October 2011
text: Nine months of images from the fighting in Libya.

headline: The Problem With ‘No New Taxes’
text: IN a debate in August, Republican presidential candidates were asked whether they would support a budget deal that bundled $10 of spending cuts for every $1 of tax increases. All said no. They rejected any deal that involved raising taxes.

headline: Carpenter Works to Keep Distractions at Bay
text: Chris Carpenter, who is set to pitch for the St. Louis Cardinals against the Philadelphia Phillies on Sunday night in Game 2 of the teams’ National League division series, spoke at length Saturday afternoon about the way his mental approach had evolved since his days as a young player.

headline: Maryland Team Wins Solar House Contest
text: A team from the University of Maryland has taken top honors at the Solar Decathlon, a competition for small, cost-effective solar-powered houses sponsored by the Department of Energy. The entries have been on view on the National Mall in Washington for over a week. A project manual and a video walk-through for the winning entry are here. Recently Joanna Foster reported in The Times on an entry from the New York area.

headline: John Sterling on YouTube: The Good and the Bad
text: One need not look any further than YouTube to understand the polarizing nature of John Sterling among baseball fans.

headline: When the Nurse Wants to Be Called ‘Doctor’
text: NASHVILLE — With pain in her right ear, Sue Cassidy went to a clinic. The doctor, wearing a white lab coat with a stethoscope in one pocket, introduced herself.

headline: The Round and the Oval
text: THERE are a great many things that Chris Christie is indeed too fat for.

headline: Cooperation in Evil
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Missing the Populist Moment
text: BY rights, this should be the election when conservative populists, frequently thwarted and co-opted by the Republican Party’s kingmakers, finally succeed in pushing an insurgent candidate to the top of the presidential ticket. Between the zeal of the Tea Party, the unlovability of Mitt Romney and the widespread hatred of all things Washington, there’s never been a better time to run against the Republican establishment and win.

headline: How Did the Robot End Up With My Job?
text: I’VE done a lot of television book interviews lately, and I continue to be struck at what a difference there is in the technology in just a few years’ time.

headline: The Bankers and the Revolutionaries
text: AFTER flying around the world this year to cover street protests from Cairo to Morocco, reporting on the latest “uprising” was easier: I took the subway.

headline: Crosby Is Out for Penguins’ Opener
text: Sidney Crosby said Saturday he would not play in the Pittsburgh Penguins’ regular-season opener in Vancouver on Oct. 6.

headline: Super People
text: James Atlas is the president of Atlas & Co., a publishing company. He is at work on a book about biography.

headline: Saving the U.S.S. Bunker Hill
text: Lt. Cmdr. Joseph R. Carmichael Jr. received a Navy Cross for “extraordinary heroism” in keeping the U.S.S. Bunker Hill afloat after it was struck by two kamikaze planes in 1945.

headline: Return of the Indispensable Man
text: Ellen Barry is the Moscow bureau chief for The New York Times.

headline: Antiterror Measures at Home
text: One of the bitter lessons of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, was the need for better coordination and sharing of intelligence among the nation’s security agencies, to flag dangerous people entering the country. But there were also well-founded concerns about how well that system was working, and whether it was being abused.

headline: Joseph Carmichael Jr., a Carrier Hero, Dies at 96
text: It was midmorning on May 11, 1945, near the Japanese island of Kyushu when the Bunker Hill, an aircraft carrier with dozens of planes and vast stores of fuel and ammunition on its flight deck, was struck by two kamikaze planes in suicide attacks within minutes of each other.

headline: Becoming Compassionately Numb
text: Benedict Carey is a science reporter for The New York Times.

headline: Schmoozing in Whose Interest?
text: On his first day in office, President Obama struck a blow for better government with his executive order banning political appointees from accepting gifts from lobbyists. Now the administration is rightly proposing to extend the ban to all 2.6 million career federal workers.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Kate King at Lanvin
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Kate King from Ford Models before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Approaching the Bench, in Search of Answers
text: The Supreme Court returns Monday to an overarching question: Are the federal courts the right forum for resolving societal problems? Last term, the conservative majority suggested the answer is no in closely divided cases about job discrimination, misconduct by prosecutors, fraud by mutual funds and other topics.

headline: Talking About Doritos
text: Arch West, the father of Doritos, died Sept. 20 at age 97, knowing that he and his product-development team at Frito-Lay had built one of the mightiest pillars of a global snack-food empire. What many fans may not realize is that Doritos are also a mighty literary device.

headline: Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

headline: Police Arrest More Than 700 Protesters on Brooklyn Bridge
text: Updated, 1:23 p.m. Sunday | In a tense showdown above the East River, the police arrested more than 700 demonstrators from the Occupy Wall Street protests who took to the roadway as they tried to cross the Brooklyn Bridge on Saturday afternoon.

headline: Conflicts and Appearances

headline: Sunday Dialogue: The Death Penalty
text: Are some crimes so abhorrent that justice demands death?

headline: The Supercommittee’s Stark Choice
text: In August, Congressional Republicans tried to box in Democrats and the White House by demanding huge deficit cuts in exchange for preventing a government default. Then they joined in the creation of a “supercommittee” on deficit reduction that they hoped would take taxes off the table and focus entirely on cuts in spending.

headline: How Yoga Won the West
text: Ann Louise Bardach is a writer at large for Newsweek. She is working on a biography of Vivekananda.

headline: Planets in the Sky With Diamonds
text: Diane Ackerman is the author of “One Hundred Names for Love” and “The Zookeeper’s Wife.”

headline: Can This Poet Save Mexico?
text: Enrique Krauze is the editor of the magazine Letras Libres and the author of “Redeemers: Ideas and Power in Latin America.” This article was translated by Hank Heifetz from the Spanish.

headline: The Stuff That Won’t Go Away
text: Jeffrey Eugenides is an American novelist whose book “The Marriage Plot” will be published this month. He won the Pulitzer Prize for “Middlesex.” Colm Toibin, an Irish writer, is the author of “The Empty Family Stories” and “Brooklyn.” He has been shortlisted twice for the Man Booker Prize.

headline: Danger’s Still Our Middle Name
text: Michael Cannell is the author of the forthcoming book “The Limit: Life and Death on the 1961 Grand Prix Circuit.”

headline: The (Not So) Roaring ’20s
text: Emily G. Owens is an assistant professor in the Department of Policy Analysis and Management at Cornell.

headline: Long-Secret Fallout Shelter Was a Cold War Camelot
text: PEANUT ISLAND, Fla. — A nuclear bomb shelter was a must-have in the 1950s and ’60s.

headline: Two Routes to Solving the Jobs Puzzle
text: Los Angeles

headline: Who Gets to Be Called a Doctor?
text: Many nurses are going back to school to earn doctorate degrees, but does that give them the right to call themselves doctor?

headline: Reading the Writing on the Envelope
text: THE Pony Express was famous for moving mail at astounding speed. Missouri to California in only 10 days! A triumph.

headline: In Texas, Extending the Miseries of Hurricane Ike
text: ANAHUAC, Tex. — The hurricane that swept through this East Texas town battered Shirley August’s house. Pieces of plywood cover the blown-out windows. Window screens, twisted by the winds, resemble abstract art. The shack in the backyard, her father’s old shoe-repair shop, appears ready to topple with one strong shove.

headline: Diamondbacks Pitch to the Brewers’ Fielder, and He Makes Them Pay in Opener
text: MILWAUKEE — Kirk Gibson saw a lot of a young Prince Fielder when Fielder’s father, Cecil, and Gibson played together for the Detroit Tigers in the 1990s. The families lived about two blocks apart, and Gibson remembers a strong-for-his-age Fielder cracking batting-practice home runs at Tiger Stadium.

headline: When Data Guys Triumph
text: JOSHUA MILBERG has plenty of business cred: an M.B.A. from Yale, experience in the mayor’s office in Chicago, a job as a vice president for an energy consulting firm.

headline: On the Docket
text: The Supreme Court, which returns to the bench on Monday, has so far agreed to hear about 50 cases, including ones on criminal and copyright law, the First Amendment and foreign affairs.

headline: As the West Celebrates a Cleric’s Death, the Mideast Shrugs
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Until about two years ago, few in Yemen or the Arab world had heard of Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born propagandist for Islamic radicalism whose death President Obama celebrated as a major blow against Al Qaeda.

headline: In New Term, Supreme Court Shifts Focus to Crime and First Amendment
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, which has been focused in recent terms on the rights of corporations and on curbing big lawsuits, returns to the bench on Monday with a different agenda. Now, criminal justice is at the heart of the court’s docket, along with major cases on free speech and religious freedom.

headline: Perry Open to Military Intervention in Mexico’s Drug War
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said on Saturday that as president, he would consider sending American troops into Mexico to help defeat drug cartels and improve border security. He indicated that any such action would be done “in concert” with the Mexican government.

headline: This Crisis Has 17 Moving Parts
text: ON WEDNESDAY, the eyes of the financial world turned to Finland.

headline: Maine City Casts Off Spurned Sculpture
text: The sculpture may have been doomed from the start.

headline: Conquering My Fear of Speaking in Public
text: SPEAKING in front of groups may not be a big deal for some people, and there are those who probably sail through their careers without ever having to do so. When I was studying for my C.P.A., I was sure that I’d be safe. But life isn’t predictable. I ended up in a career that depends on public speaking.

headline: Girardi Makes It Clear: Sabathia Won’t Pitch Until Monday
text: Joe Girardi made clear Saturday afternoon that he will not allow C.C. Sabathia to persuade him that he should pitch Sunday in Game 2 instead of Game 3 on Monday in Detroit. Girardi confirmed what he said after Friday’s game was suspended due to rain — Freddy Garcia will pitch Game 2 on Sunday.

headline: Pay the Grace Forward
text: I  WAS born in Chicago and am a middle child. My parents had 14 brothers and sisters between them, so my siblings and I grew up in a large extended family. During the summers, we spent time in Brownsville, Tenn., where my mother grew up. That grounded us in our family values — faith, family and freedom, or the ability to choose your path.

headline: Sunday: Masquerade
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — After reading the Notepad for this puzzle, I jumped to what turned out to be a false conclusion. I assumed (and you should never assume) that I would find this puzzle frustrating. First, you have to figure out the theme clues and their corresponding entries, which are not necessarily “in the language.” Then you have to “unmask” the hidden celebrities in each entry. O.K., so I was wrong.

headline: Suggestions for that, er, Tahrir on the Hudson?
text: My Sunday column is about the Occupy Wall Street movement — and in particular suggestions for financial reforms that the movement should take up. My Twitter comparison of the occupied park with Tahrir Square already raised eyebrows — and caused me to rush to clarify — so I’d welcome comments on that, or on any specific steps you recommend to reform the financial system.

headline: U.T. Making a Big Bet on the Future of Algae
text: Just off a dirt road in northwest Austin stand hundreds of 12-foot-tall tubes filled with green liquid. Nearly 15,000 gallons of algae grow inside the tubes, which are housed in a massive structure called a shadehouse. Lab workers have to climb ladders to peek inside and tend to the tiny organisms.

headline: On Immigrant Tuition, Texans See It Perry’s Way
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Tiny, Remote Marfa Poised to Be a Rock-Star Magnet
text: Something strange happened at last weekend’s Trans-Pecos Festival of Music and Love at El Cosmico in Marfa. Five hundred concertgoers — most staying in one of a hundred tents, six trailers, four safari tents and four yurts — three security guards, four sound men and one lighting specialist heard the voice of Led Zeppelin perform onstage. It seemed random and a little surreal, but somehow there was Robert Plant, live in the middle of nowhere.

headline: The Kennedy Tunnel
text: Just off Old Tunnel Road in Oakland, a stone and brass-plated marker attests to the former use of a nearby hillside. In the early 1900s, a tunnel through the hill linked Oakland and Lafayette, allowing horse-drawn and pedestrian traffic between the two growing communities. Cars used it, too. The tunnel closed in the 1940s, but a flagpole marks the entrance to this once-bustling locale.

headline: The Heart of the Art
text: DURING a residency at the Getty Research Institute in Los Angeles several years ago, I began to think about images that were created in the course of art preservation, where the realms of visual art and scientific research overlap. While taking photographs at the conservation department of the J. Paul Getty Museum, I became captivated by X-rays of art objects from the museum’s permanent collections. These ghostly images seemed to surpass the potency of the original objects of art. They were like transmissions from the distant past, conveying messages across time, and connecting the contemporary viewer to the art impulse at the core of these ancient works.

headline: Remembering Pete Gent, Who Wrote ‘North Dallas Forty’
text: Pete Gent was able to express in words what many players feel about pro football, both good and bad. While his writing left its mark on the game, it’s equally clear that the game left its mark on him. Gent died Friday from a pulmonary illness at his home in Bangor, Mich. He was 69. A few thoughts:In the early 1970s, as pro football was becoming the nation’s most popular spectator sport, a group of ex-players exposed, through both their words and their actions, the game’s seamy underside. A novel by Pete Gent, “North Dallas Forty,” based on his five years with the Cowboys, graphically depicted the pain and anguish the public couldn’t feel or see on their television screens. Yet, despite the broken bones and sleepless nights, most of the players wished it could go on forever. Many, like Gent himself, remembered their football days as some of the best times of their lives.

headline: The Songs of ‘Glee’ Give Way to Terror

headline: Don’t Stop Screaming: The ‘Glee’ Guys Introduce Their ‘American Horror Story’
text: A couple of years spent with the sunny kids of “Glee” could send anyone over to the dark side, and that’s exactly where the “Glee” co-creators Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk turned for their latest television series, “American Horror Story,” which makes its debut on Wednesday on FX. The new show begins with a husband and wife (Dylan McDermott of “The Practice” and Connie Britton of “Friday Night Lights”) and their teenage daughter (Taissa Farmiga) moving to Los Angeles to start their lives fresh. But their new Gothic fixer-up was a steal for a reason: it’s haunted by a history of murder and visited by creepy neighbors, housekeepers and unwelcome guests (including Jessica Lange, Frances Conroy and Denis O’Hare) as well as a mysterious figure in a full-body S&M costume, whom the “American Horror Story” producers have affectionately dubbed “Rubber Man.”

headline: Did the Tigers Have the Right Man at Second Base?
text: 6:48 p.m. | Updated Ryan Raburn is a useful spare part on a major league baseball club. He’s been a slightly above-average hitter over his career and plays a fine outfield. He can also fill in at second or third base, although not particularly well. According to the defensive statistics compiled from video records at Fangraphs.com, Raburn’s fielding has cost the Tigers 14 runs compared to an average second baseman over the 778 innings he has manned the keystone in his major league career. (He has performed even worse at third.)

headline: In Yemen, One Islamist Is Dead, but the Battle Goes On

headline: A Map of Organized Climate Change Denial
text: Oct. 3, 9:00 p.m. | Updated A chart of “key components of the climate change denial machine” has been produced by Riley E. Dunlap, regents professor of sociology at Oklahoma State University, and Aaron M. McCright, an associate professor of sociology at Michigan State University. The diagram below (reproduced here with permission) is from a chapter the two researchers wrote on organized opposition to efforts to curb greenhouse gases for the new Oxford Handbook of Climate Change and Society.

headline: ‘White Shirts’ of Police Dept. Take On Enforcer Role
text: The New York Police Department puts an endless list of tasks on the shoulders of its so-called white shirts — the commanders atop an army of lesser-ranking officers in dark blue.

headline: Europe to Study Telecommunications Leasing Charges
text: BERLIN — The European commissioner for digital technology was expected to begin an in-depth review Monday of the charges that the Continent’s largest telecommunications operators impose for leasing access to their national landline networks.

headline: Savior of the World, Heal Thyself: Prescription for America’s Ailments
text: In “That Used to Be Us” Thomas L. Friedman and Michael Mandelbaum join a growing number of foreign policy thinkers warning that America’s position abroad cannot endure without a renewal of the domestic sources of American prosperity and strength.

headline: Reasons for Reason
text: The inability to agree on the principles that underlie our beliefs is at the root of our political discord. And it can’t be solved by voting.

headline: Clear Channel Names Pittman as Its Chief
text: WhenRobert W. Pittman first joined Clear Channel Communications last November as the chairman of its media and entertainment business, he told the company that he was not interested in becoming chief executive.

headline: Anticipating a Defensive Error Costs Dearly
text: You have 10-4-3 of clubs in the dummy opposite A-J-5-2 in your hand. You need two winners from this suit but can afford to lose only one trick. Assuming you have no entry concerns, what will you do?

headline: In Debt Talks, Divide on What Tax Breaks Are Worth Keeping
text: WASHINGTON — Plenty of lawmakers are against tax breaks and so-called loopholes. Unless, of course, they personally helped create them.

headline: In Crossing the Border, the Risks Are More Grave
text: Veteran border crossers present an enormous challenge to American policymakers, because they continue to head north despite deterrents more severe than at any time in recent history.

headline: A New Met Diva, With a Four-Legged Co-Star
text: Those mourning the slow, steady decline of the Franco Zeffirelli era at the Metropolitan Opera can take solace in the fact that a crucial element of his directorial vision remains intact: his mystifying predilection for live animals onstage. David McVicar’s new production of Donizetti’s “Anna Bolena,” which opened last week, for some reason included two Irish wolfhounds, and the placid donkey remains in the revival of Bartlett Sher’s 2006 production of Rossini’s “Barbiere di Siviglia” that opened on Saturday afternoon.

headline: A Concert, Nearly Canceled, Keeps a Rising Star Afloat
text: The beloved concert spot Bargemusic, moored near the Brooklyn Bridge in Dumbo, floats serenely, with a cozy wood-lined interior and a temperamental toilet. It is so improbable and distinctive that it seems a small miracle each time a recital there goes off successfully.

headline: Fathers Who Tend to Their Flocks
text: The fourth and latest feature from the “moviemaking ministry” of Sherwood Pictures, a media arm of the Sherwood Baptist Church in Albany, Ga., “Courageous” contains enough parables, “are you there, God?” monologues and tearful affirmations of faith-based fatherhood to furnish a dozen megachurch services. To sweeten the sermon there is also some light gunplay.

headline: An Amorous Triangle, Spiced Up by Gunplay
text: For all its flashy sunglasses and gunplay, there’s a folk-tale essence in Tigmanshu Dhulia’s “Sahib Biwi Aur Gangster,” a riff on “Sahib Bibi Aur Ghulam,” a 1962 Hindi classic. That film concerned the chaste bond between a married noblewoman and a servant; Mr. Dhulia’s take offers Sahib (Jimmy Shergill), a rural mob godfather of declining fortunes, and Biwi (Mahie Gill), his neglected, hot-tempered wife. The gangster (Randeep Hooda), hired as a chauffeur, is secretly on a mission to set up Sahib for a hit. There’s nothing chaste about his designs: He covets Biwi and Sahib’s status as well.

headline: Stars Will Read Amazon Unit’s New Audio Book Series
text: Would you listen to a recording of “The End of the Affair” that lasted hours? What if Colin Firth were reading it?

headline: Neustadt Prize Awarded
text: Rohinton Mistry has been named the 2012 laureate of the $50,000 Neustadt International Prize for Literature, according to World Literature Today, a magazine of the University of Oklahoma. Mr. Mistry previously won the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for fiction and was a finalist in 1996 for the Man Booker Prize for “A Fine Balance,” which was also selected by Oprah Winfrey’s book club in 2001. The Neustadt Prize is given every two years and is sponsored by the University of Oklahoma, World Literature Today and the Neustadt family. An international jury considers the work of poets, playwrights and novelists for the honor.

headline: Feisty Performance at Paper Mill Playhouse
text: “Newsies the Musical” may feature rambunctious youths loudly proclaiming their rebellion onstage, but the same description could have been used for a few audience members on Thursday at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J. Three women and six teenage girls were removed from the theater after several patrons complained about an altercation and disruptive behavior during the performance, according to The Star-Ledger of Newark. Asked to leave by theater management during the intermission, the women reportedly refused. A uniformed officer then escorted them out. Based on the 1992 film “Newsies” starring Christian Bale and Bill Pullman and produced by Disney Theatrical Productions, the musical opened last week to glowing reviews under the direction of Jeff Calhoun with choreography by Christopher Gattelli and a book by Harvey Fierstein. The musical has recently drawn interest from theater owners in New York, with the intention of mounting a Broadway production.

headline: Crazy Fun at Kenzo
text: PARIS — Humberto Leon and Carol Lim presented their first Kenzo collection on Sunday with a show that was every bit as fun as promised by the two founders of Opening Ceremony.

headline: Theater Strike in Philadelphia
text: Members of the Philadelphia chapter of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees ended a daylong strike on Saturday, announcing that a one-week cooling-off period would go into effect to allow for renewed negotiations between the chapter and the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts, according to The Associated Press. The strike began after the current chapter contract, which covers about 1,000 employees from the Kimmel Center, the Merriam Theater and the Philadelphia Academy of Music, expired on Friday. The Kimmel Center canceled all Saturday events, including a musical performance by Audra McDonald. Talks between the chapter and the Kimmel Center broke down last week after the sides failed to agree on wages, benefits, working conditions and the chapter’s jurisdiction.

headline: Another Honor for Paul Simon
text: Paul Simon, above, was among 178 artists, scientists and institutional leaders inducted into the American Academy of Arts and Sciences on Saturday at Harvard, The Associated Press reported. Founded in 1780 by John Adams, James Bowdoin, John Hancock and others, the academy recognizes achievement in public affairs, science, education and culture. The ceremony included a performance by Mr. Simon of “American Tune,” from his 1973 album “There Goes Rhymin’ Simon.” Other inductees from the academy’s 231st class included the novelists Oscar Hijuelos and Luisa Valenzuela, the landscape architect Michael Van Valkenburgh and the Shakespeare scholar James Shapiro.

headline: Rock in Rio Music Festival Ends
text: Chris Martin, above, the lead vocalist for the group Coldplay, practiced his spray painting on a stage wall during his band’s performance at the Rock in Rio Music Festival in Rio de Janeiro on Saturday. Among the artists to appear at the annual series of concerts were Rihanna, Elton John, Metallica, Red Hot Chili Peppers and Shakira. The festival, which opened on Sept. 23, ended on Sunday.

headline: Ballet Divas Steal Stage From Riff, if Only Briefly
text: Robert Fairchild is a natural Riff, the charismatic head of the Jets, who, in the Jerome Robbins ballet “West Side Story Suite,” as in the classic musical, meets a senselessly violent end. It was almost a surprise, at Friday night’s New York City Ballet performance, to realize he was making his debut in the role; after that, it was just a delight.

headline: Blue Shield of California Won’t Cover Breast Cancer Drug
text: Blue Shield of California will no longer pay for the use of the drug Avastin to treat breast cancer, a sign that support for the widely debated and expensive treatment may be eroding among health plans.

headline: Rapping in the Rain, All Smiles
text: Often will.i.am, the frontman and behind-the-boards maestro of the Black Eyed Peas, will appear in public wearing what seems to be a plastic mold, or sheath, covering his head, giving him the air of an Afro-futurist cybernaut or a character from a William Gibson novel. It turns out he’s just planning for rain.

headline: Monday: Sob Stories
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — If you’re keeping track, another one of the unwritten rules of mainstream crossword theme development is: “Thou shalt not drag thy political leanings into the daily puzzle.” The daily crossword is placed squarely (sorry) in the entertainment section as a respite from the rest of the day’s news. Today, however, Stanley Newman, editor of the Newsday crossword puzzle, hitches his vowels to our 43rd president in what appears to be a tribute to George “DUBYA” Bush.

headline: Peter Gent, Football Novelist, Dies at 69
text: Peter Gent, a receiver for the Dallas Cowboys of the 1960s whose best-selling novel “North Dallas Forty” portrayed professional football as a dehumanizing business that drove pain-racked players to drug and alcohol abuse, died Friday in Bangor, Mich. He was 69.
