headline: Shifting the Suburban Paradigm
text: Is there anything made in America that’s less innovative than the single-family home? While we obsess over the new in terms of what we keep in our houses — the ever-increasing speed and functionality of our Smartphones, entertainment options built into refrigerators, sophisticated devices that monitor, analyze and report on our sleep cycles, even the superior technology of the running shoes we put on before heading out the flimsy fiberboard door — we’re incredibly undemanding of the houses themselves. These continue to be built the same way they have for over a century, and usually not as well. Walls and windows are thin, materials cheap, design (and I use the term loosely) not well-considered. The building process is a protracted affair, taking far too long and creating embarrassing amounts of building waste (over 50 percent of all waste produced in the United States, in fact).

headline: Social Media News Site Gains Clout
text: Pete Cashmore acknowledged he was nervous. Only a few years ago, he was living with his parents in a small town in northeast Scotland, trying to start a technology blog. Now, at 26, he was about to interview Elie Wiesel, the 82-year-old Holocaust survivor and Nobel Peace Prize winner, onstage at the 92nd Street Y, about the future of ethics in a digitally connected world.

Even Eli Manning, standing 25 yards back upfield with his hands clasped to the sides of his head, was sure that Victor Cruz had just inexplicably, incomprehensibly, laid the game at the Cardinals’ collective feet.

headline: Altering a Deal Without Blocking it
text: Blocking mergers is the bluntest tool in an antitrust watchdog’s armory. That is what the Justice Department is trying with AT&T’s ambition to acquire T-Mobile USA.

headline: Animated Fruit With Ambition
text: LOS ANGELES — There is little doubt that Dane Boedigheimer has created an online sensation that struck a pop cultural nerve. The “Annoying Orange” Web videos that he’s been rolling out for the last two years have racked up more than 800 million views on You Tube, where the threshold for a runaway hit is about 50 million.

headline: Oracle Convention Engulfs San Francisco With a Party Atmosphere
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Commuters driving into this city on Monday morning will discover major downtown thoroughfares closed. More than 129,000 square feet of tents will have sprouted around the city’s convention center, where 4.25 miles of power cables, 300 miles of phone and Internet wires and enough beer trucks to sate 45,000 people are in place.

headline: Though Not Ready to Play, Crosby Shapes the Game
text: DETROIT — It has been said that the N.H.L. season beginning on Thursday is about Sidney Crosby. And that, too, is largely about Sidney Crosby.

text: CAIRO — Egypt’s interim military rulers have apparently agreed to allow foreign election observers and to let political parties take a greater role in creating a permanent government.

headline: Foreclosures Are Killing Us
text: AFTER slowing down in the first half of the year, the rate of homes entering foreclosure is rising again. First-time default notices were served on 78,000 homes in August, a 33 percent increase from July. A $1 billion federal program to help jobless and underemployed homeowners ended Friday. Foreclosure notices were filed against a record 2.9 million properties last year, and an additional 1.2 million in the first half of this year.

headline: Holding China to Account
text: The dire state of the world economy reflects destructive actions on the part of many players. Still, the fact that so many have behaved badly shouldn’t stop us from holding individual bad actors to account.

headline: Unofficial Visits Draw Concern, Not Scrutiny

headline: For Politics in South, Race Divide Is Defining

headline: School Layoffs About to Fall Heaviest on the Poorest and Most Struggling

headline: Ruling for Open Courts

headline: Michael J. Drake, Planetary Scientist, Dies at 65

text: There were no damaged hands or missed calls to blame, and no punctured lung to play the hero. N.F.L. coaches like to divide the season into quarters, and they think that after the first one is over, they should have a good idea of what kind of team they have.

headline: Say No to the Keystone XL
text: Unless good sense intervenes, it looks increasingly likely that the State Department will approve the Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry a coarse, acidic crude oil from northern Alberta in Canada to refineries on the Gulf Coast of Texas. That would be a mistake.

headline: Greeks Move to Slash State Jobs for 30,000
text: ATHENS — After marathon talks with foreign auditors, the Greek government said Sunday that it had reached a deal on how to slash its unwieldy public sector by putting 30,000 workers on a scheme that would lead to early retirement for some and dismissal for others, in a bid to meet conditions set by foreign lenders for the release of crucial emergency loans.

headline: Snag for Perry: Offensive Name at Texas Camp

headline: A Broader G.I. Bill
text: Starting this month, military veterans pursuing an education under the G.I. Bill have many more choices. The money for tuition, books and housing used to be just for study at colleges and universities, but now the G.I. Bill also covers non-degree institutions like vocational and technical schools, flight schools, and licensing and apprenticeship programs.

headline: Catcher Keeps Scherzer on Target

headline: The University of Wherever
text: FOR more than a decade educators have been expecting the Internet to transform that bastion of tradition and authority, the university. Digital utopians have envisioned a world of virtual campuses and “distributed” learning. They imagine a business model in which online courses are consumer-rated like products on Amazon, tuition is set by auction services like eBay, and students are judged not by grades but by skills they have mastered, like levels of a videogame. Presumably, for the Friday kegger you go to the Genius Bar.

headline: Brewers Flex Their Muscles and Push Past the Diamondbacks Again

It is called “beast mode.” Whenever a Brewer gets a hit or makes a nice play, Fielder, the bearlike first baseman, flexes his arms forward as if trying to hug a sequoia, and the player flashes it back. Bloop or blast, it does not matter. A grunt tops it off.

headline: Crossing Over, and Over

headline: Why Bismarck Loved Lincoln
text: We usually think of the Civil War as a uniquely American event, a war unlike any other fought in the Western world during the 19th century. And of course that’s true, strictly speaking: no other country saw itself split in two over slavery. But that’s not the only way to think of the war. Put a different way, the Civil War was just one of several wars for national unification — including fighting in Italy and Germany — on both sides of the Atlantic during the mid-19th century.

headline: Brooklyn Academy Offers New Program
text: The Brooklyn Academy of Music has announced a professional development program designed to provide free support to Brooklyn art groups attempting to mount performances. As part of the academy’s 150th anniversary and in coordination with the DeVos Institute of Arts Management at the Kennedy Center in Washington, the 14-month program will offer workshops, mentoring sessions and access to academy facilities. Six spots will be available initially for nonprofit performing arts organizations, with dance being the focus for the first session.

headline: Oct. 3, 1990 | East and West Germany United After 45 Years
text: On Oct. 3, 1990, West Germany and East Germany officially became one nation after 45 years of postwar division. The Oct. 3 New York Times  reported, “Forty-five years after it was carved up in defeat and disgrace, Germany was reunited today in a midnight celebration of pealing bells, national hymns and the jubilant blare of good old German oom-pah-pah.”

headline: A Conversation With Naeem Khan
text: It’s less than an hour before Naeem Khan’s runway show at Lincoln Center showcasing his Spring 2012 collection, and I’m standing backstage with the 54 year-old designer. Photographers scurry around us shooting the clothes, which are still on hangers, while a team of stylists apply the finishing hair, makeup and nail touches on the leggy models. The mood is hectic, but Khan himself is incredibly calm.

headline: Back From Break, Congress Has a Full Plate
text: WASHINGTON — Congress returns on Monday after a week off, but it was the sort of recess during which it rains every day, and no one gets to play on the swings. Hanging over both chambers is the specter of yet another serious fiscal fight this week, with longer-term battles over trade, regulations and how best to stimulate the economy also on the horizon.

headline: Complaint Box | Children in Restaurants
text: On a weekend excursion to Baltimore in July, I chanced upon an unusual scene in a hotel restaurant. After a toddler and his parents had finished eating and left their table, a two-person cleanup crew immediately appeared, attempting to reverse the devastation that the child had wrought on and beneath the table. Apparently the toddler had shredded every last piece of bread on the table and tossed it to the floor, along with various other breakfast items. Yet nothing in the parents’ expressions or words would have led one to conclude that they were aware of the mess their child had created.

headline: Vain Glorious | Annee de Mamiel
text: Apart from switching to a richer moisturizer during the winter, most of us do not give much thought to seasonal changes and skin. But for Annee de Mamiel, there is no separating the two. Combining her training in traditional Chinese medicine, which holds that everything is seasonal, and her experience as a facialist, de Mamiel creates four limited-edition custom oils every year, each one available only during the three-month period for which it is intended.

headline: Monday Reading: Flights to Europe, for a Little Less

text: JERUSALEM — A mosque in an Arab village in northern Israel was set on fire early Monday in what the police called an arson attack, and an outside wall was defaced with Hebrew graffiti.

headline: Exit the Curmudgeon

If you have, and even if you haven’t, you are about to find out. On Sunday night, Mr. Rooney delivered his last philippic after 33 years as a regular contributor to the CBS newsmagazine.

headline: Two Chosen ‘Geniuses’ Reflect on Label
text: The MacArthur Foundation has never attached the word “genius” to its annual grants to exemplary scientists, scholars, researchers, writers, artists, composers and other creative Americans. The term “genius award” seems to have sprung up in the news media soon after the first grants were given, in 1981, and the nickname has stuck. The program simply provides a fellowship, with recipients (some 20 to 40 each year) receiving $500,000 each, no strings attached, paid in quarterly installments over five years.

headline: ‘Sesame Street’ Special on Hunger Introduces New Muppet Character

For a prime-time special to raise awareness about hunger faced by American families, Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit organization that produces “Sesame Street,” has created a new Muppet character named Lily, a 7-year-old girl representing one of the 17 million American children that the Department of Agriculture estimates are “food insecure,” meaning their access to food is limited or uncertain.

It was a little fancy for me, and I found myself going over the hits and misses of the week with Hal Rubenstein and Nina Garcia, who both liked Riccardo Tisci’s strong tailoring this season for Givenchy.

headline: Park Avenue Armory Will be Setting for Trip to Mars
text: Over the years the Park Avenue Armory has transformed its cavernous drill hall into everything including a science-fiction fun house and a landscape created from 30 tons of discarded clothing. For its next act the New York artist Tom Sachs will offer “SPACE PROGRAM 2.0: Mars,’’ his fictional mission to the planet. The project is a presentation of the Armory and Creative Time.

headline: Lions Rebuilt Team, Psyche and Record
text: It figures that the Detroit Lions would be the first team in N.F.L. history to win consecutive games after trailing by at least 20 points in each. After all, once a team has resurrected itself from a 0-16 season, come-from-behind victories are just microcosms of a much bigger rebuilding job.

headline: They Heard the Word Culture, and They Reached for Their Gun
text: Funnily enough, I was in New York when it happened. It was a short breather after several months in Kabul — a treat for my children, whom I hadn’t seen for so long. We’d been out all day — MoMA, Harlem for lunch, Yankees tickets, a cruise past the Statue of Liberty. There was a reflection on the water of the development at ground zero as we steered by. “That’s why you’re in Kabul?” my kids asked.

headline: Navigating the Net Wisely in a Health Crisis
text: Andrew Schorr, a specialist in health communications, is convinced that the Internet saved his life. Now, through a book he wrote with Mary Adam Thomas, “The Web-Savvy Patient,” he is trying to help others facing a medical crisis use the Internet to their advantage and avoid its potential pitfalls.

headline: Defending David Against Goliath
text: You may have seen a fascinating New York Times article about the lawsuit Procter & Gamble has filed against a start-up called Willa, which produces a line of cosmetics that is sold in Target and in small boutiques. It turns out that P.&G. has a line of cosmetics called Wella, a German hair care brand that the conglomerate acquired in 2003 for $7 billion. P.&G. sued Willa over the name, claiming that it was confusingly similar to Wella.

headline: Libyan Rebels Clarify Steps to New Rule
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Libya’s provisional leaders said Monday that they would resign once the former rebels defeat the vestiges of armed support for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in his home city of Surt, a move that would clear the way for a new interim government that would run the country until elections can be held.

headline: ‘Red’ and ‘Carnage’ Find New Life Well Beyond Broadway
text: The Tony Award that can reliably boost ticket sales for Broadway shows is the award for best musical: An overwhelming number of theatergoers – about 90 percent – buy tickets to see musicals rather than plays, and a Tony helps folks differentiate among the productions in the running for their ticket money.

headline: Frederick Wiseman’s Institutional Knowledge
text: From high schools, to state legislatures to boxing gyms, the documentary filmmaker Frederick Wiseman has been exploring the institutions that make the world tick. For his latest film, “Crazy Horse,” the director takes a look inside the workings of a landmark French strip club that has been operating since 1951. In his survey of documentaries at the New York Film Festival, A. O. Scott called the film “a study of artistic process that is itself a work of art, and, as such, a reminder of what a documentary can be.” Here, Mr. Wiseman discusses what interests him in the process of making documentaries and what he hopes to convey to his audience.

headline: New From Paris | Pierre Balmain
text: Balmain’s new diffusion line, Pierre Balmain, made its debut in Paris on Sunday and can best be described as a greatest-hits collection, but at one third of the price. All of the Balmain pieces that we’ve come to love — black motocross jeans, zebra-print button-down shirts and shrunken leather jackets — came styled in exactly the right model-off-duty way. The men’s wear, too, was very rocker-looking, with leather bombers and silky button-down shirts neatly tucked into skinny jeans.

headline: Substantial Pastries for Busy Teenagers
text: My son, an eighth grader who has grown six inches in the last year, will not eat lunch at school. It’s not about the sandwiches I’ve tried to pack, or the school lunches (which I wouldn’t blame him for not eating). Nor is it a question of appetite: He’s always hungry. During his 30-minute lunch period he wants to play basketball. If he goes to the cafeteria he doesn’t have time to get a game in.

headline: Another Helping of Rattlesnake?
text: If you read Sunday’s Food and Drink issue, you already know what rattlesnake tastes like: ‘‘sinewy, half-starved tilapia,’’ according to Maud Newton. Check out Maud’s follow-up post on her blog to find out what raw rattlesnake looks like (‘‘a garden hose made of filleted haddock’’) and what might be needed to cut it safely (‘‘hedge clippers’’), among other details.

headline: A Small Fix for Hypertension: Readers Weigh In
text: Last week’s special issue, Small Fixes, dealt with low-cost health innovations that are saving lives in the developing world. Online, at nytimes.com/smallfixes, readers were invited to come up with a small fix of their own: a device for detecting high blood pressure, which, left untreated, can raise the risk of coronary artery disease, stroke, kidney damage and heart attack.

headline: The Caucus | Waiting for Chris Christie
text: Oct. 3, 2011 — Governor Christie’s deliberations as he considers whether to run for president. Also, Governor Perry’s campaign faces another challenge, this one on the thorny issue of race.

headline: H.I.V.: Quick Follow-Up Testing Increases Rate Seeking Antiretroviral Treatment
text: In low-income countries, as many as two-thirds of those in need of antiretroviral drugs to treat H.I.V. infection never get them. One reason is that after a positive H.I.V. test, many patients never return to the clinic for the next step — a test to determine blood levels of CD4 cells, a measure of immune function essential to deciding whether treatment is needed, and if so, what kind.

headline: Caucus Video: Chris Christie’s Deliberations; Rick Perry and Race
text: A look at Gov. Chris Christie’s options as he considers whether to run for president. Also, Gov. Rick Perry’s campaign faces another challenge, this one on the thorny issue of race.

headline: Fourth Tibetan Monk Self-Immolates in Anti-China Protest
text: BEIJING — A young Tibetan monk set himself on fire Monday in a remote western town to protest Chinese policies, the fourth monk from Kirti Monastery to self-immolate this year, according to a Tibet advocacy group based in London.

headline: Book on Strauss-Kahn Incident Planned
text: Dominique Strauss-Kahn has left New York for Paris, but the story of his sexual encounter with a hotel chambermaid, and the criminal case that developed and then was dropped, is just reaching book publishers. St. Martin’s Press, part of Macmillan, said on Monday it had acquired a book by John Solomon, the Newsweek reporter who interviewed Nafissatou Diallo, the housekeeper who accused Mr. Strauss-Kahn of sexual assault in May. Mr. Solomon’s book “will report the inside story of how the DSK case was transformed from a slam-dunk, five-day indictment against Strauss-Kahn to a flat-out dismissal that turned the tables on his very accuser,” a statement from the publisher said. The charges against Mr. Strauss-Kahn — who called the encounter “an error” and a “moral failure” but not a criminal act — were dismissed in August after prosecutors said the accuser lacked credibility.

headline: Soon, L Will Mean Less Crowded, Subway Officials Say
text: Want to find a seat on the L train? Head to the back three cars. Avoid peak hours entirely. And if it’s between 4 p.m. and 6 p.m. on a Saturday, forget it.

headline: Riding (Slowly) Through the Heartland
text: WOOSTER, Ohio — Eighteen years ago, when I made my first cross-country bicycle journey, the ride from the Golden Gate Bridge to the George Washington Bridge took 75 days. Sunday was day 75 of my second transcontinental trip, and the distance I have yet to travel from Wooster, Ohio, to Manhattan — 470 miles by car, probably another 70 or 80 on a bicyclist’s more meandering path — is one way to measure how I’ve aged. (Another is that my knees are stiff and sore; every morning I feel  little like the Tin Man from “The Wizard of Oz,” pleading squeakily for his oil can.)

headline: Silicon Valley II?
text: The underlying assumption of Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s plan to subsidize a top-flight applied science campus in New York is that New York can replicate the spark that ignited Silicon Valley. Can it?

headline: Addressing Some Misperceptions About Mexican Immigration
text: Reading the comments attached to my article today – looking at how today’s illegal immigrants are more likely to be people who have roots and families in the United States – I was struck by something that advocates for and against expanded immigration told me while I was reporting: “This is a fact-free zone.”

headline: Disrupters and Adapters, Continued: Will the Internet Save Newspapers?
text: The two visions of higher education’s future I described in my column this week – Stanford Professor Sebastian Thrun’s mission of a virtual university and Stanford President John Hennessy’s devotion to a flesh-and-blood campus – intrigued me because of the larger context. So much of the debate about the impact of new technology tends to be polarizing. The utopians versus the skeptics, the idealists versus the realists, those who throw themselves headlong into the great mosh pit of the new, and those who cherish the familiar and time-honored.

headline: Covered in White Brick, and Showing Their Age
text: Over the decades, white brick buildings — those wedding-cake-shape stalwarts of postwar living — have fallen out of favor and in again among residents, architects and preservationists. Now some of them are falling apart.

headline: Airport Pat-Down for Breast Cancer Patient
text: Tightened security at airports has created new problems for medical patients, who may be subjected to embarrassing public pat-downs after imaging machines detect devices or implants related to their health.

headline: A Tale of Two Cities Talking
text: On sports talk radio, the N.F.L. is king, even during the baseball playoffs, and even in baseball playoff cities. That may not be quite as true in New York: with two baseball teams, one great and one awful, there is a steady supply of simultaneous gloating and grousing, and the Yankees are perfectly capable of keeping the spotlight away from the Giants and Jets. But drive 90 miles south, or head out to the Midwest, and pro football’s dominance becomes clear: who cares if we won the World Series yesterday, I am calling to demand that we give the backup quarterback a shot!

headline: Rescue Aid to Greece Delayed as Pressure Rises for Reforms
text: LUXEMBOURG — Finance ministers from the 17-nation euro zone piled more pressure on Greece early Tuesday by postponing moves to release the next installment of aid and suggesting that more austerity measures were needed.

headline: Miracle of Miracles: ‘Sunrise, Sunset’ Gets a Gay Makeover
text: 12:21 p.m. | Updated  Besides the Chicken Dance and the Electric Slide, one of the songs Most Likely to Be Played at a Wedding, at least for theater fans, is “Sunrise, Sunset,” a ballad from the 1964 musical “Fiddler on the Roof.” Sung by Tevye and Golde during their daughter Tzeitel’s wedding to the tailor Motel, the song is a melancholy look back at how time flies:

headline: An Addiction Vaccine, Tantalizingly Close
text: SAN DIEGO — Imagine a vaccine against smoking: People trying to quit would light up a cigarette and feel nothing. Or a vaccine against cocaine, one that would prevent addicts from enjoying the drug’s high.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct.3
text: A view of the day in sports, with indoor baseball and a race by the Egyptian Pyramids.

headline: Registration Begins for 9/11 Health Compensation Fund
text: The federal government’s September 11th Victim Compensation Fund began taking registrations Monday from people who believe they were physically harmed by the terrorist attacks and who are seeking financial compensation.

headline: Article vs. ‘Charticle': Comparing Coverage of a Qaeda Operative’s Killing
text: Open any day’s print edition of The New York Times, and you will see not only various types of news and opinion articles, but also creative ways of presenting content, like infographics. And the Web version enables multimedia and interactive features.

headline: Rock Stars Won’t Play for Putin
text: MOSCOW — Two popular Russian rock musicians, disillusioned with the presidency of Dmitri A. Medvedev, have said they will not appear at concerts celebrating the presidential election next March, though they performed at a similar event nearly four years ago.

headline: Dozens of Arrests Are Reported as Syrian Troops Retake Town
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government said Monday that it had arrested dozens of people in a central Syrian region that has become a flash point in fighting between defectors and security forces waging a brutal crackdown on a six-month uprising.

headline: The revenge of the slime molds, readers take a global health challenge and we take a look at pathological altruism.
text: The revenge of the slime molds, readers take a global health challenge and we take a look at pathological altruism.

headline: The Roller Coaster Ride Continues for Madoff Investors
text: Investors in the Ponzi scheme perpetrated by Bernard L. Madoff have endured more twists and turns than the Cyclone on Coney Island. Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in Manhattan delivered an abrupt change in course when he limited the claims that Irving S. Picard, the trustee appointed to oversee the investor claims, could pursue against Saul Katz and Fred Wilpon, the owners of the New York Mets, from their accounts with Mr. Madoff’s firm.

headline: Drawing Dance: Preparing to Say Farewell
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 14th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from Berlin.

headline: With Off-Lease Cars, Firm Sees Increase in Odometer Tampering
text: AIM Mobile Inspections, an evaluator of new and used vehicles, said that the incidence of odometer rollback for the purpose of misrepresenting the mileage of off-lease used vehicles had increased by 30 percent since the beginning of this year.

headline: Kerry Adviser Becomes a Lobbyist
text: The revolving door between Capitol Hill and K Street swept up another influential name on Monday, as the top foreign policy adviser to Senator John F. Kerry joined Tony Podesta’s lobbying shop.

headline: Dying Forests: How Bad Is It, Really?
text: A year ago, I was sitting in a room overlooking the Pacific Ocean with a man named Ralph Keeling. The son of Charles David Keeling, who had discovered the trend of rising carbon dioxide in the atmosphere in the 1950s, Ralph Keeling had become a famous climate scientist in his own right.

headline: Parents and Kids Say They Appreciated Autism-Friendly ‘Lion King’ Matinee
text: When someone leaves in the middle of a Broadway show, it’s usually not with smile on their face. But there was Maria Omieh, standing with her children, Joshua, 6, and Shekinah, 5, outside the 1,600-seat Minskoff Theater on Sunday. Ms. Omieh had taken them to a sold-out performance of the musical “The Lion King” that had been modified for children with autism and their families. She decided to leave during intermission, as did a few other families, but with no regrets.

headline: London Underground | Food Market Dining
text: Two recent restaurant projects — one with a life span of just a month, the other a more permanent venture — offer vivid illustrations of the liveliness of London’s current food market scene.

headline: Metro Pucks: Ranking the Top Offensive Forwards Among the Rangers, Islanders and Devils
text: There are now nine elite scoring forwards among New York and New Jersey’s hockey teams. Two years ago, list-makers would find it challenging to nominate more than one each from the Rangers, Islanders and Devils. Now it’s an embarrassment of Richards and Tavares and Kovalchuk.

headline: Diamondback Beset With Redemptions, Summer Losses
text: Ever since federal agents stormed into its office late last year, Diamondback Capital Management has been working to stay afloat.

headline: Rhapsody to Acquire Napster in Deal With Best Buy
text: Rhapsody, the subscription digital music service, said on Monday that it had signed an agreement to acquire Napster from Best Buy, uniting two cloud music players amid escalating competition in a growing market.

headline: On Subsidies, Fish and Fishing
text: A report examining the roughly $8 billion in subsidies that have flowed from the European Union or Spanish taxpayers to Spain’s fishing fleet since 2000 was published over the weekend by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists.

headline: ‘Billy Elliot’ to Close in January
text: Time to hang up the ballet shoes. The Broadway musical “Billy Elliot,” the winner of 10 Tony Awards in 2009 and a hot ticket for much of its run, will close on Jan. 8, 2012, after 3 years and 3 months of performances, the producers announced on Monday. The decision to close “Billy Elliot” came after a somewhat precipitous decline in ticket sales that accelerated through the late spring and summer amid competition from new musicals like “The Book of Mormon” and “Priscilla Queen of the Desert,” hit revivals like “Anything Goes” and “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,” and “Memphis,” the durable recipient of the 2010 Tony for best musical.

headline: Talk Therapy Lifts Severe Schizophrenics
text: People with severe schizophrenia who have been isolated, withdrawn and considered beyond help can learn to become more active, social and employable by engaging in a type of talk therapy that was invented to treat depression, scientists reported on Monday.

headline: Study Cites Increase in Cancers From HPV
text: Throat cancers caused by a virus transmitted during oral sex have increased significantly in the United States in recent years, researchers reported on Monday.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Stella McCartney
text: “It’s a bit of a battle,” said Pat McGrath backstage at Stella McCartney of making sure that models’ tan bodies match their often paler faces. “We’re warming up with the foundation.” There wasn’t much else required in the way of makeup, save for Covergirl’s Lushberry creme blush, Lash Perfect mascara and some lip balm. “Fresh, beautiful, gorgeous, glowing, young and alive,” is how McGrath sees the Stella girl. “Spontaneous and real,” was Eugene Souleiman’s description of the designer, which he translated as a bun slicked back at the sides with texture on top. To create this look, he separated a horseshoe of hair all around the head, pulling it back tightly into a ponytail polished with a makeup brush coated in Wella hair spray. The crown was then roughed up with a little of Wella’s Refined Texture product. Souleiman explained that sometimes it’s more difficult to come up with a simple look than, say, one that is high concept. That wasn’t an issue today. “With Stella, it just kind of happens,” he said. “You’re never trying too hard.”

headline: With Furtive Steps, Bloomberg Made His Way to Court
text: All along the sidewalk at the Manhattan Criminal Courthouse and lining the hallways outside the 11th-floor courtroom, the news media horde stood waiting: cameras rolling, flashes poised to pop, shoutable questions on the tips of tongues.

headline: N.F.L. Carries NBC in Sunday Night Ratings
text: For one night of the week at least, NBC has little to worry about regarding its broadcast schedule: the National Football League continues to save the network from what has so far been a dismal fall season. The Baltimore Ravens defeated the Jets, 34-17, on “Sunday Night Football” to give NBC a ratings win in all viewership categories. Final audience numbers were not available on Monday afternoon. CBS finished second over all with new episodes of “The Amazing Race” and “The Good Wife,” though the numbers were skewed higher because of N.F.L. coverage overruns across the country. On ABC, “Pan Am” quickly lost altitude; it averaged 7.75 million total viewers in its second week, down more than 3 million from the series premiere.

headline: The Pathological Altruist Gives Till Someone Hurts
text: Some years ago, Dr. Robert A. Burton was the neurologist on call at a San Francisco hospital when a high-profile colleague from the oncology department asked him to perform a spinal tap on an elderly patient with advanced metastatic cancer. The patient had seemed a little fuzzy-headed that morning, and the oncologist wanted to check for meningitis or another infection that might be treatable with antibiotics.

headline: Yahoo Has a Crowd, Wants a Voice
text: One company dominates online news, sports and finance. It has more visitors to its news site than the runner-up in the category, CNN, more in sports than ESPN and more in finance than Dow Jones, owner of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: How to Steer Toward the Path of Least Treatment
text: The first doctor Lynn Munroe consulted about her hyperactive thyroid gland recommended radioactive iodine treatment to destroy the gland, followed by a lifelong regimen of thyroid hormone replacement pills.

headline: Full Tilt Poker’s Acquirer Shows His Cards
text: Online poker is not legal in the United States. But it sure is popular.

headline: Trading With The Enemy
text: Suppose you were going to write a political-thriller potboiler. You might invent something like this: a family of billionaires who support right-wing causes and pose as super-patriots, while actually using their political influence to cover for wrongdoing on multiple fronts — not just endangering workers and the environment, but even making deals with foreign regimes that are actively anti-United States and sponsor terrorists.

headline: Free Trade Standoff Is Resolved
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration moved Monday to complete free trade agreements with South Korea, Colombia and Panama, submitting the deals for Congressional approval after resolving a standoff of months with Republicans over the details of a package both sides said they favored.

headline: Can Answers to Evolution Be Found in Slime?
text: Most of the aliens that come out of Hollywood don’t really look alien at all. They may have pizza-size eyes or roachlike antennae, but their oddities are draped on a familiar humanoid frame.

headline: Beauty and the Blob
text: Photographs of the strangely beautiful plasmodial slime molds called myxomycetes.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Yves Saint Laurent
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Dictyostelium, Connected and Unconnected
text: Two groups of Dictyostelium are colored red and green. On the left, they share the same Velcro-like hooks and merge into the same slug. On the right, they have different ones and sort themselves out.

headline: Wall Street Goes to Sefcon II on Swaps
text: The title of the lead-off panel on Monday at the Sefcon conference, a Wall Street gathering devoted to the relatively obscure world of the swap execution facility, asked a question that most people outside the financial industry would appreciate: “What is a S.E.F. and what is it good for?”

headline: My Three Favorite Musicals
text: My three favorite musicals are not “Cabaret” or “South Pacific” or “Phantom of the Opera.” But instead: “Cowgirls,” “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” and “Into the Woods.” Of the musicals I’ve seen over the last two decades, close to 100, these 3 stood out. I saw each show more than once, bought the cast albums and proceeded to play them over and over and over. “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” and “Cowgirls” each had a lengthy Off Broadway run but never transferred to Broadway. “Into the Woods” won Tony Awards when it was first produced in 1988 and when it was revived in 2002. To get a taste of each show, read about them on the Web sites Musical Heaven and The Guide to Musical Theatre and check out the clips below.

headline: Hoping to Crack Alzheimer’s, Together as a Family
text: For the Betancur family, it was a kind of pilgrimage, an act of faith in science.

headline: Suspect in Post Office Robbery Is Arrested
text: A man wanted in connection with a post office robbery four years ago fired two gunshots Monday morning at deputy United States marshals who had tracked him down to a house in Jamaica, Queens, a spokesman for the United States Marshals Service said.

headline: Autopsies Waning, Except on Television
text: Autopsies are far more common on television than in real life. According to the National Center for Health Statistics, fewer than one in 10 deaths were followed by an autopsy in 2007, compared with one in five in 1972.

headline: Yield Of Dreams (Or Rather Delusions)
text: One principle I like to emphasize is that in times of radical change and stress, analytical economics is more rather than less useful than usual. (Or it is if the economist doing it is really trying to make sense of events rather than fitting everything into his ideological preconceptions.) Why? Because in unusual and stressful situations, experience — the kind of experience business people gather over years in the market –ceases to be a helpful guide, whereas models and deep historical knowledge have at least a hope of getting at what’s really going on.

headline: One Point Seven Six
text: The invisible bond vigilantes continue to lure us into their invisible trap.

headline: For Beckham, Family and Health Are No. 1 and 1A
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — David Beckham may be 36 years old and nearing the end of a storied professional soccer career, but his often intangible appeal is still strong enough to attract interest from Europe.

headline: At Soldier Field, the Faithful Salute Payton
text: At Sunday’s Bears-Panthers game, there were “probably more fans wearing 34s on their backs at Soldier Field than at any point since the mid-80s,” wrote Dan Pompei of The Chicago Tribune. The faithful were making a show of support for Walter Payton, enshrined in the Hall of Fame in 1993, dead of a rare liver disease in 1999 and described as a Vicodin-popping, laughing-gas-inhaling adulterer in a book excerpt published last week.

headline: Wall Street's Long History of Protests
text: If there is a physical place that represents the intersection of democracy and capitalism in America, it is Wall Street. Protest movements have been drawn to it since the founding of the country.

headline: Wall Street’s Long History of Protests
text: If there is a physical place that represents the intersection of democracy and capitalism in America, it is probably in Lower Manhattan at the corner of Wall and Broad. Protest movements have been drawn to Wall Street — both the physical location and the abstract idea — since the founding of the country.

headline: Researchers Devise a Method to Meet the Beetles
text: Ambrosia beetles are hard workers. They spend their lives cultivating their food source, fungi, deep inside trees. But the beetles are just as vigilant about their privacy, which has kept their work and social habits largely a mystery to scientists.

headline: Trial Over Earthquake in Italy Puts Focus on Probability and Panic
text: The manslaughter trial of six seismologists and a government official in the central Italian city of L’Aquila, stemming from what the authorities say was a failure to warn the population before a deadly 2009 earthquake, has outraged many scientists. Thousands have signed petitions protesting the prosecution as anti-science.

headline: An Infection That Produces a Glazed Look
text: Mark Bowden’s “Worm” is about the potentially diabolical piece of computer malware known as Conficker and the efforts of cybersecurity experts to hunt it down. This book is also about its author’s efforts to tell the Conficker story in both technical terms and common parlance. The hype is easy: “Worm” can toss around alarmist terms like “Cybarmageddon” and “digital Pearl Harbor” to convey a sufficient sense of catastrophic threat. But “Worm” also needs chapters with titles like “MS08-067” and “Remote Thread Injection” to explain what the Conficker scare has really been about.

headline: Natural Selection Leaves Fresh Footprints on a Canadian Island

headline: For Giants, the Long View Looks Challenging
text: For as much as players talk about “taking it one day at a time,” they are (generally) not robots. They know which games are when, same as the fans, and even if they don’t mark down the expected wins and losses on a pocket schedule, there is still an awareness of when the team is entering a critical stretch.

headline: An Emotional Volcano With a Cool Exterior
text: Every singer, when confronting the songs of Stephen Sondheim, tends to gravitate toward a particular character, song or mood from the composer’s complex psychological checkerboard. Elaine Stritch pretty much owns “The Ladies Who Lunch,” that sophisticated blast of rage from “Company.” “In Buddy’s Eyes,” from “Follies,” more or less defines Barbara Cook’s wistful, empathetic warmth. And “Move On,” from “Sunday in the Park With George,” distills Bernadette Peters’s vulnerable sweetness.

(Or if you miss the actual event, watch it over and over on YouTube, to see how many people you recognize.)

headline: A Free-Form Festival, Wide Open to Outsiders

headline: As Justices Get Back to Business, Old Pro Reveals Tricks of the Trade
text: WASHINGTON — Justice John Paul Stevens was always courtly, but he could be a little terse and wary in interviews while he was on the Supreme Court. Since his retirement last year, he has shed some of that reticence, and he was in an expansive and reflective mood the other day as he greeted a visitor to his chambers.

headline: Bengali Spoken Here
text: GOOD Bangladeshi cooking is hard to come by in New York. Though “Bangladesh” is stamped on many menus, too often these are passports to food from other parts of the subcontinent. The longtime touchstone, Spicy Mina, in Woodside, Queens, went dark last year, supplanted by a Nepali spot that also turns out pizza.

headline: American Airlines Bankruptcy Fears Drive Down Stock
text: Shares in American Airlines’ parent company tumbled 33 percent on Monday on fears that the airline could be forced into bankruptcy as a slowing economy reduced demand for seats on its planes.

headline: Getting Through the Security Check With a Gun, Sort Of
text: FLYING is just part of everyday life with me. I’m a friendly person, and seatmates seem to like talking to me. Maybe it’s my Southern accent, but sometimes I think it’s because they think I have the greatest job in the world.

headline: A Choreographer Does One Last Swoop in New York
text: When her teacher in Germany recommended that Isabel Gotzkowsky study at Dance Space Center — now called Dance New Amsterdam — she never thought she would end up staying for 23 years. Before becoming a teacher and choreographer, she was one of the organization’s first work-study students. (Her duties included cleaning toilets — a dancer’s life is seldom glamorous.)

headline: Isabel Gotzkowsky’s New York Finale
text: Ms. Gotzkowsky, who is leaving Dance New Amsterdam after 23 years, presents three works including the premieres of “B-Sides” and “Kafka’s Cotillion” and the restaging of “Bound.”

headline: Contraceptive Used in Africa May Double Risk of H.I.V.
text: The most popular contraceptive for women in eastern and southern Africa, a hormone shot given every three months, appears to double the risk the women will become infected with H.I.V., according to a large study published Monday. And when it is used by H.I.V.-positive women, their male partners are twice as likely to become infected than if the women had used no contraception.

headline: Heroic Tale of Holocaust, With a Twist

And: In an attempt to undermine the Food and Drug Administration’s current efforts to rationalize front-of-package labeling, industry groups have devised a new campaign: change “nutrition keys” to “facts up front.” And: Julia Moskin on the new United States Farmers and Ranchers Alliance, a well-funded Big Ag group that is – incredibly — trying to position itself as an underdog in the current food climate. (Apparently it doesn’t like the term “Big Ag,” but when you have $11 million to spend on public relations, and your members include the American Egg Board, the National Milk Producers Federation and the National Pork Board, that’s what you are.)

headline: More On China And Jobs
text: Rob Johnson of INET sends me to an interesting paper by Autor, Dorn and Hanson (pdf) that uses regional data to estimate the impact of China imports on manufacturing employment. The idea is to exploit the major differences among US metro areas in industrial specialization: some areas produce a mix of goods that is in effect in China’s path, while others don’t. The results suggest, as I have been arguing, that it’s wrong to dismiss Chinese exports as not really being in competition with US production.

headline: A Leader’s Death Exposes Disarray in the Afghan Peace Process
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the two weeks since the leader of Afghanistan’s peace process was assassinated, an intense power struggle has opened among the nation’s ethnic groups — and within them — as well as among other powerful factions here, laying bare a crisis that is buffeting President Hamid Karzai from every side.

headline: A Significant Ozone Hole Is Reported Over the Arctic
text: Intense cold in the upper atmosphere of the Arctic last winter activated ozone-depleting chemicals and produced the first significant ozone hole ever recorded over the high northern regions, scientists reported on Monday in the journal Nature.

headline: Debate Poses First Big Test for Newcomer in Senate Bid
text: BOSTON — Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard professor who splashed into the Massachusetts Senate race last month after her stint in Washington as a consumer rights advocate, will face off against her lesser-known Democratic opponents Tuesday in a debate that will be an important early test of her skills as a candidate.

text: Dr. Ralph M. Steinman, a cell biologist who was named one of three winners of the Nobel Prize in Medicine on Monday for his work on the human immune response, died Friday in Manhattan, a fact unknown to the prize committee when it made its announcement. He was 68.

headline: Confident Burnett Puts Uneven Year Behind Him

headline: When Harry Should Avoid Meeting Sally
text: A philosopher I know told me that once, when he was explaining his views on a contested matter to a group of his peers, he was met with this objection: “But that sounds like Stanley Fish.” I would bet that no one else in the room had ever met me and that few if any had ever read me. It is just that for many in his corner of the discipline, “Stanley Fish” is a placeholder for ideas you don’t want to be associated with. Saying of someone that he sounds like Stanley Fish is a quick and easy way of refuting him. You might say that it takes the place of an argument or, perhaps, that it is an argument all by itself and one that can be conveniently made in shorthand. (It’s not quite ad hominem; it’s ad hominem backed up by reasons that don’t even have to be given.)

headline: Report on Medicare Cites Prescription Drug Abuse
text: WASHINGTON — Medicare is subsidizing drug abuse by thousands of beneficiaries who shop around for doctors and fill prescriptions for huge quantities of painkillers and other narcotics far exceeding what any patient could safely use, Congressional investigators say in a new report.

headline: Gibson Has One Game to Put End to Two Slumps
text: PHOENIX — Kirk Gibson’s gimpy trot and slow-motion arm pump as he circled the bases in the 1988 World Series lives as a memorable highlight. As Gibson spoke in defiant tones Monday about the Arizona Diamondbacks’ being on the brink of elimination, he created a flashback of sorts to when he shook off injury and delivered that theatrical game-winning home run.

text: For more than two hours Sunday, viewers in the New York market could choose between watching Game 2 of the Yankees-Tigers league division series and the Giants-Cardinals football game.

That question, or something like it, was being debated before Los Angeles County Superior Court judge Mark V. Mooney on Monday, in a case called Marathon Funding vs. Paramount.

text: PAINT CREEK, Tex. — Millions of large rocks litter the hills and the country roads surrounding a hunting and fishing lodge on a sprawling ranch 17 miles outside this tiny West Texas town. But only one of them required a kind of protective custody on Monday.

text: Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance giant, learned as early as 2003 of extensive foreclosure abuses among the law firms it had hired to remove troubled borrowers from their homes. But the company did little to correct the firms’ practices, according to a report issued Tuesday.

text: “Jaws,” an ode to humans’ fear of the sea, is still a cultural icon. Yet, slowly but surely, cultural attitudes toward sharks are changing, and changing thanks to a genuinely ecological view of their role in the ocean.

Their season-opening four-game stretch, dominated by offensive breakdowns and defensive volatility, has muddled the definition, creating a crisis of identity and personality.

headline: Tuesday: The Champ Turns the Tables
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you have ever been to the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament or seen the documentary “Wordplay,” you know that the stress level and the tension surrounding the finalists going into the championship rounds is almost unbearable. One little mistake, one square left blank, and the battle is lost. You wouldn’t think that a race to finish a crossword puzzle could engender that kind of drama, but it does. And every year, it’s absolutely riveting.

text: Lawyers in a federal lawsuit that has governed how the New York Police Department investigates political and religious groups for more than 25 years asked a judge on Monday to let them collect information to see if the department had violated his orders in how they monitor Muslim communities.

headline: Alabama’s Shame
text: Only about 3.5 percent of Alabama’s population is foreign-born, according to the Census Bureau. Undocumented immigrants made up roughly 4.2 percent of its work force in 2010, according to the Pew Hispanic Center. But the drafters of Alabama’s harsh immigration law wanted to turn their state into the country’s most hostile territory for illegal immigrants. They are succeeding, as many of Alabama’s most vulnerable residents can attest.

headline: Your Soaring Insurance Premiums
text: Annual premiums for employer-sponsored health coverage soared by 9 percent for families and 8 percent for individuals this year from 2010, far faster than wages or inflation. Republicans, predictably, blamed health care reform for contributing to the rise. In fact, the reforms accounted for only 1.5 percentage points of the increase this year. The value to millions of Americans who are already getting expanded coverage and benefits is undeniable.

headline: In Defense of Romney
text: Over the past several months, Mitt Romney has been an excellent presidential candidate. He has performed superbly in the debates. He has outorganized his rivals. He has relentlessly stayed on his core theme of putting Americans back to work. He has taken Rick Perry apart with a cold ruthlessness that is a wonder to behold.

headline: Interim Tunisian Leader With Ties to Old Ruler Defends a Gradual Path
text: TUNIS — As the country that kicked off the Arab Spring prepares for its first free election this month, Tunisia’s transitional prime minister, Beji Caid Essebsi, has some advice for his counterparts in Egypt, Libya or other former Arab autocracies dealing with impatient public demands unleashed by the revolutions.

headline: The Hague: Court Will Investigate War Crimes in Ivory Coast Violence
text: Judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague have given the prosecutor the go-ahead to investigate war crimes in Ivory Coast after the country’s disputed presidential elections last year. The prosecutor has said that both sides in the conflict, the forces backing the ousted leader Laurent Gbagbo and those backing his successor, Alassane Ouattara, had killed civilians and committed other crimes, including rape. Less than a week ago, the new government also formed a Truth and Reconciliation Commission to help establish peace, after the killing of an estimated 3,000 people and the destruction of vast numbers of homes.

headline: What’s Your Economic Outlook?
text: Readers shared their expectations about their job status, the future of the economy and the prospects for the next generation.

headline: Mexico: Severed Heads Found in Capital
text: Two severed heads were found on a busy highway near the Defense Ministry in Mexico City on Monday, a reminder that the capital has not entirely escaped the violence sweeping large parts of the country. One head was found on the hood of a sport utility vehicle and the other near it on a sidewalk, along with a message from a criminal gang known as the Hand With Eyes, claiming Mexico City as its territory. It was unclear whether the heads were intended to send a message to the military, which has been deployed to fight the drug cartels. Very little cartel-related mayhem has been reported in Mexico City, but a decapitated body was found in another part of the city in August.

headline: Lawyer Is Barred From Leaving Iran
text: The Iranian lawyer for two American hikers who were released in September and repatriated after spending more than two years in a Tehran prison on charges of espionage and trespassing has been barred from leaving Iran, he confirmed in a text message. The lawyer, Masoud Shafiei, said authorities had prevented him from boarding an international flight without explanation. His destination was unclear, but the Iranian Student News Agency said he had intended to go to the United States. Last week, security forces raided his home and interrogated him about the Americans, Joshua F. Fattal and Shane M. Bauer, who denounced Iran after they left the country.

headline: Everett Ellin Dies at 82; Helped Computerize Art Catalogs
text: Until the mid-20th century, the world’s greatest artworks were cataloged in shoeboxes. Then along came the computer, and for the first time, museums had a more efficient way to organize their holdings than the boxfuls of dog-eared index cards that had served them for generations.

headline: Emanuel Litvinoff, Poet and Detractor of T. S. Eliot, Dies at 96
text: Emanuel Litvinoff, an English-born Jewish poet known for his scathing verse indictment of T. S. Eliot’s anti-Semitism — and for reading it before an audience that happened to include Eliot — died on Sept. 24 at his home in London. He was 96.

headline: California: Governor Signs Law to Protect Circumcision
text: Male circumcision will remain legal throughout California, after Gov. Jerry Brown signed a bill on Sunday that prevents local governments from banning the practice. The measure was drafted in response to efforts in San Francisco and Santa Monica to outlaw circumcision for any males under 18 years old. In San Francisco, supporters of the ban gathered enough signatures to get an initiative on the ballot in November. In July, a Superior Court judge struck the initiative from the ballot, citing state law concerning medical procedures. Supporters of the Santa Monica circumcision ban failed to get the measure on the ballot. Two State Assembly members introduced legislation to prevent any potential circumcision bans — which Jews and Muslims argued violated their free expression of religion — in any other municipalities.

Chandrasekhar Rao, who had previously gone on a hunger strike in 2009, threatened again to fast to death unless the center came out with a clear-cut announcement mentioning a time frame within which the state of Telangana would be formed. “People are dying every day for the cause of Telangana,” Rao said.Jammu and Kashmir Chief Minister Omar Abdullah on Monday threatened to sue opposition leader Mehbooba Mufti for claiming he was involved in the death of a party worker (Hindustan Times). headline: Tigers’ Verlander Rides His Fastball Past the Yankees

headline: Tyler Hicks: A Decade in Afghanistan
text: OBSERVATION POST TWINS, Afghanistan — There are places and times where the politics that drive wars fade and then fade more, becoming abstractions to the people who fight or who are in a fight’s way. And there are moments when politics entirely disappear, and more elemental actions and emotions replace them.

headline: Should Schools Offer Cash Bonuses for Good Test Scores?
text: As part of the National Math and Science Initiative, some high schools have opened up their Advanced Placement courses to all students, and those who score a 3 or higher on the A.P. exam earn a $100 reward, as do their teachers. What do you think of financial incentives to perform well in school? Would you study harder if there were a cash bonus attached to a good grade?

headline: As Amanda Knox Heads Home, the Debate Is Just Getting Started
text: ROME — At least one thing was clear Tuesday as Amanda Knox headed home to the United States after an Italian court threw out the convictions of Ms. Knox and Raffaele Sollecito, a former boyfriend, in the 2007 murder of her housemate in Perugia. The case had lost none of its power to polarize.

headline: Prague Synagogue Hosts Show on the City’s Jewish Community
text: A new permanent exhibition chronicling the elusive history of Prague’s Jewish community, from the end of World War II until now, recently opened in an appropriate venue: the city’s ornate Jubilee Synagogue (Jeruzalemska 7).

headline: The Early Word: Waning
text: Today’s Times

headline: Misrepresentations, Regulations and Jobs
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

headline: In Massachusetts, a Hoarder With Discriminating Tastes
text: For last weekend’s Auto Ego article, Charles Gould, a lawyer in Newton, Mass., gave me a tour of his collection of more than 100 cars, trucks and motorcycles.

headline: Q&A: Sorting Subscriptions in Facebook
text: Q.

headline: Looking for the “Big Taste” of Bengal
text: Sleepy, slow Kolkata comes to life in the 10 days of Durga Puja, or simply Pujo, the festival celebrating the Hindu goddess Durga’s slaying of the demon Mahishasur, which started this year on Sept. 27.

headline: Dalai Lama’s Visa Request Is Denied by South Africa
text: NEW DELHI — The Dalai Lama, Tibet’s exiled spiritual leader, scrapped plans on Tuesday to attend the 80th birthday celebration of a fellow Nobel laureate, Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa, after the host government did not grant his visa request.

headline: High School Entrepreneurs Promise to Save Millions for Schools
text: Founded in January, TruantToday is a messaging service that alerts parents instantly via text and e-mail message when students cut class. The goal? Reducing truancy and restoring state and federal financing to school districts, which can lose as much as $50 each day that a student is missing.

headline: France and Belgium to Guarantee Dexia
text: PARIS — France and Belgium moved on Tuesday to shore up Dexia as fears increased that the bank’s exposure to Greek sovereign debt could lead to its collapse.

headline: An Interview With Clare Waight Keller
text: Suzy Menkes, fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune, speaks with the designer Clare Waight Keller about important inspirations in her first collection for Chloé.

headline: A New Standard for Carbon Footprints
text: In an article in Tuesday’s Times, I write about new protocols that have been developed to help companies measure their greenhouse gas emissions. The goal is to guide them in tallying emissions across the entire life cycle of a product and the value chain of a corporation. (That’s company-speak for the emissions resulting from gathering the raw materials for the product, using the product and eventually disposing of it.)

headline: Truck Bomb Kills Dozens in Somalia’s Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — This particular area of Mogadishu was supposed to be safe, a highly fortified government compound in one of the few neighborhoods that Somalia’s transitional government actually controls.

headline: Deutsche Bank to Miss Profit Goal
text: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest lender, joined a growing list of banks buffeted by the sovereign debt crisis on Tuesday, saying it would not meet its 2011 profit target owing to investor uncertainty and a loss from its Greek bond holdings.

headline: Slain Student’s Family Hopes Facts Will Emerge
text: PERUGIA, Italy — One day after an Italian appeals court overturned the conviction of Amanda Knox, one of three people convicted in the 2007 murder of 21-year-old Meredith Kercher, members of Ms. Kercher’s family said on Tuesday that they still hoped that the facts about her death would emerge.

headline: In Deal With Ford, Union Wins Wage Increases and Additional Jobs
text: DETROIT — After winning promises of thousands of new jobs and bonuses for active workers at the Ford Motor Company, the United Automobile Workers union now turns to Chrysler to wrap up its epic contract talks with Detroit’s major automakers.

headline: Christie Faces Conservative Criticism as He Decides on Run
text: As Chris Christie makes up his mind about whether to run for president, he is no doubt listening to the effusive praise from donors and activists and leading Republicans.

headline: Different but Brilliant: Wes Welker and Calvin Johnson
text: There may not be two more distinctly different players in the league, but somehow, they play the same position.

headline: Back at Home, a Marine Must Battle His Injuries
text: Unlike earlier generations of injured veterans, American soldiers who have been wounded in Iraq or Afghanistan have received quite a bit of attention. In print and on television the accounts of their attempts to recover from lost limbs and head trauma have been told and retold, accompanied by images that were startling at first but are less so now. Even “Dolphin Tale,” a film aimed at young children, has a subplot involving wartime injuries.

headline: Yves Saint Laurent: Being a Spectator
text: In all of Stefano Pilati’s collections for Yves Saint Laurent there are characters who, in ruffles and Belle de Jour uptightness, come close to representing the YSL woman, yet never quite nail her. Mr. Pilati has done some interesting collections, one or two genuinely weird ones, and some that qualified as modern. That’s not such a bad track record in seven years, but unfortunately Mr. Pilati is stuck with a label that in public perception is somewhere between a tasty bonbon and a hallowed shrine.

headline: Cooling Problem Shuts Nuclear Reactor in Japan
text: TOKYO — In a fresh blow to public confidence, a reactor in southern Japan went into automatic shutdown on Tuesday because of problems with its cooling system, clouding the outlook for an imminent restart of the country’s idled nuclear plants.

headline: Immigrants Play Key Role as City Entrepreneurs, Study Finds
text: Any taxi-riding, bodega-shopping, laundromat-using New Yorker knows that immigrants own many of the businesses that make New York tick. Now a new study shows that while immigrants constitute just over a third of the city’s population, they make up nearly half of the city’s small-business owners.

headline: Studies of Universe’s Expansion Win Physics Nobel
text: Three astronomers won the Nobel Prize in Physics on Tuesday for discovering that the universe is apparently being blown apart by a mysterious force that cosmologists now call dark energy, a finding that has thrown the fate of the universe and indeed the nature of physics into doubt.

headline: Romney Plans Foreign Policy Speech
text: Mitt Romney will deliver a foreign policy speech on Friday in Charleston, S.C., he announced Monday afternoon on Sean Hannity’s radio show.

headline: Like Putin, Like Bloomberg
text: Political ploys under way in Russia could almost serve as an instruction manual for the leadership at either end of New York’s City Hall. You have to slap your forehead in wonder that the New Yorkers didn’t think up comparable high jinks for themselves.

headline: Why Atheists Need Fundamentalists
text: I’ve written before about the interesting symbiosis that exists between militant atheism and religious fundamentalism — the way the Richard Dawkinses of the world are always eager to insist that a cartoonish figure like Pat Robertson represents the truest form of Christian faith, and that any believer who disagrees with Robertson’s pronouncements on Haiti or Hurricane Katrina obviously doesn’t understand his own religion.

headline: Promoting More Visits Between Korea and New York
text: Hoping to increase the number of visitors to New York City during the usually slow period after the December holidays, the city’s tourism agency announced a partnership with the city of Seoul and Korean Air on Tuesday.

headline: Thailand in Technicolor
text: Officially, the designer Thakoon Panichgul (above left), of Thakoon, is an adviser to Thailand’s ministry of commerce. But this summer he put business aside and spent two weeks looking for inspiration in the country’s northern mountain villages near Chiang Mai. He found it in the bright, hand-woven and embroidered silk and cotton ikats of the Karen and Lua tribes — a vibrant palette similar to the saturated red, turquoise, mustard and pink yarns in his recent spring collection. “There is something so special about these communities of grandmothers,” Panichgul says. “It’s really a dying art. Each tribe’s ikat pattern is based on memory.”

headline: Geoengineering? Time to Wake Up, Panel Warns
text: With political action on curbing greenhouse gases stalled in Congress, Cornelia Dean reports that a panel is recommending that the government begin researching the possibility of directly manipulating the Earth’s climate to lower the temperature. The Bipartisan Policy Center, which created the panel, plans a webcast discussion on the idea at 10 E.D.T. on Tuesday.

headline: This Just In: Study Shows Songs About Sex Are Hot Sellers
text: Psychologists sometimes have a way of proving what you always suspected was true. A recent study of popular song lyrics done at the State University of New York in Albany shows not only that messages about sexual relationships dominate the songs at the top of the charts, but also that songs about sex sell better than other songs.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Using the Net Wisely in a Health Crisis
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Stocks Rally After Report Europe Might Recapitalize Banks
text: A late frenzy on Wall Street led stocks to a sharp increase on Tuesday, even as fears over a major banking crisis in Europe mounted along with expectations that Greece could soon default on its debt.

headline: Christie to Make 1 P.M. Announcement
text: Chris Christie, the Republican governor of New Jersey, has scheduled a 1 p.m. news conference for Tuesday afternoon in Trenton to announce his decision about a possible presidential run.

headline: From Hibbing, Minn., a Plea for Planes to Keep Flying
text: Delta Airlines recently announced that it would probably drop or reduce commercial air service to 24 smaller cities in the United States because the flights are often half-full — or even less — and lose millions of dollars a year. Delta, under an agreement with the federal government, is the only carrier to serve the cities, which rely on the flights to stay connected to the rest of the country. Without the service, they fear isolation, and in some cases, economic calamity. Butte, Mont.; Muscle Shoals, Ala.; Waterloo, Iowa; Pierre, S.D.; Greenville and Tupelo, Miss.; Sault Sainte Marie, Mich.; and Hibbing, Minn., are among the cities where the flights are threatened. Residents of Hibbing, population 16,000, and the heart of Minnesota’s Iron Range — where iron-ore mining is the predominant industry — are particularly concerned. The city’s mayor, Rick Cannata, and Patty Shafer, a city councilor, discuss:

headline: Doctors Grow Wary of Avastin for Eye Treatment
text: Dr. Robert Feig, a retina specialist in Brooklyn and the Bronx, says he wants to save patients and Medicare money by treating eye diseases with a drug that costs $50 a dose, rather than one that costs $2,000 a dose.

headline: Queen of the Football Field
text: Four decades ago the federal education law called Title IX opened the door for girls to participate in high school and college athletics. But even the creators of that landmark legislation probably didn’t imagine the homecoming queen kicking the winning field goal.

headline: Morning T | Michel Gaubert
text: T’s Online Editor Jane Herman talks to the sound illustrator Michel Gaubert about soundtracking fashion shows, finding music to match the height of a heel and why he’s always wearing sunglasses.

headline: A Strange Lesson From Renaissance Learning
text: Something weird is happening in Wisconsin.

headline: Q&A: An Autumn Trip to Edinburgh
text: My sister, 82, and I, 65, are visiting Edinburgh in late October to visit her granddaughter who is studying at the university. We have visited before and have seen the major sights. Can you give suggestions for off-the-beaten-track treasures and treks? We both love history and share the maiden name of Duncan — so anything that links us to the “homeland” is a lure. We recognize the weather will probably be challenging, but we are intrepid!

headline: Oct. 4, 1957 | Soviet Union Launches Sputnik Satellite
text: On Oct. 4, 1957, the Soviet Union put the first artificial satellite, Sputnik I, into the Earth’s orbit, signifying the birth of the Space Age. The spherical satellite, which was about the size of a beach ball and weighed 184 pounds, was able to orbit the Earth in 98 minutes.

headline: Leading Off: Panic in Yankeeland
text: For those outside the greater New York and Boston rooting areas, the past week has been an extended festival of great amusement. First, we got to watch an overflow of Red Sox panic, which is unlike any other kind of panic in its gloom and reverberating echoes of Bill Buckner, and now we get full-on Yankees panic. Just a week after they seemed to rule the universe as the Red Sox suffered through their epic collapse, the Yankees are down, two games to one, to the plucky Tigers and facing an elimination game pitched by — and here’s where the real panic comes in — A.J. Burnett.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Sigrid Agren at YSL
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Sigrid Agren from Ford Model Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: The Reader’s Lament
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Gurgling Cod: The “fautisanal” trend in food gets a dressing down. — Julia Moskin

headline: Some Loans Go Bad; Others Just Fade Away
text: As my colleague Eric Lipton and I report in Tuesday’s paper, the Obama administration was divided early on over the loan guarantee to Solyndra, the solar equipment manufacturer that took $528 million in federal money before it filed for bankruptcy in September.

headline: The NFL Network and Time Warner Continue to Spar
text: Karen Waldkirch, a freelance writer in Wauwatosa, Wis., owns shares in the Green Bay Packers and buys season tickets to their games at Lambeau Field.

headline: Wheelies: The Fraternité Edition
text: 1:06 p.m. | Updated

headline: Galaxy Visit Red Bulls Looking to Clinch Top Record
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — A flash of brilliance by Thierry Henry on Saturday night in Toronto did not save the Red Bulls’ season as much as preserve it for yet another must-win game.

headline: Brother of Jailed Chinese Dissident Reports Prison Visit
text: BEIJING — Three brothers of Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned dissident writer who was given the Nobel Peace Prize last year, were allowed to visit him in a prison in northeast China on Sept. 28, one of the brothers told Agence France-Presse on Tuesday.

headline: Transcript of Bloomberg’s Testimony at the Haggerty Trial
text: The testimony provided by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at the trial of a political consultant, John F. Haggerty Jr..

headline: ‘Now Is Not My Time’ to Run, Christie Says
text: 1:30 p.m. | Updated Saying “now is not my time,” Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced on Tuesday that he would not seek the Republican nomination for the presidency.

headline: Morning T | Michel Gaubert
text: The sound illustrator Michel Gaubert on how he finds an apt soundtrack for fashion shows.
