headline: Bernanke Urges Obama and Congress to Do More for Economy
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, told a Congressional committee Tuesday that lawmakers and the Obama administration should do more to increase economic growth.

headline: Reviewing Neerob
text: Lately, lovers of Bangladeshi cuisine, which hums with a vibrant undercurrent of mustard oil, have been trekking to a modest restaurant in the Parkchester neighborhood of the Bronx. Bengali is the lingua franca at Neerob, the subject of this week’s $25 and Under column, but English is a viable fallback. It’s essential, though, to bring along an adventurous attitude, and it wouldn’t hurt to like fish.

headline: A Film’s Clear-Eyed Look at the War in Afghanistan
text: “Hell and Back Again,” a visceral documentary by Danfung Dennis about the war in Afghanistan, opens in Manhattan on Wednesday. In his review for The New York Times, Neil Genzlinger writes that the film’s “unvarnished and ambiguous” nature makes it more disturbing than some of the more prepackaged and sanitized efforts to relay the graphic realities of war.

headline: In Europe, Signs of 2nd Recession With Wide Reach
text: PARIS — The European debt problems that have roiled global financial markets for the last 18 months are showing signs of turning into a far deeper challenge: Europe’s second recession in three years.

headline: Chopping Down Trees to Save Forests
text: Jim Pitts stood on a Forest Service road near the Arizona town of Nutrioso and surveyed the damage in the valley below. It was July, and only a few weeks earlier the Wallow Fire, the largest in recorded history in Arizona, had swept through this section of steep slopes and tightly packed trees.

headline: DJ Shadow Talks About His Latest Sonic Collages
text: DJ Shadow has lived for 15 years in the shadow of his own success. The San Francisco disc jockey has put out just three full-length albums since the critically acclaimed “Endtroducing” in 1996, which helped define the then cutting-edge genre of instrumental hip-hop: dance music with symphonic sweep built from scores of samples dug out of eclectic and often obscure recordings.

headline: Runway In Review
text: ChloéDesigner: Clare Waight KellerDate and Location: Monday, Oct. 3, Espace Ephemere Tuileries, Jardin Des Tuileries, 1erPhotos: slide show

headline: Nick Brandt’s African Vistas
text: Brandt’s Portraits of Wildlife and Landscapes in Africa

headline: Broadway State of Mind: Alicia Keys to Compose Music for ‘Stick Fly’
text: When Alicia Keys goes Broadway, she really goes Broadway. Over the summer it was announced that Ms. Keys, the pop-R&B singer and “Empire State of Mind” vocalist, would be a producer of the coming Broadway play of “Stick Fly,” Lydia R. Diamond‘s drama about a well-to-do black family on Martha’s Vineyard.

headline: Loving Your Child’s Differences
text: As a new mother I somehow assumed I knew every thought my son had. Then he started to develop opinions of his own.

headline: Apple Unveils iPhone 4S With Voice-Recognition Features
text: Tech journalists descended upon Apple’s headquarters in Cupertino, Calif., on Tuesday for some iPhone-related announcements. Our updates from the event are below, with the most recent at the top.

headline: This Little Pinkie
text: Once confined to a fat cat’s finger, today’s pinkie rings are dainty, pretty and made for a lady. See more >>

headline: Open Cup Final: Seattle vs. Chicago
text: One of the oldest athletic competitions in the United States is also one of the most obscure and ignored.

headline: City Agencies Are Told to Cut Costs by $2 Billion
text: Citing a grim economic outlook and dimming prospects for state and federal aid, the Bloomberg administration on Tuesday asked city agencies to pare $2 billion from their budgets over the next 18 months.

headline: They Said It Had Good Bones
text: If you like the jar with the baby’s leg, wait until you see the jar holding the baby’s head. If one actress with Down syndrome doesn’t provide enough Tod Browning-style otherness for you, don’t worry — there are two. If the line about snorting cocaine off a high school girl’s nipples doesn’t do it for you, maybe the scene of the sobbing naked man masturbating will.

headline: Puerto Rico Prodded to Get Tough on Police
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The discrepancies in the Puerto Rico police logs were hard to miss. Burglaries, including stolen plasma televisions and jewelry, were coded as mere breaking and entering. Large-scale thefts of telephone company cables were labeled property damage.

headline: Obama Campaign Takes Jobs Fight to Twitter
text: President Obama‘s campaign is trying to harness the power of Twitter to put pressure on Republican lawmakers to pass his jobs bill, according to a campaign official.

headline: South Bronx Rising
text: The South Bronx is being revitalized. Michael Kimmelman, the architecture critic of The New York Times, tours the area with Amanda Burden, the director of the department of city planning.

headline: At Chanel, Everything but a Mermaid
text: Chanel transformed the Grand Palais on Tuesday into an all-white seafloor, with pebbles, giant stingrays, coral reefs and the singer Florence Welch emerging from a clamshell to sing us a song. But, as Karl Lagerfeld said, volubly pleased with himself, “no mermaids.”

headline: Democrat Wins West Virginia Governor’s Race
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin, a Democrat, narrowly won a special election for governor on Tuesday, successfully defending himself against Republican attacks that tried to link him withPresident Obama and his health care overhaul.

headline: Christie Decides Against Presidential Bid
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has decided not to seek the presidency, citing a promise he made to his state’s voters when he took office 20 months ago to “fix a broken New Jersey.” The decision ends a late flurry of indecision on the part of Mr. Christie, who had been encouraged by a growing number of Republican donors and activists who hoped he join the field of candidates vying to challenge President Obama. Read (and comment on) the full story on The Caucus.

headline: Another View: Bernanke Ups the Ante
text: Mark Spitznagel is the founder and chief investment officer of Universa Investments, a hedge fund based in Santa Monica, Calif.

text: TOP STORIES

headline: For the Long Brothers, a Shared Passion for Wheeled Speed
text: Patrick Long, the American Le Mans Series GT2 driver, and his younger brother Kevin Long, a professional skateboarder, are elite competitors in their respective wheeled pursuits.

headline: U.S. Senate’s Bill on Tariffs Angers China
text: China expressed strong objections on Tuesday to a bill in the United States Senate that would threaten higher tariffs on some Chinese goods in response to what the bill’s sponsors call China’s policy of keeping its currency artificially depressed to give its exports a price advantage.

text: Reviewing Tertulia

headline: The Frugal Traveler in Litchfield County, Conn.
text: Watching the season change in Litchfield County’s small towns doesn’t have to break the bank.

headline: Turkey Detains 140 in Inquiry on Kurds
text: ISTANBUL — The Turkish police detained more than 140 pro-Kurdish political activists in a nationwide sweep on Tuesday, including a number of elected mayors in Turkey’s predominantly Kurdish southeast.

headline: The Neon Lights Are Bright on Proskauer
text: Superlatives abound at New York’s corporate law firms.

headline: Another Immigration Misconception
text: Yesterday I addressed three misconceptions swirling around immigration and the latest story in our series, Immigration Upended, but one question seems to keep arriving in my inbox and Twitter feed: Why not just go after employers? If businesses can be regulated and punished into keeping their payrolls free of illegal immigrants, wouldn’t that solve the illegal immigration problem?

headline: Redfin Backs Off Some Agent Home-Sales Data
text: Just days after it introduced a tool that lets users search for real-estate agents by name and view their home-selling success statistics, the Web site Redfin backed out of some markets, after getting complaints from local multiple listing services about the use of some data.

headline: Litchfield County, Easy on the Wallet
text: A J’s Steak and Pizza might be intimidating, I was told — kind of a bikers’ bar. But the burgers were cheap and good, the peanuts were free, the place was still open and it was right down the road from the room where I had just dropped my bags.

headline: Bank of America Web Site Still Troubled
text: 3:01 p.m. 10/5/11 | Updated  with bank’s statement.

headline: A Gun, ‘Don’t Look at My Face,’ and Then They Hit the Safe
text: Before he could react, George Bardwil had a gun pointed in his face.

headline: A Threat of Recession in Europe
text: Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain are already in downturns or fighting to escape them, as high unemployment and austerity measures hit. And now, Germany and France, the Continent’s powerhouses, have also started to falter as banks tighten lending and business activity slows.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Chloé
text: Kava Gorna’s Paris fashion week photo diary.

headline: Milestones: Solyndra’s Meltdown
text: In August 2011, after receiving over $500 million in federal loan guarantees, Solyndra, a solar panel manufacturer, declared bankruptcy. The company’s collapse has renewed the debate in Washington over the stimulus program and clean energy subsidies.

headline: Propane Powers Patrol Cars in North Carolina
text: Thanks in part to confiscated drug money, criminals in Iredell County, N.C., may catch a ride in a patrol car powered by liquid propane.

headline: National Spotlight on Christie Misses a State Full of Troubles
text: TRENTON — New Jersey’s Big Man has peered into the right-wing abyss that is the Republican presidential primary and stepped away.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct.4
text: A view of the day in sports includes polo on the beach and an interesting method for powering a long boat at a traditional rowing contest.

headline: NBC Replaces ‘Playboy Club’ with ‘Rock Center’
text: NBC, reacting quickly to the collapse of its Monday night drama, “The Playboy Club,” announced a series of programming moves Tuesday, led by the cancellation of that 10 p.m. show and the addition of a newsmagazine hosted by its main news anchor, Brian Williams.

headline: With Christie Out, Republican Race Begins for Real
text: WASHINGTON — Memorandum to Republican activists, voters and donors: Your presidential field is set. It’s time to start sizing up the candidates, learning to love at least one of them and preparing to head toward the voting booth.

headline: Slow Days at Wagawaga
text: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

headline: Packers? Patriots? How About Madonna as a Super Bowl Contender?
text: Madonna and the National Football League are discussing a deal under which the pop diva would perform at halftime during the Super Bowl in February, but the details have yet to be ironed out, a person familiar with the talks said.

headline: Clifford Olson, Canadian Serial Killer, Is Dead at 71
text: When the Canadian police began connecting the dots in a series of child abductions and torture-murders in the summer of 1981, Clifford Olson, a career criminal with a history of sexual assaults, was placed on a list of potential suspects. It was a good hunch, as it turned out.

headline: Asked & Answered | Johnny Wujek
text: Johnny Wujek is one of a new breed of stylists who are becoming as well known as their celebrity clients — in his case the pop star Katy Perry. Since the early “I Kissed a Girl” days, Wujek has been pulling the strings behind Perry’s playful and sexually provocative image, including the cupcake bras and whipped cream bikini for the Candy Land-themed “California Gurls” video. “It’s all part of being a pop star,” says Wujek when asked whether he feels Perry’s look is appropriate for a younger audience. “Just look at Madonna, Prince or Michael Jackson, who all have had such emblematic and often controversial styles.”

headline: Los Angeles Orchestra to Lead Youth Effort
text: The Los Angeles Philharmonic has seized the initiative in guiding a national teaching program based on El Sistema, the Venezuelan-based movement that weds music teaching and social work. The orchestra announced on Tuesday that it would open an office, host yearly conferences and support a training program to sustain the effort.

headline: Opting Out of Race, Christie Says, ‘Now Is Not My Time’
text: After a kinetic month in which some of the biggest names in American industry and Republican politics urged him to run for president, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spent a quiet weekend at home, coming to a sobering conclusion on Tuesday: “Now is not my time.”

headline: Disappointing Songwriters, Supreme Court Rejects Music Appeal
text: In a victory for online music companies, the Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an appeal in a case that could have resulted in increased royalties for digital music. The decision let stand a lower court’s ruling that downloading a song does not constitute a “public performance” of it, clarifying a technical but important distinction about the way songwriters and music publishers are paid.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Human Rights Since 9/11
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nick Brandt Redo
text: Nick Brandt Redo

headline: Losing the Family Car
text: One of the more memorable posts on Motherlode was Corbyn Hanson Hightower’s account of dumpster diving to feed her family. What struck so many of you were not the facts of her life — losing a six-figure job, running through her savings, supporting her family by cleaning houses and finding food where she could. What most of you talked about was her tone, her spirit, as she described that fall. She had no apologies for her missteps, and she was determined that in spite of her current straits, that she eat well. Is organic food, you wondered, an entitlement? Is it worth slogging through the trash?

headline: Dispute Over ‘Simpsons’ Actors’ Salaries Could Halt Series
text: As “The Simpsons” character Troy McClure once asked about that popular Fox cartoon family, “Who knows what adventures they’ll have between now and the time the show becomes unprofitable?”

headline: Networks Joust for Ratings Title on Mondays
text: A role reversal is taking place between ABC and CBS on Monday nights that is most certain to have some longtime industry observers doing a double take.

headline: IPhone Gets Its Upgrade, All Under the Hood
text: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple introduced its long-awaited new iPhone on Tuesday. But it wasn’t an iPhone 5. That will have to wait.

text: 8:23 p.m. | Updated

headline: Britain and European Union Agree on Regulating Derivatives Trades

headline: To Spain, by Way of the World
text: SEAMUS MULLEN, a bearish young Vermont-raised chef with a sleeve of tattoos, was standing in the back of Tertulia last week, smiling damply in the heat and smoke of his open kitchen, as a wood fire crackled beside him and waiters in handsome plaid shirts dodged this way and that.

headline: Rangers Waive an Agitator Who Stirred Up Opponents and Headlines
text: The latest chapter for one of New York’s most colorful and controversial professional athletes may have ended Tuesday when the Rangers placedSean Avery on waivers.

headline: Reviewing Tertulia
text: This week’s restaurant review  took me to Tertulia, the chef Seamus Mullen’s new Spanish gastropub in the West Village. Have you been? An acquaintance of mine compared the experience to that of a sports bar serving excellent chicken wings, and declared it useless for all those over the age of 45.

headline: A Threat of Recession in Europe
text: Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain are already in downturns or fighting to escape them, as high unemployment and austerity measures hit. And now, Germany and France, the Continent’s powerhouses, have also started to falter as banks tighten lending and business activity slows.

headline: Identity Theft Site Aims to Sort Through Hype
text: Identity theft is an anxiety-provoking topic, and one that seems to spawn a lot of hype and misinformation. To help both consumers and businesses sort out fact from fiction, the Consumer Federation of America has opened a new Web site, idtheftinfo.org.

headline: The N.R.C. Goes Social
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission established a YouTube channel  last month. It has a Twitter account, @NRCgov, and since January it has had a blog. On Tuesday it took the next step: the chairman, Gregory B. Jaczko, hosted an online session with more than 50 bloggers, most of them pro-nuclear. He is supposed to do it again on Thursday, with anti-nuclear bloggers.

headline: Illinois Democrat to Step Down in 2013
text: Representative Jerry F. Costello, Democrat of Illinois, announced Tuesday that he would step down at the end of his term in 2013.

headline: Mets to Reduce Season-Ticket Prices for 2012
text: In the wake of another sizable drop in attendance, the Mets have announced that they were again cutting ticket prices.

headline: House Approves Spending Bill Passed by Senate, and Government Shutdown Is Averted
text: WASHINGTON — With limited discussion and zero fanfare, the House on Tuesday approved and sent to President Obama a measure to keep the government operating through mid-November, ending for now the threat of any shutdown.

headline: Trial Opens for 7 Kosovars in Organ-Trafficking Case
text: PRISTINA, KOSOVO — The trial of seven Kosovars accused of participating in an international organ trafficking ring opened here Tuesday.

headline: Film Festival | Documentaries for Hispanic Heritage Month
text: Five documentary films for marking National Hispanic Heritage Month.

headline: La Russa Is Fined for Criticism of Umpire
text: ST. LOUIS — Cardinals Manager Tony La Russa, who was fined an undisclosed amount by Major League Baseball for criticizing an umpire during a live interview on national television, offered some words of contrition before Game 3 of the team’s National League division series Tuesday.

headline: How Bondholders Would Fare in a Countrywide Bankruptcy
text: Over the past weeks, it has become quite common to speculate that Bank of America might solve its “Countrywide problem” by putting the mortgage unit into bankruptcy to escape some liabilities and litigation losses. Bloomberg News has reported on the idea, and so has Dealbook’s Deal Professor.

headline: Live Blog: Woman Dies in Helicopter Crash in East River
text: A helicopter crashed into the East River off 34th Street at 3:22 p.m. on Tuesday, killing a woman passenger and injuring three other passengers, at least one of them critically, the authorities said. The pilot escaped unharmed.

headline: Exit Christie
text: Though I urged the New Jersey governor to consider running for president and liked his chances if he did, I can understand why Chris Christie has decided against a bid. The hour is late, the hurdles are significant, and if his candidacy crashed and burned Christie would have probably thrown away his still-young political career — and with it, his ability to fundamentally reform a long-misgoverned state. As Reihan Salam put it the other day, “New Jersey needs its governor,” and a Republican Party that believes in the importance of federalism shouldn’t necessarily be in the business of promoting its most successful state officials to the national level before their statehouse work has come to fruition. (See Palin, Sarah, for a cautionary tale on that front.)

headline: Afghanistan Favors India and Denigrates Pakistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Fuming over what they have called the Pakistani role in exporting terrorism across the border, Afghan officials signaled on Tuesday that they had little interest, for now, in healing a rift with Pakistan, their eastern neighbor.

headline: More Disney Characters to Resurface in 3-D
text: Nemo, Sulley and Ariel are being converted into 3-D and dispatched to multiplexes as Disney seeks to squeeze new profits from its old animated films.

headline: Kelly, the Tigers’ Mr. Fix-It, Shows his Versatility
text: DETROIT — The Detroit Tigers’ Don Kelly is prepared for almost anything, and everything, that could happen during a game.

headline: Fiscal and Political Shifts Cloud Stadium Push
text: ARDEN HILLS, Minn. — For decades, N.F.L. teams, including those in Arizona, Ohio and Texas, have persuaded taxpayers to help them cover most of the costs of their new stadiums. The Minnesota Vikings, whose roof on their current home, the Metrodome, collapsed spectacularly last winter, are no different.

headline: No Sheen, No Problem for ‘Two and a Half Men’
text: While the initial curiosity behind a Charlie Sheen-less “Two and a Half Men” seems to be fading, the CBS comedy was still able to reach 17.3 million viewers on Monday night, narrowly beating ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” (16.5 million) as the most-watched program. On Fox, “Terra Nova” retained 100 percent of its premiere 18-to-49-year-old audience, a fantastic sign for the expensive sci-fi program. Meanwhile, the fall season had its first network casualty on Tuesday when NBC announced that it had canceled “The Playboy Club” after its third episode fell to just 3.4 million viewers.

headline: The Lowdown | Curtis Kulig
text: There is not a place on earth that Curtis Kulig doesn’t have friends. In the darkest little dive bars in Tokyo, there is evidence that he has been there. In alleyways in Los Angeles that no one ventures down and high up above the rooftops in New York, his mark winks at you familiarly — his mark being the omnipresent two word cursive tag “Love Me” that litters metropolitan downtowns the world over in spray paint and endless stickers. A photographer turned graffiti artist, Kulig is SoHo’s most unexpected nice guy. Known as equally for his sweet demeanor as for his public cry for affection (which he’s had to tone down lately), Kulig has successfully gone legit with commercial commissions like billboards for the makeup brand Bobbi Brown. This month, Kulig is trying his hand at fine art, with the opening of his first two-man show in New York, with the Los Angeles graffiti artist Skullphone.

headline: Backup Catchers, a Scary Fountain, and the Story of Tony Plush
text: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. He vows to keep Phillies homerism to a minimum.

headline: Spanning the Years in One Evening of Jazz
text: During one inspired stretch of her casually luxurious concert at the Rose Theater on Friday night, Cassandra Wilson sang material from her oldest and most recent Blue Note albums, released 17 years apart. A few of these were original songs, full of spirit talk and churning, viscous grooves. One was an adaptation of Charley Patton’s “Pony Blues,” soulful and self-assured. There was no demarcation between old and new, no sense of shifting gears. Ms. Wilson presented the songs as points in a continuum, scenes in a story yet unfinished, and maybe unfinishable.

headline: A Medical Metaphor for Climate Risk, Including the Risk of Overreaction
text: Paul C. Stern, the director of the National Research Council committee on the human dimensions of global change, has been involved in a decades-long string of studies of behavior, climate change and energy choices.

headline: Another Federal Judge Takes the S.E.C. to Task
text: An unusually hostile ruling emerged from a Manhattan courtroom last week, when a federal judge lashed out at the Securities and Exchange Commission for weak oversight. It was unusual, only because its author was not Judge Jed S. Rakoff.

headline: Festival of Rock Posters
text: A series of rock posters will be on display in San Francisco.

headline: TimesCast | October 4, 2011
text: A truck bomb kills dozens in Somalia's capital; American astronomers win the Nobel Prize in physics; and Apple announces its latest iPhone.

headline: Brooklyn Fare and Eleven Madison Park Get Three Michelin Stars
text: The tally of restaurants in New York City with three Michelin stars has risen to seven from five in the company’s 2012 Guide, which goes on sale Wednesday. Chef’s Table at Brooklyn Fare, which had two stars last year, and Eleven Madison Park, which had one, now have three, joining Daniel, Jean Georges, Le Bernardin, Masa and Per Se.

headline: Joël Robuchon Is Stephen Hanson’s ‘Japanese’ Consultant for Kibo
text: Joël Robuchon, the renowned French chef, is the consultant for Kibo, the first Japanese restaurant from Stephen Hanson’s BR Guest restaurant group. That may seem like an unusual choice, but Mr. Robuchon does have a Japanese restaurant in Monaco, Yoshi, with a Michelin star.

headline: Borodin Glows in an Intimate Salon
text: One of the sunniest pieces of classical music ever written, Borodin’s String Quartet No. 2, which the composer dedicated to his wife of 20 years, seems to imply that all is well with the world. The third-movement Notturno, which furnished the melody of the song “And This Is My Beloved” in the Borodin-drenched musical “Kismet,” is particularly dewy.

headline: Artists Painted With a Palette of Words
text: Calvin Tomkins, who has chronicled the lives of artists for The New Yorker for half a century, has somehow managed to escape the ritual of interrogation to which he has subjected everyone from Andy Warhol on down. One recent afternoon, sitting at a glass-topped table in his brightly minimalist apartment on the Upper East Side, he mentioned that he had never been profiled and is probably resistant to self-scrutiny.

headline: Trisha Brown to Receive ‘Bessie’ Lifetime Achievement Award
text: Trisha Brown, the modern dance choreographer, is to receive a “Bessie” award for lifetime achievement, the selection committee for the awards announced Tuesday. The Bessies, formally known as the New York Dance and Performance awards, and established in 1983 are named for the dance educator and mentor Bessie Schonberg.

headline: Meyer Intends to Sell Eleven Madison Park to Its Chef and Manager
text: It may be the first time a foreword to a cookbook has confirmed hot restaurant news.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Somalia, the Philippines, Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Chanel
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Romney Likens Wall Street Protests to ‘Class Warfare’
text: As anti-Wall Street protests have begun to move from Wall Street to main streets in other cities, the issue has also started to bubble up in the presidential campaign.

headline: Unesco Delays Decision on Fate of Prize Sponsored by Dictator
text: PARIS — Unesco executive board members voted Tuesday to once again postpone a decision on a proposed scientific award sponsored by a West African leader with a brutal reputation, prolonging what has already been more than a year of negotiations and hand-wringing.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Gene Simmons Family Jewels’
text: Is there nothing Gene Simmons and Shannon Tweed won’t do to try to keep “Gene Simmons Family Jewels,” the reality show about their lives, interesting? It appears that after two children and almost three decades together, they’re even willing to take the drastic step of getting married.

headline: Helicopter Plunges Into East River, Killing a Passenger; 4 People Survive
text: A helicopter with a veteran pilot at the controls, and a family of tourists he had known for years aboard, crashed in the East River on Tuesday afternoon, killing a woman despite a frantic rescue effort that involved a flotilla of police and fire vessels and dozens of emergency workers.

headline: Paco Rabanne Returns With an Edge
text: If ever there was a designer-to-brand matchup that was made of perfectly complementary parts, it would be the appointment of Manish Arora as creative director at Paco Rabanne this season. Mr. Arora’s flair for fantastical and theatrical designs is not that far off from what Mr. Rabanne was doing in the 1960s, when he made dresses of metal plates and squares that occasionally gave literal meaning to the term fashion victim.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Somalia, the Philippines, Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline: Denzel Washington Endows a Theater Professorship at Fordham
text: Denzel Washington has donated $2 million to his alma mater, Fordham University, to endow its first professorship in theater with the goal of attracting a well-known actor, director, playwright, designer or other artist to rotate into the position at the school’s Lincoln Center theater program each fall, university officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Egypt Unclear on Timetable of Power Transfer, U.S. Says
text: CAIRO — Not even Egypt’s interim military rulers know when they plan to relinquish power to a new civilian government, the United States ambassador to Egypt, Anne W. Patterson, said Tuesday.

headline: Facing Backlash, Syria Revokes Week-Old Ban on Imports of Consumer Goods
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government on Tuesday revoked a recent decision to ban imports of most consumer goods, a move that had sent prices soaring and provoked outrage among a business elite that has until now backed the leadership of President Bashar al-Assad in his nearly seven-month contest with anti-government activists.

headline: Celebrating a Master of the Avant-Garde
text: Anthony Braxton sat perched on a piano bench one recent afternoon, hands folded in his lap, wearing an intent but unreadable expression. Angled away from the piano in a no-frills rehearsal space in Brooklyn, he faced the dozen or so vocalists that currently make up his Syntactical Ghost Trance Music Choir. The singers, arranged in a semicircle, were tackling Mr. Braxton’s “Composition No. 256,” staring hard at their sheet music while trying to keep track of their conductor. It was starting to seem as if the piece, a slippery, scalar proposition, were getting the best of them.

headline: As Christie Passes, Romney Campaigns On
text: THE VILLAGES, Fla. — Though Mitt Romney has always maintained a casual cool on the topic of a possible Chris Christie candidacy — “It’d be fun if he got in,” Mr. Romney said last week in New Hampshire, with a grin plastered on his face that seemed to say it wouldn’t necessarily be that much fun at all — he seemed newly emboldened on the topic Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Youth Meets Aged Master in 2 Dances, One Score
text: The Guggenheim Museum’s Works & Process series set a particularly difficult challenge for the young ballet choreographers Emery LeCrone and Avi Scher. Requiring them both to make a dance to the same music was not unusual; comparing and contrasting is habitual at Works & Process. The difficulty arose from the selected music: five unrelated works, atonal and rhythmically irregular compositions by the august and fearsome Elliott Carter, and none of them intended for dance.

headline: Sixties Going On 30
text: The heyday of Pierre Cardin and mod fashion finds fresh inspiration in the unaffected Kirsten Dunst.

headline: As Euro Crisis Deepens, Calls for Central Bank to Act
text: FRANKFURT — Jean-Claude Trichet’s last few weeks as president of the European Central Bank may be his most contentious.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Jean Charles Castelbajac
text: Sonny Vandevelde’s Paris fashion week photo diary.

headline: Once Again, the Rays Come Up Short
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Jean Charles Castelbajac
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Bachmann Says Staff Changes Were Planned
text: DES MOINES, Iowa — Representative Michele Bachmann on Tuesday addressed the perception that her campaign had hit a rocky patch because of dwindling finances after the latest staff shakeup.

headline: A Walk in the South Bronx With the Planning Commissioner and Our Architecture Critic
text: Following up on my review last week of Via Verde, a groundbreaking green housing project soon to be completed in the Melrose section of the South Bronx, I took a walk around that neighborhood with Amanda M. Burden, director the Department of City Planning under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. We shot some video of our tour; please watch it by clicking here.

headline: Inside the Caves
text: A look at the cheeses aging in the caves at Murray’s, Artisanal and the Cellars at Jasper Hill.

headline: Cheese: A Coming-of-Age Story
text: ROB KAUFELT and Brian Ralph were standing in a cool underground bunker below Murray’s Cheese Shop in Greenwich Village, giving a visitor a tour of five temperature-and-humidity-controlled cheese caves. The man-made chambers, they said, prevent many of the things that can go wrong with cheese when it is not handled properly.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Crackers With No Gluten but Plenty of Snap
text: Yes, these new lentil crackers are gluten-free, but even if that doesn’t matter to you, they have merit as crisp snacks, for dipping and with cheese. They come in three flavors, all of them appealing: sea salt, cracked pepper and rosemary herb.

headline: Spices, Sugars, Teas: A Blast for the Senses
text: Bruno Benzacken and François Athea are cousins from a family that has been in the spice business in Europe since 1933. They came to New York eight years ago and began selling spices and teas at street fairs. Now they have graduated to a store on the Upper West Side, colorful in its array of several dozen spices, teas and blends and just as alluring for the aromas that waft from the displays. Tall canisters hold various sugars (right), and downstairs there are more spices and teas, along with assorted salts, peppers and pepper mixtures; Provençal products, including soaps; and various gadgets for grinding spices and preparing tea. They serve tea and pastries as well.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Help the Farmers

headline: Michael Dell Advises Hewlett-Packard
text: Attention Hewlett-Packard: Michael Dell thinks that you should stay in the personal computer business.

headline: A Life of Guitars, Girls and Gentle Weeping
text: As three-hour-plus Martin Scorsese documentaries about 1960s musical legends go, “George Harrison: Living in the Material World,” showing in two parts on HBO on Wednesday and Thursday, is not the best. That would be “No Direction Home: Bob Dylan,” shown on PBS in 2005. (“Shine a Light,” about the Rolling Stones, was largely a concert film and only two hours long.)

headline: Strange Ship, Stranger Crew
text: “Benito Cereno” has so much to say. Based on a novella by Herman Melville, the play, by the poet Robert Lowell, is keen to rail against oppression and condemn political hypocrisy. It’s a pity, then, that the stagey production by the Horizon Theater Rep sometimes muffles the script’s voice.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Paco Rabanne
text: Sonny Vandevelde’s Paris fashion week photo diary.

headline: ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ Returning to Broadway
text: Musicals with religious themes – as well as those with Andrew Lloyd Webber scores – are filling up Broadway theaters this season. The Stratford Shakespeare Festival’s production of Mr. Lloyd Webber’s “Jesus Christ Superstar,” which has been an audience and critical favorite there since May, will transfer to Broadway and begin preview performances on March 1, 2012, at the Neil Simon Theater, the producers announced on Tuesday. The revival of the 1971 rock opera, which has lyrics by Tim Rice, will first move to the La Jolla Playhouse later this year.

headline: Q. and A. With Norbert Wabnig
text: This week, Jeff Gordinier writes about affinage, the practice of aging cheese until it ripens — a touchy topic among fromage fanatics. Norbert Wabnig, the owner of the Cheese Store of Beverly Hills, will be answering readers’ questions on cheese, from the social (how do you assemble the perfect cheese plate?) to the more gustatory (when are you supposed to eat the rind?). If you would like to ask a question, post it as a comment below and he will respond in a later post.

headline: Leading Christie Supporter Turns to Romney
text: Ken Langone, the billionaire Home Depot founder who in recent weeks led an intense but unsuccessful effort to draft the New Jersey governor, Christopher J. Christie, into the presidential race, has decided he will now support Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, according to two people with knowledge of the decision.

headline: Adapting Julia Child for E-Readers
text: Clumsily splattering a cookbook with bacon grease is one thing. Doing it to an iPad is quite another.

headline: U.S. and New York Sue Bank of New York Mellon Over Foreign Exchange Fees
text: The New York attorney general and the United States attorney in Manhattan filed separate lawsuits on Tuesday against the Bank of New York Mellon, accusing it of cheating state and other pension funds nationwide out of foreign exchange fees over the last decade.

headline: Besides Burnett, Yanks Go With Same Lineup
text: DETROIT — The lineups are in for Game 4 of the Yankees-Tigers American League division series Tuesday night, and Joe Girardi is going with the same lineup he used in the first three games. Detroit’s Jim Leyland made two alterations with the right-hander A.J. Burnett going for the Yankees instead of the left-hander C.C. Sabathia, who started Game 3.

headline: A West Virginia Forecast: High Uncertainty
text: Voters are going to the polls Tuesday in West Virginia to cast ballots in a special election for governor pitting Earl Ray Tomblin, a Democrat who was appointed governor after Joe Manchin III was elected to the Senate, against Bill Maloney, a Republican.

headline: A Bonnie Glass of Highlands Gin
text: Gins from Scotland have distinctive personality. Hendrick’s, with its clean whisper of cucumber, is a case in point. Now there is Caorunn (pronounced ka-ROON), which offers uncommon herbal complexity, thanks to native botanicals like heather, rowan berry and dandelion, along with the more typical herbs and spices used for gin. A touch of sweetness lingers. The spirit is made in a malt distillery in the Highlands, using some equipment for treating the botanicals that dates back nearly 100 years. This gin seems to have a particular affinity for grapefruit, and a mere splash of the juice is all it needs on the rocks, though a long drink with grapefruit juice and a dash of maraschino liqueur is another winner.

headline: At the Museum, Hunting Treasure and the Man Who Hid It
text: There were really two treasure hunts at the American Museum of Natural History on Monday night. City Room failed at both.

headline: TimesCast | Nobel Nod to Dark Energy
text: October 4, 2011 — Three Americans win the Nobel Prize in physics for discovering dark energy, a force crucial to the expansion of the universe.

headline: Look of the Moment | Natalia Vodianova
text: The Look: Coquette Visage — a red lip and shoe cap a pioneeress dress with a crochet collar and hemline.

headline: Saul Perlmutter on Dark Energy
text: Saul Perlmutter explains how dark energy, which makes up 70 percent of the universe, is causing our universe to expand.

headline: Battle for Libya | October 4, 2011
text: Newly trained fighters attended a graduation ceremony in Tripoli as rebels fought on the front line in Bani Walid.

headline: In Game 3, Arizona Will Rely on a Rookie
text: PHOENIX — Arizona Manager Kirk Gibson calls the right-hander Josh Collmenter a “Ferris wheel” for his unorthodox over-the-top delivery. It’s a throwing motion Collmenter said he developed while throwing hatchets as a youngster growing up in Homer, Mich.

headline: Calvin Klein
text: New York

headline: Let’s Not Speak of ‘Hate’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama, in Texas, Pushes Jobs Bill
text: DALLAS — President Obama on Tuesday campaigned for his jobs bill and collected political contributions in the home state of Gov. Rick Perry and the Congressional district of a Republican House leader, and he did not shy away from telling affluent donors that they and the state’s oil companies should pay more in taxes for the nation’s good.

headline: Will World End Before or After Festival Does?
text: The opportunity to see two intimidating landmarks — “Once Upon a Time in Anatolia” and “The Turin Horse” — is reason enough for any filmgoer with more than a passing interest in the evolution of world cinema to be grateful for the platform of the New York Film Festival. Because the chances that either movie will soon be coming to a theater near you, as they say, are next to nil, the best time to see them may be at Alice Tully Hall in the coming week.

headline: The iPhone and the Brain
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lens: Photographs From a Decade in Afghanistan
text: “I am a photographer working for a newspaper, and to ignore this American war, or any other war that we are involved in, would be an unfulfilling way for me to work.” Tyler Hicks, a staff photographer at The New York Times, voices in a simple and understated way the reasons he keeps going back to Afghanistan after over 10 years of covering the war there. But his experiences in that time have been anything but simple or understated.

headline: Two Directions for Moroccan Cuisine
text: MOURAD LAHLOU and Paula Wolfert would not seem to have much in common. He is the 43-year-old chef of Aziza in San Francisco, his arms decorated with tattoos that signify “strength” in Arabic, a son of Casablanca, Morocco, who works wonders with spices and preserved lemons, sous-vide and meat glue.

headline: Being a Monster Doesn’t Mean Being a Bully, Too
text: MONSTER HIGH, the line of fashion dolls from Mattel that features the teenage children of legendary monsters facing the awkward struggles of high school, is getting a social conscience.

headline: Enjoying Cabernet of a Certain Age
text: THE wine in my glass was a pale, rusty red, browning at the edges, as you’d expect in an older wine. The aroma, with its intimations of tobacco and graphite, suggested a good Pauillac, with an added touch of anise. It was lovely and graceful, tangy and deliciously fresh despite the years, and the flavors persisted in the mouth. Beautiful.

headline: For 2nd Time, Adele Cancels a Tour
text: For the second time this year, Adele has been forced to cancel a sold-out tour of several American cities because of health problems affecting her voice.

headline: Republican Criticizes Norquist for ‘Paralyzing’ Congress
text: Who is this Grover Norquist, anyhow? To hear Representative Frank Wolf tell it, the antitax activist is a questionable character with some “unsavory” connections who has too much influence over the political process.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

headline: A Naked Man Can Be a Difficult Problem Onstage
text: I’m a Winner.

headline: iPhone 4S: Revolution or Evolution?
text: Apple announced its latest iPhone, hoping to slow the explosive growth of its arch-rival Android.

headline: N.B.A. Is Expected to Lose Two Weeks of Regular Season
text: A last-gasp attempt to end the N.B.A. lockout faltered Tuesday, all but ensuring that games will be lost to a labor crisis for the second time in league history.

headline: More Solyndra E-mails, and Warnings
text: The Solyndra e-mails that House Democrats used to write the memo they released on Monday, in an effort to refute the idea that political favoritism was in play, are now posted on their Energy and Commerce Web site, and they have a few more nuggets about the company.

headline: ‘How to Win Friends and Influence People in the Digital Age’
text: Why Carnegie’s Advice Still Matters

headline: Photos of the Moment | Paco Rabanne

headline: Korea’s ‘Master Chef’ Prepares a Banquet at the Met
text: A pageant and banquet celebrating Korean culture and food was held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday night.

headline: Cuts in Military Benefits
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Emily Post’s Etiquette, 18th Edition’
text: Chapter 1

headline: House Panel Investigates FEMA
text: The House Appropriations Committee is investigating the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s last-minute decision to finish the 2011 fiscal year with no additional funds, the panel’s chairman said on Tuesday.

headline: Milestones to Lose Signature Touch
text: When Austin Romine collected his first major league hit Sept. 12 in Seattle, the ball he struck made its way from right field to the Yankees’ dugout and eventually into the hands of the team’s chief athletic trainer, Gene Monahan.

headline: A Data Center Power Solution
text: The rapid growth in data centers, some with hundreds of thousands of computer servers attending to tasks as diverse as managing complex physics problems and posting pictures to Facebook, has led to a lot of worries about power consumption. A recent census of the industry indicated electricity use will grow by 19 percent just in 2012.

headline: I Am Your Nurse. Please Call Me ‘Doctor.’
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.N. Resolution on Syria Blocked by Russia and China
text: UNITED NATIONS — Months of wrangling at the Security Council over a resolution condemning Syria collapsed on Tuesday after Russia and China vetoed a measure that contained a weak reference to the possibility of sanctions against Damascus.

headline: Fox News Decides to Keep ‘The Five’
text: “The Five,” a talk show that was created to temporarily replace Glenn Beck’s show on Fox News, is being made a more permanent part of the channel’s weekday schedule.

headline: Far From Home
text: Tens of thousands of boys under the age of 18 witnessed the brutality of the Civil War firsthand.

headline: Regulator Seeks Oversight of ‘Cheetah’ Traders
text: Bart Chilton, a Democratic member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, has plans to tame the cheetahs — cheetah traders on Wall Street, that is.

headline: Chanel Never Breaks Stride
text: PARIS

headline: The iPhone 4S Is as Much About Google as Apple
text: Tuesday’s iPhone unveiling didn’t have as much to do with Apple as it did with Google. And in regards to Google, Tuesday’s announcement was, to quote the rapper Diddy, “All about the Benjamins.”

headline: Make That the Mercedes-Benz Superdome
text: Since 1975, the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans has had no other name. But on Tuesday, it officially became the Mercedes-Benz Superdome with the German luxury automaker’s acquisition of the naming rights to the home of the New Orleans Saints.

headline: Five Years Later, a Different Outcome
text: Detroit

headline: As Economies Slow, Price of Gas Falls
text: HOUSTON — The sharp slump in oil prices over the last few months is finally beginning to bring relief at the gasoline pump, with the price of a gallon of regular gasoline dropping nearly a penny a day over the last four weeks.

headline: The Boys of War
text: With hopes of adventure and glory, tens of thousands of boys under the age of 18 answered the call of the Civil War, many of them rushing to join Union and Confederate troops in the earliest days of battle. Both sides had recruitment rules that barred underage men from enlisting, but that didn’t stop those who wanted to be part of the action: some enlisted without their parents’ permission and lied about their ages or bargained with recruiters for a trial period, while others joined along with their older brothers and fathers whose partisan passions overwhelmed their parental senses. Most of the youngest boys became drummers, messengers and orderlies, but thousands of others fought alongside the men.

headline: Mark Hurd Is Still Intense
text: You may have thought Oracle was a hard-charging sales organization even before Mark Hurd showed up. Turns out there was room for more.

headline: Iraq Denies Legal Immunity to U.S. Troops After 2011
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s political leaders announced late Tuesday that they had agreed on the need to keep American military trainers in Iraq next year, but they declared that any remaining troops should not be granted immunity from Iraqi law, a point the United States has said would be a deal breaker.

headline: Handicapping IAC’s Investment in Chelsea Clinton
text: Chelsea Clinton as a corporate director? Really?

headline: Hanan Porat, Jewish Settlement Leader, Dies at 67
text: JERUSALEM — Hanan Porat, who helped turn Israel’s religious settler movement into a powerful force through the establishment of Jewish communities in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, died on Tuesday at his childhood kibbutz, which he had re-established. He was 67.

headline: In a Trial, Only a Quick Nod to a Bloomberg Aide’s Affair
text: It was expected to be a moment of supreme awkwardness for John F. Haggerty Jr., a political consultant accused of stealing money from the mayor of New York.

headline: In Florida Retirement Community, Guess What Romney Talks About?
text: THE VILLAGES, Fla. — The audience — the aging, the retired and the lively-but-starting-to-show-smile-lines men and women of Florida — could not have telegraphed Social Security concerns more clearly than Mitt Romney himself, who tried a little Social Security humor of his own Tuesday afternoon at The Villages, a retirement community about an hour north of Orlando.

headline: How About a Little Danish?
text: COPENHAGEN, Denmark — Well lookee here: the inevitable move toward taxing unhealthful foods to raise income and discourage damaging diets has begun. Last month, Hungary, almost unnoticed, began taxing foods with high levels of fat, salt and sugar. And earlier this week, with just a little more fanfare, Denmark instituted an excise tax on foods high in saturated fat.

headline: Jury Sought for Nigerian Held in Bid to Bomb Jet
text: DETROIT — Among the scores of potential jurors for the trial of a man accused of trying to blow up an airliner with a bomb in his underwear, nearly all said they had already heard something about the case, a federal judge here said Tuesday, the first day of jury selection.

headline: Hope Rising, Stores Hire for Holidays
text: Even with a turbulent economy, leading retailers say they expect to hire more, or at least as many, holiday workers as last year, when temporary hiring for Christmas grew nearly 50 percent over recession lows.

headline: Taliban Using Modern Means to Add to Sway
text: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — Punctually, at 8 o’clock every evening, the cellphone signals disappear in this provincial capital. Under pressure from the Taliban, the major carriers turn off their signal towers, effectively severing most of the connections to the rest of the world.

headline: Tenderness and Violence as Portrayed in a Murder Trial
text: On the morning she shot her husband five times with a revolver, then grabbed a second pistol and pumped six more bullets into him, Barbara Sheehan had proofread an essay on Genesis 22, written by her son for his freshman religion class.

headline: Building Architects’ Centers to Capture Public Attention
text: In the years he has been associated with the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects, Rick Bell has witnessed some great real estate deals.

headline: The Downside to a Debt Jubilee
text: Good ends do not justify bad means. That philosophical observation applies to proposals for a big American debt jubilee that are now doing the rounds. The basic idea is to slash consumer debt, which is an admirable aim for an overleveraged nation. Household debt is still 90 percent of gross domestic product, down only modestly from the 2008 peak of 100 percent. But even bank-haters should recognize that this cure might be worse than the disease.

headline: An Appeal Gone Astray Catches the Supreme Court’s Attention
text: WASHINGTON — Cory R. Maples, a death row inmate in Alabama, had what turned out to be the bad fortune to be represented by one of the most prominent law firms in the nation. The Supreme Court heard arguments in his case on Tuesday, and Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. described where matters stood.

headline: Quick Change That Lasts for the Long Term
text: On Friday I wrote about Rapid Results Initiatives, bite-sized pieces of social change that a village, government office or business will choose and try to accomplish in just 100 days.   Rapid Results Initiatives have proven to be effective at various tasks: improving  health, infrastructure, education —  service delivery of any kind.  The urgent deadline provides focus.  It’s no longer business as usual, plagued by the usual list of reasons why nothing gets done.

headline: TimesCast | Truck Bomb in Somalia
text: October 4, 2011 - A massive truck bomb in Mogadishu kills dozens, with the Shabaab Islamic group claiming responsibility.

headline: Audit Finds City’s Schools Short on Physical Education
text: Despite alarming obesity rates among school-age children and a state requirement that all students get some level of structured exercise every week, many New York City schools do not provide physical education, or do not provide it as frequently as they should, according to an audit released on Tuesday by the city comptroller.

headline: Pundits Pack Meaner Punch Than Comedians’ Fat Jokes
text: He listened to the jokes and laughed. But he read the columns and cringed.

headline: When Leaders Die, Terror Still Thrives
text: THE killing of the Yemeni-American cleric Anwar al-Awlaki on Sept. 30 is arguably the most significant attack on Al Qaeda since Osama bin Laden’s death in May.

headline: After Bronx Crash, a Bus Fleet Stays on the Road
text: In the months after a bus crash on Interstate 95 killed 15 people in the Bronx, federal officials were so concerned about the operation of the bus company, World Wide Travel, that they revoked its registration. But the disciplinary action seems to have had little practical effect.

headline: Roots of ‘Ballot Security’: Dead Voters, Party Fears and Shadowy Tactics

headline: Russia Declares It Is Close to Joining the World Trade Organization
text: MOSCOW — After high-level meetings in Washington, Russian officials said Tuesday that they were on the brink of a deal that would allow Russia to become a member of the World Trade Organization after 18 years of halting negotiations, though hostility between Georgia and Russia remains a crucial sticking point.

headline: In Detroit, Young Gets New Lease in the Playoffs
text: DETROIT — In the three and a half years that Delmon Young played for the Minnesota Twins, facing the Yankees almost always guaranteed a quiet postgame clubhouse. Not only were the Twins swept in back-to-back American League division series, with many of the games close and excruciating, but they also lost 19 of 26 to the Yankees in the regular season.

headline: Back to School in Libya, and Struggling to Adjust
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The classrooms at the Dawn of Freedom middle school were empty. Teachers shuffled around aimlessly outside or gossiped in the halls. A small group of bored teenagers sat in the theater and hatched a plan to coax their classmates back.

headline: Will Copyright Stifle Hollywood?
text: Philadelphia

headline: What Kind of Fall Am I?
text: There is no single way to measure the coming of autumn. Gardeners wait for the first hard frost, the one that blackens the basil and pulps the tomatoes still on the vine. For some, it’s the smell of wood smoke or the sight of leaves flaming out one tree species at a time. In New York City, there are different measures. Fall begins when street fashion slips into thermal chaos — down jackets, shawls, bermudas and flip-flops all on the same block. Fall begins, as it did this week, when the residual heat in the subway station feels strangely welcome.

headline: Capital Goods Orders Rise the Most in 3 Months
text: Orders for capital equipment increased in August by the most in three months, the Commerce Department said Tuesday, a sign that business investment and exports held up in the face of growing concern over the European debt crisis.

headline: At Controls of Doomed Aircraft, a Pilot With Experience
text: Five years ago, Paul Dudley was at the helm of a plane that was forced to make an emergency landing in a Brooklyn park. It was a nonevent, he said, engine trouble that he compared to “getting a blowout with your car on the highway.”

headline: Making Empty Homes Less Inviting to the Uninvited
text: LONDON — Arriving at his supposedly empty rental property just outside London recently, Sam Chima, a housing lawyer, was dismayed to find a newly installed lock on the front door and a newly installed stranger glaring from a window.

headline: Morgan Tries to Quell Rumors About Its Holdings
text: Morgan Stanley executives are battling a daily barrage of speculation and nay-saying to try to stem a sharp slide in the company’s stock.

headline: Zuckerman Spaeder Builds Out Its New York Practice
text: Over the last 35 years, the Washington law firm Zuckerman Spaeder has built a well-regarded litigation boutique, largely inside the Beltway. Now, with the hiring of three prominent lawyers in two weeks, the firm has moved to establish a formidable criminal defense practice in New York.

headline: British Squatters Rejuvenate an Abandoned Site Near Heathrow Airport
text: The British government has promised to tighten anti-squatting laws to make it easier for property owners to evict uninvited tenants.

headline: A Court Fight and a Tireless Battle Over an Image

headline: As Regulars Falter, Unlikely Slugger Provides Blast That Boosts Phillies
text: ST. LOUIS — A lot had been made about how the Philadelphia Phillies’ regular lineup, reunited at last, would propel them through the postseason.

headline: Gov. Perry’s Rock
text: Untold decades ago, someone decided to name a hunting camp in West Texas “Niggerhead,” using a phrase so commonplace around the South that it was used as a brand name for oysters, soap, tobacco and even golf tees. When Gov. Rick Perry’s family took over the lease for the camp in 1983, it could have demanded that the name be changed. It could have destroyed the rock on which the name was painted. It could have broken with an era when vicious racism was so casual that officials put such a word on maps around the country.

headline: A.C. Nielsen Jr., Who Built Ratings Firm, Dies at 92
text: Arthur C. Nielsen Jr., who transformed the company his father founded in 1923 into an international leader in market research, helping to make its name synonymous with television ratings, died on Monday in Winnetka, Ill., where he lived most of his life. He was 92.

headline: Sabathia’s Future a Question
text: DETROIT — C. C. Sabathia has been a boon to the Yankees since he arrived in New York, going 59-23 with a 3.18 earned run average in three seasons, and leading the team, both on and off the field. In 2009, he repaid his huge contract by leading the Yankees all the way to a World Series championship.

headline: A Dreadful Missed Deadline
text: Alabama is a step from executing Cory Maples for a reason so grievously wrong that the case argued Tuesday at the Supreme Court should leave no doubt why the death penalty should be abolished. Besides being barbaric, case after case is rife with constitutional defects.

headline: Kennedy’s Big Day Still an Aberration
text: Adrian Beltre joined a select fraternity when he blasted three home runs in a postseason game Tuesday against the Tampa Bay Rays in Game 4 of their American League division series. headline: The Wrong Way to Deal With China
text: China is undeniably manipulating its currency. Countries around the world, including the United States, are losing jobs because their manufacturing industries cannot compete with artificially cheap Chinese goods. For the good of the world economy, and its own long-term economic development, China should stop.

headline: How Much to Drink During a Marathon
text: The 2011 Chicago Marathon on Sunday marks the beginning of the fall marathon season in the United States, culminating on Nov. 6 with the New York City race. In those two events alone, more than 80,000 runners will attempt to cover the 26.2-mile marathon distance. But two newly released studies suggest that there are reasons to be concerned about some of the racers’ readiness. The studies show that a worrying large percentage of distance runners may not know how to drink.

headline: Polls Reveal Americans’ Doubts About Afghan War
text: As the war in Afghanistan reaches its 10th anniversary, two national surveys reveal an American public that thinks the United States should not be fighting in Afghanistan and the war has not been worth it. And a survey of military veterans examines the attitudes of those who have served both before and since Sept. 11, finding high levels of pride in their service with less certainty about American military efforts in Afghanistan.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday

Mr. Hazare demanded a written commitment from the Congress Party on the issue before Thursday’s holiday of Dussehra. (Hindustan Times)Prime Minister Manmohan Singh and Afghanistan President Hamid Karzai signed their first-ever strategic partnership agreement on Tuesday in New Delhi. India has agreed to train the Afghan national security forces, and the two countries pledged trade and economic cooperation, from developing trade routes to exploring for minerals and hydrocarbons in Afghanistan. headline: Classic Advice: Please, Leave Well Enough Alone
text: Dale Carnegie’s “How to Win Friends and Influence People,” which turns 75 this year, has sold more than 30 million copies and continues to be a best seller. The book, a paean to integrity, good humor and warmth in the name of amicable capitalism, is as wholesome as a Norman Rockwell painting. It exists alongside Dr. Spock’s child-rearing guide, Strunk and White’s volume on literary style and Fannie Farmer’s cookbook as a classic expression of the American impulse toward self-improvement and reinvention. Testimonials to its effectiveness abound. It’s said that the only diploma that hangs in Warren Buffett’s office is his certificate from Dale Carnegie Training.

Under Elattuvalapil Sreedharan, the 9-year-old Metro provides stellar service, completes projects on time and under budget, and is making a profit, despite having the lowest fares of any metro system in the world outside of Kolkata.

headline: Young Artists the Focus at Madrid Show
text: Drive along Spain’s highways long enough and you might pass the silhouette of a black bull that stands nearly 46 feet high. Originally an advertising campaign for the Osborne sherry company, the bull — there are actually a number of them across Spain — has since become a national symbol. In 2006, after almost 50 years since the first “Osborne bull” went up, the Madrid-based artist SpY, who has often been referred to as the Spanish Banksy, protested bullfighting by splattering one of the bulls with a huge splash of red paint.

headline: Can Cancer Ever Be Ignored?
text: As chief medical and scientific officer of the American Cancer Society, Otis Webb Brawley — who is also a professor of oncology and epidemiology at Emory University — is the public face of the cancer establishment. He operates in a world of similarly high-achieving, multiple-credentialed, respectable professionals, where insults tend to be delivered, stiletto-style, in scientific language that lay people aren’t meant to understand. So it can be more than a little jarring to hear, for example, James Mohler, chairman of the urology department and associate director of the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, say of his friend: “I have known Otis for over 20 years. He doesn’t come off as being ignorant or stupid, but when it comes to prostate-cancer screening, he must not be as intelligent as he seems.” Or Skip Lockwood, the head of Zero, a prostate-cancer patient advocacy group, charge that Brawley is more concerned about saving men’s sex lives than about saving the men themselves.

headline: How Glassybaby Is Trying to Win Over New Yorkers

headline: For 3 Boys, an Excellent Adventure

headline: Korea’s ‘Master Chef’ Prepares a Banquet at the Met
text: On Monday night, a raft of Korean culture and tourism groups held a dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, preceded by a pageant in the great hall (Korean fashion, as well as food, was being celebrated). The banquet reflected the cuisine of the country’s imperial court in the Chosun dynasty, which lasted from about 1400 to 1900. Han Bok-ryeo, the nation’s official “master chef,” was brought in to oversee the serving of kalbi-jjim (braised beef), kimchi, ssam (rolls), mushrooms, and root vegetables like radishes and carrots — enhanced with aromatics like baby ginseng, pine nuts, dried seaweed and dried red chile. Even tarakjuk, soft rice porridge traditionally served to the emperor at dawn, appeared as a first course, sprinkled with chives.

headline: Karzai Tries to Soothe Pakistan Over Warmer Relations With India

headline: The Moneyball of Campaign Advertising (Part 1)

They can immediately intuit that person’s strengths and weaknesses. They know what works, because they have done this so many times. They have stories of what happened 2 years ago or 4 years ago or 16 years ago. They remember the key moments — the crucial plays, the turning points. They know what it takes to win the championship.

headline: World Monuments Fund Places Manufacturers Hanover Building on At-Risk List
text: The 1954 glass box at 510 Fifth Avenue is among the cultural heritage sites at risk, according to the annual list assembled by the World Monuments Fund, which was released on Wednesday. Noting that the controversial renovation of the building at 43rd Street, a branch of what was then the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, has been the subject of a court dispute, the fund said the case “raises questions about the legality of recent alterations and the capacity of the New York City Landmarks Commission to enforce protective regulations.”

headline: Coen Brothers Producing Comedy Pilot for Fox
text: More than 13 years and who knows how many White Russians after “The Big Lebowski,” the sibling filmmakers Joel and Ethan Coen are turning their attention to another brother shamus – not an Irish monk, but a fellow private investigator – for what could be their first television project. The Coens, the Academy Award-winning writer-directors of “No Country for Old Men” and “Fargo,” are collaborating with the “Cedar Rapids” screenwriter Phil Johnston on a television series called “Harve Karbo,” about another hapless aspiring Sam Spade. According to The Hollywood Reporter, the oddly specific series will chronicle “a touchy Los Angeles private investigator — and his deadbeat friends in El Segundo — whose cases frequently force him to cross paths with a who’s who of Hollywood,” and if that sounds at least a little Lebowski-esque, we can abide. The series, which the Coens will produce for Imagine Television and for which Mr. Johnston will write the script, has so far received a pilot commitment from Fox, which means there are still, you know, a lotta ins, a lotta outs, a lotta what-have-yous, before “Harve Karbo” appears on your screen.

headline: Back Home, and Homeless
text: Mid-June, 2011: I find myself alone in a dark wooded park tucked between million-dollar houses south of Stanford University, looking for a spot in the bushes to stash my bags. Until that morning I’d been living in a cheap weekly-rate motel in Palo Alto. Before checkout, knowing I couldn’t afford the $48 fee for another night, I laid out my stuff on the bed. Over the cigarette burns on threadbare sheets, I scrounged for quarters, dimes and nickels. There was enough for an extra value meal at Taco Bell. I divided everything else I had between three bags; an olive-drab backpack my brother used in the Army Rangers, a black duffel I bought at Goodwill and a satchel for my laptop.

headline: David Cronenberg’s ‘Method’
text: While the latest film from David Cronenberg is a further departure from the psychological horror films of his early career, it does still put psychology (and psychoanalysis) at the forefront. “A Dangerous Method,” starring Viggo Mortensen, Michael Fassbender and Keira Knightley, takes place on the eve of World War I and looks at the relationship between the psychiatrist Carl Jung and his mentor Sigmund Freud. That relationship shifts when Jung takes on and develops a close bond to a new patient, Sabina Spielrein, played by Ms. Knightley. The film’s screenplay was adapted by Christopher Hampton from his stage play, “The Talking Cure.” The Times’s Stephen Holden writes about “A Dangerous Method” in his notebook about films in the festival. In this video, Mr. Cronenberg discusses how he and his team used source material — letters written by the two main subjects — to create an accurate account of both the personal and professional lives of these men.

headline: Tévez’s Shrug Heard Round the World
text: Steve Bartman went to a ball game. He tried to do what millions of baseball fans would love to do and catch a ball. No more, no less. But he interfered with play and was vilified because of it. He ceased being human and became a verb, a figure of hatred and of fun. The fact that he was a man of honor really meant nothing. What he did that night defined his life.

headline: Prints Charming | Marimekko’s New York City Flagship
text: If your retail therapist is counseling you to find a happy place, somewhere good to start might be the northwest corner of Broadway and 23rd Street, where a Marimekko flagship store opens its doors for business this week. The airy, industrial space in the former Toy Building has been whitewashed and minimally outfitted, allowing the brightly colored, impossibly upbeat prints for which the 60-year-old company is famous, to shine. The founders, Armi Ratia and her husband, Viljo, always envisioned Marimekko not just as a lifestyle brand, but as a way of life, and over the years their graphic sensibility touched everything from textiles to teapots, all of which are available for purchase. There is even an on-site seamstress, to whip up, say, a set of napkins in Unikko, the signature poppy print, or a pillow cover in the artist Astrid Sylwan’s brush strokey Vattenblänk. The folks at Marimekko hope New Yorkers will embrace the store as a meeting point; the trick, it seems, will be getting them to leave.

headline: The Importance of a True No. 1 Receiver in the N.F.L.

headline: Wall St. Protest Attracts Many New to This Sort of Thing

The last time Peter Linard, 71, a retired waiter who lives on the Upper East Side, went to a protest, he was living in Greece, where he marched for peace — in 1961.

headline: Fat Tax Update
text: Some months ago, when someone smarter than I (I can’t even remember who it was!) suggested that the Fat Tax, the subject of my column today, could get backing from the Right as well as the Left, I scoffed. Now we have the potential of David Cameron, Britain’s decidedly Tory P.M., backing a significant national fat tax in the U.K., according to the Daily Mail. He’ll be attacked for nanny-state-ism by his own members, of course, but Britain’s highest-in-Europe obesity rate (third in the world, after the U.S. and Mexico) and the dangers to the National Health system – the oldest single-payer system in the world and perhaps the largest (depends how you measure) — could make this interesting.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, the Philippines, Russia and Afghanistan.

headline: Deer Appear on Brooklyn Shore, in Disturbing Circumstances
text: White-tailed deer, tree-browsing icons of the suburban wildlife scene, have been making inroads in New York City. Their numbers on Staten Island have grown to the point where many residents consider them a nuisance.

headline: Freddie and Fannie Reject Debt Relief
text: Home values have fallen so much in Arizona that almost half the people with mortgages there owe more than their homes are worth. So when federal money became available to help stem the tide of foreclosures, the state flagged that group for help.

headline: Graphic Content | ‘Urbanized’
text: “Urbanized,” the latest design documentary by Gary Hustwit, had its premiere on Sept. 20 in New York (and is currently being screened around the world) and is the final in an accidental trilogy that includes “Helvetica” (about the ubiquitous typeface) and “Objectified” (about the impact of industrial and product design on commerce and the environment). “Urbanized,” as its title suggests, is about the design of cities. Although other films have surveyed the topic through a longer lens, Hustwit’s is about immediate problems — and some viable solutions.

headline: Pasha Fierce
text: A collector’s personal booty becomes a fantasy hotel in Fez.

headline: ‘Funny Girl’ Finds a Home on Broadway
text: In a display of moxie worthy of Fanny Brice herself, the producers of the coming Los Angeles revival of “Funny Girl” said on Wednesday they would transfer that musical to the Imperial Theater on Broadway next April — even though the show has yet to begin rehearsals.

headline: The Markets Love Some Good Deal Speculation
text: Three of the biggest movers among technology stocks on Wednesday were Yahoo, Akamai Technologies and Research in Motion. What do they have in common?

headline: On Our Radar: A Pipeline Lawsuit
text: Environmental groups sue the State Department and the Department of Interior in federal court in Nebraska to block the construction of the controversial Keystone XL pipeline. They say that TransCanada has already started to prepare the route for the 1,700-mile pipeline, even through federal environmental reviews are not complete. [Bloomberg News]

headline: Officer Faces Charges He Abused His Authority
text: 7:23 p.m. | Updated It was the Fourth of July weekend in 2008 at the Living Room Lounge in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, when a uniformed New York police officer issued a threat: No one, he said, “messes with my cousin’s place.”

headline: A Modernist Masterpiece Is About to Disappear at Kennedy Airport
text: I. M. Pei’s Terminal 6, originally the National Airlines “Sundrome,” is only weeks away from demolition.

headline: Avery Clears Waivers
text: The Rangers agitator Sean Avery cleared N.H.L. waivers on Wednesday, 24 hours after the Rangers placed him there. He was assigned to the team’s American Hockey League affiliate in Hartford, the Connecticut Whale.

headline: There’s A Fjord In My Future
text: This conference should be interesting. They say it will be webcast live; I’ll post information when the event approaches.

headline: Questions and Relief at Season’s Start
text: It was another in a succession of strong years for the N.H.L.: exciting play, soaring television ratings, record revenue and the fourth straight Stanley Cup finals between traditional hockey cities. But even as the Boston Bruins were raising the silver chalice on June 15, the riot was on outside in the streets of Vancouver, a four-hour orgy of destruction that injured scores of people and caused millions of dollars in damage.

headline: ‘New Girl’ on Fox Keeps Drawing Viewers
text: It may be just the third week of the fall TV season, but the Tuesday night programming slate has already settled into a ratings groove. Once a wild card, “New Girl” on Fox is now a mainstay thanks to a full-season pickup last week and its continued perch atop the 18-to-49-year-old demographic ratings. The comedy, which stars Zooey Deschanel, lifted Fox to another overall Tuesday night win in that category. “NCIS,” meanwhile, fulfilled the same role it has for the last nine seasons on CBS, gathering the largest possible audience (18.9 million total viewers) while posting respectable numbers in the 18-to-49 category. The one question mark: Sarah Michelle Gellar may have to go back to vampire-slaying: her new show “Ringer” on CW dropped another 33 percent in what was already a dismal 18-to-49 rating. It averaged 1.5 million viewers.

headline: Bahrain Orders Retrials for Medical Workers
text: Bahraini judicial authorities on Wednesday nullified the convictions and harsh prison terms given to 20 medical workers last week by a special security court prosecuting cases arising from civil unrest in the country. The medical workers were ordered released from custody, with new trials scheduled in a civilian court.

headline: Land Deal Is Announced to Allow New U.N. Tower and Esplanade
text: City and state officials on Wednesday agreed to a $73 million plan that would unlock an underutilized chunk of the Manhattan waterfront between East 38th and East 60th Streets, paving the way for a new United Nations office tower and esplanade along the East River.

headline: Xbox Is Now a TV Box
text: Microsoft on Wednesday announced the dawning of a “new era” of television. The actual announcement doesn’t amount to nearly that much, but it is worth noting for what it says about our TV habits.

headline: TV Chat: Ask the Critic
text: Neil Genzlinger, a television critic for The New York Times, acknowledges the ambition of the new Fox show “Terra Nova,” but in an exchange with readers he questioned what that really means: “In TV-speak, ‘ambitious’ generally means ‘expensive.’ In the real sense of the word — risk-taking, ground-breaking, etc. — ‘Terra Nova’ is in most ways the opposite of ambitious.”

headline: Homes for $280,000

text: Thousands of Greeks strike in the first protest since June; orchestra conductors gather before the United States Supreme Court; and homelessness declines in New York City.

headline: Jurors Hear Jackson Talk of Building a Children’s Hospital
text: In a recording six weeks before he died, a slurred, barely intelligible Michael Jackson told his doctor that he dreamed of building the world’s largest children’s hospital, because “I didn’t have a childhood.”

headline: Scene City: The Vampire Look Just Won’t Die
text: Carine Roitfeld brings the Paris collections to a close with a night of revelry fit for a vampire (or two).
