text: Something I was curious about:

headline: U.S. Panel Says No to Prostate Screening for Healthy Men
text: Healthy men should no longer receive a P.S.A. blood test to screen for prostate cancer because the test does not save lives over all and often leads to more tests and treatments that needlessly cause pain, impotence and incontinence in many, a key government health panel has decided.

headline: Scott Brown Locks Up The Jerk Vote
text: Awesome.

headline: A Singer Asks, Why Can’t a Man Be More Like a Woman?
text: In the flowery lyrics of “Younger Than Springtime,” that heavily perfumed Rodgers and Hammerstein love song from “South Pacific” sung by Lieutenant Cable to his islander sweetheart, the ethereal beloved is “softer than starlight” and “warmer than winds of June.” At the opening night performance of her new show, “Ah Men! The Boys of Broadway!,” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Tuesday evening Betty Buckley sang the song with conviction, then mused aloud that if only men addressed women that way, “the world would be a better place.”

headline: Conductor Replaces Baton With Violin, for an Evening
text: Virtually all conductors were trained as instrumentalists before they took up the baton, but too few keep their technique sufficiently up to date to perform publicly. Alan Gilbert, like Lorin Maazel, his predecessor as music director of the New York Philharmonic, is a violinist, and though he has played in the Philharmonic’s chamber concerts, his appearance alongside the violinist Frank Peter Zimmermann in Bach’s Double Concerto on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall was his solo debut with the orchestra.

headline: S.B.A.-Backed Lending Set a Record in 2011
text: The Small Business Administration did record business in 2011, guaranteeing more money in loans to small companies than in any year in its history. But the very smallest businesses, seeking the smallest loans, had more trouble getting an S.B.A. guarantee than in 2010.

headline: 36 Hours in Ann Arbor, Mich.
text: IT is not just the throngs of University of Michigan students dressed in maize and blue singing “Hail to the Victors” that makes Ann Arbor the ultimate college town each fall. Nor is it Michigan Stadium, with the largest attendance in the country (114,804 at one recent game), and recently renovated to the tune of $226 million. Rather it is the urban sophistication of this town — with its mix of restaurants, bars, boutiques, art-house movie theaters and world-class art museums — that keeps many University of Michigan alumni from leaving long after they have graduated. For travelers, the sheer energy and the abundance of cultural opportunities, from classical dance performances to bluegrass concerts, makes a fall visit here a good time to get into the college spirit, even if you’re not a student.

headline: 36 Hours in Ann Arbor
text: The town is a mix of restaurants, bars, boutiques, art-house movie theaters and world-class art museums.

headline: Singing Out for St. Basil’s
text: The 450th anniversary of St. Basil’s Cathedral in Red Square will be honored Oct. 14 to 17 with an international choir festival featuring a Russian choir from Boston and the premiere of a work for orchestra, organ and choir set to Anna Akhmatova’s poem “Requiem,” about Stalin-era suffering. “The cathedral’s silhouette is famous around the world,” said Lev Pankratov, the festival’s musical director and the composer of “Requiem.”

headline: A Wayward Deer Rescued in Brooklyn Later Died
text: One of the deer picked up by a police boat Wednesday in the harbor just off the Bay Ridge waterfront in Brooklyn later died.

headline: Tucked Under a Brownstone, Violins For Everyone
text: Virtuoso Resources, a violin atelier in Manhattan, has a varied collection of instruments and a few pieces of classical music history tucked away in an Upper West Side brownstone.

headline: A Salon for Musicians Big and Small
text: HAVING learned to play the violin as a boy, my husband has long harbored fantasies that our 3-year-old daughter, Meenakshi, will someday follow his footsteps into a school orchestra. While researching how she could get started, I stumbled upon Virtuoso Resources. New York has no shortage of places that stock instruments for children, but for young people eyeing the violin, viola or cello, this Upper West Side atelier offers an unusual grace note: a touch of musical history.

headline: Wall Street Watchdog Finds Its Teeth
text: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, once a sleepy Wall Street watchdog, is exercising its regulatory muscle, filing a record number of enforcement cases over the last year as it moved to clean up the mess from the financial crisis.

headline: Fuzzy, Purple and Full of Thorns
text: IT was a snowy February day in New York City when my boyfriend of three months decided to go into his bedroom to look for his camera. I followed along to keep him company, which I was doing a fine job of until my eyes landed on something entirely out of place for a mid-30s man to have in his closet.

headline: Romney Calls for More Defense Spending
text: MT. PLEASANT, S.C. — Standing among retired airplanes on the U.S.S. Yorktown, a decommissioned World War II aircraft carrier, Mitt Romney told a small group of veterans on Thursday that given the global threats to America’s interests, the nation’s defense spending should be increased instead of cut.

headline: F.C.C. Plans to Overhaul Telecom Fund to Focus on Expanding Broadband
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission on Thursday outlined a plan to transform the Universal Service Fund, an $8 billion fund that is paid for by the nation’s telephone customers and used to subsidize basic telephone service in rural areas, into one that will help expand broadband Internet service to 18 million Americans who lack high-speed access.

headline: Pictures of the Day: California and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from California,

headline: A Family Breakup in ‘Relatively Speaking’
text: The last collaboration between the actor Fred Melamed and the filmmaker Ethan Coen yielded one of the silkiest screen villains in recent years: Sy Ableman, the gently bearish widower in “A Serious Man” (2009), who seduces the wife of the main character and then keeps explaining the logic of the cuckolding to him. (Sy: “Such a thing, such a thing – you know, Larry, the way we handle ourselves in this situation is so important.”) But their latest outing together, in the Broadway production “Relatively Speaking,” has not gone as smoothly: He left the show after the matinee on Sunday.

headline: Stand Up and Be Counted
text: My girlfriend and I attended opening night at the Metropolitan Opera, featuring the world-class soprano Anna Netrebko. She was magnificent, and at the end of the evening, we gave her a standing ovation. The woman behind us called out loudly: “Sit down. I can’t see.” This led to a testy exchange with her companion: “The singers can’t see you standing.” Besides being irritated by them and with myself (for being pulled into this quarrel), I was bewildered that anyone could think of a standing ovation as rude. Your thoughts?

headline: Update on Arctic Sea Ice
text: The massive disappearance of sea ice has become one of the bellwether indicators of a changing climate, and for much of the year, it looked like this season might set a new record low for sea ice in the Arctic.

headline: Wife Who Fired 11 Shots Is Acquitted of Murder
text: She had always admitted to killing her husband, using two guns to fire 11 bullets inside the couple’s home in Queens. But she insisted she had no choice: if she had not shot him, he would have surely killed her first.

headline: Viewers Not Scared to Watch ‘American Horror Story’
text: Coming a mere 48 hours after the cancellation of “The Playboy Club,” NBC announced on Thursday that another freshman entry, “Free Agents,” will get the axe after only four episodes. The comedy could only muster 3.3 million total viewers on Wednesday. No replacement has been announced to occupy its 8:30 timeslot. Elsewhere, “The X Factor” transitioned nicely to the “Boot Camp” portion of its competition, roping in 11.5 million total viewers and winning the night for Fox in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic by retaining 100 percent of that demographic when compared to the 90-minute episode that aired last Thursday. CBS was once again the most-watched network with “Criminal Minds” (13.3 million viewers) leading the way.

headline: GOP Candidates and Univision at Odds Over Debate
text: The Univision network is at an impasse with several Republican presidential candidates that may prevent it from hosting a presidential debate early next year.

headline: Monologist Says Jobs’s Death Will Lead to Changes, but Not Softening, in Show
text: The Public Theater’s new production of “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,” a one-man show that is sharply critical of Mr. Jobs and Apple at points, will undergo changes in the aftermath of Mr. Jobs’s death on Wednesday but begin performances as scheduled on Tuesday, Oct. 11, according to its creator, Mike Daisey.

headline: Donors Gave $83,000 to Deficit Panel Members in August
text: Representative Xavier Becerra of California, the senior Democrat on the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Social Security, caused a stir in August when a supporter organizing a fund-raiser sent an invitation to donors highlighting Mr. Becerra’s appointment to the special deficit reduction committee looking for more than $1 trillion in federal spending cuts.

headline: Alcatraz Exhibition at Ellis Island Museum
text: Richard Weideman has spent about 30 years on Alcatraz, though he hasn’t done anything illegal. He is a National Park Ranger who was assigned to supervise operations there in the early 1980s and has been devoted to the island and its many incarnations ever since.

headline: Vinyl Valhalla
text: IN an era when eulogies for record stores are more common than the stores themselves, buying vinyl can feel as virtuous as shopping for locally grown produce or rejecting plastic bags. It can also be a lonely pursuit. Often record buyers are stuck refreshing auction Web sites, browsing half-empty aisles or flipping past copy after copy of Dan Fogelberg’s “Greatest Hits” at a thrift shop.

headline: Balletic Journeys Across the Stage to Inner Worlds
text: It was just another Wednesday night at the ballet, until it wasn’t.

headline: A Pair of Adolescent Outcasts Hit the Road in Search of Freedom and a Father
text: Like its heroine, a rebellious Oklahoma teenager named Danielle, “Dirty Girl” makes an aggressive show of naughtiness. Deep down, though, this movie by the first-time writer-director Abe Sylvia is desperate for approval. Starting out with a blast of profanity and sexual brazenness, it lands in a zone of earnest, sloppy weepiness. You are expected first to be shocked, then supportive, and the proper adult response is probably the kind of patient indulgence you might offer an actual unruly adolescent.

headline: For Woman Found by Police, ‘Unresponsive’ Is Least of It
text: The Police Department, busy elsewhere, can be forgiven for employing a measure of understatement in an ongoing investigation out of Queens.

headline: Letterman Tops Leno Among Younger Viewers
text: It may not be cause for celebration, because his audiences continue to decline, but David Letterman has edged ahead of his long-time rival, Jay Leno, in several important viewer categories as the new television season concludes its third week.

headline: Trembling Before the Turmoil of the Past
text: Since it packs a mini-series’s worth of drama into 90 minutes, it’s no surprise that Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig’s “Lidless” begins at a fevered pace. Alice (Danielle Skraastad), a military interrogator at Guantánamo Bay, is in a sadistic mood, discussing what fresh horrors to unleash on her subjects to get them to talk.

text: The eco-conscious Julie Gilhart shares her must-have high-fashion, low-impact favorites for fall.

headline: Blazer to Step Down From Concacaf Post

headline: Young Doctors Worry About Career Choices
text: Even though young doctors still receive a lot of job offers in one of the worst markets in decades, nearly one-third would select another profession if they had to decide on a career all over again, according to a new study out Thursday.

headline: Mementos of a Lost Battle
text: THE lambs of historic preservation fought the lions of John Portman and his hotel juggernaut at the Battle of the Helen Hayes Theater in 1982. The lions won, and the theater was destroyed, like Carthage. Later this month, anyone who wants a very substantial battlefield souvenir may bid on a truckload of 300-pound pieces of glazed terra cotta.

headline: Bare-Knuckle Bots, Showing Their Mettle in the Boxing Ring
text: You can only imagine the hyperbolic win-win pitch for “Real Steel” that brought this robot boxing movie to the screen: “Transformers” meets “E.T.” meets “Rocky” meets “The Champ,” starring Hugh Jackman of “X-Men” and directed by the “Night at the Museum” hotshot, Shawn Levy. Those are the supposedly surefire selling points behind this entertaining, something-for-everyone contrivance, set in the near future and embellished with flagrant product placement for Dr. Pepper.

headline: Open Mike, Insert Verse
text: WHEN you imagine a poetry reading, the scene that comes to mind probably doesn’t involve battalions of underwear-slinging admirers. Poetry is supposed to be dusty stuff, the reading of which can inspire even a hyperactive 4-year-old to go gentle into that good nap. And yet here is Dylan Thomas’s wife, Caitlin, describing her husband’s famous 1953 performances at the Poetry Center in New York, now part of the 92nd Street Y, “I used to come in late and hear, through the mikes, the breath-strained panting ... booming blue thunder into the teenagers’ delighted bras and briefs.”

headline: In Yankees-Tigers Game 5, Best Pitchers Are Not Starting
text: Iván Nova finished fourth in the A.L. in wins this year. Doug Fister was fourth in the league in E.R.A. While the two pitchers facing off Thursday night aren’t of the same caliber as C.C. Sabathia or Justin Verlander, most fans of both teams are probably cautiously confident in their number two playoff starters. They shouldn’t be.

headline: Is Violence History?
text: It is unusual for the subtitle of a book to undersell it, but Steven Pinker’s “Better Angels of Our Nature” tells us much more than why violence has declined. Pinker, a professor of psychology at Harvard who first became widely known as the author of “The Language Instinct,” addresses some of the biggest questions we can ask: Are human beings essentially good or bad? Has the past century witnessed moral progress or a moral collapse? Do we have grounds for being optimistic about the future?

headline: My Three Favorite Things on Craigslist Today
text: I have innocent reasons for poking around Craigslist. A friend of mine is looking for a studio apartment. I would like to find a not-too-expensive bicycle. But, once on the site, it is hard not to get pulled into all the strangeness that people in New York are selling, buying and generally proclaiming to the world. My three favorite items today:

headline: Starting Early to Create City Teachers
text: The gap between the number of minority teachers in Chicago’s public schools and minority student enrollment has widened over the last decade, but one school is working to change that by preparing the next generation of teachers.

headline: New Top Editor Named for Marie Claire
text: Joyce M. Chang, the former deputy editor at Time Inc.’s People StyleWatch magazine, will become executive editor of Marie Claire.

headline: House Blocks Resolution Demanding Apology From Perry
text: The House decided Thursday not to take up a resolution demanding that Gov. Rick Perry of Texas apologize for not immediately getting rid of a rock bearing the word Niggerhead from a ranch his family once leased in Paint Creek, Tex.

headline: Interview: Michael Fassbender
text: The actor Michael Fassbender talks about his portrayal of a sex addict in Steve McQueen's "Shame."

headline: Room for One and Occasionally More
text: IT didn’t take long for Sarbjit Singh to decide where to buy an apartment.

headline: How Greece Could Escape the Euro
text: Greece would be in much better shape now if it had never joined the euro zone, or if it had been kicked out in 2004 when it admitted that it had lied about its finances to join the club. So would the rest of Europe.

headline: Police Review Board Administrator Draws Mixed Reviews
text: At her first City Council meeting four years ago, Ilana Rosenzweig, the chief administrator of the agency charged with investigating accusations of police abuse, heard this greeting from an audience member: “Welcome to hell.”

headline: For a Bourgeois Frenchman, Happiness Is a Garret Away
text: Lighter than a meringue and as insubstantial, the French boulevard comedy “The Women on the 6th Floor” was designed for the gentle laughter it easily earns. Set in 1962 Paris, the story involves a seemingly hopeless, staid bourgeois businessman whose entire existence — family, career, sense of purpose and patrimony — is overturned after he discovers another, happier world with a group of Spanish maids living in his family’s building. As in Henri Murger’s classic “Scènes de la Vie de Bohème” (and in the Puccini opera), redemption is just a garret away.

headline: ‘Settled Science’ and CO2
text: 6:42 p.m. | Updated There’s an amusing Twitter chat under way via the hashtag #WSJscience, all centered on a Wall Street Journal opinion piece by Robert Bryce of the Manhattan Institute that makes a big deal of the utterly boring fact that climate science is not settled — as if it ever was.

headline: Occupy Anytown, U.S.A.
text: As unions tentatively throw their support behind the Occupy Wall Street protests in New York, new cities are beginning to set up their own versions.

headline: Pleasing Finicky Parents and Nostalgic Texans
text: The mailman dropped off a bunch of questions for me to answer this week. They came from people looking for restaurants to please their parents, and to please themselves. I answered them, but not before handing in a change-of-address card. This is my final column before I take on a new assignment at The New York Times. It has been a great pleasure to serve you. Now, let’s eat!

headline: Steve Jobs’s Media Impact
text: Steve Jobs transformed not just the technology industry, but also music, publishing and even parts of Hollywood. Television was one industry that eluded his revolutionary vision.

headline: New Pilots at the Keyboard
text: If drummers are the engines of jazz, then pianists are often its mapmakers. It’s not just that they’re the bandleaders and the composers; they’re also the content providers, the song finders, the place setters.

headline: A Salon for Musicians Big and Small
text: Having learned to play the violin as a boy, my husband has long harbored fantasies that our 3-year-old daughter, Meenakshi, will someday follow his footsteps into a school orchestra. While researching how she could get started, I stumbled upon Virtuoso Resources. New York has no shortage of places that stock instruments for children, but for young people eyeing the violin, viola or cello, this Upper West Side atelier offers an unusual grace note: a touch of musical history.

headline: Remembering Payton, With Eyes Open
text: I don’t believe the reaction to Jeff Pearlman would have been as harsh if he had written off our lake as an oversized mud puddle or sanctimoniously declared that a fully loaded pizza is as bad-tasting as it is bad for you.

headline: That Odd Boy and the Pilot, Still Together in the Desert
text: “The Little Prince,” the 1943 novella by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, is not just one of the most beloved children’s stories of all time, it is also a parable celebrating the wisdom of the innocent. After all, it’s about a boy from another planet who teaches an aviator who has crashed in the desert what is important in life.

headline: From Met Museum, Virtual Virtue
text: This is something you can do on an ordinary visit to the Metropolitan Museum of Art: view a Versace evening dress from 1991, made of silk and glass, that displays a crowd of heads from Warhol’s James Dean and Marilyn Monroe paintings, and look at the 16th-century armor of George Clifford, third earl of Cumberland, made of steel with elaborate fire-etched gilding. Then you can contemplate Bonnard’s eerily vibrant 1939 painting “The Terrace at Vernonnet,” before turning to a 16th-century violin made in Cremona, Italy, by Andrea Amati, whose maple sides are inscribed with a Latin couplet stating, “By this bulwark alone religion stands and will stand.”

headline: A Trek From Loss and Grief to a Life Given Greater Meaning
text: One thing you quickly realize when you sit down to watch “The Way”: Martin Sheen is a very compelling actor. Another thing you realize more slowly as the film goes along: His oldest son, Emilio Estevez, is a very sensitive director.

headline: Lines That Kept Moving and Knew No Boundaries
text: Maybe every museum, regardless of focus, should know the box-office thrill of staging a Picasso exhibition. In 2006 the Whitney Museum — of American Art, mind you — pulled it off with “Picasso and American Art,” a somewhat flawed effort that examined his influence on a host of major and minor American artists.

headline: The Fantastic and Grisly, Envisioned
text: PURCHASE, N.Y. — These are some of the things Dana Schutz has painted: A portrait of herself as an elephant. A cannibal devouring his own face. The autopsied corpse of Michael Jackson. A giant on a dissecting table. A woman stripping a wood floor with her teeth. The last man on earth.

headline: What Hesse, the Painter, Taught Hesse, the Sculptor
text: The art world tends to see Eva Hesse as an Athena-like figure, an adult from birth. Hesse was just 34 when she died of a brain tumor, leaving behind a prodigious body of work that continues to inform contemporary sculpture.

headline: N.F.L.’s Shift to Pass Goes Into Higher Gear
text: Perhaps the first clue of the approaching N.F.L. revolution came at the end of last season. In a Super Bowl between two old-school franchises, the Green Bay Packers and the Pittsburgh Steelers combined for 36 running plays, a Super Bowl low. It was football for the new age, devoid of balance, an aerial high-wire act from the shoulder-pad set.

headline: Putting Museumgoers on the Fast Track
text: If all goes as planned, the New Museum’s five-year-old building on the Bowery will become something of an amusement park beginning Oct. 26, with visitors hurtling through a giant plastic tube from the fourth floor to the second.

headline: Dishing Out the Trash Talk, by the Forkful
text: “Fear the Fork” is not a rallying cry that immediately brings football to mind. It sounds, in fact, as though it might instead be a warning against eating too much.

headline: Titanic Centennial: Salvage and Memories
text: Artifacts related to the Titanic are emerging on the market in droves in anticipation of next year’s centennial of that ship’s sinking.

headline: Video: Jobs’s Media Legacy
text: Steven P. Jobs transformed not just the technology industry, but also music, publishing and even parts of Hollywood. Bruce Headlam, the media editor of The Times, talks about his impact.

headline: TimesCast | October 6, 2011
text: Steve Jobs' legacy as a technology visionary; how he revolutionized many media industries but struggled to transform television; and the benefits of accessible technology to the physically challenged.

headline: Hacking Isn’t Just for Computer Geeks: A Food Detective Cracks Recipe Code
text: Everybody talks about food — especially on that new ABC chatterfest, “The Chew” — but nobody does anything about it. Oh, sure, someone might show you how to make a caramelized onion tart with olives or bake a cake in the shape of a Viking ship, but is anyone telling you what you really want to know, which is how to have a Cinnabon roll for breakfast without having to get out of your pajamas and drive to a Cinnabon?

headline: Putting Justice Under a Microscope
text: “Incendiary: The Willingham Case” covers a man’s execution in Texas for the murder of his children by arson. But this involving documentary, while sympathetic to opponents of the death penalty, isn’t focused on sorting out the ethical rights and wrongs of the practice. It centers instead on whether we understand or respect evolving standards of scientific evidence.

headline: A Stream of Work That Defies Visual Uniformity
text: Argh! Another year and another several dozen opportunities blown: the American avant-garde filmmaker Ken Jacobs was not anointed a “genius” by the MacArthur Foundation and given a big fat check. Again. (The most recent fellows were announced on Sept. 20.) Only 13 filmmakers have been deemed worthy of that title (Susan Sontag included) compared with at least 84 historians (in different fields), 40 or so poets and two dozen mathematicians. Clearly, at least in one respect, Mr. Jacobs picked the wrong field in which to excel. But a genius of cinema he is, though his primary tools are often light and shadow rather than film.

headline: Thomas W. Toomey
text: Mr. Toomey, 51, is the president and chief executive of UDR, a real estate investment trust specializing in multifamily developments. The company, based in Highlands Ranch, Colo., entered the New York market only this past spring, with the acquisition of 10 Hanover Square in the financial district. It has since added three other properties: Rivergate in Murray Hill, 21 Chelsea, and 95 Wall.

headline: Is That a Bulldozer I Hear?
text: NEW YORK CITY real estate is a canvas that is never quite finished — its landscape and skyline are constantly being redrawn.

headline: Where Stories Are Remembered
text: FOR years, the fourth-floor apartment in Jackson Heights, Queens, where Kewulay and Dionne Kamara raised their family hummed with activity.

headline: Theater Listings: Oct. 7 — 13
text: Theater

headline: Houses Are Few, but Not Far Between
text: FINDING a home with room for a family can be hard enough in New York City. But when Barden and Catherine Prisant decided to sell their house in the East Village because a tall building was to go up next to their beloved backyard, their challenge grew by several degrees of difficulty.

headline: Before the ‘I Do,’ the Self-Discovery
text: Thought piece about identity? Soap opera romance? Light dramedy? Tragedy? “The One” doesn’t find its footing in any of these genres; they just plod around one another uncomfortably.

headline: Paranoia Strikes Deep
text: George Will believes that Elizabeth Warren wants to turn him into a collectivist slave.

headline: A Goodbye to All the Excess
text: PARIS

headline: Triggers for Rejection
text: “WE regret to inform you...” Nobody applying for a new mortgage or a refinancing wants to see or hear these words. But last year more than two million people were turned down for home loans, according to federal data, often because they didn’t meet certain lender requirements or because their applications were incomplete or otherwise problematic.

headline: Brokering Homes, and Mortgages
text: AFTER their children left home several years ago, Carol and Sal Gaetani sold their four-bedroom colonial in Yorktown for $800,000 and took off for Manhattan.

headline: Tigers Cut Short Yankees’ Postseason
text: The Yankees’ dreams of a 28th World Series title were dashed Thursday, as they were eliminated from the playoffs in a 3-2 loss to the Detroit Tigers.

headline: Developers Raring to Rent
text: Rockville Centre

headline: An Unofficial Transit Village
text: WEST WINDSOR

headline: Helpful Sites
text: WHEN the windows of the building across the street get boarded up, chances are good that the building has been sold and plans are being hatched to replace it with something new, and maybe bigger. The building permit posted on the wall may not tell you as much as you would like to know, but your local community board can be a great resource; check its Web site regularly or sign up for regular e-mail updates. Various other Web sites may also offer clues. Here are a few:

headline: Trying Out New Ways to Deliver Health Care
text: PLANO, Tex. — At Village Health Partners, patients receive a year’s worth of wellness exams in a single visit; get their e-mails answered 24 hours a day, 7 days a week; and have their mammogram and M.R.I. results logged into their electronic medical records by the time they pull out of the parking lot.

headline: Surprise! Robin Ventura Takes Over the White Sox
text: Robin Ventura re-joined the Chicago White Sox organization over the summer, as an advisor to the farm director Buddy Bell. He did not aspire to manage, he said, because he believed Ozzie Guillen would stay in the job for a while. It was just a toe in the water.

headline: Q & A
text: A Sponsor Wants to Maintain Control

headline: Afghan Deal With I.M.F. Will Revive Flow of Aid
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s management of its banking system has improved enough that the International Monetary Fund is ready to renew its credit program with the country, the fund said in a statement on Thursday.

headline: What Do You Call This ‘Recovery’?
text: By now, more than 27 months after the economy officially stopped shrinking and started to grow again, the word “recovery” is starting to look like an imprecise way — at best — to describe what’s going on right now.

headline: Charles Napier, Actor Who Played Tough Guys, Dies at 75
text: Charles Napier, a character actor who portrayed ruffians, military officers and other strong men in films like the second Rambo movie, but who played against type as a judge in “Philadelphia,” died on Wednesday in Bakersfield, Calif. He was 75.

headline: White House Orders New Computer Security Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The White House plans to issue an executive order on Friday to replace a flawed patchwork of computer security safeguards exposed by the disclosure of hundreds of thousands of classified government documents to WikiLeaks last year.

headline: Dubow Steps Down at Gannett, Is Replaced by Martore
text: 5:03 p.m. | Updated Craig A. Dubow, the chairman and chief executive of the Gannett Company, who had been on medical leave, resigned on Thursday for health reasons, the company said. Gracia C. Martore, the company’s president and chief operating officer, was named president and chief executive by the Gannett board.

headline: Online U.: Do Students Get an Equal Education?
text: To the Editor:

headline: One Butch Cassidy Myth Is Replaced by Another
text: What if Butch Cassidy didn’t die romantically in a hail of bullets in his Paul Newman prime? “Blackthorn,” an elegiac, old-man’s western, takes as its starting point another, equally romantic myth: that he survived and lived till a ripe old age in Bolivia. It’s 1927 when the movie begins, and Butch (Sam Shepard), who calls himself James Blackthorn, decides to end his long exile and return home. On the way he becomes entangled with a hunted Spaniard (Eduardo Noriega). Adventures ensue.

headline: The Keystone XL Pipeline
text: To the Editor:

headline: Energy Loan Guarantee Official Resigns
text: WASHINGTON — The head of the Energy Department’s loan guarantee office, which approved the ill-fated $528 million loan to the solar panel manufacturer Solyndra, will leave his job on Friday, the department said on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Israel’s Worst Enemy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wickedly Grotesque
text: Images from a new exhibition of works by Dana Schutz.

headline: Breaking the Chains of Chinese Feudalism
text: A patriotic epic about the Chinese struggle to shake off imperial rule, “1911” starts with black-and-white still images of the suffering of the people. It moves on to a scene in which a woman, about to be put to death for supporting Sun Yat-sen’s rebels, is marched through the streets. “I rejoice in my martyrdom,” she says, before the executioner’s knife cuts across the screen.

headline: ‘Picasso’s Drawings, 1890 — 1921’
text: Images from the exhibition at the Frick Collection.

headline: Sharing Too Much Online
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Black Rock Band Struggling in a White Milieu
text: On the heels of “Beats, Rhymes & Life,” Michael Rapaport’s documentary on the hip-hop ensemble A Tribe Called Quest, comes “Everyday Sunshine,” a fascinating account of another musical group’s rise and fall, here the Los Angeles ska-punk rockers Fishbone. Near-rise might be more accurate, as Fishbone, despite a reputation for breathless live performance (vividly apparent in fleeting clips), has never enjoyed the mainstream breakthrough of regional peers like the Red Hot Chili Peppers.

headline: Blazer Quits Regional Post
text: Chuck Blazer announced that he would step down Dec. 31 from his position as general secretary of the Concacaf region. Blazer, 66, has served as the No. 2 man in the region since 1990. Last May, Blazer went public with information that his boss, Jack Warner, had arranged a meeting at which Mohammed bin Hammam, the head of the Asian confederation, offered bribes for votes. “I like to think that I accomplished a lot and now it’s time to move on,” Blazer said.

headline: On Apple’s Campus, Shock and Sadness
text: While the world publicly mourned the death of Steve Jobs on Thursday, Apple employees did so more quietly, as befits a company that prizes secrecy. Some employees said the mood at the company’s headquarters in Cupertino, Calif., was a combination of sadness and business as usual.

headline: Detecting a Thaw in Myanmar, U.S. Aims to Encourage Change
text: WASHINGTON — The United States is considering a significant shift in its long-strained relationship with the autocratic government of Myanmar, including relaxing restrictions on financial assistance and taking other steps to encourage what senior American officials describe as startling political changes in the country.

headline: Not Their Job
text: The American Medical Association and other physicians’ organizations have asked the Congressional “supercommittee” on deficit reduction to impose limits on malpractice lawsuits. The committee has far bigger problems to tackle, and its task of finding $1.2 trillion in deficit savings will be difficult enough. It needs to be wary of getting dragged into this and other such special pleadings.

headline: Real-Life Caped Crusaders on a Mission
text: Fighters for truth, justice and American eccentricity are celebrated in Michael Barnett’s “Superheroes,” a benign documentary portrait of costumed crusaders across the country, chasing evildoers. Among them are Zimmer, leader of the New York Initiative, a team of crime busters conducting late-night “bait patrols” on Brooklyn streets; Mr. Xtreme, a paunchy San Diego security guard camping in his van and wearing a helmet, a cape and goggles; the aging, ebullient Master Legend of Orlando, Fla.; and Thanatos, a 62-year-old in Vancouver, British Columbia, with a black hat, a fearsome green countenance and jeans.

headline: Tax Pledges Lose Allure as Eyes Turn to Reform
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Jason Chaffetz of Utah has signed a pledge never to raise taxes. He signed another pledge too, one that made it nearly impossible to vote for a bill to raise the nation’s debt ceiling. But right before that vote over the summer, in a meeting with scores of his Republican colleagues, he stood up and proclaimed that he would never sign another pledge.

headline: Eric Schmidt: Still More to the Steve Jobs Story
text: Eric Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google and a longtime friend and competitor of Steve Jobs, says Mr. Jobs’s influence may yet be seen in new ways.

headline: Qaddafi Urges Followers to ‘Rise Up’ and Fill the Streets
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the deposed Libyan leader now in hiding, broke more than a week of public silence on Thursday with a recorded message beseeching his followers to flood the streets of their country and “raise our green flags to the skies.”

headline: Mardi Gras as an Explosion of Gay Rights
text: In “The Sons of Tennessee Williams,” the documentarian Tim Wolff tracks a half-century of the gay civil-rights movement through the lens of Mardi Gras celebrations in New Orleans.

headline: In Flip-Flops and Jeans, An Unconventional Venture Capitalist
text: Four years ago, Chamath Palihapitiya, seemed poised for a long career on Sand Hill Road, the famed strip in Menlo Park, Calif., lined with Silicon Valley’s most powerful venture capital firms. As a principal for the Mayfield Fund, one of the country’s oldest venture firms, he wore the industry’s unofficial uniform faithfully everyday, a buttoned-down shirt and pressed pants.

headline: Type of Helicopter in Crash Is Prone to a Rotor Problem
text: The model of helicopter that crashed into the East River on Tuesday is particularly susceptible, in similar conditions, to a loss of tail rotor control, government reports and aviation publications say.

headline: Holiday Near, Time Again to Track Down Perfect Fronds
text: INDIO, Calif. — From a certain vantage point on Arthur Futterman’s date farm, Shulem Ekstein can see palm trees in every direction. Mr. Ekstein has been to many of these farms, waiting at the gate in his black three-piece suit, his prayer shawl poking out from underneath his vest.

headline: Occupied Wall Street, Seen From Abroad
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Answering Questions About the P.S.A. Test
text: News that an influential panel of experts is advising healthy men not to be screened for prostate cancer with a widely used test is certain to cause confusion and anxiety among men and their doctors, and reignites a debate about the benefits and risks of screening tests.

headline: A Killing Better Kept Out of Court
text: Near the end of the cross-examination of Raymond Sheehan, whose mother, Barbara Sheehan, was on trial in Queens for killing his father, one of the jurors appeared to have had enough of the prosecution’s efforts to discredit his testimony about the torments the father visited on the family.

headline: After Years of Rumors, a Tribute to a Titan of Art
text: HIGH FALLS, N.Y. — Marc Chagall slept here. Did you know?

headline: A Petite Folie in Normandy
text: The Chateau Saint-Calais, built in 1663 as a hunting lodge, now is an intimate family retreat.

headline: Iraqi Dispute About U.S. Troops Reflects Clashing Emotions
text: BAGHDAD — How the war ends here is proving nearly as chaotic as the last eight years of fighting and nation building.

headline: Leyland Needs No Advice
text: Jim Leyland has been ahead in the ninth inning of a deciding game, and he’s been behind, and has seen both games turn around, shockingly.

headline: Banned by Many Airlines, These Bulldogs Fly Private
text: When Louie York flew cross country on Sept. 15, his route from New York was anything but direct. First came a stop in Chicago and then one in Omaha, where he endured a six-hour layover.

headline: Romney Rounds Up Backing Among Key G.O.P. Donors
text: Mitt Romney appeared on Thursday to be rapidly consolidating support among some of the Republican Party’s most sought-after uncommitted donors, who have joined Bush administration veterans and other stalwarts of the Republican establishment in backing him as the Republican field settles.

headline: Pakistan Pulls Closer to a Reluctant China
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — As relations with Washington plummeted in the aftermath of the killing of Osama bin Laden in May, Pakistan’s leaders turned to China, which is seen here as an enduring all-weather friend, an alternative to the troublesome and overbearing Americans.

headline: Who Needs a Black Cat? Rally Squirrel Toys With the Phillies
text: PHILADELPHIA — Fans in St. Louis had not seen anything this elusive at Busch Stadium since Lou Brock or, come to think of it, anything this furry since Al Hrabosky.

headline: Some Unemployed Find Fault in Extension of Jobless Benefits
text: Dan Tolleson, a researcher and writer with a Ph.D. in politics, has been out of work since 2009, except for brief stints as a driver. Still, he opposes President Obama’s call for Congress to renew extensions on unemployment benefits.

headline: With Time Running Short, Jobs Managed His Farewells
text: Over the last few months, a steady stream of visitors to Palo Alto, Calif., called an old friend’s home number and asked if he was well enough to entertain visitors, perhaps for the last time.

headline: Senate Nears Approval of Measure to Punish China Over Currency Manipulation
text: WASHINGTON — In one of Capitol Hill’s longest running battles, opponents of China’s trade policies have used threats, negotiation, protests from small American businesses and even the occasional Peking duck dinner in a failed effort to stop China from manipulating its currency.

headline: City Council Grills Kelly on Police Surveillance of Muslims
text: City Council members took aim on Thursday at the New York Police Department’s surveillance of Muslims, pointedly questioning Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly about the breadth of the force’s undercover efforts in the decade since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: The Southern ‘Iron Man’
text: On the morning of Oct. 7, 1861, Thomas Webber, a 27-year-old private in the Confederate Army, and his younger brother Watkins strolled along the beach near their camp in the Florida Panhandle, reminiscing about their home and family in Mississippi as the waves lapped the shoreline. The walk boosted Tom’s morale. He had grown frustrated by inaction and idleness since he and his regiment, the Ninth Mississippi Infantry, had been dispatched to the Gulf coast months earlier. He considered quitting.

headline: Tributes to Steve Jobs Flood Social Media Platforms
text: The tributes to Steve Jobs continued to flood social media platforms from around the world on Thursday with millions of 140-character messages on Twitter, more than 3,000 videos uploaded onto YouTube and tens of thousands of people sharing news links and making comments on Facebook.

headline: Marching in King’s Shadow
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: A Glimpse Of Dussehra Celebrations
text: The festival of Dussehra was celebrated by Hindus across India on Thursday. As per Hindu mythology this day marks the victory of good over evil. It is preceded by nine days of revelry during which devotees fast, pray and feast.

headline: Ties Between Israel and Arab Allies Fray Over Mosque Burning
text: TUBA-ZANGARIYA, Israel — The founders of this Bedouin Arab village in the Israeli countryside tied their fate to that of their Jewish neighbors even before the establishment of the Israeli state in 1948.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Brewers Have Home and History
text: History is siding with the Milwaukee Brewers heading into Game 5 of their National League division series Friday against the Arizona Diamondbacks in Milwaukee.

headline: Building Apple’s Business
text: How Steven P. Jobs transformed Apple.

headline: Protests Offer Obama Opportunity to Gain, and Room for Pitfalls
text: WASHINGTON — Anti-Wall Street protesters marched past the gates of the White House on Thursday, bringing their message of economic injustice to the capital and posing an opportunity, but also a threat, to President Obama, who presents himself as a fervent defender of the middle class.

headline: Prisoner in Mortgage Fraud Sought Hit Man, Charges Say
text: The meeting took place at a gas station near Exit 58 of the Long Island Expressway last month. There, the parents of Aaron Hand, a mortgage broker in prison for a fraud scheme, met with an associate of their son and handed over $150.

headline: The Universe, Dark Energy and Us
text: Friendship, Me.

headline: Jets Dealing With Same Old Doubts
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Sione Pouha had spent the last five minutes or so discussing the Jets’ challenges Sunday at New England, so it seemed only equitable that he offer one in kind: type “New York Jets” and “underestimated” into an Internet search engine and see how many results show up.

headline: Against Nostalgia
text: Editor’s Note: Questions have been raised about the truth of a paragraph in the original version of this article that purported to talk about conditions at Apple’s factory in China. That paragraph has been removed from this version of the article.

headline: Book Business Sees a Bonanza in a Forthcoming Biography
text: It took only hours on Wednesday night for Walter Isaacson’s forthcoming biography of Steve Jobs to shoot up the best-seller list on Amazon.com, eventually moving from No. 384 to the No. 1 spot. On Thursday morning, a book buyer at Powell’s Books in Portland, Ore., quintupled its order of the book, to 500 copies. Simon & Schuster, the publisher, said it was accelerating the publication, moving the release date to Oct. 24 from Nov. 21.

headline: For Children at Risk, Mentors Who Stay
text: Samuel was out of control. He cursed at his teacher, refused to do school work, attacked other kids in the schoolyard — and Samuel was still in kindergarten. His home life was chaotic. He’d never met his father. His mother had emotional and drug problems and was unable to care for him. His grandmother did her best. His older brother was involved in violent crime and had been in and out of jail. He taught Samuel to smoke marijuana when he was 6 years old.

headline: Friday: A Great Man
text: UPDATE to the Administrivial Alert! The tribute puzzle is now available for solving in the timed applets. Thank you for your patience!

headline: Master of the Media Marketplace, and Its Demanding Gatekeeper
text: Last November, Steven P. Jobs finally achieved his long-sought goal of bringing the Beatles to iTunes. But years before he made the deal, he began working on the promotional campaign for the music, personally designing advertisements that would sit in virtual mothballs as long as necessary.

headline: Yankees Hope Burnett Gained Confidence Along With Win
text: A. J. Burnett’s explanation for his game-winning performance in Game 4 on Tuesday was that he got the ball back from the catcher “and just let it go again.” It was a simple approach that could lead him to more successes with the Yankees.

headline: California: Shooting Suspect Killed
text: A man who the police believe killed three co-workers and wounded seven other people was fatally shot by law enforcement officials on Thursday, ending a manhunt that had spread out across several Silicon Valley cities. After a 24-hour search that involved dogs, helicopters and hundreds of law officers, three sheriff’s deputies on patrol spotted a man crouching behind a car in Sunnyvale, about 40 miles south of San Francisco, officials said. Sheriff Laurie Smith of Santa Clara County said all three deputies fired at the man after he showed a gun “in a threatening manner” and they recognized him as Shareef Allman, 47. The authorities say Mr. Allman walked into a Cupertino limestone quarry where he worked on Wednesday and opened fire. He then fled and wounded a seventh person while trying to steal her car for his escape, the authorities said. The man shot by the sheriff’s deputies was pronounced dead at the scene. The coroner had not confirmed his identity as of Thursday evening, but Sheriff Smith said the body matched the description of Mr. Allman.

headline: A Question of Trimming Pay at Goldman Sachs
text: A rare loss potentially looms for Goldman Sachs. A growing number of analysts estimate that the Wall Street titan will slip into the red when it announces third-quarter results.

headline: Following Words Through a Labyrinth
text: When the Swedish Academy bestows the Nobel Prize on a Scandinavian poet, it is hard not to be skeptical. After all, the academy has managed to award the prize to three Swedish poets alone, and the last such poet — Harry Martinson in 1974 — was actually a member of the academy at the time. But it would be wrong to scold the Swedes for elevating their countryman Tomas Transtromer. Mr. Transtromer is not only a first-rate artist, but his selection, announced Thursday, corrects an almost 15-year drought for poetry. (The last Nobel laureate to be known mostly for poetry was Wislawa Szymborska, who won in 1996.)

headline: Charging for Debit Cards Is Robbery
text: WHEN Bank of America told its customers recently that it would start charging them $5 a month to use debit cards, it argued that it was forced to make that change because of regulations that altered the economics of the cards. Other banks agreed. The chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, Jamie Dimon, put the effects of the regulations this way: “If you’re a restaurant and you can’t charge for the soda, you’re going to charge more for the burger.” Both banks were responding to the Federal Reserve’s actions to limit the interchange fees banks charge stores each time a debit card is used for a purchase.

headline: Where Are the Jobs?
text: Let’s imagine that someone from the year 1970 miraculously traveled forward in time to today. You could show her one of the iPhones that Steve Jobs helped create, and she’d be thunderstruck. People back then imagined wireless communication (Dick Tracy, Star Trek), but they never imagined you could funnel an entire world’s worth of information through a pocket-sized device.

headline: Defending Life’s Work With Words of a Tyrant
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The first time Steve Jobs ever bullied anyone was in the third grade. He and some pals “basically destroyed” the teacher, he once said.

text: There’s something happening here. What it is ain’t exactly clear, but we may, at long last, be seeing the rise of a popular movement that, unlike the Tea Party, is angry at the right people.

headline: In California, Raid on Gang Members Leads to 12 Arrests
text: The Vagos Outlaw Motorcycle Gang was dealt a major blow on Thursday, with a series of raids throughout Southern California that led to the arrests of 12 members and the seizure of more than 300 guns. Members are suspected of narcotics trafficking, rape and murder, including the recent killing of a rival gang member at a Nevada casino, according to the California Department of Justice, which led the crackdown. A task force had been investigating the group since last year, leading to 25 arrests and the seizure of 46 pounds of cocaine, more than $37,000 and weapons including a grenade launcher and a rocket launcher.

headline: The Trouble With Greece
text: Europe has been right to demand that, in exchange for bailout financing, Greece carry out painful structural reforms to make its economy more competitive and able to generate more revenue to pay down the country’s huge debts. Without that pressure, Athens would likely never be able to overcome fierce resistance from public-sector unions, professionals, the wealthy and all of the special interests determined to keep doing business as usual.

headline: Apple Innovations Include Start of Big-Budget Super Bowl Ads
text: STEVEN P. JOBS would be an influential figure in advertising even if Apple’s sole contribution had been the “1984” commercial that introduced the Macintosh, which pioneered the idea of big-concept, big-budget spots created especially for the Super Bowl.

headline: ‘A Stubborn Bastion’
text: A federal judge’s order to have a court-appointed monitor oversee the employment practices of the New York Fire Department, “a stubborn bastion of white male privilege,” is entirely justified.

He found that he agreed with what he took to be the movement’s message.

text: Heard of Apple TV? A lot of people have not. That is because even though Steven P. Jobs helped upend so many businesses with a string of groundbreaking products in music, mobile phones, games and tablet computers, he barely made a dent in television.

headline: For Braun, Stadiums Remain His Temple
text: If a player with Jewish heritage reaches baseball’s postseason, the inevitable question is: will he play on Yom Kippur or go to synagogue? It is not a query on the level of the Four Questions that are asked during the Passover seder. But it is one of those curious baseball inquiries — maybe on par with, Does a rising fastball really rise? — that pop up sometimes.

headline: Panel Says U.S. Should Weigh Cost in Deciding ‘Essential Health Benefits’
text: WASHINGTON — The National Academy of Sciences said Thursday that the federal government should explicitly consider cost as a factor in deciding what health benefits must be provided by insurance plans under President Obama’s health care overhaul, and it said the cost of any new benefits should be “offset by savings” elsewhere in the health care system.

headline: Big East Presidents to Discuss Possible New Members
text: The inevitable defection of Texas Christian to the Big 12 conference has left the Big East with just six members in football and a sense of uncertainly about its future in that sport. The league’s presidents will be holding a conference call on Friday morning to discuss expansion possibilities. While nothing is guaranteed, three people with knowledge of the call have indicated that invitations to new members will be discussed and could be decided on the call.

headline: Canada: Catholic Order Settles Sexual Abuse Suit for $17 Million
text: After initially denying allegations of sexual abuse at three Quebec schools it operated, a Roman Catholic order said Thursday that it had settled a class-action lawsuit by the victims with a $17 million payment. In addition to the payment, the Congregation of Holy Cross issued a formal apology. The settlement covers incidents from 1950 to 2001, mostly at an elite Montreal boarding school formerly run by the order, which also controls the University of Notre Dame in Indiana. A separate criminal investigation by the police is continuing.

headline: A Critical Spotlight Shines on Ranked-Choice Voting
text: Steven Hill is not on San Francisco’s November ballot, but few actual candidates have been as influential, or controversial, in this year’s election.

headline: Mid Market, at Last, May Be on the Cusp of Revival
text: While Hal Fischer, interim director of S.F. Camerawork, pondered his organization’s move to the Mid Market district, he conducted an experiment. About three months ago, he went to an 11 p.m. event at the nearby Luggage Store gallery and intentionally parked his car on Sixth and Market, a notoriously troubled block in the midst of one of the city’s most crime-ridden areas.

headline: Contributions to Mayor Raise Issue of Legality
text: A manager at GO Lorrie’s, one of the largest passenger shuttle companies at San Francisco International Airport, solicited and reimbursed as much as $8,000 in contributions from employees to the election campaign of interim Mayor Edwin M. Lee, employees told The Bay Citizen this week.

text: When the Yankees went into spring training in February, they took with them their annual goal of winning the World Series, even if many outside the team did not share that expectation. The Yankees had missed out on signing the free-agent pitcher Cliff Lee, and they carried serious concerns about their pitching rotation and the age of some of their core players.

headline: A Cruel End to a Surprising Season

The third little box belonged to Alex Rodriguez. The fate of the season would fall to him.

headline: Newswallah: What’s in the English-Language Press Friday
text: Officials claimed a breakthrough in the Delhi High Court blast case that killed 15 and injured scores of others a month ago. The National Investigation Agency tasked with finding the perpetrators detained another suspect from the Kishtwar area of Jammu and Kashmir – their third arrest in the case. (Indian Express) Officials say the third suspect, identified only as Wasim, is one of the key conspirators and hatched the plot after being lured by the Harkat-ul-Jehadi Islami in Bangladesh. Jammu and Kashmir Chief Minister Omar Abdullah on Thursday once again dismissed a demand from the main state opposition party that he step down from office after the death of a party worker stoked controversy. (The Hindu) The People’s Democratic Party says Mr. Abdullah may “influence” the judicial inquiry into the death, which he denies.

headline: Rooney’s Father Arrested
text: The father of Manchester United striker Wayne Rooney was one of nine men arrested as part of an investigation into suspicious bets placed on a Scottish league match in December. Rooney’s father, also named Wayne, was arrested at his home in Liverpool. The younger Rooney was not implicated, the police said. The charges stem from the Motherwell-Hearts Scottish Premier League match last Dec. 14. One of those detained was Motherwell midfielder Steve Jennings, who played in the match and was given a straight red card with eight minutes remaining for disputing a penalty decision. It has been reported that several bets were placed on there being a red card in the match.

headline: Has Globalization Helped India’s Poor?
text: Has freer trade decreased or increased poverty and inequality in India? The debate has persisted, almost from the very beginning of India’s embrace of the global economy in 1991.Curiously, also exactly 20 years ago, Americans were engaged in a similar battle of ideas. Mapping its intellectual contours helps give us a fix on the current Indian situation.

headline: Smoke on the Water
text: A couple of natural-gas flares served as the community weather vane throughout my childhood in the coastal town of Marsa Brega, Libya. We looked to the black smoke that billowed from them morning and night to determine what the beach would be like that day. If the smoke blew out to sea, that meant scorching winds off the Sahara and water like glass, ideal conditions for spear fishing and Sunfish sailing. If it blew inland, it signaled a strong wind off the Mediterranean and rolling breakers, great for body surfing.

headline: Libya, the Most Surreal Country on Earth
text: One thing that shines clear in all this is the incredible strength and character of the ordinary people of Libya. They have shown the most outstanding examples of courage and humanity I have ever seen in my life, and I will remember this to the end of my days. They deserve peace and prosperity, and I hope they find it soon.

headline: Stuff Mike White Likes
text: In 2004, Mike White was working on a TV show for Fox, and it was not going well. He’d just had four movies he’d written come out in as many years, among them the critically acclaimed “The Good Girl,” starring Jennifer Aniston, and the commercial hit “School of Rock,” which he wrote for his friend Jack Black, and he felt stressed and overworked. Now White and the network were butting heads over the tone and direction of his new show, which was about a dysfunctional family, but which, White says, the network was trying to push closer to family-friendliness. White felt stuck and misled. “I felt like I was throwing a party, and the party sucked,” he says.

headline: Mindy Kaling
text: Mindy Kaling is a wonderful writer, and she’s right on target about catharsis not being art. It’s self-indulgence. Since when did women’s comedy become all about which pretty face could use the dirtiest words? Talk about a Pyrrhic victory for women’s comedy.

headline: Friends With Benefits
text: Is it unethical for a relatively wealthy person to apply for and receive unemployment compensation, even if he or she meets all the requirements? Is the answer different in times like the present, when government resources are extremely strained? ANONYMOUS, NEW HOPE, PA.

headline: A State is Born in Palestine
text: Sixty-four years ago, in August 1947, the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine presented to the General Assembly a startling and unexpected report, calling for an end to the British Mandate of Palestine and division of most of the territory into two independent states, with the Jewish state occupying the majority of the land. What came next, of course, is well known — a vote in the General Assembly on Nov. 29, 1947, in favor of partition, and the war that immediately followed. The decision is viewed in the Arab world as “the great crime,” and Palestinian leaders, including the current president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, regard it as the original sin that led to the catastrophe, the nakba, that befell their nation — a disaster they now want the General Assembly to remedy. What is not widely known is how a possibly pro-Arab committee, or at least one that was supposed to be neutral, came to issue a report that led directly to the establishment of the state of Israel. What happened on that committee’s trip to Palestine, and how were the minds of its members changed in a way that so radically altered history?

headline: Billy Beane
text: “Moneyball” fails to note one huge factor in the A’s success — pitching. Mark Mulder, Barry Zito and Tim Hudson were dominant pitchers, but there is little in the book or the movie to suggest how Beane got them, what statistics he saw in them or how they managed to have a collective E.R.A. under 3.00. Get a starting crew like that, and you don’t need much O.B.P.

headline: The Greed Police
text: Roger Lowenstein raises the question: Should S.E.C. regulators concentrate on insider-trader cases, which are relatively insignificant but give small investors confidence, or on preventing systemic risk in the financial system? The answer is that it should do both. Regulators are low-paid (in comparison with those they investigate) and are often lawyers who lack the skills to understand the type of securities (e.g., credit default swaps) that led to our recent economic collapse.

headline: Vettel’s Little Accident in Practice
text: SUZUKA, Japan – There was an interesting symmetry in the two first practice sessions Friday in preparation for the Japanese Grand Prix in Suzuka: Jenson Button, the only driver who is still capable of winning the drivers’ championship other than the series’ leader, finished fastest of the day in both the first and second sessions, while Sebastian Vettel, the man who needs only one more point to clinch the title, crashed in the first session.

headline: Nobel Peace Prize Awarded to Three Activist Women
text: LONDON — The Nobel Peace Prize for 2011 was awarded on Friday to three women from Africa and the Arab world in acknowledgment of their nonviolent role in promoting peace, democracy and gender equality. The winners were President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia — the first woman to be elected president in modern Africa — her compatriot, the peace activist Leymah Gbowee, and Tawakkol Karman of Yemen, a pro-democracy campaigner.

headline: What Is Your Personal Credo?
text: Steve Jobs is being eulogized the world over as a leader, innovator and risk-taker whose mantras included the Apple motto “Think different.” What are your own guiding principles?

headline: Week 5 N.F.L. Matchups: Another Turning Point
text: Packers (4-0) at Falcons (2-2)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Packers by 6.Tramon Williams’s end-of-half interception return for the Packers against the Falcons in last year’s playoffs may be remembered as a turning point in N.F.L. history. The Falcons were the better team entering the game, and while the Packers held a 21-14 lead before the play, the Falcons were driving and appeared likely to score. Williams’s interception turned the game into a rout, and the Packers have been unbeatable ever since, while the Falcons have replaced them as the team with a young quarterback and lots of talent that cannot quite get its act together.Of course, for some that turning point arrived a little late. “I’m really surprised that it kind of took him so long,” Brett Favre said of the three interminable years it took Aaron Rodgers to lead the Packers to the Super Bowl. Who knew that through all of those quasi-retirements, through his stints with the Jets and the Vikings, Favre was just impatiently waiting for Rodgers to close the deal? Favre did not sound as if  he was trying to insult Rodgers — he has simply lost the ability to compliment people who are not him — but teammates and analysts have rushed to Rodgers’s defense, which he does not really need.It had been peaceful months since the last self-serving Favre rant. What took him so long? Pick: Packers

headline: Who Made That Crossword Puzzle?
text: Among the items that appeared in The New York Sunday World on Dec. 21, 1913: woman in Yonkers is robbed at gunpoint, aviator Glenn Curtiss vows to make the world’s first transatlantic flight and phone stocks rise after AT&T relinquishes its holdings of the Western Union Telegraph Company to mollify the Department of Justice. Next to these stories, the lighthearted Fun supplement introduced that day would not seem to be terribly newsworthy. Yet featured in “Fun” was the world’s first crossword puzzle, introduced as the “Word-Cross.”

In the beginning Ms. Parker said, “It was kind of a free-for-all and nobody knew what to do.”

headline: Michael Fassbender’s Destructive Journey
text: The actor Michael Fassbender is enjoying quite a year in his film career. After a Charlotte Brontë-inspired spring and a summer as a superhero turned villain, Mr. Fassbender settles into the fall with two serious films screening at the New York Film Festival. In “A Dangerous Method,” he plays the psychiatrist Carl Jung opposite Viggo Mortensen’s Sigmund Freud. And in another psychological drama, “Shame,” he takes on the role of Brandon, a New York man struggling with sex addiction. In this video interview, Mr. Fassbender talks about how he approached his role in “Shame” and how he defined the character.

headline: How Do You Move a 340-Ton Artwork? Very Carefully
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — It is just under 60 miles from the Stone Valley Quarry here — an expanse of dust, boulders, roaring bulldozers and cut granite hillsides — to the lush campus of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art on Museum Mile. Behind a pile of rocks the other afternoon, out of sight from the road, workers scurried around a 340-ton, 21-foot-high solid granite boulder, trussed with red steel girders, gleaming under the desert sun. If all goes well, this boulder will be hovering over a cut in the earth on the grounds of the museum, and be open for viewing, by the end of November.

headline: A Detour on Road to Broadway for ‘The King’s Speech’
text: A stage version of “The King’s Speech,” the film that won the Academy Award for best picture this year, is no longer on a fast track to Broadway, as its author and one of its producers had originally envisioned. The play by David Seidler, who won an Oscar for best original screenplay for the film, will have a world-premiere production in February in Guildford, England, and then tour theaters in five other British cities through mid-March, according to the producers. A London production of the play may follow, according to a spokesman for the show, and Broadway remains a possibility.

headline: Elitist Me?
text: Aarrgghh! Yves Smith totally misreads what I was saying in today’s column, which presumably means that I didn’t write it very well. When I said that it was the job of policy intellectuals to fill in the details for the Occupy Wall Street protestors, I didn’t mean “don’t worry your pretty little heads about it, we’ll work it out”. I meant job literally as in responsibility: people like Joe Stiglitz and me have an obligation to work on this, helping to translate what justifiably angry citizens are saying into more fleshed-out proposals. That doesn’t mean taking the public out of the loop; it means putting whatever expertise you have to work on the public’s behalf.

headline: The Lowdown | Arashi Yanagawa
text: Suffice it to say that, in Japanese, Arashi Yanagawa’s first name means “big storm.” The son of a taxi driver, Yanagawa made a name for himself as a professional boxer over a four-year career that included winning the Japanese national championships. Having satisfied his father’s deepest aspirations for his son, Yanagawa moved on to his new passion: fashion design. With no schooling or training, he simply started making clothes, founding the brand John Lawrence Sullivan (named after the Irish boxer) and learning as he went. Seven years later, JLS is one of the more respected men’s-wear companies in Japan and Yanagawa maintains a solid reputation as an excellent designer. Now, he is turning his sights on men’s-wear for women.
