headline: In Iowa, Ethanol Can Still Trip Up a Candidate
text: Even in Iowa, King Corn is not all that it used to be. But can it still make a presidential candidate waffle?

headline: Ramiz Alia, an Enforcer for a Dictator and Later Ruler of Albania, Dies at 85
text: Ramiz Alia, a cult-of-personality enforcer who succeeded Albania’s Communist dictator Enver Hoxha after his death in 1985 and presided over halting and often chaotic moves toward democracy before his own downfall in 1992, died Friday. He was 85.

headline: Future of Euro Could Depend on Slovakia
text: The prospect of guaranteeing the debt of richer like Greece, Portugal and even Italy has led to public outrage in Slovakia.

headline: Rivalry Is a Sign of Order Inside the Churning Big 12
text: DALLAS — Tickets are distributed with such an air of domestic tranquillity that Texas and Oklahoma might as well be exchanging his-and-her bathrobes.

headline: 672 School Jobs Are Lost in Largest Single-Agency Layoff Under Bloomberg
text: Some of them spent the past few days scouring the wanted ads on the New York City Department of Education’s Web site. Others made sure they learned how to file for unemployment benefits.

headline: Silk Monsoons Cascade Into a Homeland Tale
text: LONDON — The ever-present tensions between history and identity, the collective past and the personal present; the paradoxical state of being that is the condition of the second-generation immigrant. These ideas are at the heart of Akram Khan’s finest choreography. And “Desh,” his first full-length solo work, which opened here at Sadler’s Wells on Tuesday, is undoubtedly among the best pieces that Mr. Khan has created.

headline: Ships, Steeds and Kings, on Two Legs
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — How can this demonstrate that? How can art demonstrate life or history or another work of art? With the speech “O for a muse of fire,” Shakespeare starts his play “Henry V” with words about the challenge for theater of trying to represent war. (“Think, when we talk of horses, that you see them.”) When Laurence Olivier made his 1944 film of “Henry V” he quickly bypassed the issue of theater, showing his audience real horses, real arrows, real armor, real grass; and he commissioned music by William Walton to help make the movie exciting and affecting.

headline: Horrors of a Coming War Painted in a 1935 Meeting
text: On July 17, 1935, The New York Times published a statement by Varian Fry in which that young American, the editor of Living Age magazine, described anti-Jewish rioting that had taken place in Berlin two nights earlier. His account was horrific, and not only because of what it foreshadowed: ordinary Germans joining Nazi thugs in what he characterized as a “holiday mood” of bloody anti-Semitic violence. “Old men and young men,” Fry wrote, “boys, Storm Troops, police, young girls of the domestic servant type, well-bred women, some even in the forties and over — all seemed to be having a good time.”

headline: Woods Plays Better and Has the Same Expectation: Victory
text: SAN MARTIN, Calif. — The fog that delayed the start of Tiger Woods’s second round for over two and half hours on Friday eventually lifted, and so did the gloom enveloping his game.

headline: Philharmonic Union Authorizes Strike
text: In a sign of potential conflict to come, the musicians of the New York Philharmonic, above, have voted to authorize their representatives to call a strike, two orchestra members said on Friday. The players spoke on condition of anonymity because orchestra leaders ordered the members not to discuss the matter. The musicians’ contract expired on Sept. 20, but they have continued to perform, not an unusual practice. Several musicians say the atmosphere seems tenser than in the past, amid fears that a diminished contract could induce players to leave for teaching jobs or other top-tier orchestras like the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Chicago Symphony. At the same time, the orchestra has 16 openings. Members of the orchestra’s negotiating committee declined to comment. In a statement the orchestra’s management said the strike authorization vote, held last week, was “standard procedure” and had no effect on its desire to reach an agreement. “While there are serious issues under consideration, we are hopeful that a new agreement will be reached, and that the orchestra will continue to perform according to the published concert schedule,” management said. Both sides “are currently engaged in negotiations,” it added, but orchestra officials declined to elaborate or to provide details on contacts between the sides.

headline: For Mayor, ‘Occupy Wall Street’ Evokes Protests From Vietnam Era
text: The simmering discontent that has provoked the Occupy Wall Street protests has prompted numerous historical comparisons. Some are calling the movement a liberal version of the Tea Party. Others see a repeat of the 1930s populism that accompanied the New Deal.

headline: Life for ‘Walking Dead’
text: Just in time for people to catch up with “The Walking Dead,” the AMC series that begins its second season on Oct. 16, the first season is now streaming on Netflix. The drama, about survivors of a zombie infestation, is the most prominent part of a multiyear content-licensing deal announced Friday by Netflix and AMC. The arrangement is the latest display of Netflix’s determination to license back-seasons of top television shows, diversifying its streaming service beyond feature films. This year the company struck a deal with Lionsgate, the producer of AMC’s “Mad Men,” to stream previous seasons of that show. Some other AMC Networks shows will also be streamed on Netflix “just prior to the premiere of subsequent seasons,” according to a news release. Those include “Portlandia” on IFC, “Braxton Family Values” on WE and “All on the Line With Joe Zee” on the Sundance Channel. Netflix did not disclose the terms of the deal, but it has been willing to pay substantial amounts for other shows and films.

headline: U.S. Attorneys in California Set Crackdown on Marijuana
text: LOS ANGELES — Federal officials on Friday warned dozens of marijuana dispensaries throughout California to shut down or face civil and criminal action as part of a major crackdown on the state’s growing medical marijuana industry.

headline: Embracing His Inner ‘Obamacare’
text: As part of his newfound assertiveness, President Obama is using the term “Obamacare,” the Republicans’ sneering dismissal of the Democratic health care reforms. We are skeptical that he will be able to turn it into a term of approbation. But it is heartening to see him finally out there defending his pioneering policy with no apologies and an uncharacteristic feistiness.

headline: Musical Themes, Covering Landscapes
text: Red Light New Music’s thematic concerts can seem either inventive or fanciful, depending on whether a listener is persuaded that the works at hand touch on the program’s unifying notion. The group’s season opener at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia on Monday evening was called “In a Landscape: Music as Map,” and it was meant, according to the season prospectus, to include works “influenced by physical environments, from the arctic to the urban to the volcanic.”

headline: Senator Protests Agency Decision to Remove Doctor Data Online
text: Senator Charles E. Grassley on Friday joined with dozens of academic researchers, consumer groups and journalism organizations who have protested an Obama administration decision to pull off the Web a database of doctor malpractice and disciplinary cases.

headline: A Suit Yields a Telling Effect on the Play in Another Suit
text: The Arthur L. Loeb Cup was played on Tuesday morning. There were 90 pairs competing, many of whom were pro-am partnerships. The tournament was held at, and the entry fees benefited, the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House in Manhattan, to which Loeb, an avid bridge player, has been a generous supporter.

headline: U.S. Envoy Puts Match to Bridges With Iraq Tell-All
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Fox Renews ‘The Simpsons’ for Two More Seasons
text: The Springfield nuclear power plant will remain operational, and it won’t be closing time at Moe’s Tavern for at least two more years: on Friday night, Fox announced that it had renewed its hit animated comedy “The Simpsons,” television’s longest running prime-time scripted series, for two additional seasons, following a contract dispute with its voice cast that had threatened to end the show altogether.

headline: ‘Will Barnet at 100’
text: A mainstay of the New York art world for eight decades gets his first retrospective there.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Paris
text: The caravan arrived in Paris for the final shows of the spring 2012 collections, carrying luggage filled with autumn clothes. Paris suffered a heat wave, and the guests stripped down.

headline: Poland’s European Union Ties May Hinge on Elections
text: BERLIN — Poles are set to vote on Sunday in elections that could well determine whether the country continues its deepening cooperation with European Union allies under Prime Minister Donald Tusk or lurches back toward a more confrontational course under its former leader.

headline: Senator Paul, Lift the Hold
text: Here’s an addition to the file marked “Extreme Dysfunction: Congress Edition.” A bill that would extend life-saving cash assistance to 5,600 disabled and elderly refugees — a bill whose support is so broad that it includes Senators Charles Schumer of New York and Jeff Sessions of Alabama, a bill that would pay for itself and even raise a bit for deficit reduction — can’t get through the Senate.

headline: In Search of ...
text: Two very good officials are leaving two of the most important jobs in New York State — one by choice, the other because Gov. Andrew Cuomo has asked him to go. Mr. Cuomo needs to quickly find exemplary replacements to run the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. And he will have to support them when they make politically tough but necessary decisions.

headline: California Prison Hunger Strike Resumes as Sides Dig In
text: LOS ANGELES — When inmates across California’s state prisons went on a hunger strike in July, prison officials negotiated with them, ultimately reaching an agreement to bring the strike to an end after three weeks.

headline: The Outcast of Brownstone Brooklyn
text: The scarlet letter may have little currency left in the realm of sexual indiscretion, but it continues to be put to vigorous use among parents — the shaming impulse particularly thrives in the wealthier precincts of brownstone Brooklyn, where the exacting standards of urbane motherhood would seem to have been invented. In a place where judgment is easily rendered on those who allow their children to drink juice, there is not much sympathy available to someone like Providence Hogan, who was charged by the Brooklyn district attorney’s office last March with embezzling from the PTA.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Ten Years In, Afghan Myths Live On
text: TEN years after invading Afghanistan, on Oct. 7, 2001, the obvious question is whether or not the United States has won the war. Osama bin Laden’s death suggests the defeat of Al Qaeda. But even after the planned withdrawal of 30,000 American troops by late 2012, nearly 70,000 will remain on the ground.

headline: Stuck in Traffic? A Star Is Born
text: IF most jobs in television are not as fabulous in real life as they seem from the battered couches of the people watching at home, the job of NY1 early-morning traffic reporter has a particularly high grunge-to-glamour imbalance: You’re on the air at 5 a.m. Your job is to tell viewers when the 2/3 trains are running local south of 34th Street and just how backed up the BQE is, in exactly 60 seconds.

headline: Chic in Review | The Million Dollar Blogger?
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Among 3 Women Awarded Nobel Peace Prize, a Nod to the Arab Spring
text: SANA, Yemen — She is only 32 years old, an outspoken human rights activist and mother of three who was unknown outside her own country until she began leading anti-government protests this year.

headline: Prominent Pastor Calls Romney’s Church a Cult
text: WASHINGTON — A Texas pastor introduced Rick Perry at a major conference of Christian conservatives here on Friday as “a genuine follower of Jesus Christ” and then walked outside and attacked Mitt Romney’s religion, calling the Mormon Church a cult and stating that Mr. Romney “is not a Christian.”

headline: Brewers Beat Diamondbacks in Game Five
text: Nyjer Morgan delivered an R.B.I. single in the 10th inning to beat the Arizona Diamondbacks 3-2 Friday in Game 5 and send the Brewers to the National League championship series.

headline: A Garage Is All Aglitter for Art’s Sake
text: We were in a decommissioned bus depot at Pier 57 in Hudson River Park when the artist Chuck Close buzzed past us with his girlfriend, Sienna Shields, seated in his lap on his electric wheelchair. Their lips passionately interlocked, and they never looked up as they rolled out the door. It was Wednesday night, and the Whitney Museum of American Art’s yearly gala, held this year under disco balls in an asphalt-and-steel garage, was wrapping up.

headline: Liberian Peace Activist Learns of Nobel Peace Prize While on Book Tour
text: Soon after she walked into the chapel, Leymah Gbowee of Liberia started singing. She was still having a hard time believing she had just won the Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: Brewers Advance by Beating Diamondbacks in 10th Inning
text: MILWAUKEE — The man of many personas, Nyjer Morgan, flitted from euphoria to sadness in the aftermath of the most important hit of his career.

headline: Scan-to-Buy Gets a Trial on Television
text: In a television experiment, shoppers this weekend watching HSN, the shopping network, can scan their TV screens with a smartphone to learn more about the products on display, and, HSN hopes, become more inclined to buy them.

headline: Kite Fighting in New York
text: A group of Pakistani immigrants in New York are preserving a traditional South Asian sport.

headline: Perry Disagrees With Supporter’s Comment on Mormon Church
text: TIFFIN, Iowa — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said Friday night that he does not believe the Mormon Church is a cult, but he declined to answer questions about a remark from a Texas pastor who criticized the religion of Mitt Romney and declared that he “is not a Christian.”

headline: Collateral Damage in the Chinatown Bus Wars
text: In 2004, a seat on a bus from Chinatown to Boston cost $10, but the related costs were sometimes staggering. Indirectly, the bus business took the life of a cocktail waitress one night at work; she was killed by a stray bullet to her head. Hundreds of man-hours of police work would follow, as would the efforts of Interpol and various police agencies in the United States and Canada seven years later.

headline: Numbers Scribbled Here and There Added Up to $600,000 in Bribes, U.S. Says
text: In recent years, federal prosecutors say, Wendell B. Walters has spent a fair amount of time scribbling down numbers on little pieces of paper.

headline: Doctor Tells How Jackson Sought Sleep
text: In an interview recorded two days after Michael Jackson’s death, Dr. Conrad Murray told the Los Angeles police that he had spent hours trying to get the singer to sleep using milder drugs before resorting to a powerful anesthetic that Jackson referred to as his “milk.”

headline: A.I.G. Unit and a French Bank Settle a Lawsuit
text: Crédit Lyonnais, a French bank, will pay $150 million to settle a suit filed by the American International Group’s SunAmerica unit over its 1993 investment in a California insurance company that the French bank had illegally acquired.

headline: Unleashing the Scientist in the Student
text: “Be careful!” shouted a seventh grader from Coney Island’s Mark Twain Intermediate School 239 for the Gifted and Talented.

headline: Koch and N.Y.U. Clash Over Terrorism Report
text: A report on terrorism prosecutions written by scholars at New York University’s School of Law has set off an ugly fight, pitting the school against former Mayor Edward I. Koch and Representative Peter T. King in what one side calls a question of intellectual freedom, and the other says is a matter of intellectual honesty.

headline: One of ‘Cuban Five’ Spies Is Released on Probation
text: MEXICO CITY — When five Cuban intelligence officers were charged with spying against the United States in 1998, the Cuban government immediately hailed them as heroes, with billboards, books and movies, and argued that their convictions and sentences — handed down in a Miami court — proved that the United States was an enemy, beholden to radical Cuban exiles.

headline: Calendars Shed Light on Enigmatic Bloomberg Aide
text: Patricia E. Harris, the first deputy mayor, is arguably the most important unelected person in city government and may also be seen as the personification, as the head of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s charitable foundation, of the blurred lines between the mayor’s public and private lives.

headline: That Felon Inspecting Trash? He Used to Be Mayor
text: My encounter with Gerry McCann began with a warrant for my arrest.

headline: Pipeline Review Is Faced With Question of Conflict
text: The State Department assigned an important environmental impact study of the proposed Keystone XL pipeline to a company with financial ties to the pipeline operator, flouting the intent of a federal law meant to ensure an impartial environmental analysis of major projects.

headline: In Schools, Yoga Without the Spiritual
text: TO “om” or not to “om”: For those who teach yoga in schools, that is a question that arises with regularity.

headline: Wall Street Weeks
text: The Occupy Wall Street encampment in Lower Manhattan is covered with damp sleeping bags, interspersed among piles of wet, abandoned clothes. Molding stuff is everywhere. It looks like a scene from “Outdoor Hoarders.”

headline: Brief Encounters, Messengers and Guides
text: WHEN Tennyson wrote that it is “better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all,” he could hardly have imagined the possibilities posed by the fleeting encounters described in the Missed Connections section of Craigslist. Now, Sophie Blackall picks up where Tennyson left off in “Missed Connections: Love, Lost & Found” (Workman Publishing), a witty, wistful collection of illustrations and commentary that originated on her blog and found their way into a charming little book.

headline: Corrections: October 8
text: NATIONAL

headline: Saturday: Sounds Like a Broken Record
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — When The Kids were younger, I hired a teenager to babysit so I could get out of the house and have a coherent thought once a week. One evening, the teenager showed up wearing a T-shirt that had a picture of the plastic inserts we used to put into the large holes of 45 r.p.m. records so that we could play them on our turntables. Strictly out of curiosity (and not masochism, as some of you are no doubt thinking), I asked the 15-year-old if she could tell me what the object on her T-shirt was, and thoroughly enjoyed the fact that she could not. The closest she could get, being only 15, was that the picture on her shirt was “neat.” To her credit, she knew that a turntable was something on which her Dad used to play records. Whatever those were.

headline: Mexico: Prosecutor Quits After 32 Bodies Are Found
text: The chief prosecutor in Veracruz State resigned Friday, a day after 32 bodies were discovered in a residential neighborhood and less than three weeks after 35 bodies were dumped on a busy highway. The state prosecutor, Reynaldo Escobar Pérez, resigned for unspecified “personal reasons,” a spokeswoman said. The departure came as federal forces flooded Veracruz and arrested 20 suspects believed to be members of rival drug gangs. President Felipe Calderón hailed the arrests on Twitter as a “great blow” to criminal gangs.

headline: Holder Reacts to Criticism of Gun Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. lashed out at members of Congress who are investigating Justice Department actions in a disputed gun-trafficking inquiry, saying Friday in a letter that public discussion about the issue had become “base” and “inflammatory” and was aimed solely at gaining political advantage.

headline: Revenge of the Gougers
text: The hardest part about writing about Bank of America’s dunderheaded plan to impose a $5-a-month fee on debit card users is deciding which of the many juicy angles to pursue. “Have Bank of America’s Managers Lost Their Minds?” asked The American Banker earlier this week. That’s one good angle.

headline: Yanks’ Rodriguez Insists He Is Up to the Challenge
text: The lasting image from the Yankees’ failed 2011 playoff campaign was almost identical to the lasting image from their exit in 2010. The only difference was that this year, Alex Rodriguez went down swinging for the final out. Last year he looked at strike three to end Game 6 of the American League Championship Series.

headline: A Night Owl Explores by Day
text: For Cosmo Baker, a D.J., music producer and writer, Sundays are a chance to wind down from traveling — coming trips include ones to South Africa and Dubai — and late-night Saturdays, while relaxing and exploring the city. Mr. Baker, 37, lives with his wife, Sydney Peck, a lawyer, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Unearthing the General

headline: Podcast: Steve Jobs, Unemployment and Patriotic Spending
text: The death of Steve Jobs has set off a global outpouring of tributes rarely seen for a business figure. What made him so special?

headline: Snapshots of Layoffs’ Effect, From the Newly Unemployed
text: The last school bell on Friday was the beginning of unemployment for 672 employees in roughly 350 city schools — school aides, parent coordinators, health aides and other support staff members. These are four of the school workers who were let go.

headline: A Michigan Star Says His Game Has Matured
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — When Denard Robinson arrived at Michigan three years ago, he spoke so fast that his offensive linemen could not understand him. He also delivered every check-down pass like Justin Verlander. And Robinson’s feet gyrated so quickly during his cameos in the pocket that he looked more like a tap dancer than a quarterback.

headline: Warm Reception for Bachmann at Values Conference
text: Representative Michele Bachmann liked the looks of the crowd gathered at the sixth annual Values Voter Summit meeting in Washington on Friday.

headline: Nocturnalist at Joan Rivers’s House
text: Nocturnalist visits a party at Joan Rivers’s house.

headline: Desperately Seeking Someone
text: Let’s get this out of the way: The presidential election is more than a year away, and things can and will change between now and then. Caveat: check!

headline: The Turban, Defiled by Suicide Bombers, Has Biblical and Emotional Roots
text: Charlottesville, Va.

headline: It’s Like Sharks vs. Jets as Senate Wrangles Over Vote, but Without Music
text: WASHINGTON — Of the multitudinous insults that have zinged across the Capitol this year, a taunt most brutal was leveraged by the Republican leader, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky on the Senate floor on Thursday night. He accused the Democratic leader, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, of “fundamentally turning the Senate into the House.”

headline: Let Go by Boston, Playing on Into October
text: The teams that will play for the American League pennant both found unlikely sources for upgrading their lineups last winter. The Texas Rangers and the Detroit Tigers signed free agents cut loose by the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Tigers-Rangers Series May Signal A.L. East Is No Longer Ascendant
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Jim Leyland sounded too exhausted to be concerned about anything but sleep. The Yankees had been vanquished, Detroit’s starting pitchers were back to resembling their normal rotation, and the Tigers will be facing a Texas team they defeated six times in nine games during the regular season.

headline: Panel’s Advice on Prostate Test Sets Up Battle
text: A day after a government panel said that healthy men should no longer get screened for prostate cancer, some doctors’ groups and cancer patients’ advocates began a campaign to convince the nation that the advice was misguided.

headline: Effects of the Standard & Poor’s Downgrade
text: Performance of treasury bonds, stocks, and the dollar since Standard & Poor’s downgraded United States treasury debt.

headline: After a Rating Downgrade, U.S. Treasuries Turn a Profit
text: TWO months ago, Standard & Poor’s downgraded the bond rating of the United States government. So far, at least, the move has done wonders for investors in the very bonds that the rating agency disparaged.

headline: General’s Career Is Stalled No More
text: The Army general who served as the military’s top intelligence officer in Afghanistan, but then found his career stalled after a controversial profile of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal appeared in Rolling Stone magazine, received his third star on Friday as he became the assistant director of national intelligence. The officer, Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn, was the top intelligence officer for the Joint Chiefs of Staff before he joined General McChrystal in Kabul to oversee a revamping of the American-led mission in Afghanistan. He pioneered new intelligence techniques to understand terrorist and insurgent networks, and to track and attack their leadership. However, after General McChrystal was abruptly relieved of command by President Obama following the publication of the unflattering magazine profile, General Flynn saw his promotions frozen. But two official investigations, by the Defense Department and the Army, found no proof of any wrongdoing by General McChrystal or by anyone on his command staff.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: The debt crisis in Greece continued to threaten to drag down Europe, the Occupy Wall Street protests gained union support, and Steven P. Jobs, the visionary co-founder of Apple, died.

headline: McKnight Showing the Athleticism the Jets Counted On
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets’ special-teams coach, Mike Westhoff, has just one guideline for those who return kickoffs: they need to be moving forward when they catch the ball. There are no invisible lines in the end zone that make a kickoff too deep to return.

headline: In G.O.P. Race, Foreign Policy Is a Footnote
text: WASHINGTON — Herman Cain suggested that Israel’s conservative prime minister would be open to allowing Palestinians right of return to the lands they fled in what is now Israel. Gov. Rick Perry suggested it was possible that American troops could be sent to Mexico if drug violence there got worse. And former Senator Rick Santorum offered that the United States should engage with the ousted Pakistani dictator Pervez Musharraf — now living in self-exile in London — to respond to the threat of Pakistan’s nuclear weapons falling into the wrong hands.

headline: Carpenter Finishes Off the Phillies
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Philadelphia Phillies banked their season on baseball’s most timeless adage: good pitching stops good hitting. It led them to 102 victories, the most in the history of the franchise. It would, they hoped, carry them to their second championship in four seasons.

headline: Insurers Review Whether to Still Pay for Routine Screening
text: Insurers and clinicians scrambled on Friday to decide whether to continue to offer routine P.S.A. tests following news that an influential panel of experts no longer recommended them for healthy men.

headline: Waiting Is Painful for Giants’ Top Pick
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The arrival of the rookie Giants cornerback Prince Amukamara has been little more than a tease to this point. He has been at practices, but not practicing. He has been a part of the team, but not a part of the action.

headline: Cardinals Beat Phillies in Game Five
text: The St. Louis Cardinals beat the Philadelphia Phillies in game five.

headline: Swashbuckling Times in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — On the contemporary streets of Los Angeles this past week, it became obvious, via billboards and bus posters everywhere, that Hollywood had developed a sudden fascination with the 17th Century. High and low, the symbols were there: swords, doublets and big floppy hats with a jaunty tilt.

headline: Split by War, Libya’s Team Reunites With a New Goal
text: Among the many Libyans who took sides in the country’s civil war were members of its national soccer team. A former captain of the team called the anti-Qaddafi rebels rats and dogs, while several of his teammates took up arms against the crumbling government. James Montague visited the reconstituted team in Zambia, where on Saturday it will try to clinch a berth in next year’s African Cup of Nations. Read his article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Secret Gardener
text: An artist who designed and maintains the grounds of Grey Gardens worked to preserve the spirit of the home’s original occupants.

headline: Evergreen ‘Gardens’
text: The legend of the two Edith Beales, the subject of a new dramatized film version of “Grey Gardens” on HBO, continues to resonate.

headline: Inside Grey Gardens
text: An exclusive look inside the legendary house shortly after it was purchased by Sally Quinn and Benjamin C. Bradlee in 1979.

headline: The Threat of Black Carbon
text: Soot — also known as black carbon — from millions of villages like Kohlua, India, is emerging as a major source of global climate change.

headline: Holiday Parking Rules
text: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Out of the N.B.A., Thomas Retains Influence There
text: The N.B.A.’s brightest stars will take their talents to Miami on Saturday night, to a smallish gymnasium at a public research university with no particular athletic identity.

headline: Want to Catch a Thief? There’s an App for That
text: The police arrested a 23-year-old Queens man on Friday for stealing an iPhone earlier in the week — and they found him with the aid of an app.

headline: The World This Week — Part 1
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: After 4 Weeks, the 2011 Top Fantasy Football Experts
text: The New York Times has a reputation for having an intellectually advanced readership. Who would have thought, though, that this high I.Q. would also apply to fantasy football predictions? The readers of this blog happen to be sitting atop our Start/Sit Accuracy Challenge, which tracks how accurate several communities are at making our most difficult “Who should I start?” decisions. Congratulations on the strong showing thus far.

headline: A Contentious Ride Into Beijing
text: Not long ago, the roads in and around Beijing were clogged by bicycles. Last week, however, the cars, trucks and buses that are the city’s new source of congestion were cleared away to make room for cyclists. But cyclists of an elite variety.

headline: The World This Week — Part 2
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Diane Cilento, Oscar-Nominated Actress, Dies at 78
text: Diane Cilento, an Australian actress whose long stage and screen career included an Oscar-nominated performance in the 1963 movie “Tom Jones,”   died in Queensland, Australia, on Thursday, a day after her 78th birthday.

headline: Tigers-Yankees Game 5 Draws High Rating
text: The Tigers’ series-clinching win over the Yankees on Thursday night on TBS attracted an average of 9.7 million viewers, the most to watch a league division series game on cable and the most since a Yankees-Angels game on Fox in 2005.

headline: Piero Weiss, Pianist and Musicologist, Dies at 83
text: Piero Weiss, a former concert pianist and recording artist who turned to musicology, becoming an author and co-author of books in the field, including a widely used textbook, and founding the music history department at the Peabody Conservatory, died on Sunday in Baltimore. He was 83.

headline: Battle for Surt | October 7, 2011
text: Anti-Qaddafi soldiers were positioned near the front line in Surt while wounded fighters were given medical care.

headline: A Decade of Dominance — Against Only One Team
text: Over the past 10 seasons, the Yankees have played nine first-round division series. In four instances, the opponent was the Minnesota Twins, and the Yankees won every one of those series. Against everyone else, they lost.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: An uncensored video clip of two senior leaders hurling abuses at each other in the Jammu and Kashmir Assembly on Monday has gone viral in the Valley.  The 141-second long clip, in Kasmiri, of the bitter exchange between Assembly Speaker Mohammad Akbar Lone and members of the opposition party MLA, has been featured on hundreds of Facebook pages. (Kashmir Live)Haryana: The local administration in the Karnal district of Haryana launched a Facebook campaign to protect females. The impetus behind the drive is to raise youth awareness about the social fallout of a skewed sex ratio. (The Tribune)

headline: All the Colors of Friday’s Qualifiers
text: It’s tough to wrap up 24 qualifying games in a comprehensive way, so let’s hit the highlights with a spin around the color wheel.

headline: Sweet and Sour Suzuka Qualifying Session
text: SUZUKA, Japan – We finally we had an interesting qualifying session for the front-runners. Never mind that Sebastian Vettel took the pole position again, his 12th in the 15 possible this season. The last laps of the session were worth the wait to watch the suspense as the leading drivers crossed the line probably the thickness of a sheet of paper apart: Jenson Button, who was fastest in every one of the three practice sessions this weekend, lost the pole position to Vettel by a few thousandths of a second.

headline: Sweet and Sour Suzuka Qualifying Session
text: SUZUKA, Japan – We finally we had an interesting qualifying session for the front-runners. Never mind that Sebastian Vettel took the pole position again, his 12th in the 15 possible this season. The last laps of the session were worth the wait to watch the suspense as the leading drivers crossed the line probably the thickness of a sheet of paper apart: Jenson Button, who was fastest in every one of the three practice sessions this weekend, lost the pole position to Vettel by a few thousandths of a second.

headline: The Wizard and the Mortal: Two Sides of Genius
text: IN August 1931, Thomas Alva Edison, age 84, became gravely ill with kidney problems. He recovered a little, then suffered a setback and was confined to bed at home, drifting in and out of consciousness. Newspapers issued multiple bulletins each day, reporting on signs of improvement or decline. The end came in the early morning of Oct. 18, 1931, with his family at his bedside.

headline: The Power of Taking the Big Chance
text: STEVE JOBS, technologist and tastemaker of modern digital culture, described himself as a captain of product design, inspiring his teams of workers, as he once said, to go “beyond what anyone thought possible” and to do “some great work, really great work that will go down in history.”

headline: Chrysler Then and Now
text: The smallest of the three American automakers has been known for its innovations and for its brushes with insolvency.

headline: Drop that Guitar and Put Up Your Hands…
text: Aug. 6, 2012, 10:39 a.m. | Updated | The Justice Department has closed its criminal case against the Gibson Guitar Company after the company agreed to a series of steps, including payment of $300,000 and forfeiture of hardwood from India and Madagascar with an estimated value of $264,000. The details can be read in a news release.

headline: Do You Know These Fans?
text: Alex Rodriguez exited stage right Thursday night after striking out to end the Yankees’ season far sooner than many fans had hoped. Can you help us identify any of the fans in this photo who were there to see him off? E-mail us at nytsportsphoto@gmail.com.

headline: Slide Show: Life After the Yankees
text: Hideki Irabu, a former New York Yankee who committed suicide in July, had tried to make a baseball comeback in California’s Golden Baseball League.

headline: 3 in Indonesia Charged With Plotting Suicide Attacks
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The Indonesian police arrested three men on Saturday and accused them of plotting two suicide attacks in the last six months that injured scores of people.

headline: Ah Yes, LM (Wonkish)
text: Brad DeLong, Mark Thoma, Matt Rognlie, and others are debating the usefulness of the textbook IS-LM model. So, my inflation-adjusted two cents.

headline: 30 Seconds With Clark Gillies: Ex-Star Hopes Isles Shine
text: Clark Gillies, a former Islanders star, rang the Nasdaq closing bell recently, and the bell survived. In fact, the market jumped after Gillies, a rare player who could fight as well as shoot and skate skillfully, performed the honors. Gillies, 57, was a key player when the Islanders won four consecutive Stanley Cups from 1980 to 1983. A member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, he was recently honored at the 26th Annual Great Sports Legends Dinner to benefit The Buoniconti Fund to Cure Paralysis.

headline: Praying, Then Producing a Hit
text: Many directors think of their work as a kind of religion, but few actually refer to their production company as “a moviemaking ministry” — unless of course they are the people behind Sherwood Pictures. The Georgia-based Sherwood Baptist Church has released four films, and its latest, “Courageous,” has shown once again that it has a way with Christian audiences.

headline: Souter’s Career
text: Justice David H. Souter, the 105th justice to be appointed to the Supreme Court, plans to retire in June after more than 18 years on the court, people informed about the decision said.

headline: Embedded at Firebase Vimoto
text: Some of the hour-by-hour conduct of the war in Afghanistan rests on young American servicemen who lead Afghan troops as their training and instincts guide them.

headline: Act IV for U.S. and Klinsmann
text: Across the Atlantic Ocean, qualifying matches in the group stage for Euro 2012 conclude Tuesday. In the Concacaf region, the preliminary round of World Cup qualifiers is in full swing. And in South America, the marathon tournament that will lead to Brazil in 2014 has finally begun.

headline: The Backwards S Of Doom (Wonkish)
text: Greg Ip reports on a Bank Credit Analyst analysis of the euro crisis that emphasizes the possibility of multiple equilibria; it’s similar in spirit to what I’ve been saying, but with a niftier picture:

headline: Re-Shoring
text: Ugly new term, but apparently the new thing; it refers to companies moving production back to America from China. The fact that such stories are being heard is support for those (including me) demanding action on the renminbi, because they show that there is indeed a margin at which changes in Chinese dollar costs move production back to the United States, and hence that the undervalued renminbi directly costs US jobs, as well as having the indirect effects I’ve written about recently.

headline: Big City Book Club: Privilege and Strife
text: Next up for the Big City Book Club is “This Beautiful Life,” the latest novel by Helen Schulman. The book revolves around a digital pornography scandal set amid the immense privileges and antagonisms of the New York private-school world. Join Ginia Bellafante, the Big City columnist, for a live online discussion of the novel on Tuesday, Oct. 18, from 1 p.m. to 4 p.m.

headline: The Leading Interpreters of a Turbulent Era
text: FOR music lovers of a certain age and inclination, the late-1960s love affair between Judy Collins and Stephen Stills remains an epic tale, and the piece Mr. Stills wrote about it — “Suite: Judy Blue Eyes” — retains its hallowed place in the canon. Little wonder, then, that Ms. Collins, in a recent conversation, grew animated when discussing the song.

headline: Celebrating Warhol at a Shrine to Pollock
text: Andy Warhol was obsessed with fame. You might say that it was his only consistent medium, and that everything else he did — painting, film, sculpture, publishing — was just a vehicle for examining its properties and effects. Now the Pollock-Krasner House and Study Center has taken his most famous utterance, “In the future, everyone will be world-famous for 15 minutes,” and used it as a springboard to create an exhibition.

headline: Al Davis, the Controversial and Combative Raiders Owner, Dies at 82
text: Al Davis, the irascible owner of the Oakland Raiders whose feuds with the National Football League reshaped professional football over the last half century and helped spur its rise to pre-eminence in the landscape of American sports, died Saturday morning. He was 82.

headline: Giants’ Umenyiora Perfects Pass-Rush Move, Building Career Around It
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora can trace the transformation of his career back to a single game film he watched in 2005.

headline: Three Characters in Their Own Separate Worlds
text: When you’ve seen a show in New York and then go to see it in New Haven with the same director (Charlotte Moore) and two-thirds of the same cast, you expect a similar experience. But the Irish Repertory Theater production of Brian Friel’s drama “Molly Sweeney” at Long Wharf Theater yields only two-thirds of the New York experience, which is lovely. The other third is, I’m sorry to say, annoying.

headline: Even in a Locker Room Apart, an Undeniable Leap of Progress
text: The most exceptional thing about Brianna Amat, who has become known as the Kicking Queen, is not her twin accomplishments as homecoming queen and place-kicker. It is that she feels accepted as a full member of the high school football team in Pinckney, Mich.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Patriots’ Offense Soars as Defense Stumbles
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The explosiveness of the New England Patriots’ offense through the first four weeks has been startling. Their quarterback, Tom Brady, leads the league in passing yards and touchdowns thrown. Their top receiver, Wes Welker, is on pace for 160 receptions and 2,464 yards. Only one team — unbeaten Green Bay — has scored more points.

headline: Revitalized Lions Suddenly a Hot Ticket
text: ALLEN PARK, Mich. — Down the hall from where Detroit Lions Coach Jim Schwartz characterized his team’s first “Monday Night Football” appearance in 10 years as nothing more than a tough division game, the veteran wideout Nate Burleson stood at his locker and hyped the game against Chicago like a preacher in a revival tent.

headline: A Play (in a Boston Preview) Within a 1940s Comedy
text: Gertrude Lawrence. Billy Rose. Guthrie McClintic. Do those names mean anything to you?

headline: Variety: A Somewhat Base Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — The quote immortalized in today’s Acrostic puzzle is a confession of sorts, and a fascinating peek into the mind of a brilliant man. Walt Whitman, nineteenth century poet and essayist, admits readily that what the American people wanted to read was the sort of thing he wanted to read himself. His 1855 collection of poems, “Leaves of Grass,” was considered immoral in its day for its honest portrayal of sensuality.

headline: Romney Tries to Reassure Socially Conservative  Audience
text: WASHINGTON, D.C. — Though Mitt Romney has stuck to a relentless focus on jobs and the economy while on the campaign trail, he departed from his usual message Saturday morning at the Values Voter Summit, devoting part of his speech to the socially conservative issues the crowd had come to hear about.

headline: France and Wales Reach Semifinals
text: France beat England, 19-12, to reach its fifth consecutive Rugby World Cup semifinal, where it will play Wales for a spot in the Oct. 23 final.

headline: Grab a Brew! Lederhosen and Dirndl Are Optional
text: OKTOBERFEST thrives on clichés: brimming tankards, dirndled Mädchens, assorted wursts. And the White Plains Oktoberfest Street Fair, from 3 to 8 p.m. Sunday, as well as the Oktoberfest at Bear Mountain State Park, held every weekend through the end of October, offer variations on the theme — beer, brats and music by bands like Alpine Squeeze and the Austrian Boys.

text: What began as a small group of protesters expressing their grievances about economic inequities last month from a park in New York City has evolved into an online conversation that is spreading across the country on social media platforms.

text: PHILADELPHIA — Chris Carpenter was the last member of the St. Louis Cardinals to leave the field at Citizens Bank Park late Friday night.

headline: Domestic Workers Convention May Be Landmark
text: WASHINGTON — When governments from around the globe passed a treaty in June to protect domestic workers, labor experts called it a surprising breakthrough for millions of exploited women.

headline: State Did Not Rush on Fracking, Commissioner Says
text: From the quietness of his office, Joe Martens, head of New York State’s Department of Environmental Conservation, answered questions on Saturday morning about the charged topic of natural gas drilling in an hourlong session online.

headline: Killing of Opposition Leader in Syria Provokes Kurds
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Tens of thousands of people poured into the streets of a Syrian city on Saturday for the funeral of a celebrated Kurdish opposition leader whose assassination the day before unleashed fury in the country’s Kurdish regions and threatened to open a new theater of opposition to President Bashar al-Assad’s rule.

headline: Susie’s Broke Yuppie Granola
text: As a self-taught cook for a family of five, I’m not exact about measurements — or anything. I just eyeball it and taste. If it seems good, I’m happy.

headline: Vacuum Is Feared as U.S. Quits Iraq, but Iran’s Deep Influence May Not Fill It
text: NAJAF, Iraq — As the United States draws down its forces in Iraq, fears abound that Iran will simply move into the vacuum and extend its already substantial political influence more deeply through the soft powers of culture and commerce. But here, in this region that is a center of Shiite Islam, some officials say that Iran wore out its welcome long ago.

headline: Russian Anger Grows Over Chechnya Subsidies
text: MOSCOW — Twelve years ago, a little-known bureaucrat named Vladimir V. Putin began a war on Chechnya, vowing to crush a fierce rebellion and return the territory to the Kremlin’s control.

headline: At Delhi 6, Cooking From Scratch
text: AT Delhi 6 in East Windsor, it’s tempting to begin a meal with dessert when the dessert in question is house-made paan ice cream, every bite a hint of exotica, every flavor an invitation to plan an extended trip to India.

headline: No Itty Bitty Tea Shoppe Here
text: It’s hard not to feel virtuous having tea at Terra at the Isabel Rose in Montclair, even if you’ve tipped your blood glucose level into the danger zone with an apricot-ginger scone or a slice of apple-blackberry-raspberry pie. The owner, Grace Chow Grund, says a great majority of ingredients in the baked goods, sandwiches, wraps and salads she sells at the tearoom are organic and from local farms. Teas and coffees are fair trade, and most are organic.

headline: A Clash of Paper, String and Glass
text: Immigrants fight in Brooklyn for the most kites downed, and the kite fighter with the best handling skills wins.

headline: Extra Point Is Almost Always Good; Is That a Good Thing?

headline: Inmate’s Release Brings Call for New Evidence Law
text: Not long after his mother was murdered, 3 1/2-year-old Eric Morton began to tell his grandmother what he had seen that terrible day.

headline: Giddy Winnipeg Reclaims Lost Prairie Companion
text: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — After an absence of 15 years, the Winnipeg Jets return to life Sunday afternoon. Which is a good thing because the emotions sweeping the citizens of this prairie city at their beloved club’s rebirth have grown to a pitch so fevered that they are practically uncontainable.

headline: Lawmakers End Boycott of Parliament in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Near the white tent where an ousted Afghan lawmaker lay moaning in bed, slowly starving herself in political protest, her onetime colleagues in Parliament congratulated themselves Saturday on their decision to return to work.

headline: A Reality for Caddies: Pink Slips on Greens
text: SAN MARTIN, Calif. — The caddie Joe LaCava was standing outside the scoring trailer waiting for postround instructions from his new boss, Tiger Woods. Scattered showers, which were in the forecast, and sprayed shots, which were not, had dampened LaCava’s debut with Woods at the Frys.com Open. Cutting through the postround gloom, Woods’s agent, Mark Steinberg, approached LaCava and wryly congratulated him on his first round.

headline: A Long Time in the Making, a Brewers-Cardinals Rematch
text: Three years later, the memory was still vivid for Mark Attanasio, the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers. Before a game at Miller Park last month, Attanasio described the scene on the field in 2008, when the Brewers clinched a playoff berth and he learned just how much the team means to his adopted city.

headline: Up From Ugliness
text: FROM the 1960s through the 1980s, the United States of America conducted a long experiment in ugliness. Our architects grew bored with beauty, our designers tired of elegance, our urban planners decided that function should trump form. We bulldozed row houses and threw up housing projects. We built public buildings out of raw concrete. We wore leisure suits and shoulder pads, buried heart-of-pine floors under shag carpeting, and paneled our automobiles with artificial wood.

headline: Where Have You Gone, Joe DiMaggio?
text: THE melancholy over Steve Jobs’s passing is not just about the loss of the inventor of so many products we enjoy. It is also about the loss of someone who personified so many of the leadership traits we know are missing from our national politics. Those traits jump out of every Jobs obituary: He was someone who did not read the polls but changed the polls by giving people what he was certain they wanted and needed before they knew it; he was someone who was ready to pursue his vision in the face of long odds over multiple years; and, most of all, he was someone who earned the respect of his colleagues, not by going easy on them but by constantly pushing them out of their comfort zones and, in the process, inspiring ordinary people to do extraordinary things.

headline: Protesters Against Wall Street
text: As the Occupy Wall Street protests spread from Lower Manhattan to Washington and other cities, the chattering classes keep complaining that the marchers lack a clear message and specific policy prescriptions. The problem is that no one in Washington has been listening.

headline: Davis Lived Up to the Label of Maverick Till His Death
text: Amy Trask glanced out her office window Saturday morning and glimpsed some fans — one of them with a dog in an Oakland Raiders jersey — who had come to the team’s training center to pay their respects to Al Davis, the iconoclastic, iconic, iron-fisted owner of the team that was defined by him, and in turn reflected him. The youngest of those fans who made the pilgrimage probably thought of Davis as a throwback, perhaps a bit of an eccentric with his white or black Raiders track suits, his Brylcreemed hair, a man whose recent misjudgments of players and coaches had consigned the team to losing, occasionally cartoonish seasons.

headline: Fans Raise a Glass to Al Davis
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the back of Ricky’s restaurant in San Leandro, the unofficial headquarters of Raider Nation, a booth was empty Saturday afternoon except for the memories on the tabletop: a Super Bowl XV program; a Raiders program from a Sept. 27, 1964 home game against the Kansas City Chiefs with Al Davis on the cover, stalking the sideline; the California license plate JST WN BBY; a Raider beer mug, a Raider helmet telephone and two pennants, one from the 1977 Super Bowl at the Rose Bowl.

text: More than 2,000 people protesting potential cuts to the national health care system staged a sit-in on Westminster Bridge in London on Sunday afternoon, blocking traffic on one of the city’s busiest bridges, The Guardian reports.

headline: Fighters Enter City Once Home to Qaddafi
text: SURT, Libya — Former rebel fighters battled their way into the heart of this coastal city on Sunday, seizing a sumptuous conference center used by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to entertain heads of state, but more recently by his loyalists as a base for their fierce defense of this city, his birthplace.

headline: Key Negotiators Make Final Effort to Save Games
text: On the night before the N.B.A. was to begin canceling games, league and union officials gathered one more time Sunday night, but once again parted without an agreement, or any overt signs of progress.

headline: Shobukhova and Mosop Win Chicago Marathon
text: CHICAGO — Striding across the finish line with a burst of speed, Liliya Shobukhova of Russia secured her third straight victory at the Chicago Marathon, becoming the first runner, man or woman, to accomplish that feat.

headline: Excerpt: 'Man and Boy' on Broadway
text: Frank Langella, left, and Adam Driver in a scene from the revival of Terence Rattigan’s 1963 play “Man and Boy.” (Video courtesy of the Roundabout Theater.)

headline: ‘Real Steel’ Is No. 1 at the Weekend Box Office
text: Boxing robots were No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend, as “Real Steel” (DreamWorks Studios/Disney) sold an estimated $27.3 million in tickets. That total was solid, but the picture, which stars Hugh Jackman as a reluctant father, will need to continue drawing large audiences to justify its hefty production budget of $110 million and tens of millions more in marketing support. Many critics disliked “Real Steel,” but audiences, especially younger moviegoers, gave it strong marks in exit polls.

headline: Matisse Sculptures to Be Auctioned
text: Since January experts at Sotheby’s have been trying to privately sell a suite of four bronze sculptures of a woman’s back that Matisse created over a period of 23 years beginning in 1908. The works belong to the Burnett Foundation in Forth Worth, and at the time the sale was announced, neither Sotheby’s nor the foundation would say what the asking price was, although dealers approached by the auction house reported that they were hoping for around $200 million for all four.

headline: No Fun? N.C.A.A. Outdoes the N.F.L.
text: And you thought the N.F.L. was the No Fun League.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘6 Days to Air: The Making of South Park’
text: There are almost as many laughs in “6 Days to Air: The Making of South Park” as there are in an actual episode of “South Park.”

headline: Support From a Love Sprite and Some Fractured Friends
text: Romantic and sexual trauma pervade “Cheerful Insanity: Chao and Katzberg in Repertory,” two plays of contrasting sensibilities at the Here Arts Center. Each barely an hour and running on different dates, they are both confessional in nature and intriguing.

headline: Paul McCartney Marries Again
text: Beatles fans now have two reasons to toast to their favorite band each Oct. 9: On what would have been John Lennon’s 71st birthday, Sir Paul McCartney married Nancy Shevell in a small civil ceremony on Sunday at Marylebone Town Hall in London, The Associated Press reported.

headline: IS-LMentary
text: A number of readers, both at this blog and other places, have been asking for an explanation of what IS-LM is all about. Fair enough – this blogosphere conversation has been an exchange among insiders, and probably a bit baffling to normal human beings (which is why I have been labeling my posts “wonkish”).

headline: Week 5 Live: Jets-Patriots Win Probability
text: As the Fifth Down has done several times already this season, we will be using a Web feature from Advanced NFL Stats that charts win probability live during today’s Jets-Patriots game.

headline: Was Failure Inevitable?
text: Ezra Klein has a generally reasonable analysis of the Obama administration’s failure to respond with sufficient force to the economic crisis. Broadly speaking, he’s saying that the eurovenn applied: an economically adequate response lay beyond the bounds of the politically feasible.

headline: In Rare Rally, Somalis Aim at Militants
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Thousands of residents of this bullet-scarred city packed into a stadium on Sunday to denounce the Shabab Islamist group for the suicide bombing last week that killed scores of people, many of them students.

headline: Syria Demands That Nations Reject Opposition Council and Protect Its Embassies
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria warned countries on Sunday not to recognize a new opposition group, the Syrian National Council, and threatened to take “strict measures” against any that did.

headline: A.L.C.S. Game 2 Postponed
text: After two rain delays interrupted Game 1 of the American League Championship Series on Saturday night, Major League Baseball did not take any chances on Sunday. With more rain expected Sunday night, Game 2 of the series between the Texas Rangers and the Detroit Tigers was postponed Sunday afternoon, about seven hours before the scheduled first pitch. It was rescheduled for Monday afternoon at 4:19 Eastern. Tigers Manager Jim Leyland also announced that right fielder Magglio Ordonez injured his right ankle in Game 1 and is out for the rest of the postseason. More details are available here.

headline: A Voice, Still Vibrant, Reflects on Mortality
text: HOUSTON — Christopher Hitchens, probably the country’s most famous unbeliever, received the Freethinker of the Year Award at the annual convention of the Atheist Alliance of America here on Saturday. Mr. Hitchens was flattered by the honor, he said a few days beforehand, but also a little abashed. “I think being an atheist is something you are, not something you do,” he explained, adding: “I’m not sure we need to be honored. We don’t need positive reinforcement. On the other hand, we do need to stick up for ourselves, especially in a place like Texas, where they have laws, I think, that if you don’t believe in Jesus Christ you can’t run for sheriff.”

headline: Poland’s Centrist Leader Claims a Second Term
text: WARSAW — In the race to govern Poland, Prime Minister Donald Tusk appeared to have a strong lead on Sunday over his conservative rival and predecessor, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, while a party that supports gay rights, abortion and some drug legalization seemed set to win representation in Parliament for the first time.

headline: Preparation by Pitcher Is Fiction; Postponement of Game 2 of the A.L.C.S. Is Real
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Sunday’s rainout of Game 2 of the American League Championship Series gave Texas Rangers starter Derek Holland another opportunity to watch a brief segment of the most important movie in his life, a movie he has never watched to its conclusion.

headline: Church Protests in Cairo Turn Deadly
text: CAIRO — A demonstration by Christians angry about a recent attack on a church touched off a night of violent protests here against the military council now ruling Egypt, leaving 24 people dead and more than 200 wounded in the worst spasm of violence since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak in February.

headline: Gun Control and Gun Rights Stay Fighting Words
text: In “Gunfight,” his provocative, highly uneven new book about the fight over gun control, the constitutional law professor Adam Winkler writes that “gun rights and gun control are not only compatible; they have lived together since the birth of America.” He argues that “despite the controversy over the meaning of the Second Amendment, Americans have always had the right to keep and bear arms as a matter of state constitutional law. Today, nearly every state has such a provision in its own constitution, clearly protecting an individual right unattached to militia service.”

headline: Giants Get Signals Crossed and Win Streak Snapped
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Antrel Rolle thought he was covering the outside receiver. So did Aaron Ross. Osi Umenyiora and Mathias Kiwanuka swore they heard a whistle. Others were less certain.

headline: This Work Is About the Movers and Shakers
text: “Self-indulgence is the key to all art,” Ishmael Houston-Jones remarked at New York Live Arts on Wednesday. He was referring, in particular, to himself and his fellow dancers, who he insisted were all “narcissistic egotists.” Considering the money they make, he asked, “Why else would you do it?”

headline: One Disease, Many Faces and Many Personal Paths
text: Take some celebrity directors, the Lifetime network and  Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and what do you get? A teary, perfectly tolerable collection of interlocking stories featuring lots of recognizable actors and two particularly well-etched segments.

headline: Don’t Let the Bedbugs Bite, and Kiss Blankie Goodbye
text: Presumably some parents of young children, not grasping the concept of parody, have actually been reading Adam Mansbach’s filthy best seller, “Go the ____ to Sleep,” to their progeny at bedtime. Now comes the anti-Mansbach: “Pajanimals,” a puppet television show in an evening time slot that is intended to help the little buggers nod off.

headline: After New Pledge to Leave, Signs of Yemeni President’s Resolve to Linger
text: CAIRO — Amid all the chaos and conflict that have engulfed Yemen, one fact seems immutable: President Ali Abdullah Saleh will not voluntarily leave office any time soon.

headline: Giants Still Own City’s Hearts, but Jets Are Closing in Fast
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Rap in and of Brooklyn, With the Rumble of the Subway Trains
text: When an orchestra wants to play outside it usually ends up in a park, a pastoral setting for picnicking and music that is familiar and not too demanding: Bernstein’s “West Side Story” Suite, say, or Mozart’s “Jupiter” Symphony. The audience is generally as white as the wine.

headline: Harvey Weinstein Is Under the Microscope Again
text: Taking its cue from a subject who’s always been able to sell sizzle sans steak, “Unauthorized: The Harvey Weinstein Project” is a bit of bait and switch. While its title implies a tawdry tell-all, this documentary actually delivers a virtual tribute to Mr. Weinstein, who co-founded Miramax Films, helped revolutionize American independent cinema and cultivated a reputation as a dyspeptic bull in the china shop of art-house sensibilities. Mr. Weinstein may not have authorized the director and producer Barry Avrich’s rather pedestrian film. But he won’t be throwing any telephones.

headline: A Composer’s Repertory in Broad Brush Strokes
text: The philosophy behind the Composer Portraits series at the Miller Theater of Columbia University runs contrary to the kind of program you will find on almost every other concert stage in town, any day of the week. Instead of mixing works by different composers to form juxtapositions that illuminate each (or not), the Miller series generally provides a handful of pieces by a single composer, providing in its best instances a useful and nuanced overview of one artist’s development.

headline: Bad Day? Some Om Will Cure It
text: There is anger management, but does anyone ever do anything about excessive joy?

headline: Monday: Dee-lish!
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This one went down very smoothly. A nice Monday grid that fell in great big chunks, and as soon as I sussed out the CC part of the theme, my brain said, “Oh, I really hope there are 10 of these! ‘Ten cc’ would be such a great theme!”

headline: Film Fest Gleams Mysterious This Year
text: In its 49th incarnation, well into respectable middle age, the New York Film Festival has experienced a growth spurt and a burst of youthful energy. The Film Society of Lincoln Center, which hosts the festival, expanded its footprint last summer, with the opening of the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center, a street-level miniplex across West 65th Street from the lofty terrace of the Walter Reade Theater. The festival’s offerings have expanded accordingly, with more classic films and retrospectives, a new documentary program and a larger selection of Views From the Avant-Garde, in addition to the 27 features in the main slate.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the trade deficit for August and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and retail sales for September, import prices for September, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for October and business inventories for August (Friday).

headline: Sinopec to Buy Daylight Energy for $2.1 Billion
text: Sinopec of China agreed on Sunday to buy Daylight Energy, a Canadian oil and natural gas producer, for about $2.1 billion in cash, as Chinese companies increasingly flock to Canada’s oil-rich resources.

headline: A Tipoff From the Bidding Results in a Different Lead
text: When you have a 4-4 fit in a no-trump contract, you will get at most four tricks from the suit. But if that is your trump suit, you will usually get an extra trick by ruffing a loser in one hand or the other. This is why players like 4-4 trump fits. However, methods like Stayman that search for a 4-4 fit suffer from one disadvantage: if a 4-4 fit is not found, the defenders have been given free information about declarer’s hand.

headline: More TV Shows Canceled
text: Three weeks into the new television season, prime-time schedule changes are beginning to pile up, as four new shows effectively have been canceled. CBS confirmed Saturday that it had halted production on the sitcom “How to Be a Gentleman,” with David Hornsby and Kevin Dillon. That came a day after the network decided to move the sixth season of “Rules of Engagement” into its Thursday time slot. “Gentleman” joins the NBC sitcom “Free Agents” and the CW reality show “H8R,” both of which were pulled from their slots on Thursday. Earlier in the week NBC made “The Playboy Club” the first victim of the fall season; the new drama “Prime Suspect” will run in its 10 p.m. Monday time slot until Oct. 31, when the newsmagazine “Rock Center With Brian Williams” starts.

headline: Immigrant Detainees
text: To the Editor:

headline: Financial Romanticism
text: One line I’ve been seeing in various places, including comments here, is the claim that the real way to deal with Wall Street is laissez-faire economics: no more bailouts! On this view, policy makers should raise their right hand in the air, place their left hand on a copy of Atlas Shrugged, and swear in the name of A is A that they will never again step in to rescue failing banks. And all will be well with the world.

headline: Two Early Films From John Akomfrah
text: Two early films from the British-Ghanian documentarian John Akomfrah are on view at the Maysles Cinema in Harlem, one eyeing black history, the other the future. Both are thought-provoking, and they coincide with the premiere of this director’s latest work, “The Nine Muses,” at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: The Nuremberg Trials
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Tribute to Michael Jackson
text: A concert in Wales honored the singer.

headline: Free Texts Pose Threat to Carriers
text: At a time when e-mail and many other forms of electronic communication are essentially free, wireless carriers are still charging as much as 20 cents to send a text message to a phone, and another 20 cents to receive it.

headline: One Outlaw’s Campaign for Urban Decorum
text: Jason Shelowitz has made it his mission to educate New Yorkers on proper urban decorum. All he had to do was break the law. Seventy times.

headline: Freud as Philosopher
text: Sigmund Freud, that seer of the psyche, taught that you could be angry and not know it. You can also be a philosopher and not know it. And Freud was just that, an unconscious philosopher of the unconscious — one who had nary a positive word to say about philosophy. Just listen to him grouse in 1933:

headline: Drawbridge in Connecticut Becomes Stuck, Disrupting Metro-North and Amtrak
text: The failure of a 100-year-old drawbridge over the Norwalk River in Norwalk, Conn., disrupted service on Sunday afternoon for hundreds of rail travelers who were forced take shuttle buses when more than six trains could not cross the river.

headline: Christians Clash with Police in Cairo
text: At least 24 people were killed Sunday when a protest by Egyptian Christians over the burning of a church escalated into rioting against military rule.

headline: Free Trips Raise Issues for Officials in Education
text: Since 2008, the Pearson Foundation, the nonprofit arm of one of the nation’s largest educational publishers, has financed free international trips — some have called them junkets — for education commissioners whose states do business with the company. When the state commissioners are asked about these trips — to Rio de Janeiro; London; Singapore; and Helsinki, Finland — they emphasize the time they spend with educators from around the world to get ideas for improving American public schools.

headline: Food Trucks, Celebrities and a Madison Avenue Walk of Fame
text: HERE is a look at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of Advertising Week 2011, which took place in New York last Monday through Friday.

headline: For Archie Comics, a Return to Superheroes
text: The comic-reading public may need to revise its vision of Archie Andrews, the perpetual teenager from Riverdale. This year alone Archie Comics has announced a continuing series for Kevin Keller, the town’s openly gay resident, digital versions of its regular series on the same day they are released in comic stores, and Spanish translations of its material for download.

headline: Giants Run Aground vs. Seattle
text: A few talking points after the Seahawks’ 36-25 victory over the Giants on Sunday:

headline: Israeli Cabinet Backs Outline for Social Change
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government on Sunday approved recommendations for new housing, education and tax measures to address the demands of the protests that swept the country during the summer.

headline: Attendance List
text: These are the state education commissioners who attended international conferences on education financed by the Pearson Foundation, the nonprofit arm of the Pearson company, one of the nation’s largest educational publishers. The list was provided by the Council of Chief State School Officers, a nonprofit group that represents the officials.

headline: ‘Tavis Smiley’ on Poverty Tour
text: Tavis Smiley has described it as “a call to conscience.”

headline: In Washington, Everyone Seems Mad at Teammates
text: Every poll shows it: Americans are hopping mad at Washington.

headline: Rise in Health Premiums
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nobel Winner Doesn’t Want to Talk About It on the Campaign Trail
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — The Nobel Peace Prize is a high-voltage endorsement for a president seeking a second term to receive four days before the election. But analysts questioned whether it would have much impact in Liberia, a sweltering tropical nation where nearly half the population cannot read.

headline: Jets Stagger Against Patriots, Losing 3rd Straight
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The door to the visiting interview room at Gillette Stadium swung open Sunday evening, and in walked Mark Sanchez. His arms were folded, his lips pursed and his eye black fresh and unsmeared. He just stood there, in full uniform save for his helmet, for about five minutes, leaning against a door as Rex Ryan, coach of the free-falling Jets, detailed his team’s struggles for a third consecutive Sunday.
