text: To the Editor:

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes a weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Standing Out in a Hyperachieving Crowd
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bats Replace Brickbats as Brewers Rally
text: MILWAUKEE — The National League Championship Series had been portrayed as a clash of philosophies, a battle between new-school ostentation and old-school politesse.

headline: Banks Brace for Fallout on Earnings
text: The protesters who have gathered for weeks near Wall Street and the highly paid investors and analysts in the buildings that surround them don’t agree on much.

headline: Staving Off Change to the Grit of the Bowery
text: It is the original boulevard of broken dreams, a street where a flophouse or two still lingers from its days as Skid Row, and where every day hungry men jostle through the doors of a remaining Christian mission for a hot meal.

headline: Declining Household Income
text: Real household income has fallen by about 10 percent since the start of the last recession

headline: Recession Officially Over, U.S. Incomes Kept Falling
text: WASHINGTON — In a grim sign of the enduring nature of the economic slump, household income declined more in the two years after the recession ended than it did during the recession itself, new research has found.

headline: Volcker Rule Could Leave Some Murky Wiggle Room
text: It was a tall order, but America’s banking regulators have taken a good stab at devising a framework for the Volcker Rule.

headline: At Clairvoyant’s Funeral, Sharing Tales of Treasure Found and Crimes Solved
text: Maybe he really did see it coming. Just indulge the possibility, friends and family plead. Maybe he knew this was how his story would end, with a funeral inside a nondescript chapel in the Bronx, evolving quickly from a solemn remembrance to a parade of eager testimonials from former clients, who were not accustomed to being in the company of believers.

headline: Biggest U.S. Banks Struggling
text: Revenue and income at the nation’s biggest banks have fallen recently.

headline: No More Adventures in Wonderland
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Labor Talks in Detroit Go Social
text: DETROIT — For generations, labor negotiations here have been the stuff of closed doors and tight lips. Just four years ago, when the United Auto Workers settled on contracts with the Big Three, the rank-and-file learned the details by crowding into union halls for meetings that were often chaotic and confusing. Many workers complained that they had not seen the fine print until the deals had been ratified.

headline: At India-Bangladesh Border, Living in Both, and Neither
text: MADHYA MASALDANGA, India — Mohammed Idris Ali’s watery rice paddies shimmer in the monsoon breeze just like his neighbors’. His tepee-shaped stacks of jute, ready to be soaked, stripped and then turned into rope, stand as tall as the ones across the rutted footpath.

headline: Conference Instability Is Filtering Down to the Next Level
text: The one remaining domino that can still reset the collegiate conference landscape is the University of Missouri, which is in the process of deciding whether to stay in the Big 12 or defect to the Southeastern Conference. Officials from the Big 12, the SEC and the Big East are all anxiously awaiting the Tigers’ decision, as it will largely dictate the futures of their leagues.

headline: Refugee Farm Projects
text: More than two dozen farming programs in the nation work with refugees.

headline: Is the Tea Party Over?
text: Austin, Tex.

headline: A Fluid Protest Movement Finds a Forum to Match
text: A STRENGTH of the Occupy Wall Street protest movement has been its flexible organization and nondoctrinaire agenda: “The one thing we all have in common is that we are the 99 percent that will no longer tolerate the greed and corruption of the 1 percent.”

headline: Brewers and Fans Are Savoring the Moment
text: Milwaukee

headline: Middle School Girls Unlock a Room of Their Own, in Miniature
text: Swing open the door, and behold a tableau that perfectly captures the tween aesthetic. The polka-dot chandelier. The zebra-print wallpaper. The lime green shag rug that pulls the look together — without being too matchy-matchy, as a pre-tween might have it.

headline: When the Uprooted Put Down Roots
text: SAN DIEGO — At the Saturday farmer’s market in City Heights, a major portal for refugees, Khadija Musame, a Somali, arranges her freshly picked pumpkin leaves and lablab beans amid a United Nations of produce, including water spinach grown by a Cambodian refugee and amaranth, a grain harvested by Sarah Salie, who fled rebels in Liberia. Eaten with a touch of lemon by Africans, and coveted by Southeast Asians for soups, this crop is always a sell-out.

headline: Panic of the Plutocrats
text: It remains to be seen whether the Occupy Wall Street protests will change America’s direction. Yet the protests have already elicited a remarkably hysterical reaction from Wall Street, the super-rich in general, and politicians and pundits who reliably serve the interests of the wealthiest hundredth of a percent.

headline: Patriots’ Defense Finds a Cure: It’s the Jets’ Wobbly Offense
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

headline: A Protest’s Ink-Stained Fingers
text: At the Occupy Wall Street demonstration in Zuccotti Park, you’ll find all of the essentials of a state-of-the-art protest: drum circles, cheeky and plaintive handwritten signs, and, next to a thrumming generator, a hub of social media activity, including live streaming of the proceedings.

headline: A Farmer’s Market With the Tastes of Home
text: At the Saturday farmer’s market in City Heights, a major portal for refugees, Khadija Musame, a Somali, arranges her freshly picked pumpkin leaves and lablab beans amid a United Nations of produce, including water spinach grown by a Cambodian refugee and amaranth, a grain harvested by Sarah Salie, who fled rebels in Liberia.

headline: New Law Creates a Demand for Patent Specialists
text: Patent lawyers are in such demand that their specialty may account for more than 15 percent of law firm job openings while representing just 3 percent of lawyers in the United States.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: The Myth of Voter Fraud
text: It has been a record year for new legislation designed to make it harder for Democrats to vote — 19 laws and two executive actions in 14 states dominated by Republicans, according to a new study by the Brennan Center for Justice. As a result, more than five million eligible voters will have a harder time participating in the 2012 election.

headline: Group Urges More Money to Aid Poor in School
text: New York State already outspends the rest of the nation on education, and a group of education experts at Teachers College at Columbia University is calling for it to spend even more.

headline: Victory Lap for Fox and Hannity
text: ATLANTA — When the Fox News host Sean Hannity arrived at Centennial Olympic Park here on Thursday night, some of the hundreds of fans who had been waiting for him since sunset rushed to the rope line for handshakes and autographs. He obliged, then bounded onto a temporary stage two blocks from the CNN Center and asked them mischievously, “Do you think it’s any coincidence that the CNN logo is in the background?”

headline: A Deal for the Deals
text: Trade is good for the economy and for employment. It opens new markets for businesses and allows access to cheaper, often better products from abroad. But it also has a dark side for workers displaced by foreign competition.

headline: Julio Mario Santo Domingo, Colombian Billionaire, Dies at 87
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Julio Mario Santo Domingo, the Colombian magnate whose $8.5 billion fortune made him one of Latin America’s richest and most influential men, died on Friday in New York. He was 87.

headline: No Right to Bear Assault Weapons
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia last week persuasively  ruled that the Constitution allows the District to ban possession of assault weapons and high-capacity magazines of bullets and to require citizens to meet sensible standards for registering guns.

headline: Toby Keith’s American Dream
text: Toby Keith is having a good year. His new song, “Made in America,” just hit No. 1 on the country charts. It’s about his aging father, who flies the American flag on his farm, wears a “Semper Fi” tattoo and worries about global trade.

headline: Navigating the City Without Sight, but With a Cane and a Teacher
text: A Queens woman with myopic degeneration learns to navigate the busy streets of New York with the help of a certified orientation mobility specialist.

headline: A Community Erased by Slum Clearance Is Reunited
text: The reunion at the Frederick Douglass Center in Manhattan on Saturday had all the trappings of a block party. About 75 people turned out, greeting one another with smiles, hugs and questions about neighbors and family. They ate chicken, macaroni and cheese and cake while a man blew soulful melodies on an alto saxophone.

headline: Doris Belack, Judge on TV’s ‘Law & Order,’ Dies at 85
text: Doris Belack, a veteran stage, television and screen actress best known for her roles as a no-nonsense judge on “Law & Order” and as the peeved soap opera producer in “Tootsie,” died on Tuesday in New York. She was 85.

headline: Els Sees a Lot of Life Left in His Game
text: SAN MARTIN, Calif. — All the attention was on Tiger Woods at the Frys.com Open, which suited Ernie Els fine. Like Woods, Els came to CordeValle Golf Club looking for his lost game, and he preferred not to be accompanied by an unwieldy search party of fans and pundits.

headline: TV and Film, From Condé Nast
text: LOS ANGELES — Condé Nast is coming to Hollywood.

headline: The Art of Wreaking Havoc With Other People’s Money
text: When Frank Langella plays good, he’s fine; but when he’s bad, he’s a wonder. Having ditched the halo he wore as the sainted Sir Thomas More in “A Man for All Seasons” in 2008, Mr. Langella — the only actor to star on Broadway as both Dracula and Richard Nixon — has stepped back into the dark side in style. And this time he’s a villain that New York audiences should really love to hate: a soulless financier who wreaks havoc with other people’s money.

headline: A Good Samaritan Fumbles With an Umbrella

headline: Freud on the Beach: Wave Theory
text: In “Being and Nothingness,” Jean-Paul Sartre recommends skiing as a model of human behavior. But the trouble with skiing, says Sartre (with a slightly paranoid swerve) is that you leave tracks behind you. “The ideal form of sliding,” he argues, “would therefore be one that leaves no trace: that is, sliding over water”‘ He might have been thinking of water-skiing, of course, but I have always liked to suppose it was surfing he had in mind.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Columbus Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Officer Saved at Gunpoint by His Own Wedged Finger
text: At the tactical meeting that began Friday night’s tour, the members of the plainclothes anticrime unit in Brooklyn’s 81st Precinct were told pay a little more attention to livery cabs. Several drivers had been robbed at gunpoint.

headline: Battle for Libya | October 9, 2011
text: Forces of the Libyan transitional government said on Sunday that they had captured a couple of significant buildings in their push to the center of Surt, the hometown of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Talking Points for Jets
text: A few talking points after the Jets’ 30-21 loss against New England.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 5
text: A look back at the Jets’ 30-21 loss to the New England Patriots.

headline: China’s Reluctant Consumers

headline: As Its Economy Sprints Ahead, China’s People Are Left Behind
text: JILIN CITY, China — Wang Jianping and his wife, Shue, are a relatively affluent Chinese couple, with an annual household income of $16,000 — more than double the national average for urban families.

headline: After Rocky Start, More Study, and Sleep, for Perry
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas struggled through his first three debates, so his aides have staged practice sessions, complete with a stand-in for Mitt Romney. He has stirred outrage among conservatives on immigration, so he is defending his stance on the campaign trail as good economics.

headline: Raiders Fans Mourn an Owner Loved and Otherwise
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the hours after Al Davis’s death was announced Saturday, a makeshift memorial sprouted at the Oakland Raiders’ practice facility: a collage of flowers and Raiders shirts, stuffed animals and homemade cards and posters with personal messages. One note, written on lined yellow paper, seemed to encompass the complicated relationship that Raiders fans had with Davis, their team’s maverick owner:

headline: Navigating the City Without Sight, but With a Cane and a Teacher
text: The streets were quiet and dark except for the glare of an occasional streetlamp casting long shadows on the cracked pavement.

headline: Dissenting Often, State’s Chief Judge Establishes a Staunchly Liberal Record
text: After he was appointed to head the Court of Appeals in 2009, New York’s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, drew attention by forging alliances to get more liberal rulings on the court, which has a 4-to-3 conservative majority. But a new analysis shows another side of his approach: Judge Lippman writes dissents from his own court far more than his predecessors did from their courts.

headline: Art Is Fleeting, at Least When It’s in the Sky
text: On a warm, clear Sunday afternoon, many New Yorkers looked up and saw not a cloud in the sky — except for the ones that were talking to them.

headline: The Party Spirit on Trial
text: Richard C. Vaughan, an attorney in Lexington, Mo., was overjoyed with Abraham Lincoln’s 1860 election. Not because the Republican Lincoln won; indeed, he had supported John Bell, the presidential candidate from the Constitutional Union Party. Rather, his joy came from the Democrats’ resounding defeat. “The prospect of the final overthrow of the Democracy in Missouri as well as everywhere else,” he wrote to a friend, “is to me a source of infinite and irrepressible pleasure in which I know you participate fully.”

headline: Scientists’ Analysis Disputes F.B.I. Closing of Anthrax Case
text: A decade after wisps of anthrax sent through the mail killed 5 people, sickened 17 others and terrorized the nation, biologists and chemists still disagree on whether federal investigators got the right man and whether the F.B.I.’s long inquiry brushed aside important clues.

headline: For Perry, Texas Roots Include Racial Backdrop
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who often waxes nostalgic about his small-town roots, grew up in an almost all-white rural area where many referred to slingshots as “niggershooters.” One elderly black resident recalls being introduced by her boss at a party decades back as “my maid, Nigger Mae Lou,” while just four years ago, a black high school student found a noose in his locker.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
text: The government has agreed to make public the audio recordings of the proceedings of the Joint Drafting Committee constituted to frame the Lokpal Bill, in response to a query filed by an activist under the Right to Information Act, The Hindu reports.The anti-corruption activist Anna Hazare is “above Parliament and had the right to threaten to go on fast to get bills passed,” his adviser Arvind Kejriwal said Sunday, marking a radical change from the civil society group’s position so far, The Times of India reports. Kejriwal justified his decision to campaign against the Congress Party in the an upcoming state election, “saying it was the ruling party’s duty to ensure passage of the Jan Lokpal Bill”, the paper reports.

headline: Keeping a ‘Pity Party’ Short, and Pushing Hard to Improve
text: Maria Velez-Clarke has for 18 years been principal of the Children’s Workshop School in the East Village, Public School 361, one of several small schools started in the 1990s by people who had worked at the widely praised Central Park East School.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: The Return of Cuddy, Er, Lisa Edelstein
text: So just how quickly can the writers and producers of “The Good Wife” move? In Sunday night’s episode, “Get a Room,” Eli Gold did crisis management on an outbreak of listeria possibly caused by Wisconsin cheese. The current real-life listeria outbreak caused by Colorado cantaloupes became national news less than two weeks ago. That’s some fancy dancing. (Of course, there was an E. coli outbreak in Wisconsin in mid-September, so maybe it was just a matter of subbing “listeriosis” in the script.) The resolution was ripped from a different headline: a pie in a chief executive’s face, a la Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Where is India’s Steve Jobs?

headline: In Japan, a Long-Term Study on Radiation Leaks’ Effects
text: TOKYO — In an effort to track the long-term health effects of the nuclear disaster at Fukushima, Japan has begun a survey of local children for thyroid abnormalities, a problem associated with exposure to radiation.

headline: Poland’s Centrist Leader Secures a Second Term
text: WARSAW — With nearly all the votes counted Monday in the race to govern Poland, Prime Minister Donald Tusk appeared to have defeated his conservative rival and predecessor, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, securing a second term in office while a party that supports gay rights, abortion and some drug legalization seemed set to win representation in Parliament for the first time.

headline: Tony Blair: ‘They Keep Insinuating and I Keep Saying it’s Not True’
text: I interviewed Tony Blair in his suite at New York’s Carlyle Hotel on the steamy afternoon of Sept. 23. He was in New York for the meeting of the U.N. General Assembly in his capacity as Middle East envoy, a post announced just hours after he stepped down as British prime minister in 2007. Blair had a short window between official meetings to sit for an interview to promote the paperback publication of his 2010 memoir, “A Journey.” Sadly he did not have enough time — nor did the Carlyle have an extra room — to allow photographer Christian Oth and his team to set their seamless backdrop anywhere or anytime else. So there we were, a trim, tanned, tieless former prime minister, his press secretary, an aide, a book publicist, a photographer and his two assistants and a reporter, all occupying one room in which the air conditioning seemed not to be functioning. At the conclusion of the interview, a flustered Cherie Blair rushed in to join the party, apparently after overhearing from the next room too many questions concerning reports that had run in the conservative tabloid that has dogged the Blairs for decades. “I couldn’t resist coming in after hearing all that Daily Mail nonsense,” she declared. Here’s what was left on the cutting room floor.

headline: When the Music Stops
text: Wedding season is just around the corner, and soon the streets of Delhi will be full of marching brass bands in colorful, shiny, ill-fitting jackets and pants. No Indian wedding seems to be complete without sonorous trumpets and drums playing classic Hindustani songs or the latest Bollywood item numbers.

headline: The Victor Cruz Show, the Good and the Ugly
text: Giants  games boil down to Victor Cruz. At least it has seemed that way recently. He caught two touchdown passes to help beat the Eagles. He lived to tell the tale of  laying the ball on the turf even though he wasn’t touched against Arizona. And he had a spectacular catch against the Seahawks but also played a role in two crucial turnovers.

headline: This Week in Small Business: A 40 Percent Chance

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Bored to Death’
text: There’s no other comedy on television quite like HBO’s “Bored to Death.” It’s simultaneously old-fashioned and amazingly up to the minute, a gumshoe fantasy set in a very real world: the Brooklyn brownstones and cafes and Manhattan co-op apartments and watering holes that shelter what passes for literary culture in 21st-century New York. The novelist Jonathan Ames, the show’s creator, works out his love-hate relationship to the city’s writing life (and those who live it) with a mix of whimsy and precise observation that can make even the most cleverly written network sitcoms — “Modern Family,” “Community” — seem mass produced and one-size-fits-all in comparison.

headline: Complaint Box | Electric Delivery Bikes
text: Like everyone else, I like to order pizza or other takeout food and have it at my door and still warm in 15 to 20 minutes. But a recent encounter with a deliveryman on a bicycle that had been souped up with an electric motor — the type that is becoming ubiquitous in neighborhoods throughout the city — alerted me to the perils to pedestrians that the drivers of these illegally motorized vehicles can cause.

headline: Final Dagger on  0-3 Road Trip for Jets

headline: On Our Radar: Oil Spill Off New Zealand
text: Five days after a container ship hit a reef, clumps of oil begin washing up on New Zealand’s North Island, stirring fear that the fuel could foul delicate estuaries. Workers had begun pumping fuel from the ship but halted the effort after weather predictions of gale-force winds. [Associated Press]

Sims of Princeton University for their research on the cause and effect of government policies on the broader economy, a major concern of countries still struggling to address the aftermath of the recent financial crisis.

headline: Stick It to Me
text: I didn’t think I was a good candidate for facial acupuncture. For one thing, the only time I’m perfectly still is when I’m asleep (or getting an expensive haircut). And quite frankly, if I’m going to be stuck with needles, I would like them to deliver the kind of instant gratification that only Botox can provide. That said, when I heard there was a kind man in Midtown who would listen to my problems (but not judge me), calm me down (without meds) and erase my fine lines (without toxins or fillers), all in under an hour, I snagged the first available appointment.

headline: Winning One for Al Davis
text: There might not have been a more inevitable result than the Raiders winning their game over the Texans on Sunday. There simply was no other possible ending. Because wherever you think the sports world’s No. 1 curmudgeon landed in the afterlife after his death on Saturday, Al Davis was going to make eternity unbearable for whoever is in charge had his beloved team not given him a proper sendoff victory. After years of raging at the N.F.L. machine, his raging might have produced actual thunder. Or an earthquake.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Sebastian Vettel Is Youngest Repeat Champion in Formula One History
text: At the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix last year, Sebastian Vettel, then 23, simultaneously won a race and a season championship. At the Japanese Grand Prix on Sunday, Vettel finished third at more than two seconds off the winning pace, yet with four races left on the Formula One calendar, Vettel, now 24, has drained the 2011 season of most, if not all of its drama by clinching his second championship in a row.

Now he will help other writers recreate the lives of their chosen subjects as the new acting executive director of the Leon Levy Center for Biography at the CUNY Graduate Center. Among his many trophies Mr. Giddins can count a Guggenheim Fellowship, a National Book Critics Circle Award, a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Jazz Journalists Association, and a Grammy.

headline: Social Media Accounts of Violence in Cairo Challenge Official Narrative
text: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reported from Cairo, at least 24 people were killed and more than 200 wounded on Sunday night in Cairo when a demonstration by Christians angry about a recent attack on a church in Upper Egypt devolved into violent clashes with the military.

headline: Scant CO2 Benefit from China’s Coal-Powered Electric Cars
text: Much has been made of China’s big push to build and deploy 1 million electric vehicles a year by 2015. The move will help cut smog and oil imports. Less has been made of the scant impact this is likely to have on the country’s emissions of carbon dioxide, given its enduring reliance on coal for most of its electricity. Here’s a “Your Dot” contribution describing the situation from Lucia Green-Weiskel, who has worked in China for the Innovation Center for Energy and Transportation and co-authored a report on electric vehicles there for the United Nations.

headline: A Village Street Slips Quietly Off the Subway Map
text: Charlton Street, a sleepy three-block lane in the southern end of the West Village, is not exactly the most famous roadway in New York. Its achievements, by this city’s standards, are average stuff: a row of landmark 19th-century town houses; a former residence of George Washington.

headline: China Suspends Boat Traffic on Mekong
text: HONG KONG — China announced Monday that it was suspending passenger and cargo traffic in the headwaters of the Mekong River after the Thai border police heard gunfire on the river, found two Chinese cargo vessels adrift carrying 920,000 amphetamine pills and one body, and then discovered the floating bodies of 11 Chinese crewmen.

headline: Copts Denounce Egyptian Government Over Killings
text: CAIRO — An angry crowd of thousands gathered at the largest cathedral here on Monday to mourn the death of two dozen Coptic Christian demonstrators killed the night before in clashes with security forces, as liberal activists lamented the military’s increasingly tight hold on power.

headline: Nearly 6,000 Corvettes Recalled for Weak Rear-Hatch Hinges

headline: Sondheim to Receive New York City Arts Honor

headline: Hearty Do-Ahead Dishes
text: This week’s hearty one-dish vegetarian meals are meant to appeal to families that include a mix of meat-eaters and vegetarians. My best friends have a vegetarian relative who is undergoing some serious surgery and will be recuperating at their home. They’re in need of several do-ahead recipes that they can all enjoy throughout the week, dishes that can be reheated at different times, as they often get home from work late.

headline: Prognosis: Slight Rise in Blood Pressure Carries Risk
text: A review of studies suggests that young and middle-aged people with slightly elevated blood pressure, or prehypertension, are nonetheless at much greater risk for stroke than those in the normal range.

headline: Risks: Stress May Harm Preemies’ Development
text: The stress of living in a neonatal intensive care unit results in decreased brain size and abnormal neurological findings for very preterm babies, a small study suggests, and the more the stress, the greater the effect.

headline: University of Texas Acquires Coetzee’s Papers
text: The South African writer J. M. Coetzee wrote his Ph.D. dissertation on the early fiction of Samuel Beckett, receiving his degree from the University of Texas at Austin in 1969, the same year Beckett was awarded the Nobel Prize. Thirty-four years later, Mr. Coetzee himself received the Nobel Prize for literature. Now the Harry Ransom Center, the same library where Mr. Coetzee did his research on Beckett, has acquired Mr. Coetzee’s papers. Among the more than 160 boxes and filing cabinets of material are family photographs, business correspondence, recordings of interviews, notebooks and early manuscripts for his novels and his autobiography.

headline: My Three Favorite Things to Buy at Duane Reade
text: I miss the old, unglamorous Duane Reade, where you could find shampoo without having to wander through a maze of sandwiches, yogurt parfaits and frozen pizza. Still, stick with it and you can find a few things worthy of navigating the aisles.

headline: Looking Back at the Values Summit
text: Representative Ron Paul of Texas won the straw poll at the Values Voter Summit in Washington over the weekend, not much of a surprise given his campaign’s propensity to truck in supporters. Mitt Romney didn’t do so hot in the unscientific poll, but the more ominous sign for his appeal to religious conservatives came from a new flare-up in the debate over the nature of his faith.

text: The Cyprus-born, London-based beauty applies the same principles to home décor and personal style as she does to designing clothing, accessories and store interiors for her label, Caramel Baby & Child. “I like things to be casual and comfortable, but also elegant and chic,” she says. “Informal formality, so to speak.” Her closet, filled with pieces by Prada, Marni and Rochas, reflects a penchant for pops of color, lush fabrics, refined prints and clean tailoring — the same attributes that separate Caramel from other kiddie companies. headline: Groupon: ‘Transparent About Our Lack of Transparency’
text: Groupon has made it clear time and again that it doesn’t quite want to act like the usual boring business. On Monday, the online coupon giant proved that yet again, by putting a new spin on transparency.

headline: Hearing Bilingual: How Babies Sort Out Language
text: Once, experts feared that young children exposed to more than one language would suffer “language confusion,” which might delay their speech development. Today, parents often are urged to capitalize on that early knack for acquiring language. Upscale schools market themselves with promises of deep immersion in Spanish — or Mandarin — for everyone, starting in kindergarten or even before.

headline: Stutterer Speaks Up in Class; His Professor Says Keep Quiet
text: RANDOLPH, N.J. — As his history class at the County College of Morris here discussed exploration of the New World, Philip Garber Jr. raised his hand, hoping to ask why China’s 15th-century explorers, who traveled as far as Africa, had not also reached North America.

headline: How the Volcker Rule May Affect Foreign Banks
text: Drafts of the proposed Volcker Rule, implementing Section 619 of the Dodd-Frank Act, have begun circulating in advance of a vote by the federal agencies to issue the proposal. The Volcker Rule would ban many forms of proprietary trading by banks and would strictly limit their investments in private equity and hedge funds.

headline: Is Failure the Secret to Success? Student Edition
text: Paul Tough’s article ‘‘What if the Secret to Success Is Failure?’’ received a tremendous response from readers when it appeared in the Education Issue last month, including 270 comments on our Web site and 40 percent of the magazine’s page views. But we were very excited to see the article have a kind of second life over at The Learning Network, a New York Times blog for students and teachers. Our colleagues at The Learning Network used the article to kick off a new ‘‘Reading Club,’’ and there were 534 student comments on Tough’s article. The Reading Club forum encourages discussion, and it was pretty exciting to see students thoughtfully debate questions about social class and character; parental influence and character; and the difference between struggle and failure. There was a lot of respectful disagreement, though the comments I read seemed to be nearly unanimous on one point: No report cards for character, please.

headline: The Laptops Don’t Work, but the Messages Get Through
American Film Institute to Give Award to Shirley MacLaine
text: Alfred Hitchcock was one of the first to see Shirley MacLaine’s cinematic appeal, casting her in his 1955 film, “The Trouble With Harry.” Now, with more than 50 Hollywood movies to her name, Ms. MacLaine will receive the lifetime achievement award from the American Film Institute, which will be presented at a gala tribute in Los Angeles on June 7, the BBC reported.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Adara Media, Mountain View, Calif., hired four executives. Two will be based in Mountain View: Jeff Cohen, vice president for strategic accounts, and Brandon Meyers, sales director. One, Mark Hersch, vice president for strategic accounts, will be based in Chicago. The fourth, Andrew Freedman, regional sales director for the eastern region, will be based in New York.

headline: A Search for Bargains Goes Social
text: Decades ago, Macy’s proclaimed, “It’s smart to be thrifty.” Now, consumers who are concerned about the economy have elevated thriftiness to a lifestyle, as evidenced by everything from TV shows about “extreme couponing” to retailers that try to turn shopping into a quest for values.

headline: Spotify Loss Widens Despite Higher Revenue
text: Spotify, the streaming digital music service that was just given a big boost through a partnership with Facebook, saw its revenue more than quintuple last year, but the company still lost more than $40 million, it reported on Monday.

headline: The Caucus | A New Political Force?
text: Oct. 10, 2011 - Washington looks for political implications as the Occupy Wall Street protests gain strength. Also, a report from New Hampshire, where the Republican campaign is centered this week.

headline: Is There a Solution to Giants’ Running Woes?
text: There are plenty of reasons for Giants fans to be up in arms Monday, even if they aren’t among the thousands (millions?) of disappointed knockout pool participants who had the Giants winning easily over the Seattle Seahawks.

headline: India Wedding Band Blues
text: Band musicians in Delhi, India, endure low wages and strict bandmasters while being looked down upon in society.

headline: Are Better Times Ahead for the Jets?
text: It was somewhat surprising that the Jets left Gillette Stadium late Sunday night with mixed emotions. Players spoke of frustration, of shock, at losing three consecutive games, all against quality A.F.C.opponents. Yet they also sounded much more encouraged than in weeks past, happier certainly than after the debacles in Oakland and Baltimore.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Disappointment? Apple’s iPhone 4S Breaks Sales Records
text: It has the repetition of a Hollywood movie script: Apple releases a new product. Some in the media and analysts quickly bemoan the new product, saying it didn’t live up to the hype they created.

headline: Provocateur’s Strong Showing Is a Sign of a Changing Poland
text: WARSAW — Waving a gun and a sex toy at a news conference may have branded Janusz Palikot as an extreme politician, but the ensuing notoriety had its benefits. Just a few years later, one out of 10 Polish voters cast a ballot for the socially libertarian-style party that bears the provocateur’s name.

headline: A Shiny Failure, Reborn as a Rehab Center
text: With buffed hardwood floors, a fireplace in the living room, marble in the bathrooms and Silestone in the kitchen, the 2,200-square-foot, full-floor apartment on West Broadway looks exactly like the luxury condo it was meant to be. The furniture is plush and neutral, original artwork hangs on the walls, there is a Wii console hooked up to the flat-screen television and, when the sights of TriBeCa’s bustle from the second-floor windows are not enough, there is a planted, furnished roof deck upstairs, with views stretching from the Empire State Building to ground zero.

headline: The Difference Between Puffery and Fraud
text: The Justice Department and the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, filed separate civil charges last week against Bank of New York Mellon, accusing it of defrauding customers of its foreign exchange services. The cases raise sticky questions about when marketing claims cross the imperceptible line from puffery to fraud.

headline: Government Aims to Build a ‘Data Eye in the Sky’
text: More than 60 years ago, in his “Foundation” series, the science fiction novelist Isaac Asimov invented a new science — psychohistory — that combined mathematics and psychology to predict the future.

headline: Romney Turns Again to the Economy
text: MILFORD, N.H. — Mitt Romney on Monday accused President Obama of fostering divisiveness in America and said the protests against Wall Street were unfairly criticizing an entire sector of the country’s economy.

headline: Revisiting the Global Food Crisis
text: Another new report has just become available on the subject of world hunger, and it may frustrate some readers. The new edition of State of Food Insecurity in the World, an annual report from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, does not actually estimate the number of hungry people across the globe.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 10
text: A view of the day in sports included wheelchair fencing and the world’s least stressed security guard.

headline: Mushroom Lasagna
text: This lasagna tastes very rich, even though it really isn’t. It combines an olive oil béchamel with a simple mushroom ragout and Parmesan cheese. I prefer no-boil lasagna noodles because they’re lighter than regular lasagna noodles. But I still boil them because I think the results are better if they’re cooked until they’re flexible (a couple of minutes) first.

headline: Edison2, X Prize Winner, Claims 350 M.P.G. Equivalent for Prototype
text: Edison2, the tiny, Virginia-based engineering company that won the $5 million mainstream class in the Automotive X Prize last year, recently tested the performance of its all-electric, four-passenger Very Light Car design — a rounded pod with outboard-mounted wheels — at Roush Laboratories in Livonia, Mich.

text: Andy Murray became the first player in 2011 to win both the singles and doubles titles at an A.T.P. tournament, taking the singles title on his own and pairing with his older brother Jamie to win the doubles at the Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships in Tokyo.

headline: California Bans Indoor Tanning for Minors
text: California this week became the first state in the country to ban indoor tanning for anyone under 18, a move that drew praise from health organizations.

headline: Decorating a Locker, Virtually
text: Middle-school girls are transforming their once-barren metal lockers with fanciful decorations that fully cover the drab chipped paint and Sharpie commentary of any former inhabitants. In today’s Times, Elissa Gootman describes the “next frontier in nesting” — polka-dot chandeliers, zebra-print wallpaper, lime shag rugs and other decorating options.

headline: Amy Winehouse’s Father Signs Deal to Write Book About Her
text: Less than three months after  the death of his daughter,  Mitch Winehouse has made a deal to write a book about her, his publisher said on Monday. The book, titled “Amy,” is “a heartfelt and revelatory memoir” that will tell what Mr. Winehouse says is the true story of Amy Winehouse’s life.

headline: Joe the Plumber May Be Joe the Candidate
text: Samuel J. Wurzelbacher, better known as Joe the Plumber from the 2008 presidential campaign, has filed papers to run for a House seat in northern Ohio.

headline: Envy May Bear Fruit, but It Also Has an Aftertaste
text: Why envy? It seems to be the most useless of the deadly sins: excruciating to experience, shameful to admit, bereft of immediate pleasure or long-term benefits. To an evolutionary psychologist, there’s a certain logic to seducing thy neighbor’s wife or stealing his goods, but what’s the point of merely coveting them?

headline: The Return of Delmon Young
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Now batting third for the Detroit Tigers and playing left field … Delmon Young?

headline: Egyptian Christians Criticize Government Over Killings
text: Egypt’s Coptic Christian church harshly criticized the government on Monday over its actions in crushing a protest in Cairo the night before that left at least 24 dead.

headline: A Delivery From Space That Made a Big Splash
text: Using a powerful space telescope, scientists have found evidence that the water in the Earth’s oceans could have been delivered by comets.

headline: At Long Last, Facebook Releases an iPad App
text: It has been the equivalent of waiting for Bigfoot. Bloggers had seen it. Developers said they had worked on it. Facebook denied its existence. Everyone else just wanted to know if it was real.

headline: Prevention: Doubts on Women’s Use of Supplements
text: Older women who used common dietary supplements died at slightly higher rates than women who did not rely on supplements, a large study has found.

headline: Dream Act Becomes Law in California
text: In California, illegal immigrants enrolling in college will be eligible for state scholarships and financial aid beginning next July.

headline: If Banks Are Outlawed, Only Outlaws Will Have Banks
text: Yglesias tells us that some Occupy Wall Street protesters have picked up Ron Paulish monetary ideas — although some know better. I thought I’d say a word about one particular idea that sounds plausible to some people but is actually quite wrong: banning fractional reserve banking.

headline: Questions on Tactic to Prevent H.I.V.
text: In the past year, three landmark clinical trials have shown that a daily dose of the antiretroviral medication Truvada can protect individuals from infection with H.I.V. — a significant discovery, given the failure so far of all efforts to develop a vaccine against the virus.

headline: In Senate Race, Warren Raises More Cash Than Brown
text: BOSTON — With help from national fund-raising groups, Elizabeth Warren has already raised $3.15 million for her United States Senate campaign, catapulting ahead of her Democratic primary opponents.

headline: With Davis Gone, Who Will Lead Raiders?
text: N.F.L. executives on Sunday gave Al Davis something he seldom gave them: a moment of silence.

headline: Flaunting Youthful Naïveté
text: Perhaps you’ve seen them on YouTube, the young girls shaking their bodies in emulation of Beyoncé while making faces more like Shirley Temple’s. Perhaps you’ve wondered if they understand the erotic implications of their movements. Is this sexual pantomime damaging? Where will it lead?

headline: The Appraisal: Sobering Up Amid City’s Lures
text: This week the Appraisal visits TriBeCa Twelve, a soon-to-open home for young adults recovering from substance abuse. It will be run by Hazelden, the Minnesota-based operator of a network of rehab centers, and be housed in a planned luxury condo development on West Broadway that Hazelden bought after the development went belly up. The Columbia University psychiatry department is a partner in the effort. Although the popular image of live-in centers for people recovering from substance abuse runs more toward campus-like complexes in bucolic settings, where fresh air and natural beauty replace the lures of drugs and alcohol, this one — intended to serve as a transition from rehab to real life — is in the midst of a heavily traveled night life zone, near bars, clubs and restaurants that would seem to pose threats to a resident’s hard-won sobriety. Have you or has someone you know been in rehab or a similar situation and found the temptations of city life hard to resist? Or do you think that treatment centers need not be remote to be effective? Please share your thoughts and experiences.

headline: In Birds, a Possible Clue to the Cycle of Abuse
text: Although it has never been definitively proven, many social scientists believe that abused children are more likely to become abusers as adults. Now for the first time, there is evidence of the phenomenon in animals in the wild.

headline: A science lesson from the singer Bjork, the life and times of University of California San Francisco’s Susan Desmond-Hellman and a new study on the nature of envy.
text: A science lesson from the singer Bjork, the life and times of University of California San Francisco’s Susan Desmond-Hellman and a new study on the nature of envy.

headline: New Hampshire’s Contrarian Streak
text: Tuesday night’s Republican debate will be on favorable turf for Mitt Romney: New Hampshire, where he owns a home and has led in every poll of Republican voters, sometimes by a substantial margin.

headline: New Way to Gain a Clear View of the Brain
text: A group of Japanese neuroscientists is trying to peer into the mind — literally. They have devised a way to turn the brain’s opaque gray matter into a glassy, see-through substance.

headline: Sigmund Freud, 1909
text: Sigmund Freud visited the United States only once, in 1909, to give a series of lectures. The New York Times found nothing about the visit worth mentioning except his departure. “Prof. Sigmund Freud” appears on Page 9 on Sept. 21, along with “Dr. C. G. Jung,” in a list of passengers sailing to Bremen, Germany, aboard the Kaiser Wilhelm Der Grosse. It was the first time the newspaper mentioned his name.

headline: In Brazil, Energy Finds Put Country at a Whole New Power Level
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Of all those who might smile at Brazil’s unfolding oil boom, Walter Link could rank near the top. A U.S. oilman here at a time of nationalist fervor, he was the former chief geologist for Standard Oil Company of New Jersey whom Brazil hired to find its oil reserves.

headline: Your Economic Outlook: Mixed Up
text: Contradictory data are nothing new in economics, but amid the slump in the United States and Europe, readers may find themselves paying increasing attention to indicators that seem to point every which way.

headline: DVRs Bring Some Shows a Ratings Boost
text: The time is coming when judgments about television shows based on initial ratings may be a foolish policy – especially with more and more viewers using recording devices to watch shows long after they have been first broadcast.

text: SAN FRANCISCO — The phone call, at home one night last week, came from a student seeking donations for the University of California, San Francisco.

headline: Ex-President of Cape Verde Wins Good-Government Prize
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — Pedro de Verona Rodrigues Pires, the former president of Cape Verde, the desertlike archipelago about 300 miles off the coast of West Africa, has won one of the world’s major prizes, the $5 million Ibrahim Prize for Achievement in African Leadership.

headline: In Milwaukee, Sausages Aren’t Just for Tailgating
text: MILWAUKEE — They appeared from behind the left-field fence in the middle of the sixth inning, five tall, costumed wieners with heads like Easter Island statues but wearing hats. The Miller Park crowd of 43,613 cheered and whistled Sunday as the Milwaukee Brewers’ famous racing sausages lined up on the warning track and took off.

headline: Norman’s Conquest
text: In the American fall collections of 1960, Norman Norell did something seemingly too radical for a man who ate most of his meals at Schrafft’s and Hamburg Heaven. He had his models paint their faces in the bohemian-urchin style of Paris in the ’20s, with darkened eyes and red lips, finished off with shingle haircuts. Then he put the girls in pants. Technically these were split skirts, but who cares? The effect was the same. Long before Yves Saint Laurent issued le smoking, square Norman was there. “They may seem a little avant-garde at first,” he told The Times after his 1960 show, for which he received a standing ovation, “but I really do believe in the look.” He had uncanny instincts for anticipating change: the elongated sweater look, the return of waistlines in the mid-’60s, the dolman-sleeve rage of the early ’70s. He showed leopard patterns in the ’40s. The flapper makeup told a lot about Norell as well: stage-struck at an early age, he designed costumes in the ’20s at the Astoria studio of Paramount Pictures, dressing Gloria Swanson in “Zaza,” and later worked on Broadway musicals and burlesque shows before moving to ladies’ fashion.

headline: The Incredible Good Luck of ‘Breaking Bad’
text: ‘‘Breaking Bad,’’ which just ended its fourth season on Sunday, had its premiere on Jan. 20, 2008. It started with a straightforward and rather narrow premise: A mild-mannered chemistry teacher named Walter White finds out he has cancer, and so he decides, in order to build up a fortune to leave to his family, to start cooking meth.

headline: Mariusz Kwiecien Withdraws From Met Performance
text: Mariusz Kwiecien, cast in the title role of the Metropolitan Opera’s highly touted new production of Mozart’s “Don Giovanni,” injured his back at rehearsal on Monday and was scratched from Thursday’s opening night, the Met said. Peter Mattei will take his place. Mr. Kwiecien hurt himself during the opening scene of the dress rehearsal and was taken to the hospital. A Met spokesman said he had no immediate information on the nature of the injury, Mr. Kwiecien’s condition or when he might return. Mr. Mattei is appearing at the Met as Figaro in Rossini’s “Barbiere di Siviglia.”

headline: A Goodbye, Understated but Riveting in Its Duets
text: On Sunday afternoon at New York City Ballet, the dancer Charles Askegard played four consecutive roles: a noble cavalier in formal attire (the pas de deux from George Balanchine’s “Diamonds”); an unadorned dancer in white T-shirt and black tights (Balanchine’s “Episodes”); a harsh messenger of death in gray shirt and black trousers (Jerome Robbins’s “In Memory of...”); and finally an American cowboy (Balanchine’s “Western Symphony”). With this display of range, Mr. Askegard made his farewell to City Ballet.

headline: How to Fix California’s Democracy Crisis
text: Stanford, Calif.

headline: NBC and Packers Cruise to Victory
text: With the Fox broadcast of Game 2 of the American League Championship Series postponed because of rain, the “Sunday Night Football” game between the Green Bay Packers and the Atlanta Falcons dominated the night en route to another Sunday ratings victory for NBC. (The Packers defeated the Falcons, 25-14). The competing shows, meanwhile, continued to struggle, especially on ABC. As little as two weeks ago the network was looking at a successful debut of its series “Pam Am,” as the premiere episode was sampled by nearly 11 million total viewers. Three episodes later, the series has fallen sharply week-to-week, with another 27 percent drop this week in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic and a dwindling total viewership of 6.4 million. The numbers weren’t much better for “Desperate Housewives,” which tied a series low in the 18-to-49 category for a new episode.

headline: Cricket Hovers After Sex to Ensure Mate’s Safety
text: Biologists have long thought of the male cricket as an insect version of the stalker boyfriend. In laboratory studies, a male cricket often lingers after copulating in an effort, researchers believed, to make sure his mate does not go searching for a different partner or reject the slow-release package of sperm he has just deposited.

headline: Post Games
text: De mortuis nihil nisi bonum. Don’t rip the dead. It seems to be the generous sentiment behind most of the coverage following the deaths of two Bay Area titans in the last week, Steve Jobs and Al Davis. And who can argue with that? Jobs was Apple; Davis was the Oakland Raiders; each transformed his industry. Who doesn’t love an iPad (or appreciate Apple’s market capitalization)? Who doesn’t thrill to the high-arcing ‘‘vertical’’ bomb that results in a 60-yard touchdown?

headline: He Joked, and the World Laughed With Him
text: Funny novels, like funny movies, rarely gain traction with prize committees. “People assume that it’s the gloomy buggers that are the serious ones,” Martin Amis has said, “but in fact, anyone who has ever been anywhere in fiction is funny.” A great comic actor, if he or she sticks around long enough, might win not an actual Oscar but a consolation prize: a lifetime achievement award. The National Book Awards need something similar for America’s comic writers. Among the first I’d nominate is Bruce Jay Friedman, whose prose, over the past five decades, has mostly been a pure pleasure machine.

headline: ‘Idol’ Singers’ Morning-After Moment
text: Scotty McCreery started out the most recent season of “American Idol” as a scrawny stick with a deep and hollow voice and an Alfred E. Neuman grin. By the time the show ended, he’d become a Nashville slickster would-be, with exaggerated gestures and bulging swagger. Lauren Alaina arrived at the show a savant, a flexible singer with preternatural confidence and a gift for interpretation. But with each week, she seemed to grow younger and younger, losing the boom in her voice, her confidence, her grip on the show’s narrative.

headline: Pressed, Sheriff Agrees to Jails Inquiry
text: LOS ANGELES — Accusations of inmate abuse in the country’s largest jail system have piled up over the last several days and weeks, with tales of volunteers witnessing beatings of prisoners. And when news broke of a federal investigation into the conduct of several guards, the Los Angeles County sheriff, Lee Baca, reacted angrily, saying the inquiry overstepped its authority.

headline: Marketers Work Around the Gore to Reach a Zombie Show’s Audience
text: BING, the two-year-old Microsoft search engine, has paid for product placements in movies including “Source Code” and television shows including “The Vampire Diaries” and “Hawaii Five-0.”

headline: Jagjit Singh, Reviver of Persian Ghazal Singing, Dies at 70
text: Jagjit Singh, a singer of wide popularity in South Asia who helped revive and popularize ghazals — a venerable form of Persian poetry set to music expressing the writer’s feelings, especially about love — died on Monday in Mumbai. He was 70.

headline: Facebook iPad App Improves on Web Site
text: Until now, navigating Facebook.com on an iPad felt like trying to write an e-mail on a calculator.

headline: Joe Aceti, Director Who Shaped TV Sports, Dies at 76
text: Joe Aceti, an innovative television director who for three decades helped shape network coverage of major sports events, including the Olympics, the World Series and the Ali-Frazier “Thrilla in Manila,” died on Oct. 4 in Kirkland, Wash. He was 76.

headline: Gulf Shrimp Are Scarce This Season; Answers, Too
text: LAFITTE, La. — The dock at Bundy’s Seafood is quiet, the trucks are empty and a crew a fraction of the normal size sits around a table waiting for something to do. But the most telling indicator that something is wrong is the smell. It smells perfectly fine.

headline: A Dark Mood Surrounds Corporate Jet Makers
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: Naked in Massachusetts
text: I have my doubts that Elizabeth Warren is elitist and I’m not convinced Scott Brown is sexist, but I’m sure of this: we just got our first glimpse of how sadly petty and predictably reductive the 2012 U.S. Senate campaign in Massachusetts is bound to be.

headline: NATO Commander Says Resilience of Qaddafi Loyalists Is Surprising
text: WASHINGTON — The commander of NATO’s air campaign in Libya has said that hundreds of organized fighters loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi pose a “resilient and fierce” threat in the two remaining pro-Qaddafi strongholds, and are exploiting the urban settings to complicate the alliance’s mission to protect civilians.

headline: Many in Both Parties Want a Window Into the Deficit Reduction Panel’s Work
text: WASHINGTON — On one crucial point, a powerful Congressional committee seeking ways to reduce the federal budget deficit has managed to produce a rare bipartisan consensus: Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives in and out of Congress say the panel is doing too much of its work in secret.

headline: The Milquetoast Radicals
text: The U.S. economy is probably going to stink for a few more years. It is beset by short-term problems (low consumer demand, uncertain housing prices, too much debt) and long-term problems (wage stagnation, rising health care costs, eroding human capital).

headline: Romney, on Friendly Turf, Keeps His Message on the Economy as Attacks Fly
text: HOPKINTON, N.H. — Facing an increasing barrage of attacks on his character from Republican rivals and critics, Mitt Romney ignored the criticism Monday and sought to maintain his focus on the nation’s struggling economy ahead of a debate on that topic here Tuesday night.

headline: When the Catch Disappears
text: Shrimpers on the Gulf Coast say this year’s season is a bad one, if not the worst in memory.

headline: Chipping Away at Gridlock
text: Democrats scored a small but significant victory for the cause of progress in the Senate late last week when they voted to prohibit one of the many delaying tactics that keep the chamber tied up in pointless partisan arguments. It was a long way from desperately needed filibuster reform, but it showed that sufficiently frustrated senators can take action to prevent the Senate from being a total dead weight.

headline: Fliers’ vs. Airlines’ Rights
text: Airlines have long been able to remove disruptive passengers from their airplanes. But while in the past only fellow travelers knew what had happened, now social media exposes these disputes to a worldwide audience.

headline: No Car, No Hotel, No Luggage. But He Got the Account.
text: ALMOST all of my business flights are commercial, not private. I’ll be the first to admit that I’m not a good flier.

headline: Enabling Mr. Assad
text: There is a lot of shame to go around after the United Nations Security Council failed last week to pass a resolution condemning Syria’s brutal crackdown. Russia, which used its veto, clearly values its arms sales and other trade with Damascus over the lives of the more than 2,900 Syrians killed during pro-democracy protests. China, which followed Russia, clearly fears any popular movement.

headline: Questioning Prostate Cancer Tests
text: American men now have an authoritative warning that getting a blood test for prostate cancer may push them toward needless tests and treatments that would do them more harm than good. The United States Preventive Services Task Force, after an exhaustive review of the scientific evidence, has suggested that healthy men should no longer receive the P.S.A. blood test to screen for a protein that may indicate cancer.

headline: Chinese City Shuts Down 13 Wal-Marts
text: HONG KONG — The fiercely nationalistic municipal government of Chongqing in southwestern China ordered all 13 Wal-Mart stores there to close for 15 days and fined the company $420,000 in a labeling dispute that has broader political implications for Western companies operating in China.

headline: Putting a Face on What’s at Stake in a Clash Over the Minimum Wage
text: At its most elemental, a battle brewing in the City Council comes down to this: Do a few thousand New Yorkers like Kimberly Ortiz deserve a raise?

headline: New York’s ‘Housekeeping’ Money
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg testified last week in a trial about whether a former campaign aide had absconded with the mayor’s $1.1 million contribution to the Independence Party. That party gave Mr. Bloomberg its line in 2009. While the court is focused on that question, the public should be asking a larger one. Mainly, why could the mayor write such a large personal check to the party?

headline: A Brash Style and Power Plays Allowed Davis to Wrest Control
text: When F. Wayne Valley hired Al Davis to coach the Oakland Raiders in 1963, he could not have imagined that Davis would one day shrewdly maneuver him out as the principal owner.

headline: Regulators to Set Forth Volcker Rule
text: WASHINGTON — The outlines of the Volcker Rule, one of the flagship provisions of the sweeping financial regulatory overhaul passed last year, will begin to take shape this week as regulators propose rules to limit the ability of most banks and Wall Street firms to use their own funds to buy and sell stocks, corporate bonds and derivatives.

headline: Al Qaeda Group Confirms Deaths of Two American Citizens
text: WASHINGTON – Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula on Monday issued a statement on Islamist Web sites confirming the deaths of Anwar Al-Awlaki and Samir Khan, two American citizens who were killed in a drone strike in Yemen last month, while saying that their killings “contradicted” the principles that the United States says it was founded upon and stands for.

headline: States Adding Drug Test as Hurdle for Welfare
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — As more Americans turn to government programs for refuge from a merciless economy, a growing number are encountering a new price of admission to the social safety net: a urine sample.

headline: Game-Ending Slam Gives Rangers Room to Breathe
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Nelson Cruz’s slump hurt enough, but even after he hit a game-tying home run in the seventh inning, the Detroit Tigers figured it was safer to pitch to him in the ninth than to Mike Napoli as they desperately fought to take the Texas Rangers into extra innings Monday night.

headline: Outside Panel Backs Prostate Test Advisory
text: In the wake of a government panel’s advice last week that healthy men should no longer be routinely screened for prostate cancer, an independent team of experts sought to explain, in an assessment of the scientific evidence in a prominent medical journal, why a simple blood test generally results in more harm than good.

headline: Coveted Jobs in Iraq Breed Diploma Fraud
text: BAGHDAD — For two years, an assistant dean at Iraq’s largest university received threats from a police officer: sign a fraudulent document certifying that the officer had graduated from the university, the dean was told, or he would be arrested or even killed.

headline: Volatility, Thy Name Is E.T.F.
text: Did you watch the markets on Monday? In the last 18 minutes of trading, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index jumped more than 10 points with no news to account for the rally. If you were left scratching your head, you were not alone.

headline: This Time, It Really Is Different
text: The title of the white paper is, admittedly, a mouthful: “The Way Forward: Moving From the Post-Bubble, Post-Bust Economy to Renewed Growth and Competitiveness.” It was commissioned by the New America Foundation, which hoped that it might “re-center the political debate to better reflect the country’s deep economic problems,” according to Sherle Schwenninger, the director of the foundation’s Economic Growth Program. Its authors are Daniel Alpert, a managing partner of Westwood Capital; Robert Hockett, a professor of financial law at Cornell and a consultant to the New York Federal Reserve; and Nouriel Roubini, who is, well, Nouriel Roubini, whose consistently bearish views have been consistently right. It is scheduled to be released on Wednesday.

headline: Olympic Protester Maintains Passion
text: More than 40 years after Tommie Smith and John Carlos ignited the sports world with their black-gloved fists raised on the victory stand at the 1968 Mexico City Olympics, Carlos says, “I still feel the fire.”

headline: Democrats Try Wary Embrace of the Protests
text: WASHINGTON — Leading Democratic figures, including party fund-raisers and a top ally of President Obama, are embracing the spread of the anti-Wall Street protests in a clear sign that members of the Democratic establishment see the movement as a way to align disenchanted Americans with their party.

headline: Robert M. Schaeberle, Nabisco Chief, Dies at 88
text: Robert M. Schaeberle, who led Nabisco through two mergers but retired as chairman and chief executive in 1986 as the company moved toward one of the biggest and most contentious leveraged buyouts in Wall Street history, died on Sept. 29 at an assisted living facility in Exeter, N.H. He was 88.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Ex-Aide Said She Drew Cuomo, as Attorney General, Into Rain Forest Case
text: Two years ago, Andrew M. Cuomo, then New York’s attorney general, unexpectedly jumped into a legal fight over an issue that had little to do with the state: damage to the Amazon rain forest from oil drilling.

headline: Representing Himself, Under Threat of Electric Shock
text: NEWARK — It is to be a most curious trial: the defense lawyer has been ordered not to move beyond a few square feet in the courtroom. He is allowed to lean on the lectern, but if he steps in either direction he will be in trouble.

headline: Just a Few Weeks Before Halloween, Weather Fitting for the Fourth of July
text: Toby Crane knew his window of opportunity was small.

headline: Anti-Qaddafi Fighters Face Stiff Resistance in Surt
text: SURT, Libya — From the windows of an apartment overlooking this seaside town, a commander peered through binoculars and yelled orders into a walkie-talkie, directing fire at a white building in the distance flying Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s green flag.

headline: Exonerated of Murder, a Boxer Makes a Debut at 52
text: PHILADELPHIA — The television crew had him up at dawn doing the Rocky fandango, dashing up the 72 stone steps of the Philadelphia Museum of Art and dancing around in triumph like another over-the-hill, underdog pugilist who had made it big.

headline: Peru Leader Ousts 30 Police Generals in Anti-Corruption Drive
text: President Ollanta Humala of Peru has dismissed two-thirds of the generals in the country’s national police force, the most forceful move yet in an anti-corruption drive he announced shortly after taking office in July.

headline: A Metropolitan Opera High Note, as Donations Hit $182 Million
text: Velvet costumes evoked Tudor opulence at Donizetti’s “Anna Bolena” during last month’s opening night at the Metropolitan Opera. The red carpet was out; celebrities lent pop culture pizazz; and the audience had a genuine star, Anna Netrebko, to cheer for, which it did, lustily.

headline: After Losing Ace, Cardinals Pieced Together a New Plan
text: MILWAUKEE

headline: At One College, a Fight Over Required Drug Tests
text: Linn State Technical College in Linn, Mo., informed students this semester that they would be required to submit to a urine test that would be checked for illegal drugs as a condition of studying at the college. Almost immediately, the American Civil Liberties Union and other groups sued on behalf of several dissenting Linn State students and have won a temporary injunction. The A.C.L.U. says Linn State is the first public college in the country to require all adult students to submit to mandatory drug tests. Linn State officials however, say the policy is legal and was developed in the interest of their 1,200 students.

headline: Late Patriots Drive Chips at the Jets’ Foundation
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It was an ideal situation for the Jets. In spite of themselves, they trailed New England by 6 points Sunday midway through the fourth quarter. The Patriots had the ball at their 22. The Jets had all three timeouts. All they needed was a stop, and an improbable victory seemed possible.

headline: Tuesday: Sore All Over
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I have a cold. I’m not sure why I’m telling you this, except that I hope you’ll understand if there are mistakes, as I’m currently typing this with my head on my desk. Seeing the entries FEVER and ACHY in the northern part of the grid made me want to nod and say, “Yup”, but nodding and saying “Yup” would be too painful, so you’ll just have to believe me when I say that they’re there. I need to conserve my energy for the rest of the post.

headline: In Wave of Labor Unrest, Kuwait Customs Strike Halts Oil Shipments
text: Three thousand striking customs officers disrupted oil shipments from Kuwait on Monday, escalating the labor unrest that has been gaining momentum in recent weeks in the emirate.

headline: N.B.A. Cancels First 2 Weeks of Play
text: The N.B.A. canceled the first two weeks of the season Monday night after another marathon bargaining session between league and union officials ended in frustration and despair.

headline: Giants Struggle to Find the Running Game They’ve Become Known For
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Conceptually, the Giants still believe they are a dominant running team. They talk about running the ball. They scheme so they can run the ball. Establishing the run is something Coach Tom Coughlin has preached for years and is a significant element in the amorphous (yet often-invoked) notion of Giants football.

headline: Big East Is Considering a Move to 12 Members in Football
text: Scurrying to revive a football conference dwindling in programs and in relevancy, the Big East said Monday that it was considering moving to a model that consisted of 12 football-playing universities.

headline: Wall St. Banks Help Hedge Funds Recruit
text: Wall Street banks often boast that they hire the best and the brightest. Now, scrambling to bolster profits, they have become full-time headhunters for some of their biggest hedge fund clients, a role that is rife with potential conflicts.

headline: Sanctions Pose Growing Threat to Syria’s Assad
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian economy is buckling under the pressure of sanctions by the West and a continuing popular uprising, posing a growing challenge to President Bashar al-Assad’s government as the pain is felt deeply by nearly every layer of Syrian society.

headline: Mayors Say U.S. Is Ignorant of Cities’ Needs
text: CHICAGO — Three big-city mayors who took part in a panel discussion Monday night criticized the federal government for not giving them the tools they need to help their cities thrive.

headline: Remembering Al Davis
text: Thoughts of the Raiders' owner often lead to his penchant for swimming against the tide.

headline: For Ukrainian Leader, Disparate Paths to Cross

headline: Video: Remembering Al Davis
text: Thoughts of the Raiders’ owner often lead to his penchant for swimming against the tide, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Translating Reality: If He Goes, So Do You
text: The Mets have cleaned out their lockers and gone home, and given their third consecutive fourth-place finish and the need to cut payroll, it’s a fair bet that numerous players who finished the season with the team will not return next spring.

headline: Iran: Airline Banned on Ticket System
text: The International Air Transport Association said Monday it had suspended Iran Air, the Iranian national airline, from the system for processing international ticket payments as a result of strengthened American economic sanctions against Iran. The suspension severely limits the ability of Iran Air to book passengers abroad. Iran’s civil aviation authority denounced the action as a violation of international rules. The airline association “is not obliged to follow the U.S. embargo against Iran,” said Farhad Parvaresh, the director of the Civil Aviation Organization of Iran.

headline: China and Myanmar to ‘Settle’ on Myitsone Dam
text: Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi of China and his counterpart from Myanmar, U Wunna Maung Lwin, agreed to “properly settle matters” after Myanmar suspended construction of the large Myitsone hydroelectric dam that was being financed and led by a state-controlled Chinese company, China’s official Xinhua news agency said Monday. The report did not say whether China was demanding financial compensation for work done on the project before Myanmar backed out.

headline: Numberplay: Turtles All The Way Down
text: Stephen Hawking’s 1988 book “A Brief History of Time” begins with the following famous anecdote.

headline: Iran: 14 New Arrests in Bank Scandal
text: Iran’s top prosecutor reported 14 new arrests on Monday in connection with a record $2.6 billion embezzlement uncovered last month at Bank Melli, the largest commercial bank in the country, and called on its fugitive managing director to return home from Canada, where he fled as the fraud was about to become public. The new arrests, coming atop 22 arrests already reported, were announced by Gholam Hossein Mohseni Ejei, the national prosecutor general, at a news conference in Tehran. He did not identify any of the suspects but according to Iranian state media accounts of the announcement, they include a number of bank managers.

headline: Wine Country Internet Provider Takes On Justice Department
text: The Obama administration has found an unlikely adversary in wine country.

headline: Wisconsin Democrats Start Drive to Recall Governor
text: Democrats in Wisconsin made a long-mulled plan official on Monday night: next month, people will begin collecting signatures to recall Gov. Scott Walker, a Republican in his first year in office whose move to limit collective bargaining rights for public workers set off a political firestorm across the state.

headline: Iraq: 19 Die Near Basra and in Baghdad
text: A land mine explosion on Monday in southern Iraq and attacks on security forces in Baghdad killed 19 people. In southern Iraq, near Basra, six soldiers were killed as they tried to clear land mines. Later in the day, an improvised bomb exploded near security forces in western Baghdad, killing 13 people, including 3 security officers who were responding to an earlier explosion. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but it appeared similar to others carried out by Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

headline: Street Protests Continue to Spread
text: As the Occupy Wall Street protests spread from Lower Manhattan to Washington and other cities, leading Democratic figures ponder how closely to embrace the movement.

headline: Markets End Mixed a Day After Rally
text: Stocks on Wall Street treaded water all day awaiting the outcome of a vote in Bratislava, where Slovakian lawmakers debated whether to back an expansion of the European bailout fund.

headline: Corrections: October 11
text: NATIONAL

headline: Riggleman to Interview With the Mets
text: The Mets will interview Jim Riggleman for their bench coach position this week to replace Ken Oberkfell.

headline: Pujols Pounds Out His Frustration in Game 2
text: MILWAUKEE — Albert Pujols lingered in the batter’s box Monday night to watch the flight of a ball he had just lifted high into the air. He was savoring the moment, it seemed.

headline: Big Data in the Dirt (and the Cloud)
text: Big data, the term for scanning loads of information for possibly profitable patterns, is a growing sector of corporate technology. Mostly people think in terms of online behavior, like mouse clicks, LinkedIn affiliations and Amazon shopping choices. But other big databases in the real world, lying around for years, are there to exploit.

headline: Internet Censorship Growth Hampers News, Study Says
text: A detailed study of Internet censorship in China and Iran shows that blocking techniques are changing rapidly and are becoming significant new obstacles for news organizations, governments and businesses.

headline: Robert Loughlin, Artist and Design Expert, Dies at 62
text: Robert Loughlin, an artist and quirky sage of Modernist design whose work as a “picker” and dealer in 20th-century furnishings influenced high-end interior decoration in the United States even though he chose to live in a trailer park, died on Sept. 27 in North Bergen, N.J. He was 62.

text: unearthly •\ˌən-ˈərth-le\• adjective

headline: Another Sexual Assault Is Reported in Brooklyn
text: A man crept up behind a woman in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, on Monday evening, groped her and then ran away, the police said.

headline: He's 97 and Famous. Spare Some Change?
text: Professor Irwin Corey, whose comedy career spans more than 80 years, has spent the past 17 years panhandling near his expensive Midtown apartment, for money to donate to Cuban charities.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
text: The 2G spectrum case continues to dominate headlines as the Central Bureau of Investigation on Monday booked former Telecom Minister and DMK leader Dayanidhi Maran and his brother, media baron Kalanithi Maran. (Hindustan Times). The bureau conducted simultaneous searches on their houses and offices. Mr. Maran is accused of receiving kickbacks from Malaysia-based company Maxis immediately after it acquired Aircell for $800 million (Times of India).

headline: Living in Both, and Neither
text: “At times I wonder, are we human beings or are we animals,” asks Manik Mia, one subject in this article by Lydia Polgreen about the enclaves of Bangladeshis living within India’s borders.

headline: Oct. 11, 1968 | First Manned Apollo Mission Lifts Off
text: On Oct. 11, 1968, Apollo 7 was launched from Cape Kennedy, Fla., with astronauts Wally Schirra, Donn Fulton Eisele and R. Walter Cunningham aboard, beginning an 11-day mission in Earth orbit. It was the first successful manned mission of the Apollo program.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 11, 2011

headline: A Mentor’s Passion for Pictures and Social Justice
text: In the mid-1980s, after I’d run through my small savings and dropped out of photography school, a friend invited me to a class at Empire State College taught by a guy named Mel.

headline: Myanmar Frees Prominent Dissident; More Political Prisoners Expected to Follow
text: BANGKOK — Myanmar freed a prominent dissident on Wednesday at the start of what state media said would be the release of 6,300 prisoners in a general amnesty that was expected to include a number of political prisoners.

headline: How Do You Personalize the Things You’re Required to Have at School?
text: According to this article, middle school students across the country are creating elaborately decorated lockers featuring items like $25 mini chandeliers and motion-sensor-equipped lamps. Is this an innocent trend that simply allows students to create an individualized space at school, or does it make students who can’t afford decorations feel inferior? How do you personalize the things you bring to, or have at, school — whether a locker, uniform, backpack, binder, or desk?

headline: Harbaugh and How the 49ers Were Built
text: From 1983 to 1998, the San Francisco 49ers won at least 10 games each season. They made the playoffs 15 times in those 16 years, and again earned playoff berths in 2001 and 2002.
