headline: Inside the Cain Tax Plan
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book “The Benefit and the Burden.”

headline: Forza 4 Doubles Down on Cars, Graphics and Clarkson
text: For gamers playing Forza 4, the new racing simulator game released Tuesday for the Xbox 360 console, every day is a track day.

headline: Director Lynch Turns Attention to Paris Night Club
text: If there’s something familiar about the brand-new Silencio, a subterranean club in Paris (142 rue Montmartre; www.silencio-club.com), it may be because you are a fan of the director David Lynch. A cross between Studio 54 and a 20th-century Parisian salon, the club takes its name from Mr. Lynch’s 2001 film “Mulholland Drive” — but that’s not where the connection ends. He also helped design it.

headline: Armchair Ethicist, Voter Edition
text: Between 1 and 5 p.m. E.S.T. today, October 11, you can discuss the following letter with the Ethicist, Ariel Kaminer. Post your comments below, and check back later to see what the Ethicist has to say.

headline: Former Ukraine Premier Is Jailed for 7 Years
text: KIEV, Ukraine — From the moment President Viktor F. Yanukovich took office last year, a central question was whether he would lead Ukraine west, toward Europe, or into a tight symbiosis with the country’s Soviet-era masters in Moscow.

headline: A Familiar Figure Begs on the Street, but Not for Himself
text: He is a familiar sight, the old man who solicits change from drivers stopped at a red light on East 35th Street in Midtown Manhattan every day near Third Avenue.

headline: The Shortfalls of Early Cancer Detection
text: The outcry among many physicians and patients over a government panel’s recent announcement that healthy men should no longer receive P.S.A. blood testing to detect prostate cancer is rooted in a long and impassioned history among cancer screening advocates that early detection must always save lives. But as science has taught us, that’s not always the case.

headline: What Happened Next
text: In my last post I imagined an exchange between myself and two tiny visitors. Three weeks without a sale, an extremely unusual event, had forced me to take a hard look at the numbers and explore what to do next.

headline: Congress: The Week Ahead
text: After a bit of unpleasantness on the Senate floor last week, members are expected to come together Tuesday to pass a bill to impose tariffs on some Chinese goods to punish Beijing for keeping its currency artificially depressed. The bill has a slim chance of ever being taken up in the House, where Democrats are pushing Republicans to consider the measure.

headline: Qatar Bets on Hobbled European Banks
text: Qatari investors are on the hunt for deals across Europe after agreeing to buy the private bank operations of the troubled European firms Dexia and KBC Group.

headline: In His Voice, There Is Peace
text: The death of velvet-voiced singer Jagjit Singh, widely credited for reviving the popularity of classical Hindustani love songs in Urdu, known as ghazals, spurred an outpouring of tributes and emotion from fans and musicians on Tuesday.

headline: A Word With: Ryan Adams Returns With New Album After Hiatus

headline: Strike Adds to Problems at Indian Auto Plant
text: MUMBAI, India — A strike at the biggest Indian car company, Maruti Suzuki, idled one of its four major production plants for the fifth consecutive day on Tuesday. The dispute pits the aspirations of manufacturing workers against the economic realities of a national labor glut.

headline: App Smart Extra: Starry, Starry Night
text: Last week’s App Smart column identified a few great apps for tracking meteor showers.

headline: Dollar Thrifty Takes Itself Off the Market
text: The Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group said on Tuesday that neither Hertz Global Holdings nor anyone else had submitted a buyout offer that met its conditions by a Monday deadline, and the company said it was no longer pursuing a sale.

headline: Nobel Laureate Faces Soccer Star in Liberian Election
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — Liberians lined up in the rain Tuesday to choose between a petite but tough Nobel Peace Prize laureate and a hulking former soccer star in this battered country’s second presidential election since the end of a bloody civil war.

headline: As Greece Avoids a Default, Recapitalization Plans Emerge for European Banks
text: BRUSSELS — Far-reaching efforts to strengthen European banks began to take shape Tuesday just as Greece cleared a major hurdle that would allow it to avoid a disorderly default on its debt.

headline: Accel in Brazilian E-Commerce Investment
text: CAMPINAS, Brazil — Accel Partners has invested in elo7, a Brazilian online handicrafts marketplace.

text: A trailer for the documentary “Eames: The Architect and the Painter,” in theaters Nov. 18.

headline: The N.B.A.’s Money Games
text: The New York Knickerbockers are about to enjoy one the best starts to a new season that they have had in a decade. That’s because there won’t be a start to the new season.

headline: A Nude Awakening
text: There’s something very sexy-cool about a glossy, nude lip. It says, “I’m hot, but I didn’t try too hard,” and it works for almost everyone. (And for almost every designer, judging by how many copped the bare-lip look for their resort and spring shows.) It’s also super-low-maintenance. “You don’t have to be concerned that your color will bleed,” says Lisa Houghton, who did the makeup on the previous page. The only caveat: you need a well-prepped pucker. Houghton exfoliated our model’s lips by dabbing on a bit of Elizabeth Arden Eight Hour Cream and rubbing it off with a tissue. Then she applied a mixture of Arden’s Crystal Clear Lip Gloss and a touch of High Shine Lip Gloss in Tropicoral for the right pinkish tone.

headline: 99 Cents Only Chain in $1.6 Billion Buyout
text: The low-cost retailer 99 Cents Only Stores agreed on Tuesday to sell itself to a group of investors that includes its founding family for $1.6 billion in cash, ending a months-long sales process.

headline: Slovakia Rejects Euro Bailout
text: WARSAW — Europe’s efforts to stem the sovereign debt crisis suffered an embarrassing and potentially costly setback on Tuesday night when Slovakia’s Parliament failed to approve the expansion of the euro rescue fund, a development that brought down the government.

headline: Textile Makers Fight to Be Heard on South Korea Trade Pact
text: WASHINGTON — There are still a few textile mills in the Carolina Piedmont, making futuristic fabrics that cover soldiers’ helmets and the roofs of commercial buildings.

headline: Brad Pitt, Zombies and Weapons: A Mystery in Hungary
text: If Hungary ever finds itself the target of an undead invasion, its police force should now be well supplied to defend the nation. Law enforcement officers there have seized dozens of weapons, including pistols, rifles and machine guns, amid conflicting reports about whether they were to be used in the filming of “World War Z,” a zombie movie starring Brad Pitt, Matthew Fox and Mireille Enos, produced by Mr. Pitt’s company, Plan B Entertainment.

headline: Hand Raised High, a Stutterer Struggles to be Heard in Class
text: I hope readers of The Choice will take a moment today to read my colleague Richard Perez-Pena’s nuanced account of Phillip Garber Jr.’s efforts to get his professor at County College of Morris in New Jersey to call on him in class.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Fresh Off the Boat: Eddie Huang says Andy Ricker of Pok Pok, in Portland, Ore., will be taking over the original BaoHaus in a few weeks to serve up his famous Thai-style chicken wings. Mr. Ricker won Best Chef Northwest at the James Beard Awards this year. — Nick Fox

headline: Intellectual Styles Of The Rich And Clueless
text: Oh, my. Jeff Immelt, who President Obama for some reason appointed to head his job creation panel, insists that what’s good for GE is good for America:

headline: ‘Twitter Trolls’ Haunt Discussions of Bahrain Online
text: That bit of advice about Bahrain, delivered to Twitter followers of a conference of Arab bloggers in Tunisia last week, highlights an often aggressive effort on social media to cajole, harass and intimidate commentators and journalists who write about the protests in Bahrain and the government’s response.

headline: Edible Selby | Pie Squared
text: Melissa and Emily Elsen, two sisters from South Dakota, opened Four & Twenty Blackbirds, their pie and coffee shop in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn, with the expectation that they would serve about 10 pies a day. A little over a year later, they are averaging more like 50 pies a day, with customers traveling from around New York City to sample their fresh, seasonal fillings, like blueberry rhubarb or strawberry balsamic. Though they are doing a brisk business, the sisters Elsen continue to make their crust from scratch, two pounds at a time. “We love the homespun, hands-on intensity of it,” Emily says. “When you make a good pie crust, it’s really gratifying.” Go to interactive feature >>

headline: Inside ‘Martha Marcy May Marlene’
text: In Anatomy of a Scene, the writer and director Sean Durkin discusses “Martha Marcy May Marlene.”

headline: Stocks, Flows, and Fuzzy Math
text: I read David Brooks citing the Tax Foundation this morning, and I thought he must have misread them. They couldn’t possibly have compared one year’s take from higher taxes on the rich with the total stock of debt, could they? They can’t possibly be that stupid, or think that their readers are that stupid, can they?

headline: Investor Says Momentum Builds for Breakup of Research in Motion
text: The call is growing louder for Research in Motion to explore a sale of all or part of the company.

headline: Palin Takes ‘Crony Capitalism’ Fight to South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea – On her first trip to South Korea, former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska sounded just like a politician on the campaign stump on Tuesday, lashing out at her pet enemy: “crony capitalism.”

headline: Wise Words On Europe
text: Kash Mansori has a very good piece on the eurozone crisis, making some points I’ve also tried to hit. Basically, he sees the peripheral countries mainly as victims of an overwhelming tide of cheap money from the core, who are now suffering whiplash when that inflow came to a sudden stop:

headline: Now Showing | Ryan Roche
text: A film showcases Ryan Roche’s latest collection.

headline: A Top Egyptian Minister Quits in Protest Over Killings
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s finance minister resigned Tuesday in protest over the killing of two dozen unarmed Coptic Christian protesters by the security forces, as reverberations from the outburst of violence two days ago continued to shake Egypt’s interim government.

headline: Young and Unawed by Woods’s Shadow
text: SAN MARTIN, Calif.

headline: Metro Pucks: Report Cards, Awards and Analysis
text: The Rangers did not win a game. The Islanders and Devils did, but not after enduring the embarrassment of getting shut out before capacity crowds at their home openers. What was learned from the first six games of the season for the Rangers, Devils and Islanders? Not much in the 82-game big picture. But for the faithful who couldn’t wait for the second weekend in October, hockey provides plenty to analyze.

headline: Sony Unveils a Camera for Speed Demons
text: It seems like camera makers are bragging less about how many megapixels are on their sensors – which  is nearly useless as a measure of quality anyway — but are taking up a new selling point: speed.

headline: Chevrolet Confirms Colorado Pickup and Camaro ZL1 Convertible
text: WARREN, Mich. — During a media event marking Chevrolet’s 100th anniversary, held at the General Motors Design Center here, G.M. announced that a new version of the Chevrolet Colorado midsize pickup truck would be offered to American buyers. The automaker also unveiled a convertible model of its ultra high-performance Camaro ZL1.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Kimann Foxman
text: It was a curious scene, walking up lower Broadway in broad daylight and hearing the heavy beats pumping from a window above. A freight elevator ride and hefty door charge later, you’d never guess it was midafternoon, as a few hundred people crowded an empty loft space and danced to music played by an all-star roster of D.J.’s. The nine-hour event was in celebration of the 12th anniversary of Tim Sweeney’s weekly radio show “Beats in Space,” which has been broadcast every Tuesday night on WNYU (89.1) since 1999. The lineup included Rub N Tug, Kimann Foxman (of Hercules and Love Affair fame, pictured here), Matthew Dear and Sweeney himself.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Martha Marcy May Marlene’
text: Cults, paranoia and a breakdown of trust are among the central topics explored in the psychological drama “Martha Marcy May Marlene,” written and directed by Sean Durkin. The film, which plays this week at the New York Film Festival before opening in theaters on Oct. 21, follows one young woman (Elizabeth Olsen) after she has escaped from a cult and has gone to stay with her sister (Sarah Paulson) and her sister’s husband. In this video, Mr. Durkin narrates a scene from the film that illustrates the haziness of Martha’s psychological state after her escape.

headline: Regulators Advance Volcker Rule
text: Federal regulators on Tuesday took a much-anticipated step toward reining in risky trading on Wall Street, introducing a proposal that would prohibit federally insured banks from making certain types of bets with their own money.

headline: Detroit Gets Its Motor Running
text: It’s hard not to root for Detroit. The city, that is. It has been dealt a pretty brutal hand by recent history, enduring the crippling combination of economic freefall, Canadian winters and Matt Millen. And no matter what you think of the place, gosh, nobody deserves Matt Millen.

headline: An Olsen Sister Finds a Spotlight All Her Own
text: ON a rainy afternoon last month, Elizabeth Olsen apologized profusely for pushing back by more than an hour a luncheon interview at a restaurant in the Gramercy Park neighborhood of Manhattan. “I’m so sorry,” she said. “I really hate being late.”

headline: Latino Players Find Home on the Prairie
text: More than 1,500 miles from his home campus in Altus, Okla., a junior-college baseball coach might have seemed out of place recently at a rundown diamond in Brooklyn. But that is how he likes it.

headline: Preserving Memories of Pets, and Then Some
text: Amy Finkel lives in an apartment in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, that does not allow pets. But she does have a groundhog (Chompers), an armadillo (Fleischesser) and a boar (Angel). They are all, however, dead and stuffed — and in the case of the boar, it is just the head.

headline: A Passion for Pictures, and for Social Justice
text: Mel Rosenthal, a photojournalist and teacher with a passion for social justice and the South Bronx neighborhood where he grew up, is retiring from Empire State College after 36 years. Our colleagues on Lens are giving him a sendoff including a slide show of his work and a Q. and A. about how he earned the trust of his subjects. “I was walking down street one day, some gang members saw me,” Mr. Rosenthal recalls. “They said, ‘What the hell you doing here?’ One lifted up his pants. He had two Berettas strapped to his ankles. I said, ‘Do you really need two guns?’ ” Read more on Lens »

headline: Treatment of Trauma to Brain Is Studied
text: Techniques being used to treat psychological lapses from traumatic brain injuries, the signature wounds suffered by troops in Iraq and Afghanistan, appear to be helpful, but lack rigorous scientific support, a government-appointed panel reported Tuesday after completing the most comprehensive analysis of the evidence to date.

headline: Raine Group Ramps Up
text: The Raine Group, an investment boutique focused on the media and entertainment industries, said Tuesday that it had made a major hire and closed on its first private equity fund.

headline: President’s Jobs Measure Is Turned Back in Key Senate Test
text: WASHINGTON — In a major setback for President Obama, the Senate on Tuesday blocked consideration of his $447 billion jobs bill, forcing the White House and Congressional Democrats to scramble to salvage parts of the plan, the centerpiece of Mr. Obama’s push to revive a listless economy.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct.11
text: The day in sports included world championships for fencing in Italy and for artistic gymnastics in Tokyo.

headline: Why I’m Not In Zuccotti Park
text: Some readers have been asking me to go make a speech at one of the OWS demonstrations. If you think about it, however, you’ll see why I can’t.

headline: Weber on the Web
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Hockey Heroes
text: “Hockey Heroes,” a short film made for the web by Bruce Weber, features Sidney Crosby and Alexander Ovechkin.

headline: Ban Hybrids From the Fast Lane, and Everyone Slows Down
text: Last spring I wrote about the indignation of hybrid car owners in California who were about to lose their rights to drive in the carpool lane. The state lawmakers who approved the July 1 cutoff seemed to take the position that virtue was its own reward.

headline: Magical Days on Panamoti Island
text: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Wall St. Banks Help Hedge Funds Recruit | In an effort to secure lucrative brokerage and trading business, big banks like Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America have become powerful recruiting forces for their biggest hedge fund clients. The banks are scouting finance executives, accountants and receptionists for free. Goldman calls the practice “talent introduction.”

headline: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company in London
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 15th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from London.

headline: Another Potential Transatlantic Suitor Emerges
text: Two bidders for Transatlantic Holdings have already walked away, but another potential suitor may yet make an offer for the reinsurance company.

headline: Banning Sexy Ads Near Schools
text: It will never happen here, but oh, how I wish it would. Over at The Gloss, Jessica Pauline Ogilvie reports that Britain  is banning outdoor “overtly sexual ads” within 100 meters of a school, and “ridiculously sexual, over-the-top, basically porn” ads won’t be allowed on billboards at all.

headline: The Big-Band Theory
text: When Preston Miller ﬁrst picked up a tuba, he knew he had found his instrument. ‘‘It’s big, it’s loud and it’s fun,’’ he says. So is the marching band at Allen High School, the largest in the country.

headline: Excerpt: 'Last Man Standing'
text: Tim Allen is a put-upon father in his new sitcom on ABC.

headline: Video, a New Tool for the Police, Poses New Legal Issues, Too
text: When a man was fatally shot by a police officer on a street in Oakland, Calif., late last month, the shooting was captured by a video camera.

headline: Excerpt: ‘How to Be a Gentleman’
text: The new CBS sitcom updates the “Odd Couple.”

headline: Wasteland of Mutants and Thugs
text: This is a tale of exhilaration and crushing disappointment, of awe and anger. This is my story of Rage, the simultaneously inspiring and infuriating new game from id Software.

headline: Online Game Challenges You to Live On $1,000 A Month
text: Could you live on $1,000 a month? An online game called Spent lets you see what it’s like to make the tough choices necessary to get by on that amount of income.

headline: Worsening Attitudes
text: Americans have given their economy a vote of no confidence. Or at least, very little confidence.

headline: The Republican Scramble, Continued
text: The comment stream in response to my Monday column – “Is the Tea Party Over?” – was divided for the most part into one camp of readers proclaiming the inevitable triumph of the Tea Party, and another, larger camp praying for its demise. There’s no point quarreling with faith (in the first case) or hope (in the second). To my mind the question is whether the Tea Party will transform itself from a backlash – the Party of Against – into a force that can make things happen. The movement’s best hope of making that leap any time soon, which you can view with approval or alarm, is Rick Perry.

headline: News Corp. Filing Rebuts Criticism of Board
text: News Corporation went on the defensive Tuesday morning after an investor advisory firm urged shareholders to vote against reinstating several key members of the media giant’s board of directors, including the chairman and chief executive, Rupert Murdoch, and his son James Murdoch.

headline: Some Pregame Comments: U.S. vs. Ecuador
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The United States men’s national team plays Ecuador in an international friendly at Red Bull Arena on Tuesday night in the fifth game of the Jurgen Klinsmann era. Though additional matches for the rest of the year have not been announced, it is expected that the U.S. will play in Europe next month.

headline: Less Is More | Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby
text: In the last several months, the British designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby of BarberOsgerby have once gain proven their impressive versatility. They’ve produced an inexpensive, wildly practical plastic chair for Vitra and directed a group of students from the ECAL in Lausanne, Switzerland, to create a playfully luxe group of objects based on a traditional Baccarat goblet. And they’ve been on fire — pardon the pun — since they were named in June as the designers of the 2012 Olympic torch, a sleek, triangular form with 8,000 perforated circles that represent each of the people who will carry the torches. (Yes, 8,000 torches — one for each torchbearer — will be produced.) But their latest effort is not about design in the expected sense.

headline: No Major Zombie Injuries After Accident on Film Shoot
text: It’s apparently a bad week to be producing a motion picture about the living dead. After what may or may not have been a weapons raid on the Brad Pitt zombie movie, “World War Z,” a platform collapse in Canada on the set of the latest installment in the “Resident Evil” series has resulted in injuries to 16 actors portraying zombies, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Seattle ‘Superhero’ Arrested in Pepper-Spraying Episode
text: Maybe now he’ll go by Pepper Man.

headline: A Marathon Runner Delivers a Baby
text: Amber Miller, a veteran marathon runner, did not have much time to celebrate after finishing the Chicago Marathon on Sunday: She had a baby to deliver.

headline: Christie Endorses Romney Ahead of Debate
text: 3:34 p.m. | Updated  LEBANON, N.H. – Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey endorsed Mitt Romney’s bid for the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday afternoon by praising his business and government experience, declaring, “Mitt Romney is the man we need to lead America.”

headline: Bachmann Releases Her Economic Plan
text: It doesn’t have the catchiness of Herman Cain’s 9-9-9 plan. It is more succinct than Mitt Romney’s 59-point proposal.

headline: In Supercomputing, a Turn to Energy-Saving Graphics Chips
text: In computing, as in so many fields, the best path to progress is often not a straight line.

headline: Tax S.U.V.'s?
text: Matt Welch, left, of Reason and Robert Frank of Cornell University debate taxing owners of sport utility vehicles.

headline: A Dark Lyricist Turns to Tales For Children
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Can you trust Colin Meloy with your children?

headline: Wheelies: The High-Occupancy Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Tappan Zee Bridge Project Gets Fast-Tracked
text: Updated: A fuller version of this article can be found here.

headline: A.I.G. Is Now Worried About Bad P.R. — for Policyholders
text: Insurance providers are constantly coming up with new products to sell to policyholders. But the American International Group has hit upon one of the more unusual new services we’ve heard of in some time: reputation insurance.

headline: Language Lessons From Babies
text: In today’s 18 and Under column, Dr. Perri Klass writes about new science of bilingualism and how scientists are teasing out the earliest differences between brains exposed to one language and brains exposed to two.

headline: Cue the Kitsch: Soderbergh to Make Liberace Film Starring Douglas and Damon for HBO
text: You spend enough years in Las Vegas and eventually its kitschy charm leaves an indelible mark on you. Having made three movies about Danny Ocean and his Rat Pack-like team of casino-heist experts, as well as critically acclaimed films like “Traffic,” “Erin Brockovich” and “Sex, Lies and Videotape,” Steven Soderbergh has turned to the only subject that was left for him: a biographical movie about Liberace.

headline: Playing From the Crib to the Console
text: Video game use is exploding among the youngest among us, according to a new survey.

headline: Should a Stutterer Speak in Class?
text: Philip Garber Jr.  is 16 and taking two college classes. He is thoughtful, engaged and eager to contribute to class discussion — a dream student in many respects. But because his stutter is extreme, it takes him far longer than other students to ask a question or make a comment. So, as Richard Pérez-Peña writes in today’s New York Times, his history teacher has asked him not to.

headline: Dreams of a McCain Presidency
text: The most interesting part of Ezra Klein’s lengthy “what went wrong” assessment of the Obama administration’s economic policy is the way it raises the possibility that a John McCain presidency might have delivered a more effective response to the Great Recession. With McCain in the White House and a Democratic majority in Congress, Klein implies, we might have had a smaller, better-targeted stimulus package (perhaps more like the one that Alice Rivlin recommended) joined to a more robust intervention in the housing market (like the one McCain’s campaign proposed in the autumn of 2008). Jonathan Chait takes this idea and uses it to make a broader argument that a McCain presidency would have forestalled the popular backlash against deficit-financed stimulus:

headline: Israel and Hamas Agree to Swap Prisoners for Soldier
text: JERUSALEM — Israel and Hamas announced an agreement on Tuesday to exchange more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners for an Israeli soldier held captive in Gaza for five years, a deal brokered by Egypt that seemed likely to shake up Middle East politics at a time when the region is immersed in turmoil.

headline: Obama Pushes Jobs Plan as Senate Prepares to Vote
text: PITTSBURGH — President Obama continued the drumbeat for his jobs plan on Tuesday, even as White House officials acknowledged that the bill’s prospects in the Senate were tenuous and Mr. Obama himself vowed not to wait for Congress to advance ideas to get American back to work.

headline: The Avante-Garde Arrives in Montclair, at Adara
text: Does Montclair, N.J., hunger for a restaurant whose mission statement promises to explore “the relationship between food, art and technology”?

headline: Prostatectomy  - series
Stanford Teams With City College (Think Engineering School)
text: In the chess match to determine which university will get a chance to build a graduate school of applied sciences on public land in New York City, Stanford is trying what might be called a C.C.N.Y. stratagem.

headline: Brightness Rises | Patrick Cox’s Third Act
text: Patrick Cox’s Wannabe loafer, a design-y take on the traditional schoolboy shoe, was a smash hit in the early ’90s — almost a million pairs were sold every year. “I was just a kid in England doing this thing that became gigantic and global,” says Cox, who was 31 at the time. Stores opened in London, then Paris and New York, and the chunky, heeled shoes all flew out the door. Then came what Cox now calls his Second Album Syndrome. “Wannabe was so huge,” he remembers. “So big. So unexpected.” What could he possibly do to top it? Though the company chugged along for a few years, Cox eventually sold it in 2007. Faced with a noncompete clause, he traveled for a bit and eventually opened a bakery called Cox Cookies and Cake  on the naughty side of Soho in London, selling baked goods that cheekily made references to the peep shows and X-rated video stores that flanked his storefront.

headline: Reviewing Per Se
text: More photos of Thomas Keller’s four-star restaurant in Manhattan.

headline: Missouri to Play in the Big 12 Next Season, and Then Decide
text: The future of Missouri’s athletic program remains the biggest mystery in college sports, though a conference call Tuesday morning provided some clarity. The Big 12’s interim commissioner, Chuck Neinas, said Missouri would play in the league for the 2012-13 season, giving the university time to decide whether to stay in the league or attempt to join the Southeastern Conference.

headline: The Coast of Utopia
text: A look at the dwellings of Cabo Polonio, a remote beach village in southeastern Uruguay.

headline: CNBC Expands Two Programs and Cancels Two Others
text: The business news channel CNBC is rearranging two of its market hours by canceling two programs and expanding two others in their place.

headline: Where’s the Beach? Under the Seaweed.
text: AN invasion of seaweed that is extraordinary in volume and geographic scope has been besieging the eastern Caribbean since June, sending resorts and government agencies from Anguilla in the north to Tobago in the south scrambling to rid beaches of the smelly, brown, bug-attracting algae before the impending high season.

headline: Director of ‘Avatar,’ ‘Titanic’ Promotes Innovation
text: 3:50 p.m. | Updated The death last week of Steven P. Jobs led some to wonder about the future of innovation in the United States. They need not worry, according to James Cameron, the film director whose movies like “Avatar” and “Titanic” have a gee-whiz element that is underpinned by science.

headline: DealBook: Momentum Builds for Breakup of RIM
text: The call is growing louder for Research in Motion to explore a sale of all or part of the company.

headline: For Cruz, a Bit of History
text: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. His Phillies homerism is no longer an issue.

headline: Video Shows Protesters Arrested in Boston and Washington
text: The police in Boston arrested more than 100 people early Tuesday morning following a march tied to a national protest movement that began on Wall Street in New York.

headline: James Woolery of JPMorgan Surveys the M.&A. Scene
text: Earlier this year, James C. Woolery left one of the plum legal jobs in the world, as a partner at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, to become the co-head of North America mergers and acquisitions alongside Chris Ventresca at JPMorgan Chase.

headline: A Glacial Ice Bar in Patagonia
text: The first ice bar in Patagonia, Argentina, opened last week just outside the town of El Calafate. GlacioBar, billed as the only bar in the world made out of glacial ice, is the latest addition to Glaciarium, a new science museum dedicated to the region’s hundreds of glaciers.

headline: Iranians Accused of a Plot to Kill Saudis’ U.S. Envoy
text: WASHINGTON — The United States on Tuesday accused Iranian officials of plotting to murder Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to the United States in a bizarre scheme involving an Iranian-American used-car salesman who believed he was hiring assassins from a Mexican drug cartel for $1.5 million.

text: A well-known advertising agency in the Northeast, Carrafiello-Diehl & Associates, is closing and its remaining accounts and employees are being absorbed by an agency named the Gate Worldwide.

headline: Council Debate on School Layoffs Grows Heated
text: At an often heated hearing before the City Council on Tuesday, Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott defended the administration’s decision to lay off 672 school support workers last week and said that officials had warned of the layoffs in June. City Council members — some of whom argued that counting the city’s share of unemployment-benefit and food-stamp costs, the savings from the layoffs would be insignificant — were unconvinced that they were necessary. headline: Utopia in Motion

headline: Is a Shorter N.B.A. Season So Bad?
text: Monday’s N.B.A. news — that the league has canceled the first two weeks of its season after negotiations with the players union once again proved unfruitful — means that each team will lose about a half-dozen games for now.

headline: N.B.A. Players Use Twitter Carefully
text: With the N.B.A. lockout growing nastier, players having a vehicle to unload their thoughts directly to fans is potentially an image disaster. Even before the Twitter age, it was only a matter of time until a player said something that instantly made all players look ridiculous and out of touch — think Patrick Ewing’s “Sure, we make a lot of money, but we spend a lot, too” comment that became the eye-roller of the 1999 lockout. Now, that danger is only 140 characters away.

headline: The Bilingual Baby Brain
text: Babies raised in bilingual or non-English-speaking households in largely English-speaking territory think differently. Perri Klass has a fascinating article  in today’s New York Times on exactly how differently: they take longer to distinguish phonetic sounds in either language, but then hear them in both; they retain an interest in other languages longer; and as their languages develop, so do strong multitasking and problem-solving skills.

headline: Joseph Cedar Discusses ‘Footnote’
text: In his latest film “Footnote,” the writer and director Joseph Cedar uses Hebrew philology and Talmudic scholarship to weave together a dramatic mystery. Concerning a father and son who are rival professors at a university, the movie looks at how a scholar can devote his life to a single topic of study. When he wrote about it at Telluride, A. O. Scott said the film “blends academic satire, classic Jewish humor and an almost Shakespearean sense of the tragic potential of the paternal bond.” “Footnote” is screening at the New York Film Festival this week and in this video, Mr. Cedar discusses elements of the film and some of the research he did to put it together.

headline: Blind Faith That Is Shaken Under a Revival Tent
text: It was after midnight at the dawn of the 1960s. Donna Johnson was 3, her brother 1, her father gone. Her mother had sold everything — “knickknacks, flatware, all of her slacks” — to join a traveling caravan of evangelists led by the preacher Brother David Terrell. Holding tent revivals in a new town every few weeks, they were essentially carnies, but instead of hawking funnel cakes, they were selling God.

headline: Motherwell Painting Declared a Forgery
text: A forged Robert Motherwell painting was branded with the equivalent of a scarlet letter on Tuesday in a legal settlement involving three art galleries and the Dedalus Foundation, which owns the copyrights to Motherwell’s works. “Spanish Elegy,” the painting at the center of the dispute, was sold to a European gallery, Killala Fine Art, for $650,000 in 2007 by Julian Weissman, who had previously worked as a salesman at Knoedler & Company in Manhattan. Before the sale Dedalus initially concluded that “Spanish Elegy” was authentic, but later backtracked and declared the work, supposedly painted by Motherwell in 1953, to be a fake. The Killala gallery said in its lawsuit that it had relied on the foundation’s assurance in making the purchase. Mr. Weissman was accused of acquiring the painting from Glafira Rosales, a dealer on Long Island, and of hiding its provenance, according to court papers. As part of the settlement, Ms. Rosales and her gallery will pick up most of the cost of reimbursing Killala for the price of the painting and Dedalus for its expenses. Mr. Weissman will pay the remaining portion. The foundation marked the back of “Spanish Elegy” (above) with a stamp in capital letters and indelible ink that says Dedalus “has determined that this painting is not an authentic work by Robert Motherwell but a forgery.”

headline: Romney Readies for Health Care Attacks at Debate
text: HANOVER, N.H. — If there’s one thing that Mitt Romney is bracing for at Tuesday night’s debate, it is an assault on his health care record as governor of Massachusetts.

headline: Baritone in ‘Don Giovanni’ Taken to Hospital
text: Mariusz Kwiecien, the Polish baritone who was cast in the title role of the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of “Don Giovanni,” which opens on Thursday night, underwent surgery for a herniated disk on Tuesday, his manager said. “The doctors feel that Mariusz’s prognosis is excellent,” said the manager, William Guerri, of Columbia Artists Management. But it was unclear when he might return to the stage. “It’s a wait-and-see proposition,” Mr. Guerri said. Mr. Kwiecien felt pain during the opening scene of Monday’s dress rehearsal, the manager said. He was taken by paramedics to a hospital, said the Met spokesman, Peter Clark. The Met tapped Peter Mattei, who was on hand for a production of Rossini’s “Barbiere di Siviglia,” to replace Mr. Kwiecien for the opening of “Don Giovanni.” The opera has 16 more performances into March, although Mr. Kwiecien was scheduled to be in the cast only through Nov. 11.

headline: Samurai Shopper | The Wages of Skin
text: Ouch. My face hurts. I know, it’s killing you too — oldest joke in the book. But it’s no joke: one occupational hazard of testing skin-care products is overdosing on irritants. Chemicals can get under your skin, and even natural substances — essential oils, for example — can wreak havoc: lavender’s aroma can be therapeutic and calming, but don’t ply your face with lavender oil. Ditto minty or citrusy oils and anything acidic, unless buried in a gentle formula. Hypoallergenics can also be problematic. Many contain potential endocrine disrupters and other nasty components. Besides, allergies are as varied as fingerprints; there’s no one-size-fits-all solution to irritated skin.

headline: U.S. Says Man Admitted Plot to Blow Up Passenger Jet
text: DETROIT — Even before the plane had landed, a badly burned Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab was admitting to a fellow passenger that, yes, he had just been trying to ignite an explosive device, a prosecutor said Tuesday as Mr. Abdulmutallab’s trial on charges of trying to blow up a plane in 2009 began.

headline: A Gypsy Love Story, Now With a Happy Ending
text: Presentations of live, high-definition ballet in movie theaters worldwide, keeping abreast with those of opera and theater, have become a trend in the last year or so. Just now, however, only one ballet company is making the most of them: the Bolshoi in Moscow. During the 2010-11 season it screened performances of “Don Quixote,” “Coppélia” and “Swan Lake”; in the 2011-12 season it is presenting six more, starting last Sunday with “Esmeralda.”

headline: Justin Vernon, the Good Boyfriend
text: Among the surprising revelations in Jon Caramanica’s magazine profile of Justin Vernon (the man behind the band Bon Iver) in June — like the existence of a tattoo of the state of Wisconsin on his collarbone — was Vernon’s relationship with the songwriter Kathleen Edwards. According to Vernon, Edwards helped keep him sane, and he, in return, was helping produce her latest record. Vernon, as you would expect, said nice things about his girlfriend: ‘‘I would always try to write songs like her,’’ he told Caramanica. ‘‘I was never that good.’’

headline: A Closer Look at the Haqqani Anniversary Attack on American-Afghan Outposts
text: FORWARD OPERATING BASE ORGUN-E, Afghanistan – Last Friday, on the 10th anniversary of the start of the Afghan war, at least several dozen fighters from the Haqqani insurgent network launched a complex attack against multiple American-Afghan outposts near the Pakistan border.

headline: Electronic Master and Pupil

headline: Electronic Music That Plays to the Senses, Both Sound and Sight
text: Most of the time, it might not matter what Skrillex is doing with his hands. Every time the bass dropped during his outrageous, frenetic, head-and-body-abusing set at the Starland Ballroom in Sayreville, N. J., on Sunday night, it rendered most other input moot. The bass was a warhead, landing with a boom, sticking around with a wobble.

headline: From Bemidji State to Flyers Rookie

headline: Plenty Bakery Opens on Upper East Side
text: Plenty is a new bakery, but it’s a throwback to a time when places with homey cakes and pastries tempted many neighborhoods. The owner, Jessica Weiss, pictured, speaks lovingly about the crumb cake, rugelach and such that her father and grandmother baked. She grew up baking on Long Island, in the Five Towns, but until recently ran and owned a tutoring company for standardized tests. She did some catering jobs before opening Plenty, which has a few tables and also serves soups, salads and sandwiches. Gradually, the inventory will expand with black-and-white cookies and more layer cakes.

headline: Sea Salt Harvested From the Surf Off Amagansett
text: Many weekend mornings find Steven Judelson, above, wearing waders and splashing into the surf off the beaches of Amagansett to haul five-gallon buckets of water from the sea. Then he and his wife, Natalie, evaporate it to make sea salt with a Hamptons pedigree. The Judelsons, two well-traveled lawyers who are passionate about food, had seen sea salts from around the world in markets and thought, “Why not out here?”

headline: Microwave Popcorn Minus the Chemicals
text: Kristy and Coulter Lewis were dissatisfied with the ingredients and additives in microwave popcorn. Quinn Popcorn, named for their baby son, uses organic ingredients and a simple food-grade parchment paper bag instead of a pouch treated with compounds like perfluoro-octanoic and metals to keep the bag from absorbing grease and increase the amount of corn that pops. You add Quinn Popcorn’s oil and seasoning mixture after the corn is popped, so grease-proofing the bag is not an issue. And if a few kernels may be duds, what pops is delicious.

headline: For Three Teenagers, Easing Life’s Struggles Through Poetry
text: On paper, “To Be Heard” may sound like the kind of production that’s better at “raising awareness” than at holding anyone’s interest. In a straightforward vérité style, it tracks the intertwining trajectories of three underprivileged New York City teenagers whose lives are transformed by their participation in a pedagogically progressive slam-poetry program at University Heights High School in the Bronx. There are inspirational triumphs and painful setbacks, and, yes, the students read their poems in sincerely unguarded performances.

headline: The Good Life Comes a Little Harder in the Finger Lakes

Forget about the glitz and conspicuous consumption associated with Napa Valley, or even the bucolic wealth and gracious living emblematic of what Robert Mondavi used to call the good life.

headline: Challenging an Unhealthy Focus on Weight and Aesthetics
text: Darryl Roberts’s scattered documentary “America the Beautiful 2” treads similar territory as his “America the Beautiful” from 2008. (Was it really that big a hit?) Among its deserving concerns are the punishing demands for weight loss in the modeling profession, the dire toll of plastic surgery and anorexia, and other manifestations of how the prevailing aesthetic abuses women (and, it suggests, men). A persistent refrain is its view of the body mass index as an insidiously excessive criterion for health.

headline: Love in the Time of Stonewall
text: In 1979, George Segal, the famous Pop artist, was commissioned to create a sculpture to commemorate New York City’s Stonewall uprising in 1969 — the seminal (although not the only) event to kick-start the gay liberation movement. The bronze sculpture, covered with a white patina, was finally unveiled in Christopher Park in Greenwich Village in 1992, after years of controversy. It depicts a life-size male couple standing a few feet away from another life-size female couple sitting on a park bench. Beth Suskin, my partner of 35 years, and I, Leslie Cohen, were the models for this sculpture. This is our love story.

headline: A War Not for Abolition
text: One Saturday in late September 1861, Manhattan witnessed a scene that was becoming commonplace in countless New England towns and cities: well over 1,000 soldiers marched through the city, in the words of one observer, “Singing reverently and enthusiastically in praise of John Brown!” Abolitionism was hardly a universal idea, but the name on everyone’s lips was that of its most fiery, violent advocate. “No military hero of the present war,” the New York Independent noted, “has thus been honored.”

headline: Thailand: Bangkok Is Warned of Flood Danger Next Week
text: The worst floods in more than 50 years threaten to overwhelm barriers protecting Bangkok, and residents should be prepared for the danger, said Deputy Prime Minister Kittiratt Na-Ranong, who called it a crisis. Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra has urged officials to complete work on three flood barriers and five more canals to drain water from the capital before high tides peak on Monday. Officials are also shoring up flood walls, preparing evacuation plans and readying medical supplies, city officials said.

headline: In Seeking Rate Increases in New York, Health Insurers Fight to Keep Secrets
text: Major health insurance companies seeking steep premium increases in New York have submitted memos to state officials to justify the higher rates. Now they are fighting to keep the memos from the public, saying they include trade secrets that competitors could use against them.

headline: Berlusconi’s Coalition Survives Despite Maze of Political Factions
text: ROME — In the 18 years that he has dominated Italian politics, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi has created the illusion that Italy has a solid two-party system. Now that his era is slowly drawing to a close, the glue has come undone, revealing the chaos that is the Italian Parliament.

headline: Finally Making Sense on Wall Street

headline: Uganda: Parliament Votes to Halt New Oil Ventures
text: Parliament voted in an emergency session on Tuesday to halt development of Uganda’s nascent oil sector. The session was called on Monday to debate the potentially lucrative industry, in which foreign contracts have been kept secret and allegations of corruption are rampant. The session continued on Tuesday with members of Parliament accusing officials close to President Yoweri Museveni of accepting millions of dollars in bribes. Lawmakers also called for a delay in the imminent signing of an agreement between the government and three oil companies, and suspended new ventures until a national oil policy could be put in place. The vote comes at a time when commodity prices have skyrocketed and dissent is spreading. Large reserves were discovered in 2006 that could turn Uganda into a major oil industry player in Africa.

headline: What Parkinson’s Teaches Us About the Brain
text: Scientific discoveries can be serendipitous, and so it was when Jay L. Alberts, then a Parkinson’s disease researcher at Emory University in Atlanta, mounted a tandem bike with Cathy Frazier, a Parkinson’s patient. The two were riding the 2003 RAGBRAI bicycle tour across Iowa, hoping to raise awareness of the neurodegenerative disease and “show people with Parkinson’s that you don’t have to sit back and let the disease take over your life,” Dr. Alberts said.

headline: A Vatican ‘Secret’ For Columbus Day
text: In a post-Dan Brown world the mere mention of the Secret Vatican Archives conjures up nefarious mystery and intrigue. In fact, the “Secret” in the archives’ name refers to the private nature of the thousands of documents that line more than 50 miles’ of shelves in a two-story bunker beneath the Vatican Museums. Many of the documents have unique historical importance, like the 1493 papal bull granting to Spain lands recently discovered by Christopher Columbus. The document, known as the “Inter Caetera” bull, is well known to scholars but perhaps less so to the general public, which will be able to peruse a fragment online at luxinarcana.org on Wednesday, the day denoting Columbus’s arrival in the Americas in 1492. It is one of 100 documents that will go on a rare public viewing at the Capitoline Museum in Rome in February as part of an exhibition celebrating the 400th anniversary of the foundation of the archives. Drafted by Pope Alexander VI, the papal bull not only granted Spain certain rights in the newly discovered lands but also called for the evangelization of the indigenous people there. “It is part of the history of the colonization of the Americas that gave rise to a series of problems whose consequences would be felt over time,” said Luca Carboni, secretary general of the archives.

text: Known for electric facials that make A-list clients look as if they’ve had face-lifts, Melanie Simon uses her magic machines (and Circ-Cell, her product line) to coax youth from even the most stubborn complexions. Go to circcell.com.

headline: MDC Looks Abroad for Acquisition
text: MDC Partners, the agency holding company known for its acquisitive ways, is making its first deal involving a public relations agency outside of North America.

headline: U.S. Tax Evasion Case Touches Julius Baer
text: PARIS — A tax evasion investigation in the United States has reached Julius Baer, a spokesman for the Swiss lender confirmed Wednesday, a day after the government charged two advisers with conspiring to help clients evade United States taxes on more than $600 million hidden in offshore accounts.

headline: S. Korean State Visit Highlights Bond Between 2 Leaders
text: WASHINGTON — During the state visit of South Korea’s president, Lee Myung-bak, which began on Wednesday, he will be feted at a White House state dinner, invited to speak to a joint session of Congress, and treated to a road trip to Detroit with President Obama, where the two leaders plan to tour a General Motors factory together.

headline: Iran Sees Plot Accusation as Diversion From Wall Street Protests
text: A day after the Justice Department accused Iranian agents of plotting an elaborate international scheme to assassinate a Saudi Arabian diplomat on American soil, the government of Iran appeared to coalesce around at least one explanation for the news: Occupy Wall Street.

headline: Wednesday Reading: More Evidence Against Vitamin Use
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Liz Claiborne Sells Portfolio of Brands
text: Liz Claiborne continues to clean out its closet of brands.

headline: Giving: The Pratham Gala
text: Pratham, the Mumbai-based nonprofit which helps educate underprivileged children in India, raised $1.1 million at its annual tri-state gala last week at the Pierre Hotel in New York City. The evening began with cocktails, and the 400 guests who paid $500 or more for a single ticket noshed on snacks like bhelpuri and dhokla.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: A Postcard on Amazon Forest Trends
text: 2:32 p.m. | Updated I received an e-mail last week from a publicist at Fleishman-Hillard, forwarding news that Brazil’s Ministry of Environment had announced the lowest Amazon deforestation rates for the month of August since precise monitoring began in 2004. The core line:

headline: Shares Are Bolstered by News From Europe
text: Wall Street closed higher on Wednesday, after a new plan was unveiled to recapitalize European banks and a deal was struck in Slovakia that is expected to permit the creation of a larger, more powerful euro zone bailout fund.

headline: Accessories as Art
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: BlackBerry’s Service Hiccups Spread; Five Continents Affected
text: Research in Motion said Wednesday that after three days it was still trying to restore service for BlackBerry customers spanning five continents.

headline: Former Saudi Ambassador on Alleged Plot
text: Former Saudi Ambassador to the United States Prince Turki bin Faisal Al Saud reacts to the alleged Iranian-backed plot against its embassy in the United States.

headline: Another Chance for a Pitching Duel
text: All too often in the postseason the overly hyped pitching matchups end up failing to deliver on their promise. With the National League championship series tied at one game each, it will be another chance for an epic battle of team aces as Yovani Gallardo of the Brewers faces off against Chris Carpenter of the Cardinals.

headline: Feeling Ageless Under Water
text: At 59, I don’t feel particularly old, but sometimes my joints do. Old injuries to both knees have turned into arthritis, and a ruptured ligament and long-gone cartilage have left me a bit wobbly. Bursitis in my hips and bone spurs in my feet don’t help much.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Guardian: From the archives, the newspaper’s original (and scathing) review of French Country Cooking by Elizabeth David, published in 1951 and still a living, breathing classic. — Julia Moskin

headline: Chevrolet to Sell Purely Electric Spark Hatchback in U.S.
text: General Motors introduced the 2012 Chevrolet Spark subcompact four-door hatchback in Detroit on Wednesday. The news was swiftly upstaged, however, by the subsequent announcement that a purely electric version would be available to American customers in limited quantities in 2013.

headline: Prada and Schiaparelli at the Met
text: Elsa Schiaparelli may share a birthday with Karl Lagerfeld (Sept. 10), but Miuccia Prada is unquestionably her sister in soul. Putting these two nimble minds together makes sense, and not simply because both are educated Italian women who enjoy a good fashion joke. The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced today that the spring 2012 exhibit at the Costume Institute will be “Elsa Schiaparelli and Miuccia Prada: On Fashion.” It will open May 10 and run through Aug. 19, with the gala on May 7.

headline: Data Reveals Wide Variation in Dental Fees
text: Consumers could save significant money on dental care by simply shopping around and asking about prices in their own communities, an analysis of health claims data shows.

headline: Tigers Ignore the Pain
text: Something far more notable happened Tuesday night in Detroit than simply a playoff baseball game. Sure, the Tigers’ 5-2 victory over the Rangers in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series was riveting enough, even if all you did was contemplate the personal expansion of the Tigers’ Miguel Cabrera — dude, Little Caesars Pizza doesn’t need another mascot — and what on earth the Rangers’ Colby Lewis was thinking by throwing the ball anywhere near Cabrera’s bat in the fifth inning.

headline: London Dispatch | Maltby Street Market
text: Borough Market has long held sway as an essential stop on the London food tour. But in the wake of disagreement over increasing rents and trading loyalties, some of Borough’s headlining purveyors left in search of new digs, setting up shop further east in and around the Victorian railway arches of Maltby, Stanworth and Druid Streets. A few years ago, Borough traders used these arches mainly for storage. But when the Monmouth Coffee Company started selling straight from its Maltby Street production site, word spread and a trickle of curious visitors began to arrive. Other vendors, encouraged, followed suit with their own stalls and the buzz got louder.

headline: U.S. Coach Doesn’t Play the Superstar Card
text: Harrison, N.J.

headline: Would-Be Plane Bomber Pleads Guilty, Ending Trial
text: DETROIT — The trial of a man accused of trying to blow up a commercial airliner with a bomb sewed into his underwear ended Wednesday, just a day after it had begun, when Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, the accused, abruptly announced that he would plead guilty to all of the federal counts against him.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct.12
text: The day in sports included surfing in France and the artistic gymnastics world championships in Tokyo.

headline: Egyptian Generals Plead for Understanding After Death of Coptic Protesters
text: CAIRO — Under mounting criticism at home and abroad over clashes with troops that killed two dozen Coptic Christians on Sunday, Egypt’s military rulers issued an extraordinary plea for sympathy on Wednesday, urging Egyptians to understand that soldiers in riot gear and armored trucks had been terrified of an angry crowd of demonstrators.

headline: Ultrasound
text: A slide show explains ultrasounds.

headline: Ear Surgery
text: A slide show explaining a surgery to move disproportionately large or prominent ears closer to the head.

headline: Tracking the Debris From Japan’s Tsunami
text: Just over six months have passed since a huge tsunami slammed into northeastern Japan, killing thousands of people and wrecking towns and villages along the coast.

headline: Not Just Another Bear Story
text: “I didn’t hit her.” “She started it.” “That’s not my mess.” Young children are bad — pathetically, often annoyingly, occasionally heartbreakingly — at making excuses. Most of them are terrible liars. It’s sometimes even funny.

headline: Complete Blood Count
text: A slide show explaining complete blood count.

headline: Animal Bite - First Aid
text: A slide show depicting the first aid procedure to treat an animal bite.

headline: Meckel's Diverticulectomy
text: A slide show depicting a surgery to remove an abnormal pouch (Meckel''s diverticulum) in the wall of the small intestine.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (0), Ecuador (1)
text: HARRISON, N.J. — While its defense looked sturdy against a quality team, the United States did not build on Saturday’s promising offensive display against Honduras. In fact, you could argue that Tuesday night’s game against Ecuador represented a step in the wrong direction — a step away from the opponent’s goal.

headline: Sunset Park Man Is Arrested in Groping Attack
text: A Sunset Park man was arrested early Wednesday in a sexual attack on a young woman. The episode was the latest in a series of attacks that have alarmed Brooklyn communities from Park Slope to Bay Ridge since March.

headline: Where in the World Should Seth Go?
text: My next trip is shaping up to be a doozy. I’ll be heading to ____________, one of a handful of cities I’ve always wanted to explore. And boy, does it have a fascinating world of ____________ to check out. Because I’m always looking for bargain accommodations, I’ll be staying at a ____________. As usual, I won’t be taking taxis: transport will be exclusively by ____________. And though I usually shun shopping on my travels, this time I’ll be looking for the perfect memento to bring home, the best____________ I can find in town.

headline: U.S. Challenged to Explain Accusations of Iran Plot in the Face of Skepticism
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Wednesday sought to reconcile what it said was solid evidence of an Iranian plot to murder Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to the United States with a wave of puzzlement and skepticism from some foreign leaders and outside experts.

headline: The Perfume Project
text: Sensorium, a nerdy, interactive exhibit devoted to perfume, has arrived in the meatpacking district. Open till Nov. 27, it’s sponsored by both Firmenich, a fragrance house, and Sephora (the $15 entry fee can be redeemed for a Sephora gift certificate). Explaining the project, Allison Slater, the vice president for retail marketing at Sephora, said: “People aren’t as interested in fragrance, and sales are down. Our sales aren’t as bad as others, but still.”

headline: Loud and Clear
text: new NYTD.embeddedSlideshowBuilder(NYTD.options);

headline: Caregiving’s Hidden Benefits
text: Could there be measurable benefits to your health, and to your brain in particular, from being a caregiver?

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

headline: Fine-Tuning Your Flight Search
text: LAST month, Google introduced the first version of its new flight search feature (Google.com/flights) and the response has mostly focused on what it does not offer. Right now, it can search only for round-trip tickets for select domestic destinations. And while it is much faster than other travel search engines, it does not display fares from all the airlines that serve a particular route.

headline: Dow Jones European Executive Resigns
text: 9:30 p.m. | Updated

headline: Between the Lines, Wall St. Banks Face a Deficit of Trust
text: By almost any measure, Morgan Stanley is fine.

headline: Mary Ellen Mark and the Robots
text: In a new column, Lynn Yaeger peeks at people’s terrifically odd, amusing and magnificent collections, starting with the robot menagerie of the photographer Mary Ellen Mark. “Their batteries have probably all melted. I’m a bad robot mom,” Ms. Mark said, looking with wry affection at the crowd of robots — pink fembots in frilly aprons! Mean metal guys with clock bellies! — that have taken up residence in her downtown loft, a place that has been her studio since almost before SoHo was SoHo. Read more (and view photos) on T Magazine’s Moment blog.

headline: U.S. Accuses Virginia Man of Espionage at Syria Protests
text: Updated  | A revised version of this post can be found here.

headline: Have a Question for N.F.L. Reporter Judy Battista?
text: Are the Buffalo Bills really that good? (And what about the 49ers?) Are the Indianapolis Colts really that bad? Can Tim Tebow succeed as the starting quarterback in Denver? What will the Raiders be like without owner Al Davis? Will Los Angeles get an N.F.L. team any time soon? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The New York Times, will answer questions from readers of The Fifth Down. Send in your questions and answers will appear on the blog on Friday.

headline: For Each U.S. Job Opening, 4.6 Unemployed
text: There were 4.6 unemployed workers for every job opening in the United States in August, according to new data from the Labor Department.

headline: Putting Down the iPad So My Kids Can See Me Read
text: In the name of encouraging my kids to read, I’ve dumped my iPad’s Kindle app.

headline: S.E.C. Advances Volcker Rule
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission became the latest agency on Wednesday to support an initial version of the so-called Volcker Rule, a new regulation aimed at curtailing risky trading on Wall Street.

headline: At City Ballet, a Need for Surprises
text: More than any other ballet company in the world, New York City Ballet has the marriage of music and dance written into its constitution. Elsewhere you may find dancing that’s just as musical, perhaps even more so. (Among the world’s troupes today, the Royal Ballet in London at its best is probably the most musically responsive.) But only at City Ballet is the heart of the repertory about dance making music register in space. As the company’s Balanchine Black & White Week in May demonstrated, its founder-choreographer, George Balanchine, was often prepared to strip everything else away until musicality was virtually all that remained.

headline: Groundbreaking Set for New Arts Center in Brooklyn
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday will break ground for a renovation of the 1918 Strand Theater in Brooklyn’s BAM Cultural District, to be shared by BRIC Arts/Media House, a multidisciplinary arts and media complex, and the UrbanGlass reNEWal Project, a center dedicated to artistic glass.

headline: Finalists Named for National Book Awards
text: For the second year in a row books about war and foreign locales enchanted the judges of the National Book Awards, whose finalists were announced on Wednesday.

headline: Frank Fires Back at Gingrich
text: Representative Barney Frank will not go quietly.

headline: Disruption on the Path to Transformation
text: Tom Friedman has posted a column that considers two views of world events — one seeing a great disruption, the other an exciting transformation. He ends the piece, not with a conclusion, but by asking readers which narrative they believe. (There’s more on the thinkers behind these views below.)

headline: City Council in Harrisburg Files Petition of Bankruptcy
text: The City Council of Harrisburg, Pennsylvania’s financially troubled capital, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday, a surprise move that was immediately opposed by the mayor and Gov. Tom Corbett, who argued that the filing was illegal under state law.

headline: In Nimby Sentiments, a Gender Divide
text: A consulting firm that conducts an annual poll on public attitudes toward development has come up with a new twist on Nimbyism: women are far more likely than men to fight proposals to build new power plants, shopping malls and big-box stores.

headline: Cadillac’s Cue: Tap, Drag, Scroll, Speak (and Drive, Too)
text: Screen-swiping, pinching to contract, tapping an icon — these actions, popularized on smartphones, have become so ingrained in our mobile society’s muscle memory that Cadillac has decided to build its new infotainment system around them.

headline: Cleared of Murder, Sheehan Reports to Jail on Gun Conviction
text: The Queens woman who shot her husband 11 times but was acquitted of murder was taken into custody Wednesday to await sentencing on a weapons possession charge.

headline: HBO Orders Third Season of ‘Boardwalk Empire’
text: The saga of organized crime in America didn’t end in 1921, and “Boardwalk Empire” won’t conclude then, either. On Wednesday, HBO announced it had renewed “Boardwalk Empire,” its period drama about mobsters, corrupt public officials and one particularly short-tempered federal agent in Prohibition-era Atlantic City, for a third season. The series, which is created by Terence Winter (a producer of “The Sopranos”) and adapted from Nelson Johnson’s book of the same title, was nominated for 18 Emmy Awards in its debut season, including nods for dramatic series and for the lead actor, Steve Buscemi, who plays the bootlegger and political powerbroker Nucky Thompson; among the eight Emmys it picked up was an award for the direction of its pilot episode, handled by Martin Scorsese, an up-and-comer we think you’re going to be hearing a lot about. “Boardwalk Empire” is believed to be one of the costliest series that HBO has produced, with a reported budget of $18 million for its pilot episode alone.

headline: A Red-Letter Day, and a Party to Match
text: LAKE HAVASU CITY, Ariz. — When Arizona executes prisoners, it uses lethal injection — not drawing and quartering, hanging or beheading, all of which have fallen out of favor since they were used with some regularity in Europe centuries back.

headline: “Too Much Moneyball”: The Story of the New York Yankees
text: Have you seen “Moneyball,” the inspiring, based-on-a-true-story film of how the Oakland A’s, despite a meager payroll, managed to compete with baseball’s richest teams?

headline: Rain Returns, but Will Victor Martinez?
text: DETROIT — A misty rain was falling at Comerica Park three hours before the scheduled first pitch of Game 4 of the American League Championship Series, but Tigers Manager Jim Leyland had more pressing matters on his mind.

headline: Think Pink
text: October is National Breast Cancer Awareness month, and thousands of designers, retailers and businesses are participating in this year’s effort to support the cause by offering exclusive items in the movement’s signature color — pink! From Tumi’s iPad case to Ann Taylor’s diamond pendant necklace and the New York Giants’ enthusiastic pink sneakers and gloves, here’s how fashion is helping to find a cure.

headline: Fewer Births in a Bad Economy
text: American birth rates have fallen noticeably in the last few years, a trend that seems to be tied to the poor economy, according to a new analysis from the Pew Research Center.

headline: Students React to SAT Cheating Scandal
text: Over at SchoolBook today, students from Stuyvesant High School have weighed in on the frequency of cheating on the SAT, inspired by the recent local scandal surrounding a young man who sat for the test under others’ identities.

headline: Deep Thinking About the Future of Food
text: Trying to tap into the best thinking about the future of global agriculture, as I have tried to do in my work as a reporter, can be an exercise in frustration. Many groups and many bright people go at the problem, but not many of them go at it in a holistic way.

headline: A Company Grows, and Builds a Plant Back in the U.S.A.
text: Today, Taphandles employs 33 people at its headquarters in Seattle and about 450 at the Chinese factory that produces the beer-marketing products it sells to breweries. But its owner, Paul Fichter, who founded the company in 1999 and anticipates $11 million in revenue this year, expects that ratio to change. Mr. Fichter, 40, just signed a lease on a 41,800-square-foot factory in Woodinville, Wash., and began manufacturing some of his products there last month.

headline: Congress Ends 5-Year Standoff on Trade Deals in Rare Accord
text: WASHINGTON — Congress passed three long-awaited free trade agreements on Wednesday, ending a political standoff that has stretched across two presidencies. The move offered a rare moment of bipartisan accord at a time when Republicans and Democrats are bitterly divided over the role that government ought to play in reviving the sputtering economy.

headline: Scientists Solve Puzzle of Black Death’s DNA
text: After the Black Death reached London in 1348, about 2,400 people were buried in East Smithfield, near the Tower of London, in a cemetery that had been prepared for the plague’s arrival. From the teeth of four of those victims, researchers have now reconstructed the full DNA of a microbe that within five years felled one-third to one-half of the population of Western Europe.

headline: Did the Government Do Something Right?
text: We’ve just published a small-business conversation with Paul Fichter, a manufacturer who is bringing some of his work back from China. Mr. Fichter’s company, Taphandles, makes beer-marketing products. He recently signed a lease to start manufacturing some of those products in Woodinville, Wash., where he expects to employ 150 workers by 2015. Mr. Fichter’s decision comports with a trend noted in a Boston Consulting Group analysis released last week that found that manufacturing outsourced to China has begun to return to the United States as the economic advantages have started to shift.

headline: Franklin Kameny, Gay Rights Pioneer, Dies at 86
text: Franklin E. Kameny, who transformed his 1957 arrest as a “sexual pervert” and his subsequent firing from the Army Map Service into a powerful animating spark of the gay civil rights movement, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 86.

headline: Study Points to Heavy-Handed Repression of Tibetan Area in China
text: BEIJING — The rise in anti-Chinese tensions and protests in a restive Tibetan region of Sichuan Province, including a startling wave of monk self-immolations, has taken place in the aftermath of sharp increases in the security budget for the area, which indicates the conflict is partly a result of heavy-handed tactics by the local security forces, according to an assessment by Human Rights Watch.

headline: Occupy Wall Street Occupies Headlines
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.– Splashed across the front page of the local newspaper here on Tuesday was a 24-year-old Occupy protester named Keith Cuesta.

headline: In Playoffs, Depth Does Not Take a Holiday
text: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. His Phillies homerism is no longer an issue.

headline: Who’s on First? Met Opera Announces Changes After Injury to ‘Don Giovanni’ Star
text: The Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday gave an update on who will fill in for Mariusz Kwiecien in the title role of “Don Giovanni.” Mr. Kwiecien had to withdraw because of a back injury that led to surgery. Peter Mattei, who is replacing him on opening night on Thursday, will also step in for the performances of Oct. 17 and Oct. 22. Substitutes for Oct. 25 and Oct. 29 were not announced.

headline: More Wireless Devices Than People
text: SAN DIEGO — Watching all those people juggling phones and tablets and e-readers in stores, subways and coffee shops, not to mention the many small shops continually offering new models of phones, you could think that there are more wireless devices than people.

headline: Caught in a Wide Web, a Trader Faces Prison
text: Last Friday, on a crystalline autumn afternoon, Michael A. Kimelman sat in the backyard of his home in Larchmont, N.Y. His toddler son was perched on his lap, sucking on a pacifier. His older boy played baseball with a friend, while his wife and daughter gawked at 10 egg-producing hens housed in their new chicken coop.

headline: Romney the Inexorable
text: I spent last night’s Republican debate trying to imagine scenarios where Mitt Romney loses the G.O.P. nomination for president. Rick Perry gets bitten by a radioactive Lincoln-Douglas debate champion and develops a sudden facility for public argument? A long-lost codicil to the Constitution is discovered, in which the Founding Fathers endorse the 9-9-9 tax plan? Utah renames itself the Republic of Deseret and secedes from the Union, forcing Romney to make a tragic choice between his religion and his country? Or, perhaps most unlikely of all — Jon Huntsman is embraced by the Tea Party and pulls off a surprise upset in Iowa?

headline: Corporations, People and Truth
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

headline: Israeli-Hamas Agreement to Trade Prisoners May Reshape Politics in Region
text: JERUSALEM — The prisoner exchange between Hamas and Israel that is expected to begin next week could reshape regional relationships, strengthening Egypt, Hamas and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel while posing an acute challenge to the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank.

headline: Arrest Is Made in Hacking of Celebrities’ Private E-Mail
text: LOS ANGELES — A Florida man was arrested Wednesday and charged with breaking into and commandeering the e-mail accounts of at least 50 celebrities — including the actresses Scarlett Johansson and Mila Kunis and the pop singer Christina Aguilera — to steal photographs, financial data and personal correspondence, the F.B.I. said.

headline: On Our Radar: Charges in New Zealand Oil Spill
text: The container ship that struck a reef off the coast of New Zealand a week ago and is still spilling oil into the sea seems to be at risk of breaking apart, officials say. The captain has been arrested and charged with “operating a vessel in a manner causing unnecessary danger or risk.” [ABC News]

headline: Want to Know About That Mushroom? Just Ask
text: Oct. 17: Please note: we are no longer accepting photos for this feature. Too many mushrooms already! Thanks to those who sent in the 300 or so pix we have received.

headline: New Team, Older Curse
text: For sheer futility in professional sports, the Chicago Cubs are the standard. They have not won the World Series in 103 years. They have not won a pennant since 1945. Their history is pocked with excruciating near misses — a billy goat, a black cat, fateful errors on the field and in the stands.

headline: A Disappearing Underwater World
text: Mark Hay, a biology professor at Georgia Tech, writes from Fiji, where he is investigating coral-seaweed competition in the coral reefs.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Myanmar, Bhutan and Washington.

headline: Ohio Senator Asks NASA to Wrest Shuttle From Intrepid Museum
text: The tussle on Capitol Hill over the space shuttle Enterprise continued on Tuesday with a senator from Ohio demanding that NASA rescind its award to New York City.

headline: Slovakia Deal Revives Hope on Fund to Save Euro
text: BRUSSELS — The day after Parliament in tiny Slovakia voted to reject the expansion of a European rescue fund, causing the government to fall and threatening efforts to end Europe’s debt crisis, politicians there struck a deal that should permit the expansion of a rescue fund for the euro after all.

headline: New Book Coming From Author of ‘Henrietta Lacks’
text: Rebecca Skloot, the veterinary technician-turned-author whose nonfiction book “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks” has not budged from the paperback best-seller list in 30 weeks, will write a new book focusing on the bonds between people and animals, her publisher said on Wednesday. The new book, currently untitled, will be released by Crown Publishers, part of Random House.

headline: 3 Years After Triple Crown Bid, Trainer Is Given a 10-Year Ban
text: New York authorities on Wednesday revoked the license of Richard Dutrow Jr., the trainer of the 2008 Kentucky Derby winner, Big Brown, barring him from state racetracks for 10 years and potentially ending the career of one of thoroughbred racing’s more controversial and successful horsemen.

headline: A Path Toward Sustaining a ‘Cultivated Planet’

Below you can read the key passage in which Gillis discusses “Solutions for a Cultivated Planet,” a new Nature paper from Jonathan Foley of the University of Minnesota and many co-authors. The core themes in the paper are echoed in a TEDx talk Foley gave last year:

headline: The Look of Karen O’s Psycho Rock Opera
text: “The costume, hair and makeup tell the story just as much as the music and choreography do,” Karen O explained days before tonight’s opening of her much-anticipated psycho-opera, “Stop the Virgens.” “The symbolic evolution of what happens to the characters is witnessed through their physical transformations.”
