headline: Divisions Grow on Federal Reserve’s Policy Committee
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee is increasingly divided between advocates for stronger steps to bolster the economy and dissenters who see little benefit and considerable risk in such efforts, according to minutes of the committee’s most recent meeting.

headline: Discover Cardholders Can Pay With Points at Amazon
text: 5:15 p.m. | Updated To note that Discover cardholders automatically earn as much as 1 percent cash back because some cardholders earn less than 1 percent.

headline: Oil Executive Promotes Shale Gas to Europeans
text: LONDON — A senior executive from Exxon Mobil warned Wednesday that Europe could miss a chance to reduce its dependence on imported energy by making it too difficult to develop shale gas and so-called unconventional resources.

headline: His Photos Are Proof: He’s With the Band
text: The photographer Bob Gruen was so deeply embedded with rock bands that he was considered a virtual member.

headline: His Photos Are Proof: He’s With the Band
text: ONE afternoon in June 1975, John Lennon got lost in the mammoth Westbeth artists’ complex in Manhattan, looking for Bob Gruen’s photo studio and apartment, after partying all weekend with Harry Nilsson.

text: Jeff Zeleny reports from the site of Tuesday’s Republican debate on Mitt Romney’s posture as the front-runner.

headline: Young and Martinez Back in Tigers’ Lineup
text: 4:13 p.m. | Updated Rain has delayed the start of Game 4 between the Tigers and the Rangers. First pitch is now expected to be at 5:15 p.m.

headline: Hemangioma Excision
text: A slide show explaining hemangioma excision.

headline: Asia Society to Host China-India Program
text: Leading writers from China and India will meet for panel discussions in New York early next month as part of a new initiative called “The ‘Chindia’ Dialogues.” The event, to run Nov. 3 through 6 at the Asia Society, will focus on cultural and social trends in both countries as well as their interaction with each other.

headline: To the Barricades
text: Gail Collins: David, I was sorry to see you didn’t have a little bit of sympathy for the Occupy Wall Street protesters.

headline: Wall Street’s ‘CrackBerry’ Withdrawal
text: Wednesday had the makings of a relatively good day for Wall Street. The stock market was edging toward positive territory for the year. Europe was hashing out a deal to recapitalize its banks. And enraged protestors remained encamped at Zuccotti Park, letting bank chieftains breath easy in their Park Avenue palaces.

headline: A Matter of Gravity: Developing Space-Based Experiments
text: Overview | In this lesson, students read about a new contest seeking student science experiments to be conducted on the International Space Station. They learn more about space-based research, design experiments they would like to see carried out in microgravity and develop scripts for video pitches to promote their ideas.

headline: Palestinians in Gaza Celebrate Prisoner Swap Deal
text: GAZA CITY — Palestinian joy erupted quickly in this isolated enclave at the first word of the Israeli-Palestinian prisoner swap agreement announced late Tuesday. And through the hours of Wednesday as the agreement’s details became clearer, the celebrations spread and Hamas, the governing authority here that rejects Israel’s legitimacy, claimed much of the credit.

headline: What You Get for ... $599,000
text: OAK GROVE, ORE.

headline: Caucus Video: Romney, Center Stage
text: Jeff Zeleny reports from the site of Tuesday’s Republican debate on Mitt Romney’s posture as the front-runner.

headline: CBS Is Top Network Standing
text: So far, CBS has done pretty well for itself over the course of this still-young fall season. How well? According to Nielsen ratings data from Sept. 19 through Oct. 9, CBS has 20 of the top 30 shows among the broadcast networks in total viewership, making CBS the first network to accomplish such a feat. It was also the number one network in average viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Stalwarts “NCIS” and “NCIS: LA” certainly helped the network’s cause on Tuesday, garnering 18.7 million viewers and 15.4 million respectively, although the two dramas hit season lows in the 18-to-49 demo. If it can hold steady, ABC will have a new entry in the top 30 with the new Tim Allen comedy “Last Man Standing.” The two-episode series premiere was sampled by nearly 13 million total viewers.

headline: In Living Wage Talks, Warfare Trumps Discourse
text: Long ago, I passed boiling summers driving taxis in New York City (an experience that no doubt still summons nightmares for my former passengers, not to mention wayward pedestrians). Other summers, I worked as a doorman, hauling bags and opening doors for royally snooty Park Avenue dowagers.

headline: DealBook: Wall Street’s CrackBerry Withdrawal
text: The BlackBerry outage, which seemed contained to the places most afflicted by the sovereign debt crisis, had spread to the heart of American capitalism.

headline: Protesters Take Aim at Dimon, but Miss His Office
text: The nearly month-old Occupy Wall Street protest has apparently settled on a favorite target for their ire, Jamie Dimon. On Tuesday, protestors marched to his apartment building in Manhattan’s Upper East Side, bearing a giant fake check critiquing the low taxes of America’s wealthiest individuals.

headline: Leg Lengthening
TV Chat: Ask the Critics
text: Now that viewers have gotten a look at most of the new shows this season, the fall television picture is becoming clearer: sitcoms like “New Girl” (with Zooey Deschanel) and “2 Broke Girls” (with Kat Dennings) have gotten votes of confidence, Tim Allen’s “Last Man Standing” earned a spot in the Top 30, while “H8R,” “Free Agents” and “How to Be a Gentleman” are out or on their way. Did these shows deserve their fates, for better or worse? Speaking of comedies, HBO unveiled “Enlightened” and came back with a new season of “Bored to Death” and a male breast-feeding scene. Has HBO finally gone too far? The television critics Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger have posted answers to your questions and comments.

headline: Pitchfork Announces New York Festival
text: The online music magazine that runs the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago — the influential outdoor showcase for indie bands — has plans to start a new festival in New York City next February, teaming up with one of the city’s largest music promoters, the Bowery Presents.

text: The Nigerian who tried to down an airliner with an underwear bomb pleads guilty; Myanmar begins releasing some political prisoners; and a breakthrough for phone-based voice recognition.

headline: After a Quarter-Century, an Author Looks Back at His Holocaust Comic
text: Art Spiegelman’s “Maus,” the most unconventional great book yet written about the Holocaust, the one that turned Nazis into cats and Jews into mice and Poles into pigs, turns 25 this year. It was the first comic book to win a Pulitzer Prize, and it changed the way comics — the term seems wrong for “Maus” — are viewed in America. It proved they could be serious art.

headline: First Stop: Target. Next Stop: eBay.
text: IT’S been a month since Target released its Missoni for Target line and scrums of shoppers cleared the discount retailer’s shelves and crashed its Web site. But as with some earlier limited-edition “masstige” collections, the frenzy has continued in the secondary market, with sold-out items going for breathtakingly inflated prices on eBay and Craigslist and in consignment shops.

headline: Hunting for a Vaccine
text: Two experimental vaccines against dengue fever are being developed, and researchers think they may be available commercially in five to seven years.

headline: For Bargain Fanatics, Uptown Mayhem
text: THE discount department store Century 21 and I go way back — well, back to 1999 or so, when, like thousands of brides attempting the minimalist glamour of Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, I bought an off-white slip dress at its flagship across from the World Trade Center. Never mind that I wasn’t yet engaged; I reveled in the price tag ($159, down from $1,595 — that’s 90 percent off) and designer label (Vera Wang, as opposed to Bessette Kennedy’s more original Narciso Rodriguez, but still) and stashed the gown confidently in a trunk.

text: A slide show depicting bunion removal.

headline: Cuomo Vows Reforms at Residential Care Agencies
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, saying he was startled by problems with the handling of abuse and neglect allegations at state facilities, on Wednesday vowed reforms at six agencies that provide residential care for the disabled, the elderly, children and the mentally ill.

headline: Bookshelf
text: In Ingo Schulze’s cheery novel “Adam and Evelyn” (Knopf, $28), a lecherous East German dressmaker gets a bit too cozy with his comrade clientele, inciting his girlfriend to go on a sex-charged romp through newly democratic Hungary.

headline: Ukrainian Opposition Leader to Be Freed Soon, Daughter Says
text: KIEV, Ukraine — For the last few months, the people who visited Yulia V. Tymoshenko in Detention Center No. 13 have been slipping something into the stacks of documents they bring her to read — the handwritten notes known in prison slang as “malyava,” exchanged by generations of Soviet inmates, who would crumple them into pea-sized balls or roll them into narrow cones and shoot them out of blowpipes.

headline: A Downtown Icon’s Nurturing Spirit
text: TWO years ago, Ellen Stewart, the founder and longtime impresario of La MaMa Experimental Theater Club in the East Village, was speaking to her entire staff at a nearby restaurant when she dropped a bombshell. “Mia,” she said, “will be the new me.”

headline: A Home and Headquarters
text: MJOMNA, Norway — On the western coast of Norway, a two-story house with a geometrical facade and an off-white exterior sits on a craggy waterfront stretch of Mjomna, one of hundreds of remote islands speckling the deep blue waters of the Sognefjord. The house calls to mind the Oslo Opera House, with its minimalistic origami-like folds. But the comparison goes beyond appearance: these walls, too, are bursting with music.

headline: Obama Campaign Treating Romney Like Nominee — By Attacking

headline: Theatrical Offerings and Instruction for Singing Birds

headline: The Campus as Runway
text: JULIA FLYNN was darting to her classes at Columbia University last week in a Marc by Marc Jacobs daisy-patterned dress and high-heeled Chloé boots, her polished turnout accessorized with a Starbucks venti latte. “I’m really loving the whole Chanel, Valentino and McQueen shows,” she said. “They completely inspired me.” She had gleaned her information that very morning from Style.com.

headline: ‘Idol’ Star at No. 1
text: This has been a good week for “American Idol” on the music charts. Scotty McCreery, who won this year’s competition, has opened at No. 1 on the latest Billboard chart with his first album, “Clear as Day” (Mercury Nashville/19 Recordings/Interscope), and reached numerous sales milestones. “Clear as Day,” which sold 197,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan, had the biggest opening week in three years for an “Idol” winner’s first album, and it is also the first debut by an “Idol” champion to open at No. 1 since Ruben Studdard’s “Soulful,” in 2003. If that were not enough, Mr. McCreery, who turned 18 on Sunday, is also the first country act to open at No. 1 with a debut, and is the youngest man to have a first album start in the top slot, Billboard reported. Also this week, Adele’s unstoppable “21” (XL/Columbia) is No. 2 on the album chart with 112,000 sales, and her recent single, “Someone Like You,” remains the No. 1 digital song, with 218,000 downloads. The No. 2 spot on the digital songs chart is also unchanged from last week: Maroon 5’s “Moves Like Jagger,” featuring Christina Aguilera, had 186,000 downloads. Tony Bennett’s “Duets II” (Columbia) is the No. 3 album this week with 71,000. Other new titles in this week’s Top 10 include Feist’s “Metals” (Cherrytree/Interscope), at No. 7, and “Take a Back Road” (Curb), the fourth album by Rodney Atkins, at No. 8.

headline: Embracing Communal and Hymnal
text: “Welcome to the Stone, and to the Ives geek-out party,” the violinist Hilary Hahn announced brightly on Monday at the Stone, a tiny, boxy East Village new-music laboratory operated by the saxophonist and composer John Zorn. Ms. Hahn, a performer who draws sizable throngs to prominent auditoriums, was making a point by celebrating her admirable new CD, “Charles Ives: Four Sonatas,” of Ives’s violin sonatas at Mr. Zorn’s space, which seats fewer than 100.

headline: I Am Not Your Mirror Image
text: Russ Roberts tries to debunk my explanation of the reasons to believe in a broadly Keynesian view of the world — and reveals more than he intended.

headline: Are Americans More Prone to A.D.H.D.?
text: The high-energy, risk-taking traits of attention deficit disorder may be part of the nation's pioneer DNA. Or maybe we're just overmedicated.

headline: Romancing the Reich
text: They met in 1929, in the photographer’s shop where she worked, in Munich. He was 40, she was 17. He devoured her with his eyes, she said. Soon after, he had her family investigated, to check that her bloodlines were Aryan. He was Adolf Hitler, an amateur artist whose charisma as a reactionary orator had propelled him to the forefront of Germany’s National Socialist party. She was Eva Braun, an attractive blonde from a middle-class family who, after one year at a school run by nuns, was back home living with her parents. We know how the story ends, though we can’t help wondering why — was she completely lacking in intelligence, or morals, or both? In “Eva Braun: Life With Hitler,” translated from the German by Damion Searls (Alfred A. Knopf), Heike B. Görtemaker takes on a task few biographers — I’m tempted to say no biographer in her right mind — would tackle, so scant and unreliable is the material.

headline: Expressing Trauma in Words and Spins
text: What has dance got to do with genocide or torture? At first the mind recoils from any such link. Yet amazingly, the French-Algerian choreographer Rachid Ouramdane plunges in, evoking post-traumatic conditions in movement imagery, and in the process he extends the whole notion of what dance can express.

headline: Park Slope, 2:12 P.M.
text: For the Jewish festival of Sukkot, which starts Wednesday evening and which Jews celebrate by erecting (and eating in) a temporary booth called a sukkah, Congregation Beth Elohim, in Brooklyn, commissioned a community sukkah designed by B-an-G Studio, a new architecture firm. The firm’s principals, Babak Bryan and Henry Grosman, won the people’s choice award in last year’s Sukkah City competition, held in Union Square. For Beth Elohim, Mr. Bryan and Mr. Grosman designed a sukkah made of 3,000 pieces of wood, which members of the congregation put together. To complete the design, temple members are painting 1,500 laser-cut cardboard leaves in colorful bursts of red, orange and yellow. The leaves will be affixed to the sukkah’s frame of wood and bent-steel spines.

headline: Bonuses Tied to Medicare’s Star System Reward Insurers
text: For the first time, a government-backed quality rating will have a financial meaning to health insurance companies looking to attract millions of older Americans to privately run Medicare coverage next year.

headline: Seeking Acceptance, and Family, in One’s Shifting Gender
text: “Southern Comfort,” which is playing at the CAP21 Theater Company’s new space in Chelsea, will never have the exposure of Chaz Bono, who is putting a human face on the transgender-rights struggle for millions of viewers this season on ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars.” But in its own small way, this affecting folk-bluegrass musical by Julianne Wick Davis and Dan Collins makes a heartfelt bid to shift perceptions.

headline: Footwork as Nimble on Court as Onstage
text: At a pivotal moment in “Lysistrata Jones,” a musical comedy about basketball and sex that is coming to Broadway next month, the title character has to make a layup on the stage-turned-court. Patti Murin, the 5-foot-4 actress playing Lysistrata, made 34 of 39 shots during an Off Broadway production last spring — a solid showing for a hoops newbie who didn’t know a layup from a free throw before being cast.

headline: Free text messages; Pioneer AppRadio; the documentary film “Connected”; tech news.
text: The Times technology reporter Jenna Wortham discusses new free messaging services that let users text over a Wi-Fi connection without having to pay SMS fees to wireless carriers. Tiffany Shlain, the founder of the Webby Awards and the director of the documentary, “Connected,” talks about making the film and her observations on the social impact of modern technology. Pedro Rafael Rosado gets a look at Pioneer AppRadio and the tech news roundup includes Facebook’s new iPad app, declining traffic to Google+ and the recent business U-turn by Netflix. Sam Grobart, the Personal Technology editor at The Times, previews his new article on life with a high-tech toilet. For Mac users wondering how to use repair utilities without a system DVD on Mac OS X 10.7, the Tip of the Week explores Apple’s built-in Lion Recovery feature.

headline: The iPhone 4S Review Roundup
text: Just two days before the new Apple iPhone 4S hits store shelves the reviews are out. What are the critics saying? To be frank, they’re not being very negative; most love the iPhone 4S, specifically the newly improved camera, its latest software update and the new “humble personal assistant,” Siri.

headline: Bathtub Gin
text: LIKE an infestation of voles, speakeasies continue to burrow their way into the city’s night life. The latest is Bathtub Gin, a fake Victorian bar “hidden” behind a coffee shop in Chelsea. Opened last month, the lounge hopes to corral herds from the meatpacking district with the easy refinement of cocktail culture.

headline: Dissident Creates by Remote Control
text: From his studio in Beijing, Ai Weiwei, the outspoken Chinese artist and dissident, had a clear view of Rikers Island. For months Mr. Ai, who was detained by Chinese authorities in the spring and released under close surveillance in June, has been limited in his travel and communications with the outside world. But recently he was able to escape, at least digitally, and even to make new work in another country.

headline: A Mixed-Race Family Tree
text: The family tree of a mixed-race woman.

headline: Robert W. Galvin, Who Ushered Motorola Into the Modern Era, Dies at 89
text: Robert W. Galvin, who took the reins of Motorola from his father and built a family-run business that pioneered Depression-era car radios and wartime walkie-talkies into a global maker of color television sets, cellphones and other ubiquities of the electronic age, died early Tuesday in Chicago. He was 89.

headline: Her Life Is a Real Page-Turner
text: TO keep her independent bookstore not only solvent but thriving (revenue is racing ahead of last year by 16 percent), Sarah McNally has a limitless supply of small tricks up her sleeve. And a whirring, wheezing behemoth at her side.

headline: Saving Philip Johnson’s Brick House
text: Ever wonder how Philip Johnson managed to live in a fishbowl? If he needed a nap, he sometimes walked across the lawn from his famous Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., to the lesser-known Brick House, where an upholstered bedroom, like something from the Arabian Nights, awaited. Perhaps to maintain the illusion that he needed nothing more than his house of windows, the Brick House was rarely shown in photos of its more-famous neighbor. Now the National Trust for Historic Preservation has begun to raise money to preserve the Brick House, which was completed in 1949 and has been closed to the public since 2008 because of problems that include leaks resulting in mold on silk wall coverings, furniture and books.

headline: Denied Veterans Benefits Over Same-Sex Marriage, Ex-Sailor Challenges Law
text: In what experts say is the first case of its kind, a disabled Navy veteran from Connecticut is challenging the constitutionality of two federal laws that define marriage as being between opposite-sex partners, saying the government denied her veterans benefits because she is married to a woman.

headline: Shopping for Storage Solutions

headline: A Sergio Rodrigues Shop Opens in New York

Next week, he has a new store opening in New York, his first in this country in more than 40 years. (His previous store, OCA, in Carmel, Calif., closed in 1968.)

headline: Sales on Pratesi, Alvar Aalto and More

headline: Storage Solutions for Athletic Gear
text: WHEN David Obel Rosenkvist moved his family to Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, from a town outside Copenhagen in August, he discovered a problem most New Yorkers will be familiar with: a lack of storage space. For Mr. Rosenkvist, the vice president for North America of Fritz Hansen, a Danish furniture company, the situation was especially problematic, as he, his wife and his two children are all outdoors enthusiasts.

headline: The Unhappy Hipsters
text: It was early in 2010, and Molly Jane Quinn, a writer, and Jenna Talbott, a graphic designer, were working, none too happily, at Design New England, a regional magazine. They cheered each other up one chilly January evening by making a tumblr blog with a simple, hilarious engine: marrying photos from Dwell magazine with deadpan captions parodying the magazine’s signature hipster anomie. “His sartorial attempt to blend in with the concrete did little to assuage the tension,” read one early post.

headline: Trying to Outrun Wealth and Fame

Jaime Johnson, 29, and her younger sister, Daisy, 24, were sometimes capturing Ms. Steir alone, sometimes including themselves in the shots. There were few props, other than a selection of straw trilbys and fedoras. “Jaime lets me use the hat to cover my face,” Daisy explained. “I don’t like my face in photos.”

headline: Some Experts Question Iran’s Role in Bungled Plot

He cannot take his key and scratch the car of a man who he claims swiped his parking spot in the pouring rain. text: Saying it had found no violations, the N.C.A.A. announced the end of its 13-month investigation into Auburn’s football program Wednesday, including the recruitment of the Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback Cam Newton.

headline: How to Pick the Best iPhone 4S Carrier
text: If you’re in the market for an iPhone 4S, you may be wondering which carrier you should give your money to. After all, you now have a new choice to consider, Sprint, not to mention the ever-shifting landscape of each carrier’s plans and add-ons. Let’s try to break it down.

headline: A Shelf-Obsessed Writer
text: I can’t remember when I first became obsessed with the cafe’s free bookcase, but sometime in the last year it was suddenly so, and I was regularly making pilgrimages there. I took books home to read, and brought others in to replace them. I noticed which ones were snapped up quickly and which sat for too long. I rooted for the galley of Emily St. John Mandel’s smart novel “The Singer’s Gun” to find a good home, but felt a little smug about another novel — which sucked up all the press in the universe when it came out, even though it was not its author’s finest work, not by a long shot, and one might wonder if perhaps the author was even phoning it in — which no one touched for weeks.

headline: Report Finds No Wrongdoing in Afghanistan Copter Crash
text: WASHINGTON -- The official military investigation into a helicopter shoot-down that caused the largest loss of American life during a single day of the war in Afghanistan has found no wrongful actions by personnel involved in the mission, nor were there equipment failures.

headline: How to Stop the Drop in Home Values

headline: U.S. Acts to Fine BP and Top Contractors for Gulf Oil Spill

headline: Season Lost by the N.H.L. Could Teach the N.B.A.

headline: Tending a Small Patch of Capitalism in North Korea

headline: McGwire Talks, Cardinals Listen
text: ST. LOUIS — He still looks as if he could hit a baseball 500 feet. Ten years after Mark McGwire took his last major league swing, and six years after his evasive testimony before a Congressional committee on steroid use, his blacksmith arms still pop out from under a black sleeveless T-shirt, like the one he wore Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Questioned on Donations, Comptroller Vows Review

headline: Democratic Senator’s Ads May Break New Ground
text: WASHINGTON — A new series of political advertisements on behalf of an embattled Nebraska senator could open the door to a flood of similar ads financed by outside groups and even businesses working directly with political candidates — a sharp departure from past practice.

headline: A Lot of Talk, but Few Stars Have Left the Country to Play
text: If he were desperate for competition — without regard to geography, lifestyle or paycheck — Carmelo Anthony could board a flight to Italy, Spain or France tomorrow. The jobs are there. Games are being played. Basketball goes on, even without the N.B.A.

headline: Unlikely Turn for a Suspect in a Terror Plot
text: WASHINGTON — His nickname was Scarface, the legacy of a brutal knife attack on a dark Houston street three decades ago that left his left cheek permanently marred. Friends and neighbors in Texas said that he could be gruff and intimidating, and that he often stood outside his house at night smoking and talking on his cellphone in a language they did not understand.

headline: Speedy Rookie Is a Hit in the Giants’ Defense
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Jacquian Williams did not realize he was fast until he was 12. That was when one of his older cousins, weary of the constant requests from Williams, finally relented and picked him to play in a backyard football game.

headline: 8 Killed in Salon Shooting in Southern California
text: SEAL BEACH, Calif. — A gunman burst into a beauty salon in this sunny Pacific Coast town on Wednesday, killing eight people and severely injuring one more in a rampage that sent patrons and workers diving to the floor and running out of the building for safety.

headline: No Jobs Bill, and No Ideas
text: It was all predicted, but the unanimous decision by Senate Republicans on Tuesday to filibuster and thus kill President Obama’s jobs bill was still a breathtaking act of economic vandalism. There are 14 million people out of work, wages are falling, poverty is rising, and a second recession may be blowing in, but not a single Republican would even allow debate on a sound plan to cut middle-class taxes and increase public-works spending.

headline: Investors’ Trust in China’s Government Falters
A Campaign Windfall for 4 Republicans Who Voted for Same-Sex Marriage
text: ALBANY — As the State Legislature this year debated the legalization of same-sex marriage, a group of wealthy financiers who support both gay rights and Republican causes offered a reassurance to Republican lawmakers: Stand with us now, and we will stand with you later.

headline: Protesters Told to Vacate Park, for Its Cleaning
text: Responding to what he called unsanitary conditions at the private park in Lower Manhattan that has served as home base to the Occupy Wall Street protest for more than three weeks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Wednesday night that protesters would be made to leave temporarily as the property was cleaned in stages.

headline: The Charges Against Iran
text: Charges that Iranian officials ordered the assassination of Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to the United States are chilling and bizarre. If true — and American officials insist they have strong evidence — this is only the latest reminder of why the United States and its allies must use all possible diplomatic and economic pressures to isolate Tehran and block its nuclear ambitions.

headline: 3 Witnesses Rebut Claim by Consultant on Poll Work
text: Not long after the 2009 mayoral election, a lawyer for Michael R. Bloomberg’s re-election campaign heard that a reporter was trying to track $1.2 million that Mr. Bloomberg had given to the Independence Party so that a political operative named John F. Haggerty Jr. could provide ballot security.

headline: A Smart Immigration Move at Rikers
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg speaks often about the need for smart and humane immigration reform. He has now rightly thrown his support behind a City Council bill that would place sensible limits on how far New York City goes to help the federal government detain and deport illegal immigrants who pose no threat to the community.

headline: With Just Three 9s, Cain Refigured Math for Taxes
text: It was a strategy session at 28,000 feet. Herman Cain, the Republican presidential candidate, and his advisers were on a campaign flight this summer between Atlanta and New Hampshire, tossing around policy ideas.

headline: Curious Contents of the Digital Library
text: Perhaps you haven’t read Mrs. Molesworth’s “Uncanny Tales” or C. Schweigger’s “Schweigger on Squint.” Perhaps you missed “How to Be Happy Though Married” or the Farmers’ Bulletin devoted to “House Rats and Mice.” No worries. They are available in 24 digital formats, including versions to suit just about any e-book reader you own. These titles, and millions more, are all out of copyright and part of the accelerating effort to digitize the public domain contents of the world’s libraries.

headline: Thursday: Proceeding Without Thinking
text: Administrivial Exciting New York Times Crossword Puzzle Contest Alert! Heads up, my friends: Will Shortz and one of our top constructors will hold a forehead-slapping puzzle contest involving next week’s puzzles that you will definitely want to get in on. Exact instructions will follow at the top of each day’s puzzle (and I will post them here as well), but hold on to all of your puzzles from Monday through Friday, because the Saturday puzzle will contain a metapuzzle that will use clues from the rest of that week. When you have solved the metapuzzle, e-mail your answer to crossword@nytimes.com. PLEASE DO NOT POST YOUR ANSWERS HERE ON THE BLOG, AND PLEASE DO NOT MAIL THEM TO ME. Only answers e-mailed to that address will be considered. Twenty-five correct solvers, chosen at random, whose entries are received by 6 p.m. Eastern Time on Sunday, Oct. 23, will receive copies of “Will Shortz Picks His Favorite Puzzles: 101 of the Top Crosswords From The New York Times.” Only one entry per person, please. The answer and winners’ names will appear on Friday, Oct. 28, at http://www.nytimes.com/wordplay.

headline: A Wedding and an Unwelcome Guest
text: A wedding is an easy peg to hang drama on, for reasons that hardly need much elaboration. Two words suffice: family togetherness. In “We Live Here,” a programmatic play by Zoe Kazan that opened on Wednesday at City Center in a Manhattan Theater Club production, the summer nuptials of the daughter of an artsy clan in New England brings about a painful family reckoning with the impact of a tragedy from a dozen years before.

headline: Dip in Birth Rates Reflects Recession, Report Suggests
text: WASHINGTON — Birth rates in the United States declined sharply during the recession, according to a report by the Pew Research Center released Wednesday. The analysis, based on data from all 50 states and the District of Columbia, suggested women were putting off having babies while the economy was weak.

Half the stalls in their shared bathroom are missing doors, and their halls are lined with spooky rows of empty cubicles whose last occupants either took off or died off.

headline: House Panel Issues Subpoena for Records on Gun Program
text: A House committee subpoenaed the Obama administration on Wednesday over a law enforcement program that allowed illegal gun purchases in the United States in an effort to link the weapons to Mexican drug cartels. Representative Darrell Issa, Republican of California and chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, said a subpoena went to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. for Justice Department documents related to the program, called Fast and Furious. Mr. Issa has said that Mr. Holder provided misleading testimony to Congress on May 3 about when he first learned of Fast and Furious, which was overseen by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. A Justice Department spokeswoman, Tracy Schmaler, said that the department had already provided thousands of documents and made many officials available for interviews and testimony. “So any notion that the department isn’t working with the committee is simply wrong,” she said.

headline: Libya Fighters Say Capture of Surt Is Near
text: MISURATA, Libya — Anti-Qaddafi fighters said they had edged closer to capturing the coastal city of Surt on Wednesday, and commanders and journalists inside the city said the fighting appeared to be confined to just two areas of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s hometown.

headline: A News Story Is Growing With ‘Occupy’ Protests
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Splashed across the front page of the local newspaper here on Tuesday was the story of a 24-year-old Occupy protester named Keith Cuesta. He was not in New York, where some have been living in a park near Wall Street for nearly four weeks, but about 1,000 miles away in Tampa, where a small group of self-described “99 percenters” have decided to camp out in solidarity.

headline: From Needle Stick to Cure for Hepatitis
text: As doctors-in-training in the early 1990s, my friends and I became obsessed with the question of what we would do if we were pricked with an infected needle at work. We all had witnessed the inexorable, often painful march toward death of patients with hepatitis C and AIDS. We imagined the despair we would feel in that situation: the dashed hopes, the lost years of schooling and training. Many of us saw ourselves walking out of the hospital and not looking back. We couldn’t imagine throwing ourselves back into the fray.

headline: The Strategies of Game 4
text: DETROIT – The fourth game of the American League Championship Series started more than two hours late, and it stretched across 4 hours and 11 innings. But it was all worth it — for the Texas Rangers, who beat the Detroit Tigers, 7-3, and for people who are fascinated by baseball strategy.

headline: Word of the Day | gory
text: gory •\ˈgȯr-e\• adjective

headline: Booster Seats Continue to Improve, I.I.H.S. Finds
text: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, a nonprofit financed by the insurance industry, has issued a new round of booster-seat ratings in which the organization named a record 31 seats as Best Bets, the top grade offered in the survey. Another five seats were named Good Bets; more than 40 seats received the second-lowest rating, Check Fit; while six were rated Not Recommended.

headline: Roasted Chilies Bring the Heat
text: The chili harvest of West Texas, southern New Mexico and Chihuahua, Mexico, begins in late summer and lasts through the first hard frost. You can encounter the smell of chilies roasting anywhere, with the frequency and randomness I associate with leaves burning in New England. I didn’t know this until I went to New Mexico, where I'd traveled for the Hatch Chile Festival, an event every native or long-termer politely advised me to avoid. (“Well, it’s a nice drive,” they’d say, and they were right about that.)

headline: Corrections: October 13
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Syrian-American Is Arrested on Charges of Spying for Damascus
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Wednesday accused a Syrian-American man of secretly working for a Syrian intelligence service. It said he collected information about people in the United States who were protesting the Syrian government’s crackdown on the country’s pro-democracy movement, as part of a scheme to “silence, intimidate and potentially harm the protesters.”

headline: Britain: Ulster Inquiry to Reopen
text: The British government said Wednesday that it would reopen its investigation into the involvement of British forces in one of the most high-profile killings in Northern Ireland during the 30 years of violence known as the Troubles. But the decision to appoint a prominent British human rights lawyer to prepare a report on the extent of police and army “collusion” in the 1989 killing of Patrick Finucane, a lawyer who had represented Irish Republic Army activists, angered his family. They had demanded a full judicial inquiry similar to the one that was completed last year into the “Bloody Sunday” killings of 1972, when British troops shot and killed 13 unarmed Catholic protesters, with another protester dying later of his wounds. The $300 million cost of that inquiry, and the 12 years it took to complete, were cited by the government as reasons for not appointing a similar inquiry in the Finucane case. A previous inquiry had shown that Mr. Finucane was shot 14 times by Protestant gunmen as he ate a meal at his home with his wife and children.

headline: European Report Criticizes Turkey; Serbia Is Now Candidate for Bloc
text: A report issued Wednesday by the European Union enlargement office criticized Turkey’s reaction to recent gas drilling conducted by Cyprus in the Mediterranean, suggesting continued troubles with Turkey’s longstanding bid to join the bloc. Turkey refuses to recognize the Greek Cypriot government — itself a member of the bloc — as the sole representative of the disputed island and calls for the reunification of Turkish Cypriots in the north and Greek Cypriots in the south. Turkey has called the gas exploration by the Greek Cypriots an act of provocation and started its own seismic exploration program in the sea, escorted by the Turkish Navy.

headline: Britain: First Steps on Change for Women Ascending to Throne
text: Prime Minister David Cameron has taken the first formal step toward a constitutional change that would allow girls and women to ascend to the British throne before their younger brothers. Mr. Cameron told the House of Commons on Wednesday that he had written to the governments of 15 other Commonwealth nations that recognize Queen Elizabeth as head of state urging their acceptance of a change in the succession rules set by the Act of Settlement, adopted in 1701, which stipulates that male children have precedence over their older sisters in succession to the throne. Mr. Cameron also urged that the law be changed to eliminate a prohibition on the accession of any monarch who is married to a Roman Catholic, calling the ban an “historical anomaly.” The changes are said to have broad support in the other Commonwealth nations, though some are said to have reservations about opening a discussion out of concern that it might reopen potentially acrimonious debate on whether the monarchy should be abolished.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Free Texting
text: Text-messaging plans and fees can add quite a bit of revenue to the coffers of the wireless carriers, but newer services for sending messages free over Wi-Fi networks may soon take a bite out of those profits. On this week’s Bits Tech Talk podcast, Jenna Wortham, a technology reporter at The Times, discusses her recent article about how free text apps like iMessage make cellphone users happy and carriers nervous.

headline: The New York Times, August 16, 1858
text: The original newspaper article on the laying of the cornerstone for St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York City.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
text: Industrial production slowed to 4.1 percent in August, raising fears that India’s economic growth could fall faster and further than analysts previously thought. Data showed a sharp decline in mining activity combined with slower growth in manufacturing. (Financial Express) One large Indian technology outsourcing company, Infosys, however, reported stronger growth in the three months ending in September, thanks in part to the declining rupee. (Mint)

headline: State Puts Pressure on City Schools Over English Language Learners
text: New York City schools are broadly failing to meet the needs of many of their thousands of students who are still learning English, and they must improve or they may face sanctions, state education officials announced Wednesday.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday, because of Sukkot. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Cleaning Together to Escape Day Labor
text: After years of waiting on a Brooklyn street corner trying to land jobs cleaning houses, Teresa Bucio decided there had to be a better way to earn a living.

headline: Spilled Oil Makes Landfall After New Zealand Cargo Ship Accident
text: Videos of the cargo ship that became stuck on a reef off the coast of New Zealand a week ago were broadcast almost immediately, as the ship began spilling oil and debris. Now more have begun to surface, documenting the sludge-covered beaches as the leaked oil makes landfall.

headline: Cuomo Says He Will Reform Agencies Serving Disabled
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, saying he was startled by problems with the handling of abuse and neglect allegations at state facilities, on Wednesday vowed reforms at six agencies that provide residential care for the disabled, the elderly, children and the mentally ill.

headline: Nina Sorokina, Dancer With the Bolshoi Ballet, Dies at 69
text: Nina Sorokina, a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet from the 1960s to the 1980s whose impeccable technique, charm and buoyancy made her an ideal partner for her husband, the fiery, athletic Yuri Vladimirov, died on Oct. 8 in Moscow. She was 69.

headline: Euro 2012 Playoffs: First Among Seconds
text: For a reason that has yet to be uncovered, UEFA’s European Championship seems to routinely provide the stage for unfancied nations to upset the odds. Whether it was Denmark’s triumph as a last-minute entry in 1992, Latvia’s reaching the 2004 tournament at the expense of Turkey, whom it eliminated in the qualification playoffs, or Greece’s triumph over Portugal in Lisbon in the same year, the Euros retain a shock quality that their more illustrious relative, the World Cup, often lacks.

headline: David Hess, Songwriter and Actor, Dies at 75
text: David Hess, a songwriter for Elvis Presley, Pat Boone and others in the 1950s and 1960s who went on to play murderous movie villains, died on Friday in Tiburon, Calif. He was 75.

headline: Mildred Savage, Author of ‘Parrish,’ Dies at 92
text: Mildred Savage, the author of “Parrish,” a tale of a teenager struggling into manhood in the vast tobacco fields of the Connecticut River Valley in the late 1940s and early ’50s — a story later adapted for a popular movie of the same title — died on Friday at her home in Norwich, Conn. She was 92.

headline: Petition Filed by Parents of Schoolchildren Killed in May 2008 Earthquake
text: A petition and partial translation of a petition filed by parents of children who dies in the May 2008 earthquake.

headline: Anyone Who Fights ‘Will be Ground to Dust’
text: MANESAR — Two lanes of traffic and a barbed wire-topped fence separate the grey-striped Maruti Suzuki India plant from dozens of workers on strike outside.Security guards in blue shirts and navy slacks eye the workers, coalesced under a fuchsia-colored tent, warily through the fence. Striking workers, both inside and outside the plant, have halted production, costing Maruti and its vendors an estimated 30 billion Indian rupees (about $612 million) so far.

headline: In Baghdad, Hip-Hop Takes Root
text: Despite faint traces of cultural impact as the United States military prepares to withdraw from Iraq, a hip-hop scene has blossomed among youth.

headline: Oct. 13, 1943 | Italy Switches Sides in World War II

headline: Jack Delano’s American Sonata
text: Jack Delano’s touchstone as a documentary photographer was Paul Strand’s imperative that one had to have “a real respect for the thing in front of him.” Through his long career – photographing everything from coal miners, sharecroppers, railroad men and Puerto Rican canecutters – he conveyed a deep respect for not just the travails of Everyman, but a true appreciation of the dignity that lay within.

headline: Do You Participate in Class?
text: October 13, 10:40 p.m. | Updated  A history professor at the County College of Morris in Randolph, N.J., asked a student with a stutter not to raise his hand during class because she felt his stuttering took up valuable class time (although the professor later disputed that account). What do you think about the professor’s decision not to allow the student to participate verbally in class? What has been your experience with class participation?

headline: Mumbai Comic Convention Spotlights Local Talent
text: The Indian market for comics and graphic novels is booming, and there is no better proof of this than the second Comic Con India. The first such convention took place in Delhi earlier this February and will remain the key event in future while Mumbai will see an “Express” version, running Oct. 22 and 23 at the World Trade Center (Cuffe Parade; 91-22-6638-7272; comicconindia.com/Express), that will travel to different cities each year.

headline: N.F.L. Needs Fair Method for Recording Interception Statistics
text: On the final play in the first half of Sunday’s game between the Jets and the Patriots, Tom Brady threw a quick out to tight end Aaron Hernandez. Jets cornerback Antonio Cromartie intercepted the pass near the Patriots’ goal line and ran the ball back to the 41-yard-line as the clock expired.

headline: What Went Wrong at One Madison Park
text: “Where else in Manhattan can you get this?” shouted Ira Shapiro as he stood high above the streets of Manhattan on the penthouse terrace of One Madison Park. It was a bright blue spring morning, and he stretched out his arms to show off the view, a clear shot in three directions: north to the Empire State Building, south to the Brooklyn Bridge and west over the Hudson River to Jersey City. Music drifted upward from the bandstand in Madison Square Park, a lovely expanse of trees and paths, 57 stories below. It was by far the tallest building on the block. “We wanted to change the skyline of Manhattan,” Shapiro said. “And we did.”

headline: In Case You Didn’t Notice: Sewage Odors Are Drawing Fewer Complaints

headline: Varieties Of Uncertainty
text: Some of the usual suspects have lately been touting a research paper by Baker et al that supposedly shows that policy uncertainty is an important factor in restraining the economy, and claiming that this vindicates the Republican view. Larry Mishel sets the record straight.

headline: Low Rates As A Sign Of Failure
text: Brad DeLong and Atrios pile on to David Cameron for suggesting that his austerity program, which has rather notably failed to deliver growth, is responsible for Britain’s low borrowing costs. As they say, British rates are low for the same reason US rates are low — not as a reward for fiscal virtue, but because everyone now expects the economy to stay depressed, and policy rates near zero, for years to come.

headline: Timely | Laura Marling, Will of the Wisp
text: Songs simmer awhile inside her head before choosing their own moment to froth out fully formed. Or so has claimed Laura Marling, a 21-year-old British sensation who is perhaps the quintessential folk singer of her generation. It’s a romantic idea, this ghostly pale lass with wispy blond hair transmuting somehow — perhaps via inspiration from the Muses — her own admittedly tangled emotions into divinely inspired songs to be sung by her divinely bestowed voice. And it’s an idea bolstered by the fact that her first two albums earned her a Mercury Prize nomination each. Marling’s newly released third effort, “A Creature I Don’t Know,” poetically titled like all her albums, trades some of her teenage urgency for a more muscular, acrobatic lyricism — the result being 10 tracks that feel evolved, or more grown-up even. In any case, it’s clear that when Marling found this new sound, the Muses did not abandon her.

headline: The Eternal Adolescence of Beavis and Butt-Head
text: Some 15 years ago, these were two of the best-known laughs in America. One begins with an uhhhh that gives way to an airy, affected heh-heh-heh — it could belong to a snob who has had one too many electroshock treatments — while the other is more guttural, a throat-clearing hnhnhnhn that sometimes shifts to a higher register and back again, like Scooby-Doo being strangled. The first belongs to Butt-Head, the second to Beavis, and in their animated show, which MTV broadcast from 1993 to 1997, that laughter punctuates just about everything the two boneheaded teenagers utter. It’s so automatic that I imagined it had actually been automated — that an engineer pressed a button every time their laughter was called for, and voilà: uhhhh-heh-heh-heh, or hnhnhnhn, or both overlapping.

headline: Spacey’s ‘Richard III’ Arrives in BAM’s New Winter-Spring Season
text: As a certain Shakespearean monarch has said, “An honest tale speeds best, being plainly told,” and in the meantime a not-so-plain production of “Richard III” will make its way to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in January as part of the 2012 winter-spring season. The Bridge Project’s presentation of the play, starring Kevin Spacey as the “deformed, unfinsh’d” Duke of Gloucester and directed by Sam Mendes, will be presented at the Harvey Theater from Jan. 10 through March 4 with its official opening night scheduled for Jan. 18, the academy said Thursday. The production was first staged over the summer at the Old Vic Theater in London (where Ben Brantley wrote that Mr. Spacey “gives fierce and flashy physical life to every twist of a power-mad man’s corkscrew mind”) and will be the final season of the Bridge Project, a three-year series of collaborations among the academy, the Old Vic and Neal Street, Mr. Mendes’s company.

headline: As Thailand Floods Spread, Experts Blame Officials, Not Rains

headline: Allen, Coen and May: 3 Wits, One Show

headline: Read Their Lips
text: The photographer Elle Muliarchyk grew up speaking half a dozen languages, from Czech to Vietnamese (her father was a diplomat and her mother was a journalist and a linguist), and during a brief career as a model she picked up some French and Italian. Her experience in the global village of fashion and her interest in languages come together in “Lips of Babel,” a series of mesmerizing close-up video portraits of models delivering tongue twisters in their native tongues. “Tongue twisters are something we all have from childhood,” Muliarchyk says, adding that they often say a lot about their culture of origin. One from Nigeria translates as “Lady Seamstress, why are you so sad? Did a hen lay an egg on the dress you just made?” while another, from India, says, “A husband slapped his wife for no apparent reason.” News of the project spread quickly through the modeling world — entirely by word of mouth — and Muliarchyk has captured 50 and counting. The first 24 are on view next week at Motilo.com, and one segment is available, above.

headline: A Beautiful Prisoner Lost in Almodóvar’s Labyrinth
text: There’s an early decisive moment in Pedro Almodóvar’s exhilarating film “The Skin I Live In,” when Robert Ledgard, a plastic surgeon and madman played with soul weariness by Antonio Banderas, gazes at the image of a woman on the wall of his bedroom. She’s bigger than life, this woman, and more beautiful. He calls her Vera (Elena Anaya), and she’s stretched out in the classic recumbent pose of the odalisque: that exotic Turkish harem dweller and Orientalist fantasy painted by the likes of Goya, Ingres and  Manet, and given opulent new life and reverberant meaning by Mr. Almodóvar, a master of his art.

headline: Petition on Debit Card Fee Attracts 200,000 Supporters

headline: Notes From the Underground | Good to Go
text: The recent Good to Go show at the Bowery Poetry Club was a mishmash of performance types. The evening’s host, the Canadian comedy star and television personality Sabrina Jalees, kept the audience entertained with hilarious in-character stand-up sketches, and Ben Lerman, an unassuming guy with a ukulele, sang an unexpectedly gripping story about being Ben Lerman — and playing the ukulele. The show was peppered with original choreography from the Good to Go Girls — Jessy Smith, Molly Merkler and Jillian Hollis (shown here) — a bubbly trio of classically trained dancers whose skits toyed with physical comedy and burlesque. All in all, it was a surprisingly professional and well-curated event from one of downtown’s few remaining homes for the obscure.

headline: At Redone Bloomingdale’s, Hit the Escalators

I have my favorite corners — J Brand and Theory — but I never ventured into the low-ceilinged, crammed denim area. Just too uninviting.

headline: Beneath Pedro Almodóvar’s ‘Skin’
text: The director Pedro Almodóvar goes below the surface with his latest film, “The Skin I Live In.” The movie, which played at the New York Film Festival and opens Friday, involves a plastic surgeon (Antonio Banderas) and a special woman in his life, Vera (Elena Anaya). Their relationship is complex, to say the least. In her review, Manohla Dargis describes the film as “an existential mystery, a melodramatic thriller, a medical horror film or just a polymorphous extravaganza.” In this video, Mr. Almodóvar talks about how skin factors into the narrative. He also discusses reuniting, after 21 years, with the actor Antonio Banderas for the project.

headline: On False Equivalence and False Inequivalence
text: Just over a week ago, I wrote a quick post on a new sociological analysis of organized efforts to sow doubt about global warming. The analysis was illustrated by a flow chart of what the researchers called the “climate change denial machine.” I added an update a day later describing a chart of the “climate alarmism machine” created in response by an Australian blogger.

headline: Ping-Pong, Anyone?
text: No matter how many tickets and t-shirts a tour sells, the Arctic Monkeys still sleep on the bus.When you’re a teenager, you drive in a van from Sheffield to small-town gigs across England, party every night, meet girls: everything moves fast and you like it. Your song about some girl who looks “good on the dance floor,” which rhymes a reference to the Montagues and Capulets with “banging tunes and D.J. sets,” leads to Internet fame, the fastest-selling debut in British history and, in 2006, instant, MySpace-amplified international stardom.

headline: Gunmen Seize 2 Aid Workers Near Kenya-Somalia Border
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Somali gunmen struck again inside Kenya, abducting two European aid workers on Thursday afternoon from a sprawling refugee camp near the Kenya-Somalia border, officials said.

headline: New Book Covers the Covers of the 1980s
text: Before music came in clouds it came in sleeves. For the iTunes generation this may come as a surprise, but to buy music in the pre-digital era required a trip to a store, where rows of labeled bins held vinyl discs in a variety of formats: long-playing albums, 45s, 12-inch singles. These records, as they were called, came in paper sleeves that were covered front and back with artwork.

headline: Rooney Banned for Three Euro Games
text: Wayne Rooney is set to miss England’s three group stage matches at next summer’s European Championships after UEFA extended his punishment for kicking a Montenegro defender last week.

text: Close to a decade ago the illustrator Matt Vescovo did some pretty hilarious animations in the style of public service announcements that appeared on MTV. I thought they were worth revisiting.

headline: European Banks Face Deadline to Raise Capital Levels
text: BRUSSELS — Europe’s banks face a deadline of three to six months to strengthen their balance sheets and to compensate for the decline in value of Greek and other south European sovereign debt, European officials said Thursday.

headline: G.O.P. Allies Form House Super PAC
text: In a sign of the intensifying fight for control of the House, allies of Congressional Republicans are forming a new Super PAC to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money to defend the G.O.P. majority next year.

headline: Google Said to Be Planning an MP3 Store
text: Five months after it introduced a cloud music service with limited capabilities, Google is in negotiations with the major record labels to expand that service and also open an MP3 store that would compete with Apple and Amazon.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Is Not Charged in French Case
text: PARIS — For the second time this year, legal officials chose on Thursday not to prosecute Dominique Strauss-Kahn on charges of attempted rape, despite what investigators here said was evidence of sexual assault, ending months of scandal that have tarnished a political career that once seemed destined to lead to the French presidency.

headline: More on #OccupyWallStreet
text: Occupy Wall Street has attracted some famous faces: Slavoj Zizek dropped by over the weekend, and Mark Ruffalo wrote about his time there for The Guardian. Also spotted there: Russell Simmons and Kanye West; Michael Moore, Susan Sarandon, Tim Robbins, even one of the stars of “Gossip Girl,” whatever that is. Danny Glover visited the L.A. branch of the movement. Food businesses like Ben and Jerry’s, Liberatos Pizza and Sixpoint Craft Ales have donated food to the protesters. More should get on board.

text: In this new column, the makeup artist Tina Turnbow runs into real beauty on the streets of New York City.

headline: Goodell, Union to Meet with Congress on H.G.H. Testing
text: Representatives of the N.F.L., including Commissioner Roger Goodell, and the players union will meet with members of Congress on Friday in Washington to discuss the holdup in putting a blood testing program for human growth hormone into effect.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Bordertown: Laredo’
text: The police-ride-along genre of reality television, somewhat listless of late, gets a nice boost from “Bordertown: Laredo,” which has its premiere with back-to-back episodes Thursday night on A&E.

headline: In American Literature, the Volkswagen Beetle as Muse and Mutant
text: “It’s hard being a single dad — especially when your son is a 1971 Volkswagen Beetle,” says the back cover to “How to Keep Your Volkswagen Alive,” a new novel by Christopher Boucher (Melville House). However curious the book’s premise, it works a pretty well-plowed surrealist furrow, hailing back to Kafka and Gogol by way of “My Mother the Car” and “Christine.”

headline: 36 Seconds in Quebec City
text: A look at the enchanting Francophone capital of Quebec province.

headline: 36 Hours in Quebec City
text: Quebec is a city of delightfully stark, yet virtually seamless contrasts.

headline: 36 Hours in Quebec City
text: QUEBEC is a city of delightfully stark, yet virtually seamless contrasts; centuries-old fortification walls lead to chic open-kitchen restaurants, and cobblestone streets give way to bike paths and innovative art institutions. The enchanting Francophone capital of Quebec province, and one of the oldest cities in North America, Quebec City received a major face lift before its 400th anniversary in 2008. Perhaps more significant than the new boutique hotels, revitalized parks and gleaming cultural centers was the overdue attention the city finally received, which continues to propel it forward. Quebec City, a historic, cultural and culinary center beside the St. Lawrence River, has emerged from the long shadow cast by its ever popular neighbor, Montreal.

text: Like anyone who feels more at home outside than in, I’ve spent a considerable portion of my life gazing out windows. (Considerable, I said, not productive).

headline: Is a Little TV Really That Bad for Babies?
text: Should babies watch TV? Of course, the American Academy of Pediatrics says no. But does “no” really mean no watching the Republican presidential debate while you nurse the baby, or locking the toddler out of the room while the kindergartner watches “Dora the Explorer”?

headline: Arthur Dubin, Historian of Railroad’s Golden Era, Dies at 88
text: Arthur Dubin, a leading historian of the golden age of American passenger railroads, when trains bore names like ocean liners and Champagne glasses were filled by elegantly attired servers, died on Oct. 3 at a nursing home in Riverwoods, Ill. He was 88.

headline: Buffetts, Buffetts Everywhere
text: Greg Sargent points us to a new Congressional Research Service report (pdf) showing that there are a lot of millionaires paying lower taxes than many middle-class Americans. On average, the tax code is progressive — but there are a lot of cases where it isn’t.

headline: TimesCast | October 13, 2011
text: The hedge fund billionaire Raj Rajaratnam is sentenced to 11 years; South Korea’s president visits the United States; and Occupy Wall Street protesters and the Tea Party agree on one thing.

headline: Hackitude
text: It really is hard having a conversation about, well, anything when the other side just rolls out the talking points instead of discussing the issues. And while I should be used to it, having it happen face to face still gets me. If you want to know what I’m talking about, watch Fareed Zakaria this weekend.

headline: La Scala Names Barenboim Music Director
text: The Teatro Alla Scala in Milan has appointed Daniel Barenboim as its music director, the first person to hold the title since Riccardo Muti left amid acrimony six years ago. Mr. Barenboim, who is also music director of the Staatsoper in Berlin, will take up the post on Dec. 1, on a five-year contract.

headline: California Health Insurer Will Issue Refunds
text: Blue Shield of California, a large nonprofit health insurer based in San Francisco, said on Thursday that it planned to return an additional $295 million to its customers as part of the pledge it made earlier this year to cap its earnings to 2 percent of its revenue.

headline: Name That Green Space in Queens

headline: Cutting Through Cute to the Real Japan
text: ONE thing is certain about the artist known as Tabaimo: her animated videos have never followed the fashion for kawaii, or cuteness, that has ruled Japanese contemporary art for years. Instead, they focus on the anxieties bubbling beneath the surface of everyday life.

headline: Occupy Wall Street’s ‘Political Disobedience’
text: Our language has not yet caught up with the political phenomenon that is emerging in Zuccotti Park and spreading across the nation, though it is clear that a political paradigm shift is taking place before our very eyes. It’s time to begin to name and in naming, to better understand this moment. So let me propose some words: “political disobedience.”

headline: Someone Is Stealing Purses at Katz’s Deli
text: If she had simply had her hand in the pickle jar at one place — or if she had stuck a finger in the maple-butter dish at the other — this would be a different story, and probably more delectable.

headline: Where Grit’s Days Are Numbered
text: AT 3:30 p.m. on a Tuesday in late September, three men were sitting at the sidewalk tables in front of Tournesol on Vernon Boulevard. Pascal Escriout, the Frenchman who owns the bistro, was sharing a bottle of Bordeaux with a couple of friends — Robert Gonçalves, his partner in Domaine Wine Bar a few doors down, and one of the guys from Sweetleaf, the coffee house over on Jackson Avenue.

headline: Obama Says Facts Support Accusation of Iranian Plot
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama vowed on Thursday to push for what he called the “toughest sanctions” against Iran, saying that the United States had strong evidence that Iranian officials were complicit in an alleged plot to kill the Saudi ambassador to the United States.

headline: The Science of Movies? A Film Festival Judges Just That
text: When Alexis Gambis fell in love with fruit flies, it was a difficult relationship to explain to his friends. So he turned the lab where he was studying the flies’ genome sequences into a studio and made a film about his passion.

text: IT may not be Bergdorf’s, as its owner likes to joke. But the competitive shopping at casaBAN — an antiques store far from Fifth Avenue, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn — is just as fierce.

headline: Sounds for a Samovar: Carnegie Hall Russian Night
text: For all the attention being lavished on Tchaikovsky’s appearances in the festival that opened Carnegie Hall in 1891 as a pretext for the hall’s 120th anniversary celebration, Carnegie has made no point of reviving the works the composer conducted, which included his “Marche Solennelle,” his Third Orchestral Suite and two of his a cappella choruses. But willy-nilly, one of those works did appear on Tuesday evening, when Daniil Trifonov played Tchaikovsky’s First Piano Concerto with Valery Gergiev and the Mariinsky Orchestra in the hall.

headline: Winners of Oprah Winfrey’s ‘Ultimate Favorite Things’ Meet Their Beetles
text: On Thursday morning, 21 people assembled in Orland Park, Ill., a southwest suburb of Chicago, to receive the keys to their 2012 Volkswagen Beetles. The cars were among 276 promised last November as surprise gifts to attendees at a special “Ultimate Favorite Things” studio taping of “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” now discontinued.

headline: A Fix for Severe iOS 5 Loading Problems
text: A lot of people have experienced problems loading Apple’s new iOS 5 iPhone and iPad operating system, usually getting an error message and being left temporarily without use of the device. It appears that the demand is overtaxing Apple servers, so some people just can’t get to the download, a problem that will clear itself up shortly.

headline: Cancer Risk From Barrett’s Esophagus Lower Than Thought
text: People who have a condition known as Barrett’s esophagus, a complication of acid reflux disease, have a higher risk of developing esophageal cancer — but the risk is far smaller than widely believed, a new study shows.

headline: From Manhattan to Sierre Leone

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra Management and Musicians Approve Labor Agreement
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra management and musicians said on Thursday that they had approved a labor agreement that represents a major step toward bringing the orchestra out of bankruptcy court. The agreement would drastically cut salaries, reduce the size of the orchestra and pull the musicians out of the nationwide union pension plan, according to the musicians.

headline: Boat Capsizes in Hudson

The boat went down off West 50th Street around 4:30 p.m. and began drifting downriver, a department spokesman said.

headline: The Other Father of Cubism
text: The Acquavella Galleries’ splendid Georges Braque exhibition is a 42-gun salute to this pioneering French Modernist. The first large Braque survey to be staged in New York in more than 20 years, it musters a vigorous if compressed account of more than five decades of art making, with 42 paintings and collages, almost all top-notch. More than half have been borrowed from American and European museums; the rest come from private collections and in several cases have not been on public display in quite some time.

headline: Exploring Truth (and Fiction) Through a Camera Lens
text: In the 1980s photography mutated into a monster that threatened to swallow fine art altogether. In the hands of artists like Cindy Sherman, Jeff Wall, Gregory Crewdson, Andreas Gursky and legions of copycats, photography parsed the day’s most urgent questions about representation, propaganda, truth and reality. But in the ensuing decades, the answers became increasingly routine, and today the beast that art photography was finds itself tired and toothless.

headline: Rent vs. Buy
text: For years my colleague David Leonhardt has been helping people calculate whether it makes more sense to rent or buy a home, based on the relative costs of each decision. This week, the economists at Capital Economics noticed an interesting phenomenon related to this tradeoff. For the first time in three decades, the median monthly mortgage payment is about the same as the median rental payment:

headline: Ask Pixar’s John Lasseter Your Questions
text: Pixar Animation Studios, the home of Woody and Buzz, not to mention James P. Sullivan and Nemo, is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year. And it’s been an impressive run — not one box-office dud among its 12 features (though some critics, including A. O. Scott of this paper, registered their disappointment with this year’s sequel to “Cars”). The company, however, is not one to rest on its laurels. There’s a full slate of Pixar films to come, including “Brave,” the first of its features with a female protagonist. And “Finding Nemo” and “Monsters Inc.” will return to theaters in 2012 and 2013 for limited 3-D runs.

headline: The Slipcovering of a School
text: THE old New York School of Printing, on 49th Street through to 50th, west of Ninth Avenue, is a modernistic surprise in the tenement miscellany of Hell’s Kitchen. Opened in 1960, it was designed by Hugh Kelly and B. Sumner Gruzen in two parts, a fluid, guitar-box auditorium set off by a stern, rectangular sweep of glass blocks and steel swing-out windows. Concealed under a plastic screen years ago, the glass blocks were exposed for a while this year, only to be covered up again.

headline: Sometimes Old-Guard Talent Must Lean on New

headline: Acrobatics, Doll-Like Movements and Coy Gestures
text: Along with Houston Ballet’s debut at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday evening was another first: the presentation of the inaugural recipient of the Rudolph Nureyev Prize for New Dance, Jorma Elo’s “ONE/end/ONE.” I wish Mr. Elo’s ballet had been one to remember; alas, the grant, worth $25,000, is off to a weak start.

headline: A Muse Rekindles That Old Magic
text: THERE was a time in the not-so-distant past when the idea of Suzanne Farrell anywhere but onstage seemed impossible. For more than two decades she was George Balanchine’s muse, willowy, glamorous and alluringly distant, the face of not only New York City Ballet but also of ballet in America. Then, after she retired in 1989, she seemed to disappear, rarely spotted around a city where she had at one time seemed omnipresent. She once told a journalist that, in between coaching gigs, she enjoyed doing nothing more than playing cards and reading mystery novels.

headline: A Mixture of Styles and Flows
text: With a political even-handedness that deserves a place in the annals of diplomacy, the Brooklyn Academy of Music is presenting the Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan this week and the Beijing Dance Theater next week. If I too were diplomatic, I would confine my response to Cloud Gate’s “Water Stains on the Wall” — choreographed by the company’s founder and artistic director, Lin Hwai-min, with its first New York performance on Wednesday evening — to describing the many respects in which it is truly admirable. Instead, however, I start by saying that it left me cold throughout its almost 75 minutes.

headline: A High-Rise Change of Plans
