headline: Michael Ondaatje’s Passage From Ceylon
text: Once, on holiday, a friend and I descended a narrow iron ladder into a floodlit cavern and followed a guide into a small boat. As he rowed us through eerily motionless waters under a low, stalactite-fanged ceiling, the overhead lights went out, and only his flashlight pierced the darkness. In its beam we could see the play of the variegated colors across the crystal-crusted walls, and the slow-moving flickers of eyeless fish, our vision completely dependent on his single beam. Reading Michael Ondaatje’s mesmerizing new novel, “The Cat’s Table,” is like being guided, just as surely and just as magically, through the author’s lustrous visions. As he did in his great 1992 novel, “The English Patient,” which won the Man Booker Prize and became an Academy Award-winning film, Ondaatje conjures images that pull strangers into the vivid rooms of his imagination, their detail illumined by his words.

headline: A Keats Brother on the American Frontier
text: Suppose you wanted to write a novel about John Keats, everyone’s favorite English Romantic poet, whose travels in “realms of gold” were purely imaginary, and who died in 1821, poor and spitting blood, at the obscenely young age of 25. Faced with such narrative restrictions, you might be tempted to invent a brother who was everything that Keats was not: practical, rich, footloose, married with a child, healthy enough to reach middle age. Why not send this imaginary brother across the Atlantic to the “rank-grown forests” (as Keats wrote in a later poem) of America, Kentucky, say, and invent encounters with luminous figures like John James Audubon and giant catfish and backwoods swindlers living on “bear sandwiches greased with bear fat”? A lively correspondence between the two brothers, spiced with verses, might serve to delineate the striking differences in their situations, and cast a reciprocal light on the poetry and the prairies.

headline: Nation-Building, Our National Pastime
text: “Nation-building” is in bad odor these days, among the foreign policy cognoscenti and the general public alike. Weariness with the long struggles in Afghanistan and Iraq has produced a grand opposition alliance of isolationists, realists, populists and left-liberal anti-interventionists, who all agree it is past time to give up the hopeless dream. As Peggy Noonan recently put it, “We should not occupy their lands, run their governments or try to bribe them into bonhomie.” American soldiers should not be “social workers.” When she visited Afghanistan earlier this year, Noonan asked an American general how the war was going and was appalled to hear his answer: “Great. We just opened a new hospital.” Noonan lamented that the American soldier was no longer allowed to be “a warrior in a warrior army.”

headline: The Marriage of Semite and Anti-Semite
text: Philip Roth, writing in these pages two decades ago, called the virtuosic Israeli writer Aharon Appelfeld “a displaced writer of displaced fiction, who has made of displacement and disorientation a subject uniquely his own.” Indeed, “Until the Dawn’s Light,” Appelfeld’s masterly and finely wrought 16th novel, begins with a displacement. The year is 1912; a young mother, Blanca Hammer, is fleeing by train with her 4-year-old son, Otto, from some unnamed menace, toward an unknown destination. “It all transpired quickly and with frightening precision,” Appelfeld writes, “as though they were no longer their own masters but in the hands of the railways, which treated them mercifully and moved them from place to place, almost without pain.”

headline: Blood in the Sand
text: James Lee Burke presses onward with his singular mission to rewrite the American western in FEAST DAY OF FOOLS (Simon & Schuster, $26.99). The southwest Texas landscape is familiar genre territory, and the stand-up protagonist, Sheriff Hackberry Holland, is the latest in a long line of principled lawmen. But the good guys don’t ride horses anymore, the bad guys have traded their six-guns for automatic weapons and a country club sprawls across part of the old Outlaw Trail.

headline: The Curious C.D.O. Bankruptcy
text: Something odd is going on in New Jersey.

headline: Ruth Toner and Simon Fiorucci
text: IF love is supposed to be ephemeral, elusive and maybe also undiscovered by its experimenters, then the wedding of Ruth Bushnell Toner and Simon David Fiorucci may have hit love at its source. After all, the couple met while looking for dark matter, one of the most ephemeral and elusive (and in fact, undiscovered) phenomena in physics.

headline: The Graphic Novel as Orientalist Mash-Up
text: Craig Thompson’s “Habibi” is a work of fantasy about being ashamed of one’s fantasies. This anxiety is native to comics, or at least to the broad strain of American comics written by white males. The work of R. Crumb, for example, is a gallery of self-loathing — portraits that register an artist’s recoil from his own noxious imaginings. Thompson’s work is much prettier than anything drawn by Crumb, but the anxieties are similar. If “Habibi” had been content to mine this narrow but rich vein of adolescent angst it might have been a comic’s comic, or at least an instructive book for young adults. Instead, it aspires to address questions of spirituality, environmental degradation and religious pluralism. The result is frankly a mess, though it does include some arresting pictures.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 6’s Toughest Picks
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE BETTER ANGELS OF OUR NATURE: Why Violence Has Declined,  by Steven Pinker (Viking, $40.) Are humans essentially good or bad? Has the past century seen moral progress or a moral collapse? Pinker addresses these questions and more.

headline: For Children of Same-Sex Couples, a Student Aid Maze
text: It took five attempts for one prospective college student and her mother to fill out the 106-question federal form that would determine whether she would be eligible for financial aid. And that was not just because the form was frustratingly complicated. What tripped them up was the fact that the student had two legal mothers — and the form had room for only one.

headline: Paperback Row
text: CREATE DANGEROUSLY: The Immigrant Artist at Work,  by Edwidge Danticat (Vintage, $14.95.) Danticat, whose books include the story collection “Krik? Krak!” and the novel “Breath, Eyes, Memory,” grew up in Haiti in the 1970s, under the Duvalier dictatorships (she has lived in the United States since the age of 12). These essays reflect on the Haitian diaspora and artists who create despite the horrors that drove them from their homelands.

headline: I Was an Under-Age Semiotician
text: It is an occupational hazard of being a writer to be appalled by the prose style you deployed in your youth. Most of the time the flaws reflect unchecked enthusiasm, or literary clichés that have not yet worn away, or a certain inability to settle on a defined voice. But reading my own college juvenilia, I have a strange and almost total sense of disconnection. This is from a paper I wrote at the age of 19:

headline: M.L.S.: Playoff Race Goes to the Wire
text: Six teams are vying for the three remaining slots in Major League Soccer’s postseason with only two weekends left in the regular season.

headline: Holding Zuccotti Park
text: Cheers erupted after an announcement was read from the Bloomberg administration that Brookfield properties, which owns Zuccotti Park, would not require protesters to leave.

headline: For Rupp, Focus Is on Families in Need

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Double Dipping
text: What happens when a super-hero goes bad? That’s the premise behind Irredeemable, a series written by Mark Waid and illustrated by Peter Krause. The former hero in question is the Plutonian and in his path are his former allies, the Paradigm, who try to impede his quest for mayhem. Plutonian’s turn to the dark side may be bad for the people he used to protect, but it’s good for Boom! Studios, which publishes the series as two collected editions hit our lists this week. On the hardcover list, at No. 7, is The Definitive Irredeemable, a deluxe reprint of the first three volumes of the series. On the softcover list, at No. 2, is volume seven, which finds the ex-hero in exile at an alien asylum.

headline: Israel Plans to Build More Housing in East Jerusalem
text: The Israeli government has submitted formal plans to build a new neighborhood of Jewish housing in a part of Jerusalem beyond the 1967 lines close to the West Bank city of Bethlehem, the anti-settlement Israeli group Peace Now reported Friday.

headline: How to File for Financial Aid if Your Parents Are Gay
text: Filling out the federal form for student financial aid is an arduous task for most applicants. But if you have two mothers or two fathers, or if you happen to be married to a same-sex partner, it can quickly escalate into an even more complicated exercise.

headline: When It Comes to Charity, Their Address Says It All
text: Imagine what they would have had to do if they lived, say, a mile away, in the 400 block of Grand Street. Pay attention to the number 400.

headline: Calls Flood In, City Backs Off and Protesters Stay
text: Inside City Hall, the calls poured in late Thursday, predicting a debacle: Hundreds of people sympathetic to the Occupy Wall Street protest were streaming into Lower Manhattan, vowing to resist a forced cleanup of the park taken over by demonstrators.

headline: New Biography Says van Gogh Did Not Kill Himself
text: A new biography of Vincent van Gogh and a “60 Minutes” report on it scheduled for Sunday night call into question the long-accepted notion — central to the myth of the troubled artist — that he committed suicide.

headline: Way Is Cleared to Rebuild Greek Orthodox Church Lost on 9/11
text: Even before the fires were extinguished at ground zero, everyone agreed that St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church at 155 Cedar Street — crushed by the collapse of 2 World Trade Center — would rise again.

headline: Vikings Stadium Project Remains Stalled
text: Minnesota legislators “appeared to be making little immediate headway on a special legislative session needed to approve” a proposed Vikings stadium project one day after a “crucial report”  on a new stadium in Arden Hills, according to a report in The Minneapolis Star Tribune.

headline: Pair of Police-Protester Incidents Adds Fuel to Occupy Wall St.
text: Updated, 8:11 p.m. | Amid the chaos in Lower Manhattan on Friday morning as the Occupy Wall Street protesters marched through the streets, there were two encounters between protesters and the police that were captured, however imperfectly, on video and then ricocheted across the Internet.

headline: Striped Bass Poached in Spicy Soy Sauce

headline: The Hyeres Competition
text: The International Festival of Fashion and Photography takes place each spring at the Villa Noailles near Hyeres, in the south of France. Viktor & Rolf and Romain Kremer are among the designers who participated in the competition. Jury leaders have included Martin Margiela, Azzedine Alaia, Raf Simons and Hussein Chalayan. The Hyeres Festival is an excellent way for emerging designers and photographers to get some recognition. The deadline for applications for the spring 2012 festival is Dec. 5. So apply! For details, go to villanoailles-hyeres.com/hyeres2012.

headline: The Minimalist: Striped Bass Poached in Spicy Soy Sauce
text: Poaching — cooking in simmering liquid — is a fairly forgiving way to cook fish, since it’s not likely to dry out. (It also virtually eliminates the likelihood of anything sticking to the bottom of the pan, which is often in the back of your mind when you sauté.) I love using this method with striped bass, which has the added bonus of being a local fish, but you can use any firm white fillets or steaks. It’s also a great way to cook mackerel or bluefish, other locals.

headline: In a Culture Clash, Olympus Ousts Its British Chief
text: TOKYO — The struggling Japanese camera maker Olympus wanted a change agent. Just not this much change, evidently.

headline: Chemistry as the Language of Life
text: Mark Hay, a biology professor at Georgia Tech, writes from Fiji, where he is investigating coral-seaweed competition in the coral reefs.

headline: Reckless in Seduction, if Not Onstage
text: Since becoming the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera in 2006, Peter Gelb has made it a priority to persuade strong, successful directors from theater and film to take on major new productions. And why not? Opera is theater. In theory, gifted directors who are mostly new to opera should bring fresh, bracing perspectives to bear.

headline: Restaurant Report: Rustic Stone in Dublin
text: When the Irish economic crisis hit, even a Michelin star and a celebrated reputation couldn’t save the chef Dylan McGrath’s fine-dining restaurant, Mint, which closed in spring 2009. Making a comeback with a more casual approach, he opened Rustic Stone in August 2010, emphasizing (gasp) healthy cuisine, free of the fatty crutches of butter and cream — and in a location bordering the pub-filled Temple Bar district, where indulgence is king.

headline: Letters: Fall Foliage
text: Fall Foliage

headline: Of Parties, Prose and Football
text: “CIVILIZATION begins with distillation,” William Faulkner wrote, and in Oxford, Miss., his adopted hometown, it’s possible for a literary pilgrim to visit what’s left of his liquor cabinet.

headline: Detour Near Kennebunkport, Me.
text: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., is probably best known as a summer playground for the wealthy, most notably the former president, George H. W. Bush. The old money is plenty visible: confident young men stride around town in freshly pressed khakis and preppy haircuts, vintage sailboats glide into port, and straight-backed seniors sip cocktails in Adirondack chairs.

headline: A High-End Trip Into a Chilean Desert
text: IF you’ve heard of the Atacama Desert in northern Chile at all, you’re likely to know one thing: it’s the driest desert on earth. That’s all I knew going in, though it triggered my reflexive mistrust of superlatives.

headline: In Denver, Shops in the Rubble of the Gold Rush
text: Now a shopping destination, the area has had a history that stretches back to the gold and silver rushes of the 19th century.

headline: Faulkner’s Ole Miss
text: A trip to view William Faulkner’s spirits is the best possible way to begin a long weekend in Oxford.

headline: Same-Sex Parents and Paying for College
text: When applying for financial aid for college, having two same-sex parents can be an asset or a disadvantage, depending on the circumstances, as the following examples illustrate. The expected family contribution, used by colleges to determine financial aid packages, takes into account the student’s household size, family income and assets, and the number of students in college, among other factors.

headline: As Calls for Protests Go Global, Italy Jumps the Gun
text: Online organizers have set Saturday as the date to spread the Occupy Wall Street protests to cities around the world.

headline: In a Volatile Market, Some Turn to Insurance Instead of Bonds
text: LIFE insurance, it’s fair to say, is a subject that provokes  strong opinions. People who like insurance see it as a way to leave money to heirs tax-free or to make sure there is money for a rainy day. Those who don’t like it see a product that generates huge fees for the seller and a diminishing benefit for buyers who probably don’t understand it.

headline: Financial Planner’s Red Flags
text: If you’re a company trying to persuade Americans to trust you with their money, the last thing you want is former employees accusing you of cheating them out of theirs.

headline: Ameriprise and the Meaning of Its 401(k) Lawsuit
text: My column this week is about Ameriprise, a company rich with history, though not always the good kind. It deserves a ton of credit for making financial planning central to its work with customers, but it has also run into plenty of trouble with regulators over the years.

headline: Questions for Amazon on Privacy and the Kindle Fire
text: The dream of every retailer is to know exactly what its customers are thinking. Are they comparison-shopping? Just looking? Will a discount help close the deal? Or is price no object? Amazon’s coming tablet, the Kindle Fire, is equipped with a Web browser that, thanks to the wonders of cloud computing, is partly housed on Amazon’s servers. That will give the retailer opportunities to track customer behavior all over the Web, gathering data and marketing intelligence as it goes.

headline: Projected Yearnings
text: We asked the Paris-based artist and lighting director Thierry Dreyfus to make the T for our winter women’s issue because he lights so many of the clothes that we see on the runways. (He did 25 shows last season alone.) But it wasn’t just the halos at Comme des Garçons or the bulbed ceiling that lifted from the floor at Rag & Bone that made Dreyfus such an easy and desirable pick. All over the world — at hotels in Belgrade and Athens, in galleries in Singapore and Milan, and at design fairs in London and Miami — Dreyfus’s installations alter and electrify their surroundings and our experiences of them. Here, he tells T how the projected image of our signature initial happened (by accident), and the kind of light he hopes women will wear this winter.

headline: Mariusz Kwiecien Set to Return to Met Stage
text: Just two weeks after undergoing surgery for a herniated desk, the baritone Mariusz Kwiecien will return to the stage in the title role of “Don Giovanni” at the Metropolitan Opera on Oct. 25, the company said on Friday. Mr. Kwiecien, his surgeon and manager reported in a conference call that “his recovery is progressing at a remarkable pace,” Peter Clark, the Met spokesman, wrote in an e-mail. He is expected to carry out all the stage action, with the possible exception of climbing down a ladder in the opening scene, Mr. Clark said. Mr. Kwiecien felt pain during the dress rehearsal last week and had to withdraw from early performances in the run. Doctors operated on his back on Tuesday.

headline: Bishop Indicted; Charge Is Failing to Report Abuse
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A bishop in the Roman Catholic Church has been indicted for failure to report suspected child abuse, the first time in the 25-year history of the church’s sex abuse scandals that the leader of an American diocese has been held criminally liable for the behavior of a priest he supervised.

headline: What Works to End Bullying?

headline: Off the Charts: Imports Are Falling, Again
text: Imports to most countries plunged when the credit crisis began in 2008, and then recovered. But in recent months, slowing economies have led to renewed declines in most countries in the euro zone.

He describes the sixth and seventh shooting deaths of whooping cranes raised in this federal program and released in the United States this year. The video above has some general background on the program.

headline: Citizens’ Testing Finds 20 Hot Spots Around Tokyo
text: TOKYO — Takeo Hayashida signed on with a citizens’ group to test for radiation near his son’s baseball field in Tokyo after government officials told him they had no plans to check for fallout from the devastated Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant. Like Japan’s central government, local officials said there was nothing to fear in the capital, 160 miles from the disaster zone.

headline: Insurance as an Investment Alternative
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about some investors who are turning to life insurance to insulate themselves from the volatility in the stock market. Insurance, after all, allows you to leave money to your heirs tax free or to make sure you have money when you need it.

headline: Look of The Moment | Sienna Miller
text: The Look: Fluff Piece — an electric dress with feathers and plenty of sparkling appliqués is as attention-grabbing as any bird of paradise.

headline: Report Faults Wall Street for High Energy Prices
text: A new report by Better Markets, a nonprofit group advocating constraints on speculative trading, blames Wall Street for inflating prices at the gas pump and the grocery store.

headline: A Burst of Autumn Color in the Great Allegheny Passage
text: CUMBERLAND, Md. — One reason I began my cross-country bike trip in midsummer was so I could be on the road as the seasons changed. I had some chilly, autumnal weather before it was actually autumn, but the foliage has been slow to turn this year. It’s only in the past week or so that the colors have taken on the burned yellows and burnished reds that we associate with fall, but I was lucky enough to be in the woods when it happened.

headline: Politico Reporter Resigns Amid Plagiarism Allegations
text: A reporter for the news Web site Politico resigned on Thursday after allegations that she had used content in a number of her stories from articles that had been published in The New York Times, The Associated Press, NJ.com and other sources.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Jill Abramson’s ‘Puppy Diaries’
text: In Sunday’s Book Review, Alexandra Styron reviews “The Puppy Diaries: Raising a Dog Named Scout,” the new book from The Times’s executive editor, Jill Abramson. The book, which began as a popular blog, examines the joys and trials of living with a rambunctious golden retriever puppy.

headline: Qaddafi-Era Flag Is Said to Have Set Off Gunfire in Tripoli
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Hundreds of anti-Qaddafi militiamen converged on several neighborhoods of Tripoli on Friday, firing heavy weapons on residential streets in a rare outburst of violence that may have started with demonstrations in support of the deposed leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Unflinching Underdog Working on an Upset
text: TIFFIN, Ohio — Justin Suddeth, a defensive back at Heidelberg University, does not need to look at the schedule to know when the coming opponent is Mount Union, a Division III football juggernaut with 10 national championships and only one regular-season loss in the last 17 years.

headline: A Golden Touch Turns Leaden
text: No wonder Occupy Wall Street took its protest this week to East 86th Street and the 28,500-square-foot limestone mansion owned by the billionaire hedge fund manager John A. Paulson. What better symbol of the excesses of Wall Street than Mr. Paulson, who made billions betting on the real estate collapse and whose opulent surroundings stand in such contrast to the million of Americans who have lost their homes?

headline: The Tapas Bar Brought Home
text: IN many cities in Spain, where much of life is lived in the street, tapas are a daily indulgence. Rather than invite friends over, you meet at a tapas bar, have a few drinks and nibble up a storm from an array of savory dishes. Your little group can wax and wane, as some peel off, stopping for tapas at a few more places.

headline: Tapas for Dinner
text: Translated to a home setting, Spanish tapas make a great way to entertain, perfect for a small city kitchen. Not at all a formal sit-down meal scenario, it works for a small group as well as a crowd. You can dispense with chairs, plates, even forks. All you need are napkins, glasses, toothpicks, and a few serving dishes.

headline: Busy Week in Food: Even More Links!
text: Is part of the reason that Danes are so happy because they cook? (Maybe. And they also have far less income inequality: a dishwasher in Denmark makes $25 an hour, gets sick days, health care, maternity leave, and a pension.)

headline: Frieze Frame | Sarah Lucas’s Bedside Manner
text: Pretty much every art fair seems to have its own drain — the place everyone eventually winds up at the end of the night. And the one that’s emerged at Frieze this year is the lounge at the St. John Hotel, on Leicester Square in London’s Chinatown, where the artist Sarah Lucas is in bed-sidency. Inside the Maritime bar, up one flight of blue, porthole-lined stairs from the hotel’s entrance, several of Lucas’s sculptures hang from the ceiling — plastic buckets and patio chairs from which stuffed pantyhose swing like Ernesto Neto-inspired breasts, conjuring the shapes of individuals who seem ready to party. Lucas herself evidently likes to stay up late; though she’s spent most of the week in pajamas in Room 15, when I visited last night, around last call, she was holding court with a room packed with fair-weary revelers like Gavin Brown and MoMA P.S. 1’s Peter Eleey.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: This weekend is the kickoff for the first Cider Week in New York, which runs from Sunday through Oct. 23. There will be more than 85 restaurants throughout the city and Hudson Valley participating in the weeklong celebration of fermented apple juice. Consider the New Amsterdam Market, South Street (between Beekman Street and Peck Slip), which is holding a hard-cider revival on Sunday from noon to 4 p.m. with hard-cider tastings, Marlow and Sons is running a cider bar, and tapas-size snacks. Early admission is from noon to 1:30 p.m., with $45 tickets, which includes 10 tastings. General admission starts at 1:30 p.m., with five tastings for $20 and 10 for $35. Additional tastings are $5 each.

headline: House Panel Examines Details of Solyndra Deal
text: WASHINGTON — The Energy Department may have made a decision without precedent when it allowed Solyndra, the now bankrupt solar technology company, to restructure its loans so private investors — not the government — would have first call on its assets in case of liquidation, two Treasury Department officials acknowledged Friday before a House subcommittee.

headline: Armed U.S. Advisers to Help Fight African Renegade Group

headline: Research Group Sees Deterioration in U.S. Fuel-Economy Gains
text: For all the attention devoted to American car buyers’ rediscovery of smaller, more fuel-efficient vehicles in 2011, a report released this week suggests that such purchase trends are having little impact on overall fuel economy.

headline: Starting Simple, Ending With Spectacle
text: Showmanship, like most things, seems to come naturally to Pat Metheny. As a virtuoso guitarist, an expansive composer and, above all, an inveterate searcher, he knows how to bring human scale and feeling to the most outsize sort of spectacle. He can also pull off the inverse, making reflective solitude seem grand and overwhelming, like a balloon incarnation of Emily Dickinson in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: An ’80s Scandal Comes to a Quiet End

BASS, the billionaire investor, certainly did not give the impression of an unhappy husband on the night of Sept. 26, when he attended the black-tie opening of “Anna Bolena” at the Metropolitan Opera. Whenever a photographer took a picture of his wife of nearly 23 years, Mercedes T. Bass, the philanthropist and fashion plate whose name appears on the Met’s Grand Tier, Mr. Bass was there by her side, his white pocket square complementing her Oscar de la Renta dress.

headline: In His Shoes
text: After being largely eclipsed by its flashier rivals, most notably the red-soled Louboutin, the quietly elegant Manolo Blahnik is once again emerging as the “it” shoe.

headline: In His Shoes
text: THIS is the tale of the little stiletto that could, a shoe that in the long-ago days of the luxury-goods boom scampered to the top of a rarefied heap. It was just a handful of years ago that the name of Manolo Blahnik, a 68-year-old London cobbler born in the Canary Islands, was familiar only to hard-core fashion hunters and residents of ZIP code 10021.

headline: The Lease Is Up, and Now, So Is the Rent
text: A LITTLE more than two years ago, Tom Graney was paying a reasonable $2,200 for a spacious two-bedroom apartment on 11th Avenue and 52nd Street.

headline: Sales Over Rentals, Even in a Credit Crunch
text: IN the last few years a number of new condominium projects, facing poor sales and tighter lending requirements for buyers, have chosen to become rental buildings. While rentals don’t usually generate as much initial revenue as sale properties, developers see them as a safe long-term bet, generally easy to fill and providing steady revenue.

headline: Another White House Description of Solyndra
text: Among the insights to be drawn from the unfolding Solyndra scandal is that the flavor and texture of political scandal have changed in the digital age. The leaked  Pentagon Papers consisted of mostly dry academic prose. The written reports submitted in the Red Scare investigations of the 1950s varied in tone from sinister to bombastic.

headline: Administration Nixes the Class Act
text: The Obama Administration on Friday announced that it was scrapping the Class Act, the government-run insurance program for long-term care authorized by the Affordable Care Act, essentially because the numbers could not be made to work. Robert Pear reports:

headline: Love the One You’re (Born) With
text: VIENNA GIRARDI was the winner of the 2010 season of the reality dating show “The Bachelor.” What she won, albeit briefly, was the heart of Jake Pavelka. The pair have since broken up — she says because of his lust for fame; he says because she’s a liar.

headline: TimesCast | Protesters Dig In
text: A scheduled cleanup of Zuccotti Park was postponed, and Occupy Wall Street protesters dig in.

headline: McCain to Pawlenty: ‘Watch the Money’
text: Tim Pawlenty had money on his mind a few weeks before he ended his bid for the Republican presidential nomination two months ago.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Flirty
text: The erogenous zone of present-day fashion is the shoe. Guests put some of the amazing variety in the spotlight at the recent New York and Paris shows.

headline: European Preview: Oct. 15-16
text: John Godfrey teased some of these games in his weekly United States national team TV guide, but here’s a little more on the biggest games in Europe this weekend from Rob Hughes.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Wins Suit Over Antibiotic’s Side Effects
text: Johnson & Johnson on Friday won a significant lawsuit concerning whether it adequately alerted doctors to the risks in prescribing its popular antibiotic Levaquin.

headline: Special Section: Cars
text: With small cars back in vogue, Saab on the ropes and used cars commanding new-car prices at the dealership, The Times offers a special Cars section, which examines the forces that are shaping and buffeting the auto industry.

headline: Hit the Escalators
text: EVERYONE has her own shopping pattern for the Bloomingdale’s mother ship on Lexington Avenue and 59th Street, but mine turns out to be not so original. I always head to the contemporary brands on the second floor, skip the third entirely (a bland sea of office clothes) and the cruise designer stuff on the fourth. I have my favorite corners — J Brand and Theory — but I never ventured into the low-ceilinged, crammed denim area. Just too uninviting.

headline: Religion, Politics and Tax Exemptions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Human Rights Group Welcomes Obama’s Decision to Send Troops to Uganda
text: As my colleagues Thom Shanker and Rick Gladstone report, “President Obama said Friday that he had ordered the deployment of 100 armed military advisers to central Africa to help regional forces combat the Lord’s Resistance Army, a notorious renegade group that has terrorized villagers in at least four countries with marauding bands that kill, rape, maim and kidnap with impunity.”

headline: A Choice From Many Potential Lines of Play
text: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands — Play in the 40th World Team Championships starts here on Sunday.

headline: Messages From Prison to an Irresistible Beat
text: There is a point late in “more more more ... future” when you think the Congolese choreographer Faustin Linyekula and his collaborators might take their title seriously, and keep going till this mythical future comes — or till they drop. Some of them already have, in fact, collapsing or slumping to the floor only to rise again and again.

headline: Siri Answers Questions From Readers
text: On Thursday, we asked readers to submit questions for Siri, Apple’s new virtual personal assistant in the iPhone 4S. Below are some of Siri’s most entertaining answers. We threw in some questions of our own because, well, once we got started, it was hard to stop.

headline: Toe to Spine, a Study in Precision
text: The amalgam of formality and informality, of technique and rawness (sometimes wildness) in the work of the choreographer Liz Gerring is something rare. Her six dancers, all attractive, look purpose-bred. The intensity with which they all use their backs is particularly impressive, as is the accentuation they bring to very simple steps. Yet they look neither homogenized nor groomed. Though the way any one of them raises a limb often looks wholly unschooled, you later realize that each moves the very same way the next time, and that so do the others. What looked naïve proves to be precise.

headline: Generational Exchange: Father and Son, Side by Side
text: The dull, conservative older generation and the rebellious, daring younger one: this is the primal narrative of the arts. But these days the situation is all too often reversed, with up-and-coming artists creating cautious, bland work that would have been unthinkable to their pioneering elders.

headline: MTV's Next Reality Star
text: MTV's college channel, mtvU, will next attempt to capture university life of an entirely deaf university.

headline: A Closer Look at Accused Self-Identified Tiger Poachers
text: The Wildlife Conservation Society has produced a short video about the remarkable case in which accused Thai tiger poachers were tracked down using cell-phone photos taken by one of the the gang, and connected to a particular slain tiger by camera-trap photos taken by conservation biologists.

headline: Views to a Kill
text: Abraham Lincoln. Anwar Sadat. John Lennon. Franz Ferdinand. Lee Harvey Oswald. John F. Kennedy. Martin Luther King. Osama bin Laden. Robert Kennedy. Mohandas Gandhi. Anwar al-Awlaki.

headline: A Mash-Up of Methods to Celebrate Life
text: “Be afraid, please be afraid of me,” sings the composer and violinist Daniel Bernard Roumain in “Symphony for the Dance Floor,” his latest evening-length cross-genre amalgam.

headline: A Surface Still Shiny After 20 Years
text: The Spin Doctors took a moment to pose for a group photo before exiting stage left at their sold-out Bowery Ballroom show on Thursday night. They were joined by a member of their management team, and by a meaningful prop: the plaque commemorating sales of five million copies of their major-label debut, “Pocket Full of Kryptonite” (Epic). The crowd, which had just heard the album performed in sequence, greeted this bit of ceremony with obliging pep, cheering both the accomplishment and, implicitly, its own contribution to it.

headline: Life’s a Pain, and Then You Play Penn
text: Martina McBride isn’t a singer given to lighthearted gesture. She’s an adult, singing about adult topics, with one of the biggest and most healing voices in Nashville. She’s best when tackling painful subjects, and while she’s capable of happiness, she could never be glib.

headline: This Detective Is Sharp but Also Introspective
text: An early sign that “Case Histories” isn’t going to be a typical British mystery: the voice of Nanci Griffith singing the lovely John Prine song “Speed of the Sound of Loneliness.” Strumming guitars and Texas twangs are not the usual soundtrack for tea-fueled detection and beatings on dark Edinburgh streets.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 14
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a Bowery hotel that houses two different worlds, a legendary comedian who panhandles in Midtown, and a cleanup in Zuccotti Park.

headline: One Definition of Collaboration: Putting Heads Together, Then Taking Turns
text: Cuqui Jerez is a Spanish choreographer, but her show “The Rehearsal” is not a dance. It is being presented by Performance Space 122, but not at Performance Space 122, which is undergoing renovations. And those are only two of the contradictions built into this offering at the Crossing the Line festival. At the show’s opening on Wednesday, Ms. Jerez and the four other troupe members seemed right at home at the Performing Garage, headquarters of the playfully experimental Wooster Group.

headline: Geren Named Mets’ New Bench Coach
text: The Mets took another step in revamping their coaching staff on Friday by naming Bob Geren, the former manager of the Oakland Athletics, as their bench coach for the 2012 season.

headline: China-India Program at Asia Society
text: Leading writers from China and India will meet for panel discussions in New York early next month as part of a new initiative called “The ‘Chindia’ Dialogues.” The event, to run Nov. 3 through 6 at Asia Society, will focus on cultural and social trends in both countries as well as their interaction with each other. The Chinese-born writers who will take part include Ha Jin, Su Tong and Yu Hua; on the Indian side, Amitav Ghosh, Amit Chaudhuri and Siddhartha Deb are among those scheduled to speak. In addition, the American scholars Jonathan Spence and Orville Schell will participate, and separate musical performances by musicians from each country are also scheduled.

headline: Teen Spirit Smells Like . . . Victory!
text: If you have — or have ever had — a teenager in your home or, really, if you have ever known a teenager, then chances are there’s been an occasion when you wondered, What was he thinking? (Or if he was thinking.) That’s why you should check out National Geographic’s October cover article by David Dobbs, “The New Science of the Teenage Brain.” It’s full of fascinating things. Even Shakespeare is enlisted to sum up the problem of teenagedom, through a character who says, of 10- to 23-year-olds, “There is nothing in the between but getting wenches with child, wronging the ancientry, stealing, fighting.” The bard neglects drinking, drug doing, driving while drinking or drug doing, cutting classes, indulging all sorts of cyber shenanigans, playing too much of that damn “Halo” video game — wait, I sound like the ancientry, don’t I? — but you get the idea. Teenagers are crazy.*

headline: Is Race Reflected by Your Outfit?
text: THE GIST Our perception of race is altered by the clothing people wear.

headline: At Muriel Brandolini’s Auction, a Style Maker’s Cache
text: A selection of Muriel Brandolini’s furniture and art collection will be auctioned next week at Phillips de Pury & Company.

headline: At Auction, a Style Maker’s Cache
text: “I LIKE things in their own juice,” Muriel Brandolini said as she conducted a visitor around an installation of her personal collection of furniture and art at Phillips de Pury & Company, which will auction the selection next week. Ms. Brandolini was referring to her taste for objects that speak of their era, yet maintain a sense of quirky character.

headline: A Gentle Push for Bikers, Not a Shove
text: NEXT summer, New York City plans to introduce its bike-share program, making two-wheeled travel possible for thousands more residents and tourists. Shared bikes, available at rental kiosks around the city, will have built-in safety features like a handlebar bell and front and rear lights that stay on all the time.

headline: U.S. to Play France in Paris on Nov. 11
text: U.S. Soccer announced Friday that the national team would play a friendly against France on Nov. 11 at the Stade de France outside Paris.

headline: Now Online | T Magazine Winter Women’s Fashion 2011
text: The winter fashion issue starts with our cover star, the musician and photographer Patti Smith, and a profile of her by A.O. Scott. Inside, the actress Kirsten Dunst talks about awards, playing dress up and Hitchcock; the Arctic Monkeys show what life on the road is like; and Henry Louis Gates Jr. discusses black culture in America. And don’t miss news of a Norell sale, Suzy Menkes on why old clothes move museum tickets, an article that explores whether acupuncture can really get rid of wrinkles and a look at the two women who are the real lovers behind a West Village sculpture. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $17,000,000
text: The three-bedroom condominium at 15 Central Park West that sold for $17 million — after last trading hands in 2008 for $6.8 million and thus generating nearly $10 million profit in just three years — was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records.

headline: The U.S.-South Korea Trade Deal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Micro-Mini Mom
text: I am a 14-year-old girl, and I get along with my mother pretty well. But she tends to wear clothes that are appropriate for girls my age — and totally wrong for 42-year-old mothers: skirts that are way too short, cropped tops and cutesy branded tees. I feel humiliated when my friends see her dressed up like that. But when I try to discuss the issue calmly, we end up screaming at each other. What can I do? Gillian

headline: Milestones: Mitt Romney
text: An interactive timeline of Mitt Romney’s life and career.

headline: Busy Mom’s Morning Yoga
text: To the Editor:

headline: Virgin Atlantic and British Airways Compete Over BMI
text: The rivalry between British Airways and Virgin Atlantic continues, this time over the midsize European carrier BMI. On Friday, Virgin Atlantic confirmed that it was in talks with the German carrier Lufthansa, the parent company of BMI, over a deal for the troubled airline. Britain’s Sky News reported earlier that the International Airlines Group — British Airways’ owner — was also in preliminary discussions. It was unclear whether the airlines were interested in buying BMI outright or merely adding some of its assets.

headline: Unilever Buys Russian Cosmetics Brand
text: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch firm, has agreed to buy an 82 percent stake in Concern Kalina, a Russian cosmetics brand, for $537 million. Under the terms of the deal, Unilever will add Kalina’s portfolio to the company’s existing skin, hair and oral care brands in Russia. Consumer product companies have been looking to the emerging markets and beyond for growth. Russia’s economy is on track to grow 4.3 percent this year.

headline: Children’s Literature
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Tall Tale, but True: Men in Heels
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Dressing Against Character
text: THE actor Kevin McHale, 23, plays Artie Abrams on “Glee,” in its third season on Fox. Before that, he belonged to the boy band NLT. A native of Plano, Tex., Mr. McHale now lives in Los Angeles. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

headline: Foreclosures Empty Homes, and Criminals Fill Them Up
text: The boarded-up homes that changed the face of Jamaica, Queens, in recent years were bad enough, the flotsam of the record wave of housing foreclosures that roared through the streets like nowhere else in New York City.

headline: Picking Up Public Radio, but Still No Talking Back
text: APP WNYC

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 14
text: See the Slide Show

headline: The Critics Of Modern Macro Are Wrong
text: It’s even worse than they think.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
text: NO. 11 MICHIGAN AT NO. 23 MICHIGAN STATENoon Eastern, ESPNIf Michigan State wins today, it will have its first four-game winning streak against its in-state rival in almost 50 years. Michigan is trying to climb back to national prominence. The winner gets sole possession of first place in the Leaders Division of the Big 10. Michigan State comes in with the top defense in the nation, allowing 173.4 total yards a game and having held four of its five opponents to 7 points or fewer. Spartans linebacker Denicos Allen had two sacks against Ohio State last week. Michigan quarterback Denard Robinson, right, is electrifying but has nine interceptions. The Wolverines are outscoring opponents, 114-21, in the second half, and much of the credit goes to the defensive coordinator Greg Mattison.

headline: Wal-Mart’s Unlimited T-Mobile Data Plan
text: Thanks to consumer watchdogs, T-Mobile has not closed its deal with AT&T — but T-Mobile has closed a deal with Wal-Mart, and it’s one that consumer advocates might support.

headline: Wedding Etiquette
text: No Marriage License,

headline: This Sunday: Twitterify the Magazine
text: Like some people, I have misgivings about Twitter. Not a philosophical quarrel. It’s more that I’m just not very good at tweeting. Mostly, I do it to promote the magazine’s articles, but sometimes that feels too self-serving, and I impulsively tweet something that momentarily strikes me as witty and/or meaningful. That never goes well. A few weeks ago, I tweeted inanely about umbrellas. Why should anyone care? It haunts me still.

headline: Far From His Usual Haunts
text: Timothy Haskell, a designer of haunted houses, scares people for a living. This season he has created two: Nightmare: Z-Day, a zombie playhouse in the Bronx, running until Halloween, and Nightmare: Fairy Tales, on the Lower East Side, through Nov. 5. Mr. Haskell, 37, whose background is in Off Broadway theater, lives in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, with his wife, Rebeca Ramirez, who works at  Heart of Brooklyn, a partnership of cultural institutions,  and their son, Diego Haskell-Ramirez, 6.

headline: A Centrist Pioneer in Egypt Faces New Competition
text: CAIRO

headline: Going With Your Gut First, Then Your Heart
text: IN marriage and relationships, even on first dates, someone’s diet has become like their clothes or religion. It tells you something about how they feel about the planet, their bodies, their communities and their children.

headline: Part of Alabama Immigrant Law Blocked
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — A federal appeals court in Atlanta temporarily blocked two provisions of Alabama’s far-reaching immigration enforcement law on Friday, but left much of it in effect as the state and the United States Justice Department continued to fight over the law in the courts.

headline: Educational Exchanges
text: To the Editor:

headline: Regents Plan Push for Aid to Illegal Immigrants
text: When they vote on their legislative agenda on Tuesday, New York State’s top education officials will focus for the first time on the contentious topic of illegal immigration.

headline: When a Casual Classic Gets Dressed Up
text: On any given evening, Recette, at 12th and Greenwich Streets, is a classic little West Village spot, casual, crowded and chatty, with candlelight and dark wood tables. But on the second Monday of each month, the staff removes about half of those tables, drapes the others with white cloths and hosts a quieter, more elegant evening. Mondays With Jesse, as the series is called, includes a 10-course tasting menu, an amuse-bouche, a glass of sparkling wine, sweets and a baked item to take home from the chef, Jesse Schenker, and the pastry chef, Christina Lee. Last week, the crowd included two friends weighing restaurants and education.

headline: With Business Already Down, Dutrow Awaits Ruling on 10-Year Suspension
text: The day after being barred from racing in New York for 10 years, the trainer Richard Dutrow Jr. won the feature race at Belmont Park on Thursday with a filly named Tiz the Argument. He has three more horses entered at Belmont on Saturday, an afternoon that, if New York authorities get their way, will be his last as a horseman in good standing until 2021.

headline: Kathryn and Gregory
text: Kathryn and Gregory talk about their first encounter at a Lindy Hop dance.

headline: Gas Boom Aids Pennsylvania, but Some Worry Over the Risk
text: MONTROSE, Pa. — In the economic downturn three years ago, Adam Diaz idled the trucks at his bluestone quarry and silenced the saws at his lumber mill.

headline: Testing State Aid Recipients for Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Israel, Swap Touches Old Wounds
text: JERUSALEM — Arnold Roth had just returned from synagogue on Friday morning when the phone rang. It was Israel’s Justice Ministry, telling him that two of the people who murdered his 15-year-old daughter Malka at a Jerusalem pizzeria a decade ago would be freed next week as part of an exchange of 1,000 Palestinian prisoners for an Israeli soldier held by Hamas.

headline: Procter & Gamble Settles Trademark Dispute With Small Company
text: A Connecticut mother and businesswoman has won the right to name her company after her daughter, Willa, despite the objections of the nation’s largest consumer products company.

headline: A Top Quarterback Teased for Being 28
text: The age jokes have become, well, old. Brandon Weeden, the senior quarterback for the Oklahoma State Cowboys, certainly does not look or feel a day over 28, which is what he will be Saturday when he takes the field at Royal-Memorial Stadium to face the Texas Longhorns.

headline: Bloggingheads: Conservative Class War?
text: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Kristen Soltis of the Independent Women's Forum debate conservative reaction to Occupy Wall Street.

headline: Perry Promises Increased Drilling and Decreased Regulation
text: WEST MIFFLIN, Pa. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas released a long-promised jobs and energy proposal Friday that resembles a wish list for the oil and gas industry, promising new drilling across much of the country, including in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, as well as a curtailing of environmental regulations and “dismantling” the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: South Korea’s Leader Helps Obama Woo Michigan
text: LAKE ORION, Mich. — The chief question rippling through a General Motors plant here in this vital swing state on Friday, as President Obama and his new B.F.F., President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea, tootled around on their free trade victory tour, was this: How did Mr. Obama get Mr. Lee to don that Detroit Tigers hat?

headline: Korean Leader’s Grandson Attending School in Bosnia
text: The grandson of the North Korean leader Kim Jong Il has started attending classes at United World College, a private English-language high school in Mostar, Bosnia, the former head of the Hong Kong branch of the school has confirmed. Stephen Codrington, currently the head of the Awty International School in Houston, Tex., interviewed the boy in Macau. Kim Han Sol, 16, is the son of Kim Jong Il’s oldest son Kim Jong Nam. “I was very impressed by his idealism,” Mr. Codrington said in a phone interview from Singapore. “He’s an intelligent, insightful boy with a maturity beyond his years. He has a real yearning for changing the situation on the Korean peninsula, which he feels very deeply about.” Mr. Codrington said that the student passed the objective criteria for admission and received no special preference.

headline: Philippines: Dictator Is Denied Burial Honors
text: The body of the former Philippine dictator Ferdinand Marcos will remain for now in its refrigerated crypt in the northern Philippines, as it has for most of the two decades since he died in exile in Hawaii. President Benigno Aquino III — the son of former President Corazon Aquino, who ousted Mr. Marcos in a 1986 uprising — appeared to put an end to a public spat with Mr. Marcos’s son, who was demanding that the body be buried in the national cemetery in Manila along with other dignitaries. Speaking to reporters on Wednesday, Mr. Aquino said that a state funeral would be the “height of injustice” toward the victims of Mr. Marcos’s strongman rule. Ferdinand Marcos Jr., who is now a senator, said he was offended by the surprise announcement, which appeared to ignore the recommendation of a presidential commission to bury Mr. Marcos with honors. “All these talks, discussions and debates turned out to be just a stage play,” Mr. Marcos said. The president replied, “I think I will have to communicate this to the vice president, I apologize, he’s been doing the study on my behalf.”

headline: In Year 11 as a Tiger, Finding Life After Toledo
text: It would have been understandable if the veteran Tigers third baseman Brandon Inge had taken his gear and gone home for good in late July.

headline: Here’s the Herminator
text: You may have heard that Herman Cain, the former chief of Godfather’s Pizza, has become the latest in a list of peculiar front-runners for the Republican presidential nomination. Perhaps the Tea Party wing is just expressing its hostility toward Mitt Romney. Perhaps there’s just something peculiar about the Tea Party.

headline: Gaza Set to Embrace Released Prisoners
text: GAZA CITY — As soon as the minarets fell silent after the noon prayers, the noise of drills, hammers and saws rose from the center of Gaza City on Friday as workmen hurled planks and scaffolding poles into place in a huge stage that is being built to greet released prisoners.

headline: Friday Night Music
text: As a baby boomer accustomed to listening to great old stuff, who has finally gotten into active artists, I face a new source of anxiety: will the next, long-awaited album live up to expectations?

headline: Union Says Not Yet to Test for H.G.H.
text: Despite the urging of two Congressmen on Friday for the N.F.L. to begin testing for human growth hormone, the players union appeared steadfast in its position that it needs more scientific information before it will consent to such a program.

headline: Liberia: President May Face Runoff
text: Partial presidential election results announced Friday suggest that the incumbent, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, could be headed to a runoff next month. With votes counted from 2,242 out of 4,457 polling places, Mrs. Sirleaf had 45 percent of the vote, to 30 percent for the ticket led by Winston Tubman, which also includes the former international soccer star George Weah, according to the National Elections Commission. If these percentages hold up, Mrs. Sirleaf would have less than the majority needed to win outright. In third place with 12 percent and the potential to be kingmaker is the former warlord Prince Johnson.

headline: The Bleakness of the Bullied
text: I have watched with a heavy heart these last few years as one child after another has committed suicide because he or she was bullied.

headline: Romney Raises $14 Million in 3rd Quarter, Second to Perry’s Receipts
text: Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, raised just over $14 million for his presidential campaign during the three months that ended Sept. 30, according to campaign filings delivered to the Federal Election Commission on Friday.

headline: The Death Penalty’s De Facto Abolition
text: A new Gallup poll reports that support for the death penalty is at its lowest level since 1972. In fact, though, the decline, from a high of 80 percent in 1994 to 61 percent now, masks both Americans’ ambivalence about capital punishment and the country’s de facto abolition of the penalty in most places.

headline: In Private, Wall St. Bankers Dismiss Protesters as Unsophisticated
text: Publicly, bankers say they understand the anger at Wall Street — but believe they are misunderstood by the protesters camped on their doorstep.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: The nation’s ports suggest that the holiday shopping season may disappoint, the Wall Street protests continued and continued to provoke, Europe pressed harder to find a solution to the deepening debt crisis and the iPhone 4S went on sale.

headline: A Park, a Memorial, a Debate
text: AN October rain was pelting down on the overgrown and under-loved slice of the Village formally known as St. Vincent’s Triangle Park. At its apex, an ugly three-story brick building still shielded the gargantuan oxygen tanks that once pumped life into the bitterly missed St. Vincent’s Hospital, which succumbed to bankruptcy in 2010. From the squat structure’s double driveway and loading dock, patients who did not leave the hospital alive were removed to their final resting places.

headline: Brewers’ Hairston Haunts La Russa, His Father’s Favorite Manager
text: ST. LOUIS — It was a little gift from one family to another, a miniature pull-cart holding a flower arrangement. Tony La Russa and his wife, Elaine, sent it to Jerry Hairston and his wife, Esperanza, after the birth of their son Jerry Jr., in 1976, when La Russa and Hairston were teammates on Class AAA Iowa in the Chicago White Sox farm system.

headline: The 1930s Sure Sound Familiar
text: Not long ago, someone suggested that I read “Since Yesterday,” a book by Frederick Lewis Allen, a popular historian of the 1930s and 1940s. Published in 1940, it turned out to be a shrewd, concise, wonderfully written account of America in the ’30s.

headline: Selective Prosecution in Ukraine
text: The seven-year jail sentence imposed on Yulia Tymoshenko, the former prime minister of Ukraine, reeks of Soviet-style political revenge.

headline: Mets’ Owners Seek to Avoid Trial by Jury in Madoff Case
text: The owners of the Mets are seeking to avoid a jury trial in the case filed against them by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud. The owners could be forced to pay hundreds of millions of dollars in the case.

headline: The Merits of Safe and Sound
text: WHY mess with a good thing?

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: That Old Celery Fizz

headline: California: Arrests in Gang Crackdown
text: More than 100 people, almost all of them connected to Central California gangs, were arrested this week in the latest effort to curb street gangs, Attorney General Kamala Harris announced on Friday. The arrests resulted from an 18-month investigation by the California Department of Justice and other law enforcement agencies that began after a gang network set up operations in Gilroy. The operation also led to the seizure of 44 firearms, 81 stolen vehicles, 3 pounds of methamphetamine and other drugs. A majority of the 103 suspects arrested were gang members with felony convictions, the Department of Justice said. Suspects will face charges relating to auto theft, guns, gangs and the sale of narcotics.

headline: Lottery Numbers
6 Attacks Linked to Pattern in Brooklyn
text: The police said Friday that they had added six attacks in subway stations to a pattern of sexual assaults that have badly shaken several neighborhoods in South Brooklyn, bringing the total number of cases in that area up to 20 since March.

headline: China: Social Media Rules Weighed
text: With the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party scheduled to begin meeting Saturday, Wang Chen, a senior propaganda official, said that social media need to be more tightly regulated. The government seems likely to follow through on many hints that it would step up regulation of various Twitter-like microblogs like Weibo, said Bill Bishop, an independent analyst specializing in social media.

headline: G.O.P. vs. the Environment
text: As of Friday, the Republican-controlled House of Representatives had voted 168 times this year to undercut clean air and water laws while blocking efforts to limit global warming, protect public lands and guard against future oil spills. Henry Waxman, the senior Democrat on the Energy and Commerce Committee, calls this “the most anti-environmental Congress in history.”

headline: Britain’s Self-Inflicted Misery
text: For a year now, Britain’s economy has been stuck in a vicious cycle of low growth, high unemployment and fiscal austerity. But unlike Greece, which has been forced into induced recession by misguided European Union creditors, Britain has inflicted this harmful quack cure on itself.

headline: Baby Boy Dies; Was Given Pills as a Toy
text: A 13-month-old boy died after he apparently swallowed pills from a bottle of prescription drugs that his parents had given him to play with as a rattle, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Saturday: Rodin’s Thinker
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — So by now we all know that Joon Pahk ripped through Jeopardy!, won an ungodly amount of (pre-tax) money, qualified for the Tournament of Champions, and generally made us all proud, yes? Good, because today he’s back as a constructor with a tough but ultimately fair and fun puzzle that contains quite a few interesting consecutive-consonant and unique entries. Notice that I didn’t say crunchy. You’re welcome.

headline: The Tigers Phone It In
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Friday was the first time the Detroit Tigers didn’t bother to show up for the A.L.C.S.

headline: Corrections: October 15
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: For the Jets, Kickoffs and Returns, at Least, Have Not Been a Problem
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Nick Folk, the Jets’ kicker, says there is not much of an art to booting a football off a tee for a living.

headline: Allegations of Iranian and U.S. Plots Are Added to a History of Hostility
text: WASHINGTON — When an Iranian scientist was shot and killed in front of his home in Tehran on July 23, he was the third researcher with supposed ties to Iran’s nuclear program to be assassinated in less than two years.

headline: Battle for Libya | October 14, 2011
text: Fighters in Surt pounded loyalists holed up in two neighborhoods with rocket and machine-gun fire Friday, but also suffered heavy casualties themselves. Wounded men streamed into frontline medical units and then were evacuated to field hospitals on the city’s outskirts.

headline: Memorial Service for Steve Jobs at Stanford
text: Apple is planning to hold a memorial for its former chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, on Sunday on Stanford University’s campus.

headline: For Perry, Lobbyist Is a Take-No-Prisoners Ally
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Behind every politician there are men and women working in the wings, operatives who can make calls, fix problems, raise money, punish enemies.

headline: One Day, Maybe, Artisanal Train Cars
text: Among the 275 tenants filling four million square feet of leasable space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard — now in the midst of its biggest expansion since World War II — are any number of industries that do not easily evoke the imagery of “On the Waterfront.” These are businesses where fine art is warehoused, where antiques are restored, where jewelry and leather garments are made — where the prosperous life, so much and so misleadingly in evidence in modern New York, receives its methodical upkeep.

headline: Big East Planning to Add Six to Make 12
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The Big East’s expansion plans have solidified with a model for what the conference hopes its new 12-team football league will look like.

headline: Wild Days Behind Him, Envoy Keeps Low Profile
text: WASHINGTON — For years, Adel al-Jubeir was the playboy Saudi envoy and man about town, hosting parties on the diplomatic circuit, hobnobbing with this city’s political elite and appearing at events with media celebrities like Campbell Brown, then the White House correspondent for NBC News.

headline: Aggressive Bills Leave No Room for Errant Passes
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It seemed as if Eli Manning had figured it out. The questions he faced after throwing a career- and league-high 25 interceptions last season seemed a distant memory. Through four games, he had thrown just two interceptions and the Giants had won three in a row.

headline: Photos From China Offer Scant Clues to a Succession
text: BEIJING — It seems a mundane enough photograph: on July 14, the front page of People’s Daily, the Communist Party’s official newspaper, showed President Hu Jintao shaking hands with military scholars. Mr. Hu’s heir apparent, Vice President Xi Jinping, was close behind.

headline: N.B.A. Players Union Fights Off Impression That It Isn’t United
text: LOS ANGELES — N.B.A players on Friday rejected Commissioner David Stern’s threat to cancel games through Christmas if there was no breakthrough in Tuesday’s scheduled meeting with a federal mediator.

headline: A Tour of Asia and an Eye for Detail
text: THE narrow entrance to Lucky Buddha in Thornwood belies this restaurant’s beautifully apportioned vastness. Inside the entry a monumental Buddha perches on a seat of river stones, a pond with swimming koi below, his presence only the beginning of an array of appealing Asian touches.

headline: U.N. Official Urges World to Stand Up for Syrians
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A top United Nations official urged the international community on Friday to protect Syrian civilians from a brutal military crackdown by the government of President Bashar al-Assad, as activists said that at least 11 people were shot dead in demonstrations nationwide.

headline: Racial Disparities in Infant Mortality
text: Chart shows infant mortality rate, cause of death and characteristics of mother.

headline: Egypt’s Military Expands Power, Raising Alarms
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers are moving to assert and extend their own power so broadly that a growing number of lawyers and activists are questioning their willingness to ultimately submit to civilian authority.

headline: Taking a Tour of the Mediterranean
text: WHILE there are French dishes available at Café d’Azur in Darien, the menu at this small restaurant is more aptly defined by the description on its window: “Mediterranean Bistro and Bar.”

headline: Germans Condemn Police Use of Spyware
text: BERLIN — A group that calls itself the Chaos Computer Club prompted a public outcry here recently when it discovered that German state investigators were using spying software capable of turning a computer’s webcam and microphone into a sophisticated surveillance device.

headline: Tackling Infant Mortality Rates Among Blacks
text: PITTSBURGH — Amanda Ralph is the kind of woman whose babies are prone to die. She is young and poor and dropped out of school after the ninth grade.

headline: U.S. Sending More Contractors to Secure Libya’s Weapons Stockpile
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department is sending dozens of American contractors to Libya to help that country’s fledgling efforts to track down and destroy heat-seeking antiaircraft missiles looted from government stockpiles that could be used against civilian airliners.

headline: New Varieties Leave Red Delicious Behind
text: GILLETTE, N.J.

headline: Jets Guard Says Internal Critics Hurt Team Unity
text: Jets guard Brandon Moore responded Friday to Santonio Holmes’s critical comments Thursday about the offensive line, telling ESPNNewYork.com that such talk “fragments the locker room.”

headline: High Output and Low Prices
text: The large production capacity of Pindar Vineyards in Peconic exploits economies of scale that translate into low prices for consumers. That’s alluring these days.

headline: A Taste of New Orleans, With a Side of Barbecue
text: Mara’s Homemade looks like a typical Long Island storefront: a long, narrow space with tile floor, bare wood tables and paper napkins. Its décor and food, though, evoke New Orleans, turning an ordinary-looking place into a destination restaurant.

headline: The World This Week, Part 1
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: The World This Week, Part 2
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Cardinals Don’t Waste Off Night by Brewers
text: ST. LOUIS — The crowd at Busch Stadium gasped when Jerry Hairston Jr., the Milwaukee Brewers’ third baseman, swooped to his side to snatch a sizzling line drive. They groaned when Yuniesky Betancourt, the Brewers’ shortstop, dashed onto the outfield grass, his back to home plate, to corral a fluttering fly ball.

headline: A Glimpse Into a Maestro’s Salon, After Hours
text: LEONARD BERNSTEIN, a man of peace with an innate theatricality, knew the value of playing against type; when the mood struck, he would jokingly threaten to clear the wee-hour revelers from his living room by digging into Aaron Copland’s gnarly Piano Variations. So said his daughter, Jamie Bernstein, as she narrated “Late Night With Leonard Bernstein,” a look at the after-hours maestro, which opened the 2011-12 season in the Copland House concert series last month.

headline: A Final Curtain, but More Opening Ones Are Ahead
text: East Farmingdale, N.Y.

headline: Both Sides Say They Don’t Feel the Pressure
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Pressure was a popular topic in the Rangers’ clubhouse Friday. Predictably, nobody would admit to feeling any for Game 6.

headline: Fats Waller, Reimagined
text: If one musical number captures the spirit of “Ain’t Misbehavin’ ” (even more than the title song), it’s probably the 1938 toe-tapper “The Joint Is Jumpin.’ ” But in the Crossroads Theater Company’s spirited new production, it’s the out-of-character numbers that are most memorable.

headline: Following Uncertainty and Finding Music
text: UNCERTAINTY is getting a particularly bad rap these days, not least from politicians and pundits who blame it for the reluctance of businesses to hire and consumers to spend. But to Carl Testa, a musician for whom the act of making art is not divorced from the conditions in which it is made, the rise of uncertainty is a precursor to social transformation.

headline: In New England, Taking on German Expressionism
text: YOU could say that Adam Van Doren was born with a silver-edged book in his hands. A third-generation member of the famous Van Doren clan of New York and Cornwall, Conn., he grew up among writers, poets, critics and academics. His grandfather, Mark, and great-uncle, Carl, were both Pulitzer Prize-winning professors at Columbia University; his uncle, Charles, also taught at Columbia until his involvement in the TV quiz show scandal of 1959 brought his career to an abrupt end.

headline: Be Careful Just Whom You Decide to Interrupt
text: “I’m sorry to interrupt, but could you guys please finish up?” a woman asked Nocturnalist’s correspondent at Town Hall theater on 43rd Street on Thursday night as he conducted an interview. He was sitting in her seat, she said.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct.14
text: The day in sports included gymnastics in Mexico and volleyball in Qatar.

headline: Iran: Did Plot Dialogue Take Place?
text: American officials said Thursday that they had conveyed their concerns to the Iranian government over the alleged plot to assassinate Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to the United States. But on Friday, Iran’s official Islamic Republic News Agency insisted that American officials had not been in direct contact with Iran. Payton Knopf, a spokesman for the United States Mission to the United Nations, said, though, that “there has been direct contact with the U.S. government.” He declined to elaborate.

headline: Cheating in New York City Schools: 14 Cases
text: A collection of reports by the special commissioner of investigation for the New York City school system.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Regents to Vote on Change to Cut Risk of Teachers’ Test-Tampering
text: The New York State Board of Regents will decide Monday whether to bar teachers from grading their own students’ standardized tests, a longstanding practice that state officials say creates a temptation for educators to cheat in an era of high-stakes exams.

headline: Vic Miles, Reporter and Anchor on WCBS-TV, Dies at 79
text: Vic Miles, who brought a no-nonsense, get-to-the-essence style to his 24 years as a reporter and anchorman for WCBS-TV/Channel 2 in New York, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 79.

headline: Ray Aghayan, Costume Designer, Dies at 83
text: Ray Aghayan designed his first dress, at 13, for a member of the royal court of the shah of Iran, which at the time employed his mother as a couturier, a sort of in-house designer for the personal and ceremonial needs of the Reza Pahlavi family.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: India’s longest railway tunnel, through the Pir Panchal mountain range, was opened on Friday. The seven-mile long tunnel, which will “connect Kashmir with the outside world,” will be operational by 2012, Northern Railway officials said. (Greater Kashmir)Manipur: A 2-month-old blockade on arterial highways connecting Manipur is wreaking havoc in the state, the Manipur People’s Party said, causing skyrocketing prices for food, fuel and other basic amenities. (Nagaland Post) However, the chief minister of Manipur, Okram Ibobi, rubbished these reports, saying “you people sit there and report, come to Manipur tomorrow and see it is not true.” (Telegraph)

headline: A Texas Town
text: In Irving, Tex., a town transformed by immigrants, a crackdown on illegal immigration is creating discord among residents.

headline: Hamilton Takes First Step Toward Silencing Critics – and Dethrones Red Bull
text: YEONGAM, South Korea – Lewis Hamilton scored pole position for the Korean Grand Prix during an exciting qualifying session on Saturday. He broke up the streaks of Red Bull team drivers Sebastian Vettel and Mark Webber, who had secured all 15 pole positions this year.

headline: Hamilton Takes First Step Toward Silencing Critics – and Dethrones Red Bull
text: YEONGAM, South Korea – Lewis Hamilton scored pole position for the Korean Grand Prix during an exciting qualifying session on Saturday. He broke up the streaks of Red Bull team drivers Sebastian Vettel and Mark Webber, who had secured all 15 pole positions this year.

headline: Buoyed by Wall St. Protests, Rallies Sweep the Globe
text: Buoyed by the longevity of the Occupy Wall Street encampment in Manhattan, a wave of protests swept across Asia, the Americas and Europe over the weekend, with hundreds and in some cases thousands of people expressing discontent with the economic tides in marches, rallies and occasional clashes with the police.

headline: Santorum Spends More Than He Raises
text: Former Senator Rick Santorum released campaign finance figures late Friday that illuminated his precarious cash situation. His campaign spent more money than the candidate raised.

headline: Tips for Using Wi-Fi Securely
text: When you use a Wi-Fi connection to access the Internet, the data you transmit flies through the air. This allows us to remain blissfully connected while wandering through the house with a laptop, in a hotel with a tablet or in a departure lounge with a smartphone, but it also comes with privacy and security risks.

headline: Strikes Hit Yemen as Violence Escalates in Capital
text: ADEN, Yemen — Airstrikes, believed to have been carried out by American drones, killed at least nine people in southern Yemen on Friday, including a senior official of the regional branch of Al Qaeda and an American, the 17-year-old son of a Qaeda official killed by the United States last month, according to the government and local reports on Saturday.

headline: Ring of Honor Inductees Set Example Beyond the Jets
text: Side by side, they are pillars not only of Jets history, but also of pro football history.

headline: A Serious Man, a Serious Fan on His Own Viking Quest
text: I’m a Minnesota Vikings fan. This fact will invariably come up in conversation within a half-hour of our meeting. My life story usually unfolds in this order: I’m a New Yorker, I don’t own an iPhone — by choice — and my lifelong allegiance to a snakebitten N.F.L. franchise that plays its home games 1,020 miles away from my Greenwich Village apartment imbued in me an existential crisis long before I could correctly spell either word.

headline: No Glory in Blocking for Backs, but Much to Gain
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Eli Manning threw the game-winning touchdown pass to Plaxico Burress with 35 seconds left in Super Bowl XLII, the most important person involved in the play was neither Manning nor Burress.

headline: Cain Unable
text: An irate correspondent is furious with me for dismissing Herman Cain’s ideas. Cain’s program, he angrily asserts, has been endorsed by none other than Arthur Laffer, a “much smarter economist than you.” Indeed, Laffer capped his brilliant career two years ago by warning, presciently, that interest rates would soar thanks to the Obama plan.

headline: In Some N.F.L. Cities, Cheering for Failure
text: Last weekend was a good one for Chris Joseph. The Miami Dolphins, the team he has rooted for since he was a child and about whom he runs a blog called Fins Nation, had a bye. Joseph was freed. Not from despair that the Dolphins might lose. But from the fear that they might win and ruin everything.

Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers.

headline: Perry Outraises Republican Field in Short Quarter
text: Building off an aggressive early sprint for cash, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas outmatched the rest of the Republican field during the fund-raising quarter that ended Sept. 30, attracting thousands of donors in Texas and beyond who gave the maximum $2,500 contribution for the primary campaign, according to documents filed with the Federal Election Commission on Saturday.

headline: Mexico’s President Works to Lock In Drug War Tactics
text: This article is by  Randal C. Archibold,  Damien Cave and  Elisabeth Malkin.

headline: Online Banking Keeps Customers on Hook for Fees
text: Customers frustrated by banks’ controversial new fees are finding out what industry insiders have known for years: it is not so easy to disentangle your life from your bank.

headline: NATO Assessment Emphasizes Setbacks for Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite a sharp increase in assassinations and a continuing flood of civilian casualties, NATO officials said Saturday that they had reversed the momentum of the Taliban insurgency as enemy attacks were falling for the first time in years.

headline: Romney Finds It’s Not Free to Move About the Country
text: Earlier this year, Mitt Romney made a point of letting voters know — via Twitter — that he is a Southwest man, a fan of the airline known for its budget fares and primary-colored planes. What he did not Tweet about, however, were the flights he took on private jets.

headline: Romney Beating Obama in a Fight for Wall St. Cash
text: It is no secret that the relationship between President Obama and Wall Street has chilled. A striking measure of that is the latest campaign finance reports.

headline: New Tool for Mountain Climbers: A Stopwatch
text: MOUNT RAINIER NATIONAL PARK, Wash. — A popular route here that includes an ascent of 9,000 feet of rock and ice takes days for most mountain climbers. One man needed only five hours. The face of the 13,000-foot Eiger, in the Swiss Alps, has long presented climbers with one of the most daunting challenges in the world. One man recently conquered it in less than three hours.

headline: European Officials Struggle Toward a Debt Solution
text: PARIS — European finance ministers said on Saturday that they had moved closer to a comprehensive solution for the debt crisis during a two-day gathering of officials  from the Group of 20 industrial nations, despite a number of unresolved problems that could still widen the scope of the crisis.

headline: Brewers Shift to Contain Pujols; Now What?
