headline: Late, Sudden, Unsurprising, the Emergence of Nelson Cruz

headline: Keeping Score: Collapse of Red Sox Offers Stark Lesson in Team Chemistry

headline: Growing Pains as Russia Tries to Revive Elite Hockey

headline: A Little Extra for Extra Points?
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: With Maya Moore
text: Maya Moore just wins. And wins. And wins. A four-time all-American at Connecticut, she won two national basketball championships and advanced to two other Final Fours, and the Huskies posted an N.C.A.A.-record 89 consecutive victories. Moore continued where she left off at the next level. Drafted first over all by the Minnesota Lynx in April, she finished third on the team in scoring at 13.2 points a game. She was the league’s rookie of the year and helped lead the Lynx, with the fellow All-Stars Seimone Augustus and Lindsay Whalen, to the franchise’s first championship.

headline: Excerpts From an Interview With President Felipe Calderón

headline: A Genius of the Storefront, Too
text: WHEN the architect Peter Bohlin arrived for his first meeting with Steve Jobs, he wore a tie. “Steve laughed, and I never wore a tie again,” Mr. Bohlin recalled.

headline: A Bit More About Cain
text: A brief note while waiting for a family member to finish with the doctor: From comments I see that some readers believe that Cain’s second “9” is a profits tax, which I’ve argued in the past probably falls on capital owners. But it isn’t: it’s a tax on all business income, defined as sales minus purchased inputs and dividends — but with no deduction for wages. So the new element here is, in effect, a 9 percent tax on wages paid.

headline: Questions About Ad Dogged Perry in 1990 Race
text: Critics largely gave Gov. Rick Perry a pass for hunting on a deer lease that once carried a racist name. Even the White House accepted Mr. Perry’s explanation that his family found the word abhorrent and had painted over it at the first opportunity.

headline: Obama Bundler List Includes New Names, Famous Faces
text: At the close of each fund-raising quarter, aides to President Obama often emphasize the amount of money he raises from his large network of grassroots supporters, the base of his Obama for America organization and a reliable source of small donations throughout the election cycle.

headline: Russia’s Hockey Revival
text: The fourth season of the K.H.L. is still in its infancy, but time spent with Dynamo Moscow over the last few weeks has offered a vivid snapshot of the K.H.L. and the broader challenges for the league.

headline: Fannie and Freddie, Still the Socialites
text: THE mortgage business is moribund. New loans are down. New foreclosures are up.

headline: Making the Most of Our Financial Winter
text: ON a traditional farm, when winter comes and there’s no need for planting, fertilizing or harvesting, it’s time for infrastructure projects. Farmers fix their barns, build fences or dig wells — important tasks that could be done in any season if there weren’t more pressing jobs to do.

headline: Pink, an Uncommon Color at a Football Game
text: The Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation teamed up with the Dallas Cowboys to raise awareness about breast cancer during a football game on Oct. 2.

headline: Social Media Gives Wall Street Protests a Global Reach
text: The online conversation about the Occupy Wall Street movement turned global over the weekend as protesters provided live Twitter updates, photos and videos from the dozens of demonstrations around the world.

headline: Welcome, Fans, to the Pinking of America

headline: Medvedev Says Leader Plan Was Studied
text: MOSCOW — President Dmitri A. Medvedev struck a defensive note in a speech on Saturday about the system for choosing Russia’s leaders, insisting that he and Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin had not decided to switch places during a fishing trip, as some commentators have suggested.

headline: Liberians Count Votes and Fraud Allegations
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Signaling potential trouble in a country with a history of political violence, nine opposition parties in Liberia on Saturday expressed dissatisfaction with a presidential election held last week, threatening to disavow the result when it is announced.

headline: Those Scan Results Are Just an App Away
text: EVEN in the vast world of apps, Dr. Patrick J. Gagnon has one with an unusual distinction: it had to be cleared for use by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Lessons From New Orleans
text: Before Hurricane Katrina, more than 60 percent of children in New Orleans attended a failing school. Now, only about 18 percent do.

headline: Gingrich Raises Under $1 Million; Campaign in the Red
text: Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker who endured mass departure of his top aides in June and has struggled to keep his campaign afloat, reported raising just $808,000 dollars during the three-month period ending Sept. 30, according to papers filed with the Federal Election Commission on Saturday.

headline: Uneasy With Labels (or Attention)
text: NOBEL prizes may be the ultimate attention-grabbers. When Theodore Roosevelt became the first American to win one, in 1906, he already had a bully pulpit — the White House — and he thumped it gleefully.

headline: How Did This Become a Commitment?
text: EVER get the sense that the junk mail you throw out every day includes an item or two that you really ought to read? Ever wonder if  some ought-to-read letters have been designed to look junky on purpose?

headline: It’s Not Just the Currency
text: The Senate’s vote on Tuesday to punish China for cheapening its currency is not likely to persuade Beijing to change its ways. On Thursday, the renminbi actually fell more against the dollar. If the currency bill were to become law — a long shot given opposition by Republican leaders in the House — the more likely response from China would be some form of trade policy retaliation.

headline: Woman Is Questioned in Killing of Son, 18, on Upper West Side
text: When the police came to Apartment 11G at 74 West 92nd Street on Friday night, they were met at the door by a woman holding a bloody sponge. On the floor behind her was the body of her 18-year-old son, dead from a stab wound to his thigh, the police said Saturday.

headline: We Thought They Wanted to Be Like Buffett
text: When Warren Buffett pointed out that the American tax system was so egregiously rigged that he paid a smaller share of his income in taxes than his secretary, very few of his peers chimed in. It was so quiet that one might have thought Mr. Buffett’s case was a fluke. It wasn’t.

headline: Bachmann Goes After Perry on Immigration and Pledges Border Fence
text: PERRY, Iowa — Representative Michele Bachmann gave one of the great stem-winding speeches of her campaign Saturday about the burdens illegal immigration places on American taxpayers, and she signed a pledge to build a “secure double fence” along every foot of the border with Mexico.

headline: Ohio Wages Fierce Fight on Collective Bargaining

headline: Michel Peissel, Tibet Expert and Adventurer, Dies at 74

headline: Bachmann Raised Almost $4 Million in Third Quarter
text: Michele Bachmann raised almost $4 million in the third quarter but spent nearly $6 million, leaving her campaign for the presidency with about $1.3 million as she heads into the final few months before voting begins.

headline: Nice Guy Finishing Last
text: PEPPERONI and flatulence. That’s what Jon Huntsman was reduced to. Groveling for attention at the Republican debate last week, he fired off one joke, a tasty one, about 9-9-9 sounding more like the price of a pizza than the contours of a tax plan. He fired off another joke, less savory, about Washington as a font of natural gas. He meant bloated and meaningless rhetoric — at least I think he did — but still. Some metaphors just aren’t worth it.

headline: “Occupy Wall Street” and Inequality
text: My Sunday column hopes and prays that the Occupy Wall Street movement will help put the issue of economic inequality on the national agenda for the 2012 election. It seems to me to be one of the background challenges our economy faces, and it’s an issue of fairness, yet it has received very little attention until recently.

headline: Laura Pollán Toledo, Who Rallied Wives of Jailed Cuban Dissidents, Dies at 63
text: MEXICO CITY — Laura Pollán Toledo, a former high school Spanish teacher who became one of Cuba’s most public dissidents as she led other wives of political prisoners in protest every Sunday, died in a Havana hospital on Friday, her family and other dissidents said. She was 63.

headline: Democracy’s Collateral Damage
text: THE Coptic Orthodox Church in Egypt is one of the oldest Christian communities in the world, tracing its roots to St. Mark the apostle and the first century A.D. Coptic Christians have survived persecutions and conquests, the fall of Rome and the rise of Islam. They have been governed from Constantinople and Ctesiphon, Baghdad and London. They have outlasted the Byzantines, the Umayyads and the Ottomans, Napoleon Bonaparte and the British Empire.

headline: To Isolate Iran, U.S. Presses Inspectors on Nuclear Data

headline: Texas in Middle of Everything but the Title Race
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — It has been a season rich in bizarre anomalies in college football. Consider that Missouri, with its long history of athletic irrelevance, has emerged as the key figure in conference realignment. Then there’s Boise State, which could be a member of the Big East by the end of this week. And don’t forget once-mighty Texas, less than two years removed from an appearance in the national title game, proving once again that its sputtering football program can’t back up its boardroom leverage, branding power and market reach.

headline: B&B’s That Break the Dolls-and-Doilies Mold
text: The phrase bed and breakfast often conjures images of stuffy homes filled with dusty doilies and collections of wide-eyed dolls. But the B&B industry and its standards have evolved. Say goodbye to the days of squeaky beds and frivolous throw pillows and embrace the shift toward classically elegant and strikingly modern retreats. Whether you prefer attentive or hands-off service, accommodations steeped in history or an urban atmosphere, there is a (feather-topped or custom-built) bed and a (candlelit or grab-and-go) breakfast that fits your needs.

headline: U.S. Cuts Back the Proposed Size of Its Force in Iraq

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Tehelka writes about the tussle between the government and India’s news media, particularly its cable news channels. Ashok Malik writes that the government  now “fears the media more than it does the opposition.” The government’s efforts to rein in the media have faltered, even as news outlets have become more shrill and unethical, he says. Vinod Mehta, the editor of Outlook magazine, tells Mr. Malik: “Transgressions of the media, in style and in content, are growing. The atmosphere of polemics and name calling is distorting national debate.”

headline: Vettel Takes 10th Victory, Red Bull Takes Title, but Hamilton Provides the Story
text: YEONGAM, South Korea — Sebastian Vettel may have won the Korean Grand Prix on Sunday in his usual dominating manner, taking his 10th victory of the season and the 20th of his career. headline: ‘Footloose’ a Wallflower; ‘Real Steel’ Still Dancing
text: Hollywood’s box-office blues continued over the weekend as remakes of “Footloose” and “The Thing” fizzled. “Real Steel” (DreamWorks Studios) repeated as No. 1 by a sliver, taking in about $16.3 million for a two-week total of $51.7 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. “Footloose” stumbled in second place, selling an estimated $16.1 million in tickets, a frail result given the months-long marketing push that Paramount Pictures lavished on the film. The good news: “Footloose,” built around a cast of unknowns, cost only about $24 million to make. “The Thing” (Universal Pictures) was third with $8.7 million in ticket sales — not exactly a bloodbath given its production cost of about $38 million but a disappointment nonetheless. George Clooney’s “Ides of March” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth, taking in about $7.5 million for a two-week total of $22.2 million. “Dolphin Tale” (Warner Brothers) rounded out the top five with $6.3 million in ticket sales, lifting its four-week tally to $58.7 million. For the weekend, North American theaters recorded $89 million in ticket sales, a 32 percent drop from the same weekend last year.

headline: As Yemeni Revolt Escalates, Pro-Government Forces Fire on Protesters for a Second Day
text: SANA, Yemen — For the second day in a row, demonstrators in the capital escalated their protest by marching into government-held territory on Sunday, and for the second day in a row they were fired on by pro-government forces. At least five people were killed.

headline: Sunday OWS Notes
text: A couple of scattered notes on what’s going on.

headline: Zimbabwe: 3 Women Charged With Sexual Attacks on 17 Men
text: The police in Zimbabwe on Friday charged three women in connection with a spate of sexual attacks on male hitchhikers over the past two years, CNN reports.

headline: Climate Change Is Shrinking Species, Research Suggests
text: Climate change’s laundry list of impacts — melting glaciers and rising sea levels, shifts in timing for bird migration and flower budding, a poleward shift of species — just got a new addition: shrinking species.

text: Our weekly review of the performances of the three local N.H.L. teams.

headline: A Print Shop Cranks Back Up, Ancient as Ever

headline: Drawing Inspiration From Rilke
text: The conductorless Orpheus Chamber Orchestra has long demonstrated its mettle in Baroque and classical fare. More recently it has ventured into romantic and contemporary terrain, which is invariably harder to navigate without a conductor.

headline: Israel Releases Names of 477 Prisoners to Be Freed in Trade
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Israel on Sunday released the names of the first 477 Palestinian prisoners that it will exchange for a soldier held by the militant faction Hamas, and the list revealed why the country has found the trade so wrenching: a majority of the inmates were convicted of manslaughter, attempted murder or intentionally causing death.

headline: Dissecting Freedom on a Grand Scale
text: There are many moments in “Visible” when what seems casual is likely to be painstakingly drawn, when multiple layers of sound, text and movement create a kind of symphony. The production still seems half-baked, yet when it coheres, it’s like good jazz: without being literal it finds its way back to its theme.

headline: A Conductor’s Homecoming
text: Polished but perfunctory music making and unadventurous programming were often the hallmarks of Lorin Maazel’s tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic. An amiable matinee concert on Friday at Avery Fisher Hall, the first time Mr. Maazel has conducted the Philharmonic since his departure in 2009, continued that tradition.

headline: In Italy, Rioting Leads to Recriminations
text: ROME — As the smoke cleared Sunday, a day after a peaceful, inchoate demonstration near the Colosseum turned into a riot, Italy fell into national soul-searching and finger-pointing.

headline: The Century’s Sounds, So Far
text: A festival of 20th-century music is just so yesterday.

headline: Hollande Wins Runoff to Become Socialist Candidate for French Presidency
text: PARIS — More than six months before the French presidential election, the main candidates appear to be set, with François Hollande, 57, winning a runoff election on Sunday to become the Socialist Party’s presidential candidate.

headline: Postal Union Turns to Wall Street for Advice on Its Future
text: Can Ron Bloom, the restructuring expert who helped shore up the automobile and steel industries in the United States, save the ailing United States Postal Service?

headline: When Applying the Paint Was Spreading the News
text: Early on the morning of July 27, 1861, New York’s 69th (Irish) Regiment returned from the First Battle of Bull Run, landing by steamboat at what is now Battery Park.

headline: Exeunt
text: The Royal Shakespeare Company has announced that Michael Boyd will step down as artistic director next year, after more than a decade in the job, the BBC News reported. The executive director, Vikki Heywood, will leave her post at the same time. Under their supervision, the company recently completed a $177 million renovation of its theaters in Stratford-Upon-Avon, England, and a successful six-week run of performances in New York at the Park Avenue Armory. Mr. Boyd is also a chief architect of the World Shakespeare Festival, a celebration set to run from April to September 2012. Mr. Boyd said in a statement that it was “time for me to pass the challenges on to a new artistic director.” The company is expected to announce a successor early next year.

headline: Following Coaches’ Orders, Giants Produce Closing Kick Against Bills
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Near the end of every Giants practice, as the players’ shoulders are drooping and their legs are dragging, a familiar refrain can be heard from the coaching staff.

headline: Monsters v. Kittens
text: Stan Lee, a co-creator of childhood mainstays like Spider-Man, the X-Men and the Fantastic Four, will join with 1821 Comics to start a multimedia imprint for children called “Stan Lee’s Kids Universe.” The imprint, announced at the New York Comic Con on Friday and reported on galleycat.com, is to feature five books, including “Monsters vs. Kittens,” created by Dani Jones, and “Reggie the Veggie Crocodile.” Also among their plans is a video game for iPhone and iPad. At a Comic Con panel presentation, Mr. Lee said, “Our main purpose is we feel that there aren’t enough comic books or books for kids that really hit the target, that gives them excitement and humor together and are filled with surprises. We have a whole new group of new characters that the kids can call their own, just as the teenagers called Spider-Man their own so many years ago.” Mr. Lee is also collaborating with the 1821 Comics co-founder Terry Douglas, the writer Max Work and the artist Skan Srisuwan on a graphic novel, “Romeo & Juliet: The War,” a futuristic interpretation of the play — but with superpowers. The book is to be released in November.

headline: Was Schwartz Justified in Being Upset With Harbaugh?
text: Lions Coach Jim Schwartz chased after Niners Coach Jim Harbaugh and bumped him after what he apparently felt was an overexuberant celebration by Harbaugh following the 49ers’ 25-19 victory on Sunday.

headline: Kenyan Forces Enter Somalia to Battle Militants
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Kenyan military stormed into Somalia on Sunday, sending hundreds of troops to battle the Shabab militant group and becoming the latest East African country to be dragged into Somalia’s intractable anarchy.

headline: A Surprising Twist in a Career That Has Been Full of Them
text: Kenny Anderson is one of the most intriguing athletes I have covered. He didn’t score the most points or transform the game, but his career from 13 to 35 illustrates the dark and light spots of an industry built on the backs of children.

headline: One Big Happy Family (and Prisoner)
text: In the horror movie “The Woman” Chris Cleek is a prosperous country lawyer with oil industry contacts and a secretary he flirts with. He runs his handsome home with almost military efficiency, having trained his family — Brian, in middle school, a chip off the old block; Peggy, a wary, withdrawn teenager; Darlin’, his charming post-toddler daughter; and Belle, his docile wife — to heed his authority. He enjoys his camouflage gear, scoped rifle and solo hunting expeditions. So when he finds the fierce, feral Woman subsisting in the woods, why shouldn’t he capture her in a net, suspend her in manacles from the roof of a ground cellar and enlist his family in her “rehabilitation”?

headline: Gross Miscalculation
text: Somehow I missed this: Joe Weisenthal informs us that Bill Gross has publicly apologized for getting the bond market so wrong, predicting a spike in interest rates when QE2 ended. As Weisenthal points out, however, Gross’s exaggerated fear of deficits was very widespread; it was, indeed, what all the Very Serious People were obsessing about, even as the real economy was falling apart.

headline: Wheldon, Indy 500 Winner, Dies After Crash
text: Dan Wheldon, a popular and congenial racecar driver from England who won the Indianapolis 500 for the second time in May, died Sunday in a fiery 15-car accident early in a 300-mile IndyCar Series race at Las Vegas Motor Speedway.

headline: A Grand Opening for the Martin Luther King Jr. Monument
text: An expansive three-hour ceremony opened the memorial to Martin Luther King Jr. in Washington on Sunday, with speeches by President Obama and civil rights leaders like Representative John Lewis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and songs by performers like Aretha Franklin, my colleagues Helene Cooper and Sabrina Tavernise reported:

headline: Monday: Welcome to Day One of the Crossword Puzzle Contest
text: Administrivial Contest Rules Alert! All the puzzles this week, from Monday to Saturday, have been created by one person, Patrick Berry. Have your solutions handy, because the Saturday puzzle conceals a meta-challenge involving the solution grids of all six. When you have the answer to the meta-challenge, e-mail it to: crossword@nytimes.com. Please do not post your answers here on the blog and please do not mail them to me! Only answers e-mailed to the above address will be considered. Twenty-five correct solvers, chosen at random, whose entries are received by 6 p.m. Eastern time Sunday, Oct. 23, will receive copies of “Will Shortz Picks His Favorite Puzzles: 101 of the Top Crosswords From The New York Times.” Only one entry per person, please. The answer and winners’ names will appear on Friday, Oct. 28, at nytimes.com/wordplay.

headline: An Innocent Who’s Adrift in Mumbai
text: Life, according to a song in the Bollywood comedy “My Friend Pinto,” is cute, and has many moods: sometimes it’s misty, sometimes it’s crispy (or so goes the translation). “My Friend Pinto” also has many moods, too many really. It’s cute, sort of, as well as crudely slapstick and sweetly picaresque, and just a bit misty and crispy.

headline: From Britain, It’s Legoland
text: WINTER HAVEN, Fla. — The Merlin Entertainments Group is one of the world’s largest operators of amusement parks and tourist attractions, entertaining more than 40 million visitors annually. But the company operates almost entirely overseas, and it has no presence in central Florida, the sweaty epicenter of the theme park universe.

headline: A Performance From Soup to Nuttiness
text: Had you been at Roulette, the theater in downtown Brooklyn, on Friday night, you would have learned — or been reminded of — a few things. Performing artists are unparalleled and exciting problem solvers, for example. The creative process, on the other hand, is often quite boring. And: the saints are the sinners who keep trying.

headline: Though Others Failed, New East River Ferries Are a Hit
text: After several failed attempts at encouraging the use of boats to commute across the East River, city officials have an unforeseen problem: too many ferry riders.

headline: Jokes and Their Relation to Crisis
text: In June, the Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney found himself under attack for a joke he tried to make at a meeting with a group of unemployed people in Tampa, Fla. “I am also unemployed,” Romney announced, insinuating that the job he lacked was the presidency.

headline: NBC Anchor Broadens His Portfolio
text: There is something disconcerting about seeing Brian Williams sitting in front of the television.

headline: Ratification of Ford Pact by U.A.W. Seems Likely
text: DETROIT — After facing strong opposition early on, a proposed contract at Ford with the United Automobile Workers union appeared nearly certain to be ratified after receiving a wave of support over the weekend.

headline: Life in Smoke and Mirrors
text: If there is a single theme running throughout Julian Barnes’s work, from his 1985 masterpiece, “Flaubert’s Parrot,” to “A History of the World in 10 ½ Chapters” (1989), “Love, Etc.,” and recent collections like “Pulse” (2011), it’s the elusiveness of truth, the subjectivity of memory, the relativity of all knowledge. While earlier books examined our limited ability to comprehend other people and other eras, his latest novel, “The Sense of an Ending” — which was shortlisted for this year’s Man Booker Prize (the winner will be announced Tuesday) — looks at the ways in which people distort or tailor the past in an effort to mythologize their own lives.

headline: Film Society Director to Step Down
text: Richard Peña, programming director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and chairman of the New York Film Festival’s selection committee, announced on Sunday, the festival’s closing night, that he will be stepping down from both posts by the end of 2012.

headline: Relearning Who You Are

headline: Scholarship You Could Dance To
text: There’s a grainy 1972 video online of  Eddie and Charlie Palmieri playing “Vamonos Pa’l Monte” at the old Central Park Bandshell. It is one of the most deeply New York things you will ever see, multi-ethnic and multi-generational and crazily rocking. As the onstage hand-held camera whirls around, you see the brothers Andy and Jerry Gonzalez, then in their early 20s, in the band, Andy on bass and Jerry on congas, each in his own rhythmic trance.

headline: Bids to Buy Citigroup’s EMI Group Are Said to Fall Short of Expectations
text: When the Warner Music Group, the home of Neil Young and Green Day, was sold in May for $3.3 billion, music executives and media analysts were pleasantly surprised. The higher-than-expected price, after a frothy auction that drew as many as 20 suitors, seemed to indicate an enduring faith in music as an investment after a decade of bad news.

headline: Saints’ Payton Coaching With Broken Leg
text: Jim Schwartz and Jim Harbaugh will get most of the headlines for their postgame altercation, but Sean Payton is making a case that he is the toughest coach in the N.F.L.

headline: Spare in Vocals, but Robust in Melody
text: On the fast-changing choral scene in New York these days, you can’t tell the players without a program.

headline: Al Qaeda Tries a New Tactic in Somalia: Philanthropy
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Al Qaeda is not known for its philanthropic activities, but this weekend in Somalia the terrorist group appears to have branched into a new business: distributing humanitarian aid.

headline: New Zealand to Meet France in Final of Rugby World Cup
text: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Previous defeats to France in important Rugby World Cup matches mean New Zealand will be trying to stay grounded despite its impressive semifinal victory against Australia on Sunday.

headline: Aggressive Bidding Pays Off at World Teams
text: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands — The 40th World Team Championships are under way here. There are 22 teams in each event: the Bermuda Bowl, the Venice Cup and the d’Orsi Senior Bowl. They are playing a round robin of 16-board matches to qualify eight teams for the knockout stage, which begins on Sunday.

headline: Video of Deadly Race Car Crash
text: Dan Wheldon, a two-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, died Sunday afternoon after a 15-car wreck at a race in Las Vegas. The video above, posted on the North American Racing League’s YouTube channel, begins with shots from the roof of Mr. Wheldon’s car and then pans out to show the enormous pile-up that tore race cars into piece and swallowed some of them in flames.

headline: Republican Debates Are a Hot Ticket on TV
text: In September 2007, Fox News put Mitt Romney, Mike Huckabee, Ron Paul, Rudy Giuliani and a man who was, back then, a long shot for the Republican presidential nomination, John McCain, on a debate stage in New Hampshire. The face-off attracted 3.2 million viewers — the most of any debate so far that year.

headline: Sue Mengers, Hollywood Agent, Dies at 79
text: LOS ANGELES — Sue Mengers, a powerful agent who represented stars like Barbra Streisand and Steve McQueen and helped shape Hollywood’s vibrant revival in the 1970s before suddenly retiring to become an interested observer and party hostess to the changing film industry, died on Saturday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 79.

headline: Battered, RIM Pins Hopes on Next Wave of Devices
text: OTTAWA — After months of misery underlined by the declining market share of its BlackBerry phone in North America, a profoundly unsuccessful move into tablet computers and, just last week, a prolonged failure of its service for millions of users worldwide, Research in Motion has a new opportunity to convince the world that it remains relevant.

headline: Finding Archimedes in the Shadows
text: BALTIMORE — “The Archimedes Palimpsest” could well be the title of a Robert Ludlum thriller, though its plot’s esoteric arcana might also be useful for Dan Brown in his next variation on “The Da Vinci Code.” It features a third-century B.C. Greek mathematician (Archimedes) known for his playful brilliance; his lost writings, discovered more than a hundred years ago in an Istanbul convent; and various episodes involving plunder, pilferage and puzzling forgeries. The saga includes a monastery in the Judaean desert, a Jewish book dealer trying to flee Paris as the Nazis closed in, a French freedom fighter and an anonymous billionaire collector.

headline: Juvenile Offenders
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Question of Identity and Its Mark on the Body
text: Since the choreographer Rachid Ouramdane has created several pieces about the psychological effects of torture and genocide, it’s good — for the sake of our nervous systems and his — that his latest work, “World Fair,” shows him headed in a different direction. Or is it? Maybe some artists just have one subject matter and one genre to which they’re best suited? Whereas Mr. Ouramdane’s “Far ...” and “Ordinary Witnesses” feature dance imagery and qualities that draw me into his disturbing vision, “World Fair,” which was performed on Friday and Saturday at New York Live Arts as part of the Crossing the Line festival, strikes me as objectionably cerebral and unappealing.

headline: A Sacred Whale Hunt Endures

headline: Dolphins Give Sanchez a Chance to Iron Out Inconsistencies
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The morning after a game, whether the Jets win or lose, Mark Sanchez scratches notes to himself on his bathroom mirror. The exact content, he said, is private. But rest assured he is not scribbling grocery lists or phone messages to return.

headline: Magazine Creates a Brand for Women Who Work
text: THE American edition of Marie Claire magazine is expanding its editorial purview — and looking for additional advertising — with a supplement devoted to working women. The effort is another sign of how print media outlets are seeking to meet the challenges posed by digital media.

headline: Libyans Hope to Discard a University’s Dark Past
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Dr. Feisel Krekshi, the new dean of Tripoli University, arrived for his first day of work accompanied by 25 young men who fought their way onto campus with Kalashnikovs and homemade grenades.

headline: Hollywood Dishonors the Bard
text: ROLAND EMMERICH’S film “Anonymous,” which opens next week, “presents a compelling portrait of Edward de Vere as the true author of Shakespeare’s plays.” That’s according to the lesson plans that Sony Pictures has been distributing to literature and history teachers in the hope of convincing students that Shakespeare was a fraud. A documentary by First Folio Pictures (of which Mr. Emmerich is president) will also be part of this campaign.

headline: Bowl Championship Series Standings
text: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a team’s B.C.S. score.

headline: The Skinny on the M.L.S. Playoffs
text: There is one berth still there for the taking in the Major League Soccer playoffs and there are four teams still with a chance of claiming it. Colorado and Houston locked down postseason berths over the weekend.

headline: After Off-Season Rancor, Young Is Leading Rangers Again
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — In the silence after the Texas Rangers’ loss to the San Francisco Giants last year in the World Series, Michael Young addressed his anguished teammates. Young, the undisputed leader of the team, who then played third base, was already looking ahead, telling the players to retain their focus for a return trip the next year.

headline: Conference Shake-Ups and B.C.S. Tweaks
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Remember when the Bowl Championship Series, the unpopular and controversial system that college football uses to determine its national champion, seemed to be the sport’s biggest problem?

headline: Seeing Value in Ignorance, College Expects Its Physicists to Teach Poetry
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — Sarah Benson last encountered college mathematics 20 years ago in an undergraduate algebra class. Her sole experience teaching math came in the second grade, when the first graders needed help with their minuses.

headline: Routine Goal-Line Play Leads to a Sudden Death and Unsettling Questions
text: PHOENIX, N.Y. — It was just another routine goal-line play in a high school football game on a Friday night. With a playoff berth on the line, Homer High School was nursing a 7-6 lead on its home field with about six minutes to play in the third quarter against a conference rival, the Phoenix Firebirds of John C. Birdlebough High School. On third down from the Phoenix 6, Homer ran a dive up the middle and was stopped short.

headline: Iran Reacts to Pressure From America
text: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, promised on Sunday that Iran would deliver “an unforgettable response” to any “improper actions” from the United States over an alleged Iranian plot to kill the Saudi ambassador to the United States.

headline: Amazon Signs Up Authors, Writing Publishers Out of Deal
text: SEATTLE — Amazon.com has taught readers that they do not need bookstores. Now it is encouraging writers to cast aside their publishers.

headline: Song Adopted by Cain’s Campaign Also Aims to Be a Tea Party Anthem
text: HARRIMAN, Tenn. — If the Tea Party had a theme song, it would be written in the key of common people crying out for accountability. It might rail against the hypocrisy of elites who lecture others about tolerance. It would chastise politicians who stuff their pockets while refusing to listen to those who elected them.

headline: Looking to Bury a Memory From 1999
text: MILWAUKEE — Even 12 years later, the memory eats at Octavio Dotel.

headline: A Print Focus on Social Media
text: Four new monthly magazines advising business owners on how to use social media tools will go on sale on Monday. Each publication focuses on one of the major platforms: Twitter, Facebook, Google and LinkedIn.

headline: Union’s Deal With Cuomo May Prevent 3,500 Layoffs
text: New York’s second-largest union of state workers, seeking to avoid thousands of layoffs that were set to begin this week, struck a last-minute deal with the Cuomo administration on Sunday on a revised package of wage and benefit concessions.

headline: On Taxes and Fences, Cain Stumbles a Bit
text: Herman Cain found out how tricky being in the national spotlight is on Sunday as he was pushed to admit that his signature economic plan, 9-9-9, would result in increased taxes for some people.

headline: Two Top Suitors Are Emerging for New Graduate School of Engineering
text: With less than two weeks left to apply in the competition for $400 million in land and subsidies to build a science and engineering graduate school in New York City, some of the world’s great universities continue to change plans and jockey for position, and there is a growing view among them that Cornell and Stanford have emerged as the favorites.

headline: For $10, He’ll Find the Guys Who Didn’t Do It
text: He is one of New York’s busiest casting directors, yet very few know of his work.

headline: 49ers Win One Battle, Then Start Another
text: DETROIT — There was a time — last season, for instance — when a game between the Detroit Lions and the San Francisco 49ers would have meant so little that it would have elicited a shrug and a snooze. That was then, when the teams started the season a combined 1-9.

text: For generations, bowhead whales have provided the central food, energy and spiritual sustenance for Eskimo villages.

headline: John Miller to Join CBS, Bolstering ‘The Early Show’
text: Every week or so comes another signal that CBS is reshaping “The Early Show,” its low-rated morning newscast. On Monday will come another: the announcement that John Miller is joining the network as a senior correspondent with a special emphasis on the morning show.

headline: Vive L’Union
text: Soon after he arrived in Paris, in early October 1861, John Bigelow, the newly appointed American consul general to France, paid a visit to a quiet house on Rue Taitbout, about a mile north of the Louvre. The home belonged to the grandly named Édouard-René Lefèbvre de Laboulaye, a small, soft-spoken professor of history at the Collège de France, one of the country’s elite institutions of higher learning. Laboulaye was an expert on American history, and Bigelow was there to ask him for a small favor: to change the way the French thought about America’s civil war.

headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Appeal
text: For a few years now, politicians straining against all of the antigovernment demagogy have been searching for a way to energize public interest and remind voters of the essential government services and protections they rely on and all too often take for granted.

headline: A Sensible Path in California
text: Gov. Jerry Brown of California took a stand for immigrants’ rights and humane, sensible government when he signed several new bills into law. It is a welcome change from the intolerance and counterproductive policies being adopted in so many other states around the country.

headline: Volcker Rule Divides Regulators
text: Regulators have faced a barrage of complaints from lawmakers and financial industry lobbyists in their 14-month-long quest to constrain risky trading on Wall Street, an effort known as the Volcker Rule. Now, as regulators begin a push to produce a final draft of the rule, they face hurdles from an unexpected group: themselves.

headline: Cambridge Vote Ends With Supermarket Mogul on Top and Grocer in Last
text: CAMBRIDGE, England — Cambridge University has not had a candidate like Abdul Arain for its top post of chancellor in the more than 750 years the post has existed. Royal consorts, dukes, lords, military heroes, even a bishop beheaded by Henry VIII have all filled the largely ceremonial post, but never anybody quite like Mr. Arain, the proprietor of Al Amin grocery store on this city’s busy Mill Road.

headline: Dedication of the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial
text: A dedication ceremony, which ended with a speech by President Obama, took the audience back through 48 years of history, to 1963 and a defining moment for the civil rights movement, when Dr. King led the March on Washington and gave his “I Have a Dream” speech on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial.

headline: Unreasonable Strip-Searches
text: Do jails have the right to strip-search anyone in custody, even for a minor offense, if there is no reason to suspect the person is concealing a weapon, drugs or other contraband? The Supreme Court heard arguments on this question last week. If it allows jails to engage in this practice, it will weaken the Fourth Amendment’s protection against unreasonable searches.

headline: John Liu and His Campaign Books
text: Comptroller John Liu is New York City’s top financial officer. He oversees the city’s $66 billion budget and its $120 billion pension fund. That makes it all the more troubling when there are questions about numerous irregularities in his own fund-raising operations.

headline: Big Cash Edge Powers Obama in Drive for ’12
text: President Obama is exploiting his early lead in campaign fund-raising to bankroll a sprawling grass-roots organization and information technology apparatus in critical general election battlegrounds. He is doing so even as the Republican candidates conserve cash and jockey for position in what could become a drawn-out nominating battle.

text: 11:00 p.m. | Updated

text: A day after protesters associated with the Occupy Wall Street movement fanned out in several marches from the southern tip of Manhattan to Times Square, resulting in dozens of arrests, Sunday’s protests were somewhat smaller and significantly more subdued.

text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: A Bronx Bureaucrat Gets Things Done by Leaving His Desk
text: After decades spent working deep in the bowels of the New York City Department of Education bureaucracy, Bob Cohen, 59, has risen to the most important job of his life: leader of Cluster One, Network 104, the Bronx.

headline: At 52, an Exonerated Man Is Victorious in the Ring
text: Four rounds in a boxing ring could not undo 26 years in prison, but Dewey Bozella made the most of them, winning a unanimous decision Saturday at the Staples Center in Los Angeles in what he says will be his only professional fight.

headline: Losing Their Immunity
text: As the Occupy Wall Street movement continues to grow, the response from the movement’s targets has gradually changed: contemptuous dismissal has been replaced by whining. (A reader of my blog suggests that we start calling our ruling class the “kvetchocracy.”) The modern lords of finance look at the protesters and ask, Don’t they understand what we’ve done for the U.S. economy?

headline: Good News! No, Really!

headline: Tensions Flare as G.I.’s Take Fire Out of Pakistan
text: FORWARD OPERATING BASE SHARANA, Afghanistan — American and Afghan soldiers near the border with Pakistan have faced a sharply increased volume of rocket fire from Pakistani territory in the past six months, putting them at greater risk even as worries over the disintegrating relationship between the United States and Pakistan constrain how they can strike back.

headline: Pleas Unheeded as Students’ U.S. Jobs Soured
text: The college student from Moldova was in the United States on a cultural exchange program run for half a century by the federal government, a program designed to build international understanding by providing foreign students with a dream summer of fun in America. So he summoned his best English for the e-mail he sent to the State Department in June.

headline: Another Tibetan Sets Fire to Self Over China Rule
text: BEIJING — A 19-year-old former monk in a Tibetan town in western China set himself on fire on Saturday in a desperate plea for Tibetan independence, according to reports on Sunday by Tibet advocacy groups. The flames were put out by police officers stationed on the street, and he was taken to a police station, the reports said.

headline: Kodak Strikes Patent Licensing Deal With Imax

headline: Debates Sway Media Coverage, Study Finds

headline: Cardinals Slug Their Way Into World Series
text: MILWAUKEE — The booming started early. In the first three innings of Game 6 of the National League Championship Series at Miller Park, the St. Louis Cardinals and the Milwaukee Brewers combined for six home runs (a major league postseason record) and 13 runs to chase both starting pitchers with remarkable haste, even for this series.

headline: Two Top Executives Resign From Wal-Mart China

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
text: The Indian government has approved Brahmos cruise missiles in the northeastern border state of Arunachal Pradesh, in what will be India’s first deployment of  offensive tactical missiles aimed at China. “With a range of 290 km, these cruise missiles are being deployed to improve India’s military reach into the Tibet Autonomous Region and counter China’s elaborate missile deployment along the Sino-Indian border”, reports the Indian Express. At an estimated cost of 65,000 crore rupees ($13.2 billion), this is one of India’s biggest military expenditures.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Will’s Inner Rat

headline: Invincible Goldman Loses Stride, Briefly
text: The exceptionalism of Goldman Sachs has taken another knock. For a brief period last week, shares of the company, led by Lloyd C. Blankfein, traded at a bigger discount to book value — or assets minus liabilities — than those of its rival JPMorgan Chase. This rarely happens and suggests that investors fear that Goldman Sach’s franchise as a trader of securities and adviser to corporations and governments may be somehow damaged.

headline: Oct. 17, 1931 | Al Capone Guilty of Tax Evasion
text: On Oct. 17, 1931, the Chicago mobster Al Capone was convicted on five of 23 income tax evasion counts he faced, and which later yielded an 11-year prison sentence. During the trial, Mr. Capone’s efforts to avoid a strict sentence were thwarted by Judge James H. Wilkerson, who refused to offer a lenient sentence in exchange for a guilty plea. Wilkerson also swapped out the jury after Mr. Capone tried to bribe the people who were serving on it.

headline: What Motivates You?
text: Peggy Payne, at age 62, is “still stewing” over not being chosen to spend the summer studying at the Governor’s School of North Carolina–in 1965. However, Ms. Payne credits this early rejection with helping her successful writing career. Have you ever had a disappointment or setback that fueled later success? How common do you think it is to respond to failure not with discouragement but a renewed “I’ll show ’em” spirit?

He sat down for an interview with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC. What follows is a condensed, edited transcript of their conversation.

headline: Raising Children Means Letting Them Go
text: My father has always said that raising children is a process of letting go. From the moment your children are born, your job is to prepare them to function in the world without you, and perhaps your biggest challenge is preparing yourself for that separation. I couldn’t help hearing my father’s voice this weekend, while reading Emily Rapp’s moving piece in The Times’s Sunday Review about having a son with Tay-Sachs, a rare and untreatable genetic disorder from which he will probably die before he turns 3. As Ms. Rapp writes, her story is closer to most of ours than we would like to imagine: on some level, we are all getting ready for the day when our children leave us or we leave them. Read her story, “Notes From a Dragon Mom,” and then come back here to share your thoughts.

It wasn’t so much that they approved of the goings-on in the park as they were thrilled to be at that location, directly across from a Brooks Brothers store on Church Street. “We always like to gather by Brooks Brothers,” Ms. Bucks said.

This Day-Glo orange grease is dripping everywhere.

headline: Much Ado About a Handshake
text: Today’s talk will, of course, be all about the handshake. When 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh grabbed Lions Coach Jim Schwartz’s hand and gave him an overzealous jerk, prompting Schwartz to chase him down maniacally as they left the field Sunday, it became the perfect sports story for this era. It’s easy to argue about, was captured fully on video that can be replayed endlessly and is entirely silly. It had no impact on how the game turned out, much less anything deeper or more meaningful. Which means it will be debated until the N.F.L. can provide you another distraction. (Tim Tebow is starting next week!)

headline: In Crowded Cairo Quarter, Islamists Try to Seize Mantle of a Revolution
text: CAIRO — In one of Cairo’s most crowded quarters, where streets are so filled with trash that bulldozers scoop it up, the Muslim Brotherhood has opened not one but two offices. Its most conservative counterpart has followed suit. An Islamist do-gooder with forearms as broad as the Nile has vowed to win a seat in Parliament.

headline: Is the ‘Good Enough’ Marriage Good for the Children?
text: The Atlantic’s current obsession with the alleged “decline of men” continues in the magazine’s November issue with a cover story by Kate Bolick that begins with a sad summing-up of her own relationship status (“I am 39, with too many ex-boyfriends to count and, I am told, two grim-seeming options to face down: either stay single or settle for a ‘good enough’ mate. At this point, certainly, falling in love and getting married may be less a matter of choice than a stroke of wild great luck.”) and then meanders on into a long discussion of the future of marriage in man-challenged America.

headline: Steven Pinker’s History of Violence
text: My column yesterday took a modest jab at Steven Pinker’s “The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined,” and I thought that I would follow up with a few more comments on his thesis. I should stipulate that I am broadly convinced by the argument that our current era of relative peace reflects a longer term trend away from violence, and broadly impressed by the evidence that Pinker marshals to support this view. (I found the book’s story more persuasive than did, say, John Gray, to pick out the most hostile review I’ve seen to date.) But here are some criticisms and caveats.

headline: Iran Accuses U.S. of Trying to Sow Regional Discord
text: Iran’s top leaders said Monday that the American accusation of an Iranian-hatched plot to assassinate Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to Washington was partly designed to sow discord between Iran and Saudi Arabia, in what appeared to be a new Iranian counterattack to the charges announced nearly a week ago. But the foreign minister of Iran said his government was at least willing to examine the evidence that the United States claims it has in the case.

headline: Delayed Down Under, a Michigan Team Recharges in the World Solar Challenge

headline: In Battling Merchants, Banks Still Hope to Overturn Durbin Rules
text: The Durbin Amendment — the legislation that limits the fees banks can earn for debit card transactions to a scale that is “reasonable and proportional” — was signed into law more than a year ago. It survived the financial sector’s strong objections to the Federal Reserve’s aggressive first swing at regulating those fees, as well as subsequent efforts in Congress to delay adoption of the new rules. Those new rules, which were eventually watered down in a compromise that left advocates fuming, took effect Oct. 1.

headline: Looking Toward 2012, Obama Finds North Carolina Less Receptive

headline: Long-Term Care Insurance and Our Collective Denial
text: This weekend brought more depressing news on the long-term care insurance front — and continued evidence that we have our heads in the sand about these issues.

headline: Is Giants’ Ballard Owed an Apology?
text: Brandon Jacobs went up to the Giants’ new tight end, Jake Ballard, on the sideline two weeks ago, seeking him out to offer a confession.

headline: Michael Wolff Steps Down as Editor of Adweek
text: Michael Wolff, a combative and contrarian figure of Manhattan media for the last generation, has left his job as the editor of the trade publication Adweek, ending weeks of speculation over his job security there.

headline: Tough Weekend for Ailing Rapper
text: The health of Rick Ross, the Miami rapper, was unclear Monday after a tumultuous weekend during which he fell ill twice while trying to fly from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Memphis and was taken to hospitals in two cities. He also failed to show up at performances on Friday and Saturday nights.

headline: Oliver Stone Faces Down Wall Street
text: Oliver Stone, the movie-making malcontent whose landmark 1987 film, “Wall Street,” has been credited with inspiring a generation of young financiers, has some ideas about reforming the world he once chronicled.

headline: AmeriGas to Buy Energy Transfer Unit for $2.9 Billion
text: AmeriGas Partners, the country’s largest propane distributor, has agreed to buy the propane operations of Energy Transfer Partners in a cash-and-share deal worth $2.9 billion.

headline: A Guide to Political Donations
text: You play the donor: a guide to spending $25 to $10 million to influence elections after the emergence of Super PACs.

headline: In Cheating Cases, Teachers Who Took Risks or Flouted Rules
text: A charter school teacher warned her third graders that a standardized test question was “tricky,” and they all changed their answers. A high school coach in Brooklyn called a student into the hallway and slipped her a completed answer sheet in a newspaper. In the Bronx, a principal convened Finish Your Lab Days, where biology students ended up copying answers for work they never did.

headline: House Paints From the Guggenheim
text: House paint has been a part of the modernist fine-art supply cabinet for more than a century, from Picasso to Pollock to Bridget Riley. Now, the Guggenheim Museum is hoping to generate a little revenue by turning the phenomenon back in the other direction. The museum has entered into a licensing agreement with Fine Paints of Europe, a Vermont company that produces high-end commercial paints,to create a set of 200 interior and exterior wall colors drawn from well-known paintings in the Guggenheim’s collection and from wall colors that curators, artists and designers (including Frank Lloyd Wright himself) have used for exhibitions over several decades.

headline: Frieze Stock Footage by Oliver Laric
text: Four scenes from Frieze Stock Footage, Oliver Laric’s video featured at the Frieze Art Fair.

text: Jake Baldridge joined the Paragraph Project, Durham, N.C., in a new post, as a partner, joining the partners Dave Alsobrooks and Dan Carlton. Mr. Baldridge had most recently been an account director at StrawberryFrog, New York.

text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Ailment Can Steal Youth From the Young
text: Patrick Fox, now 14, considers himself lucky. It took only a year to find out why he was always tired, his heart raced and he ached all over, why he became overheated easily and had terrible headaches almost every day. Once a happy, active child and good student who enjoyed school, by age 12 he could hardly get out of bed.

headline: The Caucus | Another Obama Bus Tour
text: Oct. 17, 2011 — President Obama begins another campaign-style swing to sell his jobs bill. Also, John Harwood interviews White House Chief of Staff William M. Daley.

headline: Frieze Frame | Oliver Laric’s Not So Original Footage
text: Oliver Laric is an artist who rarely has anything new to say. His work frames the creative potential of repetition, championing the idea of “the copy” as denser in meaning and, in this day and age, somehow more genuine, than any notion of a true “original.” A copy has simply lived more: it contains within it not just the image or idea at hand, but also the imprint of time, place or identity linked with that moment as well as the motive of duplication. “Versions,” Laric’s video treatise on this subject, features an animated slide show of contemporary copies (the infamously Photoshopped 2008 image of missile tests in Iran, in which the missiles were cloned for heightened visual impact; Internet memes like the Zidane head butt, remixed and disseminated by users around the world); and historical antecedents (recycled character animations from early Disney movies; figurative archetypes taken from classical sculpture) that trace its relevance back to far before copy and paste was a way of life. Laric updates the piece regularly, and now a handful of versions of “Versions” are circulating online with many of his other works, causing discrepancies and redundancies that surface as a digitally savvy form of authenticity.

headline: A Brand That Takes a Stand
text: Two longtime advertising agency executives are finding out what life is like on the other side of Madison Avenue as they bring out a line of snacks with cause marketing at its core.

headline: Limbaugh Defends Lord’s Resistance Army
text: Updated | 6:02 p.m. Apparently sensing an opportunity to tarnish President Obama’s standing with listeners who were unaware of the suffering caused by the African rebels who call themselves the Lord’s Resistance Army, Rush Limbaugh responded to the president’s deployment of 100 military advisers to combat the group in central Africa on Friday in a segment of his radio show headlined, “Obama Invades Uganda, Targets Christians.”

headline: He Made It on Wall St. and Used It to Help Start the Protests
text: Robert S. Halper, a retired Wall Street trader, spends time each day in Zuccotti Park talking to protesters about politics and their thoughts on reforming the banking system.

headline: Potato and Pesto Gratin
text: I’ve always loved the combination of pesto and warm potatoes. I usually just toss steamed potatoes with the sauce, but this time I sliced up some Yukon golds, tossed them with the pesto and made a gratin.

headline: A Surfeit of Pesto
text: Summer is long gone, but my basil doesn’t know that. When tomatoes are around I have no trouble staying on top of my crop, as rare is the tomato salad on my table that isn’t showered with slivered basil leaves. Now I’m making big batches of puréed basil with olive oil to freeze and use later for pesto and pistou (the Provençal version of pesto, minus the pine nuts). I make the pine nut and garlic paste and blend it into the basil and olive oil along with the cheese when I need the pesto; the garlic will taste much better if it’s fresh. If you don’t like the taste of raw garlic, you can always leave it out.

headline: Amish Renegades Are Accused in Bizarre Attacks on Their Peers
text: BERGHOLZ, Ohio — Myron Miller and his wife, Arlene, had been asleep for an hour when their 15-year-old daughter woke them and said that people were knocking at the door.

headline: In San Francisco, a Gathering of the E.V. Converted
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Electric car owners, advocates and even a few critics gathered Sunday in 26 cities across the country for the first National Plug In Day, sponsored by Plug In America, a nonprofit group that advocates an accelerated shift to plug-in vehicles.

headline: Government of Jordan Is Dismissed by the King
text: AMMAN, Jordan — King Abdullah II of Jordan, under growing pressure to accelerate political reform and genuine anticorruption measures, fired his government on Monday, just eight months after doing so for similar reasons in the early days of the Arab Spring.

headline: Where is Matt? Back Spanning the Globe
text: A signature of the “Today” show, “Where in the World is Matt Lauer?” is being revived after a three-year break.

headline: No Combat Role for U.S. Advisers in Uganda, Official Says
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — Most of the 100 military advisers being sent to Uganda to help hunt down the Lord’s Resistance Army, a brutal guerrilla group in central Africa, will stay in Uganda, which the group has not attacked in years, an American government official said Monday.

headline: Bloomberg Says He Seeks Balance Between Right to Protest and ‘Right to Be Silent’
text: Updated 5:10 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, speaking on the day that Occupy Wall Street protesters marked their one-month anniversary in Zuccotti Park, said he was trying to strike a balance between protecting protesters’ right to free speech and the needs of Lower Manhattan residents.

headline: I’m Keeping My Coach, but You May Not Need One
text: A guy I know wanted to start a coaching service for runners. He’s pretty fast and had run some marathons and a 50-mile race. He also coached his wife, who had successfully run a marathon. He asked if I wanted to be a coach, too, or at least provide online training advice to clients.

headline: Dutrow Given 30-Day Stay of 10-Year Suspension
text: Richard Dutrow Jr. is still in the horse racing business after a New York State Supreme Court judge on Monday granted a 30-day stay of the 10-year suspension handed down by state racing authorities.

headline: U.S. Debated Cyberwarfare in Attack Plan on Libya
text: WASHINGTON — Just before the American-led strikes against Libya in March, the Obama administration intensely debated whether to open the mission with a new kind of warfare: a cyberoffensive to disrupt and even disable the Qaddafi government’s air-defense system, which threatened allied warplanes.

headline: Former N.H.L. Players Accept Announcer’s Apology
text: Three former N.H.L. enforcers said they have accepted Don Cherry’s apology for calling them “pukes,” “turncoats” and “hypocrites” on a “Hockey Night in Canada” telecast Oct 6. Cherry, a cantankerous analyst, apologized during the show Saturday, and called Stu Grimson, Chris Nilan and Jim Thomson, “my type of guys.”

headline: A Hostage-Taker Calls, and a French News Blog Begins Tweeting
text: Pierre Haski, a co-founder of the French news blog Rue 89, received the first call from the hostage-taker just before noon on Monday.

headline: Germany Lowers Expectations for E.U. Summit
text: BRUSSELS — At the start of a crucial week for the euro, Germany sought Monday to play down expectations of a decisive breakthrough at a summit meeting of European Union leaders this weekend, indicating that an emerging five-point plan designed to end the euro zone’s sovereign debt crisis could take months to implement.

headline: Jagr Wearing One More Guise in N.H.L. Return

headline: Ex-Chief Executive of Olympus Ties Ouster to His Claim of Fraud by the Company

headline: Chimp to Man to History Books: The Path of AIDS
text: Our story begins sometime close to 1921, somewhere between the Sanaga River in Cameroon and the Congo River in the former Belgian Congo. It involves chimps and monkeys, hunters and butchers, “free women” and prostitutes, syringes and plasma-sellers, evil colonial lawmakers and decent colonial doctors with the best of intentions. And a virus that, against all odds, appears to have made it from one ape in the central African jungle to one Haitian bureaucrat leaving Zaire for home and then to a few dozen men in California gay bars before it was even noticed — about 60 years after its journey began.

headline: Management Looks to Take China’s Shanda Private
text: SHANGHAI — Shares of the Chinese gaming and Internet giant Shanda Interactive soared early Monday after the company announced a management-led buyout that would take the Nasdaq-listed company private.

headline: Devils Become Digital Host for New Jersey Youth Hockey
text: NEWARK — If you want up-to-date statistics for the players on the New Jersey Devils, the team’s official Web site is a wise place to click. If you want to find out how the Hackensack Comets, Edison Eagles, Livingston Lancers, Don Bosco Prep Ironman and all the other New Jersey high school ice hockey teams are faring, you can also go to Devils.nhl.com.

headline: Sports Replay: Oct. 17
text: Action from the Pan American Games, which continued in Guadalajara, Mexico, including swimming, volleyball and table tennis.

headline: Childbirth: Limited Gains From Supplemental Calcium
text: Most doctors encourage women to increase their calcium intake during pregnancy to protect against birth complications and thinning bones caused by the loss of calcium to developing babies. But supplemental calcium does not prevent preterm birth or improve bone density in pregnant women, according to a new report, and may be helpful only in lowering the risk of hypertension.

headline: French Court Puts L'Oréal Heiress Under Guardianship
text: Liliane Bettencourt, the aging heiress of the L’Oréal cosmetics fortune, was placed under the care of a legal guardian Monday by a judge, who based the decision on a medical evaluation that indicated she suffers from dementia and Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear 2 Human Rights Cases
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to hear a pair of cases on whether corporations and political groups may be sued in American courts for complicity in human rights abuses abroad.

headline: Bad Premonitions Before, and Ominous Signs After, Dan Wheldon’s Crash in Las Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS — The IndyCar racing community, its fans and even drivers themselves seemed almost braced for tragedy Sunday, as the season finale unfolded here. When it came, in the form of a 15-car pileup that killed the two-time Indianapolis 500 champion Dan Wheldon, there seemed to be little shock, just sadness that the worst-case scenario had indeed occurred.

headline: ‘Stay With Me’
text: Q. Often in movies or on TV, and in real life too (the motorcyclist recently dragged from under the flaming car), a trauma victim will be told to “stay with me.” Are there circumstances when it is vital for a trauma victim to remain conscious? If so, what are they, and why is it helpful?

headline: Putin Defends Decision to Seek Presidency
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin confronted criticism over his decision to seek a return to the presidency next year, warning in a television interview shown on Monday of a return to the volatility of previous decades should Russia swerve from its current course.

headline: A Company With Balanchine in Its Pedigree
text: WASHINGTON — WASHINGTON — Last weekend, while the Suzanne Farrell Ballet was performing at the Kennedy Center Eisenhower Theater here, I sometimes couldn’t help wishing that the company were on a larger stage. This week, when it comes to the Joyce Theater in New York, it will be on a stage considerably smaller. Fortunately, the repertory will be almost entirely different.

headline: Australia: Man’s Serious Illness Shows the Danger of Daring to Eat a Garden-Variety Slug
text: An Australian man has been hospitalized for more than a month in serious condition as a result of eating two garden slugs on a dare, according to Australian news media and ProMED , an online service that tracks disease outbreaks.

headline: Australians Assess Their Greenhouse Plan
text: In the wake of Australia’s move to add a price to carbon dioxide emissions — which is particularly notable considering the country is one of the world’s big exporters of coal (and related CO2 emissions) — I sent a query to some Australian analysts of climate and energy policy to see if this holds lessons for the United States.

headline: Turncoat of Placenta Is Watched for Trouble
text: In mother-and-child paintings and Henry Moore sculptures, mothers and babies meld together with such ease they appear as one. But in the course of some pregnancies, the embryo’s struggle for nutrients can escalate into all-out war with the mother, a dangerous condition called pre-eclampsia.

headline: Sandra Lee Opens Up on Life With Cuomo and Offers Career Advice
text: In a rare appearance at an event that was not about food, New York’s de facto first lady, Sandra Lee, on Monday offered a glimpse into the household she shares with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and gave young women some blunt career advice.

headline: Peering Beyond a Monologist’s Stage Presence Into His Uncensored Mind
text: Skiing is better than sex, Spalding Gray once said, “because for me a good round of sex might be seven minutes. Skiing you can do for seven hours.”

headline: Two Cancer Studies Find Bacterial Clue in Colon
text: For years, Dr. Robert A. Holt, a genomics researcher at the British Columbia Cancer Agency, wrestled with a question about colon cancer. Might it be caused, or pushed along, by a bacterial infection?

headline: Coaches Throw No Punches and Earn No Penalties
text: The pigskin pugilists were barely off the field before the real question about Jim Harbaugh and Jim Schwartz was asked: What will the N.F.L. do with two of its brightest young coaches who behaved as if they were even younger — perhaps still on the junior high school playground?

headline: Not Such a Stretch to Reach for the Stars

headline: From Telomeres to the Origins of Life
text: BOSTON — The October night before he learned he had won the 2009 Nobel Prize in medicine, the biochemical researcher Jack W. Szostak says he slept like a log.

headline: Edgar M. Villchur, a Hi-Fi Innovator, Is Dead at 94
text: Edgar M. Villchur, whose invention of a small loudspeaker that could produce deep, rich bass tones opened the high-fidelity music market in the 1950s to millions of everyday listeners, died on Monday at his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 94.

headline: The Underappreciated Hunks of Occupy Wall Street
text: No one ever said the revolution would be sexy. In fact, media coverage of Occupy Wall Street suggested quite the opposite, tending to emphasize the unkempt woolliness and generally unsanitary nature of the movement.

headline: Paul Plan Would Eliminate Cabinet Departments to Cut $1 Trillion
text: 9:29 p.m. | Updated LAS VEGAS — Representative Ron Paul on Monday unveiled an aggressive budget plan that would greatly shrink the federal government that he is seeking to run, eliminating the agency that oversees airport security, the Departments of Energy and Education and three others, while cutting all war financing.

headline: Legends Of The Rentiers
text: I feel Dean Baker’s pain. Dean is exercised over an NPR report which says that Argentina is suffering from its 2001 default — a claim that is totally at odds with the evidence. Argentina actually did very well by thumbing its nose at creditors.

headline: Drawing Dance: A Cunningham Dancer At Rest
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 16th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from London.

headline: Fiddling With a Two-Year Gap in the Busy Life of Copernicus
text: Dava Sobel has long taken a quirky approach to science history. In “Galileo’s Daughter” (1999), for instance, she focused not on the standard biographical material but on the scientist’s love for his illegitimate daughter, consigned to a convent at 13 and dead of dysentery at 33.

headline: Ending Speculation, Michael Wolff Leaves Post at Adweek
text: MICHAEL WOLFF, a combative and contrarian figure of Manhattan media for the last generation, has left his job as the editorial director of Adweek, ending weeks of speculation over his job security there.

headline: Clues About Early Diets Found in Fossilized Teeth
text: By studying the pits and scratches on fossilized teeth and analyzing the carbon isotopes on enamel, researchers have discovered new information about the diets of early hominids.

headline: A Good Week for ‘Priscilla’ at the Box Office
text: The Broadway musical “Priscilla Queen of the Desert,” which opened to mixed reviews in March and had one of the rockiest summers at the box office for new productions, had its highest-earning set of performances last week since late May, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group for theater owners and producers. “Priscilla” earned $860,673, about 59 percent of the maximum possible gross last week; the show earned $920,741 during the playing week that included Memorial Day weekend, while it reached a low point of $547,180 in early September.

headline: Your Photo, Justified

headline: On Teamwork, at Least, Chimps and Children Vary
text: Cooperation, that fine art of working together toward a common goal, is more appealing to children than to chimpanzees, a new study reports.

headline: Raising an Album, From Pigpen to Studio
text: Followers of Matthew Herbert, a British electronic musician obsessed with the possibilities of using found sounds, knew he would eventually do something like “One Pig.”

text: Some readers wanted to know about how the Sims/Sargent methodology plays into Keynesian or IS-LM-type models. Does it support them? Well, yes, but the case needs a bit of explaining.
