headline: An Author Withdraws as Book Award Finalist
text: In case there were any doubt that the annual announcements of literary prizes can yield high drama, an author was asked to withdraw from the shortlist for the National Book Awards on Monday, five days after she was mistakenly named a finalist by the National Book Foundation.

headline: On One Baroque Evening
text: The Juilliard School has assembled a respectable group of period-instrument players to teach in its historical-performance program, but it has also lined up a few starry guests to give master classes and direct concerts. Jordi Savall, who first visited the program when it began, two seasons ago, was on the podium on Saturday evening to lead Juilliard415, the program’s student ensemble, in a performance of Baroque suites at the school’s Peter Jay Sharp Theater.

headline: Israel and Palestinians Prepare to Swap Prisoners
text: RAFAH CROSSING, Gaza Strip — The cactus-lined highway that leads to this international gateway between Gaza and Egypt was draped in green bunting and flags on Monday, as Hamas stamped its Islamist mark across the scene of a long-awaited Israeli-Palestinian prisoner exchange scheduled for Tuesday.

headline: The Chemistry of Fresh Enthusiasms
text: Among the various motivations behind the festival SONiC: Sounds of a New Century, a nine-evening series of new-music concerts running throughout the city, one standout is the claim that all the included works are from composers 40 or younger. Eighth Blackbird, a polished, personable, routinely dazzling sextet, has never bound its repertory so rigidly; included in its swelling canon are staples by Schoenberg and Boulez.

headline: After a Killing, Trying to Heal Through Theater
text: On the afternoon of April 4 students at the school of the Freedom Theater, an Arab-language troupe in the Jenin refugee camp on the West Bank, were doing a reading of “Spring Awakening,” which was supposed to be their graduation project, when they heard five shots fired just outside their building. Rushing outdoors, they discovered the founder of the theater, Juliano Mer Khamis, crumpled and bleeding so heavily that he died before doctors could treat him.

headline: Fitzpatrick the Underdog?
text: William C. Rhoden discusses the contradiction of calling Ryan Fitzpatrick an underdog.

headline: Video: Fitzpatrick the Underdog?
text: William C. Rhoden discusses the contradiction of calling the Bills’ Ryan Fitzpatrick an underdog.

headline: A Bobby Short Tribute Is Exuberant and Reverent
text: What fragrance is “kinda young, kinda now, kinda free, kinda wow”? For those old enough to remember, that pitch from a 1970s TV commercial featuring Shelley Hack may unlock memories of a happy-go-lucky Bobby Short, who composed the jingle singing the praises of Charlie, the Revlon perfume for sophisticated on-the-go gals.

headline: Lumière | Wanna Know a Secret?
text: Despite the economic crisis gripping Europe, there is one industry in France that is still going strong: the discovery, telling and selling of secrets. I confess to being a sucker for books about secrets, of which I have dozens, organized in three subject areas.

headline: It’s Complicated: Dragonfly Love Comes Calling
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — Any old pond will do. Michael L. May set out one recent Wednesday morning from his cramped office at the Rutgers University entomology building to collect a few dragonflies.

headline: Coach Wants to See You. And Bring Your iPad.
text: Baltimore Ravens defensive tackle Arthur Jones, who is accustomed to lugging around a hefty playbook each August, was pleasantly surprised when he was handed a 1.3-pound tablet computer at training camp this year.

headline: Single-Sex Schools: Separate but Equal?
text: A new study debunks the benefits of segregation by sex in the classroom,  and says the practice does more harm than good. Should it be illegal?

headline: New Music From Real Estate, My Brightest Diamond, Harold O’Neal
text: REAL ESTATE

headline: The Complete Interview With President Felipe Calderón in Spanish (La Entrevista Completa en Español)
text: En respuesta a nuestros lectores, principalmente en México, publicamos la transcripción de la entrevista del New York Times con el presidente Felipe Calderón Hinojosa que tuvo lugar en su residencia oficial a finales del mes de septiembre.

headline: Missouri Moves Closer to Joining SEC
text: The University of Missouri is heading down a path to join the Southeastern Conference, said a university official with direct knowledge of the situation.

headline: Lens: Tuvalu
text: Lens: Tuvalu

headline: Escorting a Wife Out Before Plotting Begins
text: “Any Given Monday,” a biting comedy at the 59E59 Theaters about the consequences of infidelity, opens with Lenny, a middle-aged public school teacher in Philadelphia, hunkered down in his den, the remains of a pizza by the couch and the end of “To Kill a Mockingbird” playing in the background. It’s been four days since he helped Risa, his wife of 24 years, move out after she told him she was leaving him for another man. Carried her bag, even.

headline: What Main Street Thinks About ‘Occupy Wall Street’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Euro Crisis Weighing On East European Growth
text: FRANKFURT — A major development bank sharply reduced its growth forecast for Eastern Europe on Tuesday and warned of risks to the region’s banks, another example of how the sovereign debt crisis is radiating outside the euro zone.

headline: Emotion, Music and Humor at Steve Jobs Memorial
text: The memorial for Steve Jobs on the Stanford University campus Sunday night featured an intimate series of tributes from friends, colleagues and family.

headline: A Staged Enigma That Numbers Among Its Characters Something/Nothings
text: Mac Wellman’s “3 2’s; or AFAR” offers the playwright’s typically dizzying and fluid unfurling of language. References, registers and nonsense rhymes fly with madcap precision.

headline: Trying to Lift the Gloom Over Housing
text: To the Editor:

headline: In an Earlier Time of Boom and Bust, Rentals Also Gained Favor
text: During the boom years in Manhattan real estate, credit was easy, speculators developed building after building to meet rising demand for apartments, and values kept climbing, fed by a flurry of resales. But then Wall Street plummeted and the housing market followed suit, as values deflated and apartment sales came to a standstill.

headline: Insurance and the Treatment of Eating Disorders
text: To the Editor:

headline: Critics’ Picks: ‘Au Hasard Balthazar’
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Robert Bresson’s portrait of suffering and grace.

headline: How Chess Offered Insight Into a Student’s Potential
text: To the Editor:

headline: Olympus Chief Goes, but Push for Reform Goes On
text: Olympus’s embarrassing decision to dump its British chief executive two weeks after naming him to the job shows that reform in Japan is a slow and fitful process. The executive, Michael C. Woodford, was brought in to clean house at the company, and became one of Japan’s handful of foreign corporate bosses. That the board decided to fire him so soon shows the medicine was distasteful. It also strengthens the case for a bigger dose.

headline: McCourts Complete Divorce, With Frank Taking Dodgers
text: Frank and Jamie McCourt said Monday that they had settled their divorce case, resolving one major cloud hovering over the Dodgers, the team they jointly owned.

headline: Big Hole in White House Lawn Prompts Equally Big Questions
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, who has been traveling the country urging Congress to pass his jobs bill so Americans can be put to work on infrastructure projects, need only look out a window in the West Wing to see one such project. Under way on his front lawn for the last 17 months, it is highly visible and yet mysterious.

headline: TimesCast | Kenya's Military In Somalia
text: October 17, 2011 — Kenya’s military crosses into Somalia, waging a war against Shabab Islamic militants.

headline: The Cardinals See Greater Things Ahead for a Series M.V.P.
text: MILWAUKEE — In the St. Louis Cardinals’ Champagne-soaked clubhouse, the announcement that third baseman David Freese had won the Most Valuable Player award of the National League Championship Series set off a chant of “M.V.P.!” from his celebrating teammates. Freese stood on the makeshift TBS platform holding the trophy with a mix of pride and embarrassment. As someone who grew up in the St. Louis suburb of Wildwood, Mo., he could hardly be more grateful.

headline: Derek Fisher, Champion Point Guard and Face of the Players Union
text: When strikes and lockouts cripple sports leagues, the prominent voices leading the players are almost never active players themselves. That is not surprising. The lawyers who run sports unions on a daily basis have broader experience in labor issues and more expertise.

headline: Speedy In-Flight Wi-Fi, Even During a Wild Ride
text: HENDERSON, Nev.

headline: The Evangelical Rejection of Reason
text: Quincy, Mass.

headline: Tracking Jets vs. Dolphins on ‘Monday Night Football’
text: So is this officially the Jets’ first must-win game of the season? Coach Rex Ryan thinks so, and not just because the Jets need to get back to .500 after losing three in a row on the road at Oakland, Baltimore and New England.

headline: Back Home, Known for a Tragedy, Not Successes
text: LONDON — When the Englishman Dan Wheldon won his second Indianapolis 500 in May, taking the lead for the first time when another driver hit the wall in sight of the checkered flag, it barely rated a mention in Britain’s sports sections — and then, commonly, only in the fine print of the “who won what” summaries at the foot of the page.

headline: The Great Restoration
text: If, in the 1960s, you had tried to judge America by looking at the sit-ins and Woodstock, you would have had a very distorted picture of where the country was heading. You wouldn’t have been able to predict that Richard Nixon would win the youth vote in 1972, which he did. You wouldn’t have been able to predict that Republicans would go on to win four out of the next five presidential elections, a streak only interrupted by Jimmy Carter, who ran as a conservative Democrat.

headline: Bureaucracy in Greece Defies Efforts to Cut It
text: ATHENS — Stories of eye-popping waste and abuse of power among Greece’s bureaucrats are legion, including officials who hire their wives, and managers who submit $38,000 bills for office curtains.

headline: TimesCast | Greece's Big Week
text: October 17, 2011 - Greek public workers start new strikes as parliament is expected to take up new austerity measures, including new taxes.

headline: Pairings: Filet of Beef With Swiss Chard
text: St.-Joseph wines, more vinous than fruity with an often chewy density, suggest beef, perhaps a nice hunk of tenderloin for two. This cut offers a good chance to try grass-fed meat. It is ordinarily tougher, but the filet is steak at its most tender. And while the filet is often bland, grass-fed meat can have a stronger flavor. Here, it is seared, then roasted, if you can call it that: the beef cooks so fast you might just walk it past a hot oven.

headline: Finding Autumn in St.-Joseph
text: THE weather has been so bizarre this year that I almost hesitate to associate wine with the seasons. But autumn seems to have finally begun in earnest, so I feel compelled — and relieved, actually — to dip into the St.-Joseph.

headline: We Can All Become Job Creators
text: Howard Schultz. God bless him.

headline: Farmers Facing Loss of Subsidy May Get New One
text: It seems a rare act of civic sacrifice: in the name of deficit reduction, lawmakers from both parties are calling for the end of a longstanding agricultural subsidy that puts about $5 billion a year in the pockets of their farmer constituents. Even major farm groups are accepting the move, saying that with farmers poised to reap bumper profits, they must do their part.

headline: For Bachmann, a Bid to Reconnect in Iowa
text: PERRY, Iowa — Hoping for a second look from Republicans who just two months ago considered her a front-runner, Representative Michele Bachmann is going back to basics — a lot of hand-shaking and shoulder-rubbing at small events in early-voting Iowa; sharpening her message on red-meat issues to stir conservative voters.

headline: Justices Take Case on Lying About Honors From Military
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether Congress can make it a crime to lie about having earned a military decoration.

headline: Q.&A.: Fixing Picasa Photos Fast
text: Q.

headline: A Pipeline Merger Meets a Need, and Perhaps Resistance
text: Kinder Morgan’s planned $21.1 billion takeover of the El Paso Corporation is seen as a potential catalyst for consolidation in an unheralded but increasingly important part of the energy industry: the companies whose pipes carry the oil and gas.

headline: Bloomberg Says ‘Tent City’ Goes Beyond Free Speech
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, speaking Monday as Occupy Wall Street protesters celebrated the passage of a month encamped in Zuccotti Park, said he was trying to strike a balance between protecting protesters’ right to free speech and the needs of Lower Manhattan residents.

headline: Massachusetts Tries to Rein In Its Health Costs
text: BOSTON — On the Republican campaign trail, the health care debate has focused on the mandatory coverage that Mitt Romney signed into law as governor in 2006. But back in Massachusetts the conversation has moved on, and lawmakers are now confronting the problem that Mr. Romney left unaddressed: the state’s spiraling health care costs.

headline: Accounting Board Criticizes Deloitte’s Auditing System
text: In an unprecedented rebuke to a major accounting firm, the group that oversees the industry released a report criticizing Deloitte & Touche, saying that it lacked an adequate system of quality control in its audits.

headline: Stop the Keystone XL
text: Robert Redford urges President Obama to oppose the Keystone XL pipeline, which would deliver crude oil from Canada through the American heartland to refineries on the Gulf Coast of Texas.

headline: Is Religion Above the Law?
text: The religion clause case recently argued before the Supreme Court — Hosanna-Tabor v. EEOC — centers on the “ministerial exception,” the doctrine (elaborated over the last 40 years) that exempts religious associations from complying with neutral, generally applicable laws in some, but not all, circumstances.

headline: Miller Buckfire Plans to Name Golub Its Chairman
text: One of stalwarts of the restructuring world, the boutique investment bank Miller Buckfire, plans to name Harvey Golub its chairman on Tuesday, bringing in a financial services veteran to help oversee a revamping of its operations.

headline: Studies Clash on the Impact of Closing Indian Point
text: In a case of dueling studies, research commissioned by opponents of nuclear power indicates that electricity in New York State would remain reliable and reasonably priced if the Indian Point nuclear reactors were permanently shut down. The findings directly contradict those of experts hired by the Bloomberg administration.

headline: Iowa Caucuses Set for Jan. 3
text: Change that pencil marking on the political calendar to ink pen: The Iowa caucuses will be held on Jan. 3.

headline: Despite Protests, Cuomo Says He Will Not Extend a Tax Surcharge on Top Earners
text: ALBANY — Even as Occupy Wall Street stokes debate over income inequality, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo dug in his heels on Monday against extending a so-called millionaires’ tax on high-earning New Yorkers, saying the income tax surcharge would place New York at a competitive disadvantage with neighboring states.

headline: Republicans and Foreign Policy
text: For a while, we were concerned that the candidates for the Republican presidential nomination were not saying much about national security and foreign affairs. Now that a few have started, maybe they were better off before.

headline: Worries Circled Las Vegas Track Before a Pileup
text: LAS VEGAS — The recipe for disaster in auto racing is hardly a secret. Start with a problematic racing layout, mix in a field of expert drivers with rookies and rusty ones, put millions of dollars on the line and then add speed. Lots of speed.

headline: Failed Attack on U.S. Base Rattles an Afghan Valley
text: ROKHA, Afghanistan — As the suicide bombers threaded their way past patchwork farms and snow-dusted mountains here in eastern Afghanistan, they had to stop for directions. It was 4 a.m. and, apparently in need of help finding their target, they pulled up to a police station and asked the overnight guards, Which way to the Americans?

headline: Who Mailed the Anthrax Letters?
text: There was a strong sense of relief when the federal government concluded that a lone psychologically troubled government scientist mailed anthrax-laced letters in 2001, killing five people and terrorizing the nation. Now its evidence is looking increasingly shaky.

headline: G.O.P. Freshman’s Fiscal Message Clashes With His Finances
text: WASHINGTON — There is Representative Joe Walsh, a freshman from Illinois, deriding his colleagues once again for their poor stewardship of the economy. During the debt ceiling debate, Mr. Walsh took to the airwaves to call President Obama a liar for suggesting that the nation might default. Just the other day, Mr. Walsh held court at a Tea Party rally, complaining that Republican leaders in Congress had “been there too long” to understand how best to deal with the nation’s daunting fiscal issues.

headline: Another Test of Marriage Equality
text: Senator Patrick Leahy, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, took a step toward true equality for all Americans last week by planning a vote next month on whether to repeal the law that bars the federal government from recognizing lawfully performed marriages between same-sex couples.

headline: Eminent Domain Fight Has a Canadian Twist
text: A Canadian company has been threatening to confiscate private land from South Dakota to the Gulf of Mexico, and is already suing many who have refused to allow the Keystone XL pipeline on their property even though the controversial project has yet to receive federal approval.

headline: Smaller Shelters and Persuasion Coax Homeless Off Bronx Streets
text: Not far from the Major Deegan Expressway in the South Bronx is an abandoned subway platform where someone placed a plastic chair, a flimsy mattress and a nightstand. Nearby, in an old construction site, a truck trailer is lined with enough discarded furniture that it looks like a makeshift bedroom.

headline: Elouise Cobell, 65, Dies; Sued U.S. Over Indian Trust Funds
text: Elouise Cobell, a heroine to American Indians for leading a 15-year legal battle that ended with the federal government’s agreeing to pay $3.4 billion in compensation for mismanagement of Indian trust funds since the late 1800s, died on Sunday in Great Falls, Mont. She was 65 and lived on the Blackfeet reservation near Browning, Mont.

headline: Pro-Qaddafi Enclave in Desert Is Said to Fall After a Battle
text: Libyan forces fighting the vestiges of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s toppled government said Monday that anti-Qaddafi fighters were in complete control of Bani Walid, a loyalist desert enclave south of Tripoli, the capital, but had yet to proclaim total victory in his Mediterranean hometown of Surt.

headline: Lawyer Defends Himself on Charges He Orchestrated Murder of a Witness
text: NEWARK — With his pinstripe suit and cobalt tie, the defense lawyer, Paul W. Bergrin, looked the part as he addressed the jury for the first time. The prosecution’s witnesses are liars, he said, as defense lawyers do. “They will say and they will do anything,” he said.

headline: City Aims for Teamwork to End Dig-Pave-Dig Cycle on Roads
text: For many New Yorkers, the process is all too familiar: A utility company arrives, lays waste to a roadway and paves it over — just in time for private contractors to turn up and gut the street anew.

headline: The Missed Red Flags on Groupon
text: This summer, Lloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, flew to Chicago to personally pitch his firm to underwrite what was supposed to be the hottest initial public offering of the year: Groupon, the fledgling online coupon company that was being valued at around $30 billion.

headline: Stroke Victim Is Flown From South Pole
text: Renee Nicole Doucuer, who was serving as winter manager at the Amundsen-Scott research station at the South Pole when she suffered a stroke on Aug. 27, was airlifted from the isolated base on Monday. Ms. Doucuer was resting in New Zealand on Monday. She is expected to undergo tests on Tuesday to determine the severity of her stroke, and the results will determine when she flies home to Seabrook, N.H. Ms. Doucuer, 58, had been trying to leave the South Pole since her stroke. But Raytheon, which operates the station under contract from the National Science Foundation, determined that any rescue during Antarctica’s winter would unnecessarily put other lives at risk. Ms. Doucuer and her family pressured Raytheon and the National Science Foundation to have a plane on standby should the weather improve. The flight that ultimately retrieved Ms. Doucuer was the first scheduled one of the spring season. A C-17 cargo plane, which was not intended to carry passengers, made room for Ms. Doucuer and a doctor from the station.

headline: An Investor Creates a Tempest in a Coffee Cup
text: When shares of Green Mountain Coffee Roasters began trading on Monday morning, they held the distinction of being the best-performing stock on a major exchange over the last five years.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Uganda: Security Forces Clash With Protesters
text: Security forces fired rubber bullets and tear gas at stone-wielding protesters Kampala on Monday as an activist group tried to reignite street demonstrations against high commodity prices and corruption. Protest organizers were arrested in Kampala, the capital, and in the southern cities of Mbarara and Masaka. In Kampala, rioting broke out in the downtown Kiseka market, with traders throwing stones as columns of police officers and armored vehicles swept the area. A tear gas canister landed in a nearby secondary school where students were taking national exams. Opposition politicians and activists called for a resumption of the protests this week. During the initial protests last spring, at least nine people were killed and hundreds were arrested.

headline: The Northeast Passage Opens Up
text: Map shows routes once impassable by the Arctic ice cap that have opened up into new shipping lanes.

headline: Giants Enter Bye Week Liking Where They Are, and Where They’re Going
text: The final five minutes of the Giants’ 27-24 win over the Buffalo Bills might end up being recalled for changing the tenor of their season.

headline: Police Eyes Hovering Over Muslims
text: Hello to you, and to whoever might be spying on us tonight.

headline: Officer Held in Civil Rights Case After Frisking
text: A New York City police officer was charged on Monday with violating the civil rights of a black man whom he falsely accused of resisting arrest.

headline: Banks Start to Make More Loans
text: Despite all the bleak economic news, a funny thing has been happening in the financial industry over the last few months: the banks have quietly turned on the lending spigot.

headline: Tuesday: Day Two of the Crossword Contest
text: Administrivial Tournament Reminder! It’s not too late to sign up for the Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament, held this year on Friday, October 21 at Will Shortz’s Westchester Table Tennis Club. New York Times crossword puzzles, mouth-watering desserts, and additional puzzles by our puzzle master make for an evening of fun that raises money for a great cause, the Pleasantville Fund For Learning. You can even pay at the door, so if you will be in the area, stop by and say hello. I’ll be there to greet you, but I’m just warning you: the brownies are mine. All mine.

headline: Moral Issues Behind iPhone and Its Makers
text: I hate to tell you this, but your best friend has a dark secret in his past, the kind of shameful history that might just have you looking at him (or her?) a little sheepishly, with a furtive, sidelong glance instead of the former adoring gaze.

headline: Warming Revives Dream of Sea Route in Russian Arctic
text: ARKHANGELSK, Russia — Rounding the northernmost tip of Russia in his oceangoing tugboat this summer, Capt. Vladimir V. Bozanov saw plenty of walruses, some pods of beluga whales and in the distance a few icebergs.

headline: After 2 Days, Defense Rests in Bloomberg Consultant’s Trial
text: Lawyers for a political consultant accused of stealing money from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg rested their case on Monday after two days of testimony, using their four witnesses to suggest that their client, John F. Haggerty Jr., had delivered the services that the mayor paid for.

headline: A Front-Runner, but the Race Is Long
text: LAS VEGAS — He has consistently outperformed the rest of the Republican presidential field in debates. He has built a powerful fund-raising machine. He has rolled out one big-name endorsement after another. He has avoided being drawn into distracting sideshows or becoming rattled by his opponents.

headline: Battle for Libya | October 17, 2011
text: With anti-Qaddafi fighters saying they were in control of Bani Walid, it appeared that only a small district of Surt remained as a stronghold for loyalists to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Dinner and Derangement
text: During thousands of elaborate restaurant meals over dozens of piggy years, I’ve received many exacting, even loopy, instructions.

headline: Plaintiff for the Past
text: Elouise Cobell was soft-spoken, but her politeness and sense of propriety took nothing away from her tenacity. Ms. Cobell, who died on Sunday at the age of 65, was a cattle rancher, a member of the Blackfeet Tribe and a determined advocate for nearly forgotten rights of American Indians.

headline: Broadcast of an Animated Film Roils Tunisia Before Elections
text: TUNIS — In the final week of the first election campaign of the Arab Spring, political discourse here in Tunisia has been all but consumed by contention over the television broadcast of an animated film, “Persepolis,” which touched off accusations of heresy and censorship.

headline: A Tea Party Panel Supports Health Care Law’s Repeal
text: A Tea Party commission trying to “crowd-source” a plan to reduce the federal budget deficit says it found broad support for repealing the health care legislation passed last year and eliminating entire federal departments, but much less enthusiasm for changes to Medicare and Social Security.

headline: Countless Grievances, One Thread: We’re Angry
text: PHOENIX — Ken Alandt’s guitar, which he covered with bumper stickers and waved in the air at the Occupy Phoenix protest on Monday, is a symbol of the movement itself — a mélange of disparate causes, all of which prompt his blood to boil.

headline: Salmon-Killing Virus Seen for First Time in the Wild on the Pacific Coast
text: A lethal and highly contagious marine virus has been detected for the first time in wild salmon in the Pacific Northwest, researchers in British Columbia said on Monday, stirring concern that it could spread there, as it has in Chile, Scotland and elsewhere.

headline: Trump Joins Bachmann on Call With Supporters
text: He has had pizza in Times Square with Sarah Palin. He has dined at the swank Jean Georges restaurant on Central Park with Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. And on Monday night, Donald Trump joined Representative Michele Bachmann on a telephone conference call, the latest evidence for his strange king-making role in the Republican nominating race.

headline: N.B.A. and Union Meet With Mediator
text: A federal mediator met separately with officials from the N.B.A. and its players union in hopes of bringing an end to the league’s four-month long lockout. In the meetings, which lasted a few hours each, the mediator, George H. Cohen, heard arguments from both sides and asked questions of the representatives from the league and the union. He will meet the two sides together on Tuesday. Cohen’s suggestions are nonbinding, so he will have to use his powers of persuasion to get the league and the players to move closer to a deal.

headline: Italy: Hundreds of Raids, but No Arrests
text: The police conducted hundreds of raids across the country on Monday against people Deputy Interior Minister Alfredo Mantovano described as far-left anarchists. The police were searching for suspects in the riot that caused millions of dollars of damage and injured 135 people in downtown Rome during a demonstration over the weekend. The police made no arrests, however, beyond the 12 people arrested Saturday.

headline: France: Spy Agency Chief Faces Inquiry
text: Bernard Squarcini, head of the state counterespionage agency, faces further investigation on charges that he broke press freedom laws by obtaining records of a reporter’s calls in order to unmask a government mole, his lawyer said Monday. The lawyer said that the preliminary charges include violating secret correspondence and unlawfully collecting data. President Nicolas Sarkozy has denied asking the agency, the Central Directorate of Internal Intelligence, to investigate the source of information published in the newspaper Le Monde about political contributions made by the L’Oreal heiress Liliane Bettencourt.

headline: Regents Set to Alter Rules for Grading State Exams
text: Teachers in New York State will soon be banned from grading their own students’ state standardized tests, a Board of Regents committee decided on Monday, part of an effort to curtail cheating on the high-stakes exams.

headline: Live Discussion of ‘This Beautiful Life’
text: Thanks to all of you who participated in today’s discussion. Again, we apologize for the technical hiccups that may have wiped out some comments. Next up, on Tuesday, November 29, we’ll talk about Truman Capote’s classic, “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” which I invite people to reread if it’s been a while. — GB

headline: Occupy (Fill in the Blank)
text: Occupy protests around the U.S.

headline: Still Strong, Economy in China Cools Slightly
text: BEIJING — China’s economy pulled back a bit from its pell-mell pace in the third quarter, the government said Tuesday, as measures to rein in inflation and head off speculation put a brake on growth.

headline: Questions Raised Over Perry Campaign’s Reimbursements for Use of Private Plane
text: In the first two weeks of Rick Perry’s presidential campaign, his aides turned to Brian D. Pardo, a Texas businessman under investigation by federal securities regulators, to use his Cessna Citation X business jet to fly to campaign events.

headline: Corrections: October 18
text: NATIONAL

headline: Against a Winless Team, a Win Is a Win
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Every locker-room barb or play-calling criticism that emerged from the Jets’ facility last week made one thing about their game Monday abundantly clear: they had more to lose than they stood to gain.

headline: Brooklyn Artist Among Those Chosen for International Project
text: When the Brooklyn artist Kabir Carter goes to Istanbul next week he will be the first of 15 American artists chosen by the Bronx Museum of the Arts as part of a collaboration with the State Department’s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs to bring art projects to 15 foreign countries.

headline: Revis Dominates Matchup and Spoils Dolphins’ Plan
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Darrelle Revis has developed a habit of tracking opposing receivers even when the Jets’ defense is not on the field, following them step for step along the sideline, as if stalking them from across the field.

headline: Word of the Day | exuberance
text: exuberance •\ig-ˈzü-b(ə-)rən(t)s\• noun

headline: NYT Front Page for 10/18/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 10/18/2011

headline: Videos of a Texas Dust Storm Blocking Out the Sky
text: A fearsome dust storm whipped through the Panhandle and South Plains of Texas on Monday with wind gusts up to 75 miles an hour in some places, according to the National Weather Service. The wind caused some power failures and knocked out windows, and The Associated Press reported that a small cargo plane was flipped over at the Preston Smith International Airport in Lubbock.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
text: A besieged Congress party suffered a “resounding defeat” in the by-elections whose results were announced on Monday (Indian Express). As many had predicted, the Congress candidate Jai Prakash came in third in the Hisar Lok Sabha election, but the party’s loss was exacerbated by defeats in Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra and Bihar. While the Congress denied a downslide, maintaining that none of the seats were their strongholds, the BJP hailed the victory of its candidates as the “people’s verdict against a corrupt Congress government” (The Hindu).

headline: A Relegation Fight No One Wants
text: A British soccer official stirred up a hornet’s nest Monday by charging that some of the foreign owners who have bought into England’s Premier League have been meeting behind the scenes to discuss a plan to end the practice of relegation and promotion.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 6
text: Darrelle Revis’s 100-yard interception return for a touchdown got the Jets offense going in a 24-6 win over the Miami Dolphins.

headline: TimesCast | Racetrack Safety
text: An IndyCar driver's death raises questions over safety at a Las Vegas track.

headline: Israeli Soldier Swapped for Hundreds of Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM — In an elaborate prisoner exchange that could roil Middle East politics, an Israeli soldier held for more than five years by the militant Palestinian group Hamas was swapped on Tuesday for hundreds of Palestinians who have spent many years in Israeli jails, all them freed to jubilant welcomes tinged with bitterness and grief.

headline: Madras Masala
text: This has not been an auspicious time for Muthuvel Karunanidhi, the octogenarian leader of Tamil Nadu’s Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam.

headline: News Quiz | Oct. 18, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Oct. 18, 1968 | American Olympic Medal Winners Suspended for Black Power Salutes
text: On Oct. 18, 1968, the United States Olympic Committee suspended the medal-winning sprinters Tommie Smith and John Carlos from the American national team and barred them from the Olympic Village for their conduct during the playing of “The Star-Spangled Banner” at a medal ceremony at the Summer Olympics in Mexico City. Mr. Smith, who won the gold medal, and Mr. Carlos, who took bronze in the 200-meter event, wore black gloves on the podium. As the American national anthem played, the two raised their fists in a gesture of support for the black power movement.

headline: As Danger Laps at Its Shores, Tuvalu Pleads for Action
text: Tuvalu, a tiny archipelago of nine South Pacific islands threatened by rising seas, is on the front lines of the planet’s climate change debate. Current projections indicate that it will  become unlivable within 50 years, resulting in an exodus and the erasure of a rich 3,000-year-old culture.

headline: As Water Rises, There’s No Place Like (or for) Home
text: Amelia Holowaty Krales had been anxious the morning she photographed a boy in pink shorts floating in a shallow pool of coastal water, eyes closed, toes pointed up. [Slide 1.] It was the “king tide” in Tuvalu, a small archipelago in the South Pacific that is threatened by rising sea levels.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 18, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, “Park Cleanup Is Canceled, and Showdown Averted.”

headline: The Tax Reform Act of 1986: Should We Do It Again?
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book “The Benefit and the Burden.”

headline: Gerhard Richter Show in London Spans Decades
text: The work of Gerhard Richter spans decades and many styles and techniques. So it seems appropriate that a new major exhibition on the German artist at the Tate Modern in London, running through Jan. 8, is titled “Panorama.” The show includes some of Mr. Richter’s greatest works, and coincides with his 80th birthday.

headline: 36,000 Mini Cooper S Models Investigated for Fire Hazard
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether reports of engine fires constitute a problem requiring the recall of 36,000 Mini Cooper S models from the 2007 and 2008 model years. The Cooper S models are all powered by the brand’s 1.6-liter turbocharged engine.

headline: Champions League Tuesday Preview: Bayern’s Steel Curtain, and Mourinho’s Return
text: Matchday 3 in the Champions League opens with eight games and some new questions: When will Bayern Munich give up a goal? When will Manchester City and Manchester United win a game in this round? When will Inter turn things around? And where did Thorsten Fink disappear to?

headline: Correction Has Arrived for N.F.L. Passing Barrage
text: For weeks, we have been told that the N.F.L. has turned into a passing league. That the pinball-machine passing and scoring numbers were the new norm. That all the rules changes over the past three decades had left us with a game that looked more like the Arena Football League.  Then Week 6 came.

headline: Islamists Prepare for Egypt’s Election

headline: Do You Support Affirmative Action?
text: Abigail Fisher, a white woman, alleges that she was denied admission to the University of Texas because of her race. Her case has advanced and may be heard by the Supreme Court. How do you feel about the consideration of a person’s race or ethnicity in college admissions or job applications? In the name of diversity, is it fair to give one person an advantage over another?

text: Q.

headline: Behind the Class Act, a Numbers Game

headline: Even at the Laugh Factory, Losing Data Is No Laughing Matter
text: Jamie Masada will never forget the phone call last year that alerted him to the erasing of a chunk of his business and of his life. The call came from a manager at the online backup-storage company to which Mr. Masada had entrusted what might well have been the world’s most valuable collection of stand-up comedy video — 1,500 hours of acclaimed comics performing on the stage of Mr. Masada’s groundbreaking Hollywood comedy club, The Laugh Factory. Some of the video was historic, including Rodney Dangerfield’s earliest performances and stars like Dave Chapelle and Dane Cook honing their acts before hitting it big. And much of it existed only on the servers of the data storage company.

headline: Industry Flouts Bluefin Catch Limits, Study Says
text: A new study commissioned by the Pew Environment Group suggests that the fishing industry makes a mockery of efforts to regulate the catch of the endangered bluefin tuna in the Mediterranean.

headline: In Tripoli, Clinton Pledges U.S. Help to a ‘Free Libya’
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged political and economic support for Libya’s transitional government on Tuesday, even as a senior administration official warned that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his loyalists remained “a lethal nuisance” who could stall the country’s evolution.

headline: One on One: Jeff Jarvis, Author of ‘Public Parts’
text: Jeff Jarvis‘s latest book, “Public Parts,” aims to defend society’s move to public displays of personal information in an age of the Internet, social media and blogging. In the book, Mr. Jarvis argues that people should embrace what he calls publicness, rather than fear the Internet and its potential erosion of privacy. The following is an edited interview with Mr. Jarvis.

headline: Bank of America Notches $6.2 Billion Profit
text: Buoyed by one-time gains from accounting changes and the sale of assets, Bank of America reported a $6.23 billion profit for the third-quarter Tuesday, even as weakness on Wall Street hammered underlying results and the firm surrendered its position as the country’s largest bank by assets.

headline: Goldman Sachs Reports $428 Million Loss
text: Goldman Sachs, weighed down by problems in its private equity portfolio and the broader global economic woes, reported a loss of $428 million, compared with a $1.7 billion profit a year ago.

headline: Virginia Reveals Challenges Ahead for Obama
text: President Obama arrives in Virginia on his bus tour today, just as some Democratic candidates for the state legislature are running away from him.

headline: Thieves Said to Steal Truck Carrying Presidential Equipment
text: Thieves stole a truck filled with more than $200,000 worth of sound equipment, podiums and presidential seals used by President Obama, a Virginia affiliate of NBC News reports.

text: In cancer parlance I am known as an “outlier.” What that means is cancer should have ended my life years ago.

headline: Detroit Beats New York, in Baseball and in Terror Trials

headline: Did Bad Loans Continue at Bank of America After 2008?
text: Bank of America is out with earnings on Tuesday. It had net income of $6.2 billion, or 56 cents per share, but that is not the part I found most interesting in a quick review of the numbers. Instead it is the progress, or lack of same, in getting past all the bad mortgages it sold into securitizations.

headline: Hopes of Big Deal in Europe, Then Denials
text: PARIS — The roller-coaster saga of Europe’s debt crisis continued Tuesday, as hopes that Germany and France were near agreement on a big infusion of bailout money sent American stocks up in late trading.

headline: Updates on the Israeli-Palestinian Prisoner Swap
text: The prisoner swap between Israel and Hamas began on Tuesday with the exchange of an Israeli soldier, held captive for more than five years, for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as our colleagues Ethan Bronner and Stephen Farrell report. The Lede provided updates on the release of prisoners.

headline: Lookout Introduces a Security App for iPhones
text: Most iPhone users blithely believe that their phones are safe from hackers. Unlike Android phones, which have been the target of a few malicious attacks, iPhones have so far been less vulnerable because Android is growing faster and because, unlike Apple, it does not screens all apps before allowing them in its app store.

headline: Watching an Autistic Child Regress
text: Terrible pain too often accompanies mother love (and father love, for that matter). I could not let Megan Liberman’s post from Monday on Emily Rapp’s “Notes From a Dragon Mom” inch down the screen without flagging another — admittedly far less hopeless — reflection on maternal loss that I read some days ago in The Chronicle of Higher Education.

headline: Single-Family Skyscrapers Take Mumbai
text: Not far from Mukesh Ambani’s 27-storey tower, Antilia, a competing skyscraper is making its way into Mumbai’s skyline.

headline: Cornell Gains Partner in Graduate School Bid
text: Cornell University announced on Tuesday that it is joining forces with Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in its bid to build a science graduate school in New York City. Technion, a highly regarded university in Haifa that is heavily focused on computer science and electrical engineering, has been a crucial incubator for businesses in Israel’s high-tech boom.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Do You Need a Coach?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Lucy And The Eurozone Football
text: There has been a rhythm to the euro crisis: again and again, investors start to realize how bad things look, and spreads rise; then policy makers put together some sort of response, which produces a partial (but only partial) return of confidence, until it becomes clear just how inadequate that response was; then return to step one.

text: Chronic homelessness declines in New York City because of a new transitional housing program.

headline: Surprise Anti-Austerians
text: It is indeed a mixed-up, muddled-up, shook-up world. Right now, the two most prominent institutions calling for an end to the disastrous turn to short-run austerity are … Goldman Sachs and the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Views of the ’99 Percent': Corporate Power Is Up While Living Standards are Down

headline: Steam Punks
text: It was perhaps only a matter of time before the D.I.Y. ethos touched the spa world, and it has done so with style in Portland, Ore., with Löyly, a handsome, minimalist sauna in the southeast quadrant of the city. The owner, Jessica Kelso, was inspired by traditional Scandinavian bathhouses — “löyly” is Finnish for the steam produced when water is poured over sauna rocks — and wanted to bring their sense of accessibility to Stumptown. “I felt like your choices in Oregon were a hippie hot springs experience or really spendy, overly attentive spa experiences, neither of which had ever appealed to me,” she says. The Löyly vibe is one of communal shvitzing rather than solitary pampering. A $15 fee gets you access to an elegantly designed cedar sauna, wet steam room and lounge; though massages and facials are available by appointment, scrubs, salts, masks and foot soaks are do-it-yourself. The place has become as popular with corporate types as it is with the city’s artists, musicians and restaurant servers. “Everyone looks the same wrapped in a white towel,” Kelso says, “although we do see a lot of tattoos in Portland.”

headline: Our Blogs, Ourselves
text: Ryan Avent and I have been corresponding about the role of the economics blogosphere, for the Christmas issue of The Economist. I don’t know what parts of our conversation will actually show up there, but having assembled my thoughts I might as well put some of them up here.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Wine Review Online: Get to know assyrtiko, the great white wine of Santorini. Ed McCarthy takes us on tour. — Eric Asimov

headline: Just What the Jets Ordered
text: Welcome to what can officially be described as the N.F.L.’s season of dysfunction, the final requirement for that distinction being reached sometime in the Jets’ 24-6 victory over Miami on Monday night. One team looked barely motivated to get off its own bench, managed 5 whole passing yards in the first quarter, and expended far less energy on offense than its players did squawking at one another all week. And that was the team that won.

headline: Ex-Inmate Shares Stories of Stint as a Death Row Chef
text: Last month, Texas prison officials decided to end the tradition of special meals for inmates facing execution after Lawrence Russell Brewer, 44, requested a large dinner before his Sept. 21 lethal injection. Mr. Brewer, a white supremacist gang member, had been convicted of chaining James Byrd, Jr., a 49-year-old black man, to a pickup truck and dragging him along a road until he died. As his final meal, Mr. Brewer had requested a pound of barbecue with half a loaf of white bread; three fajitas “with fixings”; a cheese omelet with “ground beef, tomatoes, onions, bell peppers and jalapenos”; two chicken fried steaks “smothered in gravy with sliced onions”; a “triple meat” bacon cheeseburger with “fixings on the side”; a “large bowl” of fried okra; a “meat lovers” pizza; a pint of vanilla ice cream; a “slab” of peanut butter fudge with crushed peanuts; and three root beers. He was given some of the items, in smaller portions, but ate nothing. After the state’s decision, Brian D. Price, 60, a former inmate who as jailhouse chef cooked last meals for 218 prisoners on death row in Huntsville, Tex., offered to prepare meals for the condemned for free. Texas said thanks but no thanks. Mr. Price discusses:

text: Seventy days after he finished second in the Olympic marathon at the Athens Games in 2004, Meb Keflezighi took second in the New York City Marathon in what was then a personal-best 2 hours 9 minutes 53 seconds.

headline: A Year in the Work of Calder
text: Some of the best-known photographs of Alexander Calder, taken in 1941 by his friend Herbert Matter, show Calder in the high-windowed studio he fashioned next to a cow pasture in Roxbury, Conn., surrounded by such an explosion of sculpture and sheet-metal scraps that it looks as if a small airplane had just crashed into the site.

headline: Where Do You Rank Among the 99 (or 1) Percent?
text: Updated 12:14 p.m. to switch $846.4 trillion to billion. This is an error of the Kiplinger tool, and we’ve informed them of the miscalculation. Kiplinger says the error has been fixed.

headline: Despite Millions of Record Sales, UB40 Members Are Bankrupt
text: Four original members of UB40, the British reggae band that sold more than 70 million records, have been declared bankrupt by a judge in Britain, the BBC and Billboard reported. A judge in the Birmingham County court said government tax officers could seize the band’s assets and property to pay off outstanding debts in a ruling against the saxophonist Brian Travers, the drummer Jimmy Brown, the trumpeter Terence Oswald and the percussionist Norman Hassan.

headline: LinkedIn Wants to Make More Money From Job Recruiters

headline: Parents Urged Again to Limit TV for Youngest
text: Parents of infants and toddlers should limit the time their children spend in front of televisions, computers, self-described educational games and even grown-up shows playing in the background, the American Academy of Pediatrics warned on Tuesday. Video screen time provides no educational benefits for children under age 2 and leaves less room for activities that do, like interacting with other people and playing, the group said.

headline: Much-Needed Win for Jets, but What Does It Mean?

headline: Winter Vegetable Soupe au Pistou
text: This is a big, simple soup made with winter vegetables – all diced small and thrown into a big pot with water and simmered for an hour. It’s garnished with the Provençal version of pesto, which does not contain any pine nuts. It makes a hearty meal.

headline: A Boss Collection for a New Jersey University
text: A collection of documents, articles and books about Bruce Springsteen’s career that has been growing for years at the Asbury Park Public Library will be moved to nearby Monmouth University in West Long Branch, N.J., the university said.

headline: Friends Still Let Friends Drive Drunk
text: On Sept. 15, Matthew Grape, 21, got into the passenger seat of a car with one of his Duke University fraternity brothers. The driver hit a tree, escaping with minor injuries, but killing his dear friend. According to local press reports, the driver was charged with impaired driving.

headline: Publishing Perils in the Digital Age
text: These are uncertain times for many established writers, as the case of the Hawaiian novelist Kiana Davenport shows. Until recently she had a deal with Riverhead Books, a literary line that is a division of Penguin, for a Civil War novel, “The Chinese Soldier’s Daughter.” Ms. Davenport received an initial $20,000 advance for the tale, which was scheduled for publication next summer. That wasn’t enough money to survive on, so the writer cast about for another source of income, and self-published a book of old stories on Amazon. The result: Her novel has been canceled, the publisher wants its money back, and her publishing career is in jeopardy.

headline: More On Climate and Energy Procrastination
text: Here are three reactions to my post about Machiavelli’s view of the impediments to making big changes in societies — as in the asymmetrical nature of the battle to take the carbon out of energy systems in the face of both societal inertia and intensive efforts by entrenched interests to maintain the status quo. The first two remarks came in a group e-mail exchange and so relate to each other.

headline: Eichmann Drama Opening in Boston, With Broadway in Mind
text: The respected character actor Michael Cristofer will play Adolf Eichmann, locked in a battle of wills and wits with Mossad agents in 1960 Buenos Aires, in the new drama “Captors” at the Huntington Theater Company this fall, the company said on Tuesday. An outside team of commercial producers has already secured the rights to transfer the work to Broadway, which they hope to do during the 2011-12 season after the end of the Huntington run, a spokeswoman for the theater added.

headline: How Essential Is Indian Point?
text: As I reported in Tuesday’s paper, opponents of the Indian Point nuclear power plant assert that its two reactors can be retired in the next few years because alternatives exist that pose less risk and would not cost substantially more. New York City’s position, however, is that retiring the reactors would raise prices sharply and reduce reliability.

headline: Mark McNairy Makes Us Smile (Again)
text: Gentleman of varying persuasions of style are already familiar with the name Mark McNairy. Shoes from the designer’s footwear collection,  Mark McNairy New Amsterdam, and tailored pieces from the Ivy League-inspired outfitter J. Press, where McNairy was formerly creative director, have made their way into an eclectic mix of closets, from traditional to trendy. When it was announced this summer that McNairy would introduce a complete line of subversive-preppy clothes and accessories for men in the spring, all those fans cheered, and now — it’s official — he’s doing women’s wear, too. Inspired by his daughter, Daisy, the 50-piece collection is charmingly boyish, but (very McNairy) sexily so, with oxford shirts paired with boyfriend boxers and rugby tanks over miniskirts. Echoes of some of the men’s line motifs — a daisy print, an exploded camouflage and a floral-on-plaid shirt — mix easily with more overtly feminine pieces, like the ditsy Laura Ashley-like button-down. “Basically, I make women’s clothes from a guy’s point of view,” McNairy says. “It has nothing to do with fashion — they’re items that transcend trend.”

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Au Hasard Balthazar’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Robert Bresson’s 1966 drama “Au Hasard Balthazar,” which tells the story of a donkey in rural France and the girl who loves him. Mr. Scott points out that the film isn’t a fairy tale about an animal with human qualities, but rather “an unsettling and tragic examination of some of the deepest mysteries of existence.” Balthazar is the name of the donkey who is adopted by a family and befriended by Marie (Anne Wiazemsky).

headline: The Quandary Posed by a New Down Syndrome Test

headline: Lessons From the Financial Crisis
text: BOSTON — What did the financial crisis teach central bankers?

headline: For the Keystone Battle, a Folk Hero
text: Randy Thompson, a laconic cattle buyer, may seem an unlikely symbol of activism. Yet his likeness is now on hundreds of T-shirts across Nebraska.

headline: Documents: Mortgages and Gas Leases
text: Over the past year, bankers, credit union officials, insurers, real estate experts and appraisers have raised questions about the potential impacts that oil and gas leases have on residential and farm mortgages. The following is a collection of documents that relate to these issues, with key sections highlighted and annotated to explain their meaning.

headline: Which Americans Are Most Generous, and to Whom
text: The richest Americans give a greater share of their income to charities than low- and middle-income Americans do, but the mix of beneficiaries is decidedly different, according to congressional testimony from Frank J. Sammartino, the assistant director for tax analysis from the Congressional Budget Office.

text: Last month we announced a new feature: the The Learning Network Reading Club, an opportunity for students to read, and discuss online, a relevant, provocative long-form Times article.

headline: Offenses Point to High-Scoring World Series
text: ST. LOUIS — In the 1932 World Series, when the Yankees swept the Chicago Cubs, the teams combined to average 14 runs per game. All these years later, withstanding strong challenges from the designated hitter and the steroids era, those 14 runs per game remain a World Series record.

headline: Following Troops, Kenyan Officials Go to Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenyan officials made a surprise visit to Somalia on Tuesday to reassure the weak Somali government that Kenya was not harboring intentions to occupy Somalia, despite sending hundreds of troops across the border over the weekend.

headline: Iran Says Saudi Plot Defendant Belongs to Exile Group
text: Iran injected a new twist on Tuesday into the week-old American accusation of an Iranian plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador to Washington, asserting that one of the defendants really belongs to an outlawed and exiled opposition group.

headline: ABC and CBS Share Ratings Spoils
text: ABC and CBS settled for a split ratings victory on Monday night as “Dancing With the Stars” averaged 17.5 million total viewers over a two-hour period and led ABC to the highest total audience. CBS claimed the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, though “Two and a Half Men” continued to fall from its lofty early-season perch to 14.9 million total viewers, down another million viewers from last week. One more drop of that size and the show will be in the same Charlie Sheen territory as last year.

headline: London’s Latest ‘In’ Spot | The Arts Club
text: London may be brimming with private members’ clubs, but its latest — the newly revamped Arts Club in Mayfair — is creating quite a stir. Founded in 1863 by a group of friends (including Charles Dickens), the formerly fusty establishment has reopened with Gwyneth Paltrow (an investor) as its creative director. The stylish Art Deco-inspired interior designed by David D’Almada features marble floors, cashmere walls and art by Tomas Saraceno, John Baldessari and George Condo. Boldface names like Cameron Diaz, Mario Testino and Charlotte Dellal have been spotted supping in the restaurant, and Paltrow is known to belt out a few tunes at Club Nouveau, the nightclub downstairs that’s run by Mark Ronson. Also on the mike at times are Ronnie Wood, Mica Paris and Noel Gallagher. It costs £1,000 to join, the same fee applies each year, and the first list closes on Oct. 31. Being famous and fabulous is not a requirement, but it doesn’t hurt to be either, or both.

headline: Adventures In Credibility
text: Menzie Chinn takes us through the “Real American Jobs Act”, which is every bit as ludicrous as one might imagine. What caught my eye, however, is who the GOP is leaning on for economic validation: namely the Heritage Foundation.

headline: Sharp Criticism for Egyptian Interview With Soldier
text: CAIRO — An exclusive interview by Egyptian state television with Sgt. First Class Gilad Shalit of Israel  — fresh from captivity, and before he had seen his family — provoked strong but polar opposite reactions on both sides of the Israel-Egypt border.

headline: After Hiding, He Becomes a Celebrity
text: Symbol alert! Ali Smith’s new novel opens with a perplexing prologue: a story within a story about a man on an exercise bike whose eyes and mouth are covered by what look like mailbox flaps. A small boy appears, jimmies the flaps off with a dinner knife and instructs the man in how to make a paper airplane. The man complies and discovers that “outside, on its top, it looks like a plain folded piece of paper. Inside, underneath, it is packed tight into itself with surprising neatness like origami, like a small machine.”

headline: Live Blogging the CNN Debate in Las Vegas
text: Seven of the Republican candidates for president will gather again tonight for the eighth debate of the year and the first held in the West.

headline: Old Havana, Souped Up and Sexy
text: Usually, when an M.C. asks, “Do you want to dance?,” the question is a prod. When the Cuban choreographer Roclan González Chavez posed it at the end of his “Kings of Salsa” concert on Sunday afternoon, the answer had already been confirmed. It seemed that half the audience at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts had been onstage already, demonstrating how it’s done in the Bronx. Getting this crowd on its feet took no persuasion at all, which was fortunate for Mr. Chavez, since just sitting and watching his show was a frustrating experience.

headline: Disgruntled Palmer Is Traded at Deadline
text: The N.F.L. trade deadline is normally a somnolent affair, just a few moves involving disgruntled and mostly forgotten players. But the Cincinnati Bengals and the Oakland Raiders rocked the league Tuesday with quarterback Carson Palmer, who had threatened to retire rather than play again for the Bengals, moving to the Raiders in exchange for a first-round draft pick and another pick that could become a first-rounder.

headline: Red Bulls’ Soler Looks Back and Peeks Ahead

A win Thursday against Philadelphia at Red Bull Arena would send the Red Bulls to the postseason as the 10th and final qualifier.

Buy this, says a Gartner endorsement, and you’ll be moving with the rest of our forward-looking clientele. That is a big deal; even though $3.6 trillion is spent on information technology a year, few executives want to feel as if they are moving too fast or too slow.

text: “Paul Goodman Changed My Life” pays tribute to a man — poet, teacher, social critic, guru without portfolio — whose name was once a household word and whose books were talismans of intellectual seriousness and social concern. His current obscurity is something this documentary, directed by Jonathan Lee and including eloquent testimony from friends, family and admirers, is determined to overcome.

headline: Spring Ahead | Electric Pastels
text: Right now fall is favoring cool-factor shocks of bright, neon colors. But the spring collections took a different approach, revisiting pretty with pastels that, thankfully, aren’t too jejune. Everyone from Ralph Lauren to L’Wren Scott and Diane Von Furstenberg chose to dress women — grown women — in tones of mint, lemony yellow and sorbet pink. Meanwhile, at Marni, Christopher Kane and Rochas classic silhouettes had a retro tinge with swirls of ’60s-era daisies. Louis Vuitton delighted in remodeling things like boyish biker jackets in chickadee yellow and Easter egg blue. “I wanted to add another dimension to the neons and thought that washing out some of those vivid colors would add an interesting contrast,” says the designer Jill Stuart, whose Art Deco Miami dresses were coated in colors like macaroon pink and sea foam green.

headline: Is ‘Choice’ Less Accepted for Mothers?
text: The subset of women in America who most frequently make use of abortion services, writes Lauren Sandler in Slate this week, are … mothers. In 2008, according to the Guttmacher Institute, 61 percent of women who terminated their pregnancies already had at least one child. And in the period since the economic woes of the recession started hitting families, the National Abortion Federation reported to Ms. Sandler, fully 72 percent of clients who came seeking abortion services were mothers.

headline: Carlo of ‘Sesame Street,’ on Being an Illegal Immigrant in Real Life
text: Carlo Albán: nice American boy. Carlo Albán: illegal immigrant. When he was in high school, Mr. Albán was both, not to mention frequently stoned and a regular cast member of “Sesame Street.”

headline: House Reopens Case Against Jackson in Blagojevich Case
text: The House Ethics Committee, after a two-year delay, has reopened its investigation into whether Representative Jesse Jackson Jr. conducted a “public campaign” in late 2008 to secure an appointment to President Obama’s former Senate seat in Illinois, and perhaps broke House rules in the process.

headline: Duke Foundation To Aid Artists
text: The Doris Duke Charitable Foundation will award $50 million over 10 years to more than 200 performing artists, dance companies, theaters and presenters, the foundation is to announce on Thursday. Rather than allotting funds for specific projects as foundations typically do, the Doris Duke Performing Artists Initiative will invest in artists’ future work with flexible multiyear cash awards of as much as $275,000, starting next year. The program will offer more support to artists through residencies. Artists cannot apply for the funds; they will be chosen through an anonymous peer-review process. But the residencies will be open to joint applications from both artists and organizations. The foundation hopes to encourage artists to take creative risks, explore new ideas and address needs like health care and retirement savings.

headline: A Rare Rhapsody and Other Russian Pleasures
text: Sorting out the world of Russian orchestras can seem like a trip down the rabbit hole. The young, energetic ensemble that performed at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening was billed as the St. Petersburg Symphony Orchestra, a group directed by Alexander Titov but led here by Vladimir Lande, its principal guest conductor. But it is more properly the St. Petersburg State Academic Symphony Orchestra, a group founded in 1967 as the Orchestra of Ancient and Modern Music and known briefly (from 1985 until the end of the Soviet era) as the Leningrad State Orchestra.

headline: My Three Favorite Collections of Private Papers
text: To check Debbie Nathan’s piece on the multiple-personality postergirl Sybil, a photo researcher and I headed to the special collections room at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, which houses transcripts of Sybil’s psychotherapy sessions. Going through the boxes of Sybil’s late biographer, Flora Rheta Schreiber, which also contain her personal letters and photographs, impressed me with the intimacy of such collections. Here are some striking private details from the archives of three great public figures.

headline: Calder at Pace Gallery

headline: 36 Lawmakers Berate State Dept. on Pipeline

headline: Apple’s Profit Gains 54%, but iPhone Sales Fall Short of Expectations
text: For any other big company, a 54 percent increase in profit and a 39 percent jump in revenue would be enviable. For Apple though, weak sales of its star product — the iPhone — were enough to overshadow everything else when it reported fourth-quarter results on Tuesday, sending the company’s shares tumbling nearly 7 percent in after-hours trading.

headline: Chasing Opportunity in an Age of Upheaval
text: Nicolas Berggruen is passionate about investing. A compact, handsome billionaire, Mr. Berggruen is often talked about for his eccentricities — he does not own a home, preferring to jet around the world and live out of hotels — but his ability to find, invest in and turn around neglected companies points to a hardened and savvy approach.

headline: Protests Are a Payday for Security Firms
text: They call when they make the Forbes 400 list. They call when annual hedge fund rankings appear, when their names are mentioned on CNBC and when their children travel abroad. And, these days, they call when protesters camped in Lower Manhattan grow uncomfortable with the idea of their existence.

headline: Exotic Investments That Offer Gains, but Also Pose Risks
text: Stocks are scary these days and too risky for many investors. Cash instruments and government bonds have yields close to their lowest levels ever. That combination could heighten interest in the myriad funds that focus on exotic, none-of-the-above assets.

headline: In Uncertain Times, Municipal Bonds Call for Caution
text: When the prominent banking analyst Meredith Whitney predicted late last year that “hundreds of billions of dollars” of municipal bond defaults would occur in 2011, it rattled the nearly $3 trillion market.

headline: Take Advantage of Tax Breaks Now, Experts Say
text: In Washington’s war of words over economic and tax policy, Republicans and Democrats are aiming increasingly hostile barbs at each other that are leaving investors and business owners uncertain, even confused, about what tax and business strategies to pursue, according to financial advisers.

headline: Frieze Frame | Ken Okiishi’s Manhattan Transfer
text: The Frame section of the Frieze Art Fair, curated by Cecilia Alemani and Rodrigo Moura, made space for experimentation on the fair’s fringes in the form of 25 solo artist presentations presented by a younger batch of international galleries. Among them was Alex Zachary, one of New York’s most idiosyncratic galleries both in terms of space and location. (It has been operating out of a multilevel, formerly residential condominium a couple of blocks from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.) Fittingly, the artist Ken Okiishi’s project at Zachary’s Frame booth was a curious meditation on the psychogeography of Manhattan real estate and mythologies of uptown bohemia. Eulogizing the recently shuttered Lexington Avenue establishment Gino as a point of departure (which over time has hosted luminaries as diverse as Sophia Loren, I. M. Pei and Robin Byrd), Okiishi began by outfitting the booth in the iconic Scalamandré-designed zebra wallpaper that made its debut in the restaurant’s dining room circa 1930. He applied the same print to parasols bolted to the walls, whose slow and steady motorized twirling evoked bygone pageantry and ritziness. Faux-antique photographs of an early-20th-century apartment were hung beside the umbrellas; in actuality these were digital images lifted from the present-day Streeteasy.com listing for a unit on West 67th Street that was once home to Marcel Duchamp, from 1916 to 1918. East Side, West Side, Depression era, recession era: Okiishi’s project drew foggy connections between places and times that are factually disparate but psychically proximate. These artifacts repurposed as ready-mades contribute to a meandering mental map of the city that relies on legends like Duchamp (and Gino’s) as its compass.

headline: It Was Real, Cradle to Grave. Or Was It Just TV?
text: Mine was a short life but an eventful one. So bizarre and unpredictable was it that I sometimes wonder if it was a dream, a thing experienced yet not experienced, like a stadium rock concert that you mostly watch on the overhead screen because your seats are so far from the stage. To tell you the truth, I’m kind of glad it’s over, since it was exhausting. Let me tell you about it.

headline: In Dead Zone of Chernobyl, Animal Kingdom Thrives
text: In the months since the Japanese tsunami, we’ve heard a lot about Chernobyl as a worst-case example: here’s how bad Fukushima could have been. Now PBS’s “Nature” offers another vision: Chernobyl as a best-case demonstration that life abides despite the human race’s efforts to eradicate it. As long as the life in question isn’t ours, that is.

headline: Scandinavian Food Before It Was Fashionable
text: NOT to gloat, of course, but the resurgence of interest in Scandinavian food is something I have been anticipating for a long, long time. Currently the cuisine is termed “Nordic,” as championed by the celebrated Copenhagen chef René Redzepi, who will discuss his inventive cooking style at the Union Square Greenmarket on Saturday. He and his disciples swear by ingredients that are local, seasonal and, preferably, wild. Nordic also has a nice exotic ring, summoning visions of Greenlanders and Laplanders fishing through ice, simmering up blubber confits and salt-curing chunks of Donner and Blitzen.

headline: Get Away? Not by the Hairs on Their Chinny Chin Chins
text: Before you tune in A&E’s newest show, think for a moment about the message you’re sending to Marg Helgenberger, Emily VanCamp and Mariska Hargitay. You’re telling these lovely and presumably hard-working actresses, who all have shows in the same time slot, “I’d rather look at hogs than look at you.”

headline: A Priest and His Buddy on a Downstream Journey
text: “The Catechism Cataclysm”: did you repeat that twisty little title until you tripped over your tongue? Or, better yet, did you just challenge someone near you to say it three times in a row? The answer may be a good indicator of whether you’ll find this regressively oddball buddy picture infectiously playful or just plain irritating.

headline: Battle For Libya | October 18, 2011
text: Fighting in Surt continued Tuesday, while Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged political and economic support for Libya’s new transitional government in Tripoli.

headline: Baby Beets: Cute, Sweet and Handy
text: Love Beets are baby beets cooked and seasoned with honey and ginger; balsamic vinegar and white wine; olive oil and chiles or plain mild vinegar. The flavorings give the naturally sweet roots nice personality (the plain vinegar flavor was less appealing). The beets are convenient for hors d’oeuvres, salads, side dishes or for slicing into sandwiches. They are sold refrigerated in a resealable package.

headline: Reviewing Prime & Beyond
text: Prime & Beyond serves great steaks, but it also offers a rare opportunity to taste what Korean barbecue is like when made with USDA prime meat. Bulgogi (thin-sliced steak) and kalbi (short ribs) have a rich, succulent depth that you don’t often taste at the DIY BBQ joints on 32nd Street. And the burger, although plain — not a “bulgogi burger” marinated with garlic, sesame, and sugar — is fantastic, served Korean-style, with rice, kimchi, and a softly fried egg to bind all together.

headline: As Economy Goes, So Go Takeovers, Even as Bargains Abound
text: The merger market is like a pack of lemmings. If the economy is good , the takeover market will follow, but when times are bad, the market stalls.

headline: Hard Feelings Test Hope in Israel-Hamas Deal
text: JERUSALEM — Just off the bus in Gaza after six years in an Israeli prison, one of hundreds traded to Hamas for an Israeli soldier, Wafa al-Bass declared her next goal: abduct more Israeli soldiers. Others who returned said they could not feel satisfaction until the thousands of remaining Palestinian prisoners were freed.

headline: European Bailout Plan May Not Satisfy Markets
text: Bailing out Europe’s banks may be less expensive than governments feared and investors hoped. European Union officials are discussing a plan that would require lenders to hit a demanding core Tier 1 capital ratio of 9 percent, but would not require them to factor in the effects of a deep recession. A lower-than-expected bill is good for the finances of euro zone governments, but may not be enough to win back the market’s confidence.

headline: Commander Who Pepper-Sprayed Protesters Faces Disciplinary Charge

headline: What’s Your Favorite Vegetarian Dish for Entertaining?

headline: At Protest Central, Sleep, if You Can
text: It was 4:30 a.m. when Nocturnalist awoke to a kneecap hitting our shin. Mired in sleep, we were disoriented — where were we? The necrotic chill of the slab of pavement we lay on suddenly registered and we snapped awake: It was Monday at Zuccotti Park, Occupy Wall Street’s de facto headquarters. With hundreds of people flocking to the park, a half-acre plaza in the financial district where the protest movement has made its encampment for the past month, it seemed incumbent upon Nocturnalist to check out what has arguably become a hot new nightspot.
