headline: True to Mailer’s Life, a Brawl Over the Sale of His Brooklyn Heights Apartment
text: Norman Mailer’s Brooklyn Heights apartment has seen its share of fighting.

headline: Where Teenagers Find the Jury Isn’t Rigged
text: On Friday, Fixes examined the Youth Court of the District of Columbia, a forum where first-time nonviolent teenage offenders are judged by others who have been in the same situation.   The D.C. Youth Court is one of the largest of some 1,000 youth courts around the country.   These courts are designed to help minor offenders avoid a criminal record and stay out of juvenile justice — traditionally an efficient production line for criminality.

headline: Rhode Island: Judge Rules for Unions in Pension Suit
text: Labor unions won the first round of a potentially significant challenge to pension reform on Tuesday, with a Rhode Island state judge ruling that there is an implied contract between the state pension system and the employees who stand to benefit from it. In 2010, eight public employee unions sued the state, arguing that reducing pension benefits for workers with more than 10 years of service violated their contractual rights. The state had tried to have the suit dismissed. The ruling may complicate the state’s pension reform efforts, which will be the focus of a special legislative session next month.

headline: As City Plants Trees, Some Say a Million Are Too Many
text: In a city of steel and concrete, a single tree offers a burst of green, a cooling canopy and an antidote for frayed nerves. It seems as if nobody is against one tree. But try planting a million of them.

headline: Bystanders’ Neglect of Injured Toddler Sets Off Soul-Searching on Web Sites in China
text: BEIJING — Last Thursday, a van navigating the narrow streets of a hardware market in Foshan, in the southern province of Guangdong, struck and ran over a 2-year-old girl. The driver paused, then drove away. A surveillance camera showed that the toddler lay grievously injured for seven minutes, ignored by at least 18 passers-by, while a second vehicle ran over the child and drove on. A 57-year-old rag collector finally went to her aid.

headline: A Night in Zuccotti Park
text: The Nocturnalist camps out with Occupy Wall Street protesters.

headline: It Didn’t Add Up
text: The Obama administration was wise to suspend a long-term care insurance program that was part of its health care reform package. The program, which was to be financed by the premiums paid by enrollees, seemed unlikely to remain financially solvent in coming decades.

headline: New Malicious Program by Creators of Stuxnet Is Suspected
text: The designers of Stuxnet, the computer worm that was used to vandalize an Iranian nuclear site, may have struck again, security researchers say.

headline: Clip: ‘Tower Heist’
text: A scene from the new comedy with Ben Stiller and Eddie Murphy, opening November 4.

headline: Taking Big Risks to See a Chinese Dissident Under House Arrest
text: BEIJING — They have been pummeled with sticks or chased by rock-throwing security agents. Some have been beaten, robbed and dumped in remote farm fields without cellphones or money.

headline: Gilad Shalit’s Release
text: We share the joy of Israelis over the release of Sgt. First Class Gilad Shalit, who was held by Hamas for five years. We will leave it to the Israeli people to debate whether the deal — which includes the release of more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners — will make their country safer or lead to more violence or more abductions of Israeli soldiers or other citizens.

headline: Despite Victory, Concerns About Jets Remain
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On a conference call Tuesday, Rex Ryan uttered two of the more baffling statements of his tenure, one right after the other.

headline: Release Date in U.S. Set for New Sony Mobile Game Console
text: Jack Tretton, the president and chief executive of Sony Computer Entertainment America, announced Tuesday that the company’s PlayStation Vita mobile gaming device would go on sale in the United States on Feb. 22, 2012.

headline: Goldman Loss Offers a Bad Omen for Wall Street
text: Goldman Sachs, once Wall Street’s highest flier, has been grounded, and it does not bode well for the rest of the financial industry or the New York City economy that depends on it.

headline: U.S. Weighs Its Strategy on Warfare in Cyberspace
text: WASHINGTON — The four-star Air Force general who oversees Pentagon efforts in cyberspace acknowledged Tuesday that the Defense Department had more work to do in clarifying the military’s doctrine for waging offensive computer warfare and setting up rules of engagement to guide specific cyberattacks.

headline: Rangers Turn to Wilson, Their Ace and Student of the Game
text: ST. LOUIS — While shopping years ago at the South Coast Plaza mall in Costa Mesa, Calif., the Hall of Fame pitcher Jim Palmer strolled through the men’s department at Nordstrom. He got more than the duvet he was looking for.

headline: Leaner Airline Industry Is Profitable
text: The airline industry is leaner and earning money.

headline: Some Risks as Obama Confronts Congress
text: EMPORIA, Va. — For the last several weeks, President Obama has railed against the “do-nothing Congress.” Not content with that, he is now needling it as the “know-nothing Congress.”

headline: Big East’s Fate: Others Control Ball
text: After the Big East staved off football extinction in 2003, the league became familiar with reading its own obituaries.

headline: Lawsuit Seeks Release of Police Commissioner’s Schedule
text: A civil liberties group filed a lawsuit on Tuesday seeking to force the New York Police Department to release the daily schedules of Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly.

headline: Civil Rights and Resisting Arrest
text: The arrest of a New York City police officer, who was accused of violating the civil rights of an African-American man during a stop-and-frisk arrest, provides good reason for Justice Department officials and state lawmakers to investigate whether others on the force are engaging in similar practices.

headline: Bank of America Loses Title as Biggest in U.S.
text: For Bank of America, it is the end of an era.

headline: A Fierce Clash for Romney and Perry as Republican Candidates Debate
text: LAS VEGAS — Mitt Romney came under intensive attack from his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination at a debate here Tuesday night, with a newly assertive Rick Perry leading a sometimes personal barrage against him on conservative consistency, health care policy and even the immigration status of yard workers at his home.

headline: Q. and A.: Tom Morello Offers ‘a Record of Rousing Hopelessness’
text: Tom Morello has always written protest music. It is his aesthetic, his raison d’etre, his trademark. His politics are famously far left and incendiary. In the 1990s, he was the guitarist and one of the ideological forces behind Rage Against the Machine, the hard rock band that did social commentary during a period in American history when few were protesting.

headline: Q. and A.: Everlast Sees the ‘Ungrateful Living’ All Around Him
text: Some events change a man’s perspective. In the last three years, Everlast says, he toured Iraq to play for the troops and watched with increasing rage as old friends and family members struggled financially after the mortgage crisis and stock market crash. He also married, and he and his wife had a daughter who they learned has cystic fibrosis.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Q. and A.: Ry Cooder on Woody Guthrie, Politics and a New Album
text: Ry Cooder’s been called a lot of things: a “musician’s musician” and a “musical archeologist”; a virtuoso of rock and blues guitar; and an explorer of international styles. But no one has ever labeled Mr. Cooder, 64, a folksinger. No one has accused him of singing protest songs and serving up social commentaries in the tradition of Woody Guthrie, Pete Seeger, Phil Ochs or Bob Dylan. Mr. Cooder’s most recent album, “Pull Up Some Dust and Sit Down” (Nonesuch), may change that perception.

headline: Battle for a Holdout City Stalls Healing in Libya
text: SURT, Libya — The commander, defying a shower of bullets, urged his men to train their heavy weapons on a nest of pro-Qaddafi snipers in a school down the street. But then someone said that the loyalists had asked to surrender, and he told his men to hold their fire. It was a hopeful moment. After weeks of violence, the fighters were exhausted, the city was destroyed and hundreds of civilians were trapped in their homes in the area.

headline: Harold Leppo, a President of Lord & Taylor, Dies at 74
text: Harold Leppo, who oversaw Lord & Taylor’s expansion into a national department store chain as its president during the 1970s and ’80s, died on Friday in Stamford, Conn. He was 74.

headline: Great From Day 1, Pujols Draws Superlatives On and Off the Field
text: ST. LOUIS — Ty Cobb hit .240 as a rookie. Willie Mays started 1 for 26. With Albert Pujols, there was no progression. From the moment he arrived in the major leagues, on opening day 2001, he was the best player in the game. Three Most Valuable Player awards and three World Series into his career, he still is.

headline: 4 People Are Found Held Captive in Basement
text: PHILADELPHIA — Scraps from their captivity still littered the basement boiler room where they had been held: A sneaker, some plastic cups, stained blankets and a mayonnaise jar filled with urine.

headline: Imagined in America
text: Hong Kong

headline: Europe Cautiously Signals Its Displeasure Over a Prosecution in Ukraine
text: BRUSSELS — After the sentencing of Ukraine’s opposition leader, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the European Union on Tuesday abruptly put off a meeting with the country’s president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, in the clearest sign yet that efforts to integrate Ukraine, a former Soviet republic, more closely with Western Europe are stalling.

headline: N.B.A. Talks Pause After 16-Hour Marathon Meeting
text: With a federal mediator prodding them along, and the stakes increasing by the day, negotiators for the N.B.A. and its players union returned to the bargaining table for a marathon session that began early Tuesday and bled into Wednesday morning.

headline: Candidate’s Fighting Words Draw G.O.P.’s Fire
text: BOSTON — In her nascent Senate campaign, Elizabeth Warren has captivated the national Democratic base with her scrappy populist rhetoric, most notably in a viral YouTube video in which she exhorts wealthy business owners to pay their fair share of taxes on the grounds that “there is nobody in this country who got rich on his own.”

headline: Glad Cuts the Hyperbole for Its New Green Trash Bag
text: HOW much are marketers of green products scaling back ambitious efforts to sell eco-friendlier brands as life-changers and planet-savers? Well, a line of recycled paper products, introduced by Marcal in 2009, bears the name Small Steps rather than something grander like Giant Leaps.

headline: A Melodic Emblem Falls Out of Tune
text: PARIS — Since 1856, the four major bells atop the northern towers of the Cathedral of Notre-Dame have rung every 15 minutes, without fail. They rang for the end of World War I and the liberation of Paris in 1944. Most recently, they chimed in honor of the victims of 9/11.

headline: Senate Saves the Potato on School Lunch Menus
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate stood up Tuesday for the humble white potato and rebuffed an effort by President Obama to limit its consumption by millions of schoolchildren around the country.

headline: Gloom Grips Consumers, and It May Be Home Prices
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Ernest Markey lost his stone-cutting business in 2009. He then sold his home for half a million dollars less than its value at the peak of the housing bubble and moved with his wife, Marie, to a smaller home in a less affluent suburb. They gave up two new cars and bought one. Used.

headline: Prophecy of Machines
text: Is music technology?

headline: RIM Unveils an Upgrade, but Little Else
text: OTTAWA — Research in Motion unveiled little more than a rebranding of what it called its “next generation platform” for BlackBerry smartphones and tablet on Tuesday at its software developers’ conference, disappointing many analysts.

headline: Gay Pastor in New York Urges Change in Malaysia
text: The Rev. Boon Lin Ngeo, a Malaysian Protestant pastor whose message of tolerance for homosexuals has drawn fire in his country, sat with his male partner on a lime-green sofa inside the Office of the City Clerk in New York on a late summer day, where they waited their turn to be married.

headline: Two Competing Theories in Bloomberg Consultant’s Trial
text: In his closing argument on Tuesday, Dennis C. Vacco took aim at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, his voice rising with each sentence as he insisted that the mayor’s cohort was desperate for him to win re-election in 2009 and as he questioned the credibility of the mayor himself.

headline: A Story of Drugs and the Police
text: Because Yvelisse DeLeon of Coney Island was due at an interview for a bartending job on the evening of Jan. 25, 2007, she spent part of the afternoon getting herself ready. That process included a trip to Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Wednesday: Day Three of the Crossword Contest
text: Administrivial Heads Up For Friday! The Friday, October 21 crossword puzzle will be available at the normal time and place, but will have a format that will not be available in Across Lite. However, we will be offering a PDF version that you will need to print out to solve. That version will be available here on the blog and the Premium Puzzle Page on Thursday, October 20 at 10 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: Inquiry Faults City’s Insertion of Political View in Parents’ Petition Over School Cuts
text: It all began with a parent’s suggestion: Why not draft a petition for parents and students to sign and send to Albany protesting cuts in state aid to city schools?

headline: Officer Guilty in a Strange Hunt for Treasure
text: After learning two years ago that officials had foiled a plot by a rogue New York City police officer to jolt him with a stun gun and burglarize his apartment in Inwood, Jason B. Holt faced a question: Should he leave the building?

headline: Latinos Said to Bear Weight of a Deportation Program
text: A deportation program that is central to the Obama administration’s immigration enforcement strategy has led disproportionately to the removal of Latino immigrants and to arrests by immigration authorities of hundreds of United States citizens, according to a report by two law schools using new, in-depth official data on deportation cases.

headline: Anne Frank, a Mormon?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Quinn Says City Must Find Balance in Response to Protests
text: Speaking on Tuesday before an audience composed largely of business leaders, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, said that she was not “anti-Wall Street” but that the anger of the Occupy Wall Street protesters should not be ignored.

headline: Out With Textbooks, in With Laptops for an Indiana School District
text: MUNSTER, Ind. — Laura Norman used to ask her seventh-grade scientists to take out their textbooks and flip to Page Such-and-Such. Now, she tells them to take out their laptops.

headline: An Electrifying Ancestor
text: Evolutionary biologists at Cornell University have found that most land vertebrates — including humans — are descended from a predatory fish that lived hundreds of millions of years ago and could sense electrical fields in its environment. Soon, in evolutionary terms, the lineage of that fish split in two. One line led to fish that still retain a sophisticated electro-sensing apparatus, like the North American paddlefish. The other line led to land vertebrates — including us — that have lost the ability to detect weak electrical currents without calling the electrician.

headline: Insurers See an Opening in Commercial Mortgages
text: Over the past several months, the commercial mortgage market has been volatile, plagued by weak investor appetite, wary lenders and warnings by ratings agencies of increasing risk. But one bright spot is emerging, as life insurance companies have taken advantage of the lull to become major lenders.

headline: In Queens, Neglected Sector Attracts Big Developers
text: Willets Point, the unsightly jumble of auto shops in northeastern Queens, looks pretty much as it did in May 2007, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced plans for a $3 billion mixed-use development on the site — with the notable exception that Citi Field, the new home of the New York Mets, now looms over it.

headline: Peter Mullen, Power at a Leading Law Firm, Dies at 83
text: Peter P. Mullen joined the Manhattan law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom in 1961, when it consisted of just 10 lawyers; when he stepped down as its de facto chief executive in 1994, it had more than 1,000, and was one of the world’s richest and most prominent firms.

headline: Confessions of a Rookie Re-Enactor
text: The First Battle of Bull Run, like freshman year of college, was a time for earning reputations — and nicknames. On that same afternoon when Confederate Gen. Thomas Jonathan Jackson won his moniker, “Stonewall,” he bestowed an equally flattering reputation on a Union regiment called the 14th Brooklyn, which wore red wool trousers as part of their local militia uniform modeled after the French chasseurs. The 14th Brooklyn — the only regiment in the Union Army called by a city’s name rather than a state — was giving Jackson and his troops quite a time on Henry House Hill, and at some point Stonewall braced his soldiers for yet another charge by shouting “Hold on Boys! Here come those red-legged devils again!”

headline: In Rift Between Murdochs, Heir Becomes Less Apparent
text: LONDON — It was a striking display of unity: Rupert and James Murdoch, father and son, walking side by side through central London as they faced a crisis that had laid siege to their company. Pushing through a crush of paparazzi on a street not far from Buckingham Palace, James reached out to place a reassuring hand on his father’s back.

headline: Scenes From a Red Bulls Practice
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The Red Bulls trained at Red Bull Arena instead of Montclair State University on Tuesday, but Thierry Henry and Rafael Marquez declined to speak with the news media, and Coach Hans Backe said he had yet to see the play on which Henry drew a red card last Saturday.

headline: Glad Tosses Out Some Plastic
text: Glad plans to spend $30 million to $40 million on a campaign for a new kitchen trash bag that the company says saves enough plastic — the equivalent of 140 million bags — to cover Manhattan.

headline: Romney’s Lawn Care History and the Fight Over Immigration
text: Rick Perry’s most pointed attack against Mitt Romney in Tuesday night’s debate concerned an immigration matter that came to light when Mr. Romney was campaigning for president four years ago.

headline: More Mortgage Debt Than Property Value
text: Chart shows the ratio of total mortgage debt to property value in major metropolitan areas of the U.S.

headline: Report Faults Sleeping and Awake Controllers
text: Two airliners landed in error at Reagan National Airport on March 23 after the lone tower controller on a midnight shift fell asleep and regional officials reacted incorrectly, a federal investigation concluded. As air traffic managers tried to figure out why the tower was not responding, a regional controller left the pilots of the incoming flights with the erroneous impression that they could land using rules for airports with unmanned towers, the National Transportation Safety Board said in a report Tuesday. The planes landed safely. The board blamed the tower controller’s fatigue and the Federal Aviation Administration’s scheduling practices for the incident. The F.A.A. has since revamped scheduling, assigned at least two controllers to every tower overnight and revised the guidelines for when a tower does not respond.

text: Romney’s Texas Jobs Claim

headline: In Prisoner Swap, a Day of Joy and Tension
text: The exchange of Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier held by Hamas, for the first batch of more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners in Israel began on Tuesday.

headline: What’s Behind the Lack of Confidence
text: Economists are scrambling to understand why Americans are so pessimistic about the economy. As I describe in an article in Wednesday’s paper, a leading theory blames the funk on the collapse in housing prices, which has erased a vast amount of wealth and convinced many Americans that they will never recover financially.

headline: United Auto Workers Approve a New Four-Year Contract With Ford Motor
text: The United Auto Workers has ratified its proposed contract with the Ford Motor Company after union members at two assembly plants in Kentucky approved the accord.

headline: Viewers Get Latest Episode of ‘Real Republicans of the Trail’
text: Mitt Romney said he liked Herman Cain’s “chutzpah.” He laughed, mirthlessly, when Rick Perry accused him of lying about hiring undocumented workers in his home. And he really didn’t enjoy being interrupted. Mr. Romney put a hand on Mr. Perry’s arm, space invasion of the first kind, and said, “I’m speaking, I’m speaking, I’m speaking, I’m speaking.”

headline: Three Lawmakers Propose Cutting Contractor Wages

text: Herman Cain speaks his mind — and writes his own rules.

headline: Behind Cain’s Humor, a Question of Seriousness
text: It is safe to say that no other Republican on the campaign trail this year — or ever — has begun a speech with the phrase “Awww, shucky ducky!” the way Herman Cain did this year to the utter delight of his audience, which responded with wild applause.

headline: Red Sox Deny Drinking Report
text: The Red Sox late Tuesday issued a statement denying news media reports that Boston players were drinking beer in the dugout during games this season. Jon Lester has admitted drinking in the clubhouse with Josh Beckett and John Lackey, but the three men, and the former manager Terry Francona, each were quoted in the team statement saying no one drank in the dugout. “We accept their statements as honest and factual,” Larry Lucchino, the team president, said in the release.

headline: Rick Santorum Clashes With Mitt Romney
text: Former Senator Rick Santorum, seeking a chance to be an alternative to Mr. Romney and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas mixed it up with both of them all evening.

headline: Pete Rugolo, Arranger and Composer, Is Dead at 95
text: Pete Rugolo, the chief arranger for the Stan Kenton Orchestra in its late-1940s heyday and a prolific composer and arranger for television and film, including the series “Richard Diamond, Private Detective,” “The Fugitive” and “Run for Your Life,” died on Sunday in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 95.

headline: Romney and Perry Clash
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas led an intense and sometimes personal barrage against Mitt Romney.

headline: The "9-9-9" Plan Under Attack
text: Herman Cain spent the debate's opening moments defending his 9-9-9 tax plan against nearly unanimous criticism from his fellow candidates.

headline: Vegas Debate: A Game of Seven-Candidate Draw?
text: I’m not intrinsically averse to declaring winners and losers in presidential debates. But there are times when everything is fought more or less to a draw.

headline: Lenny Speiller Reprimanded Over Petition
text: New York City Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott reprimands Lenny Speiller, the Department of Education’s director of public affairs, for his actions regarding the insertion of political views into a petition for parents.

headline: Relationship Tension, Over Screeching Feedback
text: Sexual energy drives many good songs, and when a male and female duo write and sing songs together about the unspoken dialogue underlying their relationship, the result can be electric.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
text: On Tuesday two core members of Anna Hazare’s India Against Corruption movement quit over the group’s “political turn,” the Hindustan Times reports. Rajendra Singh and P.V. Rajagopal expressed discontent over the team’s anti Congress campaign in the run-up to the Hisar by-election, which the Congress party eventually lost.

headline: Deputies Hunt Exotic Animals on the Loose in Ohio
text: Last Updated | 2:35 p.m. The authorities in the Ohio town where wild animals roamed overnight and early Wednesday said that by the afternoon all but two — a monkey and a wolf — had been accounted for.

headline: Champions League Wednesday Preview: Porto Leery of APOEL
text: Don’t look now, but as the Champions League’s group stage comes its halfway point with eight games on Wednesday, the pride of Cyprus leads Group G. APOEL (Athlitikos Podosfairikos Omilos Ellinon Lefkosias in Greek, or Athletic Football Club of Greeks of Nicosia) goes to Portugal to face Porto leading the group by a point.

headline: The World’s Best Vada Pav, Vadkhal Edition
text: A recent reporting trip took me down the road that connects the pulsing metropolis of Mumbai to the laid-back retreat of Goa. About 80 kilometers (50 miles) outside the city, in the town of Vadkhal, my traveling companion insisted we make a snack stop. I am never really averse to snack stops, but I was surprised because he had been rhapsodizing about the fresh, Konkan-style fish curry that awaited us at our destination.

headline: Oct. 19, 1987 | Stock Market Crashes on ‘Black Monday’
text: On Oct. 19, 1987, a day that became known as “Black Monday,” the stock market crashed as the Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged 508 points, or 22.6 percent in value, its largest single-day percentage drop. The crash came after a two-week period in which the Dow dropped 15 percent.

headline: News Quiz | Oct. 19, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Thousands in Greece Protest Austerity Bill
text: ATHENS — By now, it almost feels like a ritual: a strike and large demonstration disrupted by skirmishes and tear gas ahead of a parliamentary vote on new austerity measures that Greece needs to take to qualify for the next installment of aid the country needs to fend off default.

headline: British Police Clear Encampment, Home to Hundreds, After Ruling
text: LONDON — After a long and bitter legal battle that has tested Britain’s reputation for tolerance, the authorities began clearing an encampment east of London on Wednesday, two days after the Court of Appeal upheld a ruling that occupation by its owners — so-called travelers — was unlawful.

headline: Around the World, Young and Imprisoned
text: Lizzie Sadin started researching her project “Children Behind Bars” in 1999 — though it took her more than a year to be allowed to shoot inside a prison in Russia. By then, she had no plans to seek out prisons in other countries.

headline: Don’t Blink! The Hazards of Confidence
text: Many decades ago I spent what seemed like a great deal of time under a scorching sun, watching groups of sweaty soldiers as they solved a problem. I was doing my national service in the Israeli Army at the time. I had completed an undergraduate degree in psychology, and after a year as an infantry officer, I was assigned to the army’s Psychology Branch, where one of my occasional duties was to help evaluate candidates for officer training. We used methods that were developed by the British Army in World War II.

headline: Bad Guys vs. Worse Guys in Afghanistan
text: One afternoon this summer, in a park beside the Ajmil River, I sat with seven residents of Shahabuddin, a collection of villages in northern Afghanistan’s Baghlan Province. It was the first week of Ramadan, and the park was almost empty, but still the men — some middle-aged, others stooped and gray-bearded — whispered conspiratorially and became silent whenever anybody walked close. Several minutes into our conversation, one of the younger men, who’d been mutely worrying at a piece of grass, rose and abruptly stalked off. The others, embarrassed, apologized for him. “If Nur-ul Haq finds out we spoke to you,” one of them explained, “he will kill us.”

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 19, 2011
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article, “Inflating the Software Report Card.”

headline: Zombies Turn Up the Heat in Atlanta
text: WHY has Atlanta magazine dubbed that city the “zombie capital of the world”?WHY do you think so many people want to be extras on “The Walking Dead”?

headline: What Role Does Television Play in Your Life and the Life of Your Family?
text: A new study about children under the age of 2 states that television may be harmful to the children’s development. The study’s authors suggest parents refrain from letting their young children watch television, the same advice they issued in 1999. What age do you think is appropriate for children to begin watching television? Do you have rules in your home about how much television you can watch per day?

headline: Poll Finds Some Believe Mayor Has Lost Focus
text: A narrow majority of New York City voters believe that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has lost his focus midway through his third term, according to a poll released Wednesday morning by Quinnipiac University.

headline: Are Employers Requiring People to Work Longer Hours?
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: A V-12 in a Ford Ka? Forza 4 Makes Realism Customizable
text: In a Web advertisement for Forza Motorsport 4, the new racing simulator for the Xbox 360, we hear Jeremy Clarkson say that car enthusiasts “are an endangered species.” Mr. Clarkson, the host of the BBC‘s “Top Gear” show, laments that lovers of speed and performance are being trapped in practical cars and commuter slogs. That, he says, is why a racing simulator like Forza provides sanctuary.

headline: Jerry Jones Was Right; Cowboys Should Have Passed
text: Jason Garrett has received a lot of criticism for his decision to call three straight runs while up, 16-13, with 3 minutes 36 seconds to play in Sunday’s game in New England, perhaps the harshest of which came from his boss. “We rolled the dice at the end and went conservative,” the Cowboys’ owner, Jerry Jones, said, “and it bit us. You always second-guess whether or not we should have tried to run a little offense down there instead of running it three times.”

headline: The Early Word: Combative
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: In Hong Kong, a Monthlong Celebration of Food and Wine
text: Good food and drink rank high among Hong Kongers’ obsessions, so it’s appropriate that there is a whole month devoted to it. Wine & Dine month kicks off with the Wine & Dine Festival, which runs Oct. 27 to 30 at a picturesque location on the West Kowloon promenade. Food and wine tastings may be purchased from over 200 exhibitors (general admission is free). New at the festival this year are Spanish and Japanese purveyors who promise themed food and entertainment.

headline: Tip of the Week: Mobile Updates to Your Social Network
text: Dedicated smartphone apps for social-media networks make it easy to post status updates on the go. Users with regular cellphones can also keep their friends in the loop by simply sending text messages directly to a phone number specified by the site. A few setup steps may be needed first to get the text-based posting activated (and every service may not work with every wireless carrier out there), but Facebook, Twitter and Google+ all have guides for getting started.

headline: Turkey Pursues Kurdish Rebels After 24 Soldiers Are Killed Near Iraq
text: ISTANBUL — Kurdish militants killed at least 24 Turkish soldiers in an attack near the Iraq border on Wednesday, one of the deadliest strikes in years, and Turkey’s military responded by sending hundreds of troops into northern Iraq in a counterattack on Kurdish insurgent hide-outs.

headline: Rare Parity in the St. Louis Lineup

headline: Does This Service Provider’s Web Site Make You Want the Service?

headline: Samurai Shopper | Odor Eaters
text: Once upon a time, washing with soap and water was considered radical hygiene. There was even a church injunction against water on the grounds that bathing spurred sensuality and indolence — talk about the odor of sanctity. At the same time, pestilential stench was a sign of Satan; bad odors indicated physical and moral decay. Alain Corbin’s “The Foul and the Fragrant” chronicles France in the 18th and 19th centuries when the masses stank to high heaven and perfumed gloves and sleeves inured the aesthete from those very rank rank and file. But the aristocracy was not entirely immune. Casanova, Corbin tells us, nearly fainted at the musky smell of an old nymphomaniac duchess. I sat next to her on the bus yesterday, and I nearly died too.

headline: Eurofile | Britain’s First Two-Star Pub

Her slightly grumpy apprehension derived from the fact that Hand and Flowers had just received two Michelin stars, a first for any British pub. “I do loathe the term ‘gastropub,’” she added. “I bet this place will be full of horrid people wearing new Barbour jackets and Wellies, and don’t forget we must be home by 5 p.m.” Now lost in a sea of red wine was last night’s admission that she had a date with her married Spanish airline pilot.

headline: Are You Managing Your Unemployment Insurance?
text: Every Nov. 30, the State of Illinois sends out a statement that tells businesses what rate they will pay in the coming year for unemployment insurance. I view the rate as one indication of how I did this year as a manager. This time around, I’m anticipating a gift, because we had no unemployment claims this year, and I expect the rate to go down. In a bad year, the statement feels more like a reprimand, one that comes with a bill attached.

headline: Environmentalist Explains Shifts on Biotechnology and Nuclear Power

The exchange centers on Lynas’s new book, “The God Species: Saving the Planet in the Age of Humans,” and particularly on his conclusion that some technologies that have been anathema to environmentalists are vital to a smooth human journey in this century — particularly nuclear power and crops developed using biotechnology. Also notable is Lynas’s revised view of the “skeptical environmentalist” Bjorn Lomborg, whose face he once plastered with a pie. I encourage you to read it and weigh in here.

headline: Why Occupy?

Reporting on protesters around the country, Mr. Lacey found that not every group or individual that has embraced Occupy marches for the same reasons. Though many protesters seem united in feeling that a system designed to benefit the rich and connected is not working in their favor, many are also more concerned with specific challenges affecting their local communities, such as education and the environment.

headline: The Hermès Time Machine
text: The quest to counter the relentless march of time has been pursued by dreamers and puzzled over by scientists since, well, the beginning of time. Now, the French luxury giant Hermès has cleverly succeeded in achieving the very appearance of slowing time with its new watch the Cape Cod Grands Heures, first introduced at Baselworld 2011, and available in stores in time for the holidays. The face of the new watch, which has three choices of distinct dials, shows numeric hour indicators that are clustered together, spread far apart, standing solo and intermittently spaced — all allowing for a variable speed that gives the illusion that time is moving more slowly, or more quickly. Want your afternoons to seemingly pass at a more leisurely pace? Choose a dial with wide open spaces between 2 and 4. Prefer a purportedly longer happy hour? Try the version with larger gaps between 5 and 7. This ingenious trick of time is managed by an oval wheel system that allows for the speeding and slowing of its motion, while the minutes and seconds march steadily, and constantly, on. The clever dial design encourages the romantic notion that time can actually take its time, but the hours, alas, remain the same. Always the hours.

headline: A Couple of Good Bands Buoy CMJ’s Opening Night
text: The first day of the CMJ Music Marathon is for lowering expectations. I’m spoiled because most of the shows I hear during the year are by bands that have already gotten somewhere — even if it’s only to an opening-act slot with some indie-label pals — and are playing clubs that expect people to listen. The beauty and aggravation of CMJ is that it’s a plunge into the lower echelons, the ones triaged out of my usual schedule. This is the province of peculiar club layouts, blaringly murky sound systems and disheveled guys in yesterday’s T-shirt poking at their keyboard and mixer, wishing they were Erasure circa 1989. I start to wonder if the next five days are going to be like that.

headline: Frieze Frame | Ida Ekblad’s Ruckus
text: Ida Ekblad is at once a sculptor, painter, video maker and poet. Her motley creations — crude and polished, blithe and bold — offer perspectives on modern art and culture, with and without a capital M. Her sculpture reaches back to beatific tropes of postwar art history, which she solders together with the harsh trash of today’s world: industrial materials (scrap metal is a favorite) collected from streets and junkyards. Her paintings marry similar sentiments, committing the intangible debris of brutish shapes and colors to canvas.

headline: Officials Renew Call for U.S. Review of Stop and Frisk Policy
text: The case against a New York City police officer charged with falsely arresting a black man on Staten Island in April has given new attention to the call for a federal civil rights inquiry into the Police Department’s controversial stop, question and frisk policy.

The Met’s “Siegfried” opens on Oct. 27, with the Nov. 5 matinee to be broadcast to movie theaters in high definition.

headline: TV Chat: Ask the Critics
text: This week, the critic Mike Hale took a look at a spate of major cast changes in prime time and came up with a report card on how the shows — “Two and a Half Men,” “CSI,” “The Office,” “Law & Order: SVU” and “House” — are handling the new characters. Only “CSI” got an A, while “Two and a Half Men” received a cringe-worthy D. But the critic Neil Genzlinger says he actually enjoys the Ashton Kutcher version of “Men.” How would you grade the shifts? Then there’s “The X Factor,” which is doing well with the 18-to-49 demographic but not with Mr. Genzlinger, who has some issues. Is there any “reality” in that reality competition or is Simon Cowell orchestrating everything? And what to make of the American Academy of Pediatrics warning, yet again, that parents should limit the amount of time infants and toddlers spend in front of the television screen? Are you suffering the effects of too much TV watching as a baby? You asked and the critics answered your questions:

headline: Curbside at School, a Red Carpet
text: IN the West Village, a stunningly decked-out woman is nothing unusual. But Rose Cameron still managed to turn heads in the neighborhood recently, with her long black hair and full-length fur coat. Perhaps it was because she wasn’t leaving Bar Pitti at midnight, but exiting the Little Red School House after dropping off her child. The time: 8:30 a.m.

headline: Here Come the (Stylish) Grooms
text: ON the evening of June 24, in Paris, men’s fashion writers sat down for the spring Givenchy show at the Pompidou Center. Chairs had been arranged in the street-level lobby, and by the time the show began — an arrow of scowling men in bird of paradise prints — an audience had formed outside the windows as well.

headline: U.S. Denies Iran Claims That Saudi Plot Defendant Belongs to Exile Group
text: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials on Wednesday denied Iranian news reports that a man charged in a plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador to the United States is actually an agent of an exiled Iranian opposition group.

headline: Controlling Her Voice, and Her World
text: Nika Roza Danilova, the singer who performs as Zola Jesus, seems single-minded, and her show on Tuesday night at the Knitting Factory was a unity. She had written the songs and programmed the synthesizers, played by three musicians, which blended thickly together over a drummer’s dry tribal rhythms. Her body language, except for basic bobbing, was arm and hand movements to signify her voice’s rising tones and crescendos.

headline: The Other Zuckerberg
text: “WHO wants a tequila shot?” Randi Zuckerberg shouted over the thump of “Baby One More Time,” Britney Spears’s breakup anthem.

headline: Facebook Changes Inspire More Grumbling
text: Facebook recently redesigned its site, moving things around and adding new elements. Of course, Facebook frequently fiddles with its features, and these fixes frequently infuriate its fans.

headline: A Brazen Scheme to Win The Daughter of a Count
text: The great maestro Riccardo Muti is like the butterfly in chaos theory: when he beats his baton in Europe, an opera gets performed throughout the world. In 1999 Mr. Muti revived Giovanni Paisiello’s long-neglected “Nina.” The next thing you know it has two DVD recordings and is being put on at American conservatories.

headline: Tracking Your Car’s Performance (or Lack of It) by Phone
text: As a kid, I spent hours poring over my dad’s Road & Track magazines, memorizing performance statistics and fantasizing about Porsche Turbos.

headline: An Outspoken Elder, Very Now
text: MODERN-DAY Marimekko specializes in what your average HGTV design-show host calls “pops of color.” How about a big flower arrangement, hand-painted, erupting all over your dress? Some blue and black tiger-striped bedsheets? Bright lunchboxes for your wee ones with elephants on them?

headline: Phone Stunt Seeks Box-Office Numbers
text: When it comes to publicizing movies, a lot of stars do as little as possible: a perfunctory wave from a red carpet, a chat with Jay Leno. Then there is what Jonah Hill is doing to promote “The Sitter,” an R-rated comedy set for release on Dec. 9. Mr. Hill, last seen as a statistics nerd in “Moneyball,” is so eager to make “The Sitter” a success — it’s his first film as a solo headliner — that he agreed to an unusual request from Fox’s marketing team. Fox hung posters across the country printed with Mr. Hill’s image, the message “Need a Sitter?” and phone numbers on tear-off tabs, above. About 250,000 people called, and nearly half left messages. Here comes the unusual part: Mr. Hill agreed to carry around the phone belonging to that number and randomly answer calls himself. A Fox spokesman said Mr. Hill had answered a few dozen times. On Wednesday he began returning calls. Mr. Hill, who plays an unprepared baby sitter, also recorded messages for robo-returned calls. “Your voice sounds like a cat that was strangled with a pack of menthols,” one version says in part. “Call me back.” What did Mr. Hill have to say about the gimmick? Fox said he was unavailable to come to the phone.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Oct. 20
text: Leather skirts, derby boots, and a peppy new boutique.

headline: Old Shows, New Faces, Big Risks
text: While the season’s new television shows battle for survival, like baby turtles scurrying across the beach — five of them are gone already, picked off by the bad-ratings bird — there’s an equally important but more quiet drama going on in prime time.

headline: One Month, Too Much Fashion
text: HERE is a question that has yet to be addressed in the debate over the scheduling of fashion shows next September: Would it be such a bad thing if designers in Milan went head-to-head with designers in New York and London?

headline: When Schubert Shouts Softly
text: When a musician programs a composer’s late works, it’s hard to imagine that those pieces were mostly written while the composer was still in his 20s. But the autumnal masterpieces of Schubert, who died at 31, are indeed the efforts of a young man.

headline: The mobile-search market; a streaming service for British TV shows; tech news.
text: Claire Cain Miller of The Times discusses the emerging market for mobile search services and how people tend to use search engines differently on their phones compared to sitting in front of a computer. Miguel Penella, the chief executive of the Acorn Media Group, explains how his company’s Acorn TV video-streaming service is bringing in a new American audience for British television shows. The weekly news roundup notes the memorial for Apple co-founder Steve Jobs, as well as the passing of audio pioneer Edgar Villchur; Research in Motion’s free-apps apology to its customers; and the return of a few iconic product designs. The Tip of the Week looks at ways to post to social-media sites by using text messages.

headline: Consumer Unit for Seniors Draws a Famous Name
text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has recruited a famous name: Hubert Humphrey.

headline: A Hit Maker’s Life and Lyrics
text: The venerable musician and record producer Nile Rodgers, wearing a bandanna tied around his dreadlocks, fade-out sunglasses and a charcoal-gray pinstripe jacket, arrived at Cafe Luxembourg right on schedule one morning last week.

headline: Grease Is the Word ... Again
text: THE models at the September N. Hoolywood show were turned out as various early 1960s male archetypes, all with Brylcreem coifs. College nerds, sharkskin-suited flimflam men and “West Side Story” street toughs in high waters were well represented. But the leader of the pack was the greaser, in all of his popped-collar glory.

headline: The Tippler
text: THE after-work scene at the Tippler, a new tavern under the Chelsea Market, is nothing if not civilized. Thirty-somethings in blazers and oxfords (for the guys) and skirts and ballet flats (for the girls) mingle over oysters and handmade cocktails, presumably discussing the goings-on at their respective advertising agencies or Web startups.

headline: Putting the Winds in the Spotlight
text: Chamber works for wind instruments aren’t exactly rare, yet even the best of the lot turn up infrequently outside concerts mounted by dedicated wind ensembles. Among most chamber-music presenters the care and feeding of string players can seem to be paramount. Hearing any one of the four strong pieces the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening would have been a treat for wind fanciers; hearing them all was a feast.

headline: The Paint Doctor Is In
text: IT begins simply enough. The living room needs a new coat of paint, perhaps a fresh start for both of you. But what about something different this time? No more off-white. Maybe a color that is bold and creative, but also educated, witty and ironic.

headline: The Sniping of Partisans, This Time on the Screen
text: LOS ANGELES — At a film festival in Toronto last month, the Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein tried to bait Michele Bachmann, the Republican presidential contender, into joining him for an Iowa premiere of “Butter,” in which the conservative lead character looks suspiciously like a parody of Ms. Bachmann.

headline: Swapping Girls’ Night Out for a Workout
text: JUST after 2 p.m. on a September Saturday, the heavy drinking began at Alyson Luck’s bachelorette party.

headline: Release Date of Bin Laden Film May Change
text: LOS ANGELES — The fuss over whether Sony Pictures and the filmmakers Mark Boal and Kathryn Bigelow were playing politics when they scheduled their hunt-for-Bin Laden film for release on Oct. 12, shortly before next year’s presidential election, may soon be irrelevant. Sony is planning to move the as-yet untitled film until after the election, according to two people who were briefed on the studio’s plans. Both said the picture is now virtually certain to appear after the election, and might not be released until early in 2013.

headline: The Road to Hell, Paved With Telemarketers
text: By any definition of the word “decency” it’s been a long time since Chuck Palahniuk wrote a decent book. His lurid recent efforts, from “Snuff” (pornography) to “Tell-All” (movie-star gossip) to “Pygmy” (broken English from teenage foreign terrorists), have tried the patience of even his most die-hard fans. These books have been skimpy and tired enough to suggest that this “Fight Club” author has had all the fight drained out of him. But he shows new signs of life in “Damned,” a book full of tastelessly hilarious gallows humor about a teenage girl in hell.

headline: N.B.A. Lockout Creating Uncertainty for U.S. Olympic Team
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — If the N.B.A. lockout continues, it will have a significant impact on preparations for the 2012 Olympics, Mike Krzyzewski said Wednesday. Krzyzewski, the United States national team coach, and Jerry Colangelo, the USA Basketball chairman, have discussed the matter, he said, although the uncertainty is making it impossible to plan ahead.

headline: That Man Smells Familiar
text: AS nostalgia for the early 1960s persists, a handful of men’s fragrances from that period are getting a second look.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and cosmetics companies are rallying for the cause.

headline: How Does It Feel to Adapt Dylan’s Songs for a Cabaret Setting?
text: It may sound outlandish: a British female cabaret singer interpreting Bob Dylan accompanied by a piano instead of a guitar. But Barb Jungr, a fearless iconoclast who dives into the deepest waters of popular song to wrest exotic treasure from the ocean floor, delivered a fiery personal tutorial on Mr. Dylan at Tuesday’s opening-night performance of her show “Man in the Long Black Coat” at the Metropolitan Room.

headline: Newly Released
text: This month’s new fiction is not for the fainthearted. There are stonings in two books, while bodies drop in all but one. And Howard Jacobson’s humor, in the one homicide-free offering, proves to be no less savage.

headline: What Makes Free Will Free?
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

headline: U.S. Benefits for Retirees to Rise 3.6% Next Year
text: WASHINGTON — Social Security recipients will get a 3.6 percent increase in benefits next year to help keep up with inflation, the first such cost-of-living adjustment in three years, the government announced Wednesday.

headline: Stories Come to Life in Sound and Silence
text: Cheerful stories can be fun, but angry tales are fascinating. That’s never more apparent than in “Beyond Words,” a collection of sketches presented by Bill Bowers in both mime and monologue. At his nicest Mr. Bowers is a pleasant fellow relating mildly amusing yarns. Yet when he ventures into darker territory, this one-man show comes alive.

headline: A House That Flows Into the Outdoors
text: In Key West, a hurricane-wrecked home is rebuilt as a private refuge.

headline: A Key West House Built by a Storm
text: IN October 2005, when Hurricane Wilma ripped through the Florida Keys, Kathy Houtz’s 1,000-square-foot house on Key Haven, a community just east of Key West, was practically destroyed. “It was the biggest trauma I had ever been through,” she said.

headline: Piet Hein Eek Designs at the Future Perfect
text: It was nearly a decade ago that the Dutch designer Piet Hein Eek flashed onto the scene, one in a line of stellar graduates of the Design Academy Eindhoven. For his thesis project, Mr. Eek had retooled the environmentally friendly ethos of “reduce, reuse, recycle,” using fine cabinetmaking techniques to transform wood scrap into high-style designs.

headline: Bored With White Tableware? Call John Derian
text: Astier de Villatte, the French company known for delightfully imperfect white ceramic tableware, is adding color and graphics to its dishes, a result of a collaboration with John Derian. “After almost 15 years, we were doing almost only white ceramics,” said Ivan Pericoli, one of the founders of Astier de Villatte in 1996. “It seemed natural to us, when we wanted to add images, to ask John, because he has a sensibility about color that is really close to ours.”

headline: Mxyplyzyk’s New Store in Jersey City
text: Mxyplyzyk has proved to be a survivor in a less-than-ideal retail climate: the home furnishings shop has occupied the same space in the West Village for nearly a decade. Last week, Kevin Brynan, who owns the store with his partner, Bill Cleary, opened a second one in Jersey City.

text: Wilder Quarterly, a gardening magazine being introduced on Monday, targets a new generation of growers and urban farmers.

headline: With Open Doors, and Weary Ears
text: BUILD it, and they will come. Someone built it long before we were born, around 1900. All we did was buy this house in southern Maine, but we soon found: they will come. At the halfway mark from New York City to Mount Desert, which draws them like Chaucer’s Canterbury Cathedral, they will be excited that half their journey is behind them.

Considered the first modern atrium-style hotel, it had glass elevators, lighted columns and cascading fountains that created a fizzy extravaganza of space and light, or what the former New York Times architecture critic Herbert Muschamp called “architecture at happy hour.”

headline: Cardinals Take Game 1 of World Series

They all went his way, and so the Cardinals took the first game of the 107th World Series, 3-2, in front of 46,406 at Busch Stadium. Read David Waldstein’s full story here.

headline: A Championship Uppercut

The last team, U.S.A-1 in the d’Orsi Senior Bowl, is ninth, only 3.5 victory points behind eighth. In each event — Venice Cup, Bermuda Bowl and d’Orsi Senior Bowl — the top eight qualify for the quarterfinals, starting Sunday.

headline: The Indoor Tree: A Tall, Green Slip of Summer
text: ADELE HAEG, age 6, looks adorable with bangs. Just not the bangs my daughter cut into Adele’s long, straight hair last spring after the two sneaked into the bathroom with a pair of safety scissors. In my daughter’s defense, she got the idea from “Betsy-Tacy and Tib,” a wholesome (read: deviant) children’s book from the 1940s. As copycat barbering accidents go, I suppose, it could have been worse. I’m keeping my girl away from “Sweeney Todd.”

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Search Engines for Phones

She also explains how advertisers are adapting to search-on-the-go, and how Google came to its early dominance of the mobile-search market.

headline: Barbara Kent, Star of Silent Movies, Dies at 103
text: Barbara Kent, one of the last surviving stars of silent films, who performed alongside Gloria Swanson, Greta Garbo and Harold Lloyd, died last Thursday in Palm Desert, Calif. She was 103.

headline: Film Executive to Head San Francisco Society
text: Bingham Ray, a veteran indie film executive who helped get movies like “Hotel Rwanda” and “Bowling for Columbine” on the screen, has been named executive director of the San Francisco Film Society, the society said on Wednesday. The appointment puts Mr. Ray in charge of an organization that, among other things, runs the San Francisco International Film Festival. And it fills a post that has been vacant since Graham Leggat, the previous director, died in August. Recently Mr. Ray had been working with Lincoln Center as a consultant to its film program; with SnagFilms, for which he was scouting movies; and with New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts, where he has been an adjunct professor. “Too good to be true” is how Mr. Ray described his appointment in a statement.

headline: Hurry-Up Offense: Palmer Gets Going With Raiders
text: The Carson Palmer era in Oakland was just hours old when the speculation began as to how soon he would make his first appearance in silver and black. Coach Hue Jackson has delighted in stonewalling the news media, and Palmer himself, while saying all the right things — “Come Sunday, I’m going to do whatever they ask me to do”— could not help but look overwhelmed.

headline: Big British Hedge Fund Takes Aim at the States
text: Founded 230 years ago near the banks of the Thames, the Man Group has transformed itself from a British barrel maker to a rum merchant to a $70 billion money manager dominant in Europe and Asia.

headline: Islamist Imagines a Democratic Future for Tunisia
text: ISTANBUL — For more than three decades, Rachid al-Ghannouchi has preached that pluralism, democracy and Islam are harmonious. As his country, Tunisia, heads toward the first elections after the Arab revolts on Sunday, Mr. Ghannouchi, a renowned Islamic thinker, faces a reckoning between his principles and intentions.

headline: Olympus Faces Credibility Gap
text: Olympus shares will probably languish until it comes up with some answers. The Japanese manufacturer fired its chief executive, Michael Woodford, last week and has since acknowledged effectively paying two advisers a 35 percent commission for a British acquisition in 2008. While its core business looks sound, the fear is that Olympus could be forced to take big write-downs or even delist.

headline: Mitt and Begonia-gate
text: Oh, wow! Rick Perry hit Mitt Romney with the illegal immigrant landscapers!

headline: Bloggingheads: Angry, Indebted Grads
text: Benjy Sarlin, left, of Talking Points Memo and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate about Occupy Wall Street and student loan debt.

headline: Fitting In Exercise, Between Math and English
text: Five years ago, Richard Reiss, the physical education teacher at Public School 197 in Far Rockaway, Queens, went to the principal with a problem: not even the most athletic among his students, most of whom are poor and black or Latino, had enough endurance to run a mile.

headline: L.S.U. Suspends 3 Players for Game Against Auburn
text: Top-ranked Louisiana State will be without its two best players for Saturday’s game against Auburn, according to multiple reports.

headline: After Arrests in Park Known for Sex, Cases Are Sealed, but Names Are Released
text: With its densely wooded trails and easy access, Saxon Woods, a county park in White Plains, had become widely known on Web sites catering to men interested in anonymous gay sex.

headline: Some Cheer Border Fence as Others Ponder the Cost
text: In the debate over immigration among the Republican presidential candidates, Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota signed a pledge last week to build double-fencing the entire length of the 2,000-mile border with Mexico.

headline: In Bleak ’70s, Salvo of Protest
text: OCCUPY WALL STREET, the protest encampment at Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, has many historical inspirations. After all, the tactic of sitting down and refusing to move was used by angry veterans marching on Washington in the early Depression years, striking automobile workers in the late 1930s and civil rights protesters in the 1960s. But there is a local precedent, one that few people remember today: the sit-ins and “occupations” that followed New York City’s deep budget cuts in 1975 and 1976.

headline: Not Guilty of Murder; Facing $1 Million Bail
text: A Queens woman who killed her husband, shooting him 11 times, but was acquitted of murder, will be eligible again for release on $1 million bail, according to a court order issued on Wednesday.

headline: Shopping for Camp Blankets and Throws
text: Tyler Hays, the founder and head designer of BDDW Furniture in SoHo, searched for blankets.

headline: Camp Blankets and Throws
text: IF he’s known at all, Tyler Hays is known as the founder and head designer of BDDW Furniture, the high-end furnishings store in SoHo. As it happens, Mr. Hays, 43, is also a painter and a sculptor, but he has managed to remain relatively anonymous while attracting a sizable following for his design work.

headline: They Turn On the Power
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — The play that best encapsulates the revival of Stanford’s football team, which has gone from 1-11 in 2006 to a national title contender in 2011, is called 97 Power. Right guard David DeCastro pulls hard to his left to bulldoze a linebacker, and left tackle Jonathan Martin, known as Moose, blocks a defensive end to clear the way for a simple inside running play.

headline: Perry Says He Backs Flat Tax, Drawing a Contrast With Romney
text: Rick Perry announced his support for a flat tax on Wednesday, sharpening the contrast with his Republican rival Mitt Romney and capitalizing on popular frustration with the tax system among Republican primary voters.

headline: The Fight Over How to End a War
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An unusually powerful phalanx of President Obama’s top officials, charged with organizing an orderly exit from Afghanistan, will face an outwardly confident, almost defiant Pakistan during talks that open in an atmosphere of rancor here on Thursday night.

headline: It’s What They Asked For
text: Alabama’s new anti-immigrant law, the nation’s harshest, went into effect last month (a few provisions have been temporarily blocked in federal court), and it is already reaping a bitter harvest of dislocation and fear. Hispanic homes are emptying, businesses are closing, employers are wondering where their workers have gone. Parents who have not yet figured out where to go are lying low and keeping children home from school.

headline: Not Their Job
text: President Obama’s Council on Jobs and Competitiveness has some promising job growth ideas, including ways to speed up projects in energy and infrastructure. But the 27-member council — made up mostly of corporate executives, along with a handful of investors, labor leaders and academics — has indulged in outrageous special pleading, with its assault on Sarbanes-Oxley, the antifraud law passed in 2002 in response to Enron, WorldCom and the dot-com bust.

headline: Playing Politics With Women’s Lives
text: House Republicans approved an egregious measure last week that would shrink access to abortion to the point of endangering women’s lives.

headline: Left-Handed Specialists in the Series Are Strikingly Similar
text: ST. LOUIS — For nearly 20 years, Darren Oliver and Arthur Rhodes have shared more than just job titles as major league left-handers. Since the day in 1988 when they were drafted one round apart, their paths have run parallel, and at times intertwined, as each switched from team to team.

headline: Soldier’s Family Led Campaign for His Release
text: MITZPE HILA, Israel — The release of Gilad Shalit took years of delicate negotiations at the top levels of the Israeli government and the Hamas militant group. But it also required an extraordinary campaign by his parents, Noam and Aviva Shalit, to build overwhelming support among Israel’s people and its right-leaning government to trade more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners, some guilty of heinous terrorist killings, for their son.

headline: De Blasio Pushes on Information Requests
text: The New York City public advocate, Bill de Blasio, said Wednesday that he was starting an investigation into city agencies’ responses to the state’s Freedom of Information Law requests because he was concerned that the agencies were taking too long to release public information.

headline: Hastening Slowly Through Fall
text: Caterpillars have begun to appear outside my mudroom door. They look barely animate and thickly pelted, like moss creeping up the door frame in individual inches. I wonder about the feel of caterpillar fur, but some natural caution keeps me from touching them. They are a great improvement over the slugs and the millipedes that crept up the door all summer long. The slugs looked like thick, muddy drops of gelatinous rain. There is no analogy for the millipedes. I pretend not to know they are there.

headline: Comments on Immigration Alienate Some Hispanics
text: Today, Republican candidates are competing over who can talk the toughest about illegal immigration — who will erect the most impenetrable border defense; who will turn off “magnets” like college tuition benefits.

headline: Winning Is Everything, or So Says a Law Firm
text: AMONG the most derided commercials on television are those by law firms that represent victims of accidents, which often feature tough-talking lawyers promising vengeance, video of car accidents and assorted mayhem, and modest production values.

headline: Piri Thomas, Spanish Harlem Author, Dies at 83
text: Piri Thomas, the writer and poet whose 1967 memoir, “Down These Mean Streets,” chronicled his tough childhood in Spanish Harlem and the outlaw years that followed and became a classic portrait of ghetto life, died on Monday at his home in El Cerrito, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Actively Engaged
text: Remember judicial activism? Of course you do. Not so long ago, Republicans lined up to denounce President Obama’s two Supreme Court nominees as judicial activists before the ink was dry on their nomination papers. Writing in The Wall Street Journal right after Sonia Sotomayor’s nomination in May 2009, Karl Rove advised fellow Republicans that although Judge Sotomayor would almost certainly be confirmed, Republicans should nonetheless seek to score points by “making a clear case against the judicial activism she represents.” The next year, Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah, undeterred by the fact that Elena Kagan, never having been a judge, was hard to describe plausibly as a judicial activist, explained his vote against her confirmation by saying that “Ms. Kagan’s record shows that she supports an activist judicial philosophy.”

headline: My Shrink Is My Co-Author
text: When I decided to ghost write a book with my longtime psychotherapist, colleagues said, “You’re crazy.”

headline: New Tactics and Billions to Manage City Sewage
text: The Bloomberg administration is set to commit $2.4 billion in public and private investment to applying new environmental technology to an old problem: the flow of untreated sewage and storm water into New York City’s waterways.

headline: La Russa’s Caring Side Shows Up in the Box Scores
text: ST. LOUIS

headline: On the Day After, Moving Ahead and Looking Back
text: KHAN YUNIS, Gaza Strip — He was only one of the 477 Palestinian prisoners released by Israel in exchange for a single captive Israeli soldier. But as the welcoming celebrations wound down after the swap, many men came to a refugee camp here to pay him their highest respects.

headline: Authors to Get Sales Data Online From 3 Big Publishers
text: Three major publishers said on Wednesday that they would allow their authors to access book sales data directly online, a move that appeared to challenge Amazon and its continued efforts to woo authors.

headline: Lottery Numbers
An Ordinary Football Game, Then a Player Dies
text: PHOENIX, N.Y. — Football coaches and school administrators at John C. Birdlebough High School congregated in a small room off the library Monday, huddling around a computer for a most painful and unusual review of game video. They examined every play that one student was involved in, assuming the role of medical examiners.

headline: Westchester Man Killed His Wife and Children Before Shooting Himself, Police Say
text: CROSS RIVER, N.Y. — Late in the spring, Samuel Friedlander, by appearances a successful lawyer, seemed distraught to Kenneth Novenstern, who was representing Mr. Friedlander in his divorce from his wife, Amy.

headline: Occupy the Classroom
text: Occupy Wall Street is shining a useful spotlight on one of America’s central challenges, the inequality that leaves the richest 1 percent of Americans with a greater net worth than the entire bottom 90 percent.

headline: Norman Corwin, Pioneer of Radio, Dies at 101
text: Norman Corwin, one of the last living links to radio’s golden age, a producer and dramatist whose innovative use of sound effects and unusual narrative devices attracted new audiences to serious programming, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 101.

headline: Silver Lake Group Considers Yahoo Bid
text: Potential groups of bidders for Yahoo are continuing to emerge, as suitors keep circling the faltering Internet giant.

headline: Mediator in N.B.A. Talks Has Strong Sports Pedigree
text: George H. Cohen, the federal mediator who is seeking to coax, cajole and occasionally strong-arm the N.B.A. and its players into ending their 112-day showdown, would seem to have an ideal pedigree for the role.

headline: Thursday: Day Four of the Crossword Contest
text: Administrivial Heads Up for Friday! The Friday, Oct. 21 crossword puzzle will be available at the normal time and place, but it will have a format that will not be available in Across Lite. However, we will be offering a PDF version that you will need to print out to solve. That version will be available here on Thursday, Oct. 20 at 10 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: Bad Blood Between Perry and Romney Is Longstanding
text: WASHINGTON — The hostilities flaring between Mitt Romney and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas have been steadily rising inside both camps and may signal a new, more combative phase in the Republican presidential campaign.

headline: Parking Rules in New York City
text: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzeret and Simhat Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Perry to Pay Jet Owners Higher Rate After Questions About Use
text: Gov. Rick Perry’s presidential campaign said Wednesday that it would reimburse owners of private jets an amount in the “five figures” one day after facing questions about whether it underpaid for using jets owned by wealthy donors, which could mean that the campaign may have received large, unreported in-kind contributions barred by federal election law.

headline: French First Lady Gives Birth to a Girl
text: PARIS — France’s first lady, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, gave birth to a girl on Wednesday evening. She is the first baby born to a modern-day French president while in office, the newspaper Le Figaro reported.

headline: It’s Football Weather, but Series Teams Will Adjust
text: ST. LOUIS — Several games this October have been affected by rain, forcing managers to scramble and fiddle with their rotations.

headline: Sanchez and Burress Cram for Chemistry
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — There was a talented receiver, a flashy free-agent pickup, who was slowed by injuries that first training camp. His viability was questioned, as was how quickly he could establish a groove with his new quarterback.

headline: At Front of Brooklyn Bus, a Clash of Religious and Women’s Rights
text: It does not take long to recognize that the B110 bus in Brooklyn is not like others in the city.

headline: Matthew G. Martinez, Ex-Democratic Lawmaker, Dies at 82
text: Matthew G. Martinez, a former representative from the Los Angeles area who drew attention in 2000 when, as a party-line Democrat, he angrily switched to the Republican Party for his last months in office after being defeated in a primary, died Oct. 15 at his home in Fredericksburg, Va. He was 82.

headline: There’s Nothing Like a ‘Super PAC’ for the Serious Contender
text: Herman Cain has a pop in the polls and the full attention of the political class, and now he’s got a “super PAC,” too.

headline: Prayers for Tibetans Who Immolated Themselves Denounced by China
text: The top two leaders of Tibet’s government-in-exile publicly prayed on Wednesday for the nine Tibetans who have immolated themselves over the past seven months to protest China’s Tibet policies, provoking an angry response from Beijing, where a government spokeswoman called the prayers a promotion of terrorism.

headline: Stalemate Remains on Collecting Blood Samples for H.G.H. Testing
text: Nearly two months after it had hoped to start blood testing for human growth hormone, and several days after two Congressmen announced there was a deal to begin collecting blood samples immediately, the N.F.L. and its players union remained at a standstill on Wednesday over the program.

headline: France: Writer Says She Won’t Sue Strauss-Khan
text: Tristane Banon, the French writer who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of trying to rape her eight years ago, said she would not pursue a civil case against him, after French prosecutors recently declined to charge him with attempted rape. Last week, prosecutors said they could not bring a case against him, given a three-year statute of limitations for sexual assault, but they said there was evidence that he had sexually assaulted Ms. Banon. On Wednesday, Ms. Banon said she would not pursue a suit because the case had proved that she was not a liar.

headline: It’s a Girl for the French Presidential Couple
text: C’est une fille!

headline: Cards Maneuver Their Way to a Win
text: ST. LOUIS — The formula that helped Tony La Russa lead the St. Louis Cardinals to victory in the National League Championship Series proved to be just as viable in the World Series.

headline: World Series Replay: Game 1
text: St. Louis hosted the opener and the Cardinals got off to a good start, beating the Texas Rangers, 3-2.

headline: The Ghazal
text: I created this drink, which is named after the ancient Persian poetic form, to pair with Middle Eastern snacks. Rosewater enhances the cucumber-and-rose infusion in Hendrick’s gin. A good measure of fresh lime juice brightens it up with acidity, and mint adds more flavor.

text: Kingsley Amis and Churchill could hardly stand the stuff, but a little extra vermouth goes a long way.

headline: The Vesper
text: Gin or vodka? The Vesper — which first appeared in Ian Fleming’s novel ‘‘Casino Royale’’ — lets you have it both ways. Lillet stands in for its close cousin, dry vermouth. I normally stir rather than shake, but, in this case, I defer to James Bond.

headline: Rush to Drill for Natural Gas Creates Conflicts With Mortgages
text: As natural gas drilling has spread across the country, energy industry representatives have sat down at kitchen tables in states like Texas, Pennsylvania and New York to offer homeowners leases that give companies the right to drill on their land.

headline: For the Perfect Martini, Wetter Is Better
text: The most memorable martini I’ve ever had was made at the bar in the Merchant Hotel in Belfast, by a charming young man named Luke. I requested it with Beefeater, straight up with a twist, and asked him not to be shy with the vermouth. As I watched Luke stir the drink patiently and rhythmically, then produce a diminutive coupe glass from the freezer, I sensed that the martini would be sublime. Expert execution is one thing, but an elegant setting and a genial bartender made my martini add up to more than the sum of its parts. A flawless cocktail fashioned by an imperious “mixologist” in a bar where people don’t talk to one another is no fun at all.

headline: Taking a Pounding
text: There are a number of reasons to pound a piece of meat madly before cooking it, though not all of them make sense.

headline: Radwanska Slip Gives Bartoli Hope
text: Having just won the two biggest titles of her career back-to-back in Tokyo and Beijing, Agnieszka Radwanska needed just one more win to qualify directly for the year-end WTA Championships for the first time in her career.

headline: Warning by States as Tax Revenues Fail to Rebound
text: The warning by the State of Washington’s economist was unusually blunt, a far cry from the kind of dry, green-eyeshade language that often cloaks such announcements: “We are in the fragile aftermath of the Great Recession, where a return to normalcy seems like a mirage in the desert — the closer we get to it, the further it moves away.”

headline: Knot of Worry Tightens for Fishermen
text: SEATTLE — The scientist in Canada got the results from a respected lab and held a news conference. The ice and bait man at a fish processor in Sitka, Alaska, heard the news on Facebook. Vardon Tremain read it in the newspaper while working on his trolling boat docked here in Salmon Bay.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
text: The Finance Ministry finally admitted what every economist, stockbroker and reader of the business pages has long suspected: India’s growth rate will likely fall short of 8 percent this year. The global slowdown, rising oil and commodity prices and rising interest rates are to blame, Pranab Mukherjee, India’s finance minister, said Wednesday. The lower expectations will have a major impact on the best-case-scenario budget presented earlier this year, which assumed the treasury would overflow with the proceeds of a white-hot economy (Mint).

headline: Texas Courthouse Break-In Seen as Prank
text: SAN ANTONIO — Five young men were arrested early Wednesday morning in connection with a break-in at the Bexar County Courthouse here that raised fears of a terror plot but appeared instead to be a prank.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,471 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,795 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Wednesday:

headline: Pujols’s Defense and Carpenter’s St. Louis Legacy
text: ST. LOUIS – It didn’t quite get a star on my scoresheet because the ball was not hit all that hard. But the play Albert Pujols made on Michael Young to end the top of the sixth inning of Game 1 was impressive just the same. Pujols ranged to his left, across the first base line, and tossed to pitcher Chris Carpenter covering first for the out.

headline: On Bus Tour, Obama Promotes Jobs — and Himself
text: President Obama wrapped up a three-city bus tour to states that could prove to be a struggle to hold onto in the 2012 election.

headline: Pennsylvania: Second Woman Arrested in Case of Mentally Disabled Captives
text: The Philadelphia District Attorney’s Office said it had charged the daughter of Linda Weston, the woman arrested and accused of holding four mentally disabled adults captive and stealing their Social Security checks, as a participant in the crime. The daughter, Jean McIntosh, 32, lived in the building where the four people were found over the weekend, and is being charged by prosecutors as a co-conspirator in the kidnapping and imprisonment.

headline: Living Like the Other Half
text: Three weeks ago, two city-bred, upper-class aspiring entrepreneurs from Bangalore embarked on a mission: learn more about India, by subsisting for a month on what the average Indian does – just 100 rupees ($2.04) a day.

headline: Oct. 20, 1973 | Nixon Tries to Stop Investigation With ‘Saturday Night Massacre’
text: On Oct. 20, 1973, in the so-called “Saturday Night Massacre,” President Richard M. Nixon abolished the office of special Watergate prosecutor Archibald Cox, and accepted the resignation of Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson and fired Deputy Attorney General William B. Ruckelshaus for their refusal to fire Mr. Cox.

headline: Four Questions to Ask a Business Broker

Alas, if only the process were that simple. Following are four questions to get you started on finding the right broker to help sell your business.
