headline: U.S. Officials Deliver Warning in Pakistan Over Extremists
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An unusually powerful American delegation arrived here on Thursday to deliver the starkest warning yet to Pakistan, according to a senior American official: that the United States would act unilaterally if necessary to attack extremist groups that use the country as a haven to kill Americans.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘The Wilderness Rose Up to It’

headline: Prosecutor Reveals Details of UBS Rogue Trading Case
text: LONDON – Kweku M. Adoboli, the former UBS trader charged with fraud, had his case referred to a higher court Thursday as the prosecution revealed more details about how the Swiss bank discovered a $2.3 billion trading loss.

headline: Updates on the Death of Muammar el-Qaddafi
text: The Lede followed developments in Libya on Thursday, after the interim government announced that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi had been killed in his hometown of Surt, which fell after weeks of intense fighting.

headline: China to Allow Some Local Governments to Issue Bonds
text: SHANGHAI — Amid worries that local governments in China may be running short of cash, Beijing gave approval Thursday to a trial program that will allow the authorities in four regions to issue bonds.

headline: Romney, Bachmann and the Oys of Yiddish
text: Here in New York, which probably has more Yiddish speakers than any other city in the world, including in Israel, what are we to make of recent uses of a certain Yiddish word by a couple of politicians who don’t have a Jewish bone in their bodies? We’re referring to the Mormon Mitt Romney and the evangelical Christian Michele Bachmann.

headline: Strike at Revamped Musée d’Orsay Blocks Grand Reopening
text: PARIS — A strike by workers at the Musée d’Orsay postponed the long-awaited reopening of the museum’s newly renovated galleries on Thursday. Some 34 employees, mostly security guards, staged the walkout to protest the fact that no additional workers had been recruited at the museum despite the addition of more than 21,000 square feet of display space, a museum spokeswoman said. That decision was made amid broad government cutbacks that see retiring civil servants – including museum workers – not replaced by new hires.

headline: Times Co. Reports a Profit, Aided by Digital Subscribers

headline: Fewer iPhone Activations Hamper Growth at AT&T
text: For the wireless industry, it’s a time of sluggish growth, as the carriers battle it out to find new subscribers, especially those who will pay for lucrative data plans on smartphones. headline: Muammar el-Qaddafi: 42 Years as the Face of Libya

headline: N.F.L. Week 7 Game Probabilities: The Illusion of Power Rankings
text: Every major sports outlet seems to offer N.F.L. power rankings. I admit my site offers them, too. The game probability model I use for these weekly predictions also ranks teams. I match each team up against a notional league-average opponent at a neutral site, and rank each team according to the resulting game probabilities.

headline: Obama Group’s Web Video Attacks Romney

headline: Rhode Island: Pension Rollbacks Proposed
text: Gov. Lincoln D. Chafee and the state treasurer, Gina M. Raimondo, on Tuesday proposed scaling back pension benefits for state workers and retirees in a contentious effort to reduce roughly $7 billion in unfunded obligations. The proposal would end cost-of-living increases for now, raise the retirement age and combine traditional pensions with 401(k)-type plans to shift some of the taxpayer burden to the beneficiaries. Labor unions have threatened to challenge the changes in court should they pass the Legislature.

headline: Year Later, Officer’s Killing Confounds Colleagues

What they found continues to haunt them a year later: Sgt. Sean Drenth, a well-liked 12-year veteran, sprawled on his back, dead from a blast from his own police-issue shotgun.

Rock music, which was almost unheard of in Taiwan before 1987, has gained in popularity in the last 15 years as a generation of musicians who came of age under a more democratic government have looked to British and American bands, from Metallica to Radiohead, for inspiration.

It’s accurate as far as exaggerations go. To make a general observation, the small-batch roasters in the Nordic countries roast lighter than the rest of the world, and Oslo roasts lighter than the rest of the Nordic countries.

headline: The Real Problem With Toddlers and TV
text: Toddlers and TV is a subject that just won’t go away. KJ DellAntonia wrote about it here just last week, and this week a new recommendation issued by the American Academy of Pediatrics at the group’s annual meeting in Boston has revived it again. The pediatricians said that parents should limit the amount of time their infants and toddlers spend in front of any sort of screen and reaffirmed earlier research showing that there’s really no such thing as educational TV or software for very young children.

Surely the much-reviled 1 percent does not consist of plutocrats in top hats or predators in blue suits, but of human beings just like the other 99 percent of us, albeit with more money and perhaps more to answer for.

headline: 36 Hours in Albuquerque
text: FREE association with “Albuquerque” used to yield “Bugs Bunny” and “that airport you go through to get to Santa Fe.” But New Mexico’s biggest city has come into its own in recent years. Thanks to tax breaks and great scenery, the TV and film industry is booming: Joss Whedon’s mega-budget “Avengers” wrapped here this summer, and next year, “Breaking Bad” starts shooting its fifth season with Albuquerque as a backdrop. For visitors, the sprawl can seem daunting, but it is tempered by new bike paths. On the main drag, Central Avenue, neon signs from Route 66’s heyday glow over revitalized, pedestrian-friendly neighborhoods. And along the banks of the Rio Grande, lush farmland provides a quiet oasis, not to mention heirloom beans, corn and more to feed the city’s vibrant organic movement.

headline: 100 Miles From Manhattan, Feeling Both Young and Old
text: JONAS, Pa. — Rain and a gusty headwind kept me to a half day’s riding on Wednesday, slowing my progress home, though I’m not entirely bummed about that. It’s pretty here. I’m about 100 miles from Manhattan, having climbed some roller-coaster hills and wound a woodsy path through Hickory Run State Park, and I expect to cross the George Washington Bridge in the middle of the day Saturday. Yeah, it’s about time to be back in my own bed like a settled adult and in the newsroom like a reporter with a real job.

headline: Dirty Jobs
text: It appears that Republican claims that they can create lots of jobs by weakening environmental regulation are keying off a study from the American Petroleum Institute (pdf). There are a lot of things to critique about this study, including the fact that it actually shows a relatively small number of energy jobs, which are then blown up by assuming a large multiplier. Funny how spending can only move money around, not increase total spending, if it comes from the government, and how the multiplier is a nonsense concept when applied to government spending, but totally valid when it involves oil companies …

headline: Where Awful-Awful Meant Awfully Good
text: I think Josh Ozersky is at least a little out of his mind in this piece about the demise of Friendly’s and how sad it is that sit-down fast food chains are going out of business left and right. He’s correct, of course, in saying that they’re dying because people can’t afford them, and indeed there is nothing good about that. But that’s a disease, and the closing of bad restaurants is a symptom, and maybe an upside of that is that people cook the “casual food” that they’ve been going out to eat, and then recognize the advantages of doing so.

headline: Afghan Gun Locker: Battlefield Ingenuity, and a Weapon’s Longevity
text: This year, after Western journalists poured into Libya as the civilian population took up arms and lunged into war, a line of coverage on makeshift arms production and distribution found its way into many newspapers, magazines and Web sites. The New York Times was part of this, with coverage on the anti-Qaddafi forces’ hasty acquisition, production and fielding of all manner of repurposed arms and the vehicles to carry them. Often these weapons were poorly used. Sometimes they were fired just as indiscriminately as the weapons fired by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s troops that NATO, in its United Nations-approved bid to protect civilians, claimed to marshal international will to stop. Some of these weapons were also instrumental in the anti-Qaddafi militias’ eventual success, as was visible in Misurata. (For a fuller view of many of these themes, read this report on the hidden plant in Misurata, or these explainers on the dangerous repurposing of 57-mm air-to-ground rockets or 122-millimeter Grad rockets or, in this case, the knuckleheaded firing of plainly labeled inert rockets toward Qaddafi forces in Libya’s mountainous west.)

headline: Opera House Lights Shine Again in St. Louis
text: The lights at the Kiel Opera House in St. Louis went dark after a philharmonic performance in 1991. Unused for years, the theater reopened on Oct. 1 as the Peabody Opera House, after undergoing a $78 million restoration that began in July 2010.

headline: Cover-Ups, Personal and Political
text: “Boss,” a series on Starz about a crooked Chicago mayor, is almost good, and it falls short for the same reason that the George Clooney movie “Ides of March” isn’t good enough. headline: Smile and Metaphor, Crossing Borough Lines
text: A squat, leafy tree, its trunk too broad to wrap your arms around, rises from a round patch of dirt at the center of the Brooklyn Museum’s fifth floor rotunda. Many years ago, apparently, it grew up through the body of a baby-grand piano, and now the tree is beginning to swallow the instrument the way farmland trees do the strands of wire fences. Miraculously the piano, tilted and, you would have thought, ruined, intermittently plays a mournful tune, its keys going up and down as if stroked by a poltergeist. The tune? “Strange Fruit,”  the elegiac ode to black victims of lynching made famous by Billie Holiday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Greece and England.

headline: Where Art Is Child’s Play
text: THE bar at 103 Charlton Street buzzed with excited chatter at its grand opening, as more than a dozen young Saturday revelers waited to get in. Joe Vena leaned over the black granite countertop, cheerfully taking orders with a New York bartender’s consummate skill.

headline: Over the River and Through the ’Hoods
text: THEY are hard to miss on the weekend. Some on mountain bikes or 10-speeds weave their way through hilly streets that even cars struggle to climb. The more serious ones ride in packs, wear colorful spandex suits and sit on high-end bikes made by Trek, Cervélo, Cannondale and others. They ride three and four across in the street, all but daring drivers to honk or worse.

headline: Sotheby’s as a Gallery; an Ai Weiwei at Duke
text: BROWSE AND BUY

headline: Finding Solace, Oceans From Home
text: “Le Havre,” named for the industrial port city in northern France where it takes place, is a tale of lower-depths solidarity, a stylized and sentimental fairy tale about the way the world might be, grounded in a frank recognition of the way it is.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | WORD
text: A bookstore in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, strives to create a community of people who love literature.

headline: Americans for Greater Inequality
text: As Rich Oppel and I wrote in an article today, the Republican presidential candidates have been steadily promoting flatter — and therefore more regressive — tax overhaul plans. Flatter taxes have of course always been the holy grail for many in the conservative base, but now such proposals seem to be gathering broader support, too.

headline: Appointment Ends Impasse on Bank of Italy Leadership
text: ROME — Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi made a surprise choice Thursday to take over as governor of the Bank of Italy next month, ending a prolonged impasse.

headline: In Surt, Chronicle of a Death Foretold
text: Days before the frenzied jubilation at the capture and death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Mauricio Lima had been patiently — and persistently — working the streets of Surt. Though overseas interest had waned in recent days, his attention did not. He was close up and alongside fighters as they pursued their elusive target, and his images are suffused with a nuanced touch because of that.

headline: Perry Capital Cuts Staff and Closes Hong Kong Office
text: The hedge fund Perry Capital is retrenching, according to two people with knowledge of the situation.

headline: Live and Let Laugh: A Secret Agent Reloads
text: Some may wonder why “Johnny English Reborn,” the sequel to the 2003 James Bond spoof, “Johnny English,” starring Rowan Atkinson as a bumbling MI7 agent, was even made, seeing as the original earned a modest $28 million at the United States box office.

headline: Amid Abortion Questions, Cain Steps Up Iowa Game
text: Questions from social conservatives about whether Herman Cain opposes abortion rights under all circumstances are arising anew after an interview Wednesday evening with CNN’s Piers Morgan. The issue is simmering as Mr. Cain steps up his efforts to woo Iowa’s Republican caucusgoers — many conservative Christians — by recruiting a veteran operative to lead his campaign there.

headline: Hugo Chávez Says His Cancer Is Gone
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela declared on Thursday that he had beaten cancer, less than five months after he stunned Venezuelans by revealing that he had undergone emergency surgery to remove a tumor while in seclusion in Cuba.

text: 18TH-CENTURY PORTRAITIST

headline: A View of Central Park, or 100 of Them
text: Betsy Pinover Schiff took some photographs that did not make it into her new book. Consider the ones from the apartment where the owner led her into the bedroom and told her, “I don’t want my wife to know about this.”

headline: On Our Radar: Massachusetts Leads Efficiency Rankings
text: Massachusetts edges out California for first place in the annual rankings from the Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy. California ranks second, New York is third, and Oregon, Washington, Vermont and Rhode Island tie for fourth place. [The Los Angeles Times]

headline: Ghosts Go Retro in ‘Paranormal Activity 3’
text: Spoiler Alert: In “Paranormal Activity 3,” cameras are set up inside a house, doors mysteriously slam shut, bed sheets mysteriously move and things mysteriously go bump in the night.

headline: Audit Flaws Revealed, at Long Last
text: With hindsight, we now know that auditors in 2007 should have been looking carefully at bank books.

headline: Do You Know What I Mean? Probably Not
text: THE playwright David Henry Hwang has been in high demand in China in recent years — not for works like his Tony Award-winning “M. Butterfly,” which is essentially banned there, but because of his standing as the only son of Asia to be represented regularly on Broadway. In 2005 he was invited to Shanghai to discuss Broadway-style shows that might fill the lavish cultural centers under construction across the country. Yet China’s appreciation for status symbols like Broadway and Mr. Hwang did not translate into understanding more mundane aspects of American life.

headline: A New Jewel in Town
text: Eva Zuckerman, the designer of Eva Fehren, a new fine jewelry line, first started tinkering with jewelry while working for Mor Mor Rita, a high-end children’s brand. “Women actually bought my stuff!” exclaims Zuckerman, who put her Cooper Union fine arts background on hold for the opportunity to work for the jewelry designers Philip Crangi and, later, Monique Péan. “They’re such wonderful teachers,” she says, crediting both mentors with instilling in her the importance of sustainable gems (like petrified wood and lapis lazuli stones) and innovative craftsmanship (seen in her delicate gold stackable bands and geometric rings and bracelets). And from the looks of her debut effort, this promising pupil gets a gold star.

headline: Warhol in Washington
text: Two aspects of Andy Warhol’s art are on display in unalike but complementary shows in Washington.

headline: Pop Rides the News Cycle
text: WASHINGTON — A pity that Andy Warhol, who died in 1987, couldn’t be around for the social media century. With his penchant for terse utterance, he was born to tweet. As an avid scenester with an outsider’s soul, he would have found Facebook the answer to a prayer.

headline: Footnote
text: “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,” Mike Daisey’s critically praised one-man show about the founder of Apple, will run an additional three weeks at the Public Theater before closing on Dec. 4, the Public announced.

headline: Picasso’s Muse
text: A show at the Gagosian Gallery chronicling the years that Françoise Gilot and Pablo Picasso were lovers is one of many gallery exhibitions stirring excitement.

headline: Stealing the Show
text: She’s almost 90 and still living very much in the present, quietly painting every day in her West Side studio. Yet Françoise Gilot — Picasso’s muse and lover and the mother of two of his children — is about to revisit her past.

headline: Qaddafi’s End and Libya’s Future
text: The lawless manner of Muammar el-Qaddafi’s death — he was apparently beaten, dragged and shot by a mob of armed men in the streets of Surt — is well-fitted to the lawless way he ruled his country. Like Mussolini and Ceausescu, he perished by the same sword that he lived by. We should regret the absence of the fair trial that even the worst criminal deserves, but it’s hard not to feel a certain mordant satisfaction at the ignominious way that one of recent history’s genuine monsters passed to his reward. Thus always to tyrants …

headline: The Persona and the Palette
text: He had “a sun in his head and a thunderstorm in his heart”: these words used to describe the French painter Eugène Delacroix were memorized by Vincent van Gogh and could just as easily have been applied to van Gogh himself.

headline: Microsoft Posts Gain Despite Soft PC Sales
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft said its net income rose 6 percent in its first fiscal quarter, but the company’s results continued to reflect weak growth in PC sales.

headline: Making a Judgment on Love
text: THE call came around 3:30 p.m. on a sultry Minnesota day. The hospice social worker, Cheryl, explained the situation in a rush. She had tried 15 judges, and all were either in court or otherwise unavailable. By chance, she had reached me directly.

headline: Getting to Know a Sperm-Donor Dad
text: In November 2005, I wrote an article about two teenage girls, raised in different families, who discovered they are the genetic children of the same sperm donor. The girls, JoEllen Marsh and Danielle Pagano, met through the Donor Sibling Registry, a Web site that has connected thousands of half-siblings conceived through donor insemination.

headline: Erin & Douglas
text: In this homemade video, Erin Darboven and Douglas Havlina reminisce over the phone about getting engaged at the end of their trip to the South Fork of the Salmon River in Idaho with a twisty tie ring.

text: The second date proved to be the charm for Leigh Abrams and David Waterman.

headline: Six Years After a Debilitating Stroke, Sharon Remains Responsive, His Son Says
text: JERUSALEM — Ariel Sharon, who suffered a debilitating stroke nearly six years ago while serving as prime minister of Israel and remains in a coma-like state, responds to some requests and, despite being fed intravenously, has put on weight, according to his son Gilad Sharon.

headline: My Three Favorite Ghost Films
text: As a toddler, I was terrified of one of my father’s favorite movies, “The Day the Earth Stood Still,” directed by Robert Wise. I had no idea what the story was about; it was the imagery that overwhelmed me.

headline: Moment of Truth for Red Bulls
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The Red Bulls have the Portland Timbers to thank for getting at least one albatross off their backs — Dwayne De Rosario — at least for now.

headline: L.A. Reid Defends His ‘X Factor’ Choices
text: “The X Factor” is, at this point in the show, supposed to be a competition between the four judges, each of whom is acting as a mentor to a group of contestants. But one of those judges, L.A. Reid, didn’t exactly take the gloves off when asked about his opponents. In fact, he put the kid gloves on.

headline: Earning Points, if Not Yet a Nickname
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — It would help if the Islanders’ top line had a catchy name. Then more people would take notice that not just John Tavares, but also his wingmen, P. A. Parenteau and Matt Moulson, are off to hot starts this season.

headline: A New Director for Dallas Museum of Art
text: Maxwell L. Anderson, who has been director of the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 2006, has been named director of the Dallas Museum of Art. He succeeds Bonnie Pitman, who retired from the job in June.

headline: Wikipedia’s Deep Dive Into a Library Collection
text: AMATEUR digital archivists and musical theater devotees are invited to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts on Saturday for a six-hour “editathon,” an event meant to improve Wikipedia’s musical-theater-related entries using the library’s special collections.

headline: Surveying a Range of Riches
text: One size does not fit all at the annual International Fine Art & Antique Dealers Show, which is back at the Park Avenue Armory for a 23rd year. Unlike some other fairs at this space, this exposition doesn’t try to rein in its more than 60 exhibitors — a group that includes specialists in arms and armor, fine jewelry and illuminated manuscripts among its purveyors of art and antiques.

headline: RIM Faces a Naming Problem
text: OTTAWA–While Research in Motion disappointed many analysts this week by offering relatively little specific or new information about the next generation of BlackBerry phones, it did make one announcement at a software conference. The new operating system for those phones will be named BBX.

headline: Does Facebook Change Your Brain?
text: Those of you who responded to my female friendship post by diagnosing me with a whopper case of introversion were right on the mark: in fact, my neighbor, who specializes in such things, once told me that I was the most introverted person he had ever met.

headline: Of Course, She’s Worried
text: My husband’s closest friends have three children, each with a separate behavioral diagnosis (A.D.H.D., Asperger’s, dyslexia). The mother spends a tremendous amount of time researching and navigating this world. Unfortunately, it’s all she talks about, in a stream of medical jargon. Worse, she’s constantly relating their diagnoses to my children’s behavior. “Are you worried he’s on the spectrum?” she’ll ask, when my 4-year-old spins in the backyard with a bubble wand. How should I deal with this? Stephanie, Boston

headline: Rin Tin Tin: American Hero
text: Do dogs deserve biographies? In “Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend,” Susan Orlean answers that question resoundingly in the affirmative, while also asking a harder one: Can a dog deserve an Oscar? At the first Academy Awards, presented in 1929, the charismatic German shepherd who fought off gangs of villains in movies like “Clash of the Wolves” and “Jaws of Steel” won the vote count for best actor, but the Academy blinked, recalculated and gave the honor instead to Emil Jannings. Not that the public would have necessarily protested an Oscar for Rin Tin Tin. “He is a human dog,” one fan wrote to his trainer, “human in the real big sense of the word.” As for Jannings and his colleagues, there may have been some doubt. A few years earlier, Movie magazine ran a feature asking “Are Actors People?”

headline: With New Hope, Women Activists Keep Focus on Libya

headline: A Stage Not Big Enough for a Legend
text: First, an apology all too relevant to the subject of this review. Earlier this week, in my review of the Suzanne Farrell Ballet’s season in Washington, I neglected to mention either the Kennedy Center’s orchestra or its conductor, Emil de Cou. Both show standards higher than those we are used to hearing in New York; Mr. de Cou may now be the finest ballet conductor in America. I remembered them all the more wistfully on Wednesday when the Farrell company made its debut at the Joyce Theater, dancing to taped music.

headline: Interest in Old Bank Is Repaid
text: AFTER several years doubling up with roommates in unsavory apartments in Manhattan, James Bilodeau, a musician who works for SiriusXM Radio, gave up his goal of living near his job and began looking for a place in the suburbs north of the city.

headline: Woman Escapes a Cult but Not Her Own Past
text: As its title suggests, “Martha Marcy May Marlene” is a story of fractured identity, in which a young woman tries to negotiate incompatible versions of herself, all the while wondering who she really is. The film, Sean Durkin’s impressively self-assured debut feature, switches back and forth between two periods in its protagonist’s life — an indeterminate span when she is part of a cult in rural New York and the time just after her escape from the group, when she has found refuge with her older sister and brother-in-law in their rented lakeside vacation house.

text: The Look: Yellow Jacket — a dramatic black and yellow look made all the more striking with a bit of silver jewelry and those strong, dark brows.

headline: When the Roommate Has Four Legs

headline: Public Radio Host Linked to Protest is Dismissed
text: A public radio host who was linked this week to antiwar and anti-corporate-greed protests in Washington, D.C., has been fired by one radio producer that employs her, but supported by another.

headline: Knowing When to Refinance
text: REFINANCINGS made up 79 percent of all 2011 mortgage applications as of early October, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association, about the same level as last year but well above the 54 percent average of the last decade. Many of these applications have come from so-called serial refinancers in a constant search for the lowest possible interest rate.

headline: New Leader Approved by Port Authority
text: The Board of Commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Thursday unanimously approved the appointment of Patrick J. Foye, to become the agency’s new executive director.

headline: Hipstamatic in Kabul
text: When Ben Lowy was in Afghanistan taking pictures for our article “The Bad Guys vs. the Worse Guys,” he did so using both his digital camera, to make traditional 35-millimeter photos, and the Hipstamatic app on his iPhone. Our plan all along had been to publish the 35-millimeter pictures, but once we saw what he had on his iPhone, we felt we had to use those images instead. They were more exciting and dynamic; the rich palette and high contrast brought clarity and texture and even poetry to the scenes.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 7’s Toughest Picks

headline: Shippers Are Jostling for Greater Global Share
text: AFTER a major retrenchment in the United States three years ago, DHL Express U.S. is repositioning itself with a new marketing campaign to persuade medium-size and smaller American companies to sign up for its international shipping expertise.

headline: Privacy and Press Freedom Collide in University Case
text: It was bad enough for the University of Illinois when The Chicago Tribune’s 2009 series “Clout Goes to College” exposed the existence of a “clout list” that over five years gave hundreds of well-connected students an edge in admissions, and led to the resignations of the university president, the chancellor of the flagship Urbana-Champaign campus and most of the trustees.

headline: Promised Paradise, Then Sent to Hell
text: In the quietly wrenching “Oranges and Sunshine” Emily Watson portrays Margaret Humphreys, an intrepid social worker from Nottingham, England, who exposed shameful national crimes. As recently as 1967, but especially in the 1940s and ’50s, as many as 130,000 children were removed from orphanages and group homes in Britain and deported to various locations in the Commonwealth, particularly western Australia. One deportee, now grown up, recalls being told at the age of 10 that he was being sent to a sunny paradise where he could pick oranges off trees.

text: ST. LOUIS — The Texas Rangers forced the St. Louis Cardinals to go deep into their bullpen again and hit two sacrifice flies in the ninth inning to rally for a 2-1 victory in Game 2 of the World Series on Thursday night at Busch Stadium.

headline: Jobs Tried Exotic Treatments to Combat Cancer, Book Says
text: In his last years, Steven P. Jobs veered from exotic diets to cutting-edge treatments as he fought the cancer that ultimately took his life, according to a new biography to be published on Monday.

headline: F.B.I. Scrutinized for Amassing Data on American Communities
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation has collected information about religious, ethnic and national-origin characteristics of American communities, according to internal F.B.I. documents made public by the American Civil Liberties Union on Thursday. Citing the materials, the group urged the Justice Department to tighten restrictions on F.B.I. powers.

headline: New Bottom-Line Approach Good for Cisco
Unleashing Some Havoc After a Case of Cabin Fever
text: If there’s one thing to be learned from the “Paranormal Activity” franchise, it’s that invisible demons do not like to be videotaped. It makes them antsy, and before long they’re hiding in closets, sneaking into bedrooms, breaking furniture, dragging bodies across the floor and killing somebody. And they don’t distinguish between VHS and high-definition digital.

headline: Exotic Animals as Pets: An Unregulated Risk
text: IMAGINE the panic and terror experienced by the monkeys, bears, lions and leopards that ran loose in Ohio earlier this week as they were chased and then killed by the police. Imagine the heartbreak of the police officers who were obliged to destroy the rambling menagerie. Officers are not trained to stalk big game and bring them in alive with tranquilizer darts.

headline: John Bryson Confirmed as Commerce Secretary
text: The Senate voted 74-26 on Thursday to confirm the nomination of John Bryson to be the next commerce secretary, ending a months-long struggle over President Obama’s choice.

headline: She Was Told She’d Be a Model. Of Course.
text: A stripped-down, socially conscious drama set in the slippery world of human trafficking, Yan Vizinberg’s “Cargo” is commendably free of cheap emotional manipulation. Instead the film leans almost exclusively on the focused performances of its two leads, who create a credibly barbed chemistry that goes a long way toward distracting us from the film’s low-budget deficiencies.

headline: Growths Linked to Venereal Virus Are on Rise in Women
text: Precancerous growths on the genitals are becoming more common in women, particularly those in their 40s, a medical group said Thursday, reporting a fourfold increase in women over all from 1973 to 2000.

headline: Hip Surgery Option Loses Key Backer
text: In another controversy involving all-metal hips, an influential group has found that there is insufficient evidence to show that an alternative technique known as hip resurfacing is as safe and effective as a traditional replacement.

headline: How Fame Divided Bandmates in Love
text: “The Swell Season” is less a musical documentary than the story of a breakup, even if its makers seem at times frustratingly determined to smother their film’s most valuable emotional hook. Named for the band formed by the Irish-Czech duo Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova, whose starring roles in the tiny 2007 musical “Once” and subsequent Academy Award for the beautiful song “Falling Slowly” hoisted them to international stardom, the film glances back at the two-year tour that followed those events.

headline: Long Pursuit of Justice Takes a Father Beyond the Law
text: PARIS — In the dark early hours of an October morning in 2009, acting on an anonymous tip, police officers in the French city of Mulhouse picked up an elderly German doctor who had been left — bound, beaten and bleeding — in a street near the municipal courthouse. The man, Dieter Krombach, had been kidnapped outside his home in Germany and secreted across the border into France, where there was a warrant for his arrest in connection with the death of a French girl nearly three decades ago.

headline: In Bid to Cut Costs at Some Texas Prisons, Lunch Will Not Be Served on Weekends

headline: An Electric Car Drives an Industry’s Change

text: On Thursday morning, when word reached New York from Libya that Muammar el-Qaddafi had taken a turn for the worse, a man in the Libyan mission to the United Nations on East 48th Street reflected on the moment.

headline: Party of Pollution
text: Last month President Obama finally unveiled a serious economic stimulus plan — far short of what I’d like to see, but a step in the right direction. Republicans, predictably, have blocked it. But the new plan, combined with the Occupy Wall Street demonstrations, seems to have shifted the national conversation. We are, suddenly, focused on what we should have been talking about all along: jobs.

headline: An Apology for a Guatemalan Coup, 57 Years Later
text: MEXICO CITY — More than a half-century after Guatemala’s elected president Jacobo Arbenz Guzman was overthrown in a coup planned by the C.I.A. and forced into a wandering exile, President Alvaro Colom apologized on Thursday for what he called a “great crime.”

headline: Without ‘Super PAC’ Numbers, Campaign Filings Present an Incomplete Picture
text: The third-quarter campaign finance filings are in. The numbers have been crunched. And now we know who is winning the 2012 fund-raising race. Right?

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Expected to Plead Guilty to Insider Trading
text: A hedge fund manager from a prominent Denver family is expected to plead guilty on Friday to insider trading charges.

headline: For These Men, Basketball Means Hope
text: It’s impossible not to be moved watching Anne Buford’s “Elevate,” a documentary about Senegalese basketball players given a chance to play and receive an education in the United States.

headline: Label Plan Offered to Rate Food Nutrition
text: The nutrition label on the front of a box of cereal, a frozen dinner or any other food should be as quick and easy to read as the Energy Star label on a clothes washer or an air-conditioner, according to a study released Thursday that was requested by Congress.

headline: Hamilton Is Playing the Postseason in Pain
text: ST. LOUIS

headline: Colonel Qaddafi’s End
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya died as he lived — violently. We sympathize with the Libyans who suffered for so long at the hands of the ruthless dictator and are glad he can no longer hurt them. But a gruesome video broadcast on Al Jazeera — apparently showing him being dragged, beaten and then, perhaps, shot to death by armed men — is deeply troubling, if it is real.

headline: A Protector of Women With a Chip on His Shoulder
text: There are an awful lot of terrorized women in “Boy Wonder” — so many, in fact, that the film feels like a constant assault. Their unlikely champion is Sean (Caleb Steinmeyer), a skulking 17-year-old vigilante driven by violent childhood memories of his mother’s death at the hands of a carjacker. But Sean is obsessed with more than just finding his mother’s killer: He’s also on a mission to finish off every misogynist in the five boroughs.

headline: The Power of Positive Coaching
text: Imagine you’re coaching a big soccer game, against an undefeated team that has beaten your team in all your previous matches. Your 11-year-olds are playing well and are ahead. Then, in the closing minutes, the official makes a bad call that goes against you and, because of it, you lose. After the game, the parents of your players scream at the official. The kids are disappointed, looking up at you. What do you do?

headline: After Arrest of Man in Wife’s Death, a Custody Fight
text: BOONTON, N.J. — When dusk descended here last Sunday, and the forum on domestic violence was over, some 200 people carrying candles marched up the hilly street to where Nazish Noorani had been killed exactly two months earlier in a shooting the police said had been set up by her husband.

headline: Qaddafi’s Death Places Focus on Arab Spring’s ‘Hard Road’
text: TUNIS — Like the flight of Tunisia’s dictator or the trial of Egypt’s, the capture of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Thursday afternoon captivated the Arab world, giving a renewed sense of power and possibility. But the photographs of his bloody corpse that circulated just moments later on cellphones and television screens quickly tempered that exhilaration with a reminder of the many still-unresolved conflicts that the Arab Spring has also unleashed.

headline: Romney Will Compete in Iowa, if a Bit Cautiously
text: TREYNOR, Iowa — Mitt Romney always said he would be back.

headline: An Incubator of Baseball Talent
text: ST. LOUIS — Few cities resonate with as much baseball tradition as St. Louis, and few seem as doused in team colors as this city, where even the downtown fountains are spraying water tinted Cardinal rouge this October.

headline: Now, Get Along Boys, or You’ll Be Poor
text: O.K., so they’re not Adam, Hoss and Little Joe. But the brothers who bond while reminiscing about those “Bonanza” scions — and more so by riding horses, fighting bad guys and sharing some manly chuckles amid the bickering — turn out to be their own sort of entertaining fraternal threesome in the action-genre film “The Reunion.”

headline: First as Farce, Then as Tragedy
text: The first months of the Civil War had been a series of humiliating lessons for the citizens and soldiers of the Union, highlighted by dramatic defeats at Bull Run and Wilson’s Creek. The war, it was becoming clear, would be neither easy nor quick. But it was also clear that, especially among the Union Army officer corps, those lessons had not yet fully sunk in — a fact made all too clear by the Oct. 21 disaster at the Battle of Ball’s Bluff.

headline: Two Major Hospital Groups in City Explore a Partnership
text: Two of New York City’s major hospital organizations are exploring a partnership that would give them a large share of the city’s patients and make them a formidable rival for other city hospitals in tough economic times.

headline: Migrants from Sanity
text: With 14 million Americans out of work, you would think somebody could answer the desperation call from farmers offering to pay $150 to anyone willing to pick fruit in the orchards of Washington State. But no, the apples hang at peak ripeness, a near-record crop, and the jobs go begging, despite radio ads and an appeal by Governor Christine Gregoire to the other Washington for help.

headline: Wal-Mart Cuts Some Health Care Benefits
text: After trying to mollify its critics in recent years by offering better health care benefits to its employees, Wal-Mart is substantially rolling back coverage for part-time workers and significantly raising premiums for many full-time staff.

headline: Putting a Face to a Familiar Voice
text: Early in “Being Elmo: A Puppeteer’s Journey,” a young man named Kevin Clash is seen trying to find a voice for a puppet he has made. He has the puppet say “Hi” over and over with different accents and inflections.

headline: The Arctic and the Lessons of the Gulf
text: The Interior Department has been inching closer to approving Royal Dutch Shell’s ambitious plans to drill for what are believed to be huge deposits of oil in the Arctic Ocean off Alaska. In August, it approved an exploratory drilling plan for the Beaufort Sea, and two weeks ago it upheld the validity of leases in the neighboring Chukchi Sea that had been challenged by environmental groups.

headline: After Making Capture in Pipe, Displaying the Trophies of War
text: MISURATA, Libya — They had the ultimate trophies of the revolution: the colonel’s golden gun, his satellite phone, his brown scarf and one black boot.

headline: Familiar Card for Jets in the Motivation Game
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Rex Ryan spent five minutes Thursday awkwardly fielding questions about what he repeatedly called his “unintentional” slam of San Diego Chargers Coach Norv Turner earlier in the week, then pirouetted to a much more pleasant topic.

headline: Florida Senator Denies Claim He Gilded His Family History
text: MIAMI — Senator Marco Rubio, a rising Republican star, confronted questions on Thursday that he had embellished his family history and misrepresented the year his parents first left Cuba for the United States.

headline: A Deal to Help Foster Youths Find Housing
text: New York City has reached an agreement on a proposed settlement of a lawsuit that claims the city allows older children to leave foster care only to become immediately homeless.

headline: Brothers and Champions
text: Celebrated as much for brains as for battering power, the Ukrainian brothers Vitali and Wladimir Klitschko have boxed their way from obscurity to worldwide fame with a discipline envied by many of their counterparts. Exhibiting a similar single-mindedness, Sebastian Dehnhardt’s “Klitschko” documents that journey, and if at times his mountainous subjects sound a little too self-serving, it’s not as if anyone were going to argue with them.

headline: Friday: Day Five of the Crossword Contest
text: Administrivial Format Alert! Today’s puzzle format is different, so there is no Across Lite file. Please print out and solve the PDF.

headline: As Autocrats Are Toppled, Their Fates Grow More Extreme
text: CAIRO — With Arab despots toppling at an unprecedented pace since January, a range of options for the final curtain have been tested, with Libya’s leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, typically, making the most dramatic exit with his gory death on Thursday.

headline: Blighted Existences, Eased With Hope and Humor
text: To observe that a play about extreme suffering is also explosively funny might seem absurd. But one of the many soul-piercing truths in “Sons of the Prophet,” the absolutely wonderful new comedy-drama by Stephen Karam that opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater, is that life rarely obeys the rules of dramatic consistency, or, for that matter, fair play.

headline: Each Family, Tortured in Its Own Way
text: Mothers come in for some serious savaging in “Relatively Speaking,” a reasonably savory tasting platter of comedies by Ethan Coen, Elaine May and Woody Allen that opened on Thursday night at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Obama’s Jobs Plan Is Blocked Again by Senate Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — For the second time in 10 days, the Senate on Thursday rejected Democratic efforts to take up a jobs bill championed by President Obama.

headline: Blazing a Feminist, and Hall of Fame, Trail
text: Sometimes a film feels a bit too pat and yet is impossible to resist. “The Mighty Macs,” based on the national championship run of the 1972 women’s basketball team at Immaculata College near Philadelphia, is such a film: lots of button pushing, but in the end you’re glad you saw it.

headline: Craig Keeps Making Pinch-Hits Look Easy
text: ST. LOUIS — The Cardinals’ Allen Craig spent a good part of Thursday afternoon explaining how difficult it is to pinch-hit. Yet he has made it look easy in October.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,796 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: A Teenager’s Hardships, at Home and School
text: There’s something sweet about Jonathan Segal’s modest high school drama, “Norman,” despite the contrivances of its protagonist’s predicament and its stacking of the emotional deck. Norman Long (Dan Byrd of “Cougar Town” and “Easy A”) is a smart, sensitive and reflexively wisecracking teenager with a mother who died in a car accident and a father (the consistently reliable Richard Jenkins) who’s in, yes, the terminal stage of stomach cancer.

headline: Check-In at Dodge City
text: The next time you’re aggravated, beltless and in your socks in the airport security line, you might consider the latest tally of loaded weapons confiscated from carry-on luggage around the nation.

headline: Climate Skeptics Stay Unswayed
text: A new study designed to address critiques of climate science by skeptics has confirmed that “global warming is real” and that the world’s average land temperature has risen by about 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit since the mid-1950s.

headline: Accountability in Missouri
text: It has been seven years since the Roman Catholic Church’s investigative board of laity warned that, beyond the 700 priests dismissed for sexually abusing children, “there must be consequences” for the diocesan leaders who recycled criminal priests through unsuspecting parishes. American church authorities have done nothing to heed this caution.

headline: Masked Protector of Gotham Has His Eye on Wall Street Protesters
text: He is a tycoon, but he is also a crusader for justice: Bruce Wayne is coming to Wall Street, and how the 99 percent will receive him is the latest worry facing a beleaguered Lower Manhattan.

headline: California Adopts Limits on Greenhouse Gases
text: SACRAMENTO — Fifteen months after a similar effort died in Congress, California regulators adopted a system on Thursday for combating climate change that sets limits on greenhouse gas emissions and creates market incentives to encourage oil refineries, electricity generators and other polluters to clean up their plants.

headline: Support for Move to Broaden Definition of Rape
text: Police officials and women’s groups on Thursday applauded a recommendation by a Federal Bureau of Investigation subcommittee that the definition of rape used by the agency be revised. The definition, written more than 80 years ago, has been criticized as too narrow, resulting in thousands of rapes being excluded from the F.B.I.’s annual Uniform Crime Report. The subcommittee recommends a broader definition, to include anal and oral rape, as well as rapes involving male victims. Currently, only sexual assaults that involved force and vaginal penetration are included. The proposal is subject to approval of a full advisory board, which meets in December. Women’s groups have been trying for years to get the definition changed. “What I’m happiest about is that such a clear consensus is emerging from law enforcement officials all over the country that this has to happen,” said Carol Tracy, executive director of the Women’s Law Project in Philadelphia.

headline: Massachusetts: Man’s Death Sentence Is Thrown Out
text: A judge in Boston threw out a death sentence on Thursday in a 2003 murder case, ruling that a juror had not been impartial. Judge Mark L. Wolf of Federal District Court found that the juror had repeatedly lied during jury selection in a way that called her impartiality into question. He said the convict, Gary Lee Sampson, was entitled to a new sentencing trial to determine whether the death penalty was warranted. Mr. Sampson pleaded guilty to murdering two men who had picked him up hitchhiking. It was the first federal case in Massachusetts in which the death penalty was imposed.

headline: E.P.A. to Tighten Rules on Wastewater Disposal
text: The Environmental Protection Agency announced Thursday that it would devise stricter rules for the treatment and disposal of toxic wastewater used in natural gas drilling. The agency said it planned to set standards by 2014 for the management of wastewater used in a rapidly growing drilling tactic known as hydrofracking, which involves injecting huge amounts of water to break up shale or coal bed formations and release the gas.

headline: Arab Spring and Fall
text: An update on the leaders of countries where protests have turned violent.

headline: Red Bulls Bring Home Final Spot in Playoffs
text: HARRISON, N.J. — On a cool autumn night, the Red Bulls were at their most crisp and intense when anything less would have been unacceptable.

text: NATIONAL

headline: Russia and Georgia Trade Talks Stymied
text: Talks between Georgia and Russia on Russia’s accession to the World Trade Organization ended with no agreement on Thursday, and little time remains if Russia is to join the organization by the end of the year. The two sides are to meet again on Tuesday, said Deputy Foreign Minister Sergi Kapanadze, who headed Georgia’s delegation to the talks in Switzerland. He said the discussions were stymied by Georgia’s request for information on trade through Abkhazia and South Ossetia, breakaway territories of Georgia that Russia has recognized as sovereign countries. American and Russian officials have said they hope to complete the accession process by the end of the year, which would require Georgia’s approval by mid-November.

headline: Nearly Car-Free
text: Though not quite car-free, Vauban, Germany, is a highly "car-reduced" suburb.

headline: World Series Replay: Game 2
text: Smart base running helped the Rangers score twice in the ninth inning of a 2-1 victory.

headline: Similar Script, Different Ending
text: ST. LOUIS — For those unable to see Game 1 of the World Series on Wednesday night, the key moments of that game were conveniently replayed in striking detail on Thursday. At least that was how it seemed heading into the ninth inning.

headline: Five Harlem Men Guilty in Drug-Trafficking Conspiracy
text: Five men from Harlem were convicted on Thursday of running a drug-trafficking conspiracy in a trial that examined the intricacies of what prosecutors called a gang.

headline: Word of the Day | placebo
text: placebo •\plə-ˈse-(ˌ)bo\• noun

headline: Morris Chafetz, 87, Dies; Altered View of Alcoholism
text: Dr. Morris E. Chafetz, who played an important role in changing the public perception of alcoholism from social crime or personal failing to a disease requiring treatment, died on Oct. 14 at his home in Washington. He was 87.

headline: Barry Feinstein, Photographer of Defining Rock Portraits, Dies at 80
text: Barry Feinstein, a photographer who chronicled the lives of seminal rock ’n’ roll stars of the 1960s, and who was perhaps best known for the stark portrait of Bob Dylan on the cover of the 1964 album “The Times They Are A-Changin’,” died on Thursday in a hospital near his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 80.

headline: Uganda: 2 Leaders of Protest Movement Are Charged With Treason, Police Say
text: The government is charging the ringleaders of street demonstrations this week with treason, officials said Thursday, an offense that can carry the death penalty. The police said that about 40 people had been arrested across the country since Monday, when activists tried to resume demonstrations begun in April against rising commodity prices and government corruption. The police accuse the activists of seeking to overthrow the government. Two members of the group Activists 4 Change were arraigned on treason charges on Wednesday, said Judith Nabakooba, a police spokeswoman. One of them is an assistant to the opposition leader Kizza Besigye. At least nine people were killed and hundreds arrested during protests led by Mr. Besigye this past spring.

headline: After 23 Years, a Suspect Emerges and a Family’s Wounds Are Reopened
text: Almost everything that Caitlin and Jesse Baker know about their mother, who was mysteriously murdered 23 years ago when they were small children, comes from memories shared by relatives and from fading family photos of the smiling, petite brunette.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
text: Reacting to the death of the Libyan dictator Muammar el-Qaddafi, India’s Ministry of External Affairs said the strife in Libya and the suffering of its people had been a matter of concern and it hoped that peace and stability would soon return to Libya (The Hindu). India abstained from the vote authorizing airstrikes against Libya in the United Nations Security Council earlier this year.

headline: Lines Go Up to Ferry Wind Energy to Major Cities
text: SWEETWATER — Enormous transmission towers stand beside a West Texas country road, waiting for electric wires to be strung through them. Nearby, the task of threading wires through the steel towers is already under way, as men in hard hats shift equipment into position.

text: Ryan McDonagh’s goal with two seconds left in overtime gave the Rangers a 3-2 win in Calgary on Thursday.

text: Because of the Jewish holiday Simhat Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: In High-Crime Areas, Still Too Few Police
text: Despite Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s highly promoted efforts at concentrating additional police patrols in the city’s most dangerous neighborhoods, many crime-ridden police districts still have fewer officers patrolling their streets than far safer areas of the city have, according to recent data obtained by The Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A Tale of 3,400 Retired Teachers and a Possible $90 Million Math Mistake
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Chinese Toddler Who Was Run Over Twice Dies
text: BEIJING — A  toddler who stirred a national debate on compassion after being run over twice by vans and left lying in a market street in southern China has died a week after the incident, hospital officials in Guangzhou said on Friday.

headline: Another Can’t-Miss General Manager Is Hired
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Mayor’s Political Machine Goes Into High Gear in Quest for Full Term
text: On Sept. 14, about a dozen business and labor leaders gathered in an eighth-floor conference room in the Financial District. They met for an hour, rehearsing their strategy to assure that Ed Lee, the interim mayor of San Francisco, is elected to a four-year term on Nov. 8.

headline: 20 Years After Fire, Revelation and Tribute
text: Richard Misrach has built his reputation photographing destruction, be it in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina or in the industrial area known as Cancer Alley along the Mississippi River in southern Louisiana. Twenty years ago, however, it was a disaster close to home that led him to take out his 8-by-10 large-format camera.

headline: Russians Come to the Rescue of Sonoma’s Fort Ross Park
text: On a recent weekday at Fort Ross State Historic Park, a group of schoolchildren dressed as 19th-century Russian fur traders and American Indian otter hunters gathered around the replica of a cannon at the center of the fort. As the fuse dwindled, the children covered their ears. The cannon exploded and cheers erupted.

headline: Forced From Home at 75 as Tenant Rules Bend
text: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Oct. 21, 1879 | Thomas Edison Lights the Lamp
text: On Oct. 21, 1879, Thomas Edison devised a workable electric light at his laboratory in Menlo Park, N.J. A New York Times reporter visited Edison there and wrote an article about it that appeared in the paper on Dec. 28, 1879. “The lamp which Mr. Edison regards as a crowning triumph is a model of simplicity and economy,” he said.

headline: A Masterwork Spanning 40 Years and One Island
text: This is the second of two pieces on the work of Jack Delano. Part One is here.

headline: Murakami’s Tokyo
text: During Sam Anderson’s trip to Japan for his interview with the novelist Haruki Murakami, he visited the places mentioned in Murakami’s fiction as well as sites significant to Murakami’s life and career.

headline: The Fierce Imagination of Haruki Murakami
text: I prepared for my first-ever trip to Japan, this summer, almost entirely by immersing myself in the work of Haruki Murakami. This turned out to be a horrible idea. Under the influence of Murakami, I arrived in Tokyo expecting Barcelona or Paris or Berlin — a cosmopolitan world capital whose straight-talking citizens were fluent not only in English but also in all the nooks and crannies of Western culture: jazz, theater, literature, sitcoms, film noir, opera, rock ’n’ roll. But this, as really anyone else in the world could have told you, is not what Japan is like at all. Japan — real, actual, visitable Japan — turned out to be intensely, inflexibly, unapologetically Japanese.

text: WHERE was Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi killed?WHERE did the rebellion against Colonel Qaddafi began last February?

headline: How Do You Use Facebook?
text: Research shows that for students, specific ways of using Facebook – not use of it in general – correlate with some real-life behaviors like participating in extracurricular activities and even with academic achievement. How do you tend to use Facebook, if at all? Do you think the ways you use it are reflected in other areas of your life?

headline: Revisiting Deng Xiaoping: A Word With Ezra F. Vogel
text: Ezra F. Vogel, author of a new biography of Deng Xiaoping, retired from Harvard University in 2000, but still lives just a few hundred yards from the campus. In an interview at his home in Cambridge, Mass., he discussed his book, “Deng Xiaoping and the Transformation of China”; the differing views of Deng during his rule and now; and the differences between Chinese and American politics during the opening of China to the West. Mr. Vogel talked to The Times’s David Barboza. These are edited excerpts from their conversation.

headline: Facebook’s Impact on Student Grades
text: How does Facebook activity affect a student’s grades? Reynol Junco, a professor at Lock Haven University in Pennsylvania, recently set out to determine exactly that.

headline: As Documentary Rolls Out, Elon Musk Considers His ‘Revenge’
text: “The director, Chris Paine, called me up one day and wanted to have lunch,” said Elon Musk, the Tesla Motors chief executive, in a recent telephone interview. He was discussing how he came to be featured prominently in Mr. Paine’s new film, “Revenge of the Electric Car,” which opens in New York and Los Angeles on Friday after having made the film festival rounds this year. A review of the film appeared in The Times on Friday.

headline: Pitchfork Music Festival Comes to Paris
text: Since 2006, Pitchfork Media has supplemented its tastemaking music Web site with an annual music festival in Chicago. On Oct. 28 and 29, the festival will cross the Atlantic for its first full-fledged event outside the United States, importing North American, British and Scandinavian bands for French audiences, at the Pitchfork Music Festival Paris. (Though most tickets for the festival itself are sold out, they are still available for the opening and closing party events; organizers say additional tickets will be available for the nighttime, or “club,” sessions on the 28th.)

headline: Week 7 Matchups: When the Middling Face the Mediocre
text: Colts (0-6) at Saints (4-2)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Saints by 14.The famous quote by the former N.F.L. commissioner Bert Bell — “On any given Sunday, any team in the N.F.L. can beat any other” — has been a source of reassurance for both fans and television programmers for decades. The league’s carefully maintained competitive balance almost guarantees that every week will feature several compelling games between high-quality, evenly matched opponents. Almost.Bell would never imagine a week like this, in which the best (the Patriots) and most fascinating (the Eagles, the 49ers) teams have byes, while the top contenders face pushovers and the mediocre slug it out with the middling. Matchups that looked good when the schedule was announced now merit double-digit point spreads. Case in point: the Colts vs. the Saints, a rematch of Super Bowl XLIV that promised to be a seesaw offensive battle, is now little more than a three-hour wake for Indianapolis and a chance to watch Sean Payton coach New Orleans from the booth instead of the sideline.Granted, Curtis Painter, like a frozen burrito under a filling station heat lamp, is slowly warming to the Colts’ starting quarterback job. His completion percentage has gone up every week, and the Colts offense no longer looks like an intramural team playing in a downpour. Also, Drew Brees offered hope that Payton might find a way to stand on, or slightly above, the field on the surgically repaired leg he broke in last week’s game. “I’m envisioning some kind of hovercraft on the sideline,” Brees said. Levitating coaches: another thing that Bert Bell could never imagine. Pick: Saints.

text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

headline: Can Obama 2012 Replicate Bush 2004?

But President Obama’s chances of re-election could come down to a single strategic question: To what degree can the history of 2004 be repeated in 2012?

Nicholas Felice was the first to respond to our request for photos; that’s him at right in his 2000-01 Roma jersey — “the year they won the Scudetto,” he made a point to add — but others had some interesting contributions, too.

headline: Tim Burton Lines Up a Spot in Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
text: While Halloween might seem to be the holiday best suited to the macabre spirit of Tim Burton, that darkly inclined director is about to put his own spooky stamp on Thanksgiving.

text: If there was one area of doubt about Barack Obama that lingered in people’s minds during — and even after — the 2008 campaign, it was how well he could handle a foreign policy crisis.
