headline: G.E. Profits Are in Line With Analysts’ Outlook
text: General Electric, the nation’s largest industrial company, said on Friday that it had higher net earnings for the third quarter, but price pressures in its energy business squeezed profit margins in an economic environment that the company’s chief executive described as “volatile.”

headline: For British Ex-Bankers, Life Beyond the Bailouts
text: LONDON — It has been three years since the British government bailed out Royal Bank of Scotland and the Lloyds Banking Group and nationalized the regional lender Northern Rock.

headline: Jazz Was the Answer
text: On a leafy Brooklyn block, past a plain red door and down a narrow staircase, Andrea Brachfeld is curled up in a chair, head bobbing to a funky bass solo being played in a nearby room. Here in this cramped basement recording studio off the Prospect Park Parade Grounds, she is content. She is grooving. She is fulfilled.

headline: Beyond Green: A Net-Zero College Community
text: Designing buildings that leave a lighter imprint on the environment has become the de facto standard these days. The target for many is zero net energy use, meaning that a building makes as much energy as it uses over the course of a year.

headline: A New Video Role for Groupon’s C.E.O.
text: Andrew Mason, Groupon’s 30-year-old founder and chief executive, is all grown up.

headline: Verizon Profit Jumps
text: Verizon Communications, the nation’s second-largest telephone company, said on Friday that its profit doubled during the last quarter, bolstered by customers attracted by its portfolio of iPhone and Android devices.

headline: Weekend TV Guide: Oct. 22-23: Seven Reasons to Stay Inside
text: There is a delightful scent of autumn in the air. Not too hot, not too cold — you can feel that late October snap and the extra burst of brightness and color and energy that comes with it.

headline: Thai Prime Minister to Take Command of Flood Control Efforts
text: BANGKOK — Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra said Friday that she would take direct command of flood control in Thailand as Bangkok took the risky step of opening its floodgates and as criticism of the government mounted after days of disorganization and conflicting messages.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Narrowing Losses, Groupon Seeks $16 to $18 a Share in I.P.O.  |  Groupon reported nearly breaking even in its third quarter, an important milestone as it prepares the final leg of its long journey toward an initial public offering.

headline: Bain to Buy Japanese Restaurant Chain from Nomura
text: The private equity giant Bain Capital agreed to buy Skylark, a Japanese restaurant chain, from Nomura Holdings and other investors for $2.1 billion on Friday, in one of the country’s largest private equity deals since the financial crisis.

headline: Macarthur Coal Shareholder Backs Peabody Bid
text: Peabody Energy, the American coal company, moved one step closer to acquiring Macarthur Coal on Friday after the Australian firm’s largest shareholder backed Peabody’s $4.9 billion takeover offer.

headline: Friday Reading: Large Study Finds No Cellphone-Cancer Link
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wnallet.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Plan for Gas Pipeline Has Many Critics
text: PORTUGUES, P.R. — It is his retirement refuge, a tiny house in the Central Mountain Chain, surrounded by banana and orange trees, coffee bushes and the melody of coquí frogs.

headline: Live From New York, It’s Steve Schwarzman
text: Stephen A. Schwarzman has been many things, including a mergers banker, a private equity mogul and philanthropist.

headline: 5 Things to Watch for at the News Corp. Shareholders Meeting
text: News Corporation shareholders will have the chance to confront Rupert Murdoch, the company’s chairman and chief executive, later Friday. The annual meeting, in Los Angeles, marks the first time investors have had the opportunity to question Mr. Murdoch since a phone-hacking scandal at the British newspaper unit humbled the company over the summer.

headline: Spotted on the Street | Georgia Fowler
text: The Girl: Georgia Fowler, a model at IMG Worldwide. She also studies psychology.The Place: Lower Broadway between Vesey and Barclay Streets.

headline: The Thrill of Defeat for Sports Fans
text: It will provide little solace to wounded fans of the Boston Red Sox, who recently endured the most catastrophic late-season choke in baseball history, to know that their misery has been mathematically quantified: 278 million to 1. Those are the odds of the Red Sox’ blowing a nine-game lead (which they did) and missing the baseball playoffs entirely (which they did) in the precise fashion in which they did it, as calculated by Nate Silver in The Times.

headline: Building a House of Wax in Cleveland
text: In the heart of postindustrial Cleveland, in one of those cheery urban-reclamation areas with freshly painted brick buildings and almost unnaturally green lawn spaces, you’ll find Gotta Groove Records, one of around 20 plants in the United States that still press vinyl. On the day I visited, the guts of this converted elevator factory were packed with hissing, clanking vintage record presses, and the walls were lined with band fliers and colored LPs. A dry-erase board at the far end of the shop displayed the day’s jobs, Tom Waits and Tim Buckley among them.

headline: In-Flight Entertainment
text: On a recent flight, my colleague was seated next to an employee of our major competitor. My colleague realized this when the fellow began writing e-mails about possible problems with a significant new product. Is it ethical for us to capitalize on this fellow’s stupidity? B.C., NEW JERSEY

headline: Life During Wartime
text: After more than 30 years of war, Afghanistan’s special tragedy — its wonder — is that the obstinate violence no longer represents an assault on daily life.

headline: Wouldn’t It Be Cool if Shakespeare Wasn’t Shakespeare?
text: “Was Shakespeare a fraud?” That’s the question the promotional machinery for Roland Emmerich’s new film, “Anonymous,” wants to usher out of the tiny enclosure of fringe academic conferences into the wider pastures of a Hollywood audience. Shakespeare is finally getting the Oliver Stone/“Da Vinci Code” treatment, with a lurid conspiratorial melodrama involving incest in royal bedchambers, a vapidly simplistic version of court intrigue, nifty costumes and historically inaccurate nonsense. First they came for the Kennedy scholars, and I did not speak out, because I was not a Kennedy scholar. Then they came for Opus Dei, and I did not speak out, because I was not a Catholic scholar. Now they have come for me.

headline: From Russia With Lies
text: In the summer of 1973, when I was 18, I camped on a Black Sea beach with a Ukrainian boy named Boris, whose blue eyes and sun-bleached hair made my knees wobble every time I looked in his direction. Had my mother discovered this transgression (I was supposed to be vacationing at my girlfriend’s family’s dacha), I would have felt a shame greater than what befell me six years later, when I betrayed my country by marrying an American and leaving Russia. But that summer, the Crimean sun, the turquoise sea and Boris’s cinnamon tan led me astray into the adult world of vranyo.

headline: Taken by Pirates
text: Thanks to Jeffrey Gettleman, who continually sheds light on the tragedies and injustices in this corner of the world. I appreciate how he also highlights the good fight that many Somali people are undertaking as they make the best of an incredibly complicated situation. As Gettleman highlights in this article, the Somali situation is more about economics than about religious extremism. Economic desperation causes people to do crazy things. This is true in every country of the world.

headline: Spalding Gray
text: “The Dark Prince of Downtown,” in large part about Gray’s romantic and professional relationship with the theater director Elizabeth Le Compte, fails to mention that Le Compte is one of the foremost theater directors of our time. She changed and continues to change the form of theater, and all theater looks different because of her work. Gray ultimately found his storytelling voice through her directing — another bit of history that is incorrectly characterized. Readers of this article will think “Liz” serves primarily as Gray’s girlfriend, who directs theater on the side. If this were the story of the lover of a male director, we daresay he would not be depicted in this narrative as a foil, mother or handmaiden.

headline: Can Cancer Ever Be Ignored?
text: The article “Can Cancer Ever Be Ignored?” reveals a nightmare of sloppy science. P.S.A. testing poses zero risk. It is not invasive, not radioactive, not even expensive. It is treatment that poses risk. Failing to distinguish between these two entirely different things is bad medicine, bad policy, simply bad thinking. Obviously, we have lots of work to do. We should be searching for better treatment options, better ways of distinguishing between aggressive and nonlethal cancers, better ways of identifying high-risk patients. But advising men not to be screened accomplishes nothing, except to relieve physicians of their responsibility to inform patients fully and treat them appropriately.

headline: Bad Times on Wall Street, Boom Times for Kevin Spacey
text: It is not very likely that an economist will ever win a Nobel Prize for tracking the correlations between movie-star careers and the business cycle, but if anyone were to take up this area of research, Kevin Spacey would offer an especially challenging case study. His initial rise coincided with the ’90s boom, but for most of the Bush bubble years he was out of sight, doing theater in England. Now — call it happenstance or dialectics — his comeback has arrived more or less simultaneously with the global­ crisis of capitalism.

headline: Kashmir to Lift Reviled Security Law
text: NEW DELHI — A much-despised law that suspends basic rights and shields security forces from prosecution in the disputed province of Kashmir will be lifted in some areas in the next few days, officials said Friday.

headline: Occupying Boston and Beyond, With Tent Libraries for All
text: BOSTON — This city, home to the nation’s first major public library, has a new and somewhat grittier reading nook. Housed in a green military tent, the library at the Occupy Boston encampment in Dewey Square is overflowing with scholarly tomes that have no due dates or late fees.

headline: CMJ Day 3: Twitter Reviews of Freshkills, AraabMuzik and More
text: It’s Day 4 of the CMJ Music Marathon and critics from The Times aren’t slowing down. Last night, @joncaramanica and @jonpareles covered the gamut of offerings in Brooklyn and the Lower East Side. But we can’t be everywhere. This year, we’ve invited readers to join us in appraising CMJ shows on Twitter.

headline: Readjusting Our Eye, Again
text: Revolutions with the sidearm of the Internet expose much, not least perfidy. The Telegraph in London has a fascinating obituary of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi — serious, dryly funny — that contains the observation that the Libyan leader looked like “a parody of Sixties radical chic.” It was those craggy features and retro blue-tinted shades. Colonel Qaddafi was no joke, but we once laughed (as the obituary noted) at his outlandishness. For a trip in 2002, to South Africa, his entourage consisted of a personal jet, two transport planes, a container ship filled with buses and goat meat, $6 million in petty cash and 400 security guards. Well, no more.

headline: A Mitzvah Behind the Price of a Soldier’s Freedom
text: On the Sabbath morning of Nov. 5, less than three weeks after the release of Sgt. First Class Gilad Shalit in a prisoner exchange between Israel and Hamas, Jews in synagogues throughout the world will read a Torah portion concerning Abraham’s early journeys. The text recounts how invaders conquered the city of Sodom, taking Abraham’s nephew Lot as a captive, and the way Abraham raised an army to rescue him.

headline: Fill-In | Corn Mazes
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the article “Builders of Corn Mazes Hope to Lose Visitors, and One Actually Did.”

headline: Beef Will Be What’s for Dinner for a Long Time, Panelists Say
text: Have you been persuaded that beef is waning on the American plate because it’s too destructive to the ecosystem, too hormone-pumped and too corn-fed artery-clogging?

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Serious Eats: Those crazy kids find a Coke Freestyle machine and try all 127 possible flavor combinations. Fidgety behavior and tooth decay ensue. — Eric Asimov

headline: Pesto Dishes Without the Pasta
text: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman has pulled out the hand blender to whip up extra batches of puréed basil to be frozen and enjoyed in various pesto dishes all winter.

headline: Mother of Toddler Who Was Run Over Says Microblog Is a Fake
text: A 2-year-old girl who was hit by a van and then ignored as she lay writhing in the middle of a busy market street in China died on Friday of her injuries, as my colleague Michael Wines reports.

headline: With Bamboo Roofs and Plywood Walls, Williamsburg Is Transformed for Sukkot
text: It is possible, in many parts of New York, to pass through autumn unaware of the Jewish festival of Sukkot. It is, however, impossible to pass through Brooklyn neighborhoods like Williamsburg, Crown Heights and Borough Park without knowing that the eight-day harvest holiday is under way.

headline: Chloë Sevigny Has, What Else, More Secrets in a New Television Series
text: It seems you can’t have a Chloë Sevigny project without a character or characters trying to hide a shocking secret, whether it’s a lover who disguises her gender (in “Boys Don’t Cry”) or a polygamist family concealing its multiple marriages (on the HBO series “Big Love”). So try to sound surprised when you learn that there are a couple of unexpected twists to the character that Ms. Sevigny plays in her latest project, at least one of which is strongly hinted at in its title. In “Hit and Miss,” a new series that will be shown on the satellite service DirecTV, she portrays a character named Mia who is a hired assassin as well as a pre-op transsexual. When Mia learns she’s had a son by an ex-girlfriend who is dying of cancer, she is forced “to mix her killer instincts with her newly acquired maternal ones” (hey, that’s what it says in the press release).

headline: On Our Radar: ‘Living Fossil’ Is Younger Than Thought
text: Modern-day cycads that were assumed to have existed when dinosaurs roamed the earth over 200 million years ago are actually far younger, researchers report. [The Times of London]

headline: U.S. and U.N. Demand Details From Libyan Leaders on How Qaddafi Died
text: MISURATA, Libya — International calls mounted Friday for Libya’s interim leaders to provide a fuller accounting of the final moments before Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s violent, messy death, as new videos circulated that showed him and his son Muatassim alive, apparently while in the custody of the former rebels.

headline: The Fisker Karma’s 20 M.P.G. Sticker: A Scarlet Letter?
text: With its range-extender gasoline engine engaged, the Fisker Karma plug-in hybrid was rated this week by the Environmental Protection Agency at just 20 miles per gallon. The E.P.A. figure was first reported by the blog GreenCarReports.com.

headline: The Protester and the Goldman Chief
text: In the latest installment of DealBook’s animated series, Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, is confronted by a protester from Occupy Wall Street.

headline: Trying To Unwarp The Debate
text: I visited Zuccotti Park yesterday. Michael Moore gave a short speech, transmitted by the human microphone. I gather that right-wingers are claiming that OWS is anti-Semitic; someone forgot to tell the excellent Klezmer band.

headline: Full House for Annual Advertisers Conference
text: The Association of National Advertisers, whose members are the chief marketers of the nation’s leading companies, is looking to set another record for attendance at its annual conference.

headline: A Memoir From ‘Mr. Broadway,’ With an Assist From Mrs. Broadway
text: Pat Schoenfeld, the widow of the powerful Broadway theater owner and producer Gerald Schoenfeld, has completed work on his forthcoming memoir, “Mr. Broadway: The Inside Story of the Shuberts, the Shows and the Stars,” which is set to be published in April by Applause Books. As the longtime chairman of the Shubert Organization, Mr. Schoenfeld, along with his business partner Bernard B. Jacobs, provided homes to some of the greatest Broadway hits, including “A Chorus Line,” “Cats,” “Les Misérables,” and “The Phantom of the Opera.”

headline: The Times’s Battista Answers Questions
text: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The New York Times, answers questions from readers.

headline: More People Who Can’t Handle The Truth
text: If you follow this blog regularly, you’ll know that whenever I present data — and I do present a lot of data — right-wingers will complain of “cherry-picking”. They never have a clear example of how I should do things differently — or if they do, it’s always obviously wrong. But what they really mean is that they won’t accept data that doesn’t tell them what they want to hear.

headline: I May Be Dumb, But I’m Not Stupid
text: Or something like that. The usually very insightful Kantoos seems to have missed what people like me are actually saying about the need for emergency funding in Europe.

headline: Leading Off: Rangers Go Bold, Just in Time
text: The top of the ninth inning of Game 2 of the World Series was such a tiny sliver in an otherwise unremarkable game. Sure, the starting pitchers performed admirably amid reports that their profession was as obsolete as the iPhone 2, but by the time Albert Pujols polished off the last of his fruitless four at-bats, well, hanging with the “action” was getting tougher with every pitch.

headline: Can Powerful Women Change the Workplace?
text: The New York Times’s otherwise distressing article  today on the very real possibility that, in 2012, women’s representation in the Senate may shrink for the first time in a generation did contain one real bright spot: Senator Patty Murray of Washington State, elected in the much-vaunted Year of the Woman in 1992, reflected on the contrast of then and now:

headline: On Climate, Ethics, Cow Burps and the Dalai Lama
text: Early this week, I heard through some e-mail traffic that 10 climate, behavioral and environmental scientists and scholars were meeting with the Dalai Lama to discuss “ecology, ethics and interdependence” — a mix at the core of this blog. The meeting is part of a continuing series of discussions on the interface between contemplative and scientific approaches to humanity’s challenges. Here’s one of a string of taped segments:

headline: Dry Leaves, Dead Timber and Enticements for Migrating Birds
text: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week.

headline: Leaving Bosnia (and Not)
text: There is a long and important history of memoirs and fictions, and hybrids of the two, that address the aftermath of war. “Shards,” the impressive first novel by Ismet Prcic, finds inventive ways to interrogate the anguish of enduring and then escaping Bosnia during the war of the 1990s.

headline: Up Front: Dana Spiotta
text: In her most recent novel, “Stone Arabia,” Dana Spiotta used multiple voices and narrative devices to explore the slipperiness of identity and the capriciousness of memory. So too does the novel she reviews in this week’s Sunday Book Review: “Shards,” by Ismet Prcic, about a young man’s experiences of the Bosnian war and his mental breakdown in its aftermath. Spiotta said via e-mail that she was interested in Prcic’s attempt to find “an expressive form for a consciousness in crisis.” How, she asked, does a writer describe a broken mind “without reducing it to something false or reassuringly conventional? Memory is not particularly linear — it is associative, repetitive, subjective and porous. But the writer needs to convey disorder and dysfunction without making the novel itself disorderly or dysfunctional.”

headline: ‘The Better Angels of Our Nature’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Primary Sources
text: To the Editor:

headline: Evolution of Theory
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Design of Symbols
text: We see them in airports, hospitals and government buildings, in waiting rooms and bathrooms, on exits and entrances: schematic silhouettes of men, women and children. The graphic icons are characterized by a no-frills, geometric style that is immediately recognizable and decipherable wherever they’re found. But while the symbols are ubiquitous, few people know where they had their origins.

headline: Fashion to the Rescue
text: Thinking of fighting crime but don’t know what to wear? The solution may be found at the spring 2012 collection for superheroes presented by the Brooklyn Superhero Supply Co. The event, on Oct. 24 at 9 p.m. at the Ace Hotel, is a benefit for 826NYC, a nonprofit literacy organization. The contributing designers — Christian Joy, Opening Ceremony, United Bamboo, Matt Singer, Jack Spade, Renata Morales and Complex Geometries — were asked to come up with crime-fighting attire, which left the possibilities just about endless. “There’s a lot of flexibility as to what a superhero will wear,” says Joan Kim, the director of education at 826NYC. “The Incredible Hulk just wears shorts. Some wear different accessories, some wear capes.” The seven outfits will be sold at silent auction. Other designers, including Marc Jacobs and Stella McCartney, have donated pieces for the auction and raffle ($20 per ticket). Tickets are $75 for general admission, or $150, which includes an 8 p.m. cocktail party and five raffle tickets.

headline: Charles Frazier’s North Carolina Gothic
text: Among James Fenimore Cooper’s many literary offenses, Mark Twain charged, was “surplusage.” The word’s undue thickness perfectly matches its meaning. It also feels of a piece with Cooper’s own prose, and likewise Charles Frazier’s: elegantly archaic-sounding, rough-cut and contrived.

headline: Alan Hollinghurst Imagines a Fallen Poet’s Literary Afterlife
text: Alan Hollinghurst’s novels — a distinguished body of work, both daring and fastidious — have often set out to see Britain’s modern, decriminalized gay life against the dangers and excitements of earlier decades. “The Swimming Pool Library,” to take one example, showed its uninhibited young protagonist, William Beckwith, making up his mind whether or not to write the biography of the much older and necessarily more furtive Lord Nantwich. The decision-making allowed one era to resonate against the other, in a novel whose contemporary narrative voice allowed older gay literary sensibilities, like E. M. Forster’s and Ronald Firbank’s, to enter through echo and allusion.

headline: Moby-Dick: A Display of Book Covers
text: White whales abound in this book cover collection of Herman Melville’s masterwork.

headline: How to Read Moby-Dick
text: It’s a hard sell Nathaniel Philbrick has undertaken in “Why Read Moby-Dick?” The novel’s plot has been recycled for decades, inspiring films, radio dramas, cartoons, comic books, a television mini-series, a couple of heavy metal albums, a music video and a rap rendition. How many potential readers approach the masterwork of Herman Melville without already knowing the story of Captain Ahab and the white whale? Any? And why would such an overly exposed audience embrace a work of such heft, especially as almost every edition carries the added weight of ponderous academic commentary? “Moby-Dick” would appear to be one of those unfortunate books that are taught rather than enjoyed.

headline: Consultant Guilty of Grand Larceny and Money Laundering
text: Updated, 12:40 p.m. | John F. Haggerty Jr., a Republican political consultant accused of stealing $1.1 million from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg during Mr. Bloomberg’s 2009 re-election campaign, was found guilty of second-degree grand larceny and second-degree money laundering by a jury in Manhattan on Friday morning.

headline: News Corp. to Pay $3.2 Million to Murdered Girl’s Family
text: Hours before Rupert Murdoch, chairman and chief executive of News Corporation, faces shareholders at the company’s annual meeting, the company announced Friday that it would pay $3.2 million to the family of Milly Dowler, the murdered British teenager whose phone was hacked by News Corporation’s News of the World tabloid.

headline: The Radical Entertainment of Harry Belafonte
text: Here is a gorgeous account of the large life of a Harlem boy, son of a Jamaican cleaning lady, Melvine Love, and a ship’s cook, Harold Bellan­fanti, who endured the grind of poverty under the watchful eye of his proud mother and waited for his chances, prepared to be lucky, and made himself into the international calypso star and popular folk singer, huge in Las Vegas, also Europe, and a mainstay of the civil rights movement of the ’60s, a confidant of Dr. King’s, who lived for years in a U-shaped 21-room apartment on West End Avenue, but never forgot what he ran so hard to escape from, the four or five families squeezed into a few rooms, the smell of Caribbean food cooking, the shared bathroom, his father drunk, yelling, blood on his hands, beating his mother, and “a terrible claustrophobic closet of fear.”

headline: The Women of Masada
text: You could call it a hoopla sandwich. On the back cover, a blurb from a famous, widely respected author describing the novel as “a major contribution to 21st-century literature.” On the jacket flap, a publisher’s summary proclaiming this book to be the writer’s “masterpiece.” Yet in between, instead of a gripping work of fiction that lives up to this praise, is a long novel full of middling descriptions, hackneyed characters and histrionic plot twists.

headline: How Deng Did It
text: Two mighty rhetorical questions conclude this enormous biography of Deng Xiaoping (1904-97): “Did any other leader in the 20th century do more to improve the lives of so many? Did any other 20th-century leader have such a large and lasting influence on world history?” The answers emerge from this comprehensive, minutely documented book, but not as predictably as Ezra F. Vogel, a Harvard University emeritus professor of social sciences, assumes.

headline: José Saramago Goes Back to Genesis
text: God is a petulant, small-minded tyrant in José Saramago’s final novel. Its protagonist, Cain, is sympathetic, a picaresque hero. But that description may give the wrong idea by implying ponderous qualities indicated by the phrase “village atheist.” Like that other largehearted, blasphemous comedian, Mark Twain, Saramago takes an alert interest in actual villages, and in the various villages of the mind. He perceives those literal and figurative human settlements as horrifying yet funny, a perspective that is the opposite of provincial.

headline: Hitler’s Last Gasp
text: By the morning of April 18, 1945, the war in Ansbach, a picturesque town in southern Germany, was just about over. With the Wehrmacht in retreat and the United States Army a few miles away, surrender seemed the only option. But Ansbach’s military commander, a middle-aged air force colonel named Ernst Meyer, was determined to fight to the bitter end. In an effort to avert a catastrophe, Robert Limpert, a 19-year-old theology student, destroyed what he thought were the phone lines between the town and local army headquarters. Turned in by two members of the Hitler Youth, Limpert was arrested, summarily tried and publicly executed while a crowd of his fellow citizens, some cheering, most silent, looked on. A few hours later, after Meyer had fled and Ansbach was captured without a fight, American troops cut down Limpert’s body from where it had been left hanging in the town hall square.

headline: Recreating the Horrors of Nanjing
text: Ha Jin has a talent for first lines. Consider these, from his latest novel, “Nanjing Requiem”: “Finally Ban began to talk. For a whole evening we sat in the dining room listening to the boy.”

headline: What the Generals Did to Egypt
text: On the morning of Feb. 11, 2011, hours before Hosni Mubarak submitted to the millions of his subjects clamoring for his resignation, a half-dozen retired generals sipped coffee poolside at the Gezira Club, kitted up for tennis and contemptuously dismissed the demonstrators in Tahrir Square. “Who do they represent?” scoffed a man who until recently had worked in state security. “They are loud, but don’t forget there are 79 million Egyptians who are not in Tahrir Square. They are the majority.”

headline: Second Time Is No Charm as Netrebko Cancels Carnegie Hall Recital
text: The soprano Anna Netrebko has once again canceled her New York recital debut, which was scheduled for Carnegie Hall next Wednesday.

headline: The Improbably Bright Future of Myanmar
text: As economies and societies all around them have flourished, two countries have been strikingly left out of the East Asian boom of the past generation: North Korea and Myanmar. The strategic importance, internal miseries and governing oddities of North Korea are obvious and frequently in the news. Myanmar, by contrast, is rarely mentioned. When it does appear, it is usually as the object of some new calamity — like the 2008 cyclone that killed over 100,000 people, many of them perishing after Myanmar’s benighted military rulers refused outside aid — or as the setting for dramas involving Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace Prize winner whose party triumphed in the 1990 national elections but who has spent most of the years since then under house arrest.

headline: Inside the Head of Joan of Arc
text: On Dec. 22, 1905, an Onion-like headline ran in The New York Times: “Joan of Arc Appears to Startle Mark Twain.” The article described how the hosts at a dinner in Twain’s honor had arranged for a model to arrive dressed as Joan. (Twain had long been entranced by her, and had even written a novel called “Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc.”) When she entered the room, the author “had every appearance of a man who had seen a ghost.” When he recovered, Twain said to the assembled guests: “I studied that girl, Joan of Arc, for 12 years, and it never seemed to me that the artists and the writers gave us a true picture of her. They drew a picture of a peasant. . . . But they always missed the face — the divine soul, the pure character.”

headline: Inside the List
text: VESTED INTERESTS: Last fall, Jonathan Franzen’s glasses were stolen off his face at a London party for his novel “Freedom.” Jeffrey Eugenides may be tempting similar literary vandalism if he doesn’t button up the vest he was recently seen wearing on a big billboard in Times Square advertising “The Marriage Plot,” which hits this week’s hardcover fiction list at No. 2. But at least the vest would be able to send news of its whereabouts, thanks to the Twitter feed @EugenidesVest, which started posting updates from its location “On Jeffrey’s Torso” on Oct. 13. In addition to grumbling about being stiffed by a certain prize committee (“Jeff tells me he’s been having some trouble with the National Book Awards. Something about fiction finalists and the number six.”), the vest seemed none too happy with a rather tart review of “The Marriage Plot” that appeared recently in these pages. “There’s no predicting where William Deresiewicz’s wardrobe will go,” the vest declared. “But I see bikini thongs in his future.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE MARRIAGE PLOT,  by Jeffrey Eugenides (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) Eugenides’s novel, which deftly renders the patter of college intellectuals and the sweet banter of courtship, is particularly astute about the uncertainties awaiting after graduation.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE MIND’S EYE,  by Oliver Sacks (Vintage, $15.) In these graceful essays Sacks, a practicing neurologist, explores our potential to adapt in the face of disability — among his case studies is an accomplished musician who loses the ability to read music — and describes his own ordeal with ocular cancer.

headline: Dwight Macdonald’s War on Mediocrity
text: The late, great literary and social critic Dwight Macdonald (1906-82) was on the receiving end of some of the best literary insults of the 20th century. Gore Vidal said to him, “You have nothing to say, only to add.” Leon Trotsky reportedly declared, “Every man has a right to be stupid, but comrade Macdonald abuses the privilege.” Paul Goodman cracked, “Dwight thinks with his typewriter.”

headline: Looking to the Children for Guidance in Afghanistan
text: It is a truism that children represent the future, but here in Afghanistan, that future is a very uncertain one. I have interacted with Afghan children as much as possible during the first half of my yearlong tour in eastern Afghanistan and am just as uncertain about the future of this country as when I arrived. While they have provided some of my best memories and most optimistic moments, they also have given rise to some of my deepest despair. While my experiences are by no means authoritative, I offer them as an imperfect window into Afghanistan’s future.

headline: Q. and A. | How Facebook Use Correlates With Student Outcomes
text: Is Facebook a worthless waste of time for students? Does it steal time and energy that they would otherwise spend on homework? Is it focusing their attention on trivia, facilitating unhealthy interactions with peers and teachers, and turning their minds to jelly?

headline: Ingenuity, Gowns and Mail in Washington
text: Admirers of Andy Warhol can get a double dose of the art provocateur in Washington this fall. The National Gallery of Art will explore his take on sensational tabloid news, and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden will take in his vibrant, but enigmatic, interpretation of abstract impressionism.

headline: Off the Charts: In Apparel, Inflation Is Back
text: American apparel prices, which fell rapidly early in this century and then stabilized, have begun to rise. The top two charts show consumer prices for apparel compared with late-1991 levels, and annual changes in the index. The fall in prices came as the balance of payments deficit became extremely large, as shown in the bottom chart.

headline: The End of Cheap Chinese Goods
text: The great Chinese-led deflation in goods prices may have come to an end.

headline: Hotels With Things That Go Bump in the Night
text: Do you believe in ghosts? Or maybe you just have an appetite for the eerie? Some hotels capitalize on what they used to keep hush-hush: rumors of haunting. Here’s a Halloween sampler:

headline: Inflation Out of Sight
text: Since the Great Recession began in December 2007, the overall consumer price index is up 7.5 percent, or 1.9 percent a year. But there are plenty of people who insist that the figure must understate actual inflation, citing their own impressions from visits to stores.

headline: Reflections as the ’55 Turns 57
text: The car reviewed for this week’s Behind the Wheel article, a 1955 Chevrolet Bel Air convertible, belongs to Paul Stenquist, a frequent contributor to the Automobiles section.

text: Matching photographs of people who live in their childhood homes, as children and as adults.

headline: Climate Study Does Not Placate Skeptics
text: As we noted on the blog on Thursday, a new study intended to address critiques of climate science by skeptics has confirmed that “global warming is real” and the world’s average land temperature has risen by about 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit since the mid-1950s.

headline: News Corp.’s Annual Shareholders Meeting
text: We live-blogged the annual News Corporation shareholders meeting.

headline: To Greece in a Speedboat
text: MY friend Sonia, an inventive and gifted cook, splits her time between Hell’s Kitchen and the isle of Syros in the Cyclades. Whenever I want to whip up anything Greek, she is my go-to source. So when I had a hankering for moussaka, I called her.

headline: China Charges Protectionism in Call for Solar Panel Tariffs
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government Friday condemned a demand by the American solar panel industry for steep tariffs on solar panels shipped to the United States from China.

headline: The Toys Are Gone, but It’s Still Home
text: DAN GEIST, 44, grew up in a one-bedroom apartment in Morningside Heights, the only child of artist parents who had arrived as renters in the late ’60s. He pedaled his tricycle around the living room and swung from a tension bar in a doorway. From babyhood on he gazed from his bedroom window at a tapestry of brick, a view that looked especially moody on rainy mornings.

headline: Moussaka the Traditional Way
text: In A Good Appetite, I write about a shortcut moussaka, above — a Greek friend’s quicker, easier version of the classic recipe.

headline: Applicants’ Privacy Is at Heart of Lawsuit in Illinois
text: To what extent does federal law protect the privacy of a college applicant’s personal information?

headline: Taking the Protests to the Art World
text: The Occupy Wall Street movement took on the art world, sort of, this week, with a splinter group, Occupy Museums. Convened on Thursday evening through a Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr posts, about 20 people made their way from the Museum of Modern Art to the New Museum  to a downtown gallery, protesting what they say is the conflation of art and commerce, the snobbery of the art market and high ticket prices at museums, which they called the “temples of the cultural elite.”

headline: Volcker Rule, Once Simple, Now Boggles
text: When Paul Volcker called for new rules in 2009 to curb risk-taking by banks, and thus avoid making taxpayers liable in the future for the kind of reckless speculation that caused the financial crisis and resulting bailout, he outlined his proposal in a three-page letter to the president.

headline: Stage Version of ‘Shakespeare in Love’ Moving Ahead
text: “Shakespeare in Love,” the 1998 romantic comedy that won seven Academy Awards, including best picture and acting honors for Gwyneth Paltrow and Judi Dench, is the latest film being eyed for adaptation to the stage. Two leading producers, Disney Theatrical Productions and the British impresario Sonia Friedman, have been holding meetings with the playwright Tom Stoppard – who shared an original screenplay Oscar for “Shakespeare in Love” with Marc Norman – and the director Jack O’Brien about the project, according to theater executives familiar with the creative discussions.

headline: Spring Ahead | The Head Scarf
text: A snapshot of spring’s best trends and a hint at what you’ll want to wear next year.

headline: A Risky Investment, Made Unwittingly
text: ALLEGATIONS of financial fraud have, unfortunately, become all too common in this economic downturn. But one of the latest seems worth particular note since it involves a former national chairman of the National Association of Personal Financial Advisors, who pushed the group to adopt a policy that requires members to act in the best interests of their clients and to disclose any conflicts of interest.

headline: The Caucus | The Web Video Primary
text: Oct. 21, 2011 - Some of the fiercest back and forth of the campaign is taking place in Web videos but will soon come to TV screens. Also, a report on Mitt Romney's tentative return to Iowa.

headline: Five Minutes at CMJ With Pterodactyl
text: ArtsBeat will be talking to some of the acts that are in New York this week to play the CMJ Music Marathon.

headline: Island’s Inhabitants? Clearly Not Natives
text: MOST of the classic horror films of the early 1930s have been released and rereleased on home video to the point of surfeit and beyond. But one, in many ways the most disturbing, has remained elusive: Erle C. Kenton’s 1932 “Island of Lost Souls,” an adaptation of H. G. Wells’s novel “The Island of Dr. Moreau” so extreme in its effects that Wells himself denounced it. The film was banned in Britain until 1958, when the censors finally passed it with an X rating.

headline: Before You Hand Over Your Money for Investing
text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about a Seattle investment adviser who is accused of committing securities fraud when he put his clients’ money into investments in private companies without their consent. One reason that Paul wrote about the case is that the adviser, Mark Spangler, is a former chairman of the National Association of Personal Financial Advisors, a group that requires its members to act in their clients’ best interests.

headline: Steve Jobs Biography: A Scorecard of Put-Downs
text: Every authorized biography includes some score-settling by its subject. Steven P. Jobs, the late Apple co-founder and subject of Walter Isaacson’s new book, “Steve Jobs,” proves no different.

headline: Caucus Video: The Web Video Primary
text: Some of the fiercest back and forth of the campaign is taking place in Web videos but will soon come to TV screens. Also, a report on Mitt Romney’s tentative return to Iowa.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: More than 300 varieties of sakes, many which are usually unavailable in the United States, will be poured for tasting Friday from 6 to 9 p.m. at the Joy of Sake event being held at the Altman Building, 135 West 18th Street (Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue), in Chelsea. Tickets are $90 in advance, available online, or $100 at the door.

headline: Rescued by Design
text: I JOINED the line to get into the United Nations the other day, fiddling with my iPhone before shuffling through security. The couple in back (he was toting an iPad) mused about what a design guru Steve Jobs had been. They headed toward the information desk and I toward “Design With the Other 90 Percent: Cities,” an infelicitously titled but inspired show organized by the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum and now installed (since the museum is closed for renovations) in the United Nations visitors’ lobby.

headline: Present Company Included
text: ONCE upon a time, in the magical land of ballet, a company was born. The brainchild of the hottest choreographer of the day and a charismatic former ballerina, the fledgling troupe burst onto the world’s grand stages, promising to haul classical ballet into the contemporary realm.

headline: Bridgewater’s Dalio: ‘I Think I Did Everything Right’
text: Ray Dalio, the founder of Bridgewater Associates, didn’t used to do many media appearances. But a series of big magazine profiles that focused on the intense culture of his Connecticut-based hedge fund seem to have eased the billionaire out of his shell.

headline: In Liverpool, New Cool on the Waterfront
text: A downtown revitalization has brought cultural vigor to the waterfront.

headline: Big Ticket | Park Ave. Co-op Is Sale of Week
text: The most expensive apartment sale of the week in Manhattan, according to property records, was a 15-room, 6-bedroom co-op at 625 Park Avenue that had an asking price of $29.75 million — although the final sale price could not be confirmed before publication.

headline: Susan Orlean on her book, “Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend”; Steven Heller discusses his latest Visuals column; best-seller news.
text: This week, author Susan Orlean explores the life of a canine icon in her book, “Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend”; Steven Heller talks about his latest Visuals column; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Fennel Fills In for Salads in Fall
text: THOUGH the colorful salads of summer (remember tomatoes, cucumbers, and peppers?) are justly loved, a salad in autumn — or any cold season — is a thrill. Leafy salads have their place, yes, but so do salads with no leaves or minimal leaves. Cooked vegetables make fine salads this time of year, bathed with oil and vinegar. Think beets, potatoes, carrots, artichokes. But raw vegetables can make salads that are fresh and crisp.

headline: Romney’s Premature Perry Panic
text: Mitt Romney has run a smooth, low-drama campaign so far, but its aggressive posture toward Rick Perry within the past week leaves me wondering about his strategic choices.

headline: Fox Outbids ESPN for World Cup Rights
text: Fox and Telemundo, the Spanish-language network that is a division of NBC Universal, won the American television rights to broadcast soccer’s World Cup in 2018 and 2022, according to soccer and television officials.

headline: U.S. Troops to Leave Iraq by Year’s End, Obama Says
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced on Friday that the last American soldier would leave Iraq by the end of this year, drawing to a close a divisive eight-year war that cost the lives of more than 4,400 troops, defined the presidency of George W. Bush, and helped ignite his own political rise.

headline: At CMJ, a Critic’s Imagination Come to Life, Out of Alabama
text: Imagine a CMJ buzz band not built around some cool-headed concept involving noise or irony or ambiguities or primitivism. Imagine a band not trying to make a fashion or anti-fashion statement. Imagine a band whose vocals aren’t just something to put up with because that’s  the songwriter singing. Imagine a band named after a place that actually comes from that place. And imagine a band whose New York City debut left a CMJ Music Marathon audience literally screaming for joy.

headline: Clinton Widens Audience in Pakistan, but Sticks to Tough Message
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton invited questions from a selected group of Pakistanis here on Friday, a woman in the audience humorously captured the essence of a very troubled relationship, at least from Pakistan’s point of view.

headline: BP’s Plan for Drilling in the Gulf Is Approved
text: HOUSTON — The Obama administration on Friday took another step toward allowing BP to return to the Gulf of Mexico, approving the first oil drilling plan for the company there since the explosion that sank the Deepwater Horizon rig more than a year ago.

headline: Turning a Loft Into Something Cozy
text: Heather Chaplin has worked hard to turn her loft in Park Slope, Brooklyn into a cozy, ladylike home.

headline: How to Tame a Loft: Add Lace, Talk Trollope
text: THE story of Heather Chaplin and her loft in Park Slope, Brooklyn, started auspiciously. Ms. Chaplin, a writer, and her husband, Aaron Ruby, a graduate student in philosophy, had been a couple since 1993. In 2000, the year they married, they spent $400,000 on an 1,800-square-foot loft in a building soon to be erected on 11th Street near Sixth Avenue.

headline: When Bach Laid Bare His Own Soul
text: ON the cover of his recent recording of Bach’s partitas and sonatas for unaccompanied violin Sergey Khachatryan is shrouded in darkness, head tilted back, eyes raised piously and hands pressed together above his instrument. The image is an apt representation of the reverence that musicians, scholars and listeners often bring to a discussion of these monumental works.

headline: Still Wondering If Liszt Was Any Good
text: ON Oct. 22, 1811, Franz Liszt was born in the Hungarian (now Austrian) village of Raiding. His bicentenary follows hard on the heels of Chopin’s, last year, and anticipates Wagner’s and Verdi’s, in 2013.

headline: Obama Announces Troops Will Come Home From Iraq by Year’s End
text: President Obama announced that the United States has fulfilled its commitment in Iraq and will bring all American troops home by the end of the year. “As promised, the rest of our troops in Iraq will come home by the end of the year,” Mr. Obama said.

headline: Theater Talkback: I Could Read a Book
text: You might expect that someone who spends his time watching, writing about, living and breathing theater 52 weeks a year would prefer to turn to other subjects when it comes to the pastime of leisure reading. Perhaps some molecular biology? And it’s true that for sheer diversion, or post-season recovery, I do try to avoid books that feel like homework. My new discovery – and obsession – is the British writer Angela Thirkell, who wrote more than a dozen frothy light comedies about English country life, many set in Anthony Trollope’s fictional Barsetshire.

text: The Look: Electric Lady — Southern California palms are the perfect backdrop for zebra stripes and a sunny, citrus yellow combo. A brown pencil skirt and coral lipstick complete the tropical palette.

headline: Qaddafi’s Faustian Bargain
text: Editor’s Note: Since the start of the Libyan revolution, Robert F. Worth has written two stories for the magazine. The first, “On Libya’s Revolutionary Road,” was published in April; the second, “The Surreal Ruins of Qaddafi’s Never-Never Land,” appeared in our Sept. 25 issue. Since the news broke of Qaddafi’s death, Worth has been reporting for the paper, but took time out to put together these thoughts below:

headline: A New Destination for Food and Art in Sonoma

Inside an old apple cannery, though, revelers were in a different sort of haze — one produced by the cacophonous sounds of a funk band.

headline: New Design on Croatia’s Coast
text: THE coastal town of Rovinj, on the undulating Istrian peninsula of Croatia, is no stranger to tourism, in large part thanks to its lush natural surroundings. Its fir-forested campgrounds are packed with R.V.’s bearing Austrian and German plates. Its rocky coves are claimed by staycationing Croatians slipping in and out of the cerulean Adriatic.

headline: A Man, a Bike and 4,100 Miles
text: IF you can be said to be hurrying on a cross-country bicycle trip, for about two weeks I hurried to Pittsburgh. I pushed through some dreary weather in Michigan and Ohio, climbed the roller-coaster foothills of the Appalachians and battled traffic and chewed up roads as I entered the city. From there, though, with the end of a ride that began almost three months ago looming, I slowed down and started on an oblique route home.

headline: Coast-to-Coast
text: As the author hits the homestretch of his cross-country cycling trip, the final miles beckon and loom.

headline: Ode to Autumn Salad
text: I always want salad, maybe even more so this time of year. But the season is changing, and so are the ingredients in my salad bowl. Right now, there is fragrant, crisp fennel bulb available, so in this week’s City Kitchen, we’re making the simplest fennel salad imaginable, dressed with olive oil and lemon.

headline: Rangers Win Carries Fox
text: While final Nielsen numbers were not immediately available on Friday, preliminary estimates suggest that Game 2 of the World Series between the Texas Rangers and the St. Louis Cardinals carried Fox to an overall ratings victory on Thursday night in all categories. A pitching duel capped by a ninth-inning Texas comeback drew in more viewers as the night went on with the Rangers ultimately winning, 2-1.

headline: Going to an Art Fair: What It Takes
text: Art Basel Miami Beach officially rolls into southern Florida on Dec. 1 this year, marking its 10th incarnation with more art and more flair than ever. When the show started in 2002, no one knew whether it would secure a place on the art circuit. But the jitters of planting a prestigious art fair in a place known mostly for beaches and bars faded within minutes of the V.I.P. opening. Collectors from all over the map showed up, and browsers and partiers soon followed.

headline: Attention, Shore Lovers
text: AS a name, College Point is something of a head-scratcher. Like Bowling Green or Canal Street, it is the kind of name that may once have been apt but seems now to have little bearing on reality.

headline: Design for the Poor. (And Yes, This Is Serious.)

headline: Are Dead Trees More Combustible Than Live Ones?
text: As Justin Gillis explained at length in an Oct. 1 article, huge tracts of forest are dying across the West and around the world as a result of infestations and other phenomena that many link to climate change. A big question for those who manage forests is how these millions of acres of dead trees will respond to wildfire.

headline: Netflix Says Stop the Presses!
text: Since taking over in March, writing the Talk Q. and A. hasn’t been exactly what you could call a white-knuckle experience. Since the pages of The New York Times Magazine close more than a week before they hit newsstands, we can’t outrun the news. So this week’s interview with the C.E.O. of Netflix, Reed Hastings, provided some rare deadline drama. On Oct. 6, just as we were putting the finishing touches on the interview for the Oct. 16 issue, I got an e-mail from Netflix with the subject line “URGENT.” If the magazine ran the interview with Hastings as planned, The New York Times would look “foolish.” My contact refused to offer me any specifics about what was afoot, but he said I would understand early the following week. He was good on his word. The initial interview — in which Hastings provided his justification for spinning off the disc-only service of his company into Qwikster — would have made us look pretty dopey had we published almost a week after Netflix announced that it was ditching Qwikster altogether. So we quickly put moved up our Melissa McCarthy interview to run in Hastings’s place. Hastings talked to me three days after the Qwikster mercy killing and I drew the entirety of this week’s column from that one interview. But here’s one exchange from that earlier interview that’s worth rescuing.

headline: A Century of Chevy, From Cheap Date to America’s Sweetheart
text: Its Impalas dropped us off at school. Its pickup trucks hauled our produce on the farm. Its Corvette sustained our sports car fantasies through the boredom of high school algebra class. Earlier than almost any other automotive brand, Chevy created a palette of vehicles that ranged from the small and thrifty to the sleek and sporty to the large and smartly trimmed.

text: ON a recent Saturday evening at the Harold Pratt House in New York, Terry deRoy Gruber stood on a ladder and peered through the lens of a 25-pound wood-framed camera perched atop a 10-foot tripod.

headline: Restoring Natural History
text: The Hall of North American Mammals at the American Museum of Natural History is getting an unprecedented makeover.

headline: Contemporary and Boston, Opposites No Longer
text: “There’s one thing I’ve heard over and over again here,” says Edward Saywell, the top contemporary art curator at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, who is showing off works by Ellsworth Kelly, Kara Walker, Cindy Sherman and other contemporary artists in his domain, including many new ones. “They say, ‘This can’t be Boston,’ and I say, ‘Yes, it really is.’ ”

headline: Selling the Sparkle as the Stars Twinkle
text: No auction this season is likely to generate headlines like those from the sale of Elizabeth Taylor’s gems. Her own fascination with jewels and men’s fascination with the violet-eyed actress helped her assemble one of the world’s great collections, many pieces replete with romantic history, like La Pérégrina, a 500-year-old pear-shaped pearl that she had Cartier fashion into a necklace with rubies and diamonds, and the wedding bands from her two marriages to Richard Burton.

headline: Art and Culture to Admire, and Wrap Up for the Holidays
text: Museums are not just about learning and culture. Increasingly they are becoming shopping places for the committed consumer. As the holidays approach and New Yorkers are overwhelmed with family, friends, gift-buying and entertaining, museum gift shops are an obvious stop.

headline: Performance, Indoors and Out
text: Live performance will be erupting, and possibly disrupting, New York for three weeks starting Nov. 1, when Performa 11, a  performance art biennial, begins its fourth season. The events, mostly free and including a shamanistic dating show at El Museo del Barrio and a medieval-style rap joust at Marlborough Chelsea, will take place in theater, gallery and museum spaces as well as curbside.

headline: For Photos, Collector Casts a Global Net
text: If Jo Ractliffe’s star has risen on the international art circuit during the last year, it is in many ways because of the support of the German collector Artur Walther.

headline: Extreme Museum: The Rigors of Contemplation
text: The questions have been grievous, the moral issues weighty. How far should I be prepared to go in the pursuit of high-minded criticism of exhibitions and museums? Was I obligated to munch on the Cajun-fried crickets offered at New Orleans’s Insectarium in order to get the full flavor of the place? Were my perceptions off kilter if I was the only visitor to an exhibition about the history of tattoos in Philadelphia who didn’t have one of his own? Was I being unfair to Coca-Cola’s self-celebratory museum in Atlanta because I found the highlights were soda samples it offered from around the world? Was I overly fair to the Creation Museum in Kentucky, which treated the Bible as natural history and natural history as myth, when I marveled at its skewed alternate universe?

headline: Rendezvous With Art and Ardent
text: With so many museums, exhibits, art galleries and lectures to choose from every day, how does a busy young arts professional keep up? For Francesca Merlino and about two dozen of her colleagues who work for museums and arts groups in New York City, it’s following each other’s 140-character updates on Twitter and the hashtag, #artstech.

headline: Staying Up Late at Museums
text: Darcey Howard had her reasons for showing up at the Rubin Museum of Art in her pajamas. Seeing the Himalayan paintings and multilayered manuscript pages was not one of them.

headline: Museum Mind
text: Edward Rothstein reflects on the hazards of being an art critic.

headline: Islamic Objects of Desire
text: Despite the current trend for abbreviated titles and short, snappy messages, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is calling its majestic suite of 15 newly renovated spaces, which open on Nov. 1, the New Galleries for the Art of the Arab Lands, Turkey, Iran, Central Asia and Later South Asia. It’s a mouthful but an intentional one. The curators there are trying to underscore the diversity, richness and interconnectedness of the arts that reflect a melting pot of different cultures.

headline: Latin American Art, Rediscovered Again
text: In November, the Art Dealers Association of America will start its new season of collector forums with “Latin American Art in Global Collections” at the Morgan Library and Museum. The panel will be timed to the Pinta, a Latin American Art fair now in its fifth year that coincides with Christie’s and Sotheby’s Latin American art auctions. Also next month, the Museum of Modern Art will open an exhibition devoted to Diego Rivera’s murals. Five years ago, the museum appointed its first curator of Latin American art.

headline: Beneath an Abstract Painting, a Mystery Is Revealed
text: Preserving and cleaning paintings at a museum is often a relatively straightforward, not to say dull, affair. But sometimes a compelling flesh-and-blood story awaits beneath a layer of oil and varnish.

headline: New York’s City Kids, Across the Centuries
text: New York’s oldest museum becomes its newest on Nov. 11, when the New-York Historical Society reveals its three-year, $65 million renovation — and young people will have a new home for historical exploration.

text: The president announces a complete Iraq pullout by the end of the year; NATO completes its Libyan mission; and why many keep turning to the gruesome images of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's final moments.

headline: Denver Hedge Fund Manager Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
text: A Denver hedge fund manager pleaded guilty on Friday afternoon to insider trading charges. Appearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Drew K. “Bo” Brownstein admitted to netting nearly $2.5 million in illegal profits after trading on an insider stock tip about a pending acquisition of Mariner Energy by the Apache Corporation.

headline: Europeans Seek Bold Debt Deal, Despite Differences

headline: African Union Peacekeepers Killed in Somalia Battle
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — As Islamist militants displayed scores of blood-soaked bodies, the African Union on Friday acknowledged that its peacekeeping force in Somalia had sustained heavy casualties in its battle against the Shabab, the deadly insurgent group squaring off against a multipronged assault by troops from Kenya, Uganda, Burundi, the Somali government and local militias.

headline: Spot the Other Artistic Giant on the Cover
text: In this week’s magazine, Sam Anderson delves into the bewitching universe of the literary powerhouse Haruki Murakami, whose new book, 1Q84, will be released in North America on Oct. 25. Before you become completely distracted by Murakami’s unforgettable characters and layered cultural references, take a moment to notice the photographs contributed by a second artistic giant — the acclaimed Japanese photographer Nobuyoshi Araki. He took the gorgeous, tightly-focused black-and-white portraits of Murakami.

headline: His Life After ‘Riverdance’ Is a Braid of Traditions
text: Near the end of his solo show “Out of Time,” the Irish step dancer Colin Dunne shares some old video of himself. In it he is a world champion. He is on television. He is 10. He responds awkwardly to stock questions. He holds up his chin as he dances expertly, stiff and orthodox. The moment is awfully cute, but also disturbing in context. You worry about what will happen to that boy, and what already has.

text: Six cases of childhood measles have been reported in Brooklyn over the last two weeks, the New York City health department said Friday, contributing to a spike in measles cases this year.

text: The 24-year-old Chinese pianist Yuja Wang is not above flaunting her uncanny virtuosity. And though she comes across onstage as somewhat shy, Ms. Wang has a flair for fashion.

headline: Lovelorn and Seeking a Bailout for the Heart

The following poems about the romantic repercussions of the demonstrations were “found” this month in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.com. headline: From Walden Pond to the Olympics, Swimmer Thrives in Open Water
text: CONCORD, Mass. — Wading into Walden Pond, Alex Meyer did not exactly find an idyllic sanctuary, a spot where one’s solitude is broken only by birdsong.

headline: All for One, and Then Maybe a Sequel
text: The campy new screen adaptation of “The Three Musketeers” has all the reality and visceral excitement of a $75 million literary theme park dotted with fancy villages heavily patrolled by security. In the screenplay by Alex Litvak (“Predators”) and Andrew Davies (the television adaptation of “Little Dorrit”), the historical re-enactors of European life in the 17th century speak a wooden dialect that is half flowery mumbo-jumbo from countless swashbuckling Hollywood pseudo epics, and half contemporary slang. Although I don’t remember hearing the word “dude,” it might have slipped in.

headline: Improving How We Care for the Elderly
text: To the Editor:

headline: 5 Ways to Fix a Slow PC
text: It seems to happen to most Windows users: You buy a new desktop or laptop PC. It runs fast. But a few months later, you’re sure it’s slower than it used to be. Ask for help on the Internet or in real life, and you usually get one of two answers: you must have downloaded a virus, or you need to defragment your hard drive. Bad advice. You probably don’t have a virus, and Windows doesn’t need you to run the defragmenting tool yourself these days. Your problems lie elsewhere.

headline: TimesCast | Watching Qaddafi Footage
text: October 21, 2011 - Gruesome videos of Col. Qaddafi's capture are replaying on TV and on the web. Stuart Fischoff, a psychologist who specializes in media research, explains why many can't turn away.

headline: This Sunday: Doorstops! Doorstops! Get Your Doorstops Here!
text: There are two big books sitting on my desk, and if I were the kind of editor I dream of being, I’d have read them both already. As it is, I can only claim to have read the shorter of the two volumes, Daniel Kahneman’s “Thinking Fast and Slow,” which is only 418 pages (not including appendices and index), a twee little thing compared to Haruki Murakami’s 925-page beast “1Q84.”

headline: Why State Senator Alesi, Supporter of Gay Marriage, Voted ‘No’ in ’09

headline: Another Month, Another Premiere
text: PHILADELPHIA — Does a month go by without some kind of premiere by the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky? In April the Bolshoi danced the world premiere of his three-act “Lost Illusions;” in May American Ballet Theater presented the world premiere of “Dumbarton,” and in June, its first New York performances of his full-length “Bright Stream”; in July the Mariinsky Ballet gave New York its first view of his “Anna Karenina” and “Little Humpbacked Horse”; and in September the Paris Opera Ballet gave the world premiere of “Psyché,” based on the Greek myth. On Thursday the Pennsylvania Ballet presented the North American premiere of Mr. Ratmansky’s “Jeu de Cartes.” It would be nice to think the guy took August off as a well-earned vacation, but I wouldn’t bank on it.

headline: Guy’s Guy, Keeping the Kegs Flowing
text: At the rate Nashville is emasculating, you can practically call Dierks Bentley one of the tough guys these days. He’s not a fighter, or a self-loather, or much of a mean talker, but there’s a steady flow of insouciance running through his songs, a sense of lawlessness as experienced by someone who is very mindful of the law, and would like to dodge it just a bit, if that’s O.K. with you.

headline: Timescast | NATO's Libyan Legacy
text: As NATO's mission in Libya is complete, did it meet or exceed its mandate?

headline: Nightclubs to Nightcaps: Celebrating a Genre
text: The resilience of the New York Cabaret Convention, the annual showcase of nightclub talent from around the country that is celebrating its 22nd year, speaks for itself. That longevity may be the surest sign in an unstable economic climate that the city’s venerable but fragile cabaret tradition is not about to bite the dust.

headline: The Enchanted Forest, in Sunshine and Shadow
text: Maybe the networks knew it wasn’t going to be a fairy-tale fall season — unless they made it so! That could explain the premieres of two series within a week — ABC’s “Once Upon a Time,” on Sunday, and NBC’s “Grimm,” on Friday — that are explicitly inspired by the Brothers Grimm and the folklore they collected.

headline: Fox and Telemundo Win U.S. Rights to World Cups
text: For a record sum of about $1 billion, Fox and the Spanish-language network Telemundo won the rights to broadcast the 2018 and 2022 World Cups in the United States, television executives said Friday, demonstrating the steady and diverse growth of soccer in America.

headline: Woman Trying to Shield Children Is Killed by Gunman
text: A mother picking up her child was shot to death across the street from a school in Brownsville, Brooklyn, on Friday afternoon as she tried to protect several children from a gunman on a rooftop who opened fire on a group of rivals on a crowded street, the police said.

headline: Facing an ‘Impossible’ Contract
text: VELDHOVEN, The Netherlands — With only three rounds of the qualifying stage remaining, all six United States teams look likely to make the quarterfinals at the world team championships, which will begin on Sunday.

headline: Republican Plan Would Not Help Economy, Firm Projects
text: Senate Republicans’ proposed jobs package would not reduce unemployment or spur the economy’s growth in the next year or two, according to a leading economic forecasting firm that has predicted that President Obama’s plan would achieve both goals.

headline: Out From Behind the Counter
The Ugliness Started With Bork
text: On Oct. 23, 1987 — 24 years ago on Sunday — Robert Bork’s nomination to the Supreme Court was voted down by the Senate. All but two Democrats voted “nay.”

headline: Seeds for New York: The Lawn Guy
text: A SEED, to most people, is an inscrutable thing, a closed box waiting to be unpacked. But for Ed Toth, the director of New York City’s native plant center on Staten Island, it is a wide-open window, with a view stretching back to the last Ice Age and forward into the future.

headline: Ruling Backs Forest Service in Limiting Roads in the Wild
text: DENVER — More than a decade after the Clinton administration proposed cordoning off tens of millions of acres of public lands in the West from road development, setting off a ferocious debate about wilderness and human uses of the land, a federal appeals court in Denver upheld the government’s authority on Friday in a sweeping rejection of the opposition.

headline: At a Polite CMJ, Trash Talk’s Aggression Is a Relief
text: Some things happen at Trash Talk shows that don’t happen at other CMJ shows. Theirs is the show most likely to start at an insanely late hour, the show where you are most likely to get punched in the head by the lead singer, the show where you are most likely to receive a flier marked #OCCUPYCMJ bemoaning the stranglehold of corporations over various aspects of the music business, from retail outlets to radio to touring.

headline: Bachmann’s Lack of Big Donors Could Hinder Campaign
text: There is a reason candidates court big donors. Yes, they have more money. But more important, the net share of their donations is far greater than from low-dollar donors.

headline: Battle of the Borders
text: It is probably safe to bet that the tradition of heated arguments over immigration began millennia ago, when the first country drew a line in the sand.  But the past week in the United States of America has been a hot one, at least by any recent comparison.

headline: Turkey and Iran Agree to Cooperate Against Kurdish Rebels on Borders
text: Turkey and Iran agreed Friday to cooperate against separatist Kurdish violence along their borders, while thousands of Turkish troops began the second day of a major offensive against Kurdish rebels in southeastern Turkey and Iraq. Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu, speaking at a news conference with his Iranian counterpart, Ali Akbar Salehi, said Turkey and Iran would share intelligence and convene a joint security council. “We will work together in a common action plan until we entirely eradicate this threat of terrorism,” Mr. Davutoglu said.

headline: Raiders Saying Little About Immediate Plans for Palmer, Who Faces Obstacles
text: ALAMEDA, Calif. — The sound bite was fun, and that is surely why it was heard so often on radio shows and television news reports after the Oakland Raiders completed their trade for Carson Palmer.

headline: Senate, at Least for a Day, Gets Back to Legislating
text: WASHINGTON — As if compensating for months of inaction, the Senate kicked into gear around midnight Thursday and kept working early Friday as it shelved another piece of President Obama’s economic agenda and, in a bold experiment, tried using traditional legislative give-and-take to move a spending bill for half a dozen cabinet departments.

headline: Manfred Gerlach, East German Head of State, Dies at 83

headline: A Diverse City? In Some Ways, Anything But
text: New Yorkers take an imperious pride in the belief that our city is better than other cities — fairer, obviously, and more embracing than a place like, let’s say, Kansas City. New Yorkers don’t actually need to visit Kansas City to convince themselves of this. These beliefs are self-sustaining, fed by a collective egotism and impervious to contravening realities. In matters of race, our arrogance increasingly seems misplaced.

headline: Driven By His Past, a Coach Connects
text: MADISON, Wis. — The morning after Coach Bret Bielema led Wisconsin to one of the biggest wins in his program’s history, an Oct. 1 blowout of then-No. 8 Nebraska that confirmed the Badgers’ status as a national title contender, he began crying in his office.

text: The season is upon us. Squirrels are collecting their winter nuts, the geese are flying off in formation, the hummingbirds headed south — and how the heck do they do that, anyway? Also, the high school seniors are beginning their long college visitation treks, which appear to take longer and require even more effort than that hummingbird thing.

headline: Senate Panel Approves Bill That Rewrites Education Law
text: Legislation rewriting the No Child Left Behind education law finally gained traction this week, and the Senate Democrat whose committee passed the bill said on Friday that progress became possible because lawmakers were irritated by the Obama administration’s offering states waivers to the law’s key provisions.

headline: Santander to Sell Stake in U.S. Auto Financing Group
text: Grupo Santander, the Spanish bank that is the euro zone’s largest bank by market capitalization, announced a $1.15 billion deal on Friday to sell a 35 percent stake in its automotive financing unit in the United States to a group of private equity investors, as it looks to shore up its balance sheet. Under the terms of the agreement, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Centerbridge Partners and Warburg Pincus will invest a combined $1 billion for a 25 percent share in Santander Consumer USA. Dundon DFS will pay $150 million for a 10 percent stake in Santander Consumer USA.
