headline: Wall St. Protest Isn’t Like Ours, Tea Party Says
text: At a Republican candidate forum outside Fort Worth last week, a Tea Party activist turned Senate candidate proclaimed the Occupy Wall Street protesters “unemployed, uneducated and uninformed.” To which the conservative radio host moderating the panel added, mirthfully, “This is the first occupation many of these people have seen in years.”

headline: Senator Baker’s Waveless Shore
text: Edward Dickinson Baker, a close friend and sometimes political rival of Lincoln’s, had no fear of war. In 1832, he left his fledgling law practice in Illinois to participate in the Black Hawk War, and, in 1846, he resigned his Illinois Congressional seat to serve as a colonel of the Fourth Illinois Infantry in the Mexican War.

headline: Why Not The Worst?
text: I’m doing a fair bit of research before heading off to Iceland next week, and I thought it might be worth explaining why this tiny nation is so interesting. The thing is, it’s not for the expected reason.

headline: End Date for Iraq
text: President Obama’s announcement on Friday that the last American soldier will leave Iraq by year’s end signals a welcome end to a war that was started under false pretenses and went on far too long — killing more than 4,400 Americans and many more thousands of Iraqis and costing $1 trillion over nearly nine years.

headline: Postseason Pinch-Hit Star, Three Games Running
text: In perhaps the most famous pinch-hitting moment in postseason history, Kirk Gibson of the Los Angeles Dodgers limped into the batter’s box against Dennis Eckersley of the Oakland A’s in Game 1 of the 1988 World Series. Despite a badly injured knee, and despite facing the game’s most dominant reliever, Gibson was able to put a charge into a 3-2 pitch, hitting a two-run homer to right field that gave the Dodgers a 5-4 victory.

headline: 400 Years of Artifacts Enrich a Book
text: With the holiday season soon upon us, you might want to order one of these coffee table books for a friend who loves New York:

headline: Expert Says Quakes in England May Be Tied to Gas Extraction
text: A British seismologist said Friday that two minor earthquakes in northwestern England “appeared to correlate closely” with the use of hydraulic fracturing, a method of extracting natural gas from wells that has raised concerns about environmental and seismological risks in the United States.

headline: John M. Blum, Historian of Presidents, Dies at 90
text: John M. Blum, an influential historian of the American presidency whose 1954 biography of a maligned Theodore Roosevelt was pivotal in establishing the 26th president’s reputation as one of the country’s great chief executives, died on Monday at his home in North Branford, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
text: NO. 4 WISCONSIN AT NO. 15 MICHIGAN STATE8 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

headline: Jury Convicts Consultant of Stealing Campaign Money From Bloomberg
text: A Republican political consultant was convicted on Friday of stealing money from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg after a trial that lasted nearly a month and at times cast an unflattering spotlight on the mayor’s campaign-spending habits and the murky world of political operations.

headline: Brunch, Books and Family Time
text: The conductor Fabio Luisi had been pinch-hitting on a semi-permanent basis for James Levine, the Metropolitan Opera’s music director, who has been plagued by health problems; last month Mr. Luisi, 52, was named principal conductor. A native of Genoa, Italy, and a veteran of major posts in Vienna, Leipzig and Dresden, he moved last season into an apartment on West 96th Street, just off Central Park, after finding himself increasingly in New York. He lives there with his wife, Barbara Luisi, and their son, Aldo, 13; Mr. Luisi’s two other children are grown and studying abroad.

headline: Sexual Harassment 20 Years Later
text: Twenty years ago this month, Anita Hill stepped into the glare of the national spotlight, testifying before the all-male Senate Judiciary Committee about the vulgar sexual advances she said she endured a decade earlier while working at two government agencies for Clarence Thomas, the nominee to the Supreme Court.

headline: Lunch, Landfills and What I Tossed
text: IT was warm and sunny on a recent Tuesday and the lunchtime crowd in Bryant Park was in full swarm. Hundreds of Midtown workers sat on the grass or at round outdoor tables sunbathing, talking on cellphones and typing away on laptops.

headline: Governor Cuomo’s Choices
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has shown little interest in the challenges facing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs New York City area subways, buses and commuter trains, or the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which manages the area’s ports, airports, bridges and tunnels.

headline: Occupy-apalooza Strikes a Chord
text: Thursday night I spoke to a young woman in Brooklyn who was having dinner and planning the next day. Between a morning boot camp workout at the local Y.M.C.A. and an evening meeting with friends for drinks, she was planning her first trek to Zuccotti Park to take part in the Occupy Wall Street protests.

headline: Correspondents Reflect on the War in Iraq
text: Correspondents who covered the war in Iraq are reflecting on their time there on the day that President Obama announced that American soldiers would leave Iraq by the end of the year, ending a nearly nine-year military engagement. The president appeared to leave open the possibility that a deal could still be negotiated to allow military trainers to work in the country, though it would likely be a limited number.

headline: Will Mrs. Merkel Wake Up in Time?
text: Helmut Schmidt, Germany’s 92-year-old former chancellor, sent a pointed message to his present-day successor, Angela Merkel, this week. Shortchanging Europe damages Germany, he warned in a speech in Frankfurt. “Of course the strong should help the weak,” he said, just as Germany was helped by America after World War II.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Peacocks Then and Now

headline: Double-Play Duo Drives Rangers in the Field and Atop the Lineup
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — On the Texas Rangers’ team bus after Game 2 of the World Series on Thursday night, Elvis Andrus and Nelson Cruz decided it was time to see the play everyone was talking about.

headline: Correction Officers Plead Guilty in Assault Case
text: Two former New York City correction officers accused of orchestrating a scheme in which inmates at a juvenile detention center used threats, extortion and vicious beatings to keep other inmates in line pleaded guilty on Friday to related crimes.

headline: Private Schools in Suburbs Tap Manhattan Market
text: Finally, Manhattan parents can apply to a private school this fall that does not require their 4-year-olds to undergo intelligence testing or solicit donations for the building fund. Tuition is $20,000 annually, half the cost of some other private schools.

headline: Saturday: The Meta-Challenge
text: Administrivial Contest Rules Alert! All the puzzles this week, from Monday to Saturday, have been created by one person, Patrick Berry. Have your solutions handy, because the Saturday puzzle conceals a meta-challenge involving the solution grids of all six. When you have the answer to the meta-challenge, e-mail it to: crossword@nytimes.com. Please do not post your answers here on the blog and please do not mail them to me! Only answers e-mailed to the above address will be considered. Twenty-five correct solvers, chosen at random, whose entries are received by 6 p.m. Eastern time Sunday, Oct. 23, will receive copies of “Will Shortz Picks His Favorite Puzzles: 101 of the Top Crosswords From The New York Times.” Only one entry per person, please. The answer and winners’ names will appear on Friday, Oct. 28, at nytimes.com/wordplay.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections: October 22
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Cries of Anti-Semitism, but Not at Zuccotti Park
text: Among the hodgepodge of signs that have sprouted in Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, one man in jeans and a baseball cap has been carrying placards that shout their suggestions: “Google: Jewish Billionaires” and “Google: Zionists control Wall St.”

headline: Despite Difficult Talks, U.S. and Iraq Had Expected Some American Troops to Stay
text: BAGHDAD — President Obama’s announcement on Friday that all American troops would leave Iraq by the end of the year was an occasion for celebration for many, but some top American military officials were dismayed by the announcement, seeing it as the president’s putting the best face on a breakdown in tortured negotiations with the Iraqis.

headline: Women in Love, Leaping Into Elevator Shafts
text: Judging by her new work, which explores what it means to be a woman in love — its cheeky title is simply “the One” — it just wouldn’t do to describe Lyndsey Karr as the romantic type. As a pair of women, more often naked than not, takes the audience on a trip to three sites within the Chocolate Factory, Ms. Karr, with deadpan whimsy, both demonstrates and ridicules archetypes of the besotted.

headline: Given a Second Chance, a Jets Linebacker Wraps It Up
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Twenty-four days after the Jets cut him, Aaron Maybin returned to the team Sept. 28 as pretty much the same player: a relentless and boisterous pass-rushing outside linebacker equipped with no mute button.

headline: Mets to Play Yankees in Spring Training
text: After a 16-year hiatus, the Mets and Yankees will resume playing spring-training games against each other next March, said a Yankees official who declined to be identified. The teams are tentatively scheduled to play games at each other’s complexes in Port St. Lucie and Tampa.

headline: With Talks at a Halt, Silence Reigns
text: The hotel conference rooms had been vacated, perhaps turned over to a dental convention, or a cosmetics fair, or a symposium on gastroenterology. The charts devoted to “BRI” and luxury-tax thresholds had been packed up for another day, another meeting, another hotel.

headline: Making the iBio for Apple’s Genius
text: After Steve Jobs anointed Walter Isaacson as his authorized biographer in 2009, he took Mr. Isaacson to see the Mountain View, Calif., house in which he had lived as a boy. He pointed out its “clean design” and “awesome little features.” He praised the developer, Joseph Eichler, who built more than 11,000 homes in California subdivisions, for making an affordable product on a mass-market scale. And he showed Mr. Isaacson the stockade fence built 50 years earlier by his father, Paul Jobs.

headline: A Modern Setting for Authentic Italian
text: MY lasting impression of Pranzi formed as I emerged from its formal ristorante, on the ground floor of the Trump Tower at City Center, to exit through its informal enoteca. In the jam-packed front room, a D.J. sporting French nautical stripes and tinted glasses was pushing his fun agenda from the keyboard of his bright orange Apple laptop, and the crowd — in fine spirits on a Thursday night — was loving it. We lingered for a minute, smiling, then a young man in a svelte suit held the door and with a little flourish of his hand, thanked us in the nicest way for coming.

headline: Missing Several Stars, and Also One Juror
text: “I’ve been at this job for 10 years, and this is the first time this has ever happened,” a publicist said to Nocturnalist’s correspondent near a red carpet so bereft of celebrities that we were looking for a rolling tumbleweed to interview.

headline: Where the Seafood Can Go On and On
text: GIVEN the high cost of seafood, “all you can eat” is not a phrase I expect to see at a place that serves good sushi. Mahzu Japanese Restaurant, where the all-you-can-eat special is offered on Sundays for $19.99, is an exception.

headline: A Bolívar Ready to Fight Against the Bolivarian State
text: CARACAS, Venezuela

headline: A Welcoming, Affordable Discovery
text: A CASUAL neighborhood spot with delicious yet affordable food: That is what the owners of Bistro 25 had in mind for their restaurant, which opened in January in Sayville. Michael Turner and his partner in the venture, Brian Shuren, who is also the chef, have realized their vision. My only complaint is that Bistro 25 is not in my neighborhood.

headline: Authentic Greek Fare, but Distinctly New Jersey
text: THE blue sky and sea on the cover of Mikonos Restaurant’s menu seem to promise, if not a transcendent dining experience, one that calls to mind the heat and keen light of the Mediterranean. However, the interior of this restaurant in Ewing, with a sunroom addition that makes up most of the dining room — dimly lighted in the evening — says New Jersey.

headline: Virginia: Nuclear Reactors Expected to Reopen Soon
text: The North Anna nuclear reactors in Mineral, the only ones shut down by the Aug. 23 earthquake on the East Coast, will probably be allowed to reopen within weeks, a senior official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Friday. After a two-month, $21 million inspection, staff engineers told the commission at a two-hour briefing that the plant suffered only cosmetic damage. The limited damage led the plant’s operator, Dominion, and the commission to debate whether their standard for measuring a quake’s strength — based simply on ground motion — was the best one. That measure indicated that the ground motion on Aug. 23 exceeded what the reactors were designed for. But when engineers measured the quake by the total amount of energy it delivered, the quake was far too weak to produce significant damage. (The energy measure is based on both the shaking and its duration.) Most of the cosmetic damage found at the plant was limited to concrete, Dominion said.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,797 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following American this week:

headline: In Cleveland, a Circle Is Completed
text: BEREA, Ohio — Inside his office at the Cleveland Browns’ headquarters, Coach Pat Shurmur considered the connections, the threads that unite three men.

headline: Senator Lashes Out at Critics Who Say He Embellished His Family’s Story
text: MIAMI — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a charismatic Republican whose name has circulated recently as a possible vice-presidential candidate, lashed out on Friday at those who accused him of embellishing his family’s history.

headline: The Aesthetics of Functional Pottery
text: THE works of several of the artists who pinched bowls and other forms in the “Earth” exhibition at the Arts Exchange in White Plains are also included in “American Craft Week @ The Peekskill Clay Studios.” This show presents predominantly functional pottery that illustrates the breadth of aesthetic effects that can be achieved using different conceptual and technical approaches.

headline: What the Earth Gives, and What It Inspires
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: A Rangers Fan Who’s Hard to Top
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — At 7 feet, Dirk Nowitzki likely stands as the biggest fan of the Texas Rangers. And like any truly obsessed follower, Nowitzki refers to his favorite team in the first person plural.

headline: In Friends’ Suggestive Notes, Hints of Future Power
text: So much of what’s on offer at CMJ is raw material — maybe the band’s got it all figured out, more likely it doesn’t. If it doesn’t work, maybe it’ll try again next year. Maybe it’ll reinvent itself, or break up and reconfigure before trying again.

headline: Changing Clothes for Love and Survival
text: The way things are going, William Shakespeare may soon be known as a writer of musicals. Last month, the Two River Theater Company in New Jersey opened a production of “Much Ado About Nothing” with at least three songs, accompanied by cast members on various musical instruments. Now along comes the Westport Country Playhouse’s very pretty, very funny and very lilting production of “Twelfth Night, or What You Will.”

headline: Mental Health Advocates Face an Uphill Battle
text: The way America spends its resources sometimes infuriates Jennifer Humbert of Crete, a social worker and suburban mother of two children who have mental health issues.

headline: Slowly Making a Name for Themselves
text: The lot of a Rangers fan has never been an easy one.

headline: Trash Reinvented
text: Stony Brook, N.Y.

headline: Fake Lawyers and Notaries Prey on Immigrants
text: On May 6, just hours before his asylum hearing, Mario de la Rosa, a Mexican immigrant living in Waukegan, waited in the parking lot of a CVS pharmacy for the person representing him in his case, Margaret Carrasco, to arrive. She never did.

headline: Dinner at Mom’s, With All the Emotional Trimmings
text: “Jericho” is a play about Sept. 11. It is also a traumatic-Thanksgiving-dinner-with-the-family play and a play about being Jewish. All in all, it is a lovely, humorous work with laughs that resolve into a meditation on the pains and satisfactions of living after a tragedy.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

text: After a 16-year hiatus, the Mets and the Yankees will resume playing spring-training games against each other next March, said a Yankees official who declined to be identified. The teams are tentatively scheduled to play games at each other’s complexes in Port St. Lucie and Tampa.

headline: D.E.A. Bans Chemicals Used in ‘Bath Salts’
text: The Drug Enforcement Administration took emergency action on Friday to ban three synthetic stimulants used to make products that are marketed at head shops and on the Web as “bath salts,” but are actually used as recreational drugs that mimic the effects of cocaine, LSD and methamphetamine.

headline: American Who Killed for Iran in 1980 Resurfaces to Comment on Alleged Plot
text: When the Justice Department announced last week that an undercover agent in Mexico had disrupted an Iranian plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador in Washington, using members of Mexican drug cartel recruited by a used car salesman, officials in Tehran dismissed the charges as fiction, and several prominent American experts on Iran also expressed their doubts.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Kashmir: An inquiry by an RTI activist found that the University of Kashmir has spent more than 2.16 crore Indian rupees, or 21.6 million (about $400,000), on vehicles for the university staff but has disbursed only 59 lakh rupees, or 5.9 million, towards student scholarships and fellowships in the last five years. The report said that 36 vehicles, mostly SUVs, were purchased, including a bulletproof car, which was bought for 9.25 lakh  rupees (about $20,000)(Kashmir Live).

headline: Why I Left India (Again)
text: The Hindi movie on my “return to India” flight on Dec. 13th, 2006 was “Swades” (literally: “My country,” a story about a patriotic NASA engineer who returns to India to help improve his homeland).

headline: Another Productive At-Bat for a ‘Golden Age’
text: Charles M. Conlon has been deemed — on Lens, if not elsewhere — “the greatest baseball photographer.” From 1904 to 1942, Mr. Conlon shot some 30,000 pictures of America’s pastime. In 1993, The Sporting News published “Baseball’s Golden Age,” a collection of his work.

headline: On Revis and Sweetness
text: Two media-related items to chew on this morning:

headline: Damage From Falling Satellites? Insurance Will Cover It
text: Just last month, an old NASA satellite plummeted to Earth and disintegrated. Now space buffs are keeping an eye on the retired German scientific satellite ROSAT, which is expected to crash and burn sometime this weekend.

headline: How to Get All Your Apps Everywhere
text: A particular problem for people who have bought a lot of iOS apps is getting them all consolidated across desktops, laptops, phones and tablets.

headline: Five Minutes at CMJ With Nikki Lane
text: ArtsBeat will be talking to some of the acts that are in New York this week to play the CMJ Music Marathon.

headline: The 161st Manchester Derby
text: Roy Keane remembers his first as if it were yesterday.

headline: Sharing Audio on Pods, Pads and Phones
text: The iPad is a great way to watch movies on, say, a plane trip. But if you are traveling with someone, you endanger your domestic bliss by hogging the entertainment and walling yourself off (“Sorry, dear, you’ll have to amuse yourself by re-reading the SkyMall catalog while I watch ‘Bridesmaids.’”)

headline: 30 Seconds With Shaquille O’Neal: Off the Court, but Still Going at Full Speed
text: Shaquille O’Neal was in Manhattan the other day, dunking, grabbing rebounds and even making his free throws. After announcing his retirement in June, was he preparing for a comeback after the lockout? No, that was the virtual Shaq; the real O’Neal was controlling his moves on the new digital download of EA Sports NBA JAM: On Fire Edition. O’Neal, an analyst on TNT, was hopeful there would soon be real N.B.A. games.

headline: European Wage Update
text: A followup on my last Iceland post. A key point there was that nominal wages are downwardly rigid — it’s very hard to cut them even if your country clearly has costs that make it uncompetitive. That’s why “internal devaluation” is so difficult a strategy as compared with, well, devaluation devaluation.

headline: Cap and Trade: Sweating the Small Stuff
text: One thing built into a politician’s DNA is a sense of occasion. Regulators tend to lack that gene.

headline: There’s A Hole In The Bucket
text: The torments of the euro would be funny if they weren’t so tragic. At this point the urgent need is for a big Panzerfaust — a bailout fund big enough to head off a self-fulfilling liquidity crisis for Italy. But such a fund would be backed by the credit of the euro area’s remaining AAA governments, basically Germany and France — yet at this point the euro situation has deteriorated sufficiently that taking on another commitment would undermine French credit. There’s a hole in the bucket, and every attempt to fix that hole ends up being stymied because, well, there’s a hole in the bucket.

headline: An Insurance Company With An Army
text: I gather, from what I’ve been reading and hearing in various places, that the right-wing line is that it’s all Solyndra — that your tax dollars are going to pay for vast numbers of wasteful projects.

headline: Russia Will Bar Some U.S. Citizens in Retaliation
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s Foreign Ministry announced Saturday that it confirmed a list of American citizens it will bar from entering Russia, in a retaliatory move against the United States’ adoption of the so-called Magnitsky list, which imposes sanctions on Russian officials who have been linked to the 2009 death of the whistleblower Sergei L. Magnitsky.

headline: I Never Wanted to Be a Manager. But I’ve Learned.
text: This interview with  Selina Lo, president and chief executive of Ruckus Wireless, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: How Mr. Volcker Would Fix It
text: AMID all the minutiae of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul, it’s easy to lose sight of the big question: will consumers, investors and the economy be safer?

headline: Unreasonable, Maybe, but It’s on a Social Mission
text: DANIEL EPSTEIN wants to get one thing straight: He is an unreasonable man. Happily, proudly unreasonable. Entrepreneurs who want to change the world, he says, have got to be a little crazy.

headline: The Little State With a Big Mess
text: CRANSTON, R.I.

headline: Four Nations, Four Lessons
text: AS the economy languishes, politicians and pundits are debating what to do next. When we look around the world, it’s hard to find positive role models. But as we search for answers, it is useful to keep in mind those fates that we would like to avoid.

headline: It Guards the Markets, but What About Itself?
text: THE Securities and Exchange Commission oversees the nation’s financial markets. But has it unwittingly compromised its own employees’ financial information?

headline: Variety: A Spooooky Acrostic

headline: Live Analysis: Third Saturday of October
text: Paul Myerberg and The Times’ Jere Longman will be reporting on all of the day’s action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can also follow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

headline: Raised on the Web, but Liking a Little Ink
text: ON a trip to an indie bookstore in Brooklyn in the summer, I came across a curious creation: a small, black-and-white publication that consisted entirely of snapshots of Lindsay Lohan, known for her movie roles in “Mean Girls” and “The Parent Trap,” and, more recently, for her well-publicized courtroom appearances.

headline: Appetite for Catch and Release Is Tempered
text: LEENANE, Ireland — After my years of faithfulness (well, almost) to the religion of catch-and-release fishing in the United States and Canada, I found it heretical to be told that the salmon I caught would have to be killed.

headline: Man Climbs ‘Joie de Vivre’ Sculpture in Zuccotti Park
text: A Canadian man climbed up a red sculpture in Zuccotti Park early on Saturday and perched there for several hours before the police brought him down, the authorities said.

headline: Spy Agency in Kabul Denies Claim of Abuse
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s embattled spy agency absolved itself of any wrongdoing on Saturday in the case of a wandering Islamic preacher detained by intelligence officials who ended up in a hospital this month, fading in and out of consciousness and seemingly near death.

headline: European Finance Ministers Shaping Greek Rescue and Effort to Aid Banks
text: BRUSSELS — European finance ministers said on Saturday that they were near a deal to strengthen capital reserves for their troubled banks — the first part of a package of measures meant to stem the worsening European debt crisis.

headline: Stepping Into Raiders’ Void, a Coach Makes a Bold Deal
text: Marvin Lewis dropped his cellphone in his driveway last Sunday morning, a few hours before his Cincinnati Bengals beat the Indianapolis Colts, shattering the screen and shielding him from the tidal wave of text messages to come.

headline: In His Last Days, Qaddafi Wearied of Fugitive’s Life
text: MISURATA, Libya — After 42 years of absolute power in Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi spent his last days hovering between defiance and delusion, surviving on rice and pasta his guards scrounged from the emptied civilian houses he moved between every few days, according to a senior security official captured with him.

headline: Prince Sultan bin Abdel Aziz of Saudi Arabia Dies
text: CAIRO — Prince Sultan bin Abdel Aziz, the heir apparent to the Saudi throne and one of the kingdom’s most powerful princes until illness sapped his strength in recent years, has died, raising complex succession issues at a time of political turmoil in the region.

headline: Bank’s Collapse in Europe Points to Global Risks
text: As Europe’s debt crisis has deepened, a recurring question is how much risk it poses to the United States economy, and especially American banks.

headline: Pete Seeger Leads Protesters, on Foot and in Song
text: The Occupy Wall Street protests have drawn their share of musical supporters over the past few weeks. On Friday night, Pete Seeger lent his voice to the cause, though the protesters had to go uptown to hear it.

headline: A Love Story Affirmed Life in Time of War
text: They met in the Weapons Room, where sports receptions were held in those days.

headline: The Start-Up Advantage
text: I’M from Calgary, Alberta. My mother was an artist and my father was an economist until they changed careers and became a design/build team. I grew up watching them build homes.

headline: Signs of Abuse at Institutions, Despite Settlement
text: MEXIA — At the Mexia State Supported Living Center, on the sun-bleached site of a former World War II prisoner of war camp an hour east of Waco, residents with profound disabilities and behavioral problems spend their days doing repetitive chores: sticking paper into shredders, folding towels, sorting nuts from bolts. And, in some cases, being physically abused, despite a sweeping federal settlement signed in 2009 to prevent it.

headline: For the Jets’ Cromartie, Knowledge Can Damage
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Antonio Cromartie, the Jets’ mercurial cornerback, does not have peaks. He has Himalayas. Cromartie does not have valleys. He has canyons. And some are indeed grand.

headline: Dugout Phones: Last Bastion of the Landline
text: The seed-strewn dugouts of baseball stadiums around the country may very well end up the final bastions of corded communication in this wireless era.

headline: A Golden Touch Without the Glitter
text: SHE’S not the Ronson who dated Lindsay Lohan. That’s her fedora-wearing fraternal twin, Samantha, a celebrity D.J. and singer. She’s not the Ronson who in 2008 won three Grammys, including one for producer of the year for working with Amy Winehouse. That’s her brother Mark, the recently married record producer.

headline: CMJ: Day 4 Twitter Reviews of Dum Dum Girls, Walk the Moon, Metronomy and More
text: It’s Day 5 of the CMJ Music Marathon and critics from The Times aren’t slowing down. @joncaramanica and @jonpareles did their best to hit the most promising shows. But we can’t be everywhere. This year, we’ve invited readers to join us in appraising CMJ shows on Twitter.

headline: Gotye Fans Turn Out to Sing Along
text: A hit is a hit; a market boundary, in the digital era, is permeable.

headline: Old-School in Silicon Valley
text: While other schools around Silicon Valley brag about their wired classrooms, the Waldorf school is a throwback, with blackboards and colorful chalk, bookshelves with encyclopedias, and wooden desks filled with workbooks and No. 2 pencils.

headline: No True Sense of History Without a Sense of Place
text: Among the games people play, baseball is distinguished by the preservation of landmark numbers — 56, .367, 2,632, 4,256. But Major League Baseball does precious little to preserve the places where the game once breathed.

headline: A Silicon Valley School That Doesn’t Compute
text: LOS ALTOS, Calif. — The chief technology officer of eBay sends his children to a nine-classroom school here. So do employees of Silicon Valley giants like Google, Apple, Yahoo and Hewlett-Packard.

headline: Technology, Schools and a Big Black Bug
text: I was on a hike in August when one of my hiking companions bent down to the dusty path to examine a thumb-size black beetle. My fellow hiker, Harry Barker-Fost, stared at the chunky insect as it crawled onto his hand and then over and around his forearm for the better part of three minutes.

headline: In Memoir, Rice Tells of Clashes With Cheney
text: WASHINGTON — Condoleezza Rice clashed repeatedly with Vice President Dick Cheney over what to do with captured terrorism suspects and at one point even threatened to resign when she felt circumvented, according to a memoir of her time in Washington, due out next month.

headline: The Tale of the Dueling Economists
text: JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES and Friedrich Hayek. The names conjure opposing poles of thought about making economic policy: Keynes is often held up as the flag bearer of vigorous government intervention in the markets, while Hayek is regarded as the champion of laissez-faire capitalism.

headline: The Sunny Side of Doom and Gloom
text: SINCE the market ran into serious trouble during the summer, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index has clawed its way back to the 1,200 level on four separate occasions. On the first three runs, the rallies quickly lost steam amid fresh sets of worries about the global economy.

headline: But, And, Why
text: Every once in a while I get correspondence from someone chiding me for the way I write — in particular the informality. I received one the other day complaining about sentences that begin with “but” or “and”. There is, however, a reason I write this way.

headline: Should 65 Be Your Magic Number?
text: Q. In a few years, you will reach the traditional retirement age of 65. You aren’t sure if you want to keep working past that age. What factors should you weigh?

headline: Nevada G.O.P. Relents on Early Primary
text: The Nevada Republican Party decided on Saturday to push back the date of its presidential caucuses to Feb. 4, a move that brings a sense of order to an otherwise chaotic primary calendar and keeps New Hampshire from scheduling its voting before the New Year.

headline: Japan’s Standardized Baseballs Are Popular With Pitchers
text: TOKYO — Unlike Major League Baseball, for whom Rawlings has been the official supplier of baseballs since 1977, Japan’s top league has long used multiple manufacturers.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Wins Giant Slalom and Completes Sweep
text: For all the races, titles and medals Lindsey Vonn has won in her ski racing career, she had never won a World Cup giant slalom. But with a daring and aggressive finish Saturday in Sölden, Austria, Vonn won the season-opening giant slalom and became the fifth woman to win a race in all five World Cup disciplines.

headline: Stern Must Balance N.B.A.’s Viability and Visibility
text: From 2003 through 2007, I was the commissioner of the National Basketball League of Australia. Although my league was a fraction of the N.B.A.’s size, I faced many of the same challenges Commissioner David Stern has dealt with for the past 27 years: pressure-packed labor negotiations, antagonized player and referee unions, unhappy owners (who overpaid players and lost money annually), demanding corporate sponsors, ratings-conscious television partners, scathing news media criticism and unhappy fans who were convinced that teams they disliked were cheating.

headline: A Struggling Football League Skips a Beat and Crowns a Champion
text: VIRGINIA BEACH — Fans can be forgiven if they missed the United Football League championship game Friday night: the game sneaked up on the league as well.

headline: Hollywood on Wall Street
text: WHAT enormous comfort it must give the Occupy Wall Street protesters to know that celebrities feel their pain.

headline: The Saudi Ambassador of Sangfroid

headline: The Inevitable Nominee
text: FOR the next three months, the political press will engage in an extended masquerade, designed to persuade credulous readers and excitable viewers that the Republican presidential nomination is actually up for grabs.

headline: One Country, Two Revolutions
text: I take no pleasure in seeing anyone lose a job, but I can’t say that the recent headlines showing that America’s biggest banks have been losing money on their trading operations, and are having to radically shrink as a result, are entirely bad news for the country. Over the last decade, America’s banking sector got pumped up by steroids — in the form of cheap credit and leverage — every bit as much as Major League Baseball’s home run hitters. And if one result of the downsizing of Wall Street is that more of America’s best and brightest math and physics students decide to go into science and real engineering rather than financial engineering, the country will be a whole lot better off.

headline: The Man Who Stayed Behind
text: IN the last few months, as you and I have been fretting about the economy or moaning about the weather, Ryan Boyette has been living in a mud-wall hut and dodging bombs in his underwear.

headline: Peddling Fear
text: At one o’clock in the morning Friday, in one of its rushes to get out of work and back to fund-raising, the Senate took up a measure to strip the Justice Department of the power to charge and try any non-American terrorism suspect captured anywhere in the world.

headline: U.S. Scales Back Diplomacy in Iraq Amid Fiscal and Security Concerns
text: BAGHDAD — Beyond the final withdrawal of troops that President Obama announced Friday, America’s fiscal troubles are dictating a drastic scaling back of plans for diplomatic, economic and cultural programs once deemed vital to steadying Iraq, building a long-term alliance and prying the country from Iran’s tightening embrace.

headline: The Paradox of the New Elite
text: Alexander Stille is a professor of international journalism at Columbia.

headline: A Pack of Nascar Drivers Is Ready to Break Out of Johnson’s Shadow
text: Jimmie Johnson hinted at vulnerability two races into the Chase for the Sprint Cup, as less-than-dominating finishes left him well behind the points leaders. Just as the doubts were raised, Johnson seemed to dismiss them with a second-place showing at Dover and a victory at Kansas that reminded everyone why he was nicknamed Five-Time.

headline: A Driver’s Death Raises Questions About IndyCar’s Leader
text: In the wake of Dan Wheldon’s death at a race in Las Vegas last Sunday, IndyCar officials have been all but silent. No formal statements, beyond an expression of regret and a pledge to investigate themselves. Certainly no news conferences to answer questions about the propriety of the race, which was held at a fast track not truly built to stage such an event.

headline: Knicks’ Reed: Forever a Captain Among Men
text: 11:17 p.m. | Updated Those familiar with the career of the Knicks legend Willis Reed would not be surprised by his recent take on the N.B.A. lockout and the costly cancellation of early season games.

headline: Right, Less Might

headline: Who Needs Stability?
text: Bankers in this country are not letting up on their campaign to undercut the Dodd-Frank financial reform law, which is supposed to curb risky behavior and lessen the chances of another meltdown. They are also eagerly joining their overseas brethren in a similarly fierce campaign against new international rules that would require banks to gradually increase the amount of capital they must keep in reserve to cushion against future crises.

headline: Even Worse Than Citizens United
text: The Justice Department is right to defend as essential the century-old ban on direct corporate contributions to political candidates for federal office. In a brief to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, the lawyers challenge a wrongheaded ruling by Judge James Cacheris of Virginia, arguing that the ban serves the government’s strong interest in preventing political corruption.

headline: Happy Birthday iPod!

Massachusetts, a typical state, has specialty plates for the Red Sox, the Celtics and the Bruins, Cape Cod and its islands, children, fish and wildlife, cancer research, right whales and the “Olympic spirit.”

headline: Clarence Thomas’s Brand of Judicial Logic
text: Justice Clarence Thomas was sworn in to the Supreme Court 20 years ago today. After two decades on the bench, he remains a legal outlier even on the conservative court. The results he reaches are often radical, and where his ideas come from even more so.

Lindsay and the Time Warner executive who founded the all-news New York One cable channel, Mr. Aurelio laments a change he sees in how The New York Times handles local coverage.

text: My Sunday column is about Ryan Boyette, an American aid worker who stayed behind in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan to bear witness to atrocities there, when virtually everyone else evacuated. I thought you might like to take a look at Ryan, so here are a couple of photographs.

headline: Battles to Shape Maps, and Congress, Go to Courts
text: The once-a-decade process of redrawing Congressional districts is moving from the smoke-filled back room to the courtroom. Lawsuits related to redistricting have been filed in more than half the states, asking judges to decide issues that include whether the new maps take partisan gerrymandering too far or discriminate against minority voters.

headline: Battle for Libya | October 22, 2011
text: Libya’s new leaders will declare liberation on Sunday, officials said, a move that will start the clock for elections after months of bloodshed that culminated in the death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the longtime dictator.

headline: After a Gas Explosion, Cleaning Up and Feeling Lucky
text: Phyllis Laughlin brought her 88-year-old mother, Noreen Clayton, to watch the destruction. “It gets her out,” Ms. Laughlin said. “This is better than sitting around looking at the living room.”

headline: The World This Week

headline: Even the World’s Best Players Struggle After a Timeout
text: Tournament play after a long layoff is not easy, even for elite players. They can forget what they know about openings or fail to stay up to date. A larger obstacle is the crucible of competition: the pressure can be intense, and the mind and body have to be reconditioned.

headline: Meanwhile, Greece
text: At this point Greece almost seems like a sideshow. Yet the scale of its coming default matters, especially with some players still denying that such a default is conceivable. So I would be remiss not to mention the awesomely depressing report of European Commission economists, which is marked “strictly confidential” but has, of course, gone viral.

headline: Awaiting Tunisia’s Vote
text: Tunisians prepared to vote on Sunday in the first election since the Arab Spring.

headline: Sunday: Take It From the Top
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — The “Crossing” Words Contest of ’11 is now over, but you can still e-mail your answers to crossword@nytimes.com until Sunday at 6 p.m. Eastern time. The consensus seems to be that people loved the puzzles, and the meta-challenge was the piece de resistance. Stay tuned for the second part of an interview with constructor extraordinaire Patrick Berry that I will be running shortly after the Monday puzzle goes live.

headline: Financing Questions Shadow Tunisian Vote, First of Arab Spring
text: TUNIS — As Tunisians prepare to vote on Sunday in the first election of the Arab Spring, the parties and their supporters have ramped up a bitter debate over allegations about the influence of “dirty money” behind the scenes of the race.

headline: Cain, Now Running as Outsider, Came to Washington as Lobbyist
text: WASHINGTON — Herman Cain, the Republican presidential candidate with the sharp wit and easy-to-remember tax plan, is a cancer survivor, radio host and former chief executive of Godfather’s Pizza. On the campaign trail, he talks up his business experience, casting himself as a “problem solver” and Washington outsider.

headline: From Mosque to MASH Unit in Yemeni Crisis Zone
text: SANA, Yemen — The calm inside the mosque quickly turned to mayhem as the first victim of a deadly attack on a protest march was brought in on a stretcher. The young man grasped at his abdomen with bloodied hands.

headline: Voracious Mice Scramble Food Chain on California’s Farallon Islands
text: Winter after winter, burrowing owls have been overstaying their traditional migratory visit to the storm-swept Farallon Islands, dining on the petrels that have returned to breed. The attacks have taken a heavy toll on the petrels, a native bird that breeds slowly on the small, rocky islands.

headline: Jubilant Fighters Return to Cradle of Libya’s Revolt
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Veterans of the decisive battle for Surt streamed into this eastern Libyan port city on Saturday to a raucous heroes’ welcome, firing round after round into the air and yelling greetings to a jubilant crowd that jammed the entry-point to a main boulevard into town.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Outlook magazine’s issue this week is an anniversary special about India’s much discussed youth. In the lead essay, Akash Kapur, who previously wrote the International Herald Tribune’s Letter from India, says the youth’s “optimism and self-assuredness, their faith in the future, have come to sand, metonymically, for a nation that is itself regularly rates, in surveys and opinion polls, as among the most optimistic and self-assured in the world.” The special also includes interesting features about young Indian politicians, journalists, entrepreneurs and the cosmetics business.Tehelka has a story on the plight of residents of Delhi slums who have been evicted to make way for shopping malls, apartments and other new developments. Many of the evicted residents have ended up in worse conditions further away from the city, the piece argues, because local authorities have not made any provision for low-cost housing. One evicted resident tells the magazine: “For the government, we are like cattle who have strayed into their fields uninvited.”

headline: Wrong Place, Wrong Timing for Napoli in Game 3
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Mike Napoli usually watches a game unfold from behind a catcher’s mask, but his view at first base was crystal clear when it came to the tag he applied on Matt Holliday.

headline: African and Latin Beats at Prague Festival
text: An up-and-coming festival dedicated to Latin and African dance moves kicks off in Prague’s Old Town on Nov. 2. Heading into its second year, the Afro-Bailar Festival is taking over the Latin dance club Palanca on the fifth floor of the newly renovated Kotva department store (Namesti Republiky 8; www.palanca.cz), with a solid offering of international dance performances and workshops. There will be a little of everything, from salsa, reggae and tango to the sweet rhythmic beats of Africa’s popular kizomba, mbalax and semba music.

headline: Chargers at Jets: Matchup to Watch
text: Chargers (4-1) at Jets (3-3), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: Gale Gillingham, a Packers Hall of Famer
text: In the era before offensive linemen were allowed to open their hands and extend their arms, for both run and pass blocking, Gale Gillingham was an unusual combination of power and technique. Gillingham died on Thursday at his home in Minnesota. He was 67. A few thoughts:

headline: For Pujols, a Game for the Ages
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.

headline: For New Zealand, a Rugby World Cup on Home Soil
text: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Twenty-four years of Rugby World Cup pain and misery melted away for New  Zealand on Sunday.

headline: A Salmon Virus: Where Do We Go From Here?
text: If anything is certain about the recent discovery of infectious salmon anemia in two wild juvenile salmon in British Columbia, it is the extent of the uncertainties. Questions range from whether its discovery will be confirmed in additional laboratory tests to whether it has spread widely to how to contain it. Filling in the unknowns is the first order of business.

headline: Many Die as Eastern Turkey Is Jolted by Quake
text: ISTANBUL — At least 138 people were killed and about 350 were injured after a powerful earthquake struck eastern Turkey, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said in a news conference early Monday. The death toll was expected to rise, perhaps significantly, with many people reported to be stuck beneath dozens of collapsed buildings.

headline: Deck Chairs, Titanic
text: OK, yes, European banks do need more capital. But their problems are a symptom of the underlying sovereign debt problem, which can only be resolved, if at all, with ECB lending AND a commitment to reflate. Without that, the losses on sovereign debt will blow right through any amount of newly raised bank capital.

headline: Afghan President Says His Country Would Back Pakistan in a Clash With the U.S.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Days after he stood with Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and accused Pakistan of harboring his country’s enemies, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan said this weekend that his country would support Pakistan if it ever went to war with the United States.

headline: Paul Leka, a Songwriter of ‘Na Na Hey Hey,’ Dies at 68
text: Paul Leka, a songwriter and producer who worked with many recording stars but who was best known for writing the chanting chorus of “Na Na Hey Hey (Kiss Him Goodbye),” a No. 1 hit in 1969 that was reborn in the 1970s as a sports arena anthem, died on Oct. 12 in a hospice near his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 68.

headline: U.S. to Sustain Military Power in the Pacific, Panetta Says
text: BALI, Indonesia — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said on Sunday that despite hundreds of billions of dollars in expected cuts to the Pentagon budget, the United States would remain a Pacific power even as China expanded its military presence in the region.

headline: Manchester Massacre
text: Blue Sunday in Manchester. … City blue.

headline: Clinton Defends Iraq Withdrawal Plan
text: WASHINGTON – Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday strongly defended President Obama’s plan to withdraw combat troops from Iraq by the end of the year and issued a pointed warning to Iran not to underestimate the United States’ commitment to stability in the region.

headline: Viewing Qaddafi's Body
text: Hundreds of Libyans from all over the country traveled to get a look at the body of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Tunisians Vote in a Milestone of Arab Change
text: TUNIS — Millions of Tunisians cast votes on Sunday for an assembly to draft a constitution and shape a new government, in a burst of pride and hope that after inspiring uprisings across the Arab world, their small country could now lead the way to democracy.

headline: Palestinian Bid for Full Unesco Membership Imperils American Financing
text: PARIS — The Palestinian bid for full membership in Unesco — the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization — has put both Washington and the organization into an urgent bind.

headline: ‘Paranormal Activity 3’ Has Record Opening Weekend
text: North American moviegoers were in the mood to be scared over the weekend, powering the micro-budgeted “Paranormal Activity 3” to a stronger-than-anticipated $54 million in ticket sales. That total, easily enough for No. 1, prompted Paramount Pictures, the studio behind this wildly successful horror franchise, to shriek with delight, or at least superlatives. (According to Paramount, the opening weekend total for “Paranormal Activity 3,” which cost just $5 million to make, is the biggest in history for a horror film — not accounting for inflation.) The studio partly attributed strong sales to strikingly positive reviews, which helped draw more moviegoers in their 30s and 40s.

headline: Biden Won’t Rule Out 2016 Bid for President
text: In the upcoming 2012 election, Joe Biden will rally around the flag of President Barack Obama, but in 2016? He just might run for president himself — again.

headline: Victory Exalts a New Master of Manchester
text: MANCHESTER, England — The sign said “Old Trafford welcomes supporters of Manchester City,” but in the stadium, it did not feel that way.

headline: Revolution Won, Top Libyan Official Vows a New and More Pious State
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — The leader of the transitional government declared to thousands of revelers in a sunlit square here on Sunday that Libya’s revolution had ended, setting the country on the path to elections, and he vowed that the new government would be based on Islamic tenets.

headline: Touring the Fringes, the Final Hours of CMJ
text: I made the decision to spend the final day of this year’s CMJ festival on the fringes, at several of the symbiotic, or parasitic, events that pop up during CMJ week to take advantage of the sheer number of musicians stalking the city with an hour to spare. First, there was the Fader Fort, thrown by the Fader magazine and Fiat. That was followed by a Converse-sponsored showcase of hip-hop and hardcore at Santos Party House. After that, I closed the night at the New Museum, at a party organized by the Pitchfork spin-off site Altered Zones. All times are approximate. All feelings are not.

headline: Video From the Quake Zone in Turkey
text: Updated | Monday | 9:29 a.m. After a powerful earthquake struck eastern Turkey on Sunday, video posted online showed collapsed buildings and widespread panic.

headline: Designing for Safety in Turkey and Other Earthquake Zones
text: Oct. 24, 5:32 a.m. | Updated The latest earthquake in Turkey — that country’s strongest in a decade — provides a fresh reminder of the deep vulnerability created by weak building designs in the world’s crowded seismic danger zones. There will be more horror to come there and in other places prone to powerful quakes.

headline: European Leaders Deal Directly With Debt Dilemma
text: BRUSSELS — With a new sense of urgency, the leaders of the 27 European Union nations grappled directly on Sunday with their thorniest financial and economic problems, and made progress that they promised could yield a complete package of measures within days.

headline: Perry Comments Raise ‘Birther’ Flap Again
text: New comments by Rick Perry in Parade magazine have revived the issue of whether the Texas governor believes that President Obama was born in the United States.

headline: Personal Eco-Concierges Ease Transition to Green
text: They will run your errands by bicycle, recommend a spa that gives vegan manicures or buy organic clothes for you and your dog. They will even book you a dream vacation and buy the appropriate carbon offsets.

headline: More Grim Euro Thoughts
text: It now appears that as of today European leaders have boldly agreed to … announce something or other later in the week.

headline: Jets Revive Their Offense and Their Attitude
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In a far corner of the Jets’ locker room Sunday, where tumult and turmoil once reigned, linebacker Calvin Pace peddled optimism. He spoke of keeping faith, of confidence, of “keeping that train moving to Indianapolis” — the site of Super Bowl XLVI. In two weeks, the Jets have been transformed.

headline: Kenya Says Western Nations Join Fight in Somalia, as U.S. Denies Role
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Foreign military forces have joined the offensive against the Shabab militant group in Somalia as Kenyan troops advanced toward the rebel stronghold of Kismayu from two different directions, Kenya said Sunday.

headline: Masters at Giving People the Creeps of the Kind That Keep on Creeping
text: The best work in dark fantasy and horror fiction these days is being published by small presses, haunted literary boutiques established (mostly) in out-of-the-way places.

headline: Tunisia Votes
text: David D. Kirkpatrick reports from Soussa, Tunisia, where the first democratic elections since the beginning of the Arab Spring are underway.

headline: The ‘Enabling Violation’ of International Adoption
text: Defining adoption as “trauma” betrays a prejudice in favor of the traditional heterosexual family.

headline: Republicans Turn Judicial Power Into a Campaign Issue
text: WASHINGTON — Republican presidential candidates are issuing biting and sustained attacks on the federal courts and the role they play in American life, reflecting and stoking skepticism among conservatives about the judiciary.

headline: A Card Game Played With High Stakes
text: When you arrive at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe in the East Village, the usher hands you a program and a few extra photocopied sheets. One shows a familiar face: that of the usher himself, the playwright-director-actor Rome Neal, currently playing Thelonious Monk in a one-man show at the Moldy Fig, a jazz club a few blocks away. He’s also happy to point you toward the bathroom, which is plastered with posters for “Rome Neal’s Banana Puddin’,” a monthly jazz jam session and open-mike night at the poets cafe.

headline: Family Dysfunctions and the Duct Tape Détente
text: In the people-behaving-dysfunctionally genre of reality television you’re likely to see almost anyone wander across the screen in addition to the loony stars: their relatives, their hairstylists, their therapists. But there’s one type of person you almost never see, because to put such a person on camera would undercut the fly-on-the-wall conceit behind these shows: a member of the crew doing the filming.

headline: Do Good Debaters Make Good Presidents?
text: Rick Perry has performed poorly in the G.O.P. debates and his ratings have fallen. Does it matter?

headline: Women in Love Leap Into Elevator Shafts
text: Judging by her new work, which explores what it means to be a woman in love — its cheeky title is simply “the One” — it just wouldn’t do to describe Lyndsey Karr as the romantic type. As two women, more often naked than not, take the audience on a trip to three sites within the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, Queens, Ms. Karr, with deadpan whimsy, both demonstrates and ridicules archetypes of the besotted.

headline: ’60s Soul-Jazz Filtered Through a Quiet Storm
text: George Benson comes from the school of jazz in which you play frantic bebop guitar solos in long phrases over tight disco beats, sing love ballads, mug through exaggerated voices, provide your own canned laughter, tell stories about Miles Davis and James Brown and, like a ventriloquist, say “Shut up” to your instrument. It’s the school of jazz in which your keyboardist uses synthesizer settings to conjure the flutes and woodwinds that aren’t there — even playing an entire solo in fake-flute tones — and your showman drummer plays hammer-blow downbeats and moth-wing cymbal touches.

headline: A Double Turns Double-Edged
text: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands — At the world championships here, after 48 boards of the 96-board quarterfinals, the six United States teams are locked in close battles.

headline: Apple’s Lower Prices Are All Part of the Plan
text: Something unexpected has happened at Apple, once known as the tech industry’s high-price leader. Over the last several years it began beating rivals on price.

headline: Monday: Living Off the Land
text: Administrivial Delay: Due to unforeseen circumstances, my wrap-up of the “Crossing” Words Contest and the second part of my interview with Patrick Berry will run on Monday.

headline: A Fresh Reading of ‘The Breakfast Club’
text: Fans of “The Breakfast Club” were in luck on Thursday as the Los Angeles County Museum of Art hosted a high-profile table reading of that quintessential 1985 film about teenagers and their stereotypes, Entertainment Weekly reported on its Web site. Instead of the original stars from the film, a different group of actors joined for the occasion. Jennifer Garner played the popular Claire (Molly Ringwald’s part in the movie), James Van Der Beek was Andy the jock (Emilio Estevez), Patton Oswalt was the nerdy Brian (Anthony Michael Hall), Mindy Kaling was the misunderstood Allison (Ally Sheedy), and Aaron Paul was the school-detention lifer Bender (Judd Nelson).  J. K. Simmons and Michael Chiklis were the only two (fictional) adults in the room, portraying Carl the janitor and the hard-line teacher Mr. Vernon. The event was the brainchild of the director Jason Reitman (“Juno,” “Up in the Air”). “I needed a film that was in a contained location with not too many characters, that was funny, that was populous, that had a great script that the audience would have a relationship with,” Mr. Reitman told Entertainment Weekly. He also said he would soon announce five additional readings of different movies to benefit Film Independent, an organization that supports independent film projects and artists.

headline: A Designer Without the Flash
text: Charlotte Ronson, decidedly less flashy than her twin, the D.J., has quietly evolved into one of the most successful retail entrepreneurs of her generation.

headline: Group Says Newspapers Aren’t Dead, They’re Alluring
text: With more people getting their daily dose of news online through blogs and social media sites, traditional newspapers have gotten short shrift. Print is dead or dying, say media experts, and advertising can’t keep pace.

headline: For Black Coaches in the N.F.L., Still a Steep Road to the Top
text: When Al Davis hired Art Shell as the head coach of the Los Angeles Raiders in 1989, Clarence Shelmon was a 37-year-old running backs coach at the University of Southern California.

headline: Dallas Museum Lands New Director
text: Maxwell L. Anderson, who has been director of the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 2006, has been appointed director of the Dallas Museum of Art. He succeeds Bonnie Pitman, who retired from the job in June. Mr. Anderson is a well-known figure, having run the Whitney Museum of American Art from 1998 to 2003, when he resigned after disagreements with its board. During his tenure at the Indianapolis museum attendance has more than doubled, to 450,000 visitors annually. Mr. Anderson introduced innovative Internet-based tools to engage the public, including a dedicated video channel for art and artists and a dashboard that provided users with real-time statistics, like the number of visitors that day. In June 2010 the Indianapolis Museum of Art opened 100 Acres: The Virginia B. Fairbanks Art & Nature Park, among the largest contemporary art parks in the country. Mr. Anderson is to begin his new job on Jan. 9.

headline: Metro Pucks: A Week of Underachievement, and a Bit of Cheating
text: Our weekly review of the performances of the three local N.H.L. teams.

headline: Suddenly Two Bosses Leave the Show ‘Boss’
text: Something unusual happened to the political drama “Boss” at the end of September: Starz ordered a second season before the first season had begun. Then on Saturday, the day after the premiere, Deadline Hollywood reported that two of the executive producers of the series, Richard Levine and Lyn Greene, were leaving before work started on the second season. They had shared the post of show runner for the first season. Deadline Hollywood reported that Starz and the show’s producer, Lionsgate, were seeking replacements. The creator of “Boss,” Farhad Safinia, will remain, as will four other executive producers, including Kelsey Grammer, who stars as a tyrannical Chicago mayor.

headline: Even in Jerusalem, Thoughts Stray to Zuccotti Park
text: For Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the specter of Occupy Wall Street looms large — even in Jerusalem.

headline: Anticipating Big Growth at Tesla
text: Tesla Motors makes pure electric cars, but it’s valued like a hybrid. Quarterly numbers — due in the coming weeks — hint at its ability to hit manufacturing targets. But Silicon Valley-style growth is central to the story.

headline: With Eye on Beloved Rangers, Orchestra Plays On
text: DALLAS — They stood anxiously in tuxedo tails and black evening gowns — violinists, oboists and cellists packed three deep, craning to catch a glimpse of the wall-mounted television in the musicians lounge as St. Louis Cardinals pitcher Kyle Lohse looked in for the sign.

headline: Charles Hamm, Author on American Popular Music, Dies at 86
text: Charles Hamm, who helped establish the field of American popular music history with two books that have become standard texts, died on Oct. 16 in Lebanon, N. H. He was 86.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include S.& P./Case-Shiller Home Price Index and consumer confidence (Tuesday); durable goods orders and sales of new homes (Wednesday); third-quarter gross domestic product and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and personal income, personal spending, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment survey and pending home sales (Friday).

headline: Euro Flails but Art Fair Flourishes
text: PARIS — The mood was unexpectedly buoyant at the Grand Palais here on Thursday, the opening day of the 38th International Contemporary Art Fair, even as European leaders were desperately dashing around the Continent trying to save their common currency.

headline: India and Pakistan Sidestep a Crisis
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A potential military and diplomatic crisis was averted Sunday after an Indian Army helicopter that had strayed into Pakistan’s airspace and was forced to land by its military was allowed to return home, according to Pakistani officials.

headline: Questioning Privacy Protections in Research
text: Hoping to protect privacy in an age when a fingernail clipping can reveal a person’s identity, federal officials are planning to overhaul the rules that regulate research involving human subjects. But critics outside the biomedical arena warn that the proposed revisions may unintentionally create a more serious problem: sealing off vast collections of publicly available information from inspection, including census data, market research, oral histories and labor statistics.

headline: At London Theater, a Celebration of Biblical Proportions
text: God’s terse first line in the Book of Genesis — “Let there be light” — was ready-made for the Twitter generation. If only the rest was as crisp, the British novelist Jeanette Winterson recalled thinking, as she began to reckon with that first book for a new theatrical project on the King James Bible. And then it hit her: Maybe God’s wisdom would crackle for a modern audience as Twitter posts of 140 words or less.

headline: Broadway Debut After a Life of Opera
text: The ageless mezzo-soprano Rosalind Elias had never heard a note of Stephen Sondheim’s score for “Follies” when her agent first approached her about auditioning for the small, poignant role of Heidi Schiller, which she is now playing to acclaim in the popular revival at the Marquis Theater on Broadway.

headline: A Glut of Bands, Amid a Fog of Blaring Sound
text: A big part of this year’s CMJ Music Marathon — the 31st annual showcase for mostly new, mostly independent music presented by what began as College Music Journal — went by in a haze.

text: As several leading Republican presidential candidates embrace a flat tax as a core campaign position, one contender stands out in not doing so: Mitt Romney, who has a long record of criticizing such plans and famously derided Steve Forbes’s 1996 proposal as a “tax cut for fat cats.”

headline: Seven Billion
text: ONE week from today, the United Nations estimates, the world’s population will reach seven billion. Because censuses are infrequent and incomplete, no one knows the precise date — the Census Bureau puts it somewhere next March — but there can be no doubt that humanity is approaching a milestone.

headline: Small Isn’t Always Beautiful
text: Washington

headline: From Newsstand to Cooktop
text: For the celebrity chefs Emeril Lagasse and Wolfgang Puck, the kitchen counter is about to grow more crowded with a new set of culinary tools.

headline: Well-Known Felon Still Draws a Crowd, but Louisiana Has Moved On
text: CROWLEY, La. — If the test of a first-rate intelligence, as F. Scott Fitzgerald claimed, is the ability to hold two opposing ideas in the mind at the same time, there was the whiff of brilliance amid the scent of barbecue and fry-grease at the 75th International Rice Festival.

headline: More Jobs Predicted for Machines, Not People
text: A faltering economy explains much of the job shortage in America, but advancing technology has sharply magnified the effect, more so than is generally understood, according to two researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline: The Hole in Europe’s Bucket
text: If it weren’t so tragic, the current European crisis would be funny, in a gallows-humor sort of way. For as one rescue plan after another falls flat, Europe’s Very Serious People — who are, if such a thing is possible, even more pompous and self-regarding than their American counterparts — just keep looking more and more ridiculous.

headline: A Prodigal Daughter Returns Home
text: Audra McDonald’s Carnegie Hall concert on Saturday evening had the feel of a homecoming celebration for a prodigal daughter: in an unbroken wave of adoration, all was forgiven. Ms. McDonald’s crime, if there was one, was her temporary abandonment of musical theater for television. For four seasons, while playing Dr. Naomi Bennett in the ABC series “Private Practice,” she more or less disappeared from music.

headline: Battle for Libya | October 23, 2011
text: The leader of Libya’s transitional government declared to thousands of revelers in Benghazi that Libya’s revolution had ended, setting the country on the path to elections.

headline: Jobs Plan Stalled, Obama to Try New Economic Drive
text: WASHINGTON — With his jobs plan stymied in Congress by Republican opposition, President Obama on Monday will begin a series of executive-branch actions to confront housing, education and other economic problems over the coming months, heralded by a new mantra: “We can’t wait” for lawmakers to act.

headline: After Top 2, Oklahoma St. Has Inside Track
text: The losses by national title contenders Wisconsin and Oklahoma threw the Bowl Championship Series race into a tizzy. College football, after a few weeks heavy on chalk and light on thrillers, re-emerged as the unpredictable and parity-laden beast that had driven the sport’s popularity and television ratings the past few years.

headline: Robert Pierpoint, 86, Dies; CBS News Correspondent
text: Robert Pierpoint, the CBS News correspondent who brought a human-interest touch to coverage of the Korean War and later reported on six presidents, from Dwight D. Eisenhower to Jimmy Carter, died Saturday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 86.

text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Kirchner Achieves an Easy Victory in Argentina Presidential Election

headline: No Holiday
text: Big business has clearly decided that the economic crisis is too important to waste. While Washington debates how to create jobs and cut the budget deficit, major corporations — read major campaign contributors — are pushing Congress for an enormous tax cut on corporate profits. Lawmakers seem all too eager to grant their wish.

headline: In College, Working Hard to Learn High School Material
text: In June, Desiree Smith was graduated from Murry Bergtraum High. Her grades were in the 90s, she said, and she had passed the four state Regents exams. Since enrolling last month at LaGuardia Community College in Queens, Ms. Smith, 19, has come to realize that graduating from a New York City public high school is not the same as learning.

headline: ‘What Kind of Government?’

headline: 2 Japanese Bankers at Heart of Olympus Fee Inquiry

text: It was the kind of memo that high school students would dream of getting, if they dreamed in memos.

headline: Empty Fields Fill Urban Basins and Farmers’ Pockets
text: BRAWLEY, Calif. — Three generations of Al Kalin’s family have worked their 2,000 acres of carrots and sugar beets, wheat and alfalfa for almost a century in the Imperial Valley, a scorching swath of Southern California desert that was unfit for farming until water from the Colorado River was diverted here in 1901.

headline: California’s Persistence
text: California has a long and productive history as a leader in environmental policy, requiring cleaner cars and power plants and more energy-efficient appliances. The state continued to break new ground last week when it unveiled the country’s first comprehensive, statewide cap-and-trade system to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change.

headline: Environmental Features in Science Campus Plans
text: If Cornell University were to win the city’s competition to build a new science graduate school, it would install on Roosevelt Island almost four acres of solar panels, 500 geothermal wells, and buildings with the rare distinction of generating as much power as they use.

headline: Reward at Either End of Money List
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — There was a time when Justin Leonard stalked the greens the way an eagle-eyed Luke Donald did on Sunday en route to winning the last official PGA Tour event of the year.

headline: Why Not Occupy Newsrooms?
text: Almost two weeks ago, USA Today put its finger on why the Occupy Wall Street protests continued to gain traction.

headline: Records and Wins for Houston Quarterback
text: The off-campus garage apartment that Houston quarterback Case Keenum and his wife, Kimberly, share is so modest that it does not have a full number in its mailing address. The Keenums lovingly refer to their home as the Half, a cozy starter spot.

headline: Two Cheers for the Malaria Vaccine
text: A vaccine to protect children against malaria has been shown moderately effective in a large clinical trial — an achievement that could save millions of lives. The vaccine, known as RTS,S and made by GlaxoSmithKline, is the first ever to be shown effective against a human disease caused by parasites. When tested in 6,000 infants ages 5 to 17 months in seven sub-Saharan nations, it reduced the risk of infection with severe malaria by 47 percent during the year after the shots, far less than the 90 percent efficacy rate typically sought for other vaccines. And there are other big hurdles still to surmount. There are hints that the protection may wane over time and results from administering a booster shot won’t be known until 2014. Side effects could pose a problem; seizures and fevers were higher among children given the vaccine.

headline: Apple Posts Video From Steve Jobs Tribute
text: Apple has posted a video of a tribute to Steven P. Jobs, the company’s co-founder, that took place last week at the Apple campus in Cupertino, Calif. (The video must be viewed in the Safari Web browser.)

headline: Tebow Wills Broncos to Win With His Late-Game Play
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — It seemed as if everyone in the stadium knew what play the Denver Broncos would run on the 2-point conversion that would tie the game with 17 seconds to play. For 55 minutes, Tim Tebow had barely looked like a functioning N.F.L quarterback. He took sacks and threw poorly. He was hesitant and overwhelmed.

headline: Palmer Struggles in Raiders Debut, but Provides Glimpses of Promise
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The cheers from the home fans began to pick up about two minutes into the third quarter Sunday, which seemed strange only because the Kansas City Chiefs were ahead by 14 points and driving at the time. Then again, at that point, many of the Oakland Raiders’ followers were no longer watching what was happening on the field anyway.

headline: My Kingdom for a Map
text: The Battle of Ball’s Bluff does not loom large in our memory of the Civil War. Yet it was the second-largest battle in the eastern theater in 1861 and a complete rout of Union forces. James Morgan, an expert on the engagement, has described it as an “accidental battle” that resulted from erroneous intelligence. But it also reveals something about the wartime role of maps.

headline: A Hearing Aid That Cuts Out All the Clatter
text: After he lost much of his hearing last year at age 57, the composer Richard Einhorn despaired of ever really enjoying a concert or musical again. Even using special headsets supplied by the Metropolitan Opera and Broadway theaters, he found himself frustrated by the sound quality, static and interference.

headline: Panetta’s Pentagon, Without the Blank Check
text: WASHINGTON — Tan and ruddy-faced, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta took his seat in a hearing room one morning this month ready for battle. The enemy, he warned lawmakers ominously, was “a blind, mindless” one that could “badly damage our capabilities” and “truly devastate our national defense.”

headline: Tech Giants Sizing Up Yahoo Bid
text: As a host of potential bidders circle Yahoo, several of Silicon Valley’s biggest companies are considering whether to jump into the fray themselves.

headline: Leon E. Panetta, in His Own Words
text: In two extensive interviews, Leon E. Panetta talked about his long career in Washington, his role as the C.I.A. director who oversaw the raid that killed Osama bin Laden and the challenges confronting him as President Obama’s new secretary of defense:

headline: Investors Wait Warily for Europe Bank Rescue
text: After negotiating through the weekend in Brussels in search of a comprehensive solution to the Continent’s sovereign debt crisis, European leaders reported progress on the framework of a broad rescue package.

headline: A Grass-Roots Newscast Gives a Voice to Struggles
text: Hours after Amy Goodman, the host of the grass-roots newscast “Democracy Now!,” was arrested in Minnesota in 2008 while trying to cover protesters at the Republican National Convention, she was sitting in a network news studio above the convention floor, when a producer said: “I don’t get it. Why wasn’t I arrested?”

headline: A Princess Visits Queens; Queens Is Impressed

headline: One Charger Doesn’t Go Down Quietly

headline: Studying Successful People With Mental Illness

headline: Oct. 24, 1945 | United Nations Is Born
text: On Oct. 24, 1945, the United Nations charter took effect after being ratified by the five permanent members of the Security Council (the United States, Great Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China) and a majority of the other 46 members.The  New York Times reported the following day, “In signing the protocol [U.S. Secretary of State James F.] Byrnes said the Charter was now a ‘part of the law of nations’ and that it was ‘a memorable day for the peace-loving peoples of all nations.’ But he warned that peace depended upon the will of the peoples for peace rather than upon documents.”

headline: Domebound
text: In 1948, the architect and inventor Buckminster Fuller gathered a group of his students at Black Mountain College to build a life-size geodesic dome. The dome was a flop. It succeeded, however, in planting the seed for the sculptor Kenneth Snelson, a student of Fuller’s, to develop the principle of tensegrity that would allow Fuller to build a dome for the United States Pavilion at Expo 67 in Montreal. For the Performa 11 biennial (11.performa-arts.org), the Los Angeles artist Liz Glynn will retrace Fuller’s steps, pratfalls and all. Part 1 of her performance — a loosely choreographed re-enactment of Fuller’s failed attempt — takes place on the first Sunday of the biennial in locations throughout New York City, including Times Square; for Part 2, 25 volunteers will assist in building a dome. Whether it will stand remains to be seen. But Glynn’s cast-concrete dome sculptures (above), on view at the Performa Hub through Nov. 21, are objects of perfection of which even Fuller might have approved.
