headline: Hidden Gem
text: Ten years is the length of an average commercial lease, but it’s also, as the designer Ted Muehling has discovered, the approximate life span of a neighborhood. Back in 2001, Muehling moved his storefront workshop from a formerly desolate block on Greene Street to Howard Street — at the time SoHo’s final frontier. But when a Mondrian hotel went up nearby, so did Muehling’s rent, and the designer moved on once again. His new store, on White Street in TriBeCa, is grander in proportion and there is more selling space, but also more space for Muehling to display the many things he collects and that inspire him, from natural wonders like seashells or insects to the work of his partner, the artist Mats Gustafson, or that of his friend Jan Baracz, who carves bellybuttons into large stones. And while his workrooms are smaller, for the first time Muehling has a little studio all his own — an “attic” tucked into a mezzanine under a skylight in the back. The timing could not have been better. With his product collaborations with Nymphenburg and Steuben winding down, Muehling is eager to get back to making jewelry. On a recent morning, a pair of canaries twittered joyfully, and an installation of monarch butterflies on a dried mullein stem was magically animated by a breeze from the air-conditioner. As with his previous store, this one is livened by sounds from behind the scenes — the bang of metal on metal, the murmur of NPR — evidence that this is a place where things are made and not just sold. It’s the kind of neighborhood place, Muehling points out, where you can walk in and they’ll make a new wire for your earring if you don’t mind waiting 20 minutes.

headline: Southfork Kitchen (and Its Owner) Have Survived a Year

Detachment would be healthy for all concerned — no one likes the boss hanging around all the time, and the boss could concentrate on neglected parts of his restaurant (and his life).

headline: Pressed, Italy’s Cabinet Fails to Act on Debt Crisis
text: ROME — Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi called an urgent cabinet meeting on Monday, a day after German and French leaders urged Italy to quickly pass measures to help reduce pressure on the euro, but the meeting ended with no public decisions on any new efforts to spur the country’s economic growth or cut its huge public debt.

headline: Viewers Embrace ABC’s ‘Once Upon a Time’
text: The television season may finally have its first new hit drama.

headline: What’s Performing at Performa
text: Even online, Performa 11, the visual art performance biennial, overwhelms. When a festival gets this absurdly overgrown, it no longer makes sense to try to see it all so as to understand its larger themes or curatorial arc — leave that Sisyphean task to the critics (God help us). The better strategy: cherry-pick wisely. Here, Karen Rosenberg and I offer a few promising possibilities for the festival, which runs from Nov. 1 through 21.  — Claudia La Rocco

headline: Missoni Style Everywhere You Look
text: Waiting in mid-Manhattan last month to storm Target’s pop-up shop offering the much-trumpeted Missoni for Target collection, Elsa Isaac could scarcely contain herself. “I’m thinking that this is a collector’s collection,” Ms. Isaac said. “People are going to talk about this for a while.”

headline: The Caucus | All About Iowa
text: Oct. 24, 2011 - With the primary calendar basically set, the campaign will largely center around the Hawkeye state for the next two months. Also, Rick Perry will propose a flat tax on Tuesday.

headline: Caucus Video: All About Iowa
text: With the primary calendar largely set, the campaign will center around the Hawkeye state for the next 10 weeks. Also, Rick Perry is set to propose a flat tax on Tuesday.

headline: Leave It to the Brits to ‘Solve’ the Obesity Crisis
text: The British have “solved” the obesity crisis.

headline: After Quick Growth, and Pollution, China Retools
text: Toby Smith doesn’t claim to have all the answers. Three years ago, however, he did set off on a difficult journey to ask a single complicated question.

headline: Kidding Ourselves About Our Financial Reality
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Expansion of Mortgage Program Is Limited in Scope
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government’s expansion of a mortgage refinancing program could reduce the monthly payments of up to one million homeowners, but analysts said the modest scope of the plan meant it would probably do little to heal the housing market or help the broader economy.

headline: Moderate Islamist Party Heads Toward Victory in Tunisia
text: TUNIS — Tunisia’s moderate Islamist political party emerged Monday as the acknowledged leader in elections for a constitutional assembly and began talks to form a unity government with a coalition of liberals in a rare alliance that party leaders hailed as an inclusive model for countries emerging from the tumult of the Arab Spring.

headline: Charlie Rose in Talks With ‘The Early Show’
text: The television interviewer Charlie Rose confirmed Monday that he was in talks with CBS about a role on “The Early Show,” the network’s perennial third-place morning program.

headline: Harley-Davidson Recalls 250,000 Motorcycles
text: Harley-Davidson is recalling about a quarter million motorcycles because their rear brake lights may stop working and brake fluid may leak, the manufacturer told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Shaq-a-Claus Returns to Toys for Tots Campaign
text: Although he has retired from professional basketball, Shaquille O’Neal is continuing in his role as “Shaq-a-Claus” for the Toys “R” Us annual holiday campaign for the Marine Toys for Tots Foundation.

headline: The Vanishing $2.5 Million in Insider Trading Profits
text: There are a number of benefits to a plea bargain, not the least of which is the government is much more amenable to drafting the deal in such a way as to reach a mutually agreeable sentence. The recent guilty plea by Drew K. Brownstein to an insider trading charge illustrates how a potential sentence can be reduced by leaving out transactions that lower the gain from the illegal trading.

headline: Bachmann’s New Hampshire Staff Assails Campaign
text: Members of Michele Bachmann‘s New Hampshire staff, who quit en masse last week, assailed her national campaign advisers in a statement on Monday, calling them “rude, unprofessional, dishonest and at times cruel.”

headline: Prosecution Rests in the Manslaughter Trial of Michael Jackson’s Physician
text: LOS ANGELES — The prosecution rested its case on Monday in the involuntary manslaughter trial of Michael Jackson’s physician after almost a month of testimony that provided a gloomy look at the pop star’s final days.

headline: Crossing the Finish Line
text: MANHATTAN, north of Houston Street — “The last leg of my bicycle journey was spurred by thoughts of home, of completing a task, of being welcomed back. It was a brisk final chapter, both exciting and sad, as endings tend to be.”

headline: Red Bulls’ Rost Is Old-School, and Proud of It
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — Goalkeeper Frank Rost, 38, is the oldest player on the Red Bulls’ roster (and also one of the tallest at 6 feet 5 inches).

headline: A To-Do About a Surprise ‘Much Ado’ From Joss Whedon
text: 3:28 p.m. | Updated

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 24
text: The Pan American Games continued in Guadalajara, Mexico, with events like wrestling, weight lifting and field hockey.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Lightyear
text: Lightyear, the artist formerly known as Lauren Zettler, celebrated the release of her new EP, “All of the Miles,” with an intimate performance at Flux Studios. Zettler alternated between the piano and acoustic guitar, leading a small band and two backup vocalists through a string of airtight pop-folk numbers. Well produced and thoroughly rehearsed, Lightyear is a solidly professional act from an accomplished songwriter who should soon be mentioned in the same breath with the likes of Meiko, Feist and Regina Spektor.

headline: My Three Favorite Appetizers, I Think
text: My three favorite appetizers vary by day, by week — even by moment. I like too many of them. Maybe it’s because appetizers are a tease. Or maybe it’s because you’re at your hungriest when you eat them. It seems like there are an awful lot of good ones out there. All the better to experiment. If they don’t turn out perfect, so what? They’re not the main course.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Thailand, Turkey, Libya and Cuba.

headline: Good Times Gone Bad: The Right to Harm Ourselves
text: A sports arena is a symbol of rousing good times; so is an open bar. Both are also reliable harbingers of medical disaster. And as two new books make clear, when one man’s sport is another’s undoing (or merely his own), decades may be lost in bitter disagreement over what is to be done.

headline: The Divergent Fortunes of Saab and Volvo
text: TROLLHATTAN, Sweden — On a gloomy, rainy afternoon, Rafael Hernandez strained through his exercise routine, preparing for the day that he would return to work at the local Saab auto plant.

headline: Korean Grilling on Glass, at Kristalbelli
text: Coming to Midtown before Christmas: Kristalbelli, Manhattan’s latest entry in the global quest to make Korean barbecue upscale, not just popular. Its chef, David Shim, has worked at Gramercy Tavern, L’Atelier de Joel Robuchon and Veritas. He promises Wagyu beef, organic vegetables, pork belly and the usual prize morsels for grilling.

headline: Tale of Two Swedish Carmakers
text: Volvo and Saab face vastly different outlooks, partly because of their diverging histories under their former American owners, but also because one company found a deep-pocketed rescuer and one did not.

headline: For a Night, Baseball Beats Football in the Ratings
text: Perhaps it was the 62-7 score, or the increased competition from other networks or an overall lack of interest in a match-up – a rematch of Super Bowl XLIV – between the New Orleans Saints and a Peyton Manning-less Indianapolis Colts team. Whatever the reason, preliminary estimates from Nielsen suggest that “Sunday Night Football” on NBC posted its lowest rating in nearly three years. It was not the No. 1 program of the night in total viewers or in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. That claim goes to Game 4 of the World Series, in which the Texas Rangers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-0. That baseball game averaged 15.2 million total viewers.

headline: Street Style: Capes and Vests
text: The best of readers’ street fashion photos for the week of Oct. 17.

headline: New Unease for Europe’s Rescue Plan
text: FRANKFURT — As officials worked on Monday to iron out details of a plan to solve the European debt crisis, fears were growing that the result might be another example of European leaders doing less rather than more. And concerns are that it may not be enough.

headline: Original Model T’s | David Reinfurt
text: No. 9 in a series of original artworks.

headline: Schwarzman’s Roast, in Its Entirety
text: Last week, we brought you highlights from a speech given by Stephen A. Schwarzman, the Blackstone Group co-founder, at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner. In the roast, which was widely circulated on Wall Street, Mr. Schwarzman lampooned, among others, Rupert Murdoch, Brian T. Moynihan and himself.

headline: Founder Says WikiLeaks, Starved of Cash, May Close
text: LONDON — Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, said on Monday that his Web site could be forced to shut down by the end of the year because a 10-month-old “financial blockade” had sharply reduced the donations on which it depends.

headline: In Phone Hacking Inquiry, a Renewed Focus on Executives
text: LONDON — The focus on Rupert Murdoch’s senior executives in the wake of the News of the World phone hacking scandal intensified on Monday as his former right-hand man was questioned by lawmakers and his son James was summoned to give further testimony next month.

headline: Haunting Ideas: Halloween in the Classroom and ‘On the Street’
text: This audio slide show, celebrating Halloween in Manhattan, is from October 2010, and is part of the “On the Street” series reported and narrated by Bill Cunningham, a journalist who is in his early 80s and has worked for The New York Times since the 1970s.

headline: Particles Faster Than the Speed of Light? Not So Fast, Some Say
text: “Does E still equal MC squared?”

headline: Surgery Forces Mayer to Cancel Concerts and Postpone His Album
text: John Mayer, the singer and songwriter, has undergone surgery to remove an inflamed growth on his vocal cords that forced him to cancel several concerts and postpone the release of a new album, he wrote on his Tumblr blog.

headline: Modest Farmer, Managing Mogul
text: The National Fantasy Baseball Championship, a contest paying a top prize of $100,000, draws an elite collection of contestants: computer geniuses, deep-pocketed stockbrokers and money managers, maybe a young man or woman looking to be the next Billy Beane or Theo Epstein.

headline: Drugs to Treat A.D.H.D. Reach the Preschool Set
text: Ruth Grau was first told her son had attention deficit hyperactivity disorder when he was 3. The idea of medicating him was anathema to her, so she and her husband tried an alternative approach: exercise, occupational therapy and a diet free of junk food — no sweets, no dairy, no processed food.

headline: Ray’s Pizza, ‘the’ Ray’s Pizza, Will Close on Sunday
text: Fifty-two years and countless oven-hot pies later, Ray’s Pizza — the Ray’s Pizza — will serve its last slice on Prince Street on Sunday.

headline: Yoga and Stretching Equally Effective for Back Pain
text: Weekly yoga classes relieve symptoms of low back pain about as well as intense, regular stretching sessions, a new study shows.

headline: Midlife Weight Loss Cuts Heart Risk
text: Being overweight as a teenager carries a greater risk of being an overweight adult, along with an increased risk of dying of heart disease. But overweight adolescents who slim down in middle age may lower their risk, a new study shows.

headline: Abu Dhabi Guggenheim Construction Delayed
text: Plans to award a major construction contract for concrete work on the Guggenheim museum planned for Saadiyat Island in Abu Dhabi have been temporarily suspended, the Associated Press has reported. But officials from the Tourism Development and Investment Company, which is  building the large cultural district in the Emirati capital that the Guggenheim will be part of, said another major museum there — a branch of the Louvre — is on track to open in late 2013.

headline: Mammogram’s Role as Savior Is Tested
text: Has the power of the mammogram been oversold?

headline: A Transcendence Anchored in Bach
text: When Lincoln Center introduced its White Light Festival last year, it described it as an exploration of spirituality in music. But the definition was diffuse: where the music was overtly secular, listeners were encouraged to think about the spiritual core of all great art. That was fine advice, but the works Lincoln Center assembled did not really amount to a coherent festival.

headline: Cameron Faces Internal Revolt Over European Policy
text: LONDON — After being berated by President Nicolas Sarkozy of France at a rancorous European summit meeting over the weekend, Prime Minister David Cameron on Monday faced an all-out rebellion from members of his own party over whether Britain should even be part of the European Union.

headline: Childbirth as Performance Art
text: Here are a few things you can go see at Brooklyn art galleries this week: urban tapestries, black-and-white photography, or if you time it right, Marni Kotak giving birth at the Microscope Gallery in Brooklyn.

headline: Timescast | October 24, 2011
text: A moderate Islamic party appears to win Tunisia’s first free election; the search continues for survivors of Turkey’s earthquake; and financial troubles could shutter WikiLeaks.

headline: Bees’ Migration Holds Clues to Geologic History
text: Two new bee species shed light on Panama’s history as a land bridge between South and Central America, scientists are reporting.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Quaint Block and a Symbol of Blight
text: Warren Street between Bond and Nevins offers many of the things well-off buyers seek in Brownstone Brooklyn: a pastoral, leafy feel; long rows of 19th-century town houses; proximity to transportation and charming little restaurants; young families on the block.

headline: Disposable Chopsticks Strip Asian Forests
text: Festival season in Japan is a sensory delight. Taiko drums bang while fireworks blaze overhead, delighting kimono-clad onlookers. Perhaps most central to the Japanese festival experience, though, is the food: sizzling meat on a stick, octopus balls and globs of at least four  kinds of noodles are only a few of the delicacies on offer.

headline: Smooth Desert Boulders May Be Quakes’ Work
text: Across the Atacama Desert in Chile are thousands of peculiar boulders that look as if they were rubbed smooth across their midsections.

headline: MyCityWay – Not Just for Tourists
text: Part city guide, part virtual dashboard, MyCityWay aggregates useful information into one convenient place: your mobile device. Available for more than 40 markets around the globe, each app is a comprehensive travel, reference and city-service guide wrapped into one. The free apps are available for iPhone, Android and Blackberry.

headline: Critics’ Picks: ’25th Hour’
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Spike Lee’s drama about a man preparing to go to prison.

headline: District Attorney Won’t Drop Charges Against Protesters
text: The Manhattan district attorney’s office will not summarily dismiss the charges against some 300 Occupy Wall Street protesters who were arrested and charged with disorderly conduct during rallies on the Brooklyn Bridge and at Union Square, a lawyer for the protesters said Monday.

headline: Israel Reaches Deal for Release of an American Held in Egypt
text: JERUSALEM — Israel announced Monday that it had reached an agreement with Egypt, with American assistance, for the release of Ilan Grapel, an American law student from Queens who also holds Israeli citizenship.

headline: Debt And Devaluation
text: Iceland’s condition can at best be described as “not as bad as it could have been.” I’m getting a lot of correspondence, in particular, about the problem of household debt. During the boom Icelandic citizens borrowed quite a lot, often with loans that were either euro-denominated or indexed to inflation. With the krona depreciated and real wages lower thanks to higher import prices, this leaves a lot of people in debt distress.

headline: Next for Newport Preservation: Gilded-Age Beeches
text: NEWPORT, R.I. — In the Gilded Age, the rich built marble palaces here, surrounding them with exotic trees they acquired with the same ardor they brought to assembling their fabulous collections of art.

headline: For iPhones, a Central Park Soundtrack
text: When that great emerald and hilly patch at the center of Manhattan first opened, music was limited to brief concerts under the Naumberg Bandshell. Today, of course, Central Park is fixed in sonic history — landmark rock shows, global benefits, swanky midsummer soirees — so diverse that any attempt to fuse the park’s streams, forests and rock faces into a single musical experience seems almost futile.

headline: Wired Textiles for a Phone as Useful as the Shirt on Your Back
text: John Volakis wants to make the world hands-free.

headline: Hope For HARP
text: Most quick reactions to the new Obama housing proposal have been fairly dismissive, arguing that it would provide only a small boost. I don’t have an opinion yet, because I haven’t had time to work through the details — and on this kind of thing, the devil is very much in the details. (Does that make it another 666 plan?)

headline: Lions’ Dream Season Suddenly Less Dreamy
text: The Detroit Lions are falling back to earth, with their red-hot 5-0 start now down to a 5-2 record, and they are now facing accusations of taunting by an opponent and a possible foot injury to starting quarterback Matthew Stafford.

headline: Hendra and Nipah: Antibody Treatment for 2 Deadly Viruses Shows Promise in Tests and an Emergency
text: A treatment using human antibodies against two of the scariest new viruses has protected monkeys in tests, researchers reported last week.

headline: Morgan Stanley Sells Mortgage Servicer
text: Morgan Stanley has sold its mortgage servicing company, a deal that will net the Wall Street firm $59.3 million in cash.

headline: How Revolutionary Tools Cracked a 1700s Code
text: It has been more than six decades since Warren Weaver, a pioneer in automated language translation, suggested applying code-breaking techniques to the challenge of interpreting a foreign language.

headline: At Broadway Box Office This Fall, the Play’s the Thing
text: Ticket sales for straight plays on Broadway were notably strong last week, according to theater box office data released on Monday, with most of those non-musical productions making gains in their grosses in an otherwise flat week for Broadway. Indeed, money-wise, new straight plays are poised to have one of their best fall seasons on Broadway in recent years.

headline: Sentence of the Month, Juggernauts Edition
text: In an effort to catch up after our recent debilitating case of Sentence Blindness, here are the belated candidates for September’s Sentence of the Month:

headline: A Clear Channel for the Hearing-Impaired
text: A technology widely used in public places in Northern Europe has the potential to transform the lives of tens of millions of hearing-impaired adults in the United States, The Times reported on Monday.

headline: The chambered nautilus fights for its life, talking to your shirt and the long-term battle over long-term care.
text: The chambered nautilus fights for its life, talking to your shirt and the long-term battle over long-term care.

headline: A Challenge to Conventional Wisdom on Small Business and Jobs
text: Jared Bernstein, who was until May Vice President Joe Biden’s top economic adviser, published an article on the Op-Ed page of Monday’s Times that challenges much of the orthodoxy about small business in the United States. He argues that small businesses really don’t employ the majority of Americans, and that they don’t create the majority of new jobs.

headline: Clashes With Kurds Are Pushing Turkey Back Toward Conflict
text: CIZRE, Turkey — Thousands of people filled the streets of this dusty town near the borders with Syria and Iraq on Sunday to mourn the death of a local heroine, a commander in a mountaintop training camp for Kurdish militants seeking autonomy for the country’s largely Kurdish southeast.

headline: Former ‘American Idol’ Now the Voice of Vengeance
text: KELLY CLARKSON

headline: TimesCast | Moderate Islamist Victory
text: October 24, 2011 — A moderate Islamic party appears to be the big winner in Tunisia’s first elections for an assembly to shape its new government.

headline: Retirement Plan Providers Can Now Offer Own Advice
text: Some big retirement plans offer investors the chance to hire an independent adviser that can help them choose their investments. But your plan provider will soon be able to offer the advice itself, as long as it meets rules issued recently by the Department of Labor.

headline: TimesCast | WikiLeak’s Financial Woes
text: Julian Assange says a lack of donations could shutter WikiLeaks by year’s end.

text: Lens: Pete Muller

headline: ING Direct Drops Rate on Its Savings Account
text: The foreseeable future may already be here, it seems.

headline: TimesCast | Turkey’s Deadly Earthquake
text: A day after a devastating earthquake shook Eastern Turkey, the search for survivors continues.

headline: New Leader for Liberal Research Group
text: A veteran of the Obama and Clinton administrations, Neera Tanden, will be taking over as president of the Center for American Progress, a research organization that represents the views of the president’s more liberal, and somewhat disaffected, base.

headline: Leading the March to a Mystical Place
text: Lincoln Center’s monthlong White Light Festival is back for its second year. As before, the focus of the event is a little blurry. In the words of Lincoln Center’s artistic director, Jane Moss, White Light is an exploration of music and art’s power to reveal “dimensions of our interior lives.” The programs offer “a spectrum of artistic expression that moves us inward and expands our spirit.”

headline: A Look With Fangs
text: At Carine Roitfeld’s bal des vampires in Paris this month for her book “Irreverent,” the hostess and guests, like the model Anja Rubik, in a gothic lace-up velvet number, showed that high-fashion vamp calls for skillfully smudged eyes. “Start by lining inside and underneath the lash line, then the entire lid with black pencil,” the makeup artist Kristin Hilton advises.

headline: Scenes from BlizzCon
text: The annual event celebrating the video game company Blizzard Entertainment took place in Anaheim, Calif., last weekend, drawing more than 26,000 attendees.

headline: Best Friends, in Fantasy and Reality
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — More than 26,000 people from 50 states and 49 countries arrived here last week for BlizzCon, the annual self-celebration by Blizzard Entertainment, perhaps the most revered video game company in the world.

headline: DNC Ad Goes After Romney in Arizona
text: The Democratic National Committee will on Tuesday begin its biggest sustained advertising campaign against a Republican presidential candidate so far this year, with a spot attacking Mitt Romney in the state of Arizona, traditionally Republican territory that President Obama’s advisers hope to bring into their victory column next year.

headline: Romeo Meets Radiohead in a Love Story of Twitches
text: Here’s the pitch: a ballet of Romeo and Juliet. Sure, that’s been done before, but this is contemporary, set to songs by Radiohead, sure to appeal to a youthful demographic. And get this: Juliet doesn’t kill herself. The whole love story comes through her flashbacks. This thing is stripped-down, chic, just Juliet in a corset and six men in suits without shirts. It doesn’t take up your whole evening, either. An hour and you’re out.

headline: Yes, Those Are Tom, Becky and Huck Leaping
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — On Thursday I was exploring America’s oldest grand opera house still used for its original purpose, the Academy of Music in Philadelphia. Over the weekend I was discovering its newest auditorium for opera and ballet, the Kauffman Center for the Performing Arts here in Kansas City.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ’25th Hour’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Spike Lee‘s 2002 film “25th Hour.” It stars Edward Norton as Monty Brogan, a man experiencing his last day of freedom before going to serve a long prison sentence. It tracks him as he says his goodbyes and takes care of some unfinished business. “25th Hour” features a strong ensemble cast, including Brian Cox, Barry Pepper, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Anna Paquin and Rosario Dawson as Monty’s girlfriend. “But the real love interest,” Mr. Scott says, “is New York City itself.” The film takes in the aftermath of the September 11 attacks and “it captures, better than any other movie, the mood of raw shock and grief that blanketed the city in those months.” Have you seen “25th Hour?” Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

headline: Protesters Briefly Take Over a Gallery
text: The boundaries of Occupy Wall Street expanded beyond Zuccotti Park over the weekend, as a splinter group briefly took over an art gallery in SoHo.

headline: Still No Relief in Sight for Long-Term Needs
text: WASHINGTON — The law that many Americans had hoped would transform the nation’s dysfunctional system of long-term care for the swelling ranks of people with disabilities and dementia quietly died this month, a victim of its own weaknesses, a toxic political environment and President Obama’s re-election campaign focus on jobs.

headline: Houdini Returns. (Of Course.)
text: Even in death, Harry Houdini has been hard to pin down.

headline: Perry Adds Veteran Advisers to Campaign
text: Read the complete report on Monday’s changes to Rick Perry’s campaign strategy.

headline: Tagliolini With Chicken Livers and Fennel
text: With Rosso di Montalcino wines, my appetite turns to chicken livers. Their edge of bitterness tamed by salt seems to be on the same wavelength as the wines. In Tuscany, chicken liver crostini, often seasoned with anchovies, are a typical palate awakener. I gave my chicken livers a bit more heft, with a flat noodle pasta, using black olive paste for salty bite. This dish can be a dinner party first course — the primi, as they say in Italy — to be followed by a more substantial main dish, perhaps served with a Brunello. Or the pasta and the Rosso can stand on their own for a simpler dinner in the American style.

headline: Pure Montalcino, Minus the Wait
text: IN retrospect, what was all the fuss about? Here sat the wine panel, having tasted 20 bottles of Rosso di Montalcino, reveling in the unmistakable earthy, dusty flavors of pure sangiovese. With their winsomely bitter, citrus-tinged cherry flavors, these wines were soulful and elemental, like good trattoria food. They wanted less talking and more drinking.

headline: Q&A: For Sisters, Hawaii May Beckon
text: Q.

headline: Lens: Turning Point — John Minchillo
text: Lens: Turning Point — John Minchillo

headline: Two-Sided Man Gets Two New Biographies
text: In a remarkable account of a meeting he had with Charles Dickens in 1862, Dostoyevsky recalled that the British novelist told him: “All the good simple people in his novels, Little Nell, even the holy simpletons like Barnaby Rudge, are what he wanted to have been, and his villains were what he was (or rather, what he found in himself), his cruelty, his attacks of causeless enmity toward those who were helpless and looked to him for comfort, his shrinking from those whom he ought to love, being used up in what he wrote. There were two people in him, he told me: one who feels as he ought to feel and one who feels the opposite. From the one who feels the opposite I make my evil characters, from the one who feels as a man ought to feel I try to live my life. ‘Only two people?’ I asked.”

headline: Korean Pop Machine, Running on Innocence and Hair Gel
text: Think of the work required to make just one Justin Bieber. The production, the management, the vocal training, the choreography, the swagger coaching — all that effort to create one teen-pop star in a country that’s still starving for them. South Korea has no such drought, thanks to several companies that specialize in manufacturing a steady stream of teenage idols, in groups of various configurations. One of the longest-running of these companies is SM Entertainment, which on Sunday night hosted SM Town Live, a sold-out showcase at Madison Square Garden for several of its acts, any one of which any American reality-TV talent show or major-label A&R department worth its salt would be thrilled to have discovered.

headline: Poverty in the Suburbs
text: Metro areas where the share of poor people living in the suburbs crossed the 50 percent mark between 2000 and 2010.

headline: TV Struggles to Bring War Zones to Americans
text: Hollywood has brought the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq home for American filmgoers in sometimes stunning, painful detail in recent years. “Lions for Lambs” featured stars like Tom Cruise and Meryl Streep. “The Hurt Locker” won the Oscar for best picture. “Restrepo” and other documentaries wowed reviewers.

headline: Netflix Loses Subscribers, Though Earnings Rise
text: Netflix said Monday that it ended the third quarter of the year with 23.8 million subscribers in the United States, a loss of 800,000 in three months, representing a notable decline after years of consistent growth.

headline: A Camera Narcissus Could Love
text: Samsung is offering a new camera that Narcissus might love almost as much as he loved himself.

headline: Obama Campaign Experiments With Tumblr for ’12
text: It’s no secret that President Obama’s victory in 2008 was helped by his adoption of Twitter and other social media platforms. For 2012, Republicans and other politicians are flocking to these services too, hoping to spread the party gospel 140 characters at a time.

headline: Murdoch’s Sons Rebuked by News Corp. Shareholders
text: News Corporation‘s independent shareholders voted largely against reinstating Rupert Murdoch’s sons James and Lachlan to the company board, according to a tally the company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday. Although the Murdoch family’s control of a large percentage of voting shares all but guaranteed that all 15 board members would be re-elected after a contentious shareholder meeting on Friday, the detailed tally showed widespread opposition to the roles of James and Lachlan Murdoch.

headline: When Video Killed Radio Stars
text: Like almost everyone who was a teenager in the early 1980s, when the Music Television network first went live on cable, I wanted my MTV. I’d glue myself to the channel for hours, losing body mass, muscle control and self-esteem, the way my son gives himself over to video games today. MTV demanded that you linger in front of it for entire afternoons, because it tucked its few good videos amid so many horrible ones. You had to learn Zen couch potato patience.

headline: China: Video of Monk’s Protest Released
text: A video of a Tibetan monk’s attempt to kill himself last month by self-immolation to protest Chinese policies has been released. The video was given anonymously to The Associated Press and released Sunday. It shows a monk, Lobsang Konchok, lying in a street in the town of Aba, in Sichuan Province, with his robes and shoes partly burned off. Security officers and a police car are visible in the background. The monk set himself on fire on Sept. 26 but lived. Nine Tibetans have set themselves on fire this year in Sichuan, and at least five have died.

headline: Nurturing Start-Ups in Brazil, With a Nod to Silicon Valley
text: CAMPINAS, Brazil — When the investment firm Monashees Capital first called Juliano Ipolito, the co-founder of an online handicrafts marketplace, he assumed that he would have to visit the firm in São Paulo.

headline: Florida: Judge Blocks Welfare Drug Tests
text: A federal judge on Monday temporarily blocked a far-reaching Florida law that requires public assistance applicants to take a drug test, saying the law probably violates a constitutional ban on unreasonable search and seizure. The law, which took effect in July, is the only one in the country that requires people receiving cash assistance through welfare to pass a drug test. The applicants must pay for the test themselves but are reimbursed if they test negative. A similar law in Michigan was struck down as unconstitutional a decade ago. In her ruling, Judge Mary S. Scriven of Federal District Court in Orlando said that there was “no special need” for the state to require drug tests and that it should stop, at least until the court made a final determination in the case. The “court concludes that preliminarily enjoining what appears likely to be deemed an unconstitutional intrusion on the Fourth Amendment rights” of applicants “serves the public interest,” Judge Scriven said. The ruling stems from a lawsuit filed by Luis Lebron, a Navy veteran, and the American Civil Liberties Union of Florida.

headline: Ukraine: New Test for Ex-Premier
text: The general prosecutor’s office on Monday said that it had reopened another criminal case against Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the opposition leader and a former prime minister. Ms. Tymoshenko is already serving a seven-year sentence on charges that have been condemned in the West as politically motivated. The reopened case, which dates back 15 years to her tenure as head of United Energy Systems of Ukraine, alleges that she embezzled about $3 million from the federal budget and evaded paying about $2.5 million in taxes. The case was closed in 2005, after Ms. Tymoshenko became prime minister. The announcement further dims hopes that she will be released and allowed to take part in 2012 parliamentary elections, which European leaders have said is a precondition for completing free trade and association agreements between Ukraine and the European Union.

headline: Trading Company Will Pay $1 Million to Settle S.E.C. Case
text: Pipeline Trading Systems, an alternative trading platform, will pay $1 million to resolve regulatory claims that it failed to provide the confidentiality and liquidity it advertised to customers.

headline: Live Analysis of World Series Game 5: Rangers 4, Cardinals 2
text: Their swagger was undeniable, their energy inexhaustible. And how confident must the Texas Rangers feel after taking down the St. Louis Cardinals with a two-run eighth inning that gave them a 4-2 victory Monday night in Game 5 of the World Series.

headline: Russia: Questions for Ex-Mayor
text: Yuri M. Luzhkov, Moscow’s former mayor, said Monday that he had been summoned for questioning in an embezzlement investigation of the Bank of Moscow, which is suspected of illegally funneling money into his wife’s personal accounts. Mr. Luzhkov, who was fired last year after running afoul of the Kremlin, told the Interfax news agency that he was being singled out for criticizing the authorities in a recent radio interview. Investigators have accused the bank’s former chief executive of illegally issuing a loan of more than $400 million to a shell company linked to Mr. Luzhkov’s wife. The couple, who are currently outside Russia, have denied any wrongdoing, and no charges have been filed against them.

headline: The Entry Count and the Drawing
text: SPECIAL POST — Many readers have asked about the number of entries received in Patrick Berry’s “Crossing” Words Contest and how the drawing was to be made. I don’t know if this is some sort of record for a puzzle contest, but I was impressed not only by the sheer volume of entries but by how smart you all are. Approximately 96% percent of you submitted the correct answer, so pat yourselves on the back for outwitting Mr. Berry.

headline: Declining to Criticize, IndyCar Drivers Discuss Safety With Top Racing Officials
text: As an IndyCar Series investigation continued into Dan Wheldon’s fatal accident Oct. 16 at Las Vegas, series officials met for three hours Monday with about two dozen drivers in Indianapolis to discuss ways to avoid catastrophic crashes.

headline: Drilling in Fast-Growing Areas Ushers in New Era of Tension
text: DENVER — The pattern is clear in the oil and gas business: drilling fields are going into new places. North Dakota, better known for growing wheat, is now booming with rigs. Fort Worth has upward of 2,000 gas wells right in the city itself, with most of that growth within just the last five years. Pittsburgh, facing the prospect of urban drilling, forbade it last year by a vote of the City Council.

headline: Herbert A. Hauptman, Nobel Laureate, Dies at 94
text: Herbert A. Hauptman, a mathematician who shared the 1985 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with the chemist Jerome Karle for their development of revolutionary methods for determining the structure of molecules vital to life, died on Sunday in Buffalo. He was 94.

headline: Playing the New Bjork Album, and Playing Along, With Apps
text: Since Thomas Edison invented the phonograph, there has been only one way to listen to recorded music: Listen to it. That is, to consume passively a precise sequence of sounds exactly as they have been arranged. But what if, in addition to songs, a musician provided intuitive, creative tools that let you control the basic components of the music itself? What if the musician joined with programmers and visual artists to turn the songs into encompassing interactive experiences? What if listeners were to become participants?

headline: Bigger Grants for Athletes Are Discussed

headline: U.S. Pivots Eastward to Address Uneasy Allies
text: YOKOTA AIR BASE, Japan — China was never mentioned, but when a sailor in the Japanese Navy asked Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta here on Monday whether the United States planned to cut back its forces in Asia, Mr. Panetta knew exactly what he meant.

headline: Pennsylvania: Governor Declares Emergency
text: Gov. Tom Corbett on Monday declared a fiscal emergency in Harrisburg, which allows him to assume financial control of the city and name the state’s first municipal receiver. Empowered by legislation he signed on Thursday, Mr. Corbett, left, said the capital city’s fiscal distress warranted such action. The Harrisburg City Council’s “failure to enact a recovery plan in order to deal with the city’s distressed finances has led me to declare a fiscal emergency,” Mr. Corbett, a Republican, said in a news release. “This action ensures that vital services will continue and public safety will be protected.” Mr. Corbett can now direct city and state officials to comply with his plan to ensure that debt obligations and payroll expenses are met. A receiver can be named in 30 days if officials fail to devise a full recovery plan that is acceptable to the state. This month, Harrisburg became the first state capital in at least 40 years to file for bankruptcy protection.

headline: Custody Deal for 2 Families After Killing
text: The two families fighting for custody of two young boys whose mother was killed in New Jersey this summer will share the children for now, according to a temporary agreement approved on Monday by a Family Court judge in Brooklyn.

Over time, one aide said, the binder grew to resemble the Manhattan White Pages.

headline: Turkey’s Struggles to Avoid Recession
text: The human cost of this week’s earthquake comes as Turkey fights to keep its once-booming economy on track. Ankara is playing a high-risk game by intervening in markets to shore up its currency and lacks the reserves to do so. Turkey will struggle to avoid adopting higher interest rates to shore up its currency, the lira, even though that may push a previously overheating economy toward recession.

headline: One Win for the Forests

The timber industry, off-road vehicle users and other commercial and political interests have long battled the rule, which will establish essential protections for the forests and the clean water, wildlife habitat and recreational opportunities they provide.

headline: The Purchase by Blood

Henry Sturgis Russell is captured because he has stayed to tend the wounds of his friend, Maj. James Savage. But once in Confederate hands the two are parted: Russell is exchanged while Savage begins the slow decline that will end in his lonely death at the hands of incompetent surgeons in a Confederate hospital.

headline: U.S. Agencies Infiltrating Drug Cartels Across Mexico

headline: The Biographer’s Dilemma

I had read the latter biography when it came out in 2003, and I remembered it fondly. I was trying to figure out why “Steve Jobs,” despite being full of new information about the most compelling businessman of the modern era, was leaving me cold.

headline: On the Road to Relief
text: At long last, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-run mortgage companies, have issued new rules to allow millions of underwater borrowers, who are current on their payments, to refinance their high-rate mortgages into lower-rate loans. President Obama, who pushed for the changes, rightly emphasized the benefits in a speech on Monday in Las Vegas, a city ravaged by foreclosures. Refinancings will lower monthly payments, reduce the likelihood of default and boost consumer spending.

headline: From Brooklyn Office, Mixing Clout and Charity

headline: Woman Sentenced in Effort to Smuggle Scopes to Russia

headline: Numberplay: From Sledgehammer to Scalpel
text: A few weeks ago, we celebrated the Rubik’s Cube. One of the things that I find fascinating about the Rubik’s Cube is that, even though a single move changes the position of 8 cubies, you can string together a series of moves such that you can change the orientations of exactly 2 cubies (the quarks and anti-quarks we mentioned), leaving the rest of the cube completely unchanged. Even though we move an ensemble of eight different cubies at a time, we are able to precisely cancel the motion of all of the other cubies we moved, and hone in with surgical precision on the two we are interested in. Using sledgehammer moves, we are able to create a scalpel!

headline: While Veterans Wait
text: The Veterans Affairs Department has devoted much effort and money to improve and expand its mental health care, especially for those coming home from Iraq and Afghanistan with post-traumatic stress disorder and brain injuries. But continuing reports of drug dependency, suicides and suicide attempts among veterans and active-duty soldiers suggest that urgent needs remain vast and unmet. So do persistent accounts from veterans who say they spend months waiting for mental health care.

headline: From a Farm Stand, New and Old Insights
