headline: In Week 7, Passing Defenses Continue to Show Pop
text: Last week, I wrote that the monster passing numbers from the first five weeks took a serious body blow in Week 6, evidenced by a huge decline in passing touchdowns. The knockout punch was delivered in Week 7. After teams averaged over 240 passing yards per game through the first six weeks of the season, the 26 teams playing in Week 7 combined for only 4,997 passing yards this past weekend, a paltry 191 yards per game. Nowhere was this more evident — on Sunday — than in Cleveland, as the Seahawks and Browns put on a pitiful display. The Browns and Seahawks combined for 435 yards and 9 points. It was the worst display of offense in a game not affected by severe weather in over a decade. The Colt McCoy pass attempt watch marches on: he threw 35 passes in a game in which the Browns allowed only 137 yards and 3 points.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Reassessing the Role of Mammograms
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Flood Defenses Are Overrun in Bangkok
text: BANGKOK — Bangkok’s flood defenses continued to fall on Wednesday as floodwaters pressed farther into the city after forcing the closing of the domestic airport. Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra warned that there could be as much as five feet of flooding in some areas.

headline: NATO to Lead on Libya Ties, Panetta Says
text: TOKYO — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta declined on Tuesday to say whether the United States would have a future military relationship with Libya and instead said he would take cues from allies in Europe.

headline: Credit, Blame and a Heaping Cup of Coincidence
text: As an old Roman might have said, post hoc ergo propter hoc.

headline: Virus Infects Computers in Japan’s Parliament
text: TOKYO — Computers in Japan’s Parliament have been found to be infected with a virus, officials said on Tuesday, the latest in a series of mysterious cyberattacks that have raised concerns about the leakage of sensitive information.

headline: Very Serious Europeans
text: From today’s FT:

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Groupon’s Latest Valuation Raises Doubt | Back in 1999, Barron’s ran an article that was a virtual indictment of Amazon. It questioned the company’s ability ever to turn a profit, argued that Amazon was spending far too much money on marketing and suggested that the company was using misleading accounting metrics.

headline: Amazon, Hot and Cold
text: After the close of the stock market Tuesday, Amazon.com will announce its third-quarter results. Analysts are predicting yet another revenue blowout, up 44 percent compared with last year. Amazon’s torrid growth more than 15 years after its founding makes it an object of envy and fear across the retail world. It is now a $100 billion company, about 12 times the value of Sears.

headline: Now Viewing | Cecil Beaton’s New York
text: What was Manhattan for the wildly ambitious, talented and tirelessly self-promoting 24-year-old Cecil Beaton, but a candy box of opportunities, just waiting to be picked? And pick them he did, over the course of some five decades, in a peripatetic career that saw him cross-pollinating the social and cultural elites of the Old and New Worlds, and applying his protean gifts to everything from fashion photography and portraiture to illustration to stage and costume design. “Cecil Beaton: The New York Years,” curated by Donald Albrecht and opening today at the Museum of the City of New York, includes vintage fashion prints and a wide range of portraits, from Marilyn Monroe (cajoled into relaxation in Beaton’s Ambassador Hotel suite) to the very young Mick Jagger to Wallis Simpson and the aging Greta Garbo (one of the photographer’s rare heterosexual liaisons). Together with drawings, theatrical designs and other ephemera, they illuminate this English dandy’s astonishingly productive and long-lasting engagement with the booming cultural metropolis that was Manhattan at midcentury.

headline: ArcelorMittal Backs Out of Bid for Macarthur Coal
text: ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel manufacturer, announced on Tuesday that it was pulling out of a $4.9 billion joint bid with Peabody Energy to acquire Macarthur Coal of Australia.

headline: Very Serious Americans
text: Digby finds Paul Ryan, winner of an award for fiscal responsibility, saying, well, something:

headline: As Newark High-Rise Loses Aid, Fear Sweeps Through Its Tenants
text: When it opened in 1971, Carmel Towers in Newark was a model of the sort of high-rise urban development that the federal government was encouraging through generous subsidies. Now, federal officials are cutting off financial aid to the building’s landlord, leaving hundreds of residents fearing that they could soon be evicted.

headline: 10 Questions for Rick Perry
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is seeking to jump-start his Republican presidential campaign by proposing a new tax system: a 20 percent flat rate on individual and corporate income, down from the current 35 percent top rate, and elimination of existing taxes on estates, capital gains and dividends. He sat down with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC to discuss the plan, his challenge to a Republican rival, Mitt Romney, and other issues. What follows is a condensed, edited transcript of their conversation.

headline: Irish Reality Check
text: There have been a number of articles and blog posts lately claiming that Ireland is over the hump, that it’s all coming right; see for example this recent piece by Henry Kaspar. But I was checking to see if it was still true that Icelandic CDS prices — the cost of insuring against default — were much lower than Ireland’s. And given what we’ve been hearing, the Irish CDS story comes as something of a shock:

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Guardian: Jamie Oliver, a.k.a. Sisyphus, is growing concerned that the British government is backsliding on its commitment to better school lunches.— Jeff Gordinier

headline: Stocks Close Sharply Lower on News From Europe
text: Stocks in the United States and Europe sank Tuesday as the markets got another jolt from the European Union — this time the abrupt cancellation of a meeting of finance ministers that was meant to precede a leaders’ summit meeting on Wednesday.

headline: Online Account Opening Isn’t as Easy as It Looks
text: If you’ve ever tried — and failed — to open and fund an online checking account, you’re not alone. A new report from Javelin Strategy & Research finds that only a little more than half of consumers who try to do so are successful.

headline: Shakespeare Trust Hides Playwright’s Name to Protest ‘Anonymous’
text: The Shakespeare Birthplace Trust had no apparent problems with Roland Emmerich‘s previous movies about genocidal space aliens, apocalyptic solar flares and life in prehistoric times. But when Mr. Emmerich messed with Shakespeare, that’s where the trust drew the line – right through the name of the playwright it is set up to protect.

headline: Playtime With Cats, at Any Distance
text: While visiting her mother in Pennsylvania this month, Lauren Pytel, a 47-year-old high school English teacher who lives in Tudor City, found herself pining for her cats, Tiggles ap Caduet and Munchie Effexorov, and their recently deceased siblings, Claritin and Zoloft.

headline: Leading Off: Calling All Geniuses
text: If nothing else, Game 5 of the World Series makes us want to hit the pause button on baseball history. Because even if you know only a little about the game, you know Tony La Russa is supposed to be a genius. He will tell you that himself. Baseball announcers will tell you. Over and over and over. Isn’t it written in the rule book, right there with three strikes and you’re out? The old skit was “Who’s on first, what’s on second and Tony La Russa is a genius,” wasn’t it?

headline: Conran’s Long Run
text: The British design doyen Sir Terence Conran is showing signs of his 80 years. He sits in one of the Finnish designer Yrjo Kukkapuro’s Karuselli chairs not just because it’s a design classic, but also because its curves soothe his bones. “I have a fairly bad back,” he admits. But don’t make the mistake of assuming that his retrospective exhibition, “Terence Conran: The Way We Live Now,” at the Design Museum in London from Nov. 16 through March 4, 2012, is a swan song.

headline: In the Arctic, a Debate Over New Resources and Old
text: Shell Oil has received preliminary permits to drill exploratory wells off the coast of Alaska as soon as next summer, but its rigs would work in age-old whale-hunting grounds.

headline: Banks Face Pressure on Eve of Meeting on Debt Crisis
text: BRUSSELS — European officials scrambled on Tuesday for a way to entice banks to accept much deeper losses on their Greek bonds as debt crisis talks went down to the wire before a crucial gathering of European leaders on Wednesday.

headline: After Leaving Football, a Historian Emerges as an N.C.A.A. Critic
text: When Taylor Branch and his wife, Christy, exchanged vows in 1978, Branch had to do more than promise to remain faithful through sickness and health:  he also had to give up football.

headline: House Writes a Bill to Excuse U.S. Carriers
text: One of the stranger bills to be considered by Congress passed by a voice vote on Monday evening. Officially named the European Union Emissions Trading Scheme Prohibition Act of 2011, it essentially tells American airline carriers that it is illegal for them to participate in the European Union’s cap and trade system, which charges companies for producing emissions beyond their allotted limit.

headline: Arctic Village Is Torn by Plan for Oil Drilling
text: POINT HOPE, Alaska — He once hurled harpoons at whales, but on this platinum afternoon beside the Arctic Ocean he swung a 5-iron at a frustrating little ball.

headline: Cain Campaign Says Video Is Authentic
text: Has the first viral video of the campaign season come from the Herman Cain camp?

headline: An Unnecessary Measles Outbreak
text: In a typical year, the Centers for Disease Control sees 60 to 70 cases of measles. As of Oct. 14, it had tracked 214 cases — the worst figure in 15 years.

headline: Perry’s Emphasis on Birther Issue: A Wink at the Right?
text: Rick Perry appears determined to make doubts about President Obama‘s birthplace an issue again in the Republican primary campaign even though Mr. Obama produced his long-form birth certificate months ago.

headline: Wheelies: The Growth Hormone Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Q. and A. With Toby Keith
text: Toby Keith has mellowed somewhat since the turbulent days after Sept. 11, 2001, when he became most known for his jingoistic songs supporting the troops in Iraq and Afghanistan. On recent albums he has shied away from patriotic material in favor of more soulful ballads, along with the well-made songs he has always produced about drinking, chasing girls, breaking up and living hard.

headline: Yet Another Attempt to Waylay the Enterprise
text: The governor of Washington has joined the ranks of elected officials trying to steer a space shuttle away from New York City — if only temporarily.

headline: Qaddafi, Son and Former Defense Aide Buried in Secret Place
text: MISURATA, Libya — After four days on public display in a meat locker here, the slowly decomposing corpses of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, one of his sons and his former defense minister were buried in a predawn funeral at a secret location on Tuesday, a top military official said.

headline: Spooky Sketches | Peter Som
text: T challenges 10 designers to turn everyday objects into killer Halloween costumes.

headline: They (Still) Can’t Go Home Again
text: In late September, residents of 5 of the 17 apartments at the idyllic Villa Charlotte Brontë cooperative in the Bronx were waiting for permission to go home after Tropical Storm Irene caused a landslide at the building.

headline: W. Virginia Is Close to Joining the Big 12
text: Big East football is at a critical crossroads. When West Virginia’s departure to the Big 12 becomes official, the conference will have only five teams, including one original member, Rutgers. What happens over the next week will determine whether the league will survive or divide.

headline: Rick Perry and the 'Birther' Movement
text: In an interview, Mr. Perry insisted that he is not certain that Mr. Obama was born in the United States, linking himself to the so-called "birther" movement.

headline: India's First Formula One Track
text: Race fans got a preview of India’s first Formula One track — the Buddh International Circuit outside Delhi- which opens officially at the end of October.

headline: On Our Radar: Nebraska Lawmakers Will Meet on Keystone
text: Gov. Dave Heineman of Nebraska calls a special session of the state legislature to address growing concerns over the proposed Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry tar sands oil across one of the Midwest’s most important aquifers. [The Los Angeles Times]

headline: MTV Basics: Top Minimalist Videos
text: Chuck Klosterman’s excellent memoir “Fargo Rock City” almost convinced me that I missed something by not caring about hair metal. But when it came to my own MTV viewing habits, I was always a minimalist – give me a concert clip, or even a bit of straight-on lip syncing to a good song, like this clip of Stevie Nicks and Tom Petty trading verses on the indelible “Stop Draggin’ My Heart Around.”

headline: John Harwood Interviews Rick Perry
text: Presidential candidate Rick Perry sat down with John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC to discuss his plan for a 20 percent flat rate on individual and corporate income.

headline: Panel Endorses HPV Vaccine for Boys of 11
text: Boys and young men should be vaccinated against human papillomavirus, or HPV, to protect against anal and throat cancers that can result from sexual activity, a federal advisory committee said Tuesday.

headline: M.L.S. Playoffs Still Foreign to Red Bulls Star
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — There are many things Thierry Henry has come to terms with since joining the Red Bulls from Barcelona last year. But Major League Soccer’s playoff system will never be one of them.

headline: Becoming Gaga and Minaj
text: Stephanie Rosenbloom and Simone Oliver get help from Patricia Field to put together a fashionable Halloween costume.

headline: ‘Carlin Street’ Resisted by His Old Church. Was It Something He Said?
text: Before the dirty words came the classroom pranks. The petty theft of subway riders’ fedoras. The visions of sneaking into confessional and acting as de facto priest for a day.

headline: Embracing the Pop Star in Your Closet
text: WHEN New Yorkers want Halloween costumes with sartorial flair, they skip costume shops and drugstores and head instead to the Patricia Field boutique in the Bowery, where glitter wigs and bondage pants are the everyday garb of Ms. Field’s regular customers.

headline: Charging Your Devices Through Solar Power
text: Companies have offered dozens of products that are supposed to let you charge a mobile device through solar power. But most have failed dismally. Some take too long to charge even a single battery, while others come with tedious connectors and wires.

headline: The Crisis in Long-Term Care
text: The apparent demise of the Class Act leaves many middle-income Americans struggling to cope with rising expenses for long-term care for family members, The Times reported on Tuesday.

headline: N.C.A.A.’s Grant Hike Proposal: Fair or Foul?
text: With Mark Emmert, the N.C.A.A. president, coming out in favor of increasing athlete grants by $2,000, have we finally started working through the issue of student-athletes being compensated for playing college sports? Or is it the opening of Pandora’s box, deepening the competitive gulf between the larger, richer schools and the smaller, less cash-rich ones?

headline: Space Invaders | Skateboarding and Post-Minimalism
text: What do skateboarding and post-minimalist art have in common? More than you might guess, as will be revealed at the Emily Harvey Foundation in SoHo when Redmond Entwistle’s “Monuments” (2009) and Raphael Zarka’s “Species of Spaces in Skateboarding” (2008) screen together this week. These two short films individually examine two seemingly disparate subjects and their respective influences on public space in 1960s and ’70s American suburbia.

headline: A Photographic Call to Action
text: When Clyde Butcher first began exploring the Everglades in 1984, “there was virtually nothing to photograph — it was one big ditch,” he says. A century of destructive intrusions like artificial canals, levees, pumps and spillways had left the swamps in a fragile and broken state.

headline: Japanese Brands Dominate Consumer Reports Reliability Survey, While Ford Falls 10 Spots
text: Japanese automakers continue to produce the most reliable passenger vehicles on the market, according to consumer data collected by Consumer Reports.

headline: Images From the Infield in Game 5
text: Mike Tanier will provide Bats with updates on less than important developments from the World Series.

headline: Iraqis Enjoy a Show With a Familiar Ring, but a Few Differences
text: BAGHDAD — The circus promoters blanketed Baghdad with fliers that showed tigers balancing on pedestals, poodles standing on each other’s shoulders and a woman dancing with a massive snake.

headline: The Circus Comes to Baghdad
text: Promises of tigers and a massive snake aside didn’t come to fruition, but cotton candy, sword swallowing and clowns are still drawing crowds.

headline: Why It’s Good for Romney to Be at 21 Percent
text: He’s the establishment favorite, the guy who’s run before, the clear winner in most debates. He seems eminently electable. So why can’t Mitt Romney close the deal with Republican voters?

headline: Say Anything
text: Over the last couple of days, I’ve been getting mail accusing me of consorting with Nazis. My immediate reaction was, what the heck? Then it clicked: the right wing is mounting a full-court press to portray Occupy Wall Street as an anti-Semitic movement, based, as far as I can tell, on one guy with a sign.

headline: Lemon Makes Digital Copies of Paper Receipts
text: If you’re like me, receipts seem to multiply in your wallet, balling up or shredding and generally making a mess, until I throw them away in annoyance. A new smartphone app called Lemon aims to address that problem, by making digital copies of your receipts and organizing them in handy files.

headline: Morgan Stanley Forms New Bank Advisory Team
text: Morgan Stanley has formed a new team focused on advising banks worldwide on capital and financing issues, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

headline: Perry Calls His Flat Tax Proposal ‘Bold Reform’
text: GRAY COURT, S.C. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas unveiled a plan on Tuesday to scrap the graduated income tax and replace it with a 20 percent flat rate. By throwing out  rates as high as 35 percent and eliminating estate and investment taxes, the plan would grant a major tax cut for the wealthy. It is the centerpiece of an ambitious proposal that aims to overhaul political sacred cows like Social Security and Medicare while slashing the federal budget.

headline: Obama Taps Into Hollywood in West Coast Swing
text: LOS ANGELES — With a morning taping of NBC’s “The Tonight Show” on Tuesday, President Obama makes his fourth appearance on the couch opposite the host Jay Leno, in between mining for California gold at fund-raisers in Los Angeles and San Francisco.

headline: Syrian Opposition Calls for Protection from Crackdown
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Syrian opposition group called on Tuesday for international protection from the government’s military crackdown on protesters, a day before an Arab delegation was scheduled to arrive in Syria in an effort to resolve seven months of unrest in the country.

headline: Perry Offers Plan to ‘Save Social Security’
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Tuesday offered his most detailed response yet to criticism that he views Social Security as a Ponzi scheme, spelling out changes to the federal retirement program that he said would “save Social Security for future generations.”

headline: The Real Scare Is Not Being Scary
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Chainsaws? Yawn. Bathtub electrocutions? Done them. Demented, blood-thirsty clowns? So 2001.

headline: A New Look for Aquavit
text: Hakan Swahn and his partner, the chef Marcus Jernmark, have reconfigured their Nordic restaurant, Aquavit. What was the cafe area in the front is now the main restaurant, and though the furnishings include Swedish classics like Arne Jacobsen chairs, it is less formal than the previous dining room, which was in the back and is now for private parties. There are four- and seven-course prix-fixe menus for dinner, à la carte or three courses at lunch. Traditional Swedish specialties like herring dishes will now be served from late afternoon through evening in the bar and lounge.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Computers in School?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Design Bookshelf | ‘Brilliant’
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Hey Chef! Get with the Program
text: I’ve known George Faison for 25 years or more; he was a co-founder of D’Artagnan and is now a co-owner of Debragga and Spitler, a New York meat wholesaler that’s been doing business since 1924, and a main supplier to many of the city’s best restaurants. This is a letter George sent late last week to a well-known chef, and one he’ll be sending to others. (It’s worth noting, if for no other reason than to answer the inevitable question, which I asked myself, that George doesn’t only sell naturally-raised meats – he sells industrially-produced stuff as well. But he’s on a campaign to persuade the chefs who insist that’s what they want to change their minds, and I know he’d like to supply only the right stuff.) I’ve changed nothing except misspellings.

headline: Iran Makes New Arrests in Fraud Case
text: The Iranian authorities have widened their investigation into what they say is a record $2.6 billion embezzlement uncovered in a network of Iranian banks last month, interrogating at least 67 people and putting 31 of them under arrest, state media reported.

headline: Archive Offers Rare Look Into Hussein’s Private Ruminations
text: During the 2003 invasion of Iraq, United States forces captured a voluminous archive of documents and recorded meetings that now offer a window into the private world of Saddam Hussein.

headline: Tax Deal Lures NBC Sports to Connecticut
text: NBC and the governor of Connecticut, Dannel P. Malloy, made it official on Tuesday — much of NBC’s sports operation will move to Stamford.

headline: Wall St. Giants Seek a Piece of Nigeria’s Sovereign Fund
text: Wanted: A reliable overseas business partner to invest more than $1 billion presently trapped in Nigeria.

headline: Plan for a New York Area Formula One Race Announced in New Jersey
text: 3:00 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Village Divided
text: A plan to begin offshore drilling next year could change the way of life for the Inupiat Eskimos of Point Hope, Alaska.

headline: Meetings With North Koreans End Without Date for Talks
text: GENEVA — United States and North Korean officials emerged from two days of meetings here agreeing they had narrowed their differences about negotiating on the North’s nuclear program, but they parted without fixing a date for further bilateral or multilateral talks.

headline: Hero of New Starz Series Is Leonardo da Vinci, International Man of Mystery
text: The real-life Leonardo da Vinci had no extraordinary powers, other than a first-class intellect, unparalleled artistic skills and the ability to make millions of dollars for Dan Brown a few centuries down the road. But to the Starz cable channel Leonardo is enough of a champion to feature in a new series that was announced on Tuesday and which is being created for the channel by a writer with some serious superhero credentials.

headline: Papers From Iraqi Archive Reveal Conspiratorial Mind-Set of Hussein
text: WASHINGTON — On Nov. 15, 1986, Saddam Hussein gathered his most senior aides for an important strategy session. Two days earlier, President Ronald Reagan had acknowledged in a televised address that his administration had sent weapons and spare parts to Iran.

headline: It’s a No-Brainer: AMC Orders Third Season of ‘The Walking Dead’
text: After a recent episode of “The Walking Dead” that vividly revealed the contents of a zombie’s stomach, AMC has decided it still has a healthy appetite for that popular series about the survivors of an undead apocalypse.

headline: UBS Fined $12 Million Over Short-Selling
text: 3:00 p.m. | Updated

headline: F.T.C.: 28 ‘Pay-for-Delay’ Generic Drug Deals
text: Updated: 5:30 p.m. Drug companies negotiated 28 potential “pay-for-delay” deals that slowed the marketing of cheaper generic drugs in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, the Federal Trade Commission said Tuesday in a staff report.

headline: Chris Cipollone, Citing Low Pay, Leaves Tenpenny for a New Job
text: Chris Cipollone, the chef at Tenpenny  in the Gotham Hotel in Midtown, has left.

headline: Vain Glorious | Halloween Makeup
text: Halloween is nigh, and the big question for those who dare to dress up is should one go pretty or ghoulish? This year, Lydia Hearst is going to be a scary zombie, the D.J. Chelsea Leyland is going as a “hot and sexy” black swan and Katrina Bowden (“30 Rock”) will be a pretty Tinker Bell. Stylists are expecting requests for ever-glamorous Veronica Lake Hollywood curls, period finger waves and messy Amy Winehouse beehives.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 39
text: A Pew survey found that 39 percent of Americans support Occupy Wall Street, slightly higher than the number who oppose it, and that a higher number — 44 percent — oppose the Tea Party. [Pew Research Center]

headline: The Monograms Meet: O Sits Down With RL
text: Oprah Winfrey interviews Ralph Lauren, in front of a celebrity audience.

headline: O and RL: Monograms Meet
text: THERE was no time allotted for audience questions during “An Evening With Ralph Lauren.”

headline: ‘Two and a Half Men’ Bounces Back
text: After enduring a month of steep drops following its huge season-premiere numbers, “Two and a Half Men” on CBS finally changed course on Monday night, reaching 15.4 million total viewers and posting a 6 percent increase in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic compared to last week. ABC had the most viewers for the night over all thanks to “Dancing With the Stars,” which averaged nearly 17 million total viewers over two hours.

headline: Epstein Takes Over Cubs, With Another Streak to End
text: CHICAGO — Without playing an inning, Theo Epstein rose to a level approaching Ted Williams and Carl Yastrzemski as a Boston baseball hero after delivering two World Series titles in nine years as general manager of the formerly luckless, supposedly cursed Red Sox.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 25
text: A view of the day in sports includes the strain of weightlifting, cricket celebration and an early Olympic peek.

headline: Tempers Flare as European Meeting Nears
text: PARIS — Europeans may be on edge about Wednesday’s summit meeting in Brussels on the euro crisis, but so are their leaders and their tempers.

headline: Bay Area’s Big Names Come Out for Mayor Lee
text: Every now and then in politics, you come across something you just have to watch, and this is one of them.

headline: LENS:BANKERS
text: LENS:BANKERS

headline: Help Wanted? Debating Unemployment Legislation
text: Overview | How is unemployment affecting the United States? What can be done to address the high rate of joblessness? Which steps should the federal government take, and which should it avoid? In this lesson, students explore arguments for and against the enactment of proposed legislation and hold a debate.

headline: Too Legit to Watch
text: Here’s a dose of politics, Silicon Valley style. Two investors, Ron Conway and Sean Parker, have teamed up to finance a promotional video for a San Francisco mayoral candidate, Ed Lee, reports TechCrunch. The two-minute video, a remake of M.C. Hammer’s 1991 song “Too Legit to Quit,” stars Twitter’s co-founder, Biz Stone; a Google executive, Marissa Mayer; Will.i.am of the Black Eyed Peas; and yes, Mr. Hammer. Read more »

headline: Wind, Sand and Starlings at Yanaba Island
text: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

headline: Quaintness Tucked Between Brooklyn Housing Projects
text: New York is famously a city of contrasts: old frame houses butt up against new construction, ethnicities commingle on the subway, the moneyed live in view of the poor. This week the Appraisal takes stock of a Brooklyn street where this is particularly true: Warren between Nevins and Bond in Boerum Hill, where town houses are bookended by two public housing projects in a neighborhood where property values have risen sharply over the years.

headline: Spooky Sketches | Ports 1961
text: T challenges 10 designers to turn everyday objects into killer Halloween costumes.

headline: U.S. Parts Smuggled to Iran for Iraq Bombs, Charges Say
text: WASHINGTON — Electronic parts made in Minnesota were smuggled through Singapore to Iran, and some of them ended up in the remote controls of makeshift bombs seized by American forces in Iraq, the Justice Department said on Tuesday.

headline: Are Apps for 3-Year-Olds Really Educational?
text: Is it delusional to think that apps for very young children are really educational?

headline: Netflix Market Value Shrivels
text: In July, Netflix’s market value was over $16 billion. On Tuesday, after a bruising response to the financial results the company released late Monday, the Internet movie company lost more than $2 billion in value, bringing its total market capitalization to just over $4 billion.

headline: TimesCast |October 25, 2011
text: New York City police officers are arrested for smuggling guns; European Union finance ministers abruptly cancel their meeting; and the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on Tunisia's Islamic party.

headline: Broadway Recruits Nick Jonas to Boost Kids’ Night Attendance
text: To help increase ticket sales for its annual Kids’ Night on Broadway, New York theater owners and producers have recruited a former Broadway kid himself, pop idol Nick Jonas, as the 2012 spokesman for the five-day program in February. The 19-year-old Mr. Jonas appeared on Broadway as a boy in “Les Misérables,” “Beauty and the Beast” and “Annie Get Your Gun” before achieving pinup status as a member of the Jonas Brothers band, and on Jan. 24 he will take over the lead role of J. Pierrepont Finch in the Broadway revival of “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.”

headline: Eric Asimov Is the Interim Restaurant Critic
text: While we wait for the puffs of white smoke that will issue from the chimney atop 620 Eighth Avenue when The Times names its next restaurant critic, the weekly reviews will be written by Eric Asimov. This week he takes on Salinas, in Chelsea, which is worth two stars in his book.

headline: Spain Without the Hocus-Pocus
text: EVER since the center of culinary innovation shifted to Spain with the ascent of El Bulli and other like-minded restaurants, New York has been awaiting its own specimen of contemporary Spanish gastronomy. For some reason, it hasn’t happened, at least, not entirely successfully.

headline: Reviewing Salinas
text: Yes, I’ve got myself some temp work here as the process of selecting the next restaurant critic unfolds. This week, I’m reviewing Salinas, one of a series of good Spanish restaurants to have opened in recent years.

headline: Flood Waters Free Crocodiles in Thailand
text: First it was Bengal tigers in Ohio. Now it’s crocodiles in Bangkok that have broken loose and are menacing the local population.

headline: I.B.M. Names Virginia Rometty as New Chief Executive
text: Virginia M. Rometty, a senior vice president at I.B.M., will be the company’s next chief executive, the directors announced on Tuesday. She will succeed Samuel J. Palmisano, 60, who will remain as chairman, at the start of next year.

headline: Uniqlo Alights on Fifth Avenue
text: THERE may be nothing new under the sun, but does this excuse fashion designers’ endless plunder of the past and what the late raconteur Quentin Crisp once dismissed, with an audible curl of the lip, as “decade-ism”? This season, the 1970s are back, as they have been repeatedly since the ’90s; in the ’70s people were wild for the ’30s, so if you participate in what some are calling a ’90s revival, you are in fact piling on more than 50 years of influences and references. It seems rather ... bloated, doesn’t it?

headline: Even Against Series, Viewers Flock to the N.F.L.
text: 6:15 p.m. | Updated If Major League Baseball truly wants to make an argument about still being America’s pastime after this year’s World Series, it will need some real voodoo mathematics.

headline: An Influence And Songs That Grow On You
text: The music of Kenny Wheeler doesn’t really clamor for attention. Mr. Wheeler, a quietly influential jazz trumpeter originally from Canada but living in Britain for nearly 60 years, favors graceful melody and intuitive harmony, avoiding the trappings of needless flourish and easy friction. His songs — for that’s usually what they are, solid and hummable — tend to be meticulous in their construction but free of visible effort, in the manner of fine haberdashery or good industrial design.

headline: This Time Dido’s Lament Streams Forth From a Burly Man
text: The countertenor voice is not necessarily something you want to hear in quantity. True, the ability to produce and project a falsetto sound of consistent quality is remarkable. But it is the rare countertenor who commands a wide variety of tone colors or, for that matter, even gets very far into the plural.

headline: Congressman Objects to Chinese Diplomacy
text: Lawyers for the Justice Department have declared that President Obama has the constitutional power to override a statute forbidding members of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy from engaging in activities with Chinese officials.

headline: The Grand Concourse Gets Its Due
text: The city gave an Art Deco-filled stretch of the Grand Concourse in the Bronx — along with an artists’ housing complex in the West Village, a church-turned-synagogue-turned-theater in Brooklyn and a Staten Island cottage — landmark protection on Tuesday.

headline: It’s Still a Renter’s Market, Office Landlords Learn
text: Last February, Bloomberg L.P. signed a 400,000-square-foot lease at 120 Park Avenue. Wells Fargo had originally scouted the space, but Bloomberg offered a higher rent, making one of this year’s biggest office deals. It was a sign, commercial real estate brokers said, that the Manhattan office market was tilting in landlords’ favor again.

headline: Amazon Suffers Big Drop in Income
text: Investors shrugged off Amazon’s warnings this summer that its third quarter would be weak.

headline: 8 City Officers Charged in Gun Smuggling Case
text: Eight current and former New York police officers were arrested on Tuesday and charged in federal court with accepting thousands of dollars in cash to drive a caravan of firearms into the state, an act of corruption that brazenly defied the city’s strenuous efforts to get illegal guns off the streets.

headline: Romney Taps a Virginia Suburb for Cash
text: Mitt Romney is coming to Virginia on Wednesday for a pep talk at the Northern Virginia Republican headquarters.

headline: Yemen’s Embattled Government Calls Cease-Fire That So Far Fails to End Violence
text: SANA, Yemen — The northern part of the capital city has turned into a virtual war zone in recent days, and even as the government announced a cease-fire on Tuesday, explosions boomed across the city.

headline: A Rock Star, a Lawyer and a Hotel Hand Walk Into a Magazine
text: Now we are copy editors, designers, researchers, editorial assistants, photo editors. But some people at this magazine led strange past lives. One was an indie-rock bassist, one was a lawyer, another was a Canadian.  Now Mark van de Walle, a researcher here, has written about his past life as a hotel hand/amanuensis at the Paris Review:

headline: Tenth Tibetan Reported to Self-Immolate in Anti-China Protest
text: A Tibetan monk in western China’s Sichuan province set himself on fire on Tuesday to express opposition to China’s Tibet policies, becoming the 10th Tibetan this year to self-immolate as a form of political protest, an outside advocacy group reported.

headline: Americans’ Approval of Congress Drops to Single Digits
text: Americans’ approval of Congress reach single digit for the first time in history.

headline: Michael Laiskonis Will Be Moving on From Le Bernardin
text: Michael Laiskonis (shown), who has been the pastry chef at Le Bernardin for nearly eight years, will leave by Jan. 1 to pursue other ventures, including writing a book and teaching.

headline: Look of The Moment | Camilla Belle
text: The Look: Deco Darling. A shocking pink lip, slicked hair and diamond chandelier earrings are natural pairings for a beaded evening dress inspired by Art Deco architecture.

headline: 3 Aid Workers Kidnapped in Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — An American aid worker and two colleagues were kidnapped by Somali gunmen Tuesday in the Somali region of Puntland, a Danish organization said.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Flip Men’ vs. Ratholes
text: Anyone who has roamed through television’s renovating/make-overing/house-flipping genre probably has been struck with the notion that the most appropriate tool for attacking some of the featured projects is a bulldozer. That is certainly a likely response to the opening episode of “Flip Men,” Tuesday night on Spike. When you have to rip as much out of a house as ends up being ripped out here, maybe you should have just torn the danged thing down.

headline: For Romney, an Awkward Visit
text: On Issues 2 and 3, Mitt Romney had zero to say.

headline: The Biggest Losers: MF Global and Netflix
text: There is little MF Global and Netflix have in common, except for the fact that the stocks of both companies plunged on Tuesday after a spate of bad news.

headline: My Trip to Madison: Bikes, Brews, Burgers and a B&B
text: What a great idea — if only I had thought of it: take a trip to Madison, Wis.; stay in a cozy bed- and-breakfast; get around by bike; test out burgers, brats, cheese curds and microbrews; and look for some booze to bring back home.

headline: Zoe Caldwell to Star On Upper East Side
text: Zoe Caldwell would like to invite you for tea and sandwiches. Figuratively and literally. The four-time Tony Award-winner is set to star in David Adjmi’s new play, “Elective Affinities,” directed by Soho Rep’s artistic director, Sarah Benson. The twist is that the site-specific production will take place in an Upper East Side town house that will hold a maximum of 30 people each evening, with Ms. Caldwell’s character, Alice Hauptmann, playing the role of host. Advance tickets sold out in less than 24 hours. (A limited number of tickets, however, may be made available on the day of each performance.) “I was sent from the Soho Rep a play, a one-woman play, and I said ‘Oh no no,’ ” Ms. Caldwell said in a telephone interview. “I did ‘Lillian’ ” — a 1986 play about Lillian Hellman — “and that almost did me in.” She added, “Then Charlie, my son, said, ‘You could at least read the script before you dismiss it.’ And I said, ‘Fair enough.’ ” Mr. Adjmi, best known as the author of “Stunning,” won a 2010 Whiting Award for playwriting. “I was so stunned by the writing which is marvelously exact,” Ms. Caldwell said of “Elective Affinities,” which was commissioned by the Royal Court Theater and produced by the Royal Shakespeare Company in 2005. The producers of the American premiere are Soho Rep, piece by piece productions and Rising Phoenix Repertory. It is scheduled to run Nov. 17 to Dec. 18.

headline: Robust Voices, Celebrated on a Small Stage
text: A CD release party at Le Poisson Rouge is fast becoming almost standard practice among classical musicians, a way of promoting a disc and offering a live performance of excerpts in an entertaining, low-key setting.

headline: Is It Art, Science or a Test of People?
text: Over the past several years art museums have begun to place much more emphasis on a concept they call the “visitor experience.” Few, though, have attempted to define that concept quite as broadly — or as bodily — as the New Museum, which is mounting a career survey of the Belgian-born artist Carsten Höller that opens on Wednesday.

headline: Their Year of Living Almost Famously
text: WASHINGTON — It has been a heady year for John Paul White and Joy Williams, who together are the folk-pop duo called the Civil Wars.

headline: ‘Desdemona’ Talks Back to ‘Othello’
text: NANTERRE, France — A decade ago Toni Morrison, the Nobel Prize-winning novelist, and Peter Sellars, the experimental theater and opera director, got into a fierce argument about Shakespeare’s “Othello.” He said it was a terrible play that made no sense and had outlived its usefulness. She said he was dead wrong.

headline: The Dance World Turns Out to Honor Its Own
text: This year the Bessies moved uptown. On Monday the New York Dance and Performance Awards, named after the highly influential teacher and mentor Bessie Schonberg, were given out at the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

headline: Whiting Foundation Names Winners of Writers’ Awards
text: The winners of the Whiting Writers’ Awards, given annually to authors “of exceptional talent and promise in early career,” were announced on Tuesday. The 2011 recipients include the fiction writers Scott Blackwood (“We Agreed to Meet Just Here”), Teddy Wayne (“Kapitoil”), Daniel Orozco (“Orientation”) and Ryan Call (“The Weather Stations”).

headline: Recreating The Chants Of Feisty 1200s Nuns
text: The boundless array of restrictions imposed on women over the centuries has included a ban on their singing polyphonic music in the Middle Ages. But it is thought that the nuns in Las Huelgas, a Cistercian convent for noblewomen in north-central Spain, enthusiastically flouted the rule. Indeed, the medieval abbesses at Las Huelgas could even say Mass and hear confessions, privileges revoked by the 19th century.

headline: Hawaii’s Traditions, Retold in Words and Movement
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Montclair State University’s Peak Performances series has a reputation for presenting avant-garde dance, frequently imported from abroad and for some reason unavailable in New York. What took the stage of the Alexander Kasser Theater on Thursday, however, was more like a holiday pageant suitable for a high school auditorium. Diorama groupings, a mismatch between mythic subject matter and amateur performances, even a skittish narrator giving a halting reading of stilted text — it was all there. Plus the hula.

headline: Obama to Michelle: More Candy on Halloween
text: LOS ANGELES – President Obama poked fun at Republicans and even his wife, Michelle, during a taped appearance on Tuesday on NBC’s “The Tonight Show,” cracking up the host Jay Leno if not his spouse.

headline: Feeling the Long Reach of Jack the Ripper in a Series of Gruesome Killings
text: An awful lot of copycatting is going on in “Whitechapel,” a six-part crime series starting on BBC America on Wednesday night, and only some of it is by the killer being pursued.

headline: Banks May Be Target of Their Own Tactic: Advocating a Breakup
text: Perhaps it is not Occupy Wall Street that the banks should fear, but their latest frothy financial product. Investment bankers are crisscrossing the nation peddling spinoffs. But given the weak stock prices of these banks, they may find themselves under the same pressure to split up from their own investors.

headline: Giving ‘Sweet Home Alabama’ a Polish Accent
text: Jimmy Sturr has been at this awhile. The way he snatches the microphone from its stand and yanks it up to his mouth, the ever so slight crouch in his stance when he’s trying to communicate a point, the gleam that appears to emanate from him onstage: all products of four-plus decades of work at keeping polka alive.

headline: Scaling Bach’s Mountains With Stamina and Skill
text: By refusing to specialize in a particular corner of the violin repertory, and leaping freely among several, Jennifer Koh has built a following that draws on, and ideally brings together, several of the music world’s style-conscious enclaves. Some listeners know her for the hard-edged contemporary scores she has recorded and to which she has devoted full recitals. Others associate her with the six free lunchtime recitals of Bach’s Unaccompanied Sonatas and Partitas (BWV 1001-6) she gave at Columbia University two seasons ago. She is also touring with a Bach and Beyond series in which she juxtaposes the solo Bach works with 20th- and 21st-century pieces, some written for the occasion.

headline: Eating Like a Rock Star at Emilio’s Ballato
text: An unassuming Italian restaurant on East Houston Street attracts some very famous patrons.

headline: Like Rao’s, but You Can Get In
text: ONE afternoon back in February, Scott Conant was feeling grumpy and hungry. Mr. Conant, the chef at Scarpetta, has a business office in SoHo, and he was curious about a restaurant a short walk away that a friend had recommended.

headline: TimesCast | Gun Smuggling Accusations
text: October 25, 2011 - Eight current and former New York Police Department officers were arrested for gun trafficking and smuggling cigarettes.

headline: 3 Arrested in Killing of Woman Near School
text: Three days after a 34-year-old woman was killed by gunfire in Brooklyn as she picked up her child after school, detectives arrested the suspected gunman, his brother and a half-brother, the police said Tuesday.

headline: TimesCast | Euro Debt Deal in Flux
text: October 25, 2011 - European Union finance ministers abruptly cancel a Wednesday meeting, causing stock markets in the United States and Europe to drop along with the euro.

headline: New Red Sox G.M. Pledges Only ‘Minor Changes’
text: BOSTON — The Red Sox figured they had good news to impart Tuesday with the announcement that Ben Cherington would succeed Theo Epstein as the team’s general manager.

headline: Bottle of Red, Bottle of White at Emilio’s Ballato
text: When the guy who wrote “Scenes from an Italian Restaurant” tells you to try an Italian restaurant, it seems sensible to pay attention.

headline: 2 European Banks Post Mixed Results
text: FRANKFURT — As European officials struggle to find a solution to the sovereign debt crisis, two of the region’s largest financial firms continue to deal with the fallout from the market turmoil.

headline: Volvo Adjusts to Life With a Rich, Quiet Benefactor
text: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — Between Sweden’s two main carmakers, as I reported in The Times on Tuesday, Saab Automobile has hit hard times, while Volvo Cars appears to be going great guns.

headline: Table Dressing
text: Two great tastes don’t always taste great together. The same can be true for design collaborations. Heath Ceramics are beautiful. Alabama Chanin textiles are beautiful. Their respective designers, Catherine Bailey and Natalie Chanin, are friends. But could the twain meet?

headline: Battle for Libya | October 25, 2011
text: The aftermath of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s death and the end of the revolution in Libya.

headline: Mozzarella as Medium and Muse
text: BREAKFAST meetings, perhaps, are best suited to Hollywood types, people who pitch and spin even before the first coffee. When I found myself in San Francisco early this month along with Nancy Silverton, the esteemed founder of La Brea Bakery and the restaurant Campanile in Los Angeles, the only time we could get together was for breakfast. Ms. Silverton, who now owns two of Los Angeles’s most popular restaurants, Osteria Mozza and Pizzeria Mozza, with Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich, has just published her eighth book, “The Mozza Cookbook” (Alfred A. Knopf, $35), and she suggested Boulettes Larder, in the Ferry Building.

headline: Q&A: A Wi-Fi Tablet in a 3G World
text: Q. I have an Android tablet that can connect to the Internet only through Wi-Fi. Can I get a 3G chip for it to use the phone data networks too?

headline: Talking About Sex, in Class and at Home
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cookies From Casablanca, Now in New York
text: Steve Blanco, a jazz pianist whose mother is from Casablanca, Morocco, grew up eating crumbly, shortbread-style cookies that are called ghoribas in North Africa. About a year ago he and his girlfriend and partner, Heidi Karlsen, who has baked professionally, decided to try making them with notable tweaks, like replacing semolina with rye flour and butter or cooking oil with coconut oil. They call them Sandcastles. So far they have perfected two rich, nutty flavors: marzipan and black sesame. Next in line are maple-dusted cardamom and poppy-seed-lemon.

headline: Raclette Made Simple
text: In its traditional Alpine home, raclette can involve rigmarole — lighting a fire (preferably in your ski lodge), holding a hunk of the cheese before the flames and scraping off what melts to serve with boiled potatoes and pickles. But you can simply melt some nuggets of Spring Brook Farm’s raclette from Vermont in a saucepan, and it’s just about as good. This mild yet complex cow’s-milk cheese has an earthy aroma and fruity flavor. It comes in big wheels with rust-colored rind enclosing a satiny, semisoft paste. As superb as it is for melting (burgers, pasta, soup, sandwiches), it is also excellent on a cheese tray. And it’s educational; Spring Brook is a host of the Farms for City Kids program, bringing fourth and fifth graders from urban schools to milk cows and do chores.

headline: Look Out: Patrik Ervell at Work
text: The Patrik Ervell pop-up at Boffo Building Fashion at 57 Walker Street looks more like a construction site than a high-end designer shop.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 19 through Oct. 24 with 1,650 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,475 said they were registered to vote.

headline: New Poll Finds a Deep Distrust of Government
text: With Election Day just over a year away, a deep sense of economic anxiety and doubt about the future hangs over the nation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, with Americans’ distrust of government at its highest level ever.

headline: Manhattan? BASF Prefers the Countryside
text: When BASF, the world’s largest chemical company, was looking for a new North American headquarters, opportunity was just around the corner.

text: THE unshaven guy working the mini-cannoli booth in Madison Square Park glanced from side to side, making sure the vendors next door were busy with their samosas and shaved ice.

headline: Journalist Describes Captivity in Syria
text: Sean McAllister, a British documentary filmmaker, was arrested in the Syrian capital, Damascus, last week while working secretly for Britain’s Channel 4 News. In an interview broadcast on Tuesday, after his release, Mr. McAllister described his captivity, and the torture of detained activists he overheard from his cell.

text: 2:20 a.m. | Updated Two days after a man accused of assaulting three female protesters in Zuccotti Park was arrested, some friends of his threatened to kill the woman who had filed the complaint that led to the arrest, the police said on Tuesday.

text: Complete results of the New York Times/CBS News Poll, Oct. 19-24.

headline: Martha Stewart Revisits ‘Entertaining,’ 70 Books Later
text: In 1982, the book was “Entertaining” by Martha Stewart. Now, with a media empire, television exposure, more than 70 books and a sky-high profile, her latest book is “Martha’s Entertaining: A Year of Celebrations” (Clarkson Potter, $75).

headline: The Energy Map
text: Rising energy demand in emerging economies, like China and India, is a driving force in the natural gas and oil industry and is helping to push prices higher. At the same time, technological advances are making the recovery of more conventional and unconventional resources feasible, reshaping the energy landscape around the world.

headline: A Toast to a New Breed of Bar Food
text: IT used to be that when you went to a bar, you got a free bowl of peanuts. Now the drinking has become a whole lot more interesting, and interest leads to commitment. Bar food is flirting with seriousness, tempting you to stay in your seat all night.

headline: Edwards Fights Campaign Finance Case
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Lawyers for John Edwards will head to federal court here on Wednesday to ask a judge to dismiss charges that he violated campaign finance laws by using money from two wealthy benefactors to support his pregnant mistress during his run for the presidency in 2008.

headline: John McCarthy, 84, Dies; Computer Design Pioneer
text: John McCarthy, a computer scientist who helped design the foundation of today’s Internet-based computing and who is widely credited with coining the term for a frontier of research he helped pioneer, Artificial Intelligence, or A.I., died on Monday at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 84.

headline: New Technologies Redraw the World’s Energy Picture
text: GOLDA MEIR, the former prime minister of Israel, used to tell a joke about how Moses must have made a wrong turn in the desert: “He dragged us 40 years through the desert to bring us to the one place in the Middle East where there was no oil.’ ”

headline: E.R. Care and Abortion: A G.O.P. Congressman’s View

headline: A New Generation of Unconventional Fossil Fuels
text: Giant new oil and gas fields are being mined, steamed and drilled with new technologies.

headline: Egyptian Activists Summoned by Military Prosecutor
text: Updated | Thursday, 2:20 p.m. An Egyptian military prosecutor summoned two activists for interrogation on Monday, the same day President Obama urged the head of Egypt’s ruling military council to end military trials for civilians in a phone call from the White House.

headline: On the Front Lines of the Power Grid
text: QUICK! You are on duty in a secret control room in a nondescript, windowless building. The sign out front is so small that people driving by cannot read it, and it may give no clue what goes on inside, anyway. But your task is crucial: you are matching the ever-changing power needs of tens of millions of electricity customers with supply coming from hundreds of electricity generators, deciding which units will run and which ones will be idle, and making quick adjustments for the generators you can’t schedule, like the wind machines and solar panels.

headline: Solar Power Industry Falls Short of Hopes in Job Creation
text: GOVERNMENT help for solar power was supposed to be a triple play: jobs at a time of dire short-term need; incubation of an American industry sure to be important on a global scale in the next few years; and a long-term reduction in climate-changing pollution.

headline: The Sports Industry Curbs Its Energy Use
text: Team owners and event organizers are cutting their energy consumption to save money, and they are generating new income measures by teaming up with corporate sponsors to go green.

headline: Sports Rally Around Green Projects
text: AMERICAN sports are often an exercise in excess: fans consume large quantities of beer and hot dogs, stadiums with giant scoreboards and retractable roofs are surrounded by parking lots filled with thousands of cars. In many ways, they represent the broadest cross-section of consumer culture and America’s wasteful ways.

text: William C. Rhoden discusses the latest clashes between athletes and the media.

headline: Military Drills Paired With Shrimp? For a Prince, It’s Possible
text: GILA BEND, Ariz. — Among the books mentioning princes in the Gila Bend Branch Library is “The Prince and the Potty,” about a young prince learning to outgrow his diaper, and “The Frog Prince Continued,” about a frog who was turned into a prince but kept hopping on furniture and flicking his tongue at flies.

text: A scene from “Sledgehammer,” a 1983 movie that was released this year on VHS. (Video courtesy of Intervision.)

headline: How Rick Perry’s Tax Plan Would Affect You
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who is seeking the Republican presidential nomination, today released some details on his flat tax proposal. The plan would give Americans the option of determining their taxes based on an alternate system that has one tax rate and fewer deductions.

headline: Congress Wants Hearing on H.G.H. Testing in N.F.L.
text: Three members of Congress called Tuesday for a hearing on the delay in beginning testing for human growth hormone in the N.F.L.

headline: Insurer Drops Fight to Keep Rate Filings From Public
text: The largest health insurer in New York, United Health/Oxford, has agreed to drop a fight to keep its filings for rate increases secret, putting pressure on other insurance carriers to follow suit rather than keep battling against state regulators pressing for disclosure.

headline: The Shot Heard Round Brooklyn
text: Perhaps it’s the amateur historian in me, but I gravitate to people who have experienced first-hand things I wish I had, too. Bobby Thomson’s game-ending home run that won the 1951 National League pennant for the New York Giants — and made a goat out of Ralph Branca of the Brooklyn Dodgers — is one of those experiences.

headline: Ketchup Moves Upmarket, With a Balsamic Tinge
text: TO emphasize its thickness, Heinz ketchup introduced a series of commercials in the 1970s that featured “Anticipation,” the Carly Simon song, which played as actors waited longingly for ketchup to pour onto burgers and fries.

headline: That 2011-12 N.B.A. Schedule? Never Mind
text: More N.B.A. games will be canceled soon, perhaps today or tomorrow or next week. The timing hardly matters anymore. The schedule, at least as it was presented in July, is already worthless.

headline: Luthiers: The Latest Endangered Species
text: New Haven

headline: Left-Footed Penalty Takers Showing the Way in M.L.S.
text: Fox Soccer analyst Warren Barton shared a peculiar thought on air last February shortly after Everton had ousted Chelsea from the F.A. Cup on penalties at Stamford Bridge.

headline: Sprint’s Hand in Antitrust Suit
SAT Officials Vow More Security After Cheating Arrests on Long Island
text: FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — Stung by the arrest of seven Long Island teenagers accused of cheating on the SAT, the College Board said Tuesday that it was hiring a former F.B.I. director to review its security procedures, and that by the next exams, Nov. 5, it would begin analyzing more test scores for irregularities and increase training for test-center supervisors.

headline: China Takes a Loss to Get Ahead in the Business of Fresh Water
text: TIANJIN, China — Towering over the Bohai Sea shoreline on this city’s outskirts, the Beijiang Power and Desalination Plant is a 26-billion-renminbi technical marvel: an ultrahigh-temperature, coal-fired generator with state-of-the-art pollution controls, mated to advanced Israeli equipment that uses its leftover heat to distill seawater into fresh water.

headline: Report Lays Out State’s Great Gains and Losses From Globalization
text: As international trade has accelerated in the last four decades, no state has lost more of its ability to make things or gained more through exporting ideas and professional services than New York has, according to a report to be released on Wednesday.

headline: Food Blooms in the Desert
text: Last month, I stood in the midday sun a few miles north of Anthony, N. M., and Anthony, Tex. — a town divided by the state line created in 1854 — staring out over a 15-acre plot of land that didn’t look like much. In this part of the world, it was once almost as easy to travel from the United States to Mexico and back as it is to go from one Anthony to another. Now the trip can drive you crazy, with long waits and inspections; if you’re undocumented and unlucky, it can kill you.

headline: Top Earners Doubled Share of Nation’s Income, Study Finds
text: WASHINGTON — The top 1 percent of earners more than doubled their share of the nation’s income over the last three decades, the Congressional Budget Office said Tuesday, in a new report likely to figure prominently in the escalating political fight over how to revive the economy, create jobs and lower the federal debt.

headline: The Hague: Four Prosecutor Finalists
text: A committee on Tuesday announced its list of four final candidates to become the chief prosecutor for the International Criminal Court: Fatou Bensouda of Gambia, Andrew Cayley of Britain, Mohamed Chande Othman of Tanzania and Robert Petit of Canada. The prosecutor is expected to be chosen in December to replace Luis Moreno-Ocampo of Argentina. Mrs. Bensouda is widely considered to be the front-runner.

headline: President to Ease Student Loan Burden for Low-Income Graduates
text: President Obama will announce new programs Wednesday to lower monthly loan payments for some students graduating next year and thereafter and to let borrowers who have a mix of direct federal loans and loans under the old Federal Family Education Loan Program consolidate them at a slightly lower interest rate.

headline: Baseball’s Game of Telephone
text: ST. LOUIS — In Atlanta, there are televisions in the dugouts to help the manager monitor the action in his team’s bullpen — who is warming up, and how ready a pitcher might be to enter the game.

headline: Uganda: Anti-Gay Bill Is Revived
text: Parliament has voted to reopen a debate on a bill that seeks to outlaw homosexuality and that could be expanded to include the death penalty for gay men and lesbians. The legislation, first proposed in 2009, will be sent to a committee for consideration, Speaker Rebecca Kadaga told lawmakers. The Legal and Parliamentary Affairs Committee in the previous Parliament suggested that the penalty for “aggravated homosexuality” should be the same as for “defilement,” a crime that is punishable by death.

headline: Pakistan: Judge Wounded by Gunman
text: An unidentified gunman wounded the chief justice of the high court in the Pakistani-controlled part of the disputed Kashmir region on Tuesday, the police said. The justice, Ghulam Mustafa Mughal, was shot in the abdomen and taken to a military hospital, where his condition was said to be stable. The gunman was not caught, and the motive for the attack was unclear. Kashmir is claimed by both India and Pakistan, and the attack occurred after death threats were made to another Pakistani judge, who had sentenced the killer of the Punjab Province governor.

headline: It’s Consumer Spending, Stupid
text: AS an economic historian who has been studying American capitalism for 35 years, I’m going to let you in on the best-kept secret of the last century: private investment — that is, using business profits to increase productivity and output — doesn’t actually drive economic growth. Consumer debt and government spending do. Private investment isn’t even necessary to promote growth.

headline: Telemundo Blends English Into a Mostly Spanish Lineup
text: Telemundo has long trailed its rival Univision in their competition for Hispanic television viewers in the United States. But as the number of second- and third-generation Hispanic-Americans skyrockets, the perennial runner-up is embracing a new strategy — English-language subtitles and Spanglish — to attract deep-pocketed viewers and the advertisers who covet them.

headline: Will Extremists Hijack Occupy Wall Street?
text: THE activists of Occupy Wall Street have already scored a stunning — and I think welcome — success.

headline: A Sky-High Tide, This Time Fleeting, but Perhaps a Glimpse of Torrents to Come
text: From his window in Broad Channel, Queens, Dan Mundy sees the tides of Jamaica Bay swing from high to low, the pendulum of a celestial clock. “Right now, 10 after 1 in the afternoon, it is 25 minutes from dead-low tide,” he said on Tuesday. “It’s much lower now than it would usually be. The mud flats are bigger.”

headline: Nusrat Bhutto, Political Force in Pakistan, Dies at 82
text: Nusrat Bhutto, a near-mythic figure in Pakistan’s modern history, whose husband, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was executed in 1979 after being deposed as prime minister in a military coup, and whose daughter Benazir Bhutto, a former prime minister, was killed by a suicide bomber while campaigning for office in 2007, died Sunday in Dubai. She was 82.

headline: Barack Kissinger Obama
text: Who would have predicted it? Barack Obama has turned out to be so much more adept at implementing George W. Bush’s foreign policy than Bush was, but he is less adept at implementing his own. The reasons, though, are obvious.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,472 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,804 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: In Chicago, Michelle Obama Takes On ‘Food Deserts’
text: CHICAGO — Michelle Obama took an afternoon away from fund-raising for her husband’s re-election campaign on Tuesday to draw attention to another — and far less divisive — goal: reducing childhood obesity.

headline: Moving Beyond the Cold War Coach
text: Youth sports in the United States is a contradiction. In surveys, parents overwhelmingly say that youth sports should emphasize values like teamwork, honesty, discipline and fair play. But when adults are asked what values they think youth sports actually reinforce most, they say competitiveness and the importance of winning.

headline: How to Fix the Wireless Market
text: It’s good that wireless companies have agreed to warn customers when they are about to exceed monthly limits on voice, text or data usage or incur international roaming fees, which can result in thousands of dollars of extra charges. But consumers need more protection.

headline: A Foolish Time to Cut Housing Aid
text: With record numbers of families teetering on the verge of homelessness, Congress should be shoring up the precious few federal programs that provide affordable housing for the poor, the elderly and the disabled. Instead, both the House and Senate are considering cuts to the Department of Housing and Urban Development budget, which would hurt cash-strapped states and communities in sheltering the most vulnerable citizens.

headline: Europe Faces New Hurdles in Crisis Over Debt
text: PARIS — New fissures and disagreements emerged on Tuesday on the eve of a European Union summit meeting promoted as the moment for agreement on a comprehensive solution to the two-year-old euro crisis. Crucial financial measures were left unresolved, and Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy faced strong opposition inside his governing coalition to major changes demanded by the Europeans.

headline: So Much for Small Government
text: House Republicans usually claim to be champions of both small government and states’ rights, which makes it hypocritical, and downright reckless, that they are obsessed with taking away the authority of states to decide who is allowed to carry a concealed and loaded handgun.

headline: In Shifting Landscape, UConn Loses Ground
text: STORRS, Conn. — In the lobby of the University of Connecticut’s football facility, there is a trophy case that displays mementos from the team’s trip to the Fiesta Bowl last season. Among the items are a football with the game’s date on it, a game-day program and a plaque.

headline: Why Has the Black Death Paled?
text: Could there be a better pretext for a disaster movie? Scientists from McMaster University in Ontario and the University of Tübingen in Germany have reconstructed the genetic code of the microbe that caused the Black Death.

headline: Tévez Situation Takes Another Odd Turn
text: The news that Manchester City has fined its sulking striker Carlos Tévez a month’s pay and sentenced him, essentially, to time served as a punishment would seem to put to rest the controversy that has been a rare stain on the club’s solid start to the Premier League season.

headline: A Leading Pioneer
text: NEW LONDON, Conn. — Except for a strategic bit of elastic that may be required, the blue running tunic, circa Smith College 1961, still fits. It will be worn again a half-century later, this time in celebration and tribute rather than defiance.

headline: One Day After Disaster, Manager Explains Himself
text: ST. LOUIS — He has won two World Series, been a subject of books about his managerial prowess and is considered by some as one of the best managers in baseball history. But on his way to what will undoubtedly be a Hall of Fame induction, Tony La Russa, a manager for 33 years, stumbled Monday night.

headline: Perry Makes Digs at Romney on Fox News
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas capped an eventful day on the campaign trail Tuesday with an interview on “The O’Reilly Factor” on the Fox News Channel. He expressed regret for participating in campaign debates, which have largely resulted in poor reviews for him. And yet again, he came in tongue a-blazin’, this time with some choice digs at his chief rival, former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts.

headline: Limits of Magical Thinking
text: Steve Jobs, the mad perfectionist, even perfected his stare.

headline: Tunisia Liberals See a Vote for Change, Not Religion
text: TUNIS — The liberal political parties emerging as surprise runners-up in elections here argued Tuesday that their success had tempered the commanding victory of the Islamists while offering lessons for their secular allies around the region.

headline: Rick Perry’s Tax and Spending Plan
text: Rick Perry wants to cap spending at 18 percent of G.D.P., the lowest rate since 1966.

headline: In Case of Rain, a Case for Carpenter
text: ST. LOUIS — With a 90 percent chance of rain predicted for Wednesday, there is a possibility that Game 6 of the World Series at Busch Stadium could be rained out. If so, it might provide the St. Louis Cardinals with the opportunity to bring their ace, Chris Carpenter, back on short rest for a potential Game 7 on Friday.

headline: Wednesday: Exhibited Perfect Braking
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Sorry about the title. The Girl is learning to drive, and braking seems to be very much on our minds these days. That, and parallel parking, as well as not taking turns on two wheels. I will get through this, but I’m pretty sure that this is the point in raising children where parents skip over other comforts and just turn directly to heroin.

headline: Couple Who Took 8 Children From Foster Care Face Jail
text: A Manhattan couple who slipped their eight children out the back of a foster care agency in Queens and absconded with them for a week pleaded guilty on Tuesday to second-degree custodial interference.

headline: Twitter and TV Get Close to Help Each Other Grow
text: Type the term “X Factor” into Twitter’s search engine on a Wednesday or Thursday night and within moments, hundreds of viewer compliments and complaints about the Fox television show of that name will appear.

headline: DuPont Earnings Continue to Surpass Analysts’ Expectations
text: The DuPont Company, the top United States chemical maker, reported third-quarter profit and sales on Tuesday that beat analyst estimates, and then it raised its full-year forecast.

text: On Wednesday, because of Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Haitians Train for a Future With a Military
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — For hours, Robeson Arthiste dragged himself through the dirt like a commando, marched “left, two, three, four,” dived behind bushes pointing an imaginary gun and grimaced while a razor blade removed every bit of hair from his head, leaving a trickle of blood.

headline: Islanders, Looking for a Win and Not a Fight, Get Neither
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders apparently needed to win a game more than they needed to prove any more points with their fists Tuesday night, so the pugnacious left wing Trevor Gillies was scratched before they played the Pittsburgh Penguins at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Ex-Associate Testifies Against Reputed Arms Trafficker

headline: A New Breed of Knee Injury in Young Athletes
text: Sometimes physicians will notice a medical trend well before science confirms its existence. That has been the case with injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament, the main ligament that stabilizes the knee joint, in young athletes. “Doctors who treat kids have all been saying over and over that the numbers of A.C.L. tears are going up dramatically,” says Dr. J. Todd Lawrence, an orthopedic surgeon and pediatric sports medicine specialist at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia. But surprisingly little firm data has confirmed that hunch.

headline: Political Newspaper Endorsements: History and Outcome
text: Newspaper editorial pages have been endorsing presidential candidates for well over a century. On Oct. 11, 1860, the New York Times editorial page threw its hat behind a “Mr. Lincoln, of Illinois, familiarly known as ‘Old Abe,’ age 51, height six feet seven, by profession Rail-Splitter.”

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
text: The head of the agency that manages travel for Kiran Bedi severed ties with her nongovernmental organization,  India Vision Foundation, on Tuesday. Anil Bal, proprietor of Flywell Travel, claimed that the controversy over the inflated travel invoices furnished by Ms. Bedi had unnecessarily tarnished his reputation. Mr. Bal, a founding member of the foundation, also resigned as trustee of the organization (The Indian Express).Prime Minister Manmohan Singh was skeptical of the July 2005  nuclear agreement with the United States in the run-up to the joint statement declaring the pact, a new book by former U.S. Secretary of State Condelezzaa Rice claims. Mr. Singh was wary about the impact of the deal on domestic politics, Ms. Rice writes in her upcoming memoir “In No Higher Honor.” The then-foreign minister, Natwar Singh, was far more adamant about the deal — called  the U.S.-India Civil Nuclear Cooperation — and worked with U.S. officials to persuade the prime minister it was a good idea (Hindustan Times).

headline: ‘X Factor’ Watch: Squabbling and Dancing (and Some Singing), All of It Live
text: Some welcome testiness finally worked its way into “The X Factor” on Tuesday night, but so did lots of unwelcome choreography, headache-inducing lighting and overorchestration. Some of the singers in this live show were more or less swallowed up by their absurdly excessive production numbers as “The X Factor” abandoned its roots as a singing competition and turned into something resembling a bad Broadway musical.

headline: Panetta Says North Korea Remains a ‘Serious Threat’

headline: A Firecracker-Free Diwali?
text: For most people, Diwali festivities are incomplete without the crackling of firecrackers. And almost everyone has a favorite, ranging from the innocuous “phooljhadi,” or sparkler, to the rocket, which usually fails to live up to its name, hissing into the sky with fierce intensity only to fall flat on the ground within minutes. And then there is the pernicious-sounding “bomb,” whose name says it all. They come in different shapes and sizes but the firecrackers have one thing in common: they unleash an ear-splitting bang when they are set ablaze.

headline: What Have You Made Yourself?
text: We borrow this question from a teacher at the Bertie Early College High School in Windsor, N.C., who asks her students to name the last thing they have made themselves, even if it is as simple as cookies, to get them thinking about design. What have you made yourself, recently or at any time in your life? Do you like making things by hand? Do you wish your school had a design or building course?

headline: Euro Zone | Film and Fitness in Rome
text: The International Rome Film Festival, which starts Thursday and runs until Nov. 4, may not have the panache of Cannes or Venice. But what it lacks in star power, it usually makes up for with content and, of course, location. This year, Charlotte Rampling will attend for “The Eye of the Storm,” a film also starring Geoffrey Rush about a fading beauty planning her own death. Maggie Gyllenhall and Rupert Everett are in town to promote “Hysteria,” a film about the history of the vibrator; and Richard Gere will collect an honorary acting award.

headline: Petula Clark Heading to Midtown
text: Petula Clark, the British singer and actress best known for her hit “Downtown,” will make her first appearance at a New York City nightclub since the 1970s early next year, her publicist said. Ms. Clark, who is 78, lives in Switzerland and has not played New York for decades. She will appear at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Park Avenue at 61st Street from Jan. 24 to Feb. 4, performing her hits, including “I Know a Place” and “My Love,” as well as songs from musicals she appeared in, both onstage and screen.

headline: The Student Loan Proposal: What It Might Mean for You
text: Blogger’s Note: Tamar Lewin writes on The Times’s Web site on Wednesday that President Obama will announce new programs “to lower monthly loan payments for some students graduating next year and thereafter and to let borrowers who have a mix of direct federal loans and loans under the old Federal Family Education Loan Program consolidate them at a slightly lower interest rate.” Mark Kantrowitz, the publisher of the financial aid Web sites finaid.org and fastweb, was asked by The Choice to write a quick essay explaining what the proposal might mean for applicants this year, and in the future, for current students and recent graduates. — Jacques Steinberg

headline: The Naughty Necklace
text: RISING hemlines get all the attention, but what about necklines? They’re one of the few things on the rise lately, reaching a recent high — on shirts buttoned all the way to the chin — on spring 2012 runways at Jason Wu, Céline and Dior. It makes a kind of sense, then, as the eye moves north of the collarbone, that chokers, those much maligned neckpieces synonymous with the 1990s, would stage a comeback.

headline: Liviu Ciulei, a Daring Theater Director, Dies at 88
