text: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

headline: Daniel B. Burke, Leading Media Executive, Dies at 82
text: Daniel B. Burke, who helped engineer the acquisition of the American Broadcasting Company by Capital Cities, one of the boldest corporate takeovers of the 1980s, and went on to become chief executive of the merged company, died on Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 82.

headline: Big 12 Might Admit Louisville, Not West Virginia
text: West Virginia University athletic officials spent most of Tuesday preparing to leave the Big East Conference for the Big 12. The Mountaineers’ athletic director, Oliver Luck, was so sure of the move that he tipped off Big East colleagues Monday night and told staff members Tuesday.

headline: Mao’s Rockets and the Eastern Afghan Border War, Part I
text: Cold War Weapons and Afghanistan’s Unending Fight

headline: I.V.F. Without the Risk of Multiple Births?
text: A few years ago, a friend, who, like many of our peers, got started late in the baby game and ended up going the  in vitro fertilization route, told me she was pregnant with twins. They’d used two embryos to maximize the chance of getting pregnant, and both had taken. But they didn’t want twins. The next time I saw her, she had one baby.

headline: State Officials Have Frequently Overruled Local Board’s Rejection of Liquor Licenses
text: Community Board 3 is often seen as the party pooper of the downtown dining and drinking scene, regularly voting to oppose new liquor licenses for restaurants and bars in the East Village and Lower East Side.

headline: Millepied Retires From City Ballet
text: Benjamin Millepied, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, has retired and plans to focus on his choreography, the company announced on Wednesday. Mr. Millepied, 34, originally from Bordeaux, France, and known to many non-balletomanes as the choreographer for the Oscar-nominated movie “Black Swan,” joined the company in 1995 after training at City Ballet’s affiliated School of American Ballet. He was promoted to principal in 2002 and originated roles in ballets by Jerome Robbins, Peter Martins, Christopher Wheeldon, Alexei Ratmansky and others.

headline: Spooky Sketches | Mandy Coon
text: T challenges 10 designers to turn everyday objects into killer Halloween costumes.

headline: When Should a Small Business Hire a Finance Chief?
text: At Quickoffice, which sells software that allows users to create and edit documents on mobile devices, Alan Masarek always enjoyed getting deep into the numbers of his business — almost as if he were chief financial officer instead of chief executive.

headline: Like the Best Zombies, VHS Just Won’t Die
text: FOR horror fans like Evan Husney, a movie that looks like it’s been art-directed to death is a real killer.

headline: Rule Allows U.S. a Close Look at Big Hedge Funds
text: WASHINGTON — Large hedge funds, the very private investment outfits that borrow money to magnify their big financial bets, will be required for the first time to report detailed information on their investments and borrowings under a rule adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday.

headline: Yes, Mitt Romney Backs Efforts to Limit Unions in Ohio
text: FAIRFAX, Va. — Mitt Romney on Wednesday reaffirmed his support for efforts to crack down on unions in Ohio, apologizing for causing “confusion” by appearing to waffle on the issue in that state a day earlier.

headline: In Fight Against Securities Fraud, S.E.C. Sends Wrong Signal
text: Back when the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission was doing its work, I would check in periodically with someone who worked there to find out how it was going.

headline: Have You Tried to Hire a C.F.O.?
text: In a small-business guide we’ve just published, Alan Masarek talks about how he decided it was time for his business to hire a chief financial officer.

headline: Libya’s Interim Leader Asks NATO to Stay Through the End of 2011
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Libya’s interim leader said Wednesday that he had asked NATO to prolong its air patrols through December and add military advisers on the ground, despite his official declaration on Sunday of the country’s liberation after the killing of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Study: Yaz Has Higher Risks of Blood Clots
text: A new study of 1.3 million Danish women over nine years adds to the evidence that some newer birth-control pills, including the best-seller Yaz, have a higher risk of causing potentially dangerous blood clots.

headline: Chelsea Market Halloween Display Raises Hackles as Well as the Dead
text: A gray zombie baby chews on a severed human hand. A demonic toddler stares out with bright red eyes that in a horrifying twist, perfectly match the bows in her pigtails. A grandfatherly man with blood pouring from his mouth relaxes on a wooden chair, a pink teddy bear and a white-eyed, fang-baring baby resting in his lap.

headline: Yale Press to Publish Forgotten Eugene O’Neill One-Act in Book Form
text: In 1912, the 24-year-old Eugene O’Neill tried to kill himself with an overdose of Veronal, but botched the job and was found unconscious by friends. He later wrote about the experience in an autobiographical one-act play, “Exorcism,” which ends with the O’Neill character, Ned Malloy, experiencing a kind of resurrection. “The Past is finally cremated,” he says. “I feel reborn, I tell you.”

headline: Big Hair and Bad Blood: VHS-Era Horror Obscurities From A to Z
text: For a certain subset of horror fan, the high quality of Blu-ray is unwatchable compared with the painfully grainy-hazy look of VHS (especially do-it-yourself titles that look like they were made over a weekend in some guy’s backyard). In recent years, small distributors and a few majors have released 1980s horror movies, mostly of the schlock variety, on special-edition VHS tapes as well as on DVD.

headline: Early Snow Turns Colorado’s Fall Foliage to Winter White
text: GOLDEN, Colo. — A heavy, out-of-season winter storm slammed into Colorado and southeast Wyoming on Tuesday night, delivering in one roundhouse punch more snow than the Denver area typically gets in all of October. The piling on then continued through Wednesday, with a total of 12 to 14 inches falling in some places in foothill communities like this one, west of Denver, and even more in the higher peaks and passes of the Rockies.

headline: Will You Give Your Son the HPV Vaccine?
text: A federal panel has recommended that boys be given the vaccine for human papillomavirus, or HPV. But will parents agree to it?

headline: For This Menace, Only One Thing to Do: Ready, Aim, Fireworks!
text: TERRE HAUTE, Ind.

headline: The Truth Has A Well-Known, Well, You Know
text: Greg Sargent takes us to Paul Ryan’s latest speech, in which Ryan expresses outrage over what President Obama is saying:

headline: Ladies’ Day: FIFA’s List of 10 for Women’s Player of the Year
text: Will this be the year that Marta will be dethroned as the winner of FIFA’s women’s world player of the year? Marta, a skillful Brazilian, has won the award for the past five years and was among the 10 players nominated Wednesday for this year’s award.

headline: Vain Glorious | Prieto Select
text: An unlikely beauty director at best, I’m the girl who — horrors — doesn’t take off her mascara at night (if I’m even wearing any) and never mastered the fine art of foundation. I do have a couple of guilty pleasures, like an occasional cat eye or a sweep of blue eye shadow, but my application skills are next to nil. What’s more, I barely know how to wield a hair dryer or flat iron. If I don’t have time to run to Orlo or Garren, I’m sunk.

headline: Wild-Eyed Theorists In Pinstripes
text: In what amounts to a perfect followup to my post on the amnesiac economy, Paul De Grauwe takes the ECB to task for refusing to do what is necessary to save the euro, and taking refuge in a very narrow definition of its role.

headline: Bus Operator Denies Discriminating Against Women
text: A bus company that transports primarily Orthodox and Hasidic Jewish passengers between Williamsburg and Borough Park in Brooklyn has denied that it discriminates against female passengers by compelling them to sit at the rear of the bus.

headline: Irish Election Shows Signs of Erasing Boundaries
text: GALWAY, Ireland — On an autumn evening beside the storied beauty of Galway Bay, with a chilly gust blowing off the Atlantic, Martin McGuinness breezed into a popular tourist hotel that looks out across the bay with the air of a man who has found a measure of peace after a lifetime gripped by Ireland’s troubled past.

headline: Critic of South Korean Leader Elected as Seoul Mayor
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A civic activist and vocal critic of President Lee Myung-bak rode a growing call for political change to become mayor of the South Korean capital, Seoul, winning a poll widely seen as a bellwether for the presidential election in December next year.

headline: Showtime Thriller ‘Homeland’ Secures a Second Season
text: Orange alert! The Department of Homeland Security may have retired its color-coded terrorism alert system, but the pervading sense of paranoia that it represented isn’t going away, and neither is Showtime’s hit series, “Homeland.” On Wednesday that cable channel said it had ordered a second season of “Homeland,” its serialized thriller about a dogged if possibly paranoid C.I.A. officer (played by Claire Danes), a recently released American prisoner of war (Damian Lewis) who may be a sleeper agent for Al Qaeda, and Mandy Patinkin’s epic beard. (O.K., the beard is not as crucial to the story, but some of us still find it fascinating.)

headline: The Caucus | A Tough Number for Obama
text: Oct. 26, 2011 — A look at one especially challenging result for President Obama in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: The Crow Patrol
text: Terre Haute, Ind., shares a problem with Auburn, N.Y., and Lancaster, Pa.: Crows. Lots and lots of crows.

headline: Caucus Video: A Tough Number for Obama
text: A look at one especially challenging number for President Obama in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Also, Mitt Romney is the endorsement frontrunner, but how much will it help him?

headline: Cuomo Warns of Chaos if Redistricting Fight Goes to a Judge
text: As the process of redrawing legislative boundaries heads to the courts in many other states, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday said that he hoped to avoid that outcome in New York, warning that chaos would ensue if a judge was forced to sort out the state’s redistricting procedures.

headline: Boeing Posts Strong Profit but Cuts Delivery Forecast
text: Boeing said Wednesday that its third-quarter earnings topped estimates and projected that its new 787 Dreamliner would earn at least a low, single-digit profit from sales of the first 1,100 planes.

headline: Returning for a Breeders’ Cup Overflowing With Story Lines
text: They got money, $26 million in purses, and a record number of horses pre-entered – 193 of them were pre-entered Wednesday. We’re talking the 28th running of the Breeders’ Cup World Championships, an event that has turned into a lucrative and truly global event.

headline: 4,177 Students and One Principal: A Day in the Life at Francis Lewis High School
text: Principals these days are expected to be a little bit of many different things: manager, educator, financial whiz, social worker, enforcer, data analyst, cheerleader and contortionist (figuratively, at least). They are the people with whom the buck stops. Fernanda Santos, who covers city schools for The Times, tagged along with a city school principal all day.

headline: Fall Forecast: More Protests at Struggling Schools
text: If advocates fulfill their plans, this will be the season of protests, especially at schools that are among those on the city's list of 20 struggling schools targeted for possible closing if the city feels other measures will not improve their performance.

headline: You Call This Choice?
text: The mother had spent her summer dragging herself from one office to another, speaking in broken English, begging that her daughter be allowed to change high schools. She was sent away, time after time, told there was nothing that could be done. She felt confused, dismissed, helpless. A middle school teacher tells her student's story and asks: Why keep attempting to navigate the jungle that is the high school choice process when we should be creating a road?

headline: Photo Replay: Oct.26
text: France’s national rugby team was welcomed home after its runner-up finish in the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand, and baseball put a tarp over Game 6 of the World Series in St. Louis.

headline: Got Questions? Battista Has Answers
text: Is Christian Ponder for real after an impressive debut as the Minnesota Vikings’ starting quarterback? Does Plaxico Burress’s re-emergence and two straight victories mean the Jets are back? Should the Peyton Manning-less Colts pack the whole thing back onto the moving vans? Judy Battista, The Times’s N.F.L. reporter, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Friday.

headline: Bomb Leads to Fatal Fire on Tanker Near Kabul
text: DASHT-E-RABAT, Afghanistan — A fuel tanker with a bomb hidden on board exploded Tuesday night on the road to Bagram Air Base, setting off an inferno that killed at least 10 people and left dozens more badly burned, many critically, local officials and witnesses said.

text: Photographs from Thailand, Yemen, Turkey and Britain.

headline: Under a Versatile Web
text: THIS Lulu Guinness umbrella can switch from rain shield to festive costume accessory in a snap. That cute umbrella you’ve never found and the answer to this year’s weary Halloween costume? Score!

headline: Victory Eludes Chaz Bono, but Not Fame
text: On Tuesday night, at about the halfway point in the current season of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars,” the judges and viewers voted to eliminate Chaz Bono. But not before he had become, as one gay rights media advocacy group put it, “the world’s most well-known transgender person.”

text: Mother Nature is trying to turn me into an optimist here:

headline: Cashing In on Your Hit YouTube Video
text: Katie Clem posted a video on YouTube this month of her daughter Lily’s poignant and funny reaction to her sixth birthday present, a trip to Disneyland, for her friends and family. Then it went viral.

text: “You got a good mag (like the pulp-heads say) …”

headline: Breaking the Pacifier Addiction
text: I’m thrilled to be writing Motherlode this week for so many reasons. I love the topic, I love the audience and at this very moment, I need advice.

headline: Missing No More: Jack the Cat Turns Up at J.F.K.
text: Jack the Cat did not patronize the duty-free shops. He was never spotted near any of the drinking establishments. And if he bothered to sample the food court fare, his emaciated condition would register as a scathing critique.

headline: Insurers Weigh In on Health Care Law
text: The health insurance industry is urging the Supreme Court to decide as quickly as it can whether the federal health care law is, in fact, constitutional and to consider what other parts of the law should be struck down if the individual mandate does not pass muster.

headline: Life as a Runway: African Style Glows in Brooklyn
text: A salvaged shipping container may seem an unpromising showcase for cutting-edge style. But not to Hekima Hapa, who set up shop in one of the rectangular spaces scattered throughout the Dekalb Market in Brooklyn on Saturday.

headline: The Conflict Between Global Companies and Local Laws
text: In the context of financial institutions, it is widely understood that the nation-by-nation approach to dealing with failing banks through laws like the Orderly Liquidation Authority of Title II of the Dodd-Frank Act really does not work. There is no such thing as a purely domestic “too big to fail” financial institution.

headline: BP to Drill Again in the Gulf of Mexico
text: The Obama administration on Wednesday gave BP its first drilling permit in the Gulf of Mexico since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded in April 2010.

headline: An Accessibility Map for the Impaired
text: A new online rating tool to help people with disabilities evaluate the accessibility of restaurants, hotels and other sites was released this month by the Rick Hansen Foundation. The Global Accessibility Map was designed as an easy-to-use source for people with mobility, sight and hearing impairments. (Visually impaired users can access it using standard software programs that convert text into audible content.)

headline: Adele Is No.1, Yet Again
text: Adele continued to dominate the music charts with what is far and away the most popular album of the year as her “21” (XL/Columbia) album rose once again to the No. 1 slot on the Billboard album chart.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg Welcomes Yelp to New York
text: On Wednesday, Mayor Michael Bloomberg went to Union Square to welcome Yelp, the latest Silicon Valley company to put down roots in Manhattan.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 40
text: Are the Occupy Wall Street protesters the modern-day equivalent of wandering serfs in 14th-century Britain? Or are they a bunch of grubby lowlifes and ex-cons? [Metro Focus, New York Post]

headline: Artifacts | Frances Stark’s Best Thing
text: Some people like to talk during sex. Others get their kicks by talking about it. And then there are those who would rather just watch.

headline: F.T.C. Claims Abusive Tactics by Two Debt Collection Firms
text: In tough economic times, with many people out of work and struggling to pay their bills, it’s no surprise that debt collectors are out in force. But recently, the Federal Trade Commission moved to shut down two California-based operators that handled collections nationally, including one that is accused of using tactics so egregious that they resemble scenes from a film noir script.

headline: My Three Favorite Tumblrs
text: To my mind, the blogging tool Tumblr is far superior to any other on the Internet. It’s simple, easy to customize and has built a great sense of community. Apparently I’m not the only one to feel this way. Tumblr passed 10 billion page views last month, up nine billion from last year.

headline: Pinker on Reason and Morality
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

headline: Put Me In, Coach! Getting in the Quantitative Game with Fantasy Football
text: Overview | How do we measure individual and team success in sports? How can we use multiple factors to project future performance? In this lesson, students use statistical analyses and quantitative evaluations to get the edge in fantasy football. By looking at data, measuring matchups and making projections, students put their analytic skills to the test in fantasy sports competitions.

text: 6:19 p.m. | Updated

text: Lens: Nina Berman Occupy

headline: In Denver, Obama Asks Students for Support
text: DENVER — President Obama on Wednesday ended a three-day Western trip that was heavier on politics than policy, rallying thousands of college students whose enthusiasm belied the struggle he will have to win this state again in 2012.

headline: Defectors Claim Attack That Killed Syria Soldiers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A force of Syrian Army defectors claimed responsibility for a Wednesday attack that killed a military officer and eight soldiers in central Syria, another signal that disaffected troops are taking a larger role in the antigovernment uprising and pushing it into more violence after months of a brutal government crackdown.

headline: Perry Won’t Back Confederate Plates in Texas
text: Gov. Rick Perry said Wednesday that he did not support a proposal to create license plates in Texas bearing the Confederate flag, ending speculation over where he stood on an issue that risked becoming divisive in his home state.

headline: A Profession Lands a Starring Role in Literature About the Theater
text: ACTORS often make cameo appearances in novels, and the theater frequently serves as a bloodstained backdrop for murder mysteries. Yet excellent novels about the art of acting will scarcely fill a shelf. In addition to “Lucky Break,” here are five of the best in English.

headline: The Controversial Cartoons of Pi San
text: Controversial animations from the Chinese blogger Pi San.

headline: Where an Internet Joke Is Not Just a Joke
text: The cellphone vibrated softly, insistently, echoing off the whitewashed walls of the artist’s studio. It was a Sunday morning in early April, and Wang Bo — an Internet animator better known to his legions of online fans by his nickname, Pi San — ignored the call at first. He wanted no intrusions. A compact 40-year-old with short-cropped hair and arched eyebrows that give him a look of permanent bemusement, Pi San is most famous for creating a mischievous cartoon character named Kuang Kuang, but he earns money by making animations for corporations, and he was on a deadline. Pi San had bicycled to his studio in a defunct factory building on the outskirts of Beijing that morning, hoping to finish up some work in peace. But the buzzing of the phone didn’t stop.

headline: Afghan Leader’s Invitation Could Reopen Doors for Former U.S. Commander
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai has invited retired Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, who led NATO troops here in 2009 and 2010, to Afghanistan, and General McChrystal plans to make the visit in the next few weeks, Afghan and American officials said.

headline: ‘The Journals of Spalding Gray’
text: The following entries span five decades of Spalding Gray’s life and are culled from The Journals of Spalding Gray. The book is organized chronologically by decade. Each decade is given its own prologue, a passage from Gray’s private writing from that time that offers a glimpse of this era in his life.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Thailand, Yemen, Turkey and Libya.

headline: Fox and CBS Share the Spoils
text: Another Tuesday, another ratings split between Fox and CBS, with the former seizing the 18-to-49-year-old demographic and the latter reaching the highest overall viewership.

headline: Democrats’ First Offer: Up to $3 Trillion for Debt
text: WASHINGTON — Faced with an approaching deadline and increasing skepticism about Congress’s ability to accomplish the task before it, Democrats on a special Congressional committee assigned to reduce the nation’s debt load on Wednesday made their first offer to Republicans based on earlier budget talks that ultimately collapsed.

text: T challenges 10 designers to turn everyday objects into killer Halloween costumes.

headline: Iranian, Refusing to Play Israeli, Expelled From Chess Meet
text: PARIS — One of Iran’s top grandmasters was expelled from an international chess tournament on Tuesday after he refused to play a match against an Israeli opponent, the director of the tournament said.

headline: TimesCast | October 26, 2011
text: Occupy protests in Oakland, Calif., and Atlanta lead to crackdowns and arrests; severe flooding in Bangkok; and almost 90 percent of Americans do not trust the government to turn the economy around.

headline: New York Metro Area Has Highest Inequality in Country
text: It’s probably no wonder that the “Occupy” movement began with Wall Street: the New York metropolitan area has the highest inequality in the country, according to a new report from the Census Bureau.

headline: The Caucus | Mitt Romney's Endorsements
text: Mitt Romney is in Virginia stumping for cash, but also endorsements. But how much support from elected officials actually benefit his campaign?

headline: Kirstie Alley May Lead ‘Hollywood Whores’ to Broadway
text: The musician Lance Bass is aiming a new play, “The Fabulous Lies of Hollywood Whores,” for Broadway in spring 2012, with the television celebrity Kirstie Alley in negotiations to play a demanding diva who uses a Los Angeles department store as cover for her high-end escort service, an executive involved with the production said on Wednesday.

headline: To Be Young, Hip and Mormon
text: WITH his manly stubble, flannel shirt and skinny black jeans, Brandon Flowers looks every bit the hipster front man for his rock band, the Killers.

headline: Beware the Upper West Side Glasses-Cruncher
text: An unrepentant spectacle-stomper appears to be roaming the Upper West Side.

headline: New Tool Helps Evaluate Student Loan Options
text: Worried about paying back your student loans? The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau now offers an online “student debt repayment assistant” tool that can help you evaluate possible options.

headline: Mudslides and Flooding Ravage Areas of Scenic Beauty in Italy
text: ROME — Flailing through mounds of sludge left by torrential rains, rescue workers cleared debris and hunted for survivors in Tuscany and Liguria on Wednesday after mudslides and flooding left at least six people dead and hundreds homeless in those areas, among the most picturesque in Italy.

text: Lens: Nan Goldin refer

headline: Architect Hopes to Build a Dubai Home for Herbie the Love Bug
text: The architect Graham Henderson is a fan of Herbie, the star of the 1968 Disney film “The Love Bug.” Mr. Henderson, who is based in Dubai, claims to own a replica of the Volkswagen Beetle, No. 53, used in the film.

headline: Sister Slips Away, Under Her Camera’s Gaze, in Update of Bergman
text: The blood has been drained from Ingmar Bergman’s “Cries and Whispers” in Ivo van Hove’s clinical stage adaptation of the celebrated film, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of the Next Wave Festival. The saturated reds that were a stylistic hallmark — and a symbolic one — of Bergman’s movie are nowhere to be seen in Mr. van Hove’s cooler, more diffuse examination of the agonies of a woman’s death and its impact on her two sisters and the devoted maid who attends her.

headline: Some Losers in Consumer Reports Reliability Survey Are Winners in Showrooms
text: The Consumer Reports Annual Auto Reliability Survey, released on Tuesday afternoon, is intended to provide shoppers with a sense of the projected reliability of new models. But as the sales of some new cars indicate, a poor showing in the study does not translate to poor performance in the marketplace.

headline: Study Shows Why It’s Hard to Keep Weight Off
text: For years, studies of obesity have found that soon after fat people lost weight, their metabolism slowed and they experienced hormonal changes that increased their appetites. Scientists hypothesized that these biological changes could explain why most obese dieters quickly gained back much of what they had so painfully lost.

headline: Bloomberg Conducts
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg led the resident Encores! Orchestra in the National Anthem at the reopening of New York City Center.

headline: A Welcome Windows Phone
text: Did you hear the news? A new model of a certain black, rectangular, touch-screen smartphone has just arrived. Its new software contains what the company says are hundreds of new features. The most eye-popping enhancement is speech recognition: you can tell this new phone to call someone, text someone or give you driving directions.

headline: Edible Selby | Boon Boxes
text: As the creative director of Chez Panisse, the Kyoto, Japan-born chef Sylvan Mishima Brackett learned a thing or two about catering intimate events with élan. Add to this his mother’s down-to-earth cooking and the artful presentation at the restaurants where he apprenticed in Japan, and you’ve got the influences behind Peko-Peko, the catering business Brackett opened in 2008. “I wanted to cook food that was relaxed and delicious and easy to appreciate,” he says. Brackett has gained a following with his seasonal bento — dishes include pickled plum, Dungeness crab rice and miso-cured black cod — delivered in bamboo husk boxes. Go to interactive feature >>

headline: Kenyan Motives in Somalia Predate Recent Abductions
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Kenyan government revealed on Wednesday that its extensive military foray into Somalia this month to battle Islamist militants was not simply a response to a wave of recent kidnappings, as previously claimed, but was actually planned far in advance, part of a covert strategy to penetrate Somalia and keep the violence in one of Africa’s most anarchic countries from spilling into one of Africa’s most stable.

headline: Interior Backs Mining Limits Near Grand Canyon
text: The Obama administration issued an environment impact statement on Wednesday for its proposed 20-year extension of a moratorium on new mining claims in a million-acre buffer zone around the Grand Canyon.

headline: TimesCast | Floodwaters Rise In Thailand
text: October 26, 2011 — As Thailand faces the heaviest flooding in 50 years, some neighborhoods are sacrificed.

headline: For Children’s Sake, Taking to the Streets
text: MALKA LUBELSKI marched for economic justice last Sunday dressed as Minnie Mouse.

headline: Skelos and Baldwin Get in Each Other’s Faces Over Taxes, via Twitter
text: The State Senate majority leader, Dean G. Skelos, has faced ample criticism over his opposition to an income-tax surcharge on high-earning New Yorkers.

headline: For Coffee Fans, a Collection of Virtual Treasure Maps
text: The rise of coffee houses has been a blessing and a curse for coffee lovers. If you’re far from your favorite spot, the search for a decent replacement can be excruciating.

headline: ‘Pauline Kael: A Life in the Dark’
text: In addition to her growing dissatisfaction with the run of new movies, Pauline was not particularly happy with her situation at The New Yorker. She continued to do battle with William Shawn over tone and language in her copy, and after more than ten years of the same arguments, she was suffering from battle fatigue. Shawn, for his part, was just as exasperated as he once had been about Pauline’s insistence on using sexual and scatological language that he deemed inappropriate for the magazine. Their arguments had lost none of their sting over the years; as always, Pauline seemed to enjoy pushing Shawn to the limits, trying to find a crack in his gentlemanly decorum. “I can remember a couple of times, at least, seeing him turn so red when they would start arguing,” remembered William Whitworth, who served as Pauline’s immediate editor for a time in the 1970s. “She would never let it go. Shawn had had a heart attack, and I thought a couple of times that he might fall over on the floor right there in the office. She was the only person in the process whodidn’t treat him the way the world of journalism did, and the way the rest of us did, as a very special little person — which he was. She treated him like one of the guys and talked to him that way, with a lot of wisecracks.”

headline: Trial Run
text: REMOVING nail polish, at least with solutions containing acetone or similar solvents, is a smelly business (and can be irritating to skin and lungs, according to the Environmental Working Group, a nonprofit advocacy group).

headline: The ’70s, as Dramatic as a Movie
text: At the imperial zenith of her career, Pauline Kael labeled a film “the most virtuoso example of sophisticated kaleidoscopic farce that American moviemakers have ever come up with.” This was in the midst of the 1970s, a period that Kael’s sharpest protégé, James Wolcott, now calls “the feudal age of film criticism.” That era is due for new scrutiny with the publication of three new books about the period. Each has a lot to say, though none entirely explain Kael’s heady assessment, above, of the 1975 film “Shampoo.”

headline: A Renovated Duplex Penthouse in Hong Kong
text: The city’s market has fluctuated as the government has taken steps to control runaway prices.

headline: Finally, the Web at Hand
text: NEXT week, the first issue of a glossy magazine from the editors of Style.com, with the puzzling name of Style.com/Print, will hit newsstands. The cover shows a close-up of Lindsey Wixson, the model from Kansas with the strawberry-shaped smoocher, framed by a thick lipstick-red border. There are no teasers about what’s inside, just a quote from Ms. Wixson that suggests she will never be known as the Joan Didion of her trade.

headline: Computer Nerd Creates Superhero Showdown
text: The most expensive Bollywood movie ever made, “Ra.One,” a sci-fi superhero thriller, is a kind of entertainment machine set to dazzle, Hindi cinema with a crush on high-tech.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Oct. 27
text: Graphic statement sweaters; a Patrik Ervell pop-up shop; and Halloween makeup.

headline: The Challenges of Prosecuting Rajat Gupta
text: The indictment of Rajat K. Gupta on conspiracy and securities fraud charges presents the Justice Department with new challenges it has not faced in prosecuting other cases involving insider trading by the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam. Wiretaps of Mr. Rajaratnam played a key role in his own conviction, but whether they will be admissible in court against Mr. Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs director, will be a key point that could tip the balance of the case.

headline: For a Boy Born Different, Sports as Salvation
text: Cleaving to the sports-as-salvation playbook with more fastidiousness than creativity, “The Hammer” offers a sincere but wearyingly formulaic portrait of triumph over adversity.

headline: Original Model T | David Reinfurt
text: Reinfurt's T sways in a breeze of his own making.

headline: That Merit-Based Aid Offer Is Final, Universities Insist
text: At Purdue University, merit-based financial aid offers are final and nonnegotiable. “We put that on our Web site — in red,” said Pamela Horne, dean of admissions and associate vice provost for enrollment management at Purdue, speaking on a panel titled “Merit Aid Negotiation” on Wednesday as part of this year’s College Board conference in New York.

headline: House Hunting in ... Hong Kong
text: A RENOVATED DUPLEX PENTHOUSE IN HONG KONG

headline: Scene City: At a Museum, Screams of Delight
text: Art denizens try Carsten Höller’s experiential art at V.I.P. opening and dinner.

headline: Crackdown on Oakland’s Protesters Is Felt in Zuccotti Park
text: News from the West Coast began pouring into Zuccotti Park on Tuesday via telephone, text message and Twitter feed: the Oakland, Calif., encampment was being evicted.

headline: Andrea Electronics; Big Data; stylish hard drives; tech news.
text: Doug Andrea, the chief executive of Andrea Electronics, discusses his company’s 75-year history in the audio industry. Quentin Hardy, the deputy technology editor of The Times, explains what “Big Data” is and how it’s being used to put online advertisements in front of people. The weekly news roundup includes Nokia and Microsoft’s new mobile phone venture, Netflix’s continued woes, a new round of “Grand Theft Auto,” and computer scientists cracking the cipher of an 18th-century manuscript. The Tip of the Week offers a quick way to clean up old bookmarks in Firefox.

headline: Fashion’s Digital Future
text: 8:26 p.m. | Updated

headline: Roundabout Extends Its Commitment to ‘Sons of the Prophet’ and Its Playwright
text: Roundabout Theater Company plans to stay in the Stephen Karam business.

headline: Can Islamism and Feminism Mix?
text: Oxford, England

headline: A Coast Guard Challenge: Arctic Drilling
text: As I noted in my article in Wednesday’s paper, Shell Oil has received several preliminary permits to begin drilling exploratory wells off the Arctic coast of Alaska next summer even as foes of drilling there argue that the severe conditions — ice, darkness, brutal storms — will make it impossible to properly respond to a spill or other problem.

headline: At a Museum, Screams of Delight
text: NEW YORK parties, where any number of bad things can happen to a sensitive guest, often provoke as much delight as anxiety. Tuesday’s opening of Carsten Höller’s funhouse exhibition at the New Museum was no exception.

headline: Double Seven
text: IS the stiletto-barbed meatpacking district ready to grow up and evolve from shrill to chill? That’s a premise behind the Double Seven, a reincarnation of the popular bar that sat on West 14th Street from 2005 to 2007.

headline: Seeking Reward, Giants Cornerback Found Risk Instead
text: LOS ANGELES — As an infant, Terrell Thomas climbed onto his mother’s coffee table and promptly fell through the glass top. In elementary school, he skateboarded down a flight of concrete stairs and ripped open a series of gashes that his mother said ran from his navel to his hairline. At the University of Southern California, he shredded his knee while playing football.

headline: Two Massachusetts Democrats Say They Won’t Run, Clarifying State Politics
text: Two Democrats announced decisions in Massachusetts today that drained a bit of suspense from the state’s politics. Members of the state’s House delegation who feared getting drawn out of their districts when one is stripped from the map breathed a sigh of relief as one of their own announced his retirement, and the Senate primary field narrowed.

headline: In Spain, Levante Is Back on Top
text: Spain’s Mediterranean coast is, for now, home to the top team in La Liga — and it is not named Barcelona.

headline: Lawmakers Seek Inquiry on Keystone XL Process
text: Lawmakers have called on the State Department’s inspector general to investigate the department’s handling of a crucial environmental study on the proposed Keystone XL pipeline and urged President Obama to delay a decision on the project until the report is completed.

headline: Unemployment’s Toll on Americans
text: Poll results showing the toll of unemployment on Americans.

headline: Brazil’s Sports Minister Steps Down
text: BUENOS AIRES — Brazil’s embattled sports minister resigned on Wednesday amid accusations of corruption. He is the sixth minister to step down in disgrace since President Dilma Rousseff took office in January.

headline: Making His Own Mark, Once Again
text: FANS of design have undergone something of a shift in the last few years, from unalloyed fascination with the beauty that design can produce to a more sober appreciation tinged with issues like pollution and exploitation.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 19 through Oct. 25 with 445 adults throughout the United States who said they were currently out of work and looking for a job.

headline: Facing Hardship, Jobless Still Say They Have Hope
text: The nation’s lingering unemployment crisis has forced many people without work to dip into their savings, borrow from relatives and do without necessities including health insurance, and most people who receive unemployment benefits said that the money was not enough to meet their basic needs, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll of jobless Americans.

headline: The Buzz
text: B OO! With Halloween falling on a Monday, fashionable hosts are not waiting to get gussied up. The party train leaves Thursday night.

headline: When Confidence Is Lower Than the Economy Itself
text: Distrust in government is at its highest level in recorded history. Americans are worried that the economy is cratering. Protesters in the Occupy movement are voicing the frustrations of an increasing number of people.

headline: TimesCast | Economic Poll
text: October 26, 2011 - The latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that almost 90% of Americans distrust the government to turn the economy around.

headline: Perry May Curtail Role in Coming Debates
text: A spokesman for Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, raised the possibility on Wednesday that Mr. Perry might not participate in all of the contest’s upcoming debates.

headline: New York Times Poll on Unemployment
text: Despite enduring hardships and being even more pessimistic about the nation’s economy than the general public, unemployed Americans remained optimistic about eventually landing a job.

headline: Destroying Houses to Save Cities
text: Are banks helping or hurting a community by bulldozing foreclosed property?

headline: More Trading Helps Nasdaq Meet Forecast
text: The Nasdaq OMX Group, the exchange operator, posted third-quarter earnings on Wednesday that matched estimates, as an increase in trading helped its revenue.

headline: Nan Goldin at Matthew Marks
text: Ms. Goldin’s multimedia project “Scopophilia” — a term that means “love of looking” — pairs her photos with photos of works from the Louvre.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Big Data
text: Just what is “Big Data” and why is it such a big business? Quentin Hardy, a deputy technology editor at The Times, discusses his recent Bits blog post on the topic — and why it might be a good idea for future college students to consider a major in statistics.

headline: Homes for $485,000
text: A Carpenter Gothic house in Maine, an Arts and Crafts house in Kansas City, Mo., and a modern house in Colorado.

headline: The Look of Love
text: The artist Nan Goldin has not lived full time in New York for several years, so the tiny apartment she keeps on West 14th Street feels more like a dorm room than a home, scattered with dog-eared books and mementos and a beaten-up scale model of the Matthew Marks Gallery, where a show of new work opens on Saturday, her first solo exhibition in the city since 2007.

headline: Whose Plays? That Is the Question
text: To the Editor:

headline: What You Get for ... $485,000
text: BATH, ME.

headline: Occupiers, Tea Partiers and a Dash of Star Power
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tree Planting in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Complete Sports, Abridged
text: The Reduced Shakespeare Company is performing its “Complete World of Sports (Abridged)" at the New Victory Theater. Lorne Manly sat down with the cast for an even more abridged chat on sports.

headline: Mayor as Maestro: Bloomberg Holds His Own
text: Though Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg did not particularly wow critics in his orchestral debut Tuesday, two seasoned teachers of conducting who viewed a video of Mr. Bloomberg leading the Encores! orchestra through “The Star-Spangled Banner” said that for a rank beginner, the mayor acquitted himself pretty well.

headline: Bloggingheads: Does the 1% Matter?
text: Mark Schmitt, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and Kevin Williamson of National Review debate Occupy Wall Street and the top one percent.

headline: Once Booed, Clemson Quarterback Is Now Unbeaten
text: In this era of texting and Twitter and message boards, disgruntled Clemson football fans are old-fashioned when it comes to holding a quarterback accountable.

headline: Delayed by Injury, Giovanni Still Arrives
text: The Polish baritone Mariusz Kwiecien looked nimble on his feet, sang robustly and threw himself into the title role of Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night in the new production by the director Michael Grandage. Whatever one’s take on Mr. Kwiecien’s portrayal of a role he considers his calling card, his performance was a triumph of physical rehabilitation and artistic determination.

headline: On Location | Andalusia
text: A 10,800-square-foot house built on 120 acres in a sleepy village serves as a second home for a British couple.

headline: Seduction of Melody and Hint of Anger
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra and its audience are counting the months until next fall, when Yannick Nézet-Séguin takes over as music director. But Charles Dutoit, who holds the quaint title of chief conductor through the end of this season, brought the orchestra to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening and showed that it has by no means languished during his watch. Section for section, and as a unified whole, the ensemble produces a magnificent sound. And when Mr. Dutoit is in his element, in music that demands coloristic breadth, precision and high voltage, the orchestra can be hard to match.

headline: For High School Seniors, a Jacket to Keep Them Strong
text: At a convocation ceremony on Wednesday, seniors at the Eagle Academy for Young Men in the Bronx pledged to pursue a path to knowledge and serve as models for their younger classmates. To symbolize their commitment, they are given a navy blue jacket at a convocation ceremony.

headline: An American Minority’s Road to Rights
text: It may be the least-publicized revolution of our time but the one whose impact ultimately reaches the furthest, affecting the way our buildings and buses are built, the way our schools are structured, the way our businesses conduct hiring and outfit their work stations. It’s the disability-rights movement, and “Lives Worth Living,” a Thursday “Independent Lens” on PBS, reconstructs how it emerged and eventually pushed through the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990.

headline: TimesCast | Occupy Protests
text: October 26, 2011 — Occupy protests gain momentum, leading to crackdowns, arrests, and threatened court action. Updates from Oakland, Calif., Atlanta, and Providence, R.I.

headline: Dressing Up Power Lines Comes With Limits
text: VALSGARD, Denmark — Norbert Baars may not know much about art, but he knows what he likes. No one is going to mistake the big 90-foot pylon, part of a power line that crosses his dairy farm here in the hilly Danish countryside, for a Michelangelo or even a Calder.

headline: East River Ferries
text: To the Editor:

headline: Look Who’s Trashing ‘Jersey Shore’ Now
text: We find Beavis and Butt-Head where we left them — resiliently stuck to that dirty couch, watching their flickering TV, laughing with that combination of giggle and heavy pant. The products of heavy metal, collapsed family structures and inertia, they’re mischievous and susceptible, and not gumptious enough for real misbehavior.

headline: Massachusetts: M.I.T. Freshman Is Found Dead
text: A freshman at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, whose father is a Nobel-winning scientist on the faculty, was found dead in his dormitory room, the university said Wednesday. The death of the student, Satto Tonegawa, son of Susumu Tonegawa, is under routine investigation by the state police and the Middlesex County district attorney’s office. “There is no indication that there was foul play,” said Cara O’Brien, a spokeswoman for the district attorney’s office. Susumu Tonegawa, director of the Riken-M.I.T. Center for Neural Circuit Genetics, won the 1987 Nobel Prize for medicine or physiology. His son Satto, a prize-winning pianist, grew up in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Last month an M.I.T. sophomore, Nicolas E. Del Castillo, was found dead in his dorm room, a death that was ruled a suicide.

headline: Maple Leafs and Their Star Player Give Toronto Fans Reason for Hope
text: It is an old gag in championship-starved Toronto: “Go Leafs go ... and take the Blue Jays, Argonauts and Raptors with you.” That’s a bit harsh — the Argonauts last won a title in 2004, the Blue Jays in 1992 and ’93 — but the joke is really aimed at the team that matters most in Toronto, the Maple Leafs, who have not lifted the Stanley Cup since 1967.

headline: After 16,000 Miles, the Rangers Skate on Home Ice
text: When Rangers fans enter Madison Square Garden on Thursday for the first sports event at the newly renovated arena, they will find better sightlines, some upper-bowl seats seemingly cantilevered over the ice, interior corridors at least twice the width of the narrow old ones, luxury suites that look like Manhattan apartments, many more restrooms — in short, a vastly improved building.

headline: Tuesdays With Nan Goldin
text: Thursday’s Arts pages feature Randy Kennedy’s interview with Nan Goldin, who is known for her photographs of “life lived at full tilt, of addiction and physical abuse, of friends and lovers ravaged by AIDS and other afflictions,” as Mr. Kennedy writes.

headline: All That Authenticity May Be Getting Old
text: LIKE so many others her age, Casey Barber, 33, furnished her home with affordable basics from major retailers, pieces like that requisite “Ikea table that is still making the rounds after all these years,” she said.

headline: Ruth Madoff Says Couple Tried Suicide in 2008
text: On Christmas Eve 2008, two weeks after Bernard L. Madoff confessed to running history’s largest Ponzi scheme, he and his wife, Ruth, attempted suicide in their Manhattan penthouse.

headline: Movie for a Rained-Out Ballgame
text: ST. LOUIS – How to spend a rained-out night off in the World Series? Tony La Russa, the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, said he planned to see “Moneyball,” the movie about Oakland Athletics General Manager Billy Beane.

headline: An Eternal Optimist Plumbs Some Demons
text: “A professional Pollyanna” is how Amanda McBroom, the Los Angeles cabaret singer and composer of “The Rose,” cheerfully described herself on Sunday evening at the Metropolitan Room in her new show, “Strange Days.” Ms. McBroom, accompanied on piano by her longtime songwriting collaborator, Michele Brourman, fortified that image with a sturdy rendition of “A Cockeyed Optimist.”

headline: Sketching Out Euripides and Mother-Son Dynamic
text: The story has been told a few times now, but it bears repeating: Four years ago the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon struck out on his own, leaving the safety net of the New York City Ballet, where he was resident choreographer. With the former City Ballet principal Lourdes Lopez he created Morphoses/The Wheeldon Company, which was intended to be a dynamic home for artistic collaborations.

headline: In Spain, Creating a Back-to-the-Land Experience
text: CASARES, Spain — The curvy drive from the sleepy Andalusian village of Casares to Chris and Lisa Stone’s mountainside vacation home should take about 10 minutes—unless a herd of goats ambles across the road.

headline: Chrysler Workers Approve Pact That Adds 2,100 U.S. Jobs
text: DETROIT — The last of the major automaker labor contracts was ratified on Wednesday when officials of the United Automobile Workers union announced that employees at Chrysler had approved a four-year agreement.

headline: A Phone App to Keep Fans in Touch
text: Most sports events occur in stadiums or arenas, with defined boundaries and seats around the playing field. Marathons are different: runners race past the fans who line sidewalks, only to be replaced by more runners.

headline: Spending a Night With Ghosts Where Legislators Roam
text: ALBANY — In a black bowler hat and flowing frock coat, Stuart Lehman stands out at the Capitol. It is just past 5 o’clock, and around him state workers hustle toward the doors.

headline: American Cultural Group to Visit China
text: This is not your average cultural exchange. There are no obscure acrobatic troupes and no awkward high school students.

headline: Neglected Children, Messy Houses and Guilt
text: In case you missed it, the Working Mother Research Institute surveyed 3,781 women and issued a report called “What Moms Choose.” It quantifies a lot of things we know, and a few that we don’t. Here are a few statistics to throw out over dinner, if you belong to one of those families who have civilized, discussion-based dinners (I tell myself that will happen when the children are older):

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,473 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,805 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Record $20 Million Gift to Help Finish the High Line Park
text: Many visitors to the High Line, the popular park that wends above street level on the West Side of Manhattan, stop at its northern terminus and peer wistfully through a chain-link fence at the as-yet unreclaimed half-mile segment to the north. Until this week, the nonprofit conservancy that operates the High Line still needed to raise $85 million to finish the park and maintain it.

headline: Rebels Said to Find Qaddafi Tie in Plot Against Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — When Tripoli, the Libyan capital, fell, rebel fighters found secret intelligence documents linking Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to a plot by former members of Saddam Hussein’s military and Baath Party to overthrow the Iraqi government, according to an Iraqi official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Merrill Markoe’s Cast of Characters
text: The veteran comedy writer and author of a new book of essays, “Cool, Calm & Contentious,” has filled her Malibu, Calif., home with unusual statues, portraits and more.

headline: Angela Adams’s New Collection
text: Pathways, Angela Adams’s new collection of rugs, is made up of what the designer calls “organically shaped” pieces with patterns that aren’t immediately recognizable. Three of the tufted wool designs (Garden, left; Stream; and Woods) were inspired by Ms. Adams’s nature walks, and each is intentionally uneven, much like a natural landscape.

headline: Pieces Inspired by the Runway
text: Tina Frey, a San Francisco-based designer, started her company four years ago in her living room, making cast-resin tabletop items influenced by fashion. “A lot of my inspiration in terms of design and color is influenced by what I see on the runways,” she said.

headline: Sales at Buck House, Jensen-Lewis and Others
text: Buck House is taking 25 percent off all furniture and accessories Thursday, from 5 to 8 p.m. (a 1950s Italian brass and marble occasional table, originally $1,600, is $1,200); 1318 Madison Avenue (93rd Street), (212) 828-3123 or buckhouse.com.

headline: Hipcycle, a Place for Repurposed Goods
text: Andrew Sell, pictured, who recently started Hipcycle.com, said his ambition is for it to become “the Amazon of upcycled products.” If Hipcycle doesn’t yet have the sales or range of products of the online retail giant, its merchandise is at least more novel.

headline: Americana, Italian Style
text: “The idea behind Lance was the merging of two cultures,” said Stefano Bruni, an Italian native who started the furniture and accessories company with his American fiancée, Anne Arnold, earlier this year. “Americans have powerful symbols that Italians love, like a flannel shirt, a Hudson Bay blanket, a pair of jeans. These are age-old American traditions that inspired our line.”

headline: Childproofing: Crawling Your Way to Safety
text: AFTER we closed on our new house 10 years ago, we stopped by with the kids — ages 2, 8 and 12 — to show them the place. We were there for no more than 15 minutes when we heard a loud pop just behind us and looked, in horror, to find our 2-year-old holding a key pointed at an outlet.

headline: The Carpenter’s Carpenter
text: LARRY HAUN, who turned 80 in May, grew up on the wind-blown Nebraska plains, in a balloon-framed wood house with no insulation, electricity, running water or central heating. His first  “constructions” were a little house, a wagon and some shelves he made with orange crates and a curved-claw hammer.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Will installing stone countertops in my kitchen increase the home’s value?

headline: Merrill Markoe on Puppets and Monkey Portraits
text: Merrill Markoe, the veteran comedy writer who helped David Letterman develop the format for his late night television show in the early 1980s and who, for a time, was the show’s head writer as well as Mr. Letterman’s live-in girlfriend, has a book of essays, “Cool, Calm & Contentious,” out next week. The theme of the book, she said, may be being with crazy people in crazy situations. In fact, many of the essays are not only crazy-funny, but crazy-heartbreaking. Ms. Markoe, who grew up in Miami and San Francisco and intended to be a painter, writes about the narcissistic mother who belittled her work and a sexual attack when she was a 19-year-old art school student at the University of California, Berkeley, in the 1960s. And while she has been discreet about her relationship with Mr. Letterman, declining interviews when he was blackmailed for having an affair with a staff member a couple of years ago, she has a good deal to say about a fellow who sounds a lot like him here, although she calls the man in question Bobby.

headline: Akamai President Steps Down and Is Said to Want Top Job at Yahoo
text: If Yahoo wants him, David Kenny is available.

headline: Pipeline Plan Stirs Debate on Both Sides of Hudson
text: A debate that pits energy needs against safety risks is playing out in the New York region as federal officials weigh approval of a natural gas pipeline that would terminate in the West Village in Manhattan.

headline: Clearing Up Some Confusion About the New Federal Student Loan Rules
text: On Wednesday, President Obama introduced two changes to the federal student loan program that could affect several million borrowers. The broad outlines of his plans to encourage loan consolidation and assist people who are struggling financially are reasonably clear.

headline: Rainout Leaves Time to Tinker With Rotations
text: ST. LOUIS

headline: Nightmare on the Subway
text: Sunday Metropolitan Haunting...

headline: Dictators Get the Deaths They Deserve
text: San Francisco

headline: Crony Capitalism Comes Home
text: Whenever I write about Occupy Wall Street, some readers ask me if the protesters really are half-naked Communists aiming to bring down the American economic system when they’re not doing drugs or having sex in public.

headline: Officers Get 7 Years for Killing That Helped Inspire Egypt’s Revolt
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian court sentenced two police officers to seven years in prison on Wednesday for the beating death of a 28-year-old man whose killing helped set off the Egyptian revolution.

headline: In Brooklyn, Space and Light Meet Woodwork
text: PROBLEM: You like Midcentury Modern furniture and bright colors. But the dining room in your old house has its original walnut panels. It is formal and dark, and your husband does not want to paint it.

headline: Coaxing a 1910 Town House Into Midcentury Modern
text: A dark Brooklyn home with period wood paneling gets a contemporary look.

headline: A City Where Campaign Posters Can Promote Past Arrests
text: The next New York mayoral election is two years away, but prospective candidates are already busy raising money, lining up endorsements and, in some cases, burnishing their rap sheets.

headline: Deep Backlog Is Detailed at City’s Bias Watchdog
text: New York City’s watchdog on discrimination issues has fallen so far behind on its workload that it should consider private financing to compensate for chronic budget cuts, according to an audit from the city comptroller, John C. Liu.

headline: Detective Tells of Fatal Shots Fired at Car
text: Looking through the side window of Sean Bell’s crashed car, the detective grew alarmed as he saw a passenger reach for something. Then the man’s arm began to rise toward him. The detective said he surmised there was a gun at the end of that arm.

headline: Europe’s Debt Threatens MF Global, and Corzine
text: Jon S. Corzine’s return to Wall Street has run into a wall of turbulence.

headline: When Secrets Aren’t Safe With Journalists
text: Washington

headline: Romney Appears to Waver on Ohio Anti-Union Rules
text: FAIRFAX, Va. — Mitt Romney’s critics are quick to accuse him of being a flip-flopper on important issues, part of an effort by Democrats and his Republican rivals to establish him as a politician without a core.

headline: China Reins In Entertainment and Blogging
text: BEIJING — Political censorship in this authoritarian state has long been heavy-handed. But for years, the Communist Party has tolerated a creeping liberalization in popular culture, tacitly allowing everything from popular knockoffs of “American Idol”-style talent shows to freewheeling microblogs that let media groups prosper and let people blow off steam.

headline: N.B.A. Negotiations Yield a Glimmer of Hope for Full Season
text: Optimism, a rare visitor in N.B.A. circles in recent months, crept back into the room on Wednesday — slowly, cautiously and with muted fanfare. The lockout is not over, and a labor deal is not yet in reach. But it may be on the horizon by the weekend.

headline: So Much for the Nativists
text: Here’s a Capitol riddle for you: Representative Lamar Smith, one of the most reflexively anti-immigrant hard-liners in Congress, is sponsoring a bill to flood the agriculture sector with up to half-a-million visas for guest workers. Understand why and you’re well on your way to unpacking the nation’s dysfunctional relationship with undocumented immigrants.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Wrong Fix for No Child Left Behind
text: The revised No Child Left Behind Act that passed out of the Senate education committee last week goes too far in relaxing state accountability and federal oversight of student achievement. The business community, civil rights groups and advocates of disabled children are rightly worried that the rewrite of the law would particularly hurt underprivileged children.

headline: Some Cities Begin Cracking Down on ‘Occupy’ Protests
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — After weeks of cautiously accepting the teeming round-the-clock protests spawned by Occupy Wall Street, several cities have come to the end of their patience and others appear to be not far behind.

headline: James Lane’s Revenge
text: When James H. Lane led his brigade of Kansas troops into the town of Osceola, Mo., on Sept. 22, 1861, he seemed to answer a prophetic question posed by George Miller, a Missouri minister, earlier that year. When a young Missourian told the minister he was glad of the advent of national civil war, as Missourians “want a chance at Kansas,” Miller replied, “Does it not occur to you that it would also give Kansas a chance at Missouri?”

headline: Home Is Where the Jamba Juice Is
text: This month, Townies goes out of town, to the other side of the continent — Los Angeles.

headline: New York’s Redistricting Charade
text: New York’s legislative redistricting committee is holding public hearings around the state, but the exercise is a sham. The new political districts are being drawn in secret for one overriding purpose: to protect party majorities and incumbents, often for life.

headline: For Occupy Protesters and Police, Frustrations Mount
text: After a confrontation in Oakland on Tuesday night, frustrations are mounting for both the Occupy demonstrators and law enforcement in cities around the country.

headline: The Only St. Louis Pitcher’s Name That La Russa Got Right
text: ST. LOUIS — In all the confusion regarding the string of names that were botched and misconstrued in Game 5 of the World Series on Monday, the only one that was accurately conveyed from the dugout to the bullpen was the one that Cardinals Manager Tony La Russa and many others have had the most trouble pronouncing.

headline: A Stunning Fall From Grace for a Star Executive
text: Last year, Rajat K. Gupta delivered a commencement speech at the Indian School of Business, a graduate school in Hyderabad that he helped start.

headline: More Questions About Mammograms
text: Two years ago, a group of outside experts who advise the federal government raised a furor when it suggested that mammography screening to detect breast cancer early, when it is theoretically most treatable, should be scaled back. Now a new analysis published in the Archives of Internal Medicine, a journal of the American Medical Association, has found that while some women have their lives saved by mammograms, a vast majority found to have tumors do not benefit — probably because they have slow-growing cancers that would never have killed them or could have been treated at a later stage, or they have aggressive cancers that are deadly even if detected early.

headline: Iran’s Power Struggle Goes Beyond Personalities to Future of Presidency Itself
text: WASHINGTON — An unusual proposal by Iran’s supreme leader to eliminate the position of president has highlighted an increasingly bitter struggle within the country’s political elite, as the leader and his allies continue to try to undercut the powers of Iran’s ambitious president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

headline: In High Schools, a Critical Lens on Food
text: A commercial for McDonald’s fish sandwiches played in a classroom at Park Slope Collegiate one day last month as part of a class called the Science of Food. It was clear that many students had seen the ad — several sang along with the jingle — but this was the first time they had been asked to critique it.

headline: Stanford’s Estimated Cost for Science School Doubles
text: Stanford University’s proposed graduate school of science on Roosevelt Island carries a $2.5 billion price tag, the university said Wednesday, more than double its estimate just weeks ago.

headline: As Cain Promotes His Management Skills, Ex-Aides Tell of Campaign in Chaos
text: If Herman Cain feels his management skills are up to any challenge, some of his former staff members think he should have started with the disorder in his own campaign.

headline: Telling Court of a Scheme to Sell Arms to Terrorists
text: A Russian man accused of being a weapons trafficker was ready, willing and able to provide arms, training, money-laundering services and even political assistance to a terrorist organization that he believed planned to kill United States citizens, a former associate of his testified on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: After Carriage Horse Dies, Mayor Rejects Calls for Ban
text: Days after a carriage horse collapsed and died in Midtown, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday dismissed calls for a ban on the carriage industry, saying he could not imagine why “anybody wants to destroy something that is part of New York’s heritage and that tourists love.”

headline: New Offer for Sabathia in the Works
text: ST. LOUIS — The Yankees are close to completing a new contract proposal for the left-hander C.C. Sabathia, which they intend to present to him before he can opt out of his current contract, according to a baseball executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Thursday: Visibly Scared Out of One’s Wits
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s a lot to like in this puzzle, but perhaps my favorite part is that it allowed me to draw little pictures of ghosts inside some of the squares of this rebus. That wasn’t a completely original idea. Jeffrey Schwartz, second place winner of the 2011 Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament, drew them during the championship round and I thought that was a lot more fun than trying to cram the word GHOST into each square. Congratulations as well to champion Robert Mackey and third place winner Elaine Lippman.

headline: Absolut Celebrates Its 30 Years of Marketing to Gay Consumers
text: MARKETERS like to mark milestones, whether it is the 50th anniversary of the debut of “The Dick Van Dyke Show,” the 125th anniversary of the introduction of Coca-Cola or the 150th anniversary of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Now, a brand is about to celebrate something that typically passes unnoticed: the 30th anniversary of a media placement.

Analysts even suspect that Nuance, which has a market capitalization of nearly $8 billion, has licensed technology to Apple for the new iPhone 4S, though neither company will confirm that. But Nuance’s sky-high valuation multiple is a stretch.

headline: Little Team Back on Top in Spain
text: After spending fewer than 24 hours in second place in the Spanish league following Barcelona’s 1-0 win at Granada on Tuesday, Levante vaulted back into the top spot Wednesday courtesy of a goal by Ruben Suárez in injury time that enabled the small club from Valencia to score another big victory, 3-2 against Real Sociedad. It was Levante’s seventh consecutive win. Real Madrid jumped over Barcelona and into second place on the strength of its 3-0 win against visiting Villarreal.

headline: Employee Pleads Guilty in Fatal Crane Collapse

headline: Red Bulls Cash In on Playoff Chance
text: FRISCO, Tex. — The Red Bulls were riding a wave of momentum last week as they became re-energized just in time to salvage a spot in the M.L.S. playoffs. Still, their captain, Thierry Henry, had issued a warning that the team needed to play better if it expected to beat F.C. Dallas.

headline: George L. Sherry, Envoy and Well-Known Voice at U.N., Dies at 87
text: George L. Sherry, a former United Nations official who helped calm crises around the world — a role that evolved from his time as the leading rapid-fire translator of speeches by Russian diplomats in the organization’s early days — died in Manhattan on Friday. He was 87.

headline: Liquid Nitrogen Optional
text: Eleven Madison Park is a grand and airy urban palace of a restaurant in the Metropolitan Life North Building at the foot of Madison Avenue. The dining room has wide marble floors and soaring, double-height ceilings, and huge windows that overlook the leafy acres of Madison Square Park. It is among the most beautiful restaurants in the world.

headline: Teaching Doctors to Be Mindful
text: It was 6:40 in the morning and nearly all of the doctors attending the medical conference had assembled for the first session of the day. But there were no tables and chairs in sight, no lectern, no run-throughs of PowerPoint presentations. All I could make out in the early morning darkness were the unmoving forms of my colleagues, cross-legged on cushions and raised platforms, eyes closed and hands resting with palms upward in their laps.

headline: Can Romance Be Reduced to Pronouns?
text: Behavioral scientists have long known that humans, whether in the schoolyard or in a dimly lighted bar, have a tendency to subconsciously mimic the sounds, style and movement of others. Recent research, however, shows that this mimicry also extends to how we speak and write. Even the least important words we choose can say a lot about us.

headline: Herman Cain, Outlier
text: Herman Cain, the Georgia businessman who has never held elected office, is tied for the lead in national polls of Republican voters — or perhaps even slightly ahead of Mitt Romney, as he was in Tuesday night’s New York Times/CBS News poll. Mr. Cain has also led in most recent polls of the Iowa caucuses and the South Carolina primary, has taken the lead in Ohio, and is close to Mr. Romney in Florida. If all you had to go on was the polls, you might think that Mr. Cain was the favorite to win the Republican nomination.

headline: An Occupy Wall Street March to Support Those in Oakland
text: Hundreds of protesters in New York City marched on Wednesday night to show solidarity with protesters in Oakland, Calif., where the police used tear gas to disperse crowds a night earlier. About a dozen demonstrators were arrested in New York, the police said.

headline: Thousands Flee Bangkok as Flooding Spreads
text: BANGKOK — With government officials saying there was nothing more they could do to protect the capital from devastating flooding, tens of thousands of people were fleeing Bangkok on Thursday, jamming train and bus stations and clogging the southern highways out of town.

headline: Cities Begin Cracking Down on ‘Occupy’ Protests
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — After weeks of cautiously accepting the teeming round-the-clock protests spawned by Occupy Wall Street, several cities have come to the end of their patience and others appear to be not far behind.

headline: ‘Ra.One’ Dazzles and Disappoints

headline: Oct. 27, 1904 | New York City Subway System Opens
text: On Oct. 27, 1904, the first rapid transit subway, the Interborough Rapid Transit (I.R.T.), opened in New York City. The line ran approximately nine miles from City Hall north to Grand Central Station, then west to Times Square and up the West Side to 145th Street.The New York Times described the excitement among city dwellers for the subway’s opening: “For the first time in his life Father Knickerbocker went underground yesterday; went underground, he and his children, to the number of 150,000, amid the tooting of whistles and the firing of salutes, for a first ride in a subway which for years had been scoffed at as an impossibility.”

headline: Greeks Applaud E.U. Agreement to Cut Debt
text: ATHENS - George Papandreou, the Greek prime minister, on Thursday hailed his country’s latest bailout as marking “a new day for Europe and for Greece,” after European Union and International Monetary Fund officials reached a deal under which banks would write off 50 percent of the face value of their Greek debt, a major step toward working out an overall deal to safeguard the euro.

headline: No More Mr. Nice Guy

Then you nonchalantly grind them up in your garbage disposal. Something tells me you’re more like this guy than Frasier Crane.

headline: Lynda Barry Will Make You Believe In Yourself
text: Dorie Cox left her little house by the Fort Lauderdale airport at 7:15 a.m. on a Wednesday morning this past summer to take a three-train journey to Miami. The Tri-Rail zipped along beside I-95 into the city; the Metrorail took her past the hospital where her best friend died; the elevated Metromover looped, conductorless, around downtown and dropped her off at Miami Dade College.

headline: Do You Trust Your Government?
text: A new poll found that Americans’ distrust of government is at its highest levels in history. Anger resulting from a grim job market and growing economic inequality has fueled protest movements from Occupy Wall Street to the Tea Party, and American’s approval of Congress has dropped to 9 percent. Do you still have faith in the American government? Why or why not?

text: SAN FRANCISCO — Perhaps it should not have surprised corporate information technology departments that employees would use Dropbox, a service for easily sharing files among different devices by storing them in “the cloud.” But that did not mean they loved the idea of confidential files on a service they could not control.

headline: Cellphone Ban Is a Tale of Two City Schools
text: Five years ago, the city started aggressively enforcing its 1998 ban on electronics to keep cellphones out of schools, except for students with medical conditions. Yet today, students at most schools know they can get away with carrying their phones unless they flaunt them. It is the students at schools with metal detectors who pay a price for following the rules, by using trucks and bodegas to stash their phones for a dollar a day.

headline: Making Restaurant Recommendations Smarter
text: One of the neat tricks of the new iPhone 4S is how Siri, its virtual assistant feature, taps into the restaurant database of Yelp to recommend local dining options. When I ask Siri, “What’s the best place to get dessert nearby,” it grabs a list of a dozen purveyors of sweetness in my area, ordered by their Yelp ratings.

headline: Toronto Bans Shark Fin Sales
text: Shark fin soup will be off the menu before long in Canada’s largest city. After a frequently theatrical debate that included the flight of an inflatable shark around its chamber, the Toronto City Council voted this week to ban the consumption, possession and sale of shark fins.

With the so-longs and the take cares, Mr. Reed tacked on: “Let’s make a record together.” It was no throw-away.

headline: Paper Trail
text: Print may be dying, but not in the design world. The exhibition “Archizines,” at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London from Nov. 5 through Dec. 14, features 60 contemporary architecture magazines, fanzines and journals from more than 20 countries. The show’s curator, Elias Redstone, who writes the London Underground column for T’s blog, The Moment, collected the publications on his travels, compiling them first as an online project (archizines.com), with art direction by Folch Studio in Barcelona. But an exhibition of the print versions makes perfect sense: the power of the Internet notwithstanding, it’s more fun to turn real pages than digital ones.

headline: With Gupta’s Arrest, Insider Inquiry Goes Beyond Wall St.

headline: Who Benefits From Extra Day Off?
text: While the baseball world spends the day contemplating which team benefits from a washed out night in the World Series, there are many pluses in a day’s delay before Game 6. You can almost picture the Cardinals scrambling to install a new wireless bullpen phone system, with Tony La Russa wandering around Busch Stadium saying, “Can you hear me now?” The Rally Squirrel has another day to improve his first-to-third time. The Rangers can spend time being even pickier on what kind of Champagne they will stash in their clubhouse for a potential celebration. Is it better to spray oneself with ultra brut or demi-sec? Or perhaps a nice prosecco?

headline: Art Forgers Whose Victims Included Steve Martin are Sentenced
text: A group of art forgers who sold falsely attributed oil paintings to art collectors, and whose victims included the comedian Steve Martin, were sentenced on Thursday by a court in Cologne, Germany, Bloomberg News reported. Wolfgang Beltracchi, the leader of the ring, which since the 1990s sold dozens of fake paintings said to be made by artists like Heinrich Campendonk, Fernand Léger and Max Ernst, was given a six-year sentence; his wife, Helene, was sentenced to four years while her sister, Jeanette, received a 21-month suspended sentence. Otto Schulte-Kellinghaus, a fourth member of the ring, was sentenced to five years.

headline: No ‘Highway Therapy’ for Pepper-Spray Commander

headline: Drifting Along, Tumbleweeds Are Piling Up Across Plains

headline: Microsoft and Yahoo Equalize Health Benefits for Gay Employees
text: With open enrollment season in full swing, several big companies have said that they would begin to reimburse gay employees for the extra taxes they pay on health insurance for their significant others. headline: Facebook-Led Consortium Plans to Remake Big Computing
text: A consortium of technology heavyweights led by Facebook wants to fill the world with enormous low-cost computing centers, using the same collaborative techniques that created an explosion of software development over the past decade. In the process, they may also outmaneuver Google.

headline: Exploring Corn, Energy and Humanity’s Growth Spurt
text: I’ve been on the road, learning about damaging and sustainable agricultural methods (and a big corn-to-ethanol plant) in Iowa, meeting with hundreds of science-oriented high school students in Houston to discuss energy and innovation and speaking about how new opportunities for globally sharing and shaping insights and information can be a prime route toward sustaining human progress on a finite planet (and on a tight budget).

headline: A Passage to the Buddh Circuit in India
text: NEW DELHI – Since Tuesday I have been on a series of airplanes, taxis, metros, commuter trains and have walked through garbage heaps and dark unknown alleys in parts of the world I never dreamed existed. On the final leg of the trip Thursday morning I took a strange, motorized rickshaw from Noida City Center to the Buddh International Circuit outside New Delhi.
