text: A selection of breakthrough performances from the holiday season.

headline: At Lever House, Public Is Always Welcome. Except This Sunday.
text: Any day is a fine day for visiting the garden courtyard of Lever House at 390 Park Avenue, that midcentury Modernist “Mad Men” masterpiece that was beautifully rejuvenated a decade ago. Any day, that is, but one.

headline: British Monarchy Scraps Rule of Male Succession in New Step to Modernization
text: LONDON — The 16 countries that recognize the British monarch as head of state struck a historic blow for women’s rights on Friday, abolishing male precedence in the order of succession to the throne. But the possibility of a Catholic monarch will have to wait, nearly 500 years after Henry VIII broke with Rome.

headline: A Bouquet of Offerings to Test Uncertain Waters
text: DESPITE the overstuffed catalogs and upbeat marketing campaigns, it’s been a nerve-racking six months in the auction world. With all the uncertainty surrounding the financial markets, putting together the important November auctions has been a challenge for Sotheby’s, Christie’s and, to a lesser extent, Phillips de Pury. Those considering selling are wondering if the assets on their walls are safer there than the stocks in their portfolio. And collectors sitting on cash and eager to buy are asking themselves, “At what price?”

headline: Offerings To Test Uncertain Waters
text: The fall auction season features a conservative mix of works by tried-and-true artists.

headline: Another View: A Simpler Rein Than the Volcker Rule
text: Claire A. Hill and Richard W. Painter are professors of corporate law at the University of Minnesota Law School.

headline: The Look of ‘Immortals’
text: Images from Tarsem Singh’s action adventure film.

headline: It’s Gods vs. Mortals, and It Isn’t Pretty
text: THE gods may not be crazy, but they can certainly get a little angry. Some of their fury is on display when their turf is threatened in the film “Immortals,” a new interpretation of Greek mythology that blends dramatic landscapes with aggressive action, all in 3-D.

headline: As Casino Opens Its Doors, Pent-Up Demand Is Released
text: Shortly after 1 p.m., when the doors of New York City’s first casino, next to the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, opened to the public, Kim Franklin, 45, from East New York, Brooklyn, brushed past a security guard, extended both arms to ensure that no one behind her in line could pass and broke into a jog as she approached the escalators.

headline: Trick or Treat, Wall Street Style
text: This weekend, thousands of Americans will cobble together Wall Street-themed costumes in preparation for Halloween. (Pre-emptive note: dressing in a suit and tie and labeling yourself “The One Percent” is not as clever as you think.)

headline: Photo Replay: Oct.28
text: The Pan American Games continued in Mexico and many of the world’s best snowboarders and freestyle skiers performed in London.

headline: Accused Picasso Thief Pleads Guilty
text: Mark Lugo, the Hoboken, N.J., man who was charged this summer with stealing a Picasso drawing from a San Francisco art gallery — and whose lawyer said at the time that he planned to plead not guilty — has now pleaded guilty to grand theft, the BBC reported.

headline: November Release Schedule
text: All dates are subject to change.

headline: Protests Turn Violent in Tunisian Town That Sparked the Arab Spring
text: In Sidi Bouzid, the Tunisian town seen as the birthplace of the Arab Spring, crowds of angry protesters on Friday burned a government building, a day after video emerged of men ransacking the local office of Ennahda, the moderate Islamist party that won a plurality of seats in this week’s parliamentary elections.

headline: 1894 Roper Motorbike Aims at World Auction Record
text: It’s not the first-ever American motorcycle. That distinction belongs to its older brother, the original 1869 Roper steam velocipede residing in the Smithsonian Institution. But it may earn a superlative all its own.

headline: St. Louis Brewers Think Small
text: IN the late 1800s, St. Louisans flocked to brewery gardens to drink, play and socialize. Most were immigrants accustomed to beer as part of daily life, as vital as bread. Out of this enthusiasm arose Anheuser-Busch, perhaps the best-known large-scale brewery in the country. No matter its size, locals have remained loyal to the hometown company.

headline: Letters: Tales From the Safari
text: To the Editor: Regarding “For Now, It’s a Cheaper Safari” (Practical Traveler, Oct. 23), my self-drive safari to Namibia in November 2008 was an incredible experience. We arranged lodging but drove ourselves. We found our experience to be less crowded and also less expensive than a standard safari trip. ELIZABETH McCOURT

headline: Hotel Review: Tune Hotel in London
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: A Gothic Tour of Italy
text: VISITORS to Italy tend to seek its sunny, Dionysian side — vino, pasta, opera, cinquecento art, George Clooney on a Vespa. But, like a chilly draft on a hot day, Italy’s gothic angle offers intimations of darkness that make a moment on the piazza even more delicious. Consciously or not, anyone sipping prosecco at sunset in Rome or Naples savors an extra spoon of dolce in their vita thanks to the contrast between the beauty of the present and the proximity of catacombs, ruins and sites of ancient suffering.

headline: Frank Lloyd Wright’s Wisconsin
text: WHEN I told my friends that I was planning a family vacation in Wisconsin, I received either blank stares or teasing comments about the admittedly unsexy specialties for which the state is known. There was mention of cows and cornfields and cheese curds. Yet Wisconsin is also Frank Lloyd Wright country, the place where he was born and reared and to which he kept returning. To travel there is to marvel at the contrast between the calm landscape and the delirious inventiveness of his work.

headline: In Anhui, China, Centuries-Old Charm
text: JUST 250 or so miles to the west of the gleaming high-rises of Shanghai sits a window into a world hundreds of years old. Despite the dramatic upheavals brought by war, the Cultural Revolution and industrialization, the hamlet of Xidi, in the mountainous province of Anhui, along with other villages in the area, has managed to remain largely untouched since the late Ming and early Qing dynasties, starting hundreds of years ago. Wander the narrow, labyrinthine lanes and peek into the open-air courtyards of grandiose homes, with their wooden lattice windows, rock gardens, watercolors and calligraphy scrolls, and it can feel as if you are slipping back in time to the days of the Chinese emperors.

headline: ‘Harlem of South’ Revived in Richmond, Va.
text: In Jackson Ward, new galleries and shops recall the heyday of an earlier era.

headline: China’s Anhui Province
text: As more and more Chinese move to cities, the small villages of Anhui west of Shanghai offer a respite.

headline: On Frank Lloyd Wright’s Trail in Wisconsin
text: In Wisconsin, marvel at the inventiveness of the architect’s work.

headline: Exploring Italy’s Macabre Past
text: Italy’s gothic angle offers intimations of darkness that make a moment on the piazza even more delicious.

headline: Leading Actresses to Bow Out of ‘Spider-Man’ in November
text: The two lead actresses in the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” who muddled through months of backstage drama and script changes last winter, will leave the show in November when their contracts expire, the producers said on Friday.

headline: Greek Anger on Debt Agreement Is Focused Especially on Germany
text: ATHENS — Every Oct. 28 Greece celebrates “Oxi Day,” or “ ‘No’ Day,” a national holiday commemorating Greek resistance to the Axis powers during World War II. On Friday, those celebrations took on a greater weight. As Greeks suffer from harsh austerity measures, there is growing popular sentiment here that the country has ceded key parts of its sovereignty, and its pride, to its foreign lenders.

headline: December/January Release Schedule
text: DEC.

headline: A Riveting Glimpse of a Vanished Bird
text: Two feet tall, the imperial woodpecker of Mexico once reigned as the largest woodpecker in the world. But aggressive logging and even poisoning by the lumber companies in its Sierra Madre habitat is thought to have driven the bird into extinction sometime in the mid-20th century.

headline: Lotsa Links
text: Great graphic about menhaden (bunker) from the Pew Environmental Group. Really gets the message across: stop overfishing!

headline: London Underground | Animal Estates, London Edition
text: Designers are used to designing for people, but what if the client was an animal? I’m not talking about designing a kennel for your dog, but rather homes for all the animals that are native to our cities, yet which are often forgotten. Can the birds and the bees, the kestrels and the beetles, all be accommodated in the concrete jungle? This is what the artist Fritz Haeg is encouraging us to think about at the “Animal Estates London HQ: Urban Wildlife Client Services.”

headline: The History of the World in 100 Objects
text: A group of curators aimed to tell the history of the world through 100 objects culled from the British Museum’s collections.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Gets Nostalgic for Christmas
text: Each Christmas shopping season, toymakers and retailers like to bring back vintage playthings, the better to appeal to parents – and grandparents – whose nostalgia for their own childhoods informs their buying decisions. For Christmas 2011, Toys “R” Us is bringing back vintage advertising.

headline: Stuff That Defines Us
text: London

headline: C K Swett Shakes Up Auctioneering
text: C K Swett has emerged as one of the most prominent celebrity auctioneers on New York’s busy charity circuit.

headline: CW Network in Deal to Put Shows on Hulu
text: The CW Network is on a digital licensing tear. On Friday, the network, jointly owned by CBS Corporation and Warner Brothers Entertainment, announced a five-year deal to put CW shows on the Internet streaming service Hulu.

headline: Brown Still Longs to Coach in N.B.A.
text: Like a moth to a flame, Larry Brown can’t seem to stay away from basketball. Brown, 71, last coached the Charlotte Bobcats, who either resigned or was fired, depending on the story, last season.

headline: Vertex Bests Merck in New Hepatitis C Drug Sales
text: Updated: 4:45 p.m. In the closely watched bout between two new hepatitis C drugs, it’s a knockout in the first round.

headline: Liu Hires Ex-Attorney General to Review His Campaign Finances
text: Facing pressure to explain apparent irregularities with his campaign fund-raising practices, John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, said Friday that he had hired a former state attorney general to review his books.

headline: Favorites of the Season, Cherished All Year
text: ‘The Nightmare Before Christmas’ (1993)

headline: Parm, the Torrisi Spinoff, Opens in Days
text: This offshoot of Torrisi Italian Specialties, opening on Nov. 7, taps the same Italian-American vein as the parent restaurant, but in a more familiar way. The new place, done with cute retro wallpaper, will serve chicken francese, baked ziti, garlic bread, an “Italian Thanksgiving” turkey dinner and sandwiches or platters of eggplant parm and meatball parm, refined in the hands of the chef-partners, Mario Carbone and Rich Torrisi. It will have a small takeout counter in the front, seats at the bar (a full bar this time), and tables for 30 in back.

headline: On Gawa, Swiftlets, Parasites and Limestone
text: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

headline: A Reality Check on Ambitious Climate Targets
text: An interesting commentary published in Nature this week explores what it would take to achieve California’s ambitious plan to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases 80 percent below 1990 levels by 2050. It is worth exploring here because it holds lessons that apply far beyond that state.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Happy Halloween
text: Our paperback list has the perfect book for this trick-or-treating season. “Batman: The Long Halloween,” at No. 9, is a new edition of one of Batman’s greatest adventures, with extra pages previously available only in a hardcover version. The story, written by Jeph Loeb and illustrated by Tim Sale, is set in the early days of Batman’s career. Gotham City is overrun with mobsters, and the colorful freaks that make up the hero’s rogues gallery are just starting to emerge. The mystery, originally told over 13 issues, centers around a murderer named Holiday, who strikes on a special day each month – whether it’s Christmas, Mother’s Day or Independence Day. He does not get a lot of panel time, but one of the creepiest moments comes from Calendar Man, who is housed in Arkham Asylum and does not enjoy the fact that another villain is stealing his motif of date-based crimes.

headline: Before Twitter, Name-Dropping Self-Promotion
text: IN 1801 a composer and cellist named Andreas Romberg decided to dedicate a set of string quartets to Haydn. “This dedication will surely not be unappreciated by you,” Romberg wrote excitedly to his publisher, “as it will doubtless promote the sale of the work. Now tell me if we don’t understand our public — or rather, the world!”

headline: Many Points of Entry to Music
text: LEON KIRCHNER, who died at 90 in 2009, was best known as a searching, formidable and vividly intuitive composer. But he was as complete a musician as America produced in the mid-20th-century: an excellent pianist, a probing conductor and a revered (if intimidating) teacher at Harvard. Students like Yo-Yo Ma and Alan Gilbert passed through his legendary seminar in the analysis and performance of chamber music.

headline: MF Global Put Up for Sale, This Weekend Only
text: 8:13 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Shoe Leather Never Wears Thin At This Cop Shop
text: IF ever a television series captured the gritty essence of police work, it wasn’t “Dragnet,” with its just-the-facts dispassion, or “Hill Street Blues,” with its urban blight, or any version of “Law & Order,” with its gruesome crimes.

headline: The Puppets Take Manhattan
text: Occupy Wall Street prepares giant puppets for the Halloween parade.

headline: Gunman Fires at U.S. Embassy in Sarajevo
text: A gunman identified by Bosnian news reports as a radical Islamist fired an automatic rifle at the American Embassy in downtown Sarajevo on Friday, wounding a guard and paralyzing the city during the afternoon rush hour before a police SWAT team wounded and arrested him.

headline: A Playful Occupy Halloween Trots Out the Puppets
text: As it’s grown, Occupy Wall Street has spawned many splinter groups – from Occupy Education to Occupy Museums. This week another, perhaps more playful, faction emerged: Occupy Halloween – “because the top 1% shouldn’t get all the candy,” as its slogan goes. A few days before Halloween, in a rented studio in Brooklyn’s Dumbo neighborhood, volunteers were busy assembling costumes and puppets for the Village Halloween parade, and for several pop-up events to take place around the city on Monday.

headline: Beninese Yelps, Norwegian Tongue Clacks
text: El Rego et Ses Commandos

headline: Pounding the Pavement, Beyond Manhattan
text: NEW YORKERS have been fleeing Manhattan in search of more affordable housing for so long that just about every neighborhood in the other boroughs has been anointed the city’s next great destination for bargains.

headline: The Best Investing Advice? Maybe Not the Conventional Method
text: WITH the stock market so volatile lately, investors have been asking how to ride out the swoons and maybe even outperform the major indexes. The answers — at least according to an analysis by one firm — do not necessarily conform to accepted wisdom.

headline: On Debates, Put Perry Down as a ‘Maybe’
text: CONCORD, N.H. — Will he or won’t he? Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who suggested this week that it might have been a mistake to attend all the Republican debates and that he might not participate in some coming ones, now says he could be open to attending more.

headline: Fresh Face and a New Identity
text: The Chrysler 200, in both its convertible and sedan forms, represents a significant step forward from its predecessor, the Sebring. But that’s not saying much.

headline: A White Halloween? You Might Not Be Dreaming
text: Either the calendar seems wrong or the forecast, but no, it really is true: snow is expected to fall on New York City on Saturday, and — at least for a while — stick.

headline: New DVDs to Warm Your Toes By
text: ‘Winnie the Pooh’ (2011)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Thailand, Turkey and Sri Lanka.

headline: Coming Soon
text: Images from some of the films coming this holiday season.

headline: In California, a Final Exam for Heavy-Duty Hybrids
text: Hybrid technology is working its way off road, and two heavy-duty earth movers, a bulldozer and tracked excavator, are preparing for large-scale emissions tests in California.

headline: Labour Party Leader Set to Win Ireland’s Presidential Election
text: DUBLIN — Michael D. Higgins, a veteran politician and author, was on course Friday to score a come-from-behind win in the race for president of the Irish Republic as his main rivals conceded defeat before the final tallies were counted.

headline: TimesCast | October 28, 2011
text: Greeks celebrate sovereignty, while questioning their dependence; Rick Perry may skip some debates; and Britain takes steps to modernize the monarchy.

headline: Cardinals’ Comeback Fuels Fox Victory
text: On Thursday, at least in terms of television ratings, the World Series was the only game in town. Fox easily won the night in all categories thanks to the St. Louis Cardinals’ remarkable extra-inning comeback 10-9 victory over the Texas Rangers in Game 6. CBS came in second despite seeing drops across the board, with “The Big Bang Theory” leading all other scripted programs at 14.3 million total viewers.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Thailand, Turkey and Sri Lanka.

headline: A Different Sort of Investment Strategy
text: In this week’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan writes about an analysis of over two decades of data on the performance of some 300 mutual funds. The idea was to determine which funds outperformed a benchmark — in this case, the Vanguard S.&P. 500 Index Fund — over that time.

headline: Books Unbound
text: Is any form of traditional media under more assault than the book? For half a millennium, it was happily contained between covers: easily understood by a child, disposable, nearly indestructible, demanding minimal energy, a triumph of economy and form. The Internet has upended all that, of course. Yet the strongest impression from several of the sessions at the Books in Browsers conference in San Francisco over the last two days is that while the off-line book might be dying, the online book has yet to be born.

headline: China Has Homemade Supercomputer Gain
text: China has made its first supercomputer based on Chinese microprocessor chips, an advance that surprised high-performance computing specialists in the United States.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review
text: DealBook, a well-known early riser, fell asleep before the seventh inning Thursday night, so we know how it feels to miss out on exciting developments.1 If you’re the type who worries about missing the latest deal talk, take a quick look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Touch of Evil: Eli Roth Recreates Infamous Experiment for Discovery Channel
text: The horror filmmaker Eli Roth’s gory “Hostel” helped to define a subgenre often referred to as torture porn. As an actor in the World War II revenge fantasy “Inglourious Basterds,” he played a vigilante soldier who beat Nazis to death with a baseball bat.

headline: From Not So Good to Not So Bad
text: TESTED 2011 Chrysler 200 Limited

headline: Released From Rehab, but Still a Bit Unsteady
text: AS Chrysler has tried to rescue its aged product lineup from the ravages of cost-cutting, bankruptcy and general neglect, some models have needed more radical surgery than others. The deficiencies of the Sebring convertible, for instance, were so encompassing that its upgrades included a new name. Say hello to the 200 convertible.

headline: Cardinals Won’t Have Holliday for Game 7
text: ST. LOUIS — Not only is Matt Holliday not starting Game 7 for the Cardinals on Friday night, he’s off the World Series roster entirely after severely bruising his right pinky finger in Game 6. Adron Chambers replaces him on the roster, while Lance Berkman — fresh off his three-hit, three-R.B.I. night with four runs scored — will bat cleanup again Thursday night.

headline: A Family of Italian Twins That Took a Different Approach
text: ASK a well-informed rider to name the venerable motorcycle maker whose gutsy air-cooled V-twins are a longstanding source of national pride and you might get this surprising, but correct, answer: Moto Guzzi.

headline: A Greek Politician Who Pushed Back Against Perks
text: ATHENS

headline: To Ban or Not to Ban Cellphones? Mixed Signals
text: The ban on cellphones in schools is not new, but it still inspires many opinions and hot debate. WNYC reported on the topic, and hosted a talk show segment on Thursday, and the callers and SchoolBook users are still talking. Listen to the report and join the discussion on whether the ban has run its course, and how some educators are embracing the technology in the classroom.

headline: Tempers Flare at Birthplace of Arab Spring After Some Tunisian Votes Are Nullified
text: Protesters angered by a local outcome in Tunisia’s first free election burned a central government building on Friday in the impoverished town of Sidi Bouzid, which is widely regarded as the birthplace of the Arab Spring.

headline: TimesCast | Greeks Question Debt Deal
text: October 28, 2011 - Greeks celebrate their sovereignty, while questioning their dependence on Europe for a financial bailout.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Frank Rich Discusses the Career of Pauline Kael
text: In Sunday’s Book Review, Frank Rich reviews two books that chronicle the life and career of the contentious film critic Pauline Kael: “Pauline Kael: A Life in the Dark” by Brian Kellow and “The Age of Movies: Selected Writings of Pauline Kael,” edited by Sanford Schwartz.

headline: Another Flap Over an Alleged Romney Flip
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Just days after Mitt Romney came under attack for seeming to waver on antiunion rules in Ohio, the former governor of Massachusetts drew scrutiny yet again for alleged shape-shifting. The issue of the moment? Climate change.

headline: Reassessing the Year Punk Broke
text: Remembering the year punk broke.

headline: Sonic Tattoos, Gingerly Reconsidered
text: IN 1991, the year Nirvana’s breakthrough album “Nevermind” (DGC) was released, the artist Andrew Kuo was a 13-year-old alternative rock superfan of bands like Nirvana, Fugazi and Dinosaur Jr. A year later he became obsessed with the film “1991: The Year Punk Broke,” which documented Sonic Youth’s 1991 tour of Europe and features backstage antics from the likes of Thurston Moore and Kim Gordon of Sonic Youth, Kurt Cobain and Dave Grohl of Nirvana, and Courtney Love.

headline: Staging, Ever More Virtual
text: FOR the longest time, if brokers wanted to “stage” an apartment to sell, they needed to buy or rent furnishings, wall covering, carpets and other interior decorations. Then, a few years ago, advances in computer rendering gave them a simple and cheap way to hire a virtual staging company to render those items into a photograph of an empty room.

headline: Five-Ku: Halloween Horror-Flick Haikus
text: First rule: When in aSlasher film, teens, don’t sign upFor camp called Camp Blood.

headline: Old World in a Big City
text: When Mary Theresa McCombe was growing up in Crestwood, a tidy 415-acre pocket of well-tended colonials, Tudors and Victorian single-family homes in a leafy neighborhood just west of the Bronx River in Yonkers, she often tarried on her way to and from school to admire one particularly stately Tudor perched on a double lot.

headline: Customs Tuned to the Times
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: Aftermarket Fluctuations
text: The Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show may lack the glitz of the boom years, but it’s still the place to search for the auto industry’s next big thing.

headline: What’s in Store | Carhartt Work in Progress

headline: Selling Pieces of Law Firms to Investors
text: Imagine an afternoon trip to a Wal-Mart: You pick up socks, a flat-screen television and a microwave meal. After checking out, you stop in the photo studio at the front of the store for a family portrait, and then shift one booth over to a lawyer, who drafts your will or real estate contract.

headline: Thrilling Series Game Scores a Ratings Victory
text: One of the most memorable World Series games ever played lifted baseball’s biggest attraction to a dominant ratings victory on Thursday night, the first time this match-up was able to crush (almost) all comers.

headline: Nelson Schwartz on the European financial crisis, Gretchen Morgenson on the foreclosure talks, Jim Collins and David Gillen on luck and business, and Christina Romer on Ben Bernanke’s chance for a “Volcker moment.”
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with Nelson Schwartz on the European financial crisis, Gretchen Morgenson on the foreclosure talks, Jim Collins and David Gillen on luck and business, and Christina Romer on Ben Bernanke’s chance for a “Volcker moment.”

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 28
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the opening of the first casino in New York City, a record-breaking gift for the High Line, and haunted tours through the State Capitol.

headline: Dead Sea Scrolls in Times Square
text: The history surrounding the Dead Sea Scrolls is the subject of an understated new exhibition at Discovery Times Square.

headline: 500 Words About the Common Application
text: A look at how we transformed an article about the Common Application to match the word limit that students face when composing their personal statements.

headline: A Young Bassist, a Young Pianist, Two Sets: So Similar, and Yet So Different
text: Derrick Hodge, a 32-year-old bassist, and Aaron Parks, a 28-year-old pianist, share a wide-open view of music making, an agenda of unfolding possibility. They both come out of jazz and still basically belong to it, though their output reflects whole-body immersion in R&B, gospel and hip-hop (Mr. Hodge); classically tempered indie rock (Mr. Parks); and atmospheric film music (both). For a handful of years they both worked in a band led by the trumpeter Terence Blanchard, an important mentor for dozens of musicians their age. But their aesthetic differences were what stood out at 92YTriBeCa on Wednesday night as each led his own band.

headline: Elastic Experimentalists With a Sense of Rhythm
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — During the making of “FAR,” the choreographer Wayne McGregor was surrounded by eight cameras and multiple cognitive scientists. As with previous works, Mr. McGregor invited scientists into his process and let them analyze his copious notebooks.

headline: Continuing to Play With the Tension Between Formality and Wildness
text: Two rows of delicate filament light bulbs encased in glass globes lined the entryways Thursday night at the Kitchen. They called to mind the lights in the Metropolitan Opera House that rise to signal a show’s imminent start.

headline: A Thai Restaurant Standby Comes Home
text: A FAVORITE offering in Thai restaurants, usually as an appetizer, is tod mun, little fried fish cakes scented with kaffir lime leaf. These spicy fish cakes are good any time of year and make a fine snack with drinks, served with a little dipping sauce.

headline: N.B.A. Talks Stall and More Games Are Canceled
text: Talks sputtered, games disappeared and frustrations simmered anew Friday afternoon when N.B.A. owners and players moved to the precipice of a deal, then squandered the moment. Any hope for a full season died when the negotiations did.

headline: The Scrolls as a Start, Not an End
text: Don’t expect to see the glittering marvels of King Tut’s tomb. Few artifacts at the provocative new exhibition at Discovery Times Square —“The Dead Sea Scrolls: Life and Faith in Biblical Times” — will inspire aesthetic wonder. Pottery, silver coins, iron arrowheads, limestone pitchers, scraps of parchment — such are the seemingly mundane yields of many archaeological excavations, and they are prevalent here as well.

headline: Kaffir Lime and Other Citrus Pleasures
text: What would we do without citrus fruits? Our cooking would be dull without them. But unless we live in temperate climates, for the most part we depend on their availability to be shipped from citrus-growing zones. So much for locavore leanings: sometimes we just need stuff from elsewhere. We need to be able to add a big squeeze of lime, or the grated zest of lemon or orange, to so many dishes, sweet or savory.

headline: Chic in Review | Thumbs Up for the Bieber’s Up Do
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Good Divorce
text: I NEVER wanted to get divorced. My parents’ split had been like an antipersonnel bomb, ripping everyone to pieces. So for 16 years, I stayed married.

headline: The Past Brought Into the Light: Breaking Down a U2 Breakthrough, Chord by Chord
text: Artists’ windy chatter about their creative angst rarely makes interesting listening for anyone but hard-core fans, and there’s a fair amount of it in “From the Sky Down,” a documentary by Davis Guggenheim about U2. But the film, showing Saturday night on Showtime, has a few segments that get beyond platitudes.

headline: Colombian-Style Chicken, Short Rib and Potato Stew
text: Adapted from Ana Jovancicevic

headline: From Colombia, the Ultimate One-Pot Meal
text: LAST spring, I had an elaborate Colombian dish called ajiaco at my friend Ana’s dinner party.

headline: Bargain Hunters, Hold That Click
text: ON Gilt.com, where shoppers vie for limited-time discounts on designer brands, a Kate Spade cabana-stripe medium tote bag was recently $169, plus $5.95 shipping. That same day, the bag was on KateSpade.com for $130 with free shipping — about $45 cheaper.

headline: And About That Corn
text: Corn season is waning, so if you can’t find decent ears of corn to make the Colombian chicken, short rib, and potato stew featured in “A Good Appetite,” feel free to substitute frozen corn. I’ve seen it sold on the cob in large supermarkets, and that is ideal here. But if you can find only kernels, just use about a cup of them in place of the cobs, stirring them in during the last few minutes of cooking. Also something to note: The corn used in Colombia, I’ve read, has larger kernels and is less sweet than what we typically get. But the sweet corn tastes wonderful, authenticity aside.

headline: One Wheel in the Future, One in the Past
text: Moto Guzzi’s current array of niche motorcycles are a throwback to the Italian maker’s rich history.

headline: Herman Cain Stumps in … Alabama
text: HOMEWOOD, Ala. — Herman Cain steered his unconventional presidential campaign on Friday to Alabama, where he submitted paperwork to appear on the ballot in the March 13 primary – a date deep into the race when all but the strongest candidates presumably will have fallen out.

headline: The Debate Over Routine Mammograms
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reviewing the Chrysler 200 Convertible
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Jerry Garrett reviews the 2011 Chrysler 200 convertible, a car that shares a nameplate but no body panels with its sedan sibling, reviewed by John Pearley Huffman.

headline: A Young Auctioneer Breaks Into the Gavel Clique
text: IN a dressing room at Cipriani 42nd Street on a weekday evening not long ago, a young floppy-haired auctioneer named C K Swett was circling the room, reciting a nearly unintelligible stream of words to himself. “Hey well all right sir here we go there and what are ya gonna give for ’em, I have a 600 dollar down here now 10 and now 25 and now 35 and now there 50 now 60 will ya give me 60 now 75, 75 another 85 dollars another buy ’em there,” he said in a jumbled patter, barely pausing for breath.

headline: Analyzing Steve Jobs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Victoria Anne Bonney and Joseph Kearns Goodwin
text: VICTORIA BONNEY was enduring a forgettable date in September 2009 when a close friend texted her, foretelling her fate.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 42
text: With snow in the forecast and Zuccotti Park newly bereft of gas generators protesters are stocking up on Mylar sleeping bags and bike generators. [City Room, Dawn Hoag via Twitter, Young Manhattanite]

headline: Leaving Bach in the Past, a Violinist Turns to Schumann, Franck and Bartok
text: With so much unaccompanied violin music of Bach on New York stages in recent days — Gidon Kremer played the Chaconne last Saturday and Jennifer Koh the six sonatas and partitas on Sunday — Christian Tetzlaff might have felt like the odd man out at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening. Mr. Tetzlaff devoted his recital to sonatas by Schumann, Franck and Bartok. But when it comes to Bach, he has been there and done that: two years ago he played all the unaccompanied violin works in a stunning marathon recital at the 92nd Street Y.

headline: Transcript of Red Bulls Conference Call
text: The Red Bulls decided not to hold a training session Friday, but will be training in Saturday’s predicted winter storm before playing the Los Angeles Galaxy in the first game of a home-and-home M.L.S. playoff series Sunday at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J.

headline: Sitting on the High Line, Watching the Actors Go By
text: Last Sunday evening in Chelsea, a man robed like an Arab sheik crossed 10th Avenue while gently swinging a blue suitcase. On the opposite corner stood another man who appeared to be a Hasidic Jew, ringlets dangling under his black hat. Just as they were inches apart, the suitcase popped open — and out poured packets of condoms by the dozen. The two scrambled to scoop them up, with the help of passers-by who were plainly stifling laughter.

headline: Undocumented Workers
text: To the Editor:

headline: This Sunday: Excuse Me While I Get Fitted for a Hazmat Suit
text: If you look at our cover this week and think maybe you have enough worries in your life without adding anthrax back to the list, I completely understand. I feel that way myself sometimes. But I urge you to at least read the first section of Wil Hylton’s story about the state of bioterrorism preparedness — it’s only 400 words — and I’ll be surprised if you don’t feel compelled to keep going. Yes, you’ll be a little freaked. Maybe a lot freaked. But Wil’s reporting isn’t just about the nightmarish scenarios that could befall us. It’s about what exactly the U.S. government has been up to since the anthrax attacks in the wake of 9/11, and the shocking extent to which we have wasted precious time and billions of dollars on poorly defined policy objectives and bureaucratic logjams. This is not merely bad news. This an exposé that ought to inspire a rethinking of the entire program.

headline: From Sneakers to Point Shoes, a Parade of Styles and Movement
text: At every performance of the annual Fall for Dance Festival at City Center the atmosphere is terrific. The theater’s crowded, anticipation’s high, and the stylistic diversity of each program is marvelous. On Thursday, at this year’s first performance, many of us were also discovering happily just how many features of the recently reopened theater have been altered and refreshed. What remains is the immediacy of rapport between stage and auditorium: City Center remains an exciting dance house.

headline: Officials at St. Paul’s Cathedral in London Move to Evict Protesters Camped Outside
text: LONDON — Officials at St. Paul’s Cathedral said Friday that they would go to court to force the removal of hundreds of protesters who have camped outside the cathedral for two weeks, demonstrating against economic inequality and corporate greed.

headline: Ackman Takes a Ride on the Canadian Pacific Railway
text: The billionaire hedge fund manager William A. Ackman has been working on the railroad — in particular, the Canadian Pacific Railway.

headline: A 7-Year-Old With a Very Developed Sense of Self
text: A fundamental problem with the new Fox cartoon “Allen Gregory” — though not the biggest one — is that it’s never clear what the show is satirizing. The title character is nominally a privileged 7-year-old horrified at the prospect of attending a public elementary school, but he’s drawn as a boutonniere-wearing dandy and talks like a supremely egotistical talent agent. He’s a little bit Stewie from “Family Guy,” a little bit Ari Gold from “Entourage,” a little bit Frasier and Niles Crane, a little bit Mr. Magoo.

headline: Exercise in Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Europe Tries to Lure Chinese Cash to Back Rescue of Euro
text: PARIS — A day after European leaders unveiled their latest plan to save the euro, top officials opened talks with China in an effort to lure tens of billions of dollars in additional cash, giving China perhaps its biggest opportunity yet to exercise financial clout in the Western world.

headline: Officers Jeer at Arraignment of 16 Colleagues in Ticket-Fixing Investigation
text: A three-year investigation into the police’s habit of fixing traffic and parking tickets in the Bronx ended in the unsealing of indictments on Friday and a stunning display of vitriol by hundreds of off-duty officers, who converged on the courthouse to applaud their accused colleagues and denounce their prosecution.

text: Live coverage and analysis of Game 7 of the World Series from Pat Borzi and other Times reporters and editors in St. Louis and beyond.

headline: They’re Not the Supremes, but They Know the Tunes
text: When you go to one of those shows that seem to exist only to be marketed to a certain age or ethnic group (like “Menopause: The Musical” or “My Mother’s Italian, My Father’s Jewish, & I’m in Therapy!”), your expectations may not be particularly high. But Dorothy Marcic’s “Sistas: The Musical,” now playing at St. Luke’s Theater, is a sweet and sassy if slightly rickety little show.

headline: After Waging a Seesaw Battle, France Wins the Senior Bowl
text: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands — At the world team championships here on Friday, France defeated U.S.A.-2 to win the d’Orsi Senior Bowl by 165 international match points to 160.3. Third place went to Poland.

headline: Cigarettes Are Enlisted to Test Ways of Quitting
text: When a truck recently delivered 45,000 cartons of cigarettes to a research company in North Carolina, it was a turning point in the government’s war on smoking.

headline: Groupon Weighs Raising I.P.O. Price
text: It appears investors are flocking to Groupon’s forthcoming initial public offering like customers to one of the daily deal giant’s coupons.

headline: For Cain, Reverse Is a Prominent Gear
text: HOMEWOOD, Ala. — Ask Americans what they know about Herman Cain and, of course, there is his “9-9-9” tax plan, made memorable through constant repetition.

text: Alfred, N.Y.

headline: The Cain Enigma
text: Sometimes life resembles fiction. Other times it resembles “Star Trek.”

headline: Little-Girl Time and Big-Boy Sports
text: David Kaplan is in the enviable position of running a museum that is not just thriving, but expanding by popular demand: the Children’s Museum for the Arts tripled in size when it moved to its new home on Charlton Street in SoHo on Oct. 1. Mr. Kaplan, 50, the museum’s executive director, lives in Chelsea with his wife, Elaine Lacognata, 40, a singer-songwriter; their daughter, Marae, 5; and an aquarium of tropical fish. He spends Sunday mornings roaming with Marae; in the afternoons, he blows off steam by boxing or playing basketball.  ROBIN FINN

headline: Patterson’s Response to His Appeal Dismissal, and Other Case Documents
text: Despite a recommendation by the Texas Board of Pardons and Parole that Kelsey Patterson be spared due to severe mentally illness, he was executed for a double murder in 2004.

headline: College Football All … Day … Long
text: If you’re at the game or on the couch and in need of real college football analysis or even some wisecracks — or have some of your own to share — Paul Myerberg and The Times’ Jeré Longman will be live-blogging all day on Saturday. Join the party and impress your friends.

headline: Bloggingheads: Tax the Poor!
text: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Rich Lowry of National Review debate raising taxes on the bottom half.

headline: A Former Leader Returns With a Signature Piece
text: Kurt Masur’s 11-year tenure as the New York Philharmonic’s music director was often turbulent. There were tensions between him and the players caused by differences in the ways that old-school European conductors and modern American orchestra players think about a music director’s power and prerogatives. But when Mr. Masur left New York, in 2002, the Philharmonic sounded vastly better than it had when he took it over from Zubin Mehta, in 1991. And whatever grievances the players might have had in the 1990s, they respond well to him when he returns as a guest (with the title music director emeritus).

headline: Students and Teachers Are Furious Over High School Scheduling Mess
text: Administrators met with parents and teachers at Long Island City High School on Friday to try to address frustrations over a problem that left many students with entirely new schedules, two months into the school year.

headline: Excerpt: 'Allen Gregory'
text: Jonah Hill stars as a 7-year-old sophisticate in the new Fox animated series.

headline: What a Family Faces After a Murder: The Terrible Mechanics of the First Week
text: There is a house on 91st Avenue in Woodhaven, Queens, that, with Halloween approaching, has fake yellow crime-scene tape strung across its porch. It reads, in spooky script, “Caution: Enter if you dare.”

headline: Wedding Etiquette
text: Gifts Galore
