text: Two weeks ago, more than 100,000 young people got an early start on Halloween at ComicCon at the Javits Center.

headline: Yankees Extend Radio Contract With WCBS
text: ST. LOUIS — The Yankees extended their contract with the radio station WCBS 880 to broadcast their games through the 2012 season, meaning that the announcers John Sterling and Suzyn Waldman will most likely come back in their same roles.

headline: What the Costumes Reveal
text: On Friday, the law firm of Steven J. Baum threw a Halloween party. The firm, which is located near Buffalo, is what is commonly referred to as a “foreclosure mill” firm, meaning it represents banks and mortgage servicers as they attempt to foreclose on homeowners and evict them from their homes. Steven J. Baum is, in fact, the largest such firm in New York; it represents virtually all the giant mortgage lenders, including Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Wells Fargo.

headline: Bank of America Rethinking Debit Card Fee
text: After setting off a firestorm of criticism from consumers, Capitol Hill and the White House, Bank of America is rethinking elements of its plan to charge customers $5 a month to use their debit cards.

headline: Set in Their Ways, but Still Very Flexible
text: DOMINIQUE MARTINET, 67, loves the noise surrounding her apartment in Manhattan, the roar of the buses, the conversations just begging to be overheard, the street-corner strains of music.

headline: 40 Killed Across Syria in Deadliest Friday Demonstrations Since May
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces killed at least 40 people on Friday during antigovernment demonstrations across the country, according to human rights activists, as the government of President Bashar al-Assad intensified a brutal military crackdown that has failed over eight months to extinguish a popular uprising.

headline: Are the Candidates in the Top 1 Percent?
text: All presidential candidates must fill out a form declaring their finances. The form asks how many assets and income sources the candidate has within certain ranges. Here are the ranges of each candidate’s declared assets and income compared with a threshold that represents whether they are within the top 1 percent of earners.

headline: Car Bomb in Aden Kills Yemeni Counterterrorism Chief
text: TAIZ, Yemen — The head of counterterrorism in the southern port city of Aden was killed Friday after a car bomb exploded beneath his vehicle, according to a senior security official.

headline: One Nation, Innumerate
text: Via Brian Beutler, Politico has part of George Will’s forthcoming attack on Romney:

headline: Mexico: 20 Killed in Shootouts
text: Twenty people were killed Friday in multiple shootouts in two states, law enforcement officials said. In Michoacán, 14 bodies were found in three different locations. Of these, 10 people died in the city of Pátzcuaro after a confrontation with soldiers patrolling the area. Michoacán has been beset by violence in recent years, much of it attributed to the Familia drug cartel, and recently the cartel’s turf war with a splinter group called the Knights Templar. In the state of Sinaloa, a confrontation between members of an organized crime gang on a highway left six people dead, three of them unarmed civilians.

headline: Fresh Food and Vintage Movies
text: Monday nights can feel slow in New York, as many spots take a day of rest after the busy weekend. But at La Gazzetta, the lively trattoria on the ground floor of Villa Pacri in the meatpacking district on Gansevoort Street at Ninth Avenue, it is a different story. On Mondays, it draws a crowd of regulars from the neighborhood, couples on first dates and families, for Cinema Italiano, its weekly screenings of classics like “To Kill a Mockingbird” and “The Godfather” — a hipper dinner theater for the downtown set — and for a menu offering Italian snacks, pastas and entrees. Last week, as the original “Casino Royale” with Peter Sellers and David Niven played in the background, a couple from London on their way to Buffalo and Toronto mixed business and pleasure.

headline: Selig’s Not Worried About the Mets
text: ST. LOUIS — Commissioner Bud Selig said the Mets, who borrowed $25 million from Major League Baseball after last season, still had not paid back the loan. But Selig said he was not worried about getting the money back.

headline: Italy: Emergency Declared in Flood Zones
text: The Italian government declared a state of emergency on Friday in areas struck by flooding and mud slides earlier this week, and allocated $92 million to assist residents there. Torrential rains and flash floods on Tuesday and Wednesday killed at least seven people and left hundreds homeless in coastal areas of Tuscany and Liguria, including villages of Cinque Terre, Unesco World Heritage sites. Rescue and clean-up efforts continued Friday, but were hampered by inaccessible roads and disrupted electricity, water and gas.

headline: Savings Rate Is Dropping, and Experts Are Puzzled
text: When the recession began, Americans began to save more of their money, prompting predictions that their financial habits might be changing permanently.

headline: Iceland Videos
text: The IMF now has videos of the whole thing posted.

headline: Victories and Questions Pile Up for Paterno
text: Penn State is in the midst of what could be a memorable season. The Nittany Lions are atop the Big Ten standings. And Joe Paterno is on the verge of setting the record for coaching victories in Division I college football.

headline: The Court and the Next President
text: The Republican presidential hopefuls have been saying alarming things about the federal courts.

headline: Live From Moscow: It’s Friday Night at the Bolshoi, Friday Morning in New York
text: The Russians take their gala concerts seriously. That, at least, seemed to be the case when the Bolshoi Theater celebrated its reopening in Moscow after a huge renovation, on Friday evening, with a program seen in a live HD broadcast at Big Cinemas Manhattan on the Upper East Side, on Friday morning.

headline: Study Finds Slight Decline in Veterans Using Shelters
text: Homeless veterans are most likely to be middle-aged white men with a disability. Younger veterans are more than twice as likely to be homeless than nonveterans in the same age group. And California has the most homeless veterans of any state, accounting for about a quarter of the nation’s total.

headline: Reads and Reactions
text: In this edition: a lot of Herman Cain and overly confident punditry, some crowded estimates and two more endorsed ideas about newspaper endorsements.

headline: For Their Own Good
text: The case for vaccinating all preteens against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cancer keeps getting stronger. After a thorough review of the evidence, an influential federal advisory committee recommended that boys ages 11 and 12 should routinely be vaccinated against the human papillomavirus, or HPV, echoing a 2006 recommendation for vaccinating girls of that age.

headline: Death Row in Pennsylvania
text: Pennsylvania ranks high among states that impose death sentences and low among those that carry them out: 208 men and women are on death row, but no one has been executed since 1999; only three people have been executed since the penalty was reinstated in 1976.

headline: Friday Night Music
text: Still loving this album:

headline: Not Just Another Wind Farm
text: At the center of a newly opened wind farm in central West Virginia is the largest battery installation attached to the power grid in the continental United States.

headline: America, Renewed
text: On Friday, a brilliant morning sun piercing their eyes, 125 Americans-to-be got ready to take the citizenship oath on Liberty Island.

headline: Despite Attention to Abuses, Disability Filings at the L.I.R.R. Remain High
text: More than half of the Long Island Rail Road workers who retired last year applied for federal disability benefits, a rate far higher than the national average, even as federal officials and prosecutors tried to stem a chronic pattern of abuse of the public benefits system by the railroad’s retirees.

headline: In Florida Battle, Casino Cash vs. Disney Image
text: MIAMI — The battle for Florida’s tourism soul has been joined.

headline: Riveting Series Caps a Scintillating Season
text: ST. LOUIS

headline: Batteries at a Wind Farm Help Control Output
text: ELKINS, W.Va. — Another wind farm opened on another windy ridge in West Virginia this week, 61 turbines stretched across 12 miles, generating up to 98 megawatts of electricity. But the novel element is a cluster of big steel boxes in the middle, the largest battery installation attached to the power grid in the continental United States.

headline: Man Accused in ’78 Newark Killings Goes on Trial
text: NEWARK — The boys worked for the handyman, but they were working him, too. They helped him with odd jobs around town, riding in the back of his green pickup with “Evans and Son” painted on the side. He paid them in small amounts of cash, or a sack of White Castle hamburgers, and sometimes, in marijuana.

headline: Fixated on What He Fixes
text: Peter Guggenheim has worked so long at Stuart Electronics that his feet have worn holes through two layers of tile and an inch of plywood, down to the floorboards behind the counter.

headline: Leader Picked for Review of U.S. Loans on Energy
text: WASHINGTON — The White House directed a well-known businessman on Friday to conduct an independent review of government loans to energy companies, as House Republicans announced they would consider subpoenaing records related to a 2009 loan to a California manufacturer of solar-energy equipment that is now bankrupt.

headline: Were New Yorkers Always Seen as Fast-Talking and Rude?
text: Born This Way?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Animation Gives an Edge to Streaming Services
text: One of the most popular options on Hulu, ranking alongside mainstream TV hits like “Modern Family” and “Glee,” is an animated series about an adolescent ninja and his pink-haired love interest battling a mysterious organization.

headline: William A. Niskanen, a Blunt Libertarian Economist, Dies at 78
text: William A. Niskanen, an economist who was dismissed by the Ford Motor Company after bluntly opposing the company’s embrace of trade protection, and who later served as a member of President Ronald Reagan’s Council of Economic Advisers, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 78.

headline: Convert Straddles Worlds of Islam and Hip-Hop
text: He was a “15-year-old white kid with Dad a diagnosed schizophrenic, rapist and racial separatist and Mom fresh off her second divorce,” Michael Muhammad Knight writes in his 2006 memoir, “Blue-Eyed Devil: A Road Odyssey Through Islamic America.” At home in Rochester, he “listened to a lot of Public Enemy and read ‘The Autobiography of Malcolm X’ and by 16 had a huge portrait of Ayatollah Khomeini” on his bedroom wall.

headline: Joy in Russia as a Symbol of the Arts Reopens
text: MOSCOW — The interior of the newly restored Bolshoi Theater was resplendent with sable and décolletage and claret-colored damask on Friday, as Russia’s new aristocrats leaned out from their balconies with opera glasses, hoping for a glimpse into the czar’s box, where the president was sitting.

headline: Nostalgia and Drama in Buck’s Game 6 Call
text: When Joe Buck punctuated the Cardinals’ game-ending home run in Game 6 of the World Series on Thursday night with the same line his father, Jack, used to call Kirby Puckett’s home run at the end of Game 6 of the 1991 World Series — “We will see you tomorrow night” — it seemed as if the moment had been scripted in broadcasting heaven.

headline: Corrections: October 29
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Dark Days for a Team Adrift
text: Outside the stadium where the Miami Dolphins play, a bronze statue of Don Shula shows him being carried off the field on the shoulders of his players. It is a tribute to a team of a much different era, when the Dolphins had the N.F.L.’s only perfect season and their defense was so good that it did not have to spend a week arguing about why it could not stop a goal-line run that everybody knew was coming.

headline: In Romney’s Backyard, Perry Highlights Abortion
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas came to what is essentially Mitt Romney’s home turf Friday and attacked him during a dinner speech for his position on abortion.

headline: Romney Fields Friendly Questions in New Hampshire
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Just hours before Gov. Rick Perry of Texas addressed a Republican dinner across town on Friday, Mitt Romney fielded questions from a largely friendly crowd here, offering up his opinion on matters as diverse as the price of gas and the Occupy Wall Street movement.

headline: YouTube Plans to Make Big Bet on New Online Channels
text: YouTube, making an expensive bet on original content, is planning to create dozens of channels featuring comedians, sports stars, musicians and other entertainers, the company said on Friday.

headline: Saturday: Producer of Shooting Stars
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s one thing for someone to think that we are immature. It’s another thing entirely for someone to say it in a crossword puzzle, and that’s what Barry C. Silk seems to be doing. Not once but twice Mr. Silk admonishes us to ACT ONE’S AGE and that it would be nice if we GREW UP.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 8’s Toughest Picks
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: What a Gentleman Wears to Receive an Award
text: When Wyatt Workman, the 8-year-old winner of an award for his work on ocean conservation (he raised nearly $4,000), was too bashful to come onstage at GQ magazine’s Gentlemen’s Ball, it was hand-delivered. The actor Josh Lucas leapt from the stage and presented it to the child, who was frozen in the audience on Wednesday night.

headline: America’s Exploding Pipe Dream
text: We are slowly — and painfully — being forced to realize that we are no longer the America of our imaginations. Our greatness was not enshrined. Being a world leader is less about destiny than focused determination, and it is there that we have faltered.

headline: Sports Medicine Said to Overuse M.R.I.’s
text: Dr. James Andrews, a widely known sports medicine orthopedist in Gulf Breeze, Fla., wanted to test his suspicion that M.R.I.’s, the scans given to almost every injured athlete or casual exerciser, might be a bit misleading. So he scanned the shoulders of 31 perfectly healthy professional baseball pitchers.

headline: The $16 Muffin That Wasn’t
text: WASHINGTON — The office of the Justice Department inspector general on Friday retracted its much publicized claim that the agency had spent $16 per breakfast muffin at a conference. And it expressed regret for the “significant negative publicity” for the department and for the hotel that hosted the meeting that resulted from the erroneous finding in a report last month.

headline: Storing With Style
text: A neo-Gothic tower on Second Avenue houses an unusual storage system, still in use after more than 80 years.

headline: Storing the Stuff of Dreams
text: IT sounds like something out of a dime novel, or maybe a Nicolas Cage film. Behind the mute facade of a largely windowless neo-Gothic tower lies an ingenious system of steel vaults traveling on rails. Within those armored containers, which have been in continuous use since the Jazz Age, are stored some of New York City’s most precious objects and, presumably, a good number of its darkest secrets.

headline: Berkman Hits in Clutch, and at the Microphone
text: ST. LOUIS — Lance Berkman entered the news conference room at Busch Stadium first, about half an hour after one of the most memorable games in World Series history. Berkman took two questions before David Freese, the No. 1 star of the night, bounced in and took a seat next to him on the platform.

headline: For a Gallery at the Edge, Fame Is Born Tuesday
text: MARNI Kotak would not give birth in just any art gallery.

headline: Waiting to Play, and to Redeem His Name
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — As the Giants completed their dramatic victory over the Buffalo Bills this month, Jimmy Kennedy watched on television, pumping his fist while churning his legs on an elliptical machine at a gym near Denver.

headline: Presidential Candidates? Few Are the 99 Percent
text: Occupy Wall Street protesters have touched a nerve with their slogan, “We are the 99 percent.” It has focused attention on the ground gained by the rich even as a brutal economy has pushed the typical American family backward. Economic inequality may or may not become a central issue in the presidential race, but the candidates have at least one reason to hope it does not.

headline: Bringing the Torah to Life on Painted Nails
text: HARTSDALE, N.Y.

headline: Western Companies See Prospects for Business in Libya
text: WASHINGTON — The guns in Libya have barely quieted, and NATO’s military assistance to the rebellion that toppled Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi will not end officially until Monday. But a new invasion force is already plotting its own landing on the shores of Tripoli.

headline: Underdog Turns Heads at the Top in Spain
text: VALENCIA, Spain —The team is known as Levante UD and since 1939 it has spent only 10 percent of its history in La Liga, Spain’s top soccer league.

headline: Closing for a Spell, Just to Prove It’s Ours
text: ANY day is a fine day for visiting the garden courtyard of Lever House, that midcentury modernist “Mad Men” masterpiece that was beautifully rejuvenated a decade ago. Any day, that is, but one.

headline: In Rubble-Strewn Sitra, Faces of the Young Foretell a Grim Future for Bahrain
text: SITRA, Bahrain — Sometimes a name suggests a condition. There was Beirut a generation ago, Baghdad more recently. In Bahrain, a Persian Gulf state so polarized that truth itself is a matter of interpretation, it is Sitra. Here, the faces of young men foretell a future for the country that looks like the rubble-strewn and violent streets of this town.

headline: Virus in Pacific Salmon Raises Worries About Industry
text: Advocates for wild salmon said Friday that a deadly virus had been detected again in a Pacific salmon in British Columbia, but it was not clear if it would prove lethal to the fish population.

headline: Yankees Stay With WCBS on Radio
text: The Yankees have extended their contract with the radio station WCBS 880 to broadcast their games through the 2012 season, meaning that the announcers John Sterling and Suzyn Waldman will most likely come back in their same roles.

headline: Congressmen Say Union May Be Stalling on H.G.H.
text: The chairman and the ranking member of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, in a letter about the failure to begin testing for human growth hormone sent to the N.F.L. and the players union Friday, said “it appears that the players’ union may be using stall tactics to avoid complying with the collective bargaining agreement.”

headline: Easy to Use, or Steal, but Inching Out of Reach
text: Among his various legacies, Steve Jobs, whose memorial continues with the arrival of the iPhone 4S, left us with a tangible and resonant symbol of our economic frictions: an easily brandished, easily taken device that in its sleek design and intuitive simplicity flaunts the relative effortlessness of affluent, knowledge-class living. The have-nots, particularly teenagers, covet and seek what, by now, the haves assume as birthright and dependency.

headline: Where the 1 Percent Fit in the Hierarchy of Income
text: Chart of the hierarchy of income in the United States.

headline: Telling the Story of 41 Years on the Run
text: CASAS NOVAS, Portugal — George Wright, the fugitive murderer who was captured in Portugal last month, 39 years after hijacking a jetliner and demanding a $1 million ransom, said he figured authorities in the United States had given up the chase long ago. But, he said, he never stopped worrying that they would come knocking.

headline: California: Official Arrested
text: The state finance director, Ana Matosantos, was arrested early Friday and accused of driving drunk after the police saw her swerving near the Capitol. Ms. Matosantos offered her resignation to Gov. Jerry Brown, but he did not accept it and she reported to work. “My decision to drive last night was reckless and irresponsible,” she said in a statement.

headline: Texas Manager Stands By the Closer Who Let It Slip Away
text: ST. LOUIS — Texas Manager Ron Washington said his team seemed relaxed and normal Friday afternoon, the day after twice failing to get the final strike to finish off the World Series in Game 6. Washington described the disappointment in that 10-9 loss in 11 innings as “taking a blow to the gut.”

headline: Cuban Food, Authentic and Light
text: WHEN I first started working in Manhattan, in the 1980s, I became acquainted with the cheap but absolutely delicious Cuban food that was then ubiquitous on a strip of Ninth Avenue in Chelsea. It was an exciting culinary experience — a window into an unfamiliar culture and a taste awakening. One dish in particular satisfied me every time: picadillo, that basic beef hash made Cuban-style, with tomatoes, green olives and raisins.

headline: Changes to Rules Help Ease Pressure on Amateurs
text: After the English amateur Tom Lewis burst onto the golf scene with a share of the first-round lead at the British Open in July, rumors swirled that dollar signs were dancing in his eyes and that he would jump to the professional ranks while his endorsement earnings potential was hot.

headline: All the Way Back, the Cardinals Win the World Series
text: ST. LOUIS — When the St. Louis Cardinals were down to their apparent final strike of the season, in both the ninth and 10th innings of Game 6 on Thursday night, Manager Tony La Russa told his players in the dugout not to forget to thank the fans for their support amid what was looking like a crushing season-ending loss.

headline: Iraq: Baghdad Bomb Toll Rises
text: The death toll from twin bombings on Thursday in a Shiite neighborhood of Baghdad rose on Friday to 36 killed and 78 wounded, according to an official at the Ministry of Interior. Initially, on Thursday evening, officials put the number of deaths at 12, but many who were hurt later succumbed to their wounds. Among the dead were several police officers and soldiers.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
text: NO. 11 OKLAHOMA AT NO. 10 KANSAS STATE3:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

headline: A Neighborhood Pub, Channeling Ireland
text: IT’S barely 7 o’clock on a Saturday evening and the throttle is wide open at Thatcher McGhee’s Irish Pub and Eatery in Pompton Lakes. The large square bar is packed two deep with knots of sports fans, young couples and off-duty mechanics talking about the day’s work. A burly patron who could easily be a finalist in a Jeff Lebowksi lookalike contest is well into a plate of bangers and mash, next to a heavily tattooed fellow picking his way through his Thatch fries, an unholy concoction featuring three cheeses, bacon and ranch dressing, which seems to be a house favorite.

headline: World Series Replay: Game 7
text: The St. Louis Cardinals win the World Series, beating the Texas Rangers, 6-2.

headline: Rev. Dean Brackley, 65, Dies; Served in El Salvador
text: The Rev. Dean Brackley belonged to an order of priests, the Jesuits, sometimes referred to as “God’s Marines,” because of a 16th-century founder’s military background and because of their long tradition of intellectual rigor as teachers and missionaries.

headline: Howard Wolpe, Backer of ’86 Anti-Apartheid Act, Dies at 71
text: Howard E. Wolpe, a former congressman who played a crucial role in passing legislation that imposed economic sanctions on South Africa in the 1980s, helping to bring an end to apartheid while overcoming two vetoes by President Ronald Reagan, died Tuesday at his home in Saugatuck, Mich. He was 71.

headline: For Restaurant Chains, Some Far-Off Links
text: DRIFTWOOD benches, surfboards and paintings of pelicans evoke the Florida coast at Hurricane Grill and Wings in Syosset; steel-drum music plays on the sound system.

headline: Final Delights Before the Frost
text: The air may be a bit nippier, but it is not too late to enjoy the fruits of the fall harvest at local farms. At this time of year that means apples (and apple cider), along with pumpkins, squashes, gourds — and pies. These three orchards are representative of what is available at many farms around the state.

headline: 2 Coaches Diverging on Game of Life
text: Sometimes a costume says it all. In Richard Dresser’s “Rounding Third,” the final offering of the Penguin Rep Theater season, the opening scene depicts two men meeting face to face for the first time. One, wearing horn-rimmed glasses and a tweed sport jacket over a V-neck sweater, looks natty. The other, in well-worn jeans and a T-shirt emblazoned with “Local Sports Legend,” could not be scruffier. Charlotte Palmer-Lane’s textbook-clear outfits tell you right off the bat that Mr. Dresser’s comic meditation on Little League baseball is going to center on an odd couple.

headline: The World This Week, Part One
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: The World This Week, Part Two
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: At Liverpool, the Statistics Sometimes Lie
text: Liverpool fans well recall just how deflated Anfield seemed when a League Two side, Northampton, sent the Reds crashing out of the Carling Cup at the first opportunity last September.

headline: A Palm-Studded Outpost of 1940s Hollywood
text: There are plenty of musicals with clever lyrics. Some offer clever books. A handful even manage clever melodies. But “City of Angels,” which won six Tonys in 1990, is the rarity that has all three. And it demands clever costumes, clever sets and clever staging as well.

headline: Goya’s Dark Etchings From a Past Full of Horrors
text: One of the advantages of art history is that it provides a sense of perspective. If you think we’ve got it bad, with our financial crisis, wars and natural disasters, just look at Spain in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. A brilliant, sobering and visionary window onto that world is provided by “Los Caprichos (The Caprices),” a series of 80 etchings by Francisco José de Goya y Lucientes (1746-1828), currently on view at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor.

headline: A Classical Myth With Contemporary Style
text: Marina Carr’s intense, incisive new play, “Phaedra Backwards,” at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, is based on a myth that, while not exactly simple, is straightforward enough.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Police on Thursday arrested two militants from the militant organization Lashkar-e-Taiba for twin blasts that occurred in Baramulla and Srinagar in August. The detainees, identified as residents of the Sopore district, are charged with killing two paramilitary personnel and a civilian in the Baramulla town and injuring 11 pedestrians in Srinagar (Kashmir Live).

headline: Freese Is Most Valuable, and Most Improbable
text: ST. LOUIS — Waves of red awaited David Freese as he headed toward yet another postgame interview. A major league official jogged alongside Freese, carrying the World Series most valuable player trophy Freese had just won, the main reason ESPN wanted to talk to him.

headline: Qantas Fleet Grounded for Second Day
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Qantas Airways, Australia’s national carrier, kept its worldwide fleet grounded for a second day on Sunday as government officials and business and labor leaders said they were working to end a dispute between the airline and its employees that has left at least 80,000 passengers stranded.

headline: Muppets, Warhol and Rebirth: Lady Gaga Holds Court in India
text: “Performance art is my life. The idea is to create a fantasy that is so great that when we are together, it feels very real.” So said Lady Gaga at a news conference in New Delhi, and so she has.With 15 million followers on Twitter, the most in the world, and 44 million ‘likes’ on Facebook, the 25-year-old Grammy-winning artist, has redefined what it means to be popular.

headline: 12 Americans Die as Blast Hits Bus in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — At least 12 Americans were killed when a Taliban suicide car bomber attacked an armored shuttle bus in Kabul on Saturday, military officials said.

headline: What You Thought About ‘Why I Left India’
text: India Ink’s recent first-person essay, Why I Left India (Again) unleashed an explosion of comment and discussion on our pages, on Facebook, Twitter and outside blogs. It also inspired a fictional parody, dinner party arguments in Manhattan, an Asia Society round up, and a psychological analysis from a mental health professional.

headline: The Weekend Word: Second Look
text: Today’s Times

headline: New Track, Old Story:  Vettel Scores 13th Pole Position this Season
text: NEW DELHI – Sebastian Vettel continued his domination of qualifying sessions this year by scoring his 13th pole position of the season at the inaugural Indian Grand Prix outside New Delhi on Saturday. Vettel joins Alain Prost and Ayrton Senna in the record books with the second largest number of pole positions in a season. Nigel Mansell holds the record of 14 pole positions, which he achieved in 1992 at Williams. With two races left in the season, Vettel has a chance to beat the record.

headline: New Track, Old Story:  Vettel Scores 13th Pole Position this Season
text: NEW DELHI – Sebastian Vettel continued his domination of qualifying sessions this year by scoring his 13th pole position of the season at the inaugural Indian Grand Prix outside New Delhi on Saturday. Vettel joins Alain Prost and Ayrton Senna in the record books with the second largest number of pole positions in a season. Nigel Mansell holds the record of 14 pole positions, which he achieved in 1992 at Williams. With two races left in the season, Vettel has a chance to beat the record.

headline: For Texas, the Moment Slipped Away, Twice
text: St. Louis

headline: Urban Forager | Reishi, the Leathery Healer
text: It’s difficult these days to walk around the city without finding fungi growing in planters, on wood mulch, or at the base of trees, so I wasn’t surprised to discover a beautiful cluster of red-shellacked reishi mushrooms growing fan-like at the base of a tree at the College of Staten Island.

headline: Kelly Clarkson, a Pop Star Proud in Her Own Skin
text: THE other night, Danielle Travali, 25, was listening to Kelly Clarkson’s new album, “Stronger.” Ms. Travali has fought her brigade of demons and then some, describing herself as an eating-disorders survivor.

headline: Denial In Depth
text: Columbia Journalism Review has a takedown of a “study” from American Enterprise Institute purporting to show that inequality hasn’t increased, after all. What’s striking is the way AEI doesn’t even resort to the usual practice of concocting misleading numbers; it just flat-out lies about what various other peoples’ research, like Robert Gordon’s work, actually says.

headline: Falling Short In Europe (Again)
text: Kash Mansori is unhappy with the state of the Italian bond market just days after the supposed big rescue. Indeed, the Panzerfaust has fallen far short; Italy is having to roll over its debt at levels that are unsustainable, and the unraveling of the euro is definitely still on.

headline: A Fourth Jewel for the Crown, Found in November
text: For decades, all those competing at the highest levels of North American racing have commenced each new year with their sights set on winning the same three races – the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes. Victories in these classics significantly raise the stature of horses, jockeys, trainers and owners alike and have a lasting impact on one’s legacy, often tipping the scales in one’s favor when it’s time to be considered for the Hall of Fame.

headline: Can Breakfast Replace Family Dinner?
text: Can the family breakfast serve the same purpose as the family dinner?

headline: Receiver Learns Roles, but Hasn’t Found One
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Over the past two seasons, Ramses Barden has been Hakeem Nicks. He has also been Mario Manningham, Steve Smith and, on occasion, Domenik Hixon.

headline: Occupy Protests Test the Mayor of Oakland
text: When Jean Quan was an undergraduate, she once sat for 10 hours inside Sproul Hall at the University of California, Berkeley, demanding better treatment for minority students. As a community activist, she helped unionize hospital workers and organized parents in a poor neighborhood of West Oakland.

headline: For Rangers Fans, the Promised Land Was Two Strikes and a Few Inches Away
text: By the time the last out was made, Rangers fans knew what was coming. They had felt the tide shift in the late innings of Game 6, which will surely go down as one of the most torturous losses in World Series history — not one, but two blown chances to win the championship on a single pitch.

headline: Variety: A Wartime Diagramless
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert! Today’s Diagramless is 17 squares wide by 17 squares deep with regular crossword symmetry. The entry for 1-Across begins in the sixth square of the first row.

headline: Live Analysis: Closing Down October, Looking to November
text: Paul Myerberg and The Times’ Jere Longman will be reporting on all of the day’s action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can also follow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

headline: Someone Ought to Make a Movie
text: ST. LOUIS — Carpe diem.

headline: Path May Be Untraditional, but the Tar Heels’ Goal Is the Same
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — North Carolina basketball traditionalists apparently have an issue with their Tar Heels. Not the team. The uniforms.

headline: Heavy Autumn Snowstorm Barrels Across Northeast
text: October, said the calendar. Before Halloween. And the 2.5 million trees occupying New York City’s open spaces confirmed it was fall — not winter — with glorious canopies of leaves stretching along their boughs.

headline: Life Without Manning Leads to Thoughts of Life Beyond Him
text: It has long been a truism in sports: there is perhaps no player more important in any team game than the quarterback.

headline: Big Brown Carries the Burden of His Owners
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Big Brown is having a good autumn. His first crop of yearlings, a handsome bunch, has been selling crisply. The horsemen here in the bluegrass in advance of this week’s 28th Breeders’ Cup have been buzzing about what they have seen from Big Brown’s babies in the sales ring. The big bay is in Australia, mating with a full book of 130 mares, and being paid nicely to do so: $27,500 a date.

headline: Militants Strike at Troops at Base in Somali Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Islamist militants mounted heavy attacks against African Union and Somali troops in Mogadishu on Saturday. At least a dozen people were killed, witnesses said, although there were conflicting reports on the number of casualties.

headline: Israeli Drone Strike Kills Militants in Southern Gaza
text: GAZA — Israeli airstrikes killed seven Palestinian members of Islamic Jihad’s armed wing in southern Gaza on Saturday, according to the militant group, and Gaza militants fired salvos of rockets at cities in southern Israel, killing one Israeli man and wounding at least two others in a sudden escalation of cross-border violence.

headline: Ideas for Spreading Quake-Resistant Building Methods
text: Design for Disaster

headline: Occupy Movement, After Legal Victories, Faces Weather
text: Continuing a week of crackdowns across the country, 26 Occupy Nashville protesters were arrested early Saturday, the second such roundup, for trespassing. And for the second night running, a judge dismissed the protesters’ arrest warrants, according to an official for the Tennessee Highway Patrol.

headline: Kyrgyzstan Votes for a President, Feeling the Pull of Russia
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan — When Russia’s prime minister, Vladimir V. Putin, unveiled a plan this month to form a new alliance of former Soviet countries called the Eurasian Union, some of them cringed at the specter of some kind of U.S.S.R. version 2.0.

headline: In a Big Company, Make Everyone an Entrepreneur
text: This interview with  Lynn Blodgett, president and C.E.O. of ACS, a Xerox company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: 30 Seconds With Mark Messier
text: Mark Messier is best known around New York as the captain of the Rangers when they won the Stanley Cup in 1994, their first championship in 54 years. But next Sunday, he will trade skates for running shoes and hit the streets for the New York City Marathon. Messier, 50, will represent the New York Police and Fire Widows’ and Children’s Benefit Fund and Tomorrow’s Children’s Fund in the race.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: What’s Luck Got to Do With It?
text: BETTER to be lucky than good, the adage goes.

headline: Podcast: European Debt, Settlement Talks, Fed Policy and Jim Collins
text: European leaders reached agreement this week on a far-reaching package aimed at resolving the Greek debt problem, recapitalizing vulnerable banks and bolstering the euro zone’s financial rescue fund. Stock markets around the world rallied on the news.

headline: A Conversation With Ariel Schulman
text: Ariel Schulman, the director of the box office smash Paranormal 3, takes more questions.

headline: Free Agent Outlook: Pujols, Sabathia and Reyes Stand Above the Rest
text: With the World Series over, the hot-stove season begins in earnest as each team sets its sights on contending next year. This free-agent class, though not particularly deep, has an incredibly high end that includes the best hitter and two of the best pitchers in the majors.

headline: When the City Was a House of Horrors
text: The late 1970s and early 1980s — when buildings were burning, fiscal crises were raging and the Dead Boys were playing at CBGB — were a macabre time in New York City’s history, a period when it could be said that the city resembled a haunted house.

headline: A Deal That Wouldn’t Sting
text: AFTER months of back and forth, a deal that is supposed to punish large financial institutions for foreclosure misconduct may be nigh.

headline: Dear Ben: It’s Time for Your Volcker Moment
text: IN October 1979, inflation was running at more than 10 percent a year, and the Federal Reserve’s gradual interest rate increases weren’t solving the problem. So Paul Volcker, the Fed chairman, dramatically changed how monetary policy was conducted. Today, an equally intractable unemployment crisis demands that Ben S. Bernanke, the current Fed chairman, stage a quiet revolution of his own.

headline: For Kurds in Turkey, a Country’s Conflict Rends Families
text: SIRNAK, Turkey — Portraits of Mevlude Gungen’s two eldest children hang just above the television, the only piece of furniture in her spare living room. On a recent day, the set was tuned to the station run by a Kurdish militant group, bringing her news of the conflict that has haunted her country — and her family — for years.

headline: More Thoughts On Weaponized Keynesianism
text: Let me follow up a bit on the sudden discovery by Republicans that cuts in government spending cost jobs and drive up the unemployment rate – as long as the spending is on destruction rather than construction. Oh, and thanks to commenters for reminding me of Barney Frank’s coinage, “weaponized Keynesianism.”

headline: Ugandans May Get a Game Yet
text: When the team from Kampala, Uganda, was denied visas and was unable to play in the Little League World Series last July, the filmmaker Jay Shapiro found himself adding a heart-rending chapter to the documentary he was filming about the team, and doing so in a sea of sympathy. All kinds of people, from children offering to donate their baseball mitts to major league players, contacted him to ask the same thing: what can I do?

headline: Can Super Mario Save the Day for Europe?
text: FRANKFURT

headline: Hinting at an End to a Curb on Polygamy, Interim Libyan Leader Stirs Anger
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — It was just a passing reference to marriage in a leader’s soberly delivered speech, but all week it has unsettled women here as well as allies abroad.

headline: It’s 3-D, High Definition and in Your Face
text: PEOPLE who want to enjoy the eye-popping effects of 3-D movies at home, far from the multiplex, usually do so on a 3-D television set.

headline: In Colorado, a Power Struggle With the Power Company
text: BOULDER, Colo. — Many Americans these days, from the huddled masses of Occupy Wall Street to the coifed confines of the presidential campaign, are talking about the future of capitalism.

headline: Commercials, by Multiple Choice
text: ON a television set, 10 feet away, commercials are often irritating.

headline: The Slogans Stop Here
text: EXPRESSING your own views is challenging enough.  Describing someone else’s opinions without talking to them first opens the door to serious trouble.

headline: Mets Name a First-Base Coach
text: The Mets continued revamping their coaching staff on Saturday, naming Tom Goodwin their first-base coach. Goodwin, 43, was the minor league outfield and base-running coordinator for the Boston Red Sox for the last three seasons.

headline: Bringing the Haves and Have-Nots Together for Curry and Compassion
text: As the evening light dimmed, Shrawan Nepali greeted each person who stood in a long line waiting for his food: a woman with her butterscotch-colored cocker spaniel, a poet poring over a mystery book, art students, commuters, a homeless woman with crimson sneakers and men wearing black hoods to guard against the cold and conversation.

headline: The Mystery of the $25,000 Phone Bill
text: THE Haggler has been traveling recently, and that can mean only one thing: a column that opens with a rant about traveling. Our subject this time is hotel doors, the kind that go ka-boom when they close.

headline: Comedian Is Serious, Mostly, as Candidate
text: MIAMI BEACH — Wearing a black suit and tie with neon-pink laces on his kicks, the man in the video struggles up Ocean Drive, past the Art Deco hotels and the hangovers they house. He pulls a trolley freighted with two voting machines — the ones that hung those chads long ago and made election infamy.

headline: China Reshuffles Top Leadership at Financial Regulators
text: SHANGHAI — China reshuffled the leadership of three of its financial regulatory agencies on Saturday, one of the first steps in what is expected to be a major leadership change at the top of the Communist Party next year.

headline: Arsenal Sends Chelsea to 2nd League Loss in Row
text: Robin van Persie scored a hat trick to lead Arsenal to a 5-3 win over Chelsea on Saturday in the English Premier League, while first-place Manchester City beat Wolverhampton, 3-1.

headline: One Role, With 10,000 Variations
text: ASK people to describe a typical day at work and some will say it’s impossible — each day is different. But there are other jobs where people do the same thing every day, like driving the same bus route, or performing the same role in a play year after year. I’ve played the psychiatrist Margaret Brent in “Perfect Crime,” an off-Broadway play, for almost 25 years, ever since it opened.

headline: Former Leader of Brazil Is Said to Have Throat Cancer
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, has throat cancer and will begin chemotherapy soon, his hospital said Saturday in a statement.

headline: A King of Kosher
text: I  WAS born in Casablanca when Morocco was still a French protectorate. The humid climate was not good for my asthma, so when I was 7 my parents sent me to a home for children in a French mountain village where the air was healthier. My parents visited when they could and I went home during holidays, but the separation was traumatic for all of us. I lived there for three years and it cured my asthma.

headline: Dolphins at Giants: Matchup to Watch
text: Dolphins (0-6) at Giants (4-2), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: Considering When It Might Be Best Not to Know About Cancer
text: After decades in which cancer screening was promoted as an unmitigated good, as the best — perhaps only — way for people to protect themselves from the ravages of a frightening disease, a pronounced shift is under way.

headline: Medical Marijuana Dispensary in Oakland Is Focus of Federal Government
text: Richard Lee, the leader of the marijuana legalization movement in California, does not appear to be intimidated by the federal government’s crackdown on medical marijuana dispensaries.

headline: October Surprise: White Snow on Green Leaves
text: Here’s the view from my front porch of a rare sight in late October in the Hudson Valley: maple foliage that’s still green because of a warm September and covered in white flakes from a pre-Halloween snowstorm.

headline: Los Cenzontles Mexican Arts Center
text: Tucked between a laundry and a discount grocery in a strip mall, Los Cenzontles Mexican Arts Center — a nonprofit organization founded in 1994 by the musician Eugene Rodriguez — offers classes in Mexican dance, music and art for children of all ages. The rhythmic beat of stomping feet echoes into the parking lot.  LOUISE RAFKIN

headline: Snow Comes Early to East Coast
text: A storm moving up the East Coast threatened to pull down power lines and dump up to a foot of snow in some areas.

headline: Letters: Volcker and the Money Market Funds
text: To the Editor:

headline: South Sudan Turns Toward British Heritage
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The new nation of South Sudan has expressed a desire to join the Commonwealth, a group composed mainly of former British colonies, and said that it would change the language used in schools from Arabic to English. The two actions further cement its pivot from the Arab world of northern Africa toward the largely Anglophone east.

headline: Bob Beaumont, Who Popularized Electric Cars, Dies at 79
text: Bob Beaumont, who thought every home should have an affordable electric vehicle in its driveway and sold more than 2,000 of them, the tiny, trapezoidal creation known as the CitiCar, decades before General Motors and Nissan came up with their own versions, died on Monday at his home in Columbia, Md. He was 79.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, October 30
text: For frequent Sunday show viewers, this should sound familiar: The struggling economy and the 2012 presidential race are both on the menu this week.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 2 Amid Turkish Crackdown on Kurds
text: ANKARA, Turkey — A female suicide bomber killed two other people and wounded 20 on Saturday in Bingol, a predominantly Kurdish town in Turkey’s east, as the army continued a major offensive against Kurdish separatists in the region.

headline: Pizzas and Pessimism
text: BEING surprised by something nutty from Herman Cain’s presidential campaign is like balking at an autopsy in a “CSI” episode: certain things go with the territory. Still, you had to pause and peel your jaw off the ground after watching an Internet ad for Cain that prompted considerable conversation last week.

headline: What Tax Dollars Can’t Buy
text: OVER the last 30 years, the U.S. economy has generated more large fortunes and more stress for the middle class. While the rich have grown extraordinarily rich, median wages have barely increased, the costs of health care and higher education have jumped, and socioeconomic mobility has lagged behind that of other developed nations. Americans have never begrudged the wealthy their success, as long as they had a chance to rise higher than their parents, and perhaps get rich themselves. But our era of diminished expectations is putting that in doubt.

headline: Did You Hear the One About the Bankers?
text: CITIGROUP is lucky that Muammar el-Qaddafi was killed when he was. The Libyan leader’s death diverted attention from a lethal article involving Citigroup that deserved more attention because it helps to explain why many average Americans have expressed support for the Occupy Wall Street movement. The news was that Citigroup had to pay a $285 million fine to settle a case in which, with one hand, Citibank sold a package of toxic mortgage-backed securities to unsuspecting customers — securities that it knew were likely to go bust — and, with the other hand, shorted the same securities — that is, bet millions of dollars that they would go bust.

headline: Addicted to Exercise?
text: FOR decades, scientists have studied areas deep within the brain that seem associated with pleasure and addiction.

headline: The Bloated Nuclear Weapons Budget
text: Twenty years after the end of the cold war, the United States still has about 2,500 nuclear weapons deployed and 2,600 more as backup. The Obama administration, in an attempt to mollify Congressional Republicans, has also committed to modernizing an already hugely expensive complex of nuclear labs and production facilities. Altogether, these and other nuclear-related programs could cost $600 billion or more over the next decade. The country does not need to maintain this large an arsenal. It should not be spending so much to do it, especially when Congress is considering deep cuts in vital domestic programs.

headline: After Liberation, Nowhere to Run
text: Tripoli, Libya

headline: The Genius of Jobs
text: ONE of the questions I wrestled with when writing about Steve Jobs was how smart he was. On the surface, this should not have been much of an issue. You’d assume the obvious answer was: he was really, really smart. Maybe even worth three or four reallys. After all, he was the most innovative and successful business leader of our era and embodied the Silicon Valley dream writ large: he created a start-up in his parents’ garage and built it into the world’s most valuable company.

headline: The Arab Intellectuals Who Didn’t Roar
text: IN mid-June, the Syrian poet known as Adonis, one of the Arab world’s most renowned literary figures, addressed an open letter to the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad. The stage was set for one of those moments, familiar from revolutions past, in which an intellectual hero confronts an oppressive ruler and eloquently voices the grievances of a nation.

headline: Falling Crime, Teeming Prisons
text: Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, has a smart proposal to create a bipartisan commission to review the nation’s troubled criminal justice system and offer recommendations for reform. The National Criminal Justice Commission Act would be a valuable first step toward reducing crime as well as punishment. Unfortunately, Senate Republicans derailed the bill recently, with some falsely claiming that it would encroach on states’ rights.

headline: You Want to Track Me? Here You Go, F.B.I.
text: ON June 19, 2002, I ran into a bit of a problem that turned my life upside down. It happened at the Detroit airport as I was entering the country. I realized something wasn’t right when the immigration agent at United States Customs slid my passport through the reader, then froze. “Is there something wrong?” I asked. He was still frozen. After a few moments, he said, “Follow me, please,” and I ended up at the Immigration and Naturalization Service’s airport office.

headline: A Pilgrim’s Progress
text: “I NEEDED to save myself,” says Annie Leibovitz, explaining what motivated her new book of photographs, “Pilgrimage.” “I needed to remind myself of what I like to do, what I can do.”

headline: Our Unpaid, Extra Shadow Work
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: Twitterology: A New Science?
text: DENIZENS of the Twitter-verse, please be advised: Whether you are a Libyan celebrating the demise of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a New Zealand office worker sleepily starting your day or a California teenager trying out the latest slang, your words are being analyzed.

headline: Gracias, Pero No Gracias
text: There are almost 12 million potential Hispanic voters in the United States. And both parties say they are eager to court their votes. So one has to wonder why the Republican presidential contenders would miss the chance to debate before the largest possible audience of Spanish-language television viewers.

headline: Wall Street Protesters Hit the Bull’s-Eye
text: Occupiers of Zuccotti Park and other sites around the country have been criticized for the fuzziness of their goals. Their complaint that the privileged few in the top 1 percent are getting a disproportionate share of the nation’s prosperity, however, is spot on. And Wall Streeters are taking a bigger and bigger chunk of that income.

headline: Wait Wait... Don’t Tell Me
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait

headline: Ariel Schulman
text: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

headline: The Times Gives Them Space, but Who Pays Them?
text: PEOPLE don’t just argue about what is written on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times. They argue about who is doing the writing and why.

headline: Jumping Jacks and Lobs at a City Budget Parade
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Managing Mental Illness in a High-Powered Job
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Using Technology to Teach
text: In schools and in homes, teachers and parents wrestle with the role of technology in children’s lives. Our readers weigh in.

headline: The ‘Shadow’ Republican Party
text: Outside organizations are a growing presence in the Republican Party, recruiting top strategists and donors from the traditional party structure.

headline: Outside Groups Eclipsing G.O.P. as Hub of Campaigns
text: About once a month, a dozen or so of the country’s most influential Republicans meet in a bare-walled conference room in Washington to discuss how to make further gains in the Congressional elections next year and defeat President Obama.

headline: The Latest in … Brain Research on Addiction
text: We in the pundit world probably don’t pay enough attention to science, and in Sunday’s column I make a too-rare foray in that direction. I write about new research, based on brain scans, on addiction and happiness. One lesson is that sugary foods can constitute an addiction – but so can running, and also generosity. Read the column and post your thoughts!

headline: Why Our Candidates Disappoint Us
text: Atlanta

headline: Sunday: Hollywood From Right to Left
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Right off the bat I knew I would like this one. For one thing, it’s the brainchild of two constructors I find very entertaining, Andrea Carla Michaels and Patrick Blindauer. It’s also about Hollywood movies. Now that’s entertainment.

headline: As Fall Veto Session Begins, Lawmakers Question Quinn’s Ability to Lead
text: With each green light that blinked last week on the General Assembly voting boards approving electricity legislation, Gov. Pat Quinn’s influence with lawmakers seemed to fade.

headline: Speechmaking Call and Response at Alabama Straw Poll
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Maybe you’ve heard: there was another obscure straw poll held in America, and a legion of well-organized Ron Paul supporters turned out.

headline: Jailing Fewer Would Trim County Costs, Official Says
text: In times of austerity, it can be very difficult for elected officials to advance any significant agenda items while also balancing a budget. But the Cook County Board of Commissioners president, Toni Preckwinkle, is trying to do just that.

headline: State Finds a Way to Make Weatherization Work
text: For conservative opponents of the federal stimulus package, the beleaguered Weatherization Assistance Program has been an easy target. Texas’ component of the Obama administration’s “green jobs” initiative has also been plagued by well-documented problems and criticisms, and the disdain of Texas’ Republican leadership, including Gov. Rick Perry.

headline: Day After Day, Her Voice Takes Listeners to the Stars
text: SAN ANTONIO — On a clear, cool night in the early 1960s, a father drove his young, pajama-clad daughter to one of the T-head piers on Corpus Christi Bay to marvel at an object in the sky.

headline: Enforcement Is Next Task for Law on Wage Theft
text: HOUSTON — For two years, Diego Gala, a Mexican immigrant in the country illegally, worked five days a week cleaning a private school for less than minimum wage. His employer refused to pay him overtime even when he was forced to work on the weekends. Mr. Gala did not speak up, fearing deportation if he reported his boss.

headline: Drilling Debate in Cooperstown, N.Y., Is Personal
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — The letter that arrived in Kim Jastremski’s mailbox on County Highway 52 suggested that she stop protesting the possibility of natural gas drilling. It seemed more of a threat than a request.

headline: U.S. Planning Troop Buildup in Gulf After Exit From Iraq
text: MacDILL AIR FORCE BASE, Fla. — The Obama administration plans to bolster the American military presence in the Persian Gulf after it withdraws the remaining troops from Iraq this year, according to officials and diplomats. That repositioning could include new combat forces in Kuwait able to respond to a collapse of security in Iraq or a military confrontation with Iran.

headline: Looks Like Salzburg
text: First, it was Tropical Storm Irene that forced the postponement on Aug. 28 of the Red Bulls’ game against the Los Angeles Galaxy.

headline: Indian Middle Class Finds Its Political Voice
text: The wealthier India has become, the more politically disillusioned many of the middle-class beneficiaries have grown.

headline: College Football Replay: Oct. 30
text: Rain and snow soaked the East Coast, and a storm of touchdowns showered the rest of the country, with blowouts for Florida State, Michigan and Oklahoma.

headline: Protests Awaken a Goliath in India
text: DWARKA, India — Shubhrangshu Barman Roy and his childhood friends are among the winners in India’s economic rise. They have earned graduate degrees, started small companies and settled into India’s expanding middle class. They sometimes take vacations together and meet for dinners or parties, maybe to celebrate a new baby or a new business deal.

headline: Soggy Trick-or-Treaters Visit White House
text: If his Halloween candy didn’t deter the egg throwers that President Obama feared, the weather would have.

headline: Up by 3 Goals, Rangers Find a Way to Lose Again
text: It looked as if Coach John Tortorella’s experiment was working. He broke up the tandem of Marian Gaborik and the $60 million free agent brought in to ignite him, Brad Richards, and the Rangers had a three-goal lead over Ottawa with just 11 minutes to play Saturday afternoon.

headline: Cain and Romney Top Iowa Poll
text: WASHINGTON — Two months before the first votes are to be cast in the Republican presidential nominating contest, Herman Cain and Mitt Romney have the strongest support among party activists who plan to participate in the Iowa caucuses, according to a poll released on Saturday evening.

headline: A Tattoo Parlor Prepares to Depart the Chelsea Hotel
text: The tattoo parlor on the ground floor of the Chelsea Hotel was nearly empty on Saturday afternoon, and Ivan Arte, a worker there, said he had only one scheduled appointment, a man coming in to get a half-sleeve dragon with flowers.

headline: Pujols Not Ready to Look Forward
text: ST. LOUIS — When Albert Pujols came to bat in the seventh inning of Game 6 of the World Series on Thursday night, the St. Louis Cardinals were losing and on the brink of elimination, and Pujols had not had a hit since his three home runs in Game 3.

headline: With the Big East Teetering, Rutgers Stumbles
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — The snow-globe conditions for West Virginia’s 41-31 victory over Rutgers on Saturday afternoon provided a fitting backdrop for two Big East programs caught in the disorienting swirl of conference realignment.

headline: N.B.A. Deal Is Tantalizingly Close, but Last Hurdle Is a Big One
text: The new N.B.A. labor deal is practically done. You wouldn’t know it from the headlines, the dour news conferences or the apocalyptic rhetoric spilling from league officials. But the deal, in practical terms, is about 95 percent complete.

headline: Yanks Pick Up Options for Cano and Swisher
text: The Yankees exercised their one-year, $10.25 million option on right fielder Nick Swisher’s contract Saturday. They also picked up the $14 million option on Robinson Cano’s contract.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Day’s Best in College Football
text: KEVIN DECKER The New Hampshire quarterback had 335 yards of total offense and scored the go-ahead touchdown to lead host New Hampshire over Rhode Island, 31-24. Decker led an efficient six-play, 68-yard drive in the third quarter, erasing a 3-point deficit with a 1-yard touchdown run. He finished 14 of 21 for 257 yards.

Richardson, an Anguilla justice of the peace, officiated at Cap Juluca, a resort in Maundays Bay on Anguilla, in the British West Indies.

text: Lauren Fadeley and Francis Veyette, dancers with the Pennsylvania Ballet in Philadelphia, were married Saturday evening at Minorca by the Sea, a condominium complex in New Smyrna Beach, Fla. Cohen of Boston. Rabbi Dr. Elliot J. Cosgrove officiated at the Jumeirah Essex House hotel, with Cantor Azi Schwartz assisting.

Vieyra of Tallmadge, Ohio. Rabbi Hayyim J. Angel performed the ceremony at Congregation Shearith Israel in Manhattan.
