headline: Building Collapse Kills Construction Worker
text: A construction worker was killed after a building he was working in collapsed and buried him under six feet of rubble in the Bronx on Saturday afternoon, the police said.

headline: New Dreams for Field
text: DYERSVILLE, Iowa — Mike Dollar had a faraway look as he watched his wife, Laura, hit baseballs to their son, Jesse, who fielded them at shortstop in an Atlanta Braves T-shirt. Abby, their daughter, played catcher. The sun was bright, the sky was clear and the cornstalks were waving in the breeze.

headline: Stanford and Luck Pull Out a Victory
text: LOS ANGELES —  Stanford’s perfect season was on the brink of ruin against U.S.C. on Saturday night because of a rare mistake by its impeccable quarterback Andrew Luck. With a little over three minutes to play in the fourth quarter, Luck threw a pass that cornerback Nickell Robey intercepted and returned 32 yards to put the Trojans ahead, 34-27.

headline: Metro Pucks Weekly: Blown Leads, a Controversial Call and a Lot of Losses
text: Our weekly review of the performances of the three local N.H.L. teams.

headline: Newswallah: Longreads Edition
text: A look at some of the long-form journalism we have been reading this week.

headline: Two Masters Explored in Roman Show
text: The exhibition “Filippino Lippi and Sandro Botticelli in Florence in the 1400s,” showing at the Scuderie del Quirinale (Via XXIV Maggio 16; english.scuderiequirinale.it) through Jan. 15, follows the lives and works of those two painters, with particular emphasis on Lippi’s career, style and innovations. More than 40 of his works are juxtaposed with those of other masters, mainly Botticelli, whose supporting role in the exhibition serves to illuminate the character of the junior master.

headline: Occupy Protesters Regroup After Mass Arrests
text: DENVER — Protesters in Denver and Nashville regrouped on Sunday, a day after dozens of arrests at demonstrations inspired by Occupy Wall Street in both cities.

headline: Qantas Flights to Resume After Grounding
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Qantas Airways was expected to resume flying Monday after a government tribunal ordered the airline to lift its grounding of the entire fleet over the weekend, which stranded thousands around the world.

headline: Breeders’ Cup Memories, From the First Break Out of the Gate
text: I was at Hollywood Park on Nov. 10, 1984, for the inaugural running of the Breeders’ Cup. My dad and I had been going to races in Southern California for just over a decade by that time, and we rarely missed a feature race on a weekend at any of the area’s major tracks, so there was no way we were missing the first Breeders’ Cup.

headline: Floodwalls Keep Bangkok Dry but Provinces Angry
text: BANGKOK — Shielded by hundreds of thousands of sandbags piled shoulder high along the city’s outskirts, most of Bangkok remained dry on Sunday, allaying fears for now that the massive metropolis would be swamped by monsoon floodwaters.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Fires of Faith,’ Part 3
text: It’s perhaps the most beloved (and, for many, most sacred) book ever published in the West, but oh, the birth pangs. BYUtv has been exploring the creation of the King James Bible in “Fires of Faith,” a well-made three-part documentary (also viewable on the channel’s Web site) that concludes Sunday night.

headline: A Volcker Moment Indeed (Slightly Wonkish)
text: Christina Romer calls on Ben Bernanke to adopt a nominal GDP target, and suggests that he consider himself in a position comparable to that of Paul Volcker — where Volcker took drastic action to fight inflation, Bernanke should do likewise to fight unemployment.

headline: Social Security Bait And Switch, A Continuing Series
text: Dean Baker is angry at the Washington Post for spreading disinformation about Social Security. He’s right, of course — and it’s shocking that a well-known fallacy is the subject of a “news analysis” that purports to inform readers.

headline: A Sister’s Eulogy for Steve Jobs
text: I grew up as an only child, with a single mother. Because we were poor and because I knew my father had emigrated from Syria, I imagined he looked like Omar Sharif. I hoped he would be rich and kind and would come into our lives (and our not yet furnished apartment) and help us. Later, after I’d met my father, I tried to believe he’d changed his number and left no forwarding address because he was an idealistic revolutionary, plotting a new world for the Arab people.

headline: Committing to Debates, Perry Plays Down the Issue
text: Even as Rick Perry admits he has struggled during televised debates against the polished Mitt Romney and other G.O.P. candidates, the Texas governor maintains he could handle President Obama, a man he has acknowledged to be a “very good debater.”

headline: Cain Gets Tough Treatment for Video’s Cigarette Scene
text: WASHINGTON – Had Herman Cain known he would be running into a human buzzsaw named Bob Schieffer on Sunday, he might have had second thoughts about including a now infamous scene at the end of his new campaign video that shows his chief of staff, Mark Block, coolly smoking a cigarette.

headline: ‘Puss in Boots’ Leads at Weekend Box Office
text: DreamWorks Animation’s “Puss in Boots,” a spin-off of that studio’s “Shrek” franchise, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, taking in an estimated $34 million. An unusually heavy autumn snowstorm in the Northeast may have kept some potential ticket buyers at home: Hollywood had been expecting a total closer to $40 million. But “Puss in Boots,” which cost about $130 million to make and was distributed by Paramount Pictures, received strong critical reviews and an A-minus from audiences in exit polls, opening up the possibility of solid sales in weekends ahead.

headline: Storm Leaves More Than 2 Million Without Power
text: Millions of people across the Northeast found themselves without power on Sunday after an unusual autumn storm dumped record amounts of snow.

headline: India Wins, as Vettel Leads From Start to Finish
text: NEW DELHI — Proving both the world and its own skeptics wrong, India staged its first Formula One race on Sunday in what has been hailed as a success for a country with a tarnished reputation for hosting international sporting events.

headline: India Wins, as Vettel Leads From Start to Finish
text: NEW DELHI — Proving both the world and its own skeptics wrong, India staged its first Formula One race on Sunday in what has been hailed as a success for a country with a tarnished reputation for hosting international sporting events.

headline: Obama Adviser Unloads on Romney
text: David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama and one of the chief architects of his 2008 victory, accused Mitt Romney of trimming his views for political gain and lacking the conviction needed to hold high office. The comments were unusual for their harsh assessment of Mr. Romney’s politics and his character at this early stage of the campaign and for the fact that they came from an official serving in the White House rather than in Mr. Obama’s Chicago-based re-election campaign.

headline: Tested Again and Again, Cain Takes Comfort in His Rise in the Polls
text: HOMEWOOD, Ala. — For Herman Cain, these have been the sweet days.

headline: She Lives
text: A correspondent’s daughter will be trick-or-treating as the confidence fairy:

headline: Starting Lineups: Red Bulls vs. Los Angeles Galaxy
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Starting lineups for the first leg of Major League Soccer’s Western Conference semifinal between the Red Bulls and the Los Angeles Galaxy:

headline: Russian Aide Says Issues With Georgia on Joining Trade Group May Be Settled Soon
text: MOSCOW — A top adviser to President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia said Sunday that the handful of outstanding issues necessary for Russia to join the World Trade Organization could be resolved in a matter of hours, suggesting that a deal was imminent after 18 years of stop-and-go negotiations.

headline: Supreme Court to Weigh Effects of Bad Plea Advice
text: WASHINGTON — Anthony Cooper shot a woman in Detroit in 2003 and then received laughably bad legal advice. Because all four of his bullets had struck the victim below her waist, his lawyer said, Mr. Cooper could not be convicted of assault with intent to murder.

headline: A Comical Analysis of Sports’ Childish Side
text: What’s the worst way a day can end for a diligent Manhattan worker bee? You’ve logged some late hours at your desk, pushing through a project or getting ready for that big meeting in the morning. You hop the 11 p.m. train for your suburban castle, looking forward to winding down on the ride.

headline: Pet Lovers, Pathologized
text: In a 1991 interview titled “Eating Well,” Jacques Derrida wonders whether a head of state (chef d’Etat) could gain office by declaring himself or herself a vegetarian.  He concludes, “The chief (chef) must be an eater of flesh.”

headline: In East Harlem, ‘Keep Out’ Signs Apply to Renters
text: East Harlem has been undergoing a resurgence for two decades, yet the neighborhood is still pockmarked with four- or five-story walk-ups where the ground-floor stores are bustling and the apartments above are devoid of life. Their windows are boarded up, blocked up or just drearily empty, torn curtains testifying to no one’s having lived there for years.

headline: Nebraska Seeks a Say on the Route of a Pipeline
text: With a federal decision anticipated soon on whether an oil pipeline will be allowed to run from Canada through the nation’s midsection, lawmakers in Nebraska are being summoned on Tuesday to an unexpected legislative session over the issue, which has stirred up a level of rancor that few had predicted.

headline: After a Week Off, a Day on Edge
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — This was supposed to be the final trip to the breakfast buffet for the Giants, a last loll on the beach for a team that opened this season facing a slew of lesser opponents, then spent the past month playing three home games (and enjoying a bye week) before entering what should be the toughest stretch of schedule in the league.

headline: Tapping Beethoven to Lift a Radio Station’s Profile
text: BEETHOVEN is a giant of classical music. For an offbeat effort on behalf of a classical music station, he is becoming an Obey Giant.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Attacks on Foreigners in Capital Get Afghan Faction’s Message Across
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Every bomb, they say, has a return address.

headline: A Filmmaker Wants to Help Others Use Product Placement
text: LOS ANGELES — “He’s not selling out, he’s buying in,” says the slogan for “POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold,” Morgan Spurlock’s whimsical documentary about product placement in movies and television shows.

headline: CNN Is Said to Be Revamping Its Morning Lineup
text: CNN, which remodeled its afternoon and evening schedule earlier this year, is now on the verge of remaking its morning schedule.

headline: European Doom Loop
text: For once — and I almost never say this — I think Dean Baker is being a bit too hard here. The Draghi piece was mainly a profile, and I’m willing to cut a bit of slack on the macro analysis.

headline: Seeing Tantrums as Distress, Not Defiance
text: When I describe the process I went through to get my 3-year-old into preschool to non-New Yorkers, they look at me as if I was wearing an astronaut suit to a dinner party. Eight interviews? Eight tours? Eight applications? For a kid who still has trouble drinking out of a cup? Absurd.

headline: For a Free-Form Radio Conference, a Kindred Spirit
text: It would be hard to overstate the level of preposterousness that surrounds Jon Gnarr, the punk rocker-turned-comedic actor-turned mayor of Reykjavik, Iceland. Mr. Gnarr was elected in 2010 after he formed a quasi-satirical political party, the Best Party; his campaign promises included putting a polar bear in the city zoo and offering free towels in the swimming pools — as well as a promise to break all his campaign promises.

headline: Monday: A Halloween Puzzle With Bite
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Happy Halloween, everybody! Have you all purchased your candy to dole out to trick-or-treaters? Anyone dressing up in costume for the holiday? Here on the East Coast, we’re having a very snowy Halloween, and if I was going to dress up, it would most likely be as a Resentful Homeowner Who Is Getting Really Tired of Shoveling Her Walkway. On the other hand, I’m hoping there will be lots of chocolate left over to make it worth my while. There’s always a silver lining, am I right?

headline: Advertising Companies Fret Over a Digital Talent Gap
text: When the Ad:tech advertising technology conference hits New York next week, marketers, advertising agencies and recruiters may spend less time listening to the panelists and more time working the floor to find new employees.

headline: What Was Rafa Marquez Thinking?
text: The Red Bulls’ 1-0 loss to the Galaxy on Sunday ended with the teams’ pushing and shoving at midfield after the Red Bulls’ Rafael Marquez threw the ball at a Galaxy player after the final whistle. Moments later, Marquez and defender Stephen Keel were flat on their backs, with Keel apparently bloodied in the melee.

headline: Huntsman Video Takes On Romney ‘Backflips’
text: The campaign of Jon M. Huntsman Jr. on Sunday released a Web video titled “Backflip,” which highlights what it calls some of Mitt Romney‘s flips on issues like abortion, gun control and the Ohio proposal to curb the bargaining power of unions.

headline: Love and Eros in Motion Among the Deities
text: Do we watch dance in terms of form or expression? As shapes, rhythms and beauty or as meanings, stories and significance? Actually, there’s no either/or about it. Dancing is both/and: both a metric, spatial pattern and a profoundly human act at the same time. Yet it always takes me aback to see how drastically Indian classical dance often sets up an apparent dichotomy. That bit was about angles and meters, this bit is about character, emotion and story. But one dancer performs both. By commuting between the two aspects, she demonstrates contrasting planes of existence.

headline: ‘Jersey Shore’ Arrives in Academia. Discuss.
text: CHICAGO — When Deena Cortese was added to the cast of “Jersey Shore” in Season 3, she was nervous that she wouldn’t be welcome, that she wouldn’t be able to forge a place for herself in a group with well-established social dynamics.

headline: Titans Clash Over a Mere Cadenza
text: “Artistic differences.” It’s the euphemism of choice to save face and explain away unpleasant disputes among performers. The phrase pops up all the time in the arts, but in truth it describes nothing.

headline: Comedy Troupe Delivers Its Second New York Baby
text: Taking her first tour on Friday night of the completed Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, known as U.C.B.East for short, in the East Village, Amy Poehler examined its renovated 124-seat performance space, its twin lobbies on Third Street and Avenue A and its momentarily immaculate bathrooms, “so clean you could improvise off them,” she said.

headline: Race Across Time to Stop Assassin and Fall in Love
text: Stephen King’s latest magnum opus, “11/22/63,” finds a way to revisit and even revise the events surrounding the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The book’s front cover depicts a newspaper account of Kennedy’s death in Dallas on that date. Its rear cover presents the opposite outcome, with the president and first lady looking happy and unscathed.

headline: For Home Entertainment Releases, a Rare Bright Spot
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s troubled home entertainment business is moving in an unaccustomed direction: Up.

headline: Bartok at Home, With a Touch of the Mischievous
text: Many of the artists chosen by Carnegie Hall to present a series of Perspectives concerts have brought in colleagues from diverse international cultures to share the programs and expand, well, the perspective.

headline: Someday His Horse Will Come (and Win)
text: A low-key mockumentary set in the world of horse racing, “And They’re Off ...” has its moments but not quite enough to carry it across the finish line. (Racing puns stop now.) Though some of the sport’s stars — like the trainers Doug O’Neill and Bob Baffert, he of the white moptop and dark shades — make cameo appearances and acquit themselves decently, the movie is more interested in down-and-out dreamers than in Kentucky Derby or Breeders’ Cup winners.

headline: Tides of Trance Meld Divine Echoes of South Asia and Africa
text: A trans-Islamic jam session, blending ecstatic trance music from Pakistan and Morocco, was the finale of the concert Saturday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium. The Pakistani group Qawal Najmuddin Saifuddin & Brothers — making its New York City debut — and the New York group of Moroccan Gnawa musicians, Hassan Hakmoun and Friends, shared a double bill, and then performed together. The concert marked the opening of the museum’s dazzling New Galleries for the Art of the Arab Lands, Turkey, Iran, Central Asia and Later South Asia.

headline: Not Business as Usual for Visiting Minnesotans
text: It was high time the Minnesota Orchestra and its Finnish music director, Osmo Vanska, brought something else to Carnegie Hall. For five concerts in a row in previous visits an ensemble known to be adventurous in Minneapolis played only Beethoven and Sibelius: great composers, to be sure, and in sterling performances, Sibelius in particular being a Vanska specialty. But still.

headline: Remembering Sounds That Coltrane Built
text: In remaking the music from John Coltrane’s 1961 record “Africa/Brass,” as Reggie Workman did on Friday at Rose Theater, the first step is filling its dimensions. It’s not just that you have to fill it with loudness, though you do: the album has a huge cumulative sound. You have to fill it with people, presence and purpose, and you have to justify its repetitiveness. You have to honor pieces of music that seem to want to go on forever.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review ‘Chinglish’
text: NYTimes.com readers had mixed to positive reactions to “Chinglish,” David Henry Hwang‘s new comedy about Chinese-American relations (and relationships) that opened on Broadway last week. Some found the show’s approach to linguistic and cultural confusion humorous; others thought that it had a one-note plot and that the jokes failed to land. (In his review for The New York Times, Ben Brantley called “Chinglish” a “sporadically funny” play “laid out with the frame-by-frame exactness of a comic strip.”)

headline: Dutch Hosts Are Winners of Bermuda Bowl
text: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands — At the world team championships here on Saturday, much to the delight of hundreds of spectators, the Bermuda Bowl was won by the host nation. In the 128-board final Sjoert Brink, Bas Drijver, Bauke Muller, Simon de Wijs, Ricco van Prooijen and Louk Verhees Jr., with Eric Laurant the nonplaying captain, defeated U.S.A.-2: Daniel Zagorin, Kevin Bathurst, Joe Grue, Justin Lall, John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge, with Curtis Cheek the nonplaying captain. The final score was 300 international match points to 255. Italy was third.

The concert series, which is scheduled to run from Jan. 11 through Feb. 11 at the Allen Room of Frederick P. Rose Hall, is to include Mr. Moore (Feb. 2); Elaine Paige , the British musical theater actress (Feb. 10); and a performance by Lin-Manuel Miranda previewing his new work, “The Hamilton Mixtape” (Jan. 11). The lineup is also to include the Broadway stars LaChanze (Jan. 19), Michael Cerveris (Jan. 21) and Laura Benanti (Feb 11).

headline: ‘In Living Color’ to Return on Fox
text: “In Living Color,” the sketch comedy series that introduced America to the Wayans brothers 20 years ago, is being resurrected for Fox by one of the brothers. The network said on Friday that Keenen Ivory Wayans, left, was set to host and produce two half-hour specials in the mold of “In Living Color,” which was shown between 1990 and 1994. The shows will appear on Fox next spring and could serve as test episodes for a full series. The programs will have new cast members and musical performances. Mr. Wayans and one of his brothers, Damon, were standouts on the original series, which also featured performers who were not well known at the time, including David Alan Grier, Jennifer Lopez, Jim Carrey and Jamie Foxx.

headline: Study Says Artists Have Higher Salaries
text: Artists in America constitute a tiny portion of the nation’s work force, but they tend to be more entrepreneurial, better educated and, with a median salary of $43,230, better paid than the average worker by nearly $4,000, according to a survey released Friday by the National Endowment for the Arts. Nearly 2.1 million Americans — 1.4 percent of the total work force — fit into the 11 occupations that the government counts under the artist heading. That includes comics and movie stars, set designers and floral designers. Six in 10 have college degrees, compared with 1 in 3 over all, and 1 out of 3 are self-employed (3.5 times more likely than the average worker). But can you make a living? Mom and Dad want to know. No problem if you become a movie star, concert master or architect (whose median annual salary is $63,000). But the median income drops to $30,000 or less in acting, photography, music or dance. When was the last time your waiter was a part-time actor?

headline: Mining Salt From the Sea
text: One of the magical aspects of running a business is how it eventually taps into everything you know, or thought you knew. Maybe that’s why you got into that particular business in the first place, without ever knowing about this secret synergy. Southfork Kitchen has drawn upon just about every experience or interest I have ever had, both obvious and all but forgotten, from music to design, food to entertainment, media to human interaction (oy, those human interactions!). More than a string of nouns, it is nearly a summation of a life.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: It’s All About Connections
text: A rare occurrence on “Affairs of State,” the season’s sixth episode of “The Good Wife” on Sunday night: Alicia Florrick was unequivocally on the wrong side of the case. She and the new associate, Caitlin, defended a Taiwanese student who was a suspect in a rape and murder aboard a party boat. The story seemed to revolve around the question of diplomatic immunity (in this case, the lack thereof), but that was a MacGuffin. In the final minutes we and Alicia discovered that she had been defending the killer.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
text: India successfully hosted its first-ever Grand Prix on Sunday, in front of a 95,000 strong crowd at the Buddh International Circuit outside New Delhi. National dailies were united Monday in their praise for the “flawlessly executed” event (Times of India), which has “dispelled myths” (CNN-IBN) about India’s ability to host high-end sporting events after the debacle of the Commonwealth Games. “I honestly cannot wait to come back to India,” said the two-time world champion Sebastian Vettel, echoing the sentiments of other Formula One drivers whose time in India has left an “indelible mark” on them (Indian Express). “Good tracks these F1 fellows are used to but friendly, open people proved to be India’s greatest ambassadors,” according to the Hindustan Times.

headline: Oct. 31, 1984 | Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi Assassinated
text: On Oct. 31, 1984, Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was assassinated near her residence by two vengeance-seeking Sikh security guards. The men were angry at Gandhi’s authorization of a military attack on a revered Sikh temple in Amritsar five months earlier.Gandhi, the daughter of Indian independence leader and first Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, first acceded to prime minister in 1966. Her New York Times obituary described her as “strong-willed, autocratic and determined to govern an almost ungovernable nation that seemed always in strife” and “a decisive—some said dictatorial—leader.”

headline: Antique Cars on Display, and on the Road, in London
text: Two hundred years ago it was illegal to drive over four miles per hour on the streets of England, and cars had to be preceded by a man on foot waving a red flag. Luckily, in 1896, the speed limit was raised to 14 miles per hour and cars no longer had to have someone walk ahead of them — the red flag requirement having been eliminated in 1878. In the fall of 1896, motorists celebrated their newfound freedom by driving an “Emancipation Run” from London to the seaside town of Sussex. Today, a re-enactment of the event, now called the Brighton Veteran Car Run, takes place annually with a procession of pre-1905 cars driving from London to Brighton, about 60 miles away, this year from Nov. 4 to 6.

headline: Who Is Your Role Model?
text: People choose their own role models–from older siblings to favorite teachers and even people they have never met. The late Steve Jobs, co-founder and former C.E.O. of Apple, has repeatedly been called a role model in the outpouring of grief since his death in early October. Do you have a role model? If so, does this person’s behavior guide you to make the right choices in your life now? Is your role model someone you aspire to be like when you get older?

headline: ‘Big Countries’ Are Sought to Help Fight in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Kenya and Somalia on Monday called for other nations to help in their fight against Islamist insurgents, as an aid organization said that five civilians were killed and more than 50 wounded when a military aircraft hunting the militants struck a displaced-persons camp in southern Somalia.

headline: TMX Board Backs Maple’s $3.8 Billion Takeover Bid

headline: Former Prime Minister Set to Win Kyrgyzstan Presidential Vote
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan — A former prime minister, Almazbek Atambayev, was set to win a presidential election in this strategically important Central Asian nation with more than 63 percent of the vote, the Central Election Commission reported Monday.

headline: As News Animations Go Mainstream, Taiwanese Pioneers Try Playing It Straight

In Atlanta as in Taipei, animators were asked to illustrate what reportedly happened in Libya that day just before Colonel Qaddafi was captured and the cameras started rolling.

At 4-3, the Jets are a game behind, and if they can win both, they will be in no worse than a tie for first place in the division. The Jets would have the tiebreaker advantage over both teams.

headline: Posthumous Amy Winehouse Album Will Be Released in December

The album, called “Lioness: Hidden Treasures,” will be released by Island Records, which released her two previous albums, “Frank” and “Back to Black,” and will contain 12 tracks Ms. Winehouse recorded between 2002 and 2008, including covers of “Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow” and “The Girl From Ipanema.” Other songs include a slower-tempo version of Ms. Winehouse’s hit “Valerie” and a new composition called “Between the Cheats” that Ms. Winehouse planned to include on a possible follow-up to “Back to Black.”

headline: The Long Good Buy
text: After 24 years in the same rent-controlled apartment that I had used as my office (but absolutely not as a mortuary or dental practice, which everyone knows is against code, if you’re reading this, L.A. Housing Department), I got the heave-ho when the owners informed me that they needed the place for family. Having been in this one spot for so long, I actually began to look forward to moving, exploring a new part of town, and even gave some mild thought to deaccessioning some pieces I had collected over the years. On my first day of packing, however, I found a New Yorker cartoon that helped me make up my mind. It showed an old man lying on his deathbed. Looking up at a visitor, he says, “I should have bought more crap.”

headline: Leading Off: Race Is On to the N.F.L.’s Bottom, and Top
text: The most remarkable thing about the slate of N.F.L. games on Sunday is that they finally made the races at the top of the standings nearly as riveting as the one going on at the bottom. It took until Week 8, but we got a clash of powerhouses in the Patriots-Steelers game and a hint that the Eagles might be rounding into a juggernaut to remind us that A) the football gods are not just going to hand a second straight Super Bowl trophy to Green Bay, and B) not every coach dreams of penciling Andrew Luck into next year’s lineup.

headline: EPIphenomena

headline: Beau Bridges Succeeds John Larroquette in ‘How to Succeed’ on Broadway

Mr. Bridges, whose credits include the films “Norma Rae” and “The Fabulous Baker Boys,” will take over the role of the corporate big shot J. B. Biggley in “How to Succeed” on Jan. 3 for a run that is scheduled to end on July 1. He inherits the role from John Larroquette, the “Night Court” and “Boston Legal” star who won a Tony Award for his performance in the musical earlier this year.

headline: Can You Have a Good Divorce?
text: I was utterly taken with Susan Gregory Thomas’s article on “The Good Divorce” in the Sunday Styles section. My parents are rounding the bend on 61 years of marriage, but I well remember the nuclear effect that divorce had on my best friend’s life. Her parents split when she was 11. They went on to poison every holiday, every birthday, every milestone event for decades. The first time I can recall them ever being in a (large) room together without tearing it down was at my friend’s wedding, when we were 30.

headline: The Downside of Doctors Who Feel Your Pain

headline: How John Jay Got Its Name (but Not Who Suggested It)
text: It was originally dubbed the College of Police Science in 1965, but students considered the acronym (COPS) undignified. A contest was held to find a better name (the prize, half a gallon of Scotch). Theodore Roosevelt was rejected because he was already memorialized in other institutions. Objections were mustered to Felix Frankfurter — the name, some said, invited ridicule.

Sony Pictures Television said on Monday that it will produce the as-yet-untitled show with Flavor Unit Entertainment, the production company of Queen Latifah and Shakim Compere, and Overbrook Entertainment, the company of James Lassiter and Will Smith (who in 1991 gave Queen Latifah one of her earliest screen appearances on his sitcom “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air”).

headline: Public Universities Seeking Out-of-State Students
text: In an article published on Sunday in The Chronicle of Higher Education, Eric Hoover and Josh Keller reported that public universities are escalating their recruitment of out-of-state students – students who not only bring geographic diversity to campus, but also pay higher tuition rates and improve a school’s bottom line. That finding echoes the results of a recent Inside Higher Ed survey that concluded that more universities are seeking students based on their ability to pay.

headline: Creep Show | Sue de Beer’s ‘Haunt Room’
text: The New York artist Sue de Beer has long established herself as an aesthetic interlocutor of teens and the occult, so Halloween provides an apt occasion for her to unveil a new work. De Beer’s practice first took root through domestically appointed video installations that channeled deep, dark, suburban, subcultural angst. She has steadily drifted toward explorations of the paranormal, conjuring Puritan New England for her 2007 horror film, “The Quickening,” and more recently — and more minimally — evoking the inherent eeriness of spaces through structures inspired by Brion Gysin’s “Dream Machine” or corporate entities like the Seagram Building. “Haunt Room,” which opened over the weekend on the 14th Street passageway of the High Line, is a 15-foot-wide frosted plexiglass tetradecagon outfitted with powerful infrasound speakers that pump low-frequency tones outside the range of human hearing. According to experiments conducted by Goldsmiths College, these vibrations are capable, in theory, of producing a “haunted” feeling — or at the very least the perception of strange smells and physiological hallucinations like dizziness. Visitors may enter and judge for themselves how easily their sensory perceptions are smeared. “This is a New York ‘haunted house'” de Beer says. “New York City architecture doesn’t have gabled roofs or spooky parlors. It has office buildings, apartment buildings. And the only empty buildings here are either condemned or in the financial district.”

headline: FX Adds Another Chapter to ‘American Horror Story’
text: We’ll chalk it up to pure coincidence and nothing more sinister that FX waited until Monday – Halloween – to announce that it is ordering a second season of its macabre series “American Horror Story” from creators Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk. The show, which stars Dylan McDermott and Connie Britton as a struggling married couple living in a haunted Los Angeles mansion where people can’t seem to stop dying, has been a hit for the cable network, drawing nearly 3.2 million viewers for its Oct. 5 debut and averaging about 2.8 million for each new installment. FX said that, through four episodes, “American Horror Story” was on track to become the highest-rated first season of any series it has broadcast, surpassing Mr. Murphy’s plastic-surgery drama “Nip/Tuck,” which began in 2003. The second season of “American Horror Story” will run 13 episodes; no debut was immediately announced, though it will likely run in the fall, at which point we’ll know whether it’s more or less terrifying than Charlie Sheen’s new FX series, “Anger Management.”

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 45
text: Even within a square block, room for tension: a look at the geographical divide within Zuccotti Park between Occupy Wall Street’s true believers on the east side and some less committed hangers-on and troublemakers on the west side. [Daily News]

headline: The Get | Ronnie Kirsch Clutches
text: Ronnie Kirsch’s polymer clay clutches stood out among the piles of diamonds and silk pajamas at Bergdorf Goodman’s holiday preview. It was refreshing to see such a colorful clutch after a season of so many neutral handbags. Right on time for spring’s pop fluorescents, the stripes are actually made of clay, then set in an oven like pottery. Kirsch, who holds a bachelor’s in fine arts from the Rhode Island School of Design and worked in the design departments of Cartier and the Tiffany & Company before starting her own collection, treats the bags as she would works of art. We recommend doing the same.

headline: It’s Official: Mets’ Citi Field to Shrink
text: Citi Field, the nearly $800 million stadium built by and for the Mets, was the realization of a family dream, constructed with government financial backing and the support of two mayors. The stadium, with its Ebbets Field touches, was an ode to the past. With its Shake Shack burgers and lobster rolls, it was also a bold bid to cash in on pricey ballpark amenities.

headline: DeLong On Central Banking
text: Just read the whole thing — it’s short. Brad gives us an important history lesson, showing that the lender of last resort function has always been an essential part of a central bank’s job, and that the Bank of England played that role when necessary even though it lacked proper legal authority.

headline: TimesCast | Qaddafi's Hometown In Rubble
text: October 31, 2011 - On the ground in Surt, Libya, Colonel Qaddafi's hometown and the site of his last stand.

headline: Behind New York’s Pension Changes, a Quest for Higher Returns
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York’s comptroller, John C. Liu, should perhaps call their ambitious plan to revamp the city’s five public-employee retirement funds “No Pension Plan Left Behind.”

headline: John Maus, Hearing Gregorian Plainchant in New Wave
A Lehman Brothers, in Miniature
text: MF Global Holdings and one of its United States subsidiaries filed for Chapter 11 protection on Monday.

headline: Fighting the Overprotective Impulse
text: I don’t mean to rub it in for those of you in the Northeast (O.K., maybe a little), but Sunday was gorgeous in Berkeley, Calif.: balmy, blue sky and, touch wood, steady ground. My husband and daughter and I took advantage by indulging in a stack of pancakes at an outdoor cafe. She got itchy as Steven and I lingered over coffee and the Sunday paper (why is it that kids wolf their food down when you want to lounge and are impossibly pokey when you don’t?) and she asked me if she could go to the bookstore. The store was down the block, around the corner and across one high-traffic street that had a crosswalk but no stop sign or light.I glanced at Steven, hoping for a clue about how to respond.

headline: Kardashian Divorce Forces the E! Network to Scramble
text: One of the biggest stars on the E! network, Kim Kardashian, said Monday that she was separating from her husband, Kris Humphries, 72 days after an extravagant, literally made-for-television wedding. Ms. Kardashian cited irreconcilable differences, but some of her fans and detractors sensed a business decision. Ms. Kardashian, after all, had earned millions of dollars by selling the television rights to her Aug. 20 wedding to E!, which has shown Kardashian family reality shows for several years. E! made the most of it, premiering “Kim’s Fairytale Wedding: A Kardashian Event” on Oct. 9 and 10 and replaying it almost every day since then.

headline: Anxieties Stir as Greece Plans Referendum on Latest Europe Aid Deal
text: ATHENS — In a surprise move that jolted Europe and put his political future in play, Prime Minister George A. Papandreou announced Monday that his government would hold a referendum on a new aid package for Greece, putting austerity measures — and potentially membership in the euro zone — to a popular vote for the first time.

headline: Broncos Should See What They Have in Tebow
text: Almost a week after Halloween, Dr. Frankenstein will come to the N.F.L., rolling out quarterback experiments in Oakland and in Denver that originated at opposite starting points but hoped to yield the same result: passing play effective enough to resuscitate a franchise.

headline: Qaddafi’s Canarsie Pen Pal
text: To say Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was a special pen pal of Louis Schlamowitz would be stretching the truth.

headline: Super PAC Plans Pro-Perry Advertising in South Carolina
text: 4:57 p.m. | Updated A new Super PAC called Make Us Great Again plans to begin at least $100,000 in advertising over the next 10 days on behalf of Rick Perry in the key state of South Carolina, where campaign analysts say Mr. Perry must perform well in the January primary to have any real shot at the GOP presidential nomination, according to a rival campaign and local television industry officials.

headline: Some Help Getting Reimbursed for OTC Drugs
text: New I.R.S. rules that went into effect this year, as part of the Affordable Care Act, made it harder for consumers to have non-prescription medicines reimbursed from health-care flexible spending accounts.

headline: Do ‘Nice’ Doctors Make Better Doctors?
text: In an effort to improve the doctor-patient relationship, many medical schools are now filtering out candidates who lack communication skills. Breeding nice doctors, it seems, is becoming something of a trend. But in an essay in today’s New York Times, Dr. Lisa Rosenbaum asks whether selecting future doctors based on their interpersonal skills could backfire:

text: There is light at the end of the debate tunnel: There will be only four debates next fall during the general election campaign.

headline: Cain Faces Allegations, and Now, the Possible Repercussions
text: The political impact of the accusations leveled against Herman Cain is difficult to assess in the early hours after they surfaced. But the allegations — and the reactions to them — have the potential to reshape the dynamics of the Republican presidential contest.

headline: Tunisia Summons Arafat Widow in Corruption Inquiry
text: The Tunisian government has issued a warrant for the widow of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat in connection with a corruption investigation, the Tunisian state-run news agency reported on Monday.

headline: A Hoarder’s Collection Goes Up for Sale
text: While Lee Roy Hartung may have lacked focus as a collector, he still left behind an extensive collection of cars, motorcycles and memorabilia, which is being auctioned this week in Glenview, Ill.

headline: Kardashianomics
text: There are lots of reasons why marriage can be a good financial investment, including that marriage correlates with higher lifetime earnings. But of course for one (soon to be former) celebrity couple — Kim Kardashian and Kris Humphries — the payoff is much quicker, without that whole till-death-do-we-part commitment.

headline: Beauty Spots

text: A soccer tournament played in the Iron Triangle, a surreal land of junkyards and auto shops in Willets Point, Queens.

headline: A New Variation in Boarding an Airplane
text: Since checked-bag fees have become ubiquitous, more passengers now carry bags onto the plane. This can result in lines while boarding. In a new seating procedure being used by American Airlines, passengers are grouped randomly, so that their seats are scattered throughout the plane.

headline: A Gym at the Inn
text: Rochelle Jacobs has been working out at Exhale, the mind and body spa, two to three times a week for the last nine years. She says she is so dedicated to her gym that she picks her hotels based on their fitness offerings.

headline: Mississippi’s Ambiguous ‘Personhood’ Amendment
text: ON Nov. 8, Mississippi voters will be asked to decide on a proposed amendment to the state constitution, which would define as a person “every human being from the moment of fertilization, cloning, or the functional equivalent thereof.”

headline: Turkey: Sandblasting Jeans for ‘Distressed’ Look Proved Harmful for Textile Workers
text: Sandblasting new blue jeans to make them look “distressed” killed a number of young Turkish textile workers before the practice was outlawed, a new study has found.

headline: U.N. Says 7 Billion Now Share the World
text: Feeling claustrophobic? You’re not alone. According to United Nations demographers, 6,999,999,999 other Earthlings potentially felt the same way on Monday when the world’s population topped seven billion. But if you’d rather go by the United States Census Bureau’s projections, you’ve got some breathing room. The bureau estimates that even with the world’s population increasing by 215,120 a day, it won’t reach seven billion for about four months.

headline: City Nixes New Museum’s Group Soaking Sessions
text: “Everybody into the pool!” will no longer work so well as a catchphrase for the New Museum’s career survey of the adventurous work of the Belgium-born artist Carsten Höller, which opened last week. As one of its showstoppers, the exhibition includes a giant sensory deprivation tank created by Mr. Höller, in which museumgoers are invited to disrobe and lie in heavily salted water with a few friends or strangers to achieve a kind of out-of-body experience.

headline: Better Batteries: Not Just for Cars Anymore
text: As I wrote in Saturday’s paper, energy storage will be critical to making wind power more useful. Some wind farms are forced to dump a substantial portion of their production because they churn out megawatts in the middle of the night, when there is very little demand for it. At such times, some grid operators even charge generators for making power rather than paying them for it.

headline: A Reminder on Maintaining Bone Health

headline: Lost in Space
text: Q. Science-fiction films often depict people being killed by going out an airlock into space. What would that be like?

headline: Another Question, This Time Financial, for Herman Cain
text: Early in his candidacy, Herman Cain may have accepted tens of thousands of dollars in goods and services for his campaign from a tax-exempt organization founded by his top aide, documents from the organization show, raising the prospect of serious violations of tax and election law by both Mr. Cain’s campaign and the organization.

text: OVER the years, I’ve traveled well over one million miles for business. I approach every flight with a good attitude and roll with whatever happens.

text: The Taxi of Tomorrow — the oblong Nissan minivan unveiled with great fanfare by the city this spring — is a few steps closer to becoming the Taxi of Today. And the public is being invited to take a peek.

headline: Global Population Reaches 7 Billion, or Doesn’t
text: An effort by the United Nations to draw attention to the fact that the global population is now or soon will be 7 billion sowed confusion on Monday, as some news organizations, anxious to put a human face on the estimate, searched the globe for a newborn to anoint the seven billionth person, conflating a projection with an exact count.

headline: The Ideas Behind a Move to ‘Occupy London’
text: The Occupy London movement does not yet have concrete aims, but it does appear to have some deep, and eclectic, philosophical underpinnings.

headline: Welcome
text: If you don’t know my name, you probably know my work. I’m the editorial page editor of The New York Times, which means I’m in charge of the paper’s opinion sections in print and online — editorials, Op-Eds, letters to the editor and Sunday Review. I head the editorial board, the 19 people who produce the unsigned editorials you can read on our site and in our paper every day. Those articles represent the institutional voice of the board, the editor and the publisher — not, and I can’t say this often enough even if Republican politicians refuse to believe it, the Times newsroom.

headline: ‘A Toad-Eat-Toad World,’ and Other Tales of Animal Cannibals
text: When Richard Shine, a biologist at the University of Sydney in Australia, first heard the mystery of the missing eggs, he feared it was another case of what might be called invasive toadkill. He and his colleagues were studying the cane toad, Rhinella marina, a big, warty, sludge-colored Latin American amphibian that was brought to the continent years ago in an ill-fated effort at beetle control.

headline: In Sex Harassment Cases, How Much Would an Executive Know?
text: UPDATE: 6:32. Despite Mr. Cain’s earlier statements that he was “unaware” of any settlements, he later provided details about one settlement to several interviewers.

headline: Thanksgiving Side Dishes, Part 1: Winter Squash
text: I’m already thinking about Thanksgiving and the side dishes I want to make this year. If the number of people who signed up for the Healthy Thanksgiving Side Dishes class I taught at Vail Restaurant Month in Colorado a few weeks ago is an indication, I’m not the only one.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Thailand, Russia and Washington.

headline: It Is Designed to Break Your Heart
text: Last Thursday, just before the sixth game of the World Series, ESPN’s Jayson Stark wrote a piece about the Texas Rangers’ relationship to their local sports fans, suggesting that the team’s recent success and potential title might be finally earning them a place in the hearts of Dallas’s football-mad faithful. Despite their long World Series drought, Stark noted, the Rangers had never inspired the same kind of undying passion as frustrated franchises like the Cubs or Indians or pre-2004 Red Sox: Instead of agonizing over their baseball nine’s inability to win it all, the Dallas-Fort Worth fan base mainly just ignored them. But a Rangers victory over the Saint Louis Cardinals, he suggested, might change all that: “If these Rangers find a way to win just one more time, life in Texas may never be the same all-Cowboys-all-the-time universe again.”

headline: A Nursing Home Shrinks Until It Feels Like a Home
text: Toni Davis spent much of her childhood roaming the corridors of a nursing home in West Orange, N.J., where her mother was the director. Even now she recalls the pleas of the residents there: “ ‘Please help me, please take me home with you,’ they’d beg,” Ms. Davis said. “I remember asking my mom, ‘Why can’t we take them home for dinner for just one night?’"

headline: For a Giant Single-Celled Organism, Home Is the Deepest Address on the Planet
text: Researchers returning from an expedition to the Mariana Trench in the western Pacific, the deepest part of the oceans, say it is home to single-celled organisms more than four inches long.

headline: Europe’s Debt Crisis Stymies Financial Overhaul
text: LONDON — As the Continent grapples with the sovereign debt crisis, financial regulatory revision in Europe has been put on the back burner, with some rules delayed until at least 2013.

headline: Hugh Jackman’s Show Earns More Than $1.2 Million
text: Hugh Jackman’s new concert on Broadway set a house record at the Broadhurst Theater, earning more than of $1.2 million last week, a result of the producers’ decision to charge exorbitant prices for tickets to Mr. Jackman’s first return to Broadway as a singer since his Tony Award-winning performance in “The Boy from Oz” eight years ago. The previous record at the Broadhurst was about $1.18 million set by a production of “Merchant of Venice” starring Al Pacino during the week between Christmas and New Year’s Day last season.

headline: Unveiling the Attributes of the Divine
text: Over the past decade New Yorkers have caught tantalizing glimpses of the Indian dancer Shantala Shivalingappa at the Fall for Dance Festival and in several works by Pina Bausch. On Sunday, however, the World Music Institute gave us a whole evening of Ms. Shivalingappa, at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts. One evening was hardly enough.

headline: ‘Passion de Jeanne d’Arc’
text: Charles Hazlewood conducting a new score for the 1928 film “Passion de Jeanne d’Arc” at Alice Tully Hall, part of Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival. (Video courtesy of Lincoln Center.)

headline: HarperCollins Acquires Religious Book Publisher
text: HarperCollins Publishers said on Monday that it would acquire Thomas Nelson, a publisher based in Nashville, bolstering the company’s strength in the market for inspirational and religious books.

headline: Rich Get Biggest Break in Perry Tax Plan, Study Finds
text: Gov. Rick Perry’s proposal for an opt-in flat tax would primarily benefit the wealthiest Americans, according to a new analysis from the Tax Policy Center, a nonpartisan research organization. Compared with current tax policy, the plan would most likely reduce federal tax revenue by $570 billion, or about 15 percent.

headline: In a Blending of Cultures, Politics Pushed Aside
text: In his lucid and haunting works, the composer Toru Takemitsu synthesized the sounds of his native Japan with the techniques of Western modernism. Speaking from the stage of the 92nd Street Y on Thursday evening, the English violinist Daniel Hope summed up this cosmopolitan style: “So far, and yet very near.”

headline: Joan of Arc’s Suffering, This Time With Sound
text: Silent films have always had a devoted constituency among history-minded cinema enthusiasts, and aficionados of the form will tell you that directors and actors cultivated an artistry in those dialogue-free movies that was lost when talkies displaced them. For more casual viewers, public screenings are relatively hard to come by. These days they are most likely to be seen as part of a musical performance. Composers, it turns out, are doing more to keep these classics in public view than film societies.

headline: The Sea That Gives, and Takes Away
text: It is a sign of the skill, range and taste of the Czech-born choreographer Dusan Tynek that a new dance of his will often recall the work of a great choreographer, a different one each time. That same trait is what keeps Mr. Tynek from advancing out of the artistic category of promising. The first section of his new “Widow’s Walk,” performed on Friday as part of his company’s two-week season at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, could have been made by Martha Graham.

headline: A Point Guard’s Nightmare Descent Into Drugs
text: Heroin and painkillers play a larger role than basketball in “Unguarded,” an ESPN documentary on Tuesday night. “I come in here and tell you my nightmare,” the onetime star Chris Herren, long past his glory days, tells a gym full of high school students, and that’s the function of the film as well. Unlike the students, we don’t have to listen to him, but it’s a pretty good story; even if sports aren’t your thing, you might find it worth hanging around the gym for an hour and a half.

headline: Lessons From a Halloween Costume
text: A year ago I made the seemingly mundane choice to let my son choose his costume for Halloween. He chose Daphne from Scooby Doo. A few parents at his preschool disapproved, I wrote a blog post about it,  and in the blink of an eye, the post set off a national discussion about gender identity, bullying and a parent’s role in both issues.

headline: For a Basso Profundo, a New Literary Tune

text: Major American environmental groups have dodged the subject of population control for decades, wary of getting caught up in the bruising politics of reproductive health.

headline: The Jazz Chameleon, in All His Colors
text: Chick Corea, the ebullient and eternally youthful pianist, bandleader and composer, turned 70 this year. Being a jazz musician, he’s bound by custom to celebrate this mile marker on the bandstand, aglow in retrospection. Had there been a corporate-sponsored jazz festival in New York this summer, he probably would have headlined Carnegie Hall sometime around his birthday, on June 12. Instead he’s taking over the Blue Note for most of November, beginning on Tuesday: two sets a night, in 10 different configurations, with collaborators old and new. It’s the more fitting option by far.

headline: Improviser With a Touch of ‘I Love Lucy’
text: Do you remember the mirror routine between Lucille Ball and Harpo Marx in the “I Love Lucy” show? A homage to a scene in the Marx Brothers film “Duck Soup,” it features Lucy dressed as Harpo. When she finds herself face to face with the real thing — typical Lucy — she must pretend that she is his reflection and mimics his every move. It’s comedy gold.

headline: Lumière | Closin’ Up the Ritz
text: The marble fountain sang. The waiters moved with elegance and grace. The sun softened the sharp edges of the late October afternoon. The outdoor terrace at the Ritz was open for tea. It could have been perfect.

headline: Luring a New Headmaster With a $3.8 Million Town House
text: The buyer was looking for a town house in Brooklyn. It needed living space for a family of five and entertaining space for crowds in the dozens. It had to be within walking distance of Pierrepont Street — ruling out Park Slope — but outside of Brooklyn Heights, with its higher price tags.

headline: Cooper Union Looks at Charging Tuition
text: Facing serious financial trouble in a weak economy, Cooper Union, the New York City college founded in 1859 to provide free education for the working class, may begin charging undergraduate tuition for the first time in more than a century, its president said Monday.

headline: Justices Hear Arguments in Faulty-Lawyer Cases
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments Monday in two cases concerning what should be done when criminal defendants pass up favorable plea bargains based on unprofessional work by their lawyers.
